What a Q!!!!. The queue for the cable car is beyond imagination! It was such a long queue and the line come right down the stairs and onto the road!! The counters move ever so slowly. Once you buy the ticket, there is another queue to get onto the cable car. We waited more than a hour to get the tickets. Once up in the hill, the village was not much of an attraction, mainly commercialized cafes and souvenir shop. The walk around was ok but not outstanding. The claim up to the buddha was ok. The whole experience was the cable car but on a stormy windy day, it was a very frightening experience. The car stopped halfway due to high way and the car swayed quite a bit. Some people got a bit nausea. There isnt much to do that would take up a few hours. Only the Monastry and the Buddha worth seeing and between them 1hr tops. Recommend not to go if there is rain or wind. The cable car at the top prone to strong wind!!

Great views from the chair lift.. This attraction is a must when visiting Hong Kong. The chairlift will take you up though breath taking views to the Big Budda. I recommend you take a glass bottom chairlift up and a normal chairlift back down to cut down on costs. I also recommend you wait until after lunch to see this attraction to avoid the crowds and long wait to get on to the chairlift.

The Island is worth a visit and easy by ferry. We went on the ferry which was a pleasant trip - the deluxe tickets were only £3.70 each and the views were lovely. There were water buffaloes roaming around and there was a bus up to the Buddha which was easy enough to use. It was a nice walk around the island and we stopped for a coffee before getting the ferry back - a good afternoon if you like ferries and scenary

Not a good idea if it's a cloudy and rainy day. Just got of the scariest ride I had so far. The operater had to stop the ride a few times due to strong winds. My advise will be to skip this and bus up here if it's a cloudy and rainy day.More details will be:The cable car is ventilated, so the cold wet wind came inside.The cable car was slammed by the winds from time to time. It was swaying all along the way.After we broke the low lying clouds, the strong wind stopped and it was incredible silent, we sighed relief... Only to be slammed again by strong winds.The operator apologised over the speaker, it wasn't clear enough but I managed to hear the word typhoon.The Good SideEven though it was the scariest ride I had, there were a few moments we had glimps of beautiful sceneries. So if it wasn't for the typhoon, it would have been a great ride.

Interesting place. We took an organised day tour of Lantau Island and it was very interesting. Apart from the new airport, the rest of the island is not developed and the people have no hustle and bustle like the rest of Hong Kong. There are only a few roads and the your of Tai O fishing village was a step back in time. The Kwan Tai temple built in 1488 is a must to see. The tour included a tour of the Big Buddha and a ride back on the Ngong Ping 360 cable car.If you don't like heights you might have a problem. The cable cars do sway a bit in the wind but the views are spectacular!

Such a great day!. This island really does have a lot to offer. I went to ngong ping village first. Then to tai o village next by bus. The mo lin monastery is here and the big buddha also. Using the cable car is a must. I used the crystal clear bottom one for great views and I booked online. It cut out hours of queuing! This really is a must see island
Nice cable car journey.. It was comfortable and picturesque trip. Specially as we had pre booked voucher ticket to beat the long que. Bonus was aerial view of KHG airport.

Have a Travel Plan B. Have a Plan B - not for the island visit - which is excellent - but for your travel plans.We arrived at the Cable Car at about 11.45am and after an hour's wait finally reached the kiosk. We took the option of the Cable Car / Bus / Boat roll-up option, but only after I purchased the tickets did the ticket seller tell us that we needed 4-5 hours and the last cable car back was at 4.45pm. Moreover, if you think that you're nearing the cable car when you bought your ticket think again. Concealed from view, behind the ticket office is the next queue for the cable car. Longer even than the one that we had stood for over an hour in already. So, tip number 1 is, unlike us, to arrive early !The lack of information in the lead up to purchasing the ticket troubled me. For example during the entire length of the queue to the kiosk posters promoted the cable car / bus/ boat trip combo but failed to give any info on the times or routes of the buses, the time of the last cable car down, the last time for the boat trip etc leaving you with the impression that you were probably getting value for money by purchasing the combo ticket, but not giving you the opportunity of planning how to use it, especially at times of heavy queues. So, if the queue is snaking up towards the kiosk when you arrive, have a Plan B, and take account of the following:1. The free buses that are part of the combo ticket run long after the last cable car down the hill from the Buddha.2. If, therefore, you are cutting it fine to visit Tai-O and get back for the return of the last cable car forget the cable car. You can get a bus back either to the MTR station or alternatively a different bus to the Ferry Terminal which for a small extra fee takes you back to Hong Kong Island. As for the island itself, it is a must for any visit to HK. The Buddha is impressive and Tai-O is fascinating.

Great Day Trip. We got the day trip to Lantau Island. Enjoyed the ride of the cable car, view of island and the scenery so beautiful. Went to Tai O, and got a boat ride to see White Dolphin and walk around at Tai O, a must to try on their Beancurd Pudding (Tau Huay). Went to see the great buddha but did not climb up all the way thou they say only take 10 mins to walk up. Great day to spend there especially on a great cooling day!!
Discovery Bay. an enjoying day - Discovery Bay has an almost European feel to it. We had a great lunch - worth the trip.
impressed. We enjoyed the ride the cable car, I was impressed with view, the island is very nice, for a walk is a great, great time and great fun

As good as weather that day. I've been there when the weather was bad and it was a big disappointing but when the weather was good during my second visit, this place was really beautiful. Cable car was fun too, especially crystal one.

Start early, worth a visit. I was disappointed that I didn't spend enough time on the island. Took the gondola up to see the big Buddha, but would have liked to do some hiking in the area. If planning to go get there pre 10 am to beat the queues for the gondola.

Fabulous. We picked a sunny day, so views were amazing; the cable car was not working so took bus 23 from MTR Tung Chung to Tai O after which we took bus 21 to Ngong Ping which were part of the experience. Big Buddha and Monastery are beautiful. There were queues for the buses back to MTR station so we took a taxi. Really great day.

Don't forget the outlet shops. Lantau has a lot going for it. There's all the usual attractions, Big Buddha etc. But after you've finished doing the touristy things, the outlet shops next door to the MTR are worth a visit on the way home. There's lots of shops and the prices are the best we found in HK.

What else in Lantau Island?. In Lantau, there are the Po Lin Temple, the Big Buddha, the Tram, but what else? Indeed, there is a place that Hong Kong has not developed. Hong Kong is a crowded city. 7 million people are crowded in very small place. If all the land is develop for living, perhaps Hong Kong is not that crowded. In Lantau, there are many rural places, hiking trails, historic temples, beaches and villages and so on. The Phoenix mountain is the second highest in Hong Hong where you can see the sun rise.

Sight seeing, camping and so on. Lantau is a very big island and it houses Discover Bay (a residential estate & complex) and the rest if the island and where the Big Buddha, the Sunset Peak and the Trappist Monastery situate.For Discovery Bay, it is a mixed, primarily residential, development consisting of upmarket residential development and private and public recreational facilities in Hong Kong. There, one would find a boutique hotel called "Auberge" which is small and cozy but which services could improve as their staff is very green. Restaurants in Discovery Bay is mid market and touristy, but as Discovery Bay is more spacious, outdoor sitting is better served. For the Sunset Peak or Tai Tung Shan, it is the third highest peak in Hong Kong and is within Lantau South Country Park and Lantau North Country Park and stands at a height of 869 metres above the sea level. Having a hike there is an achievement which could take 3-4 hours!For the Trappist Monastery, it is home to a number of Roman Catholic monks of the Cistercian Order of the Strict Observance, or Trappists. Finally; the Big Buddha, it is a large bronze statue of Buddha Shakyamuni, completed in 1993, and located at Ngong Ping, Lantau Island, in Hong Kong. One could walk up and have panoramic view of Lantau and then visit Ngong Ping 360, which is a tourist project featuring a cable car, but which sadly encountered some teething problems as when it was first launched.

Amazing experience right from the cable car to the giant Buddha, monastery, etc.. The views are breath taking and totally worth your money and time. The Cable car ride (popularly Ngong Ping 360) is the best way to get to Lantau island. Now a few words of caution: The time we visited (Feb'16), the wind was chillllyyyy, dont know how it is all the year round but would advice all to carry some warm clothing, also be sure to cover ur ears and use gloves cause trust me it can get windy. The main attractions on lantau island are "Big Buddha", "Po Lin Monastery", "Tai O" and "Pui O" and "Disneyland". The best way to get to Lantau island and explore is:1. Take the MTR Tung Shun Line all the way to Tung Shun.2. Take the cable car to Ngong Ping for the Po Ling Monastary and Big Buddha 3. Take the Bus (hourly) to Tai O village. Bus #21 from the Big Buddha (~15 minutes).4. Take an inexpensive boat trip to see the wooden-stilt houses along the waterfront and, on a good day, the pink dolphins out in the bay.5. Wander through the village with its market and tiny shops and along the shore line to the Old Police Station perched on the cliff-side.6. Tea and cheesecake would be my recommendation at the Old Police Station, but a wide range of refreshments are available.7. Walk back to the village and take the bus back to Tung Shun and the MTR back to Hong Kong City for a bit of night life.

Giant Buddha and Cable Car - a must for every Explorer!. Upside1. We took a tour, and everything was so well organized. Was a breeze! 2. The place is beautiful, exciting, cold, clean, magical3. The Cable car offered very scenic views of the island4. Cold/ Windy - bring a thick scarf5. Souvenir shops abound6. Vegetarian food served at the Monastery near the Giant Buddha (walking distance)7. Subway, Starbucks and other stores are also in pavillion (walking distance) for those looking for other dining options Downside1. Queues are long, better book a tour to avoid waiting

Cable car ride to the giant Buddha. We decided to take the cable car ride to go see the giant Buddha, we weren't disappointed the views were breathtaking. It was fairly busy but we bought our vouchers beforehand from reception at our hotel the Novotel City Gate which is really conveniently positioned across the road. This enabled us to avoid the large queues and use the fast track. It's quite a long ride upto the Buddha not for those who are afraid of heights but well worth it in our opinion. It works out about £18 each, there were four of us in our party, but each cable car holds upto ten people so unless you want to pay for a private car you have to share.

Make sure you buy your ticket in advance. We booked this trip with Viator and so glad we did as we could not believe the length of the queue of people buying tickets to the cable car on the day. We zoomed up the outside of these long lines of people and figure we would have saved up to a couple of hours in time. The cable ride was terrific even though the day was quite smoggy and it afforded great views of the airport and the mountains. Once there we enjoyed visiting the Big Buddha, the monastery and a tasty vegetarian lunch (no meat allowed on this site) before taking the cable car back down the mountain to be astounded by even longer queues at around 3pm.

Day Trip. Anyone with a few days in Hong Kong should spend one of them exploring Lantau Island. You can either sign up for a tour of the island with a company, or make your own way over and see what you wish and spend time how you like, although the convenience of being on a tour and them knowing the roads is hard to pass up. Some of the must see attractions are the small fishing village known as Tai O where you can have a quick lunch and go out on a boat ride to see the pink dolphins, the big Buddha statue with it's accompanying monastery, and of course the cable car ride to or from the train station up to the Buddha, with it's amazing views. If not going with a tour, be sure to plan your day and transportation ahead of time to make sure no time is wasted trying to figure out how to get where you are going.

Tai O fishing village - a whole new side of traditional Hong Kong. We took the MTR to Tung Chung and then the number 11 bus to the stilted fishing village of Tai O on Lantau. It was about a 30 minute MTR ride followed by a 50 minute bus ride and is one of the more remote locations in Hong Kong. We got there early to avoid the crowds and pottered around the lovely little market, explored the temple and then walked up to the top of the ridge and along the pathway that goes above the village. A great escape from the crowds of Hong Kong though there were many Chinese tourists when we went. The village is set to change rapidly if plans go ahead to link it to the mainland by a massive highway. See Tai O now before it's too late.
Good views. Taking the cable car is a good choice, that can save a lot of energies, and you will get enough good views during the riding and finally you will see the giant Buddha.

Make sure you book this tour on Lantau Island. We booked a day tour to Lantau Island through Viator. (Lantau Island & Giant Buddha Day Trip from Hong Kong). This included a ferry ride to the Island, bus trip to Tai O Fishing Village, boat trip, bus to the Big Buddha and Monastery (including a beautiful Vegan lunch) and cable car ride.Ryan was our tour guide on Lantau and he was excellent. His knowledge of the culture and sights was endless and his passion for the country and people is clearly evident. The trip to Tai O Fishing Village was one of the highlights of our trip to Hong Kong and the visit to the Big Buddha is truly memorable.

Fun ride to get to the Big Budha. Went with family and had an awesome cable car ride....the views were amazing and it was even more thrilling with the glass floor cable car...the monastery was great as well and we had pictures taken

Beautiful. We went to see the Big Buddha and visit the monastery. It's a bit of a hike (bring water and an umbrella if it's sunny) but the views are breathtaking. We took the cable car down and it was really nice!

Very fun way to get to Big Buddha. The cable car ride was awesome. Takes about 20 mins each way. You should pre-buy your tickets and I think you can spend a bit more to jump the line. It's worth it. I waited almost 3 hours.

Best Island Tour. I suggest that you take this Island tour Between February-April so there will be no fog and you can maximize the view from your cable car ride. I don't recommend taking this island tour from May onwards because it is always raining by then and most of the cable car rides will be cancelled during thunders storms or heavy rain. Include the Tai O fishing village tour because it will be worth it. Especially the boat ride around the fishing village because, if you're lucky you can see dolphins or a school of flying fishes jumping out of the water. It is also near a big shopping outlet. So, if you're a shopping addict then it is a 2 in 1 trip.

Nice getaway from the city. It was nice to visit Hong Kong but is was even better to get into Lantau Island. I would recommend Tai O (fishing village) it's very accessible by bus and you can take the bus from there to Po Lin Monastery and Big Budda. Very inexpensive on public transportation, since it's a bit outside of Hong Kong.
Great cable car ride, very scenic. Great cable car ride very scenic, takes quite some time in the queue to get on but worth the wait. Queues get longer during the day so go early.

Big Buddha and the cable car. Big Buddha, Wisdom Path and the cable car ride sums up the experience at Lantau. If this was only for the cable car ride, would have been still worth it. Be ready for the long queues of the cable car though.

Slower paced area. The sky tram is down for repairs March 2016 so check their website directly before you go. Lantau Island is a much more nature loving, relaxed environment than what people usually thing of when thing of Hong Kong. We took a taxi ride all the way up to the Big Buddha since the sky tram was down, and then rode a bus down from Tai O back to the airport. We saw large animals that looked like bison haning out by the side of the road. There were bus stops where people were getting on but we couldn't figure out where they lived and where they came from because everywhere you see, it looks just like mountain ranges and greenery with no housing anywhere. It's a very relaxing ride to go up to the Big Buddha area and Tai O.

Well worth a visit. It is definitely worth pre booking your tickets for the cable cars as you will miss the huge queues. We were so relieved that we did, as the queues were very very long. If you take the crystal cabin there is an even shorter amount of time to wait (but we weren't that brave). There are the usual fast food outlets at the end of the cable car ride, before you get to the big Buddha. Coming back at the end of the day either leave a little before the place closes or be prepared for a 70 minute wait to return on the cable cars. The buses to Tung Chung MTR were also subject to long queues. Less people seem to opt for the return journey by ferry so we found we were able to get on a bus to the ferry relatively easily and then hop straight onto the ferry back to Hong Kong, using our Octopus cards. A fabulous day out

Great Way to Wait for your Flight. Having checked our cases in at Kowloon Airport Express for our 5pm flight out of Hong Kong, we had the chance to visit Lantau Island. We caught the Airport Express to the airport and a short taxi ride to the cable car terminus. Thankfully the queues for the cable car weren't too long, make sure you bring some warm clothing with you as the gondolas can be quite draughty, they also sway a bit in the wind, so be prepared. But it is a wonderful ride with amazing views of the airport on it's manmade island and the $14b bridge to Macau which is under construction.We visited the village, which has a number of shops selling nice souvenirs of Hong Kong, not the usual cheap stuff that you see everywhere, there's even a shop selling nothing but chopsticks.The walk up the steps to the Buddha will take your breath away, as will the view from the top.The Po Ling Monastery is beautifully decorated, and well worth a few photos. In fact the whole area is a photographers paradise.

Tourists. We spent 9 days on the Island as an escape from the rush of Hong Kong Island. We were out and about every day. Did shops sight seeing cable car and did make a couple of trips back to Hong Kong Island. We enjoyed our stay at Silvvermines Resort. Would recommend a stay here. Transport links were good.

Lantau Island -- so much more than Disneyland. Or the Nong Ping 360 cable car. Lantau is considerably bigger than Hong Kong Island, as a glance at the map will show. It has beaches, mountains and tourist attractions, including the two already mentioned, and the Big Buddha, Nong Ping village and Citygate outlet mall. You can combine some of them (say, the outlet mall, cable car, the Buddha and monastery village) in a day, but if you'd rather take it easy and the weather is good, just take the ferry from Central to Mui Wo for a day on the beach. There are lots of places to eat, from perfectly safe 'dai pai dongs' selling fresh local food, to bars and local restaurants. For a glimpse of more of the island, take a bus from the ferry either to the Big Buddha or to Tung Chung. Hikers can enjoy Lantau's walking trails, many of which are not too demanding. But the uphill trails to Lantau Peak and Sunset Peak are only for serious hillwalkers.
Go for the Ngong Ping 360. Cable car ride is the best way in and out of Lantau island to get to the Big Buddha. Do try the crystal cabin for one way of the trip at least, it's a unique experience.

An amazing experience despite the bad weather. As the cable car was under maintenance, we took up a bus ride up to visit the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. There was a slight drizzle but the problem was easily solved as there were biodegradable raincoats for sale at an affordable price. The place was very misty, and we couldn't see the Big Buddha from the bottom of the stairs, but as we made our way up the Buddha statue slowly came into view, which made it even more magnificent than any other normal day. It was a breathtaking experience and I'd definitely recommend this place to my friends who have chosen Hong Kong as a travel destination.I would also like to recommend the Wisdom Path for people who are interested in Buddhism. You'll need to walk about 10 minutes to the reach the 38 wooden steles, and on each wooden stele is a line from the Heart Sutra, a Buddhist classic.

Loved!!! Highly recommend!. I truly loved this island and riding the cable car to the Big Buddha. We got to the main cable car entrance by taking the metro from TST. I believe there are other ways, but we felt that the metro was the easiest. From there, we jumped on the cable car (purchase the tickets online to avoid the lines as much as possible!!!!). I initially tried to avoid the cable car, since I have a fear of heights and also have motion sickness at times, but I bit the bullet and just decided to ride the cars. The cable car was not that bad and only started to slightly sway towards the end...I believe this is because it was a windy day. However should you not want to get to the big Buddha by cable car, you can take a bus (which I heard you can still get motion sickness from the winding roads) or taxi.Once you get to the Buddha (after 20 min by cable car), you will first enter a village which is somewhat touristy. Walk through the village and you will get to the base of the Buddha and the templeThe sight is something truly unbelievable. It is recommended for individuals of all ages. Fyi- dress warm if a cold day as the cable car has little open air slits so it can get a little breezy.

Best tour outside city center. We tried several tours and all in all we liked this one very much.The cable car was quite spectacular 6000 meter long going up to 900 meter altitude. Here is much cooler than in the city and we had to buy warm jackets there. The big Buddha is impressive and it is worthwhile to take the stairs all the way up. The village offer a selection of souvenirs and foods. From here we did an exciting bus trip down to she fishing village. A short white dolphin spotting tour was in lauded and indeed we could see many dolphins. The trip was enjoyed both by adults and kids in our group.

Fascinating Day Trip to Lantau Island. We spent a fascinating day at Lantau Island by visiting Ngong Ping Village, Lo Pin Monastery, Big Buddha, and Tai O.We took the MTR from our hotel in Kowloon to Tung Chung on Lantau Island. From the Tung Chung MTR station, we walked to the cable car station. It was a Saturday and we had to wait about 40 minutes to get on the cable car. It was about a 25-minute ride on the cable car to Ngong Ping Village. You do get a nice view during the cable car ride.Ngong Ping Village is quite touristy but worth exploring. Cattle do roam freely in the village. There were many shops and eateries catering to tourists lining the main street of the village.The Lo Pin Monastery is a short walk from the village centre. It’s worth exploring also. The Monastery Restaurant serves a vegetarian meal. We walked the Wisdom Path next to the monastery that led to the 38 wooden columns with inscriptions from the Heart Sutra.The Big Buddha is just next to the monastery. It’s a 268-step climb to the top. It’s definitely worth the climb for a good view of the surrounding countryside.Afterwards, we took the bus to the fishing village of Tai O. Tai O is definitely worth a visit for something that is completely different from that of Kowloon. At the end of our visit, we took the bus back to Tung Chung to catch the MTR back to our hotel in Kowloon. There was an unusually long wait of about an hour to catch the bus.

Relax - A real change from Kowloon & HK Island.. There are a couple of ways to get to Lantau Island (MTR, ferry, road) but once there allow time to explore; a full day would not be enough. If you arrive by ferry at Mui Wo, bikes are available for hire or catch one of the many busses that go to various parts of the island. We were amazed at the beautiful coastline, deserted beaches and rugged landscape with a rainforest feel about the place. Bikes were not our scene but by jumping on and off the regular busses we covered a lot of ground, including some of the local 'villages' where we were really welcomed. Don't forget the Octopus Card!

Lantau's tranquility. Skip the Big Buddha, a tourist trap. Instead take the Outlying ferry to Mui Wo pier. From there you can start hiking or just stroll along the promenade to see some village life. There is a wonderful Turkish restaurant, Bahce at Mui Wo Center ground floor. There are one or two modest but safe seafood restaurants along the shore, too. If you had enough of the urban jungle head to serene Lantau for half a day. For serious hikers get a map and head for the Lantau trail.

The Good, The Bad & The Ugly. As I understand it, there are 3 main things to do on Lantau Island: Tai-O (the fishing village), the Big Buddah / Po Lin Monastery and that Sky-Ride thing at Ngong Ping 360.The Good: I took the ferry from Hong Kong to Lamma. It's about 50 minutes. Beautiful scenery along the way, fun ride! Then, I took a bus to Tai-O. The bus ride is great - lots to see, lots of twisty roads. Tai-O was my favorite part of going to Hong Kong. It's like going back in time with houses built on stilts over the water. For 3 dollars they'll take you on a boat tour of the area.From Tai-O you can catch a bus to the Big Buddah. It's awesome! A must see. The Po-Lin Monastery is amazing also. The bus signs are clear and easy to read. It's nearly impossible to get lost.The Bad: The line at Ngong Ping to catch the SkyRide was ridiculously long. About an hour wait. I skipped it.The Ugly: My guidebook listed having the vegetarian lunch at the Po Lin Monastery as a "must-do." Don't do it! The food is terrible. Tasteless, bland, ugly dining room, and way to expensive. When the est part of your Chinese meal is the rice, you know the food sucks!
Nice spot. Nice family adventure. Good for rainy weather. Too many trails to follow. Not possible to cover in a day.
A must see, but really busy. Really nice trip, especially if you not only visit Big Buddha and the temple (which is a bit obligatory) but to escape from the crowd by walking some tracks..

A quiet and peaceful place. Took a ferry across, nice, quiet and peaceful place where it is like no one is in a hurry to go anywhere. Took a walk around the nearby area, there are small little shops selling souvenirs, seafood restaurants, and some snacks. you will love the place if tranquility is what you are searching for.

Nice trip to Lantau Island!. It was a great experience going into Cable Car for long scenic view and reach Lantau Island. You could enjoy a very nice view of Hong Kong Airport, the city and the Big Budha. This island has other options to explore also.

Cable car to the Buddha. The queues can be extensive and there are a variety of payment options keep to the cheapest and queue a little longer. Don't do a glass bottom cable car it has no more to offer is more expensive and you will wait as long as for normal cars

So Different to Hong Kong. Just loved Lantau Island so very different to Hong Kong & yet only a short ferry ride away. Tom's - Café Paradiso at Mui Wo has great breakfasts and Tom is such a character. The island is so much quieter & slower with lots of amazing hikes and the landscape & flora is just amazing. Tai O Village is very touristy but worth exploring.Do be sure to catch the local buses not just the tourist cable car & tourist only buses. You can learn so much about how the locals live here. You will see stunning mountains, little villages and stunning beaches. The main attraction the Big Buddha is beautiful and do be sure to go inside & learn about its construction and time line etc. Lunch in the Monastery is a real treat, we stood in line with some locals who helped us pick out some very different foods - what a treat & so cheap. Brilliant day trip or if you can stay a little longer.

Long Wait, but worth it!. We visited the island, via the cable cars just after Chinese New Year. We did have a long wait to access the cable cars, which was unsurprising, due to the timing! However we absolutely loved it. We got lots of lovely pictures, and visited the monastery and the sitting Buddha. I would recommend going when the weather is nice, as you can see for miles!We went on the crystal cab;e cars, with the glass bottom - amazing experience!

Impressive but very busy. The big Buddha itself is very impressive and the cable car up to the peak was a great experience but the 2hour wait to get the cable car took away from the experience some what. I'd recommend getting there early to avoid long queues.

Beautiful Scenery. We made the trip up to the Big Buddha, what a neat experience, would definitely go again. Highlight was the 10,000 Buddha's room(I think that is what it was called. Very tourist-y. Make sure to leave this place early enough. We got caught in a wind storm on the gondola it was fog, dark and the gondola was swinging. It stopped a few times, Might have been one of the scariest times of my life.

Take the time to visit Lantau, it's amazing. The MTR gets you there pretty quick, there is a lot to do even before you get in the cable car, malls etc. If you want to avoid the line and get a thrill pay for the glass bottom car, almost no line and a great ride. Buddha statue and the village at the top is very cool. We were there at Chinese new Year so it was a mob scene but lot's of fun.

A little bit touristy. Overall the experience was pleasant. Unfortunately due to rain & fog, the only activities I could participate in were the walk to the Budda which was beautiful, enjoy the Monastery and the 360 activities. I didn't enjoy these, just put on for the tourists. If you are visiting Lantau, make sure you are able to participate in the nature walk and take time to see the locals and how they live. Beautiful spot, cable car fantastic but not on a foggy wet day.

Island with Buddist Monastery where we had a simple lunch.. The highlight of this visit was the Monastery where new monks were being initiated that day so it was crowded with family members and monks of both sexses . There is also a massive statue of the Budha towering over the landscape, sitting up a steep flight of stone steps & surprisingly a simple Riding School nearby! What a contrast!

Visit to Big Buddah on Lantau. This is a good day visit to Lantau, the Big Buddah and the Monastery. It is worth climbing to the top where you will fabulous views all round while you circle the terraces to get " Elightenment"

A Day Trip to Lantau Island. We made the choice to get on a tour of Lantau Island, due to the fact it was our first full day in Hong Kong and the learning curve of getting around and time was important. It worked out great. Get picked up at our hotel in Kowloon and driven to the ferry docks in Hong Kong. Crossing Victoria Harbor in a ferry was a fun experience. On another coach we traveled Lantau Island. Visiting Tai O was as close to a mainland China small fishing village I’ve ever been and was in awe of its heritage and way of life. Rode a small boat that passed through the over water homes with a few locals waiving at us tourists. The Big Buddha and the grounds of the Po Lin Monastery was beautiful and humbling. As a non Buddhist, it was a peaceful exploration surrounded by true buddhists worshipping. It was wonderful watching them in practice of tradition. As if the modes of transportation so far wasn’t enough, we came down the mountain using the Ngong Ping 360 Skyrail. The Skyrail cable car was a joy to ride down the mountain. Heights and sights were exhilarating! Once down we were on a coach again to our perspective hotels. Could not image trying to cover all this on our own. One great benefit was not having to wait in lines to get on the ferry or Skyrail, and having Chinese vegetarian lunch included.
An island of differeces. This island does not only have the major air port but the Great Buddha, Disneyland and great natural beauty
Best Cable Car Experience Ever!. Lantau Cable Car gave us a very spectacular view of Western HK. From mountain view, strait view, to cultural park of Big Buddha.

Lantau Island visit. To have a FULL day, we caught the ferry from the Central Pier complex and had a leisurely ride to the island ( about 40mins). We then caught a bus from outside the ferry dock which terminated at the Po Lin Monastery which has the Giant (Big) Buddha and the Hall of Ten Thousand Buddha's. The Giant Buddha is at the top of a 1000step stairclimb so I wouldn't recommend it for the unfit or those in a rush, but it was quite spectacular and there's a museum inside as well. We also had lunch at the monastery which was quite tasty and then made our way down through the village to the cable car which is an amazing ride across the island and the channel back to Hong Kong Island! This terminated opposite a MRT station which then took us back into HK. I would recommend this as a FULL day ou as we did it but if you're pushed for time , I'd probably take the MRT to the HK cable car station and do it to and from Launtau Island. The journey is 50 min return that way.

The island is big!!!!. Not only is the airport located her but also Asia Expo, Disneyland and and the Big Buddha!!! There is housing on the island at Discovery Bay. There are also a lot of hiking trasilsd.

Disneyland. My favourite place in HK. Parades were awesome. Be there once the park opens to catch all the shows! Maybe due to the cold weather queue for rides were not long and enjoyed the fireworks at the end of the day

So different. Away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong Island Kowloon Lantau has a very different experience to offer - everything from the "new" airport and Disneyland to wonderful signs if nature, hills and forests.
Nice scenery. The cable car ride to the Big Buddha was great. The scenery was excellent and I did not think Hong Kong had such a great view and non-polluted places.

Get away from the high rises and the crowds. Plenty of things to do here - take the cablecar to Ngong Ping and the Po Lin monastery, hike in the mountains, take a bus to Silvermine Bay (Mo Wui) or Tai O and for shopping fanatics there's the Citygate Outlet Mall in Tung Ching. Makes a good stopover between planes as so handy for the airport.

A Must See!. This is a must see! No need to take a tour, you can easily do it on your own. We took the MRT to get there and returned on the cable car. The Big Buddha is awesome! It was busy when we went, but still a highlight!

If not wind. Many of the time i tried to visit on my holiday but when ever i reach on main gate they said today is wind so strong cant cant visit via cable car.But i did last time its worth to visit to there with family.

Great ride. Well worth doing both the ride and the island. Allow a full day no need for a tour.
Catch the MRT and pay for the ride to the Big Budda

A government planned island. The government planned the new airport, as well as a lot of the new housing that is found on Lantau Island. The idea was to entice people to move from over-crowded and astronomically expensive Hong Kong proper. With the Tsing Ma bridge and the various ferries, commuters can easily get to work, etc and yet live on Lantau. There are a number of interesting places to visit on Lantau Island, including the Po Lin Monastery, beaches, and Tai O fishing village.You could easily spend a day or more on the island. Enjoy.

Great day out. Visited on our own took MTR from Tsim Tsau station on Kowloon to Tung Chung visited outlet malls. Then cable car from there up to Big Buddah then bus No 211 to Tai O fishing village did 20 minute boat trip to see stilt houses then tea at Heritage hotel. Bus number 1 to Mui Wo and ferry back to Hong Kong central. Cost of travel £20 including cable car. Took all day but well worth it despite fog and a thunderstorm.
Very nice Island getaway. We really enjoyed our trip to Lantau Island. Was unique and great to see our some locals live and see the little fishing village

Don't bother with the cable car. we didn't bother with the cable car as the que was over two hours, instead we got a bus to Tai pai fishing village for a fraction of the price and it was a nice way to see a bit of the island.

Relaxing and Religious Experience. Traveling to Lantau Island is a relaxing, entertaining and religious experience. Guests may reach Lantau Island by ferry, by bus, by MTR. Getting to Lantau Island is half the fun because the trip involves a Ngong Ping 360 cable car ride which lasts 30 minutes or so. On the peak is one of the world's largest outdoor Buddha Statue.
Worth a visit. We did the Cable car and Big Buddha. Worth a visit and enjoyed the day. Easy to get there on MTR. Good view of airport

One of the longest cable car rides we've ever taken!. It was a pity about the weather. As we departed from the cable car station we could look back on Hong Kong airport, but as our journey progressed higher up the hillside, we were shrouded in mist. On arrival at the summit, it seemed surreal. A Starbucks & other cafes & shops. After a short walk we arrived at the Temples. Although it felt like a Holy place on one hand with people lighting sticks of incense, it is spoilt by commercialism.
A day of adventure. A very nice place to venture with many place to be with nature. There are a few way to go there but with the MTR and cable car it is the fastest and most convenient.

A paradise close to the city. Lantau Island is a beautiful and fantastic place to visit! No matter whether you like lovely beaches, small villages, tasty food, hiking and nature or if just want to escape the busy streets of Hong Kong with its thousands of people, Lantau never disappoints. By MTR it only takes approx. 45 minutes from Central in HK Island to Tung Chung. From Tung Chung you can either take a ferry to Tai O or buses to various destinations in Lantau. Alternatively there's a ferry service from Central Piers to Mui Wo in Lantau which roughly takes the same time as the MTR as well. If you have been to Lantau once, you will always return.
A beautiful reprieve . A full day of views, activities a d experiences. I highly recommend arranging a tour which also visits local stilt house fishing town

Another pleasant place to spend your weekend in Hong Kong. Lantau Island is where the Hong Kong Int'l airport is. Many visitors go there only to catch up flights. On the other side of the Island, however, it is another world. There is a fantastic hiking trial with ease and stunning sea view that your whole family will enjoy; There are nice beaches along the hiking trail that you can stop over and relax. During summer times Lantau Island is also a popular place for water sports; Only a few minutes of walk from the Tung Chung MTR station, a cable car takes you all the way to the Big Buddha and the surrounding beautiful walks; Hong Kong Disneyland is also on Lantau Island...Lantau Island is beautiful, welcoming and relaxing. We love Lantau.
Stunning views. Great cable car experience especially good because you have a great view of the International Airport and the sea.

Beautiful place. Caught the ferry to see the big bhudda and caught the wrong one and ended up on the other side of the island but it was a nice mistake a lovely beach there so had a drink there then caught a taxi to the other side lovely views wild animals all the way along the route and very scenic beautiful
Awesome island!. During the time we visited its a foggy day and when e ride the cable car we cant sea any view. But when we reached to the Big Buddha , it was a very nice place.
Beautiful Island. This is a very pretty island to get away from the city. I took the cable car up to the Big Buddha location and I can recommend it.

Hiking! . Was conned to do a 1/2hour hike from Citygate to Tai-O the fishing village. Turned out to be a 3 hour hike, climbed up 92 stories (according my iPhone). What can I say about it? Excellent! I didn't know Hong Kong has such wonderful trails! The weather was kind as it was quite cooling. It is a very scenic and comfortable hike. Just be prepared with good walking shoes!

Amazing!. It is a fantastic trip. We took the tour bus from the cruise terminal. Nice driving time. The view is great. We stopped at the small fishing village, first. That village deserves a stop and I wish I had done extra time to enjoy some local food. We went to see the bug Buddha. It is very impressive. It is really big. Great view. Then we took the cable car down and that was spectacular.
Great visit to see the Big Buddha. Great day out to see the Big BuddhaCan be reach d by cable car or ferryMuch quieter than Hong Kong island or Kowloon . Worth the visit .

Cable car, Tai O and seaside. The Big Buddha and the cable car going up there is the best known sights of Lantau. The cable car ride does´t have it´s own listing. It is somewhat scary if you have a fear of heights. The guy I travelled with had a little bit of that and felt anxious at times. It was mostly fun, though. The winds were quite strong when we did the ride, and that felt very intense. Especially near tower T7. The car swung sideways a lot. We also opted for the glass bottom car, which meant great views and more a sense of hanging by a cable, and nothing else. Spectacular views and an impressive ride. Highly recommended.

Go for the cable car and the Buddha. A must visit even for a short HK visit - the cable car route (well worth the view from the glass box) and the giant buddha are the main highlights. Can also try the buddhist veg food at the monastery near the Buddha. But do not bother shopping, or souvenir hunting, as these are pretty expensive here compared to the various markets.
Iconic. Please don't go to Hong Kong without going to the big Buddha! We took the fantastic cable car but for the more energetic you can hike it! Wouldn't like to say how long that would take?

Chillaxing Experience!. We took the cable car and the crystal cabin... it was value for money since the queue was not long as compared to the ordinary cabin. The ride was smooth although there was a point were we stopped due to the wind. We saw the trail since it was glass bottom - if you are afraid of heights, please don't take the crystal cabin.It would be much cost efficient if you take the package for HKD255. With 10% discount if you pay with VISA.

Make a full day available for the trip. Lots of interesting things to see. Cable car ride is a wonderful 30 mins of views. Wear comfy shoes to climb up to the Big Buddha. If you have time, jump on the coach to Tai O fishing village only 15 mins away and go on a boat trip (about $25 for 20 mins) around the fishing village.

a great getaway from the busy city. Easily reachable by MTR, it's a big island with lots to do: the cable car Ngong Ping 360, the big Buddha, the Chi Lin temple, the vegetarian meals, and of course hiking!
Beautiful views. Use cable car when going there or spend a long day climbing. There is a Big Budda there and it is definitely worth to see.

Lantau Visit. I love Lantau and would love to come back. Such a clam and peaceful place. I highly recommend the small cafe rather than the set meal by the monastery, not that the meal is not good it is great. However the cafe has some unusual dessert/cakes to try and the noodles are lovely. The Crystal cable car is also amazing, coming down in this really does give the most amazing views. They get about 6 people in the cable car so if you are a couple or smaller group be prepared to share. Remember to take water and sunscreen with you, it can be very hot up there in the clouds.

great day out. we got a crystal bottom gondala - you could see the road, then the water and then the forest underneath you the whole way - pretty cool. very touristy up the top - every thing to get the dollar from you - but it can be easy avoided if you want.

Fantastic trip to the big buddha. Fantastic trip to the big buddha over the sea and mountain only 5 min from Hong Kong airport. The buddha is one of the biggest in the world, and you will love this nice trip.

Sweet Escape from Bustling Hk. I saw this place from one of Running Man (South Korea reality show) series when they were in Hongkong. I kept telling myself that I want to go to this place if I had a chance to go to Hk.I only have one day in Hk, and I already spent half a day getting lost in Nathan road searching for my hostel. However, I'm glad making the right choices by bought the ticket to Lantau Island from my guesthouse and I choosed the Crystal Cabin for round trip. It's around 100hkd cheaper rhan the original price in the lantau island web.When I arrived in the ticket gate, the queing was really long (altough its Tuesday), they split the line into two, the left line was really long, almost 500m until the ticket counter. I asked the people there and show me my "ticket" that I bought from the hostel, she told me to go to the right line and straight to the ticket counter for exchanging my "ticket" (happened to be a voucher) with the real ticket.And I felt so pitty with people that quieing to buy the ticket there. It its the best to buy the ticket upfront from the web/ from your hostel/ hotel. After I got my real ticket (kind of sticker bracelet), I thank God that I choosed the crystal cabin, its a bit more expensive than the usual cabin, but again, I saved my time since because the quieing for the crystal cabin much shorter than the common cabin.Before hop on into my cabin, I downloaded their apps so I could listen the e-guide along the journey from Hk to Lantau Island (It's avalaibke in some language including english - of course). Once you arrived in Lantau Island, it's best to skip the "village area" it's more like an artificial street that full with souvenir shops.Just go straight to the Big Budha statue, climbing some steps and enjoying the view, but don't spent too much time there. Going down and took the narrow street to "wisdom path" (just follow the street board), not many people walk to that way, but its the right way, just walk, you will go inside a small forest.The forest so quite and relaxing, you will only meet some people along the way... just keep walking, followed the small road, its about 15 - 30 minutes walk (depend on your speed), until you find the wisdom path on the right and lantau peak if you go straight. I didnt have a chance to go to Lantau Peak because its almost dark and still have to walk down, but I enjoyed the Wisdom Path a lot, the hike and the fresh air.After going down, I made a stop at the vegetarian cafe and had some dessert, the price is really cheap and the food so tasty. I also buy some souvenirs from the store in the villae before ride my crystal cabin. And again, so grateful that I bought the crystal cabin, I boarding at my crystal cabin in 10 min. While the others that took the common cabin still standing in "never ending queing"The next time I go to Hk, I want to come here again but through walking path instead took the crystal cabin. It will take some hours, but anyway, I love hiking, so I dont mind. :)

Lantau island . Travel to Lantau island. A nice place to visit but prepare well or end up waiting in long long lines. Maybe I was unlucky being a public holiday but I would still suggest to research the best times to visit. All modes of transport were busy. Decided to use the mtr which was pretty good. Taxi is a no no as it would be pretty costly. If you have a car then that wouldn't be an issue for you. But then again you have tolls to pay. So there is always something. Once you get there you will enjoy for sure. The view is truly awesome and more dependant on the tone of day, but each have their own lovely types of views. So time your journey well and you will enjoy it either way.

A good day out. Lantau as lots to do longest cable car ride, the Big Budder. You must go to Tai o when on the island this village is Hong Kong as it was when a fishing port the houses are all on stilts over the water. to get there take the No 11 bus from the bus station it takes about 1 hour to get there and costs 20c with an octopus card its well worth the trip

Cath Up With Friends. Had the pleasure of seeing this wonderful place with a few good friends, a gorgeous sunny day, a great ferry trip there and a good cold drink and delicious pub lunch - a good Sunday hideaway

Easy to go on MTR. Loved the ride on the MTR but when we arrived the queue for the cable car was 90 mins plus due to the Chinese New Year so wandered around the designer outlet shops there and decided to go on the cable car on another occasion

Interesting Lantau Island. We took the Crystal Cabin cable car ride from Tung Chung to see the Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery and Ngong Ping Village. The ride was interesting because of the glass bottom and the beautiful 360 views of the mountains. Unfortunately it was a very foggy day and we could not see the Big Buddha. However on the positive side, the fog added a different ambiance to our visit, which we also enjoyed. Ngong Ping village has a selection of food and souvenir shops including Starbucks and Subway. Po Lin Monastery has an impressive Ten thousand Buddha Hall which is a must-see. We ate the best tasting Tofu-fa (bean curd dessert) at the Po Lin monastery food area but did not have the vegetarian meal there.We did not get to visit Tai O Fishing Village but did some bargain hunting at the Citygate outlet shopping mall just beside the cable car station.One tip: Do book your cable car tickets online and do arrive early in the day to start your cable car journey, specially on a weekend. We were there at around 9:30am on a Saturday at the tail end of the Chinese new year holidays. Since we already had tickets, we need not queue and were able to take the cable car ride almost immediately. When we came down from the cable car at around noon, the lines that had formed were unbelievably long already.

Lantau is a must, but make sure it is a clear day!. Interesting visit, great cable car ride, shops are not a rip off. Avoid the 'Vegetarian meal' at all costs, soup like dishwater, tasteless vegetarian dishes. I'm sure the old monks had better than this.
great day trip. you can easily spend a day looking at the island and its attractions - the Buddha, monastery, fishing village, beaches....Disneyland. easily accessed by rail, ferry or car/bus.
Awesome Cablecar Journey to Ngong Ping. The cable car from Tung Chung was fantastic . The views were spectacular . A great way to see the island.

hiking trip!. Decided to leave the crowded city, and headed for Lantau. We arrived by boat, took a walk by the sea (excellent view), and started hiking. The trail was steep, but it was an easy trip. Fresh air, sea view all the way.

Be Sure to visit. It is a must when visiting Hong Kong to visit Lantau Island to see the Big Buddha. Hopefully I get to go on the Cable Car next time, visiting during Chinese New Year is a negative. The lines for the cable car were too much and unbearable so we opted for the bus ride which was great and scenic.

Memorable!. Be it the cable car, the sights, or Tai O, Lantau Island makes for a truly memorable day trip!
Lots to see and eat too!
Highly recommended!

Great Views. The cable car boasts some beautiful views of the bay and the rest of the Island leading to the Buddha. Go early to avoid long ques for tickets, or book tickets online. The village at the end of the cable car, leading to the Buddha and the Ministry is full of fast food chains and a whole loads of souvenir shops. whilst up at the Buddha take a little time to walk around the Wisdom Path and the monastery they are both very beautiful.

Diverse. It was good surprise, as it gets you away from the hustle and bustle of fast pace of the city. You can enjoy the beautiful fishing village with great dried seafood. And the other great attraction after you see Buda and the monastery. a great way to end it is the Gondola ride down the mountain.

Fantastic views. Having been to Hong Kong over several years we have always wanted to go up in the cable car. The day was rather misty but we decided to go. We were not disappointed, the ride up was fantastic even though at times we couldn't see in front of us. Once we reached the top the weather cleared and the views were fantastic. Plenty to see and do at the top, almost like another world. On our return journey the sky was completely clear ,so going down was even more exciting.

Lots to see. Get the ferie to mui WA and discover a selection of 12 amazing path ways planned for all types of walk from easy to very difficult. Along the way of all the paths you will discover a different side of Hong Kong beautiful nature. And don't forget to try great food and drink at the Turkish restaurant called bache in mui WA.

Great views. We had a great day out visiting Lantau Island. The cable car trip was amazing, you could see so far and the photo opportunities were amazing. We had my grandchildren with us and they loved the trip. Lots of shops when you get to the top and also a variety of eating options.
book in advance, and go on a clear day. we took the glass cable that was incredible. the island is lovely but for me, the cable took our breath away.

Beautiful Island - See Big Buddha and Tai O Village. Was great on a sunny day and took a cab down from the top and was able to see more of the island. The beaches looked beautiful and we saw an ocean side prison on the way!
Awesome Day Trip. The views traveling to and from Lantau Island were some of the best photo opportunities I have ever had loved it

Lots to see Go early. Go early to beat the crowds but stay all day. This place is very cool and very kid friendly. Big Buddha is here and so are the fishing villages. Take your time and soak it all in

Long, beautiful cable car ride. Took the Ngong Ping cable car ride while it was raining. Although I wasn't sure if it was safe, I still went ahead with it. Surprisingly, it wasn't as scary as I thought it would be. It was pretty sturdy and the ride was really smooth. Although the time I went was pretty foggy, I enjoyed the view.

excellent views trip of a lifetime magic in every way . it was the holiday experience of a lifetime. it was one of the best things I have ever done while on a trip and it was another one off my bucket list .

The Buddah and the tempel is a must see. We went up with the cable car, and the views were amazing. You can see a part of the city from high up, waterfalls and the mountain. Up in the mountain there was the biggest sitting buddah of the world, made of copper. The tempel is also very beautifull. Worthwhile and all for 180 HK dollar!

Hardly know you're so close to the city. There's an outlet mall there if you need any american shop discounts. Plenty of places to eat in the bus terminal is easy to find to go to the top of the mountain for the giant Buddha.
Worth it for the Cable Car ride. The Buddha was huge but not exciting or in my mind worth a visit purely to see it - however the ride on the cable car over the island makes it all worth while!

Not for the Faint of Heart - especially if you take the Glass Botton gondola. WOW what views -- this keeps climbing and turning and climbing again -- we went when it was windy and cold so it does rock and you look down at the water a long way below -- we still took the trip and glad we did -- bought the tickets online ahead of time -- gets you ahead of the lines

skip the cable car if it's raining. You can get to Ngong Ping village, the Big Buddha, and Po Lin Monastery by cable car, but if it's pouring rain you won't be able to see anything. If you keep walking from the MTR station, you can take the 23 bus, which offers a nice view along the winding roads and is much cheaper. Some nice walks in the monastery and even a remote youth hostel make for a nice getaway from the city.

Beautiful countryside escape from busy Central / Hong Kong. The beautiful surroundings of Lantau are in stark contrast to busy central Hong Kong. Emerald hills and lots more to see. Many people visit the Big Buddha which can be very busy but there's lots more to see and do on Lantau Island. Would definitely recommend!
Enjoyable . We enjoyed this sightseeing day.Hong Kong has so many things to see and do so add this to your list as well.Lots going on within this area.

Well worth a day trip. Really enjoyed our trip to Lantau Island by cable car.Ngong Ping village still has a quaint feeling to it even though it is so busy.We took a glass bottomed cable car and really enjoyed it. Views are really quite stunning and the mist adds to the atmosphere.

Beautiful. Lantau Island is actually a very big place, and hosts many attractions. As it happens, some of them are pretty inspiring and beautiful (such as the big Buddha, the Buddhist temple or the many country trails) whereas others are less interesting (such as the shopping areas, which I found totally boring).

A must visit when in Hong Kong. We limited our visit to the cable car ride and the Big Buddha but it is clear that the Island has so much more to offer it is just a matter of how much time you devote to this part of your journey. Had we had more time we would have spent time at the beach and a visit to the pink dolphins. In fairness the weather in January had been very unsettled so perhaps the beach may not have been worth the time. That said I am certain that most will be blown over by the cable ride and Big Buddha. Nice shopping arcade come Mall at Tung Chung by the MTR station.

A must-do Tourist activity!. As a first-timer to Hong Kong in January 2016, this excursion was by far the most memorable of the trip. The cable car journey to and from the Island is incredible and Lantau Island is beautiful. The temples and giant Buddha are a must-see. There is a little village at the top which is cute and ample photo opportunities. A truly unique experience that I won't forget. Just a heads up - the queues for the cable car can be ridiculous!

Great island- prioritize it!!. We discovered this island only towards the end of our trip and regretted we didn' t prioritize it from the beginning. It seems that there are so many things to do there.Definitely the cable car and the visit to the temple near the Big Budha.While riding on the cable car (we took the crystal cabin with the glass floor) we saw many path ways that go through the island and we really sorry we didn't have time left to explore them. If you love nature walks- prioritize this island!!!

Memorable Ropeway Trip. Must visit place in hongkong. The entire ropeway stretches over sea, land and mountain travel time of about 25-30mins. The view from the top is awesome, the airport and the Lantau island is best viewed from ropeway. Big Buddha is the main attraction here. Adventure seekers can climb the mountain by foot, pathway available. Road way is also there.

Great view. The cable ride has great view of the airport and its runway at the initial portion. Subsequently great view of the greenery around the area. The main tourist area are overall quite spacious. Nice trip and felt quite peaceful there.

An Amazing Tranquil Experience. Points to consider: Wear good walking shoes, wet wipes, umbrella and windbreaker. Early morning 9am, I took the longest cable car ride to arrive at Ngong Ping Village. I was greeted with lots of interesting shops selling traditional and modern art crafts, food stalls selling snacks and familiar brands like Starbucks. I would recommend to take a stroll through these stalls just to soak in the atmosphere of the unique setting of the village on such height and peaceful surrounding. Continuing on towards the Big Buddha, the challenge of the steps came. The challenge was the slippery steps but it was all worth it for the magnificent view of the sculptures. There was time before my vegetarian meal so I went to the path of Wisdom which is hard to tell which is the path to start but the friendly locals are always willing to guide you. A couple who goes there for daily workout took me not only to the Path of Wisdom but also to the Sunset Peak. Oh my! that breath taking sight and of course the hike for the weak urban dweller took my breath away too! The path to the Sunset Peak is at a split to Path of Wisdom which is an easier hike. After the hike, I am all ready for my one-man meal! But my observation tells me that the more people you eat with the better the variety. However my vegetarian meal is still very yummy! the best was the fried spring roll which was crispy on the outside and crunchy on the inside. I took a bus ride over to Tai O via Bus 21 which took about 20 minutes to get there.I followed the bridge over the silt houses and chanced upon the famous Lor Mai Chi (糯米糍) and 茶果 (cha kwo) which have many flavors so I bought a few to try. It was so good that I also had them as my breakfast. The bean filling tasted like Singapore's Ang Ku Kueh. I did not take the dolphin tour as I have read reviews and asked many which feedback that they did not manage to see any and I spent more time walking around which led me to cover the area for more interesting sight and food. From Old Man rock to the other end of the lookout pavillion, I covered within 2hours. Since I was alone, I managed to move quickly around and covered the both Ngong Ping and Tai O by 3pm. So I had the option to go to another part of the island but I choose to return to the main island and cover other destination in the evening. In summary this is a great island for outdoor lovers, children to see a simpler lifestyle and foodie!

The Weather Affected Our Experience. We enjoyed seeing the countryside as well as the high rise communities, but we felt we spent a lot of money and time doing this activity. Don't do it unless the weather is good.

the land of Big Buddha, Disneyland and airport.. Lantau Island is the Island which has Airport, Disneyland,Ngong Ping and The Big Buddha. Its connected with HK Island and Kowloon Via MTR and Road. we took a bus from the airport to HK Island, the views of Island and sea harbour were amazing.

Worth the trip, get the cable car. Getting to Lantau Island is half the fun. Make sure you use the cable car (Ngong Ping 360) from near Tung Chung MTR station. Also save time in ticket lines by buying your ticket online. Also recommended is the "crystal car" option - the cable car has a glass floor - adds another dimension to the 20 min trip.Once you get to Lantau there is lots to do including the Big Bhudda and nearby Po Lin monastery. A real highlight for us was to get the bus from the village down to the Tai O fishing village (now that's real Hong Kong !). then get the bus back to Ngong Ping for your return cable car trip.A great day out !

Hike to the Big Buddah. I found it hard to find reviews on this hike so hopefully this will help anyone wanting to know more.The path is a bit tricky to find as it is not near the start of the cable car. If you google run lily blog spot there are some good directions. I printed these and showed them to the locals who were really helpful. Take exit A from the metro and when you leave the station head in 2/3o'clock direction up the slope. You want to he headwind towards the fire station & hospital but then need to get on the far side of the estate of flats. From there it's off on the bike path to the right to find the path.The first part of the path is pretty steep with lots & lots & lots of stairs!! Think about 100 flights! There are 30 markers and once on the path it is really well marked. There is a wooden stretch part way up which includes slopes and stairs. I wouldn't recommend doing this if it has rained hard as it was very slippy when I went. If you are determined to go anyway, hike up but get the cable car down. I planned on hiking both ways but decided I'd be on my butt slipping on the wood if I tried to come down...although it is really well maintained, think slippy decking with algae on it. The rest of the path is stone & concrete so the underfoot grip is fine. It's 5.7km & my Fitbit had it down as about 200 flights of climbing in total (100 on the first bit then it eases off more). It's not all stairs, plenty of flat bits & slopes too. Took me 2.5 hours & I'm reasonably fit. It is well worth it & very rewarding. You may see other people on the path but not many. If you can make it out in my pics. The white looking building near the open water in the first pic which looks a bit like Sydney opera house is where the metro & cable car are. You will need to be heading away from this to the right, past the estate of flats & past a little playground to get to the green bridge which you can just make out in my second pic if you enlarge it. Look under the hill to the right of the buildings.....in the foreground of the cranes... Once you get there to the bridge it's very easy! There's also a very clean public toilet right by the playground area which I didn't expect! Happy to help with any questions

Well Worth A Day Trip.. There are a couple of ways of reaching Lantau Island from Kowloon or Hong Kong Island; we took the ferry from Central and then the No.2 bus to the Big Buddha and Monastery . Due to the travel time and the pleasure of being at the site of the Big Buddha, you want to allow yourselves the whole day to visit this very impressive sight. Basic vegan food is sold at the monastery's café. Communication if you don't speak Chinese is impossible so if you have any food allergies etc... take your own food with you. Whatever you do make sure you visit the whole site and not just the Big Buddha!!! Oh and be prepared to bump into the odd cow or dog!

Interesting sleepy island , great hideaway from city. It's accessible by boat (45min ride from Central pier). If you want to really explore the island, go in the morning and you can take a few hours to hike through the island and end with a seafood meal before heading back to the main HK islands. Make sure you check boat service times before you go. It's quite an interesting fishing village and quite rustic compared to bustling HK city. Nice beaches to relax on as well. The seafood restaurants can be pricey. So be prepared to pay.

Great Place to Sightsee. It was a fantastic long journey on the cable car to Lantau Island. I didn't manage to take the crystal clear glass cable car. I took the normal one and that itself was a splendid experience. I had one cabin by myself so me and my husband had a wonderful time taking photos!

Amazing experience and you have to try it!. What a view from the cable car, i could not image how people built such a wonderful cable like this one in Hong Kong. Nothing much in lantau island but these cable car make me excited. Defitnitely try one more time when back to Hong Kong.
Naturally beautiful. Quiet side with nature's beauty to enjoy with the Cable car and trekking and ofcourse Disneyland! Makes sense to stay on the island before heading to Hong Kong

little piece of heaven far from the craziness of HK. a small peaceful island with great vegetation taking a stroll down the streets you almost feel disconnected from the big skycrapers, crazy shopping malls...

So many things to do..... Lantau island lies west of HK. It is easily accessible by the Tung Chung mtr line from downtown. It offers many things to do, so you'll need at least two days if you want to visit all it has to offer.This was my third time in HK and I think I saw everything there.Your first encounter with Lantau will be when you land at HKIA.The Big Buddha statue and the Ngong Ping village, along with the cable car ride to them, are things not to be missed (see my reviews for them). Being by the Buddha up there, there's a Po Lin monastery and Tai O fisherman village.For kids, there's Disneyland also on Lantau, but in my opinion this is the least interesting Disneyland in the world, with attractions for really young ones only.

Really cool. Going on the cable cars is great fun - just try to make sure it's a clear day as the views aren't up to much when you've only got 20 metres in each direction.Also recommend booking your ticket online in advance as the queues here get MASSIVE.

Great Experience. This is one of the highlights of Hong Kong. Always better to book in advance to avoid the queues. We visited it on a Sunday and the queue to buy the tickets was a 90 mins wait. Secondly, book the crystal bottom cabins (not very expensive but worth the experience plus the queue is shorter). The views from the glass bottom, especially of the sea inlet are awesome.Once on the top, its a different world from the hustle and bustle of HK. Clean air, very breezy and chilly (November month). Spend time walking around, one can spend a full day just hiking all the trails around the top. Shopping and visits to the various ticketed attractions can be avoided.

An amazing experience. We had the most amazing day on Lantau Island, the Big Buddah is well worth the long queues for the cable cars. If you plan to go during a peak period, reserve tickets online, it cuts out a very long wait! You just pick them up at the kiosk when you arrive. There is also a Chinese village with Temples and workshops. The views are stunning too, so don't forget your camera.Enjoy, we did!

High & High. Very nice place & literaly on top of Hong Kong.You take a cable to the top & suddenly you find yourself in a differenet world alltogether.Nice place away from the city hustle bustle.Ideal place to spend along with your family among monks & rituals of differenet sort.

Gives you a different perspective to Hong Kong. I took my girlfriend over to Mui Wo on Lantau Island for lunch as I wanted to show her that Hong Kong isn't just high rises, that there are still many very local areas. We caught the local bus from Tung Chung (only tourists n bus), then sat in local cafe for lunch, followed by walk around the beach area where locals were having bbq's and enjoying a Sunday outing.

Do not expect to see white dolphins. We did not do the touristic organised tour to Lai o fishing village - opted for the local transport at a quarter of the price which was an adventure on its own! However do not expect to see dolphins on the 20 minute boat trip - its like looking for lion in the streets of johannesburg! The village itself is awesome but a tourist trap of note

Go with a tour. And you won't have to wait in line to purchase tickets and to wait forever to go on the cable car to getto the island. We only did a half day tour and we had a great guide. We believed he actually lived on the island but was well traveled and his English was terrific.

Fisherman's life. Other than Ngong Ping village in Lantau Island, there is another village where worth to go, that is Tai O village. Long times ago, most people living there was fisherman, they built their houses on the seashore. Even now, there are a lot of houses builing onto the sea. Tai O is a village where give you calm and relax, you can see the living style of old village people there. Along the Tai O main street, there is a lot of restaurant and some shops selling snack which it cannot be found in anywhere other than Hong Kong. Moreover, if you have time, take a small boat to see the Dophins, the trip is not expensive, around HK$30 per head.

Excellent place. One of the best places in the city, lots of things to do and visit to- Disneyland,Noah's ark,airport spotting,big Buddha,cable car ride and the beautiful crystal cabin and lots more. Not to forget to visit Tai O fishing village which is a hidden gem outside the hustle and bustle of the city. Scintillating place.

Touristy but worth it. If you're going to do any major tourist attraction in Hong Kong, Lantau Island may as well be the one. It's popular with tourists but not as crowded or chaotic as the city. Go early to take the cable car but be prepared to suffer in a loooong lineup on the way back down. Spend the day; take your time. Climb up to the Big Buddha, visit the Po Lin Monastery and the vegetarian restaurant for some small treats, and get on that bus to Tai O. As much as I hate crowds and lineups, Lantau was a real highlight of my trip to HK.

Definitely worth a visit! Would be better to explore the outskirts . The cable car up to lantau island is really fascinating! The view of the mountains around is just amazing! Lantau island also has plenty of places that's really scenic for tourists to visit! One of the places that I really love would be tai o! Tai O is a really scenic spot, and it's very laid back and chill. However, the transport to Tai O is really inconvenient as the buses only leaves lantau island for tai o every 30minutes...

For fun. Lantau Island is a collection of things to do that are a little different than what you'll find in Central or Kowloon. The buses are bumpier, the views are more natural, and the ferry is a common mode of transportation to visit smaller outer islands or to get back to Hong Kong Island. It's also where Disneyland and the airport are, but I'm not going to Disneyland and everyone goes to the airport. There are mountain trails to hike, cable cars to ride, Big Buddhas to admire, outlying fishing villages to walk around, parks and temples to explore and good food to eat! Choose a few of the many things to do on the island and make a day of it!

Cable car to Big Buddah. We took the cable car and it was an amazing experience. The line to get on however was around 2 hours long at 1100 am. We spoke to a man selling some package there who told us that the crystal (glass bottom) cable was a much quicker line. This cost more! and on this day we saw lots of people on the regular cable car move in the line far quicker than we did, so that information was not correct.

Great trip out of the big city. Very nice cable car ride to the buddha statue at Ngong Ping 360 on the Lantau Island. You can get there by subway. Just a short ride. The Tian Tan Buddha was wort visiting too.
EN-ROUTE TO BUDDHA. Very touristy. Extremely long queues in December. Try arriving early to board the cable car and arrive at Buddha before the tourist rush.
So many things to do. There are so many tourist attractions and beautiful scenery on Lantau Island, including the a Big Buddha and Disneyland.
best ever trip to Lantau island. love Lantau island which we were really having fun in there and its worth to visit rather than other places in Hong Kong

Simply amazing! . From the beautiful beaches to the small town fishing villages and ancient temples. It was well worth the bumpy boat right over. We did a trip which took us up to the big budda( also worth a visit) however if your scared of heights I wouldn't recommend the cable car ride down.

Worth a day trip. Lantau was cool. We got a late start due to a late night in LKF. We took the ferry across and immediately made our way toward a Mexican restaurant at the port. It's pretty darn bueno, but that's hardly one of the major attractions in Lantau. We really had no clue what to do so we wandered into the tour office next door and the sweet lady gave us a map and an easy itinerary I'll share with you. We took the 100 bus to the Tai O fishing village. The busses are comfy tour-type with a/c and you get a nice tour of the island. Tai O is a cool place to wander around and spend maybe two hours going through the market, taking pics, and checking out the little houses on stilts. Not really a lot of eating options other than street snacks - good thing we had those fish tacos. You can take a boat ride from here, but we were short on time (see 'late start.') From there we caught a cab because the next bus was 40 minutes and the sun was starting to go down. We went to the big Tian Tan Buddah where there's a little shopping village and a lot of stairs to climb up to the buddah. We skipped the stairs for a stop at Starbucks (again, late night), but you can clearly see the buddah and be impressed by its size from far below. You can also get a pretty cool view from the cable car. We bought a ticket for a glass bottom car, but I don't really think it was worth it. It's not that much more, but it's not THAT high and there's really nothing to see below but trees and water. The idea of it was better than the reality. The cable car runs down to the other side of the island from where the ferry dropped us off and from there you can take the train right back into Hong Kong Island. There's also a massive outlet mall you can hit before getting on the train. It's a perfect loop and an easy day trip to get out of the city. We saw lots of nice walking trails and beaches that would be a relaxing way to kill some time on a warmer day.
Amazing. The que was long in getting the tickets but very fulfilling once you already in the cable car. First timers should visit this place.
reccomend only in good weather. only if there is sunny weather than you can go to see beautiful views.but in rainy days or when some clouds - nothing to do there but airport

A MUST!. Lantau Island was my most favorite attraction in Hong Kong. From the Big Buddha to the street food everything was amazing. The cable cars were a bit scary but the views from them were amazing. Highly recommend this place

Airport, shopping & heritage..... The island is home to a large modern international airport with excellent transport links to Kowloon & Hong Kong.
There is the City Gate shopping outlet, Disneyland, the cable car to the Big Buddha.

Go early!. We did not buy tickets ahead of time so we arrived shortly after 9am to line up for tickets for the cable car and we were 10th in line (The cable car open at 10am). Ticket purchase was quick and the line moved fast. You have the option to ride in cable cars with a clear bottom (either both ways or one way). We went on a clear day and the view was amazing! They try to fit 8 people per cable car.We arrived at the village and spent some time there browsing the shops. They were pretty pricey but some neat souvenirs.
