Tourism Object and Shopping Center. take MTR station to lantau island. visit City Gate shopping outlet, or you can take cable car only for HKD 160 to NgongPing Giant Buddha statue, or you can having fun at the Disneyland

Fantastic Views and see the largest Sitting Bronze Buddha.. You would need to ask your hotel how to can get there as there are a couple of ways arriving there. See my other reviews where I suggested that you pay a visit to the HK Tourist Info. centre at the Kowloon Star Ferry Terminus. Get an idea as to what you wish to do in HK before getting the "how to get there" info. Also, you can plan before travelling - google Discover Hong Kong and have fun.

Round-the-island Tour with Diverse Sightseeing / Hiking / Swimming Activities. Lantau Island is actually the largest island in the city with such diversity for activities that one can't miss: (1) Culturally the Big Buddha Monastery near the Lantau mountain top by the more typical cable car or a public bus from the island's hub at Tung Chung, the terminus accessible by the MTR subway train or any E-prefixed airport bus enroute to the airport, OR for the venturesome, just hike uphill from Tung Chung more or less alongside the cable car. (2) Alternatively less aggressive hikers can go on the Tung Chung - Tai O Trail for a relatively flat hike for 5 hrs (about 12 km) on the island's northwest section facing the airport's runway and the Pearl River's mouth. (3) At the end of the somewhat flat trail is Tai O, an old fishing village with stilted houses on the water. (4) Or one can pass the hike above to take the public bus from Tung Chung to crawl over the mountains with numerous hairpin turns to the south side of beaches for a swim, and then crawl over again to Tai O.(5) After seeing the stilted houses at Tai O, one could take another bus to Mui Wo along the Island's south side to catch the ferry to Central back to the city hence completing the tour round the island.The above is a very full day or two, the latter if one includes one of the above two hikes.
great day. A great day visiting Lantau Island, the Big Budda and the monestry which included a vegetarian lunch and a ride on the cable cars down to the mainland. Not to be missed.

One day tour. The Lantau was one of the busier port before Britain occupier Hong Kong. It has been quieted few hundred years until the airport relocated to Lantau.You could plan your trip from Tung Chung then take the 360 Cable card to Ngon Ping, after that, take bus to Tai O to see the one and only old fishermen port and enjoy the good and fresh see food in HK.

Budda. We went up to see the Budda via cable car what a great view of all the surrounding area and of the new bridge and when you look down there is a water fall. Too get to Budda is268 steps so only fit persons can do this in the heat of the day The monastery visit is a must to hear the monks chanting on our trip we returned by bus

Don't miss!. Amazing experience! Don't miss. Take the train from Hong Kong to the end of the line and you cross the street to the cablecar. Bring toilet paper, antibiotic wipes, a hat. No shade on the island at all!

A peaceful spot. The food available on the Lantau island is really tasty. The big Buddha monastery is very beautiful and extremely quiet and peaceful. You can cover the entire Lantau Island walking in a single day. The cable car ride is a fascinating and an amazing experience. The serene beach on the Lantau Island viz., Cheung Sha beach is exceptionally clean and pleasant.
Lantau. travel around and see the full island. go on the cable car, 25 minutes of panoramic views.Go and see the Big Budda

Experience with crystal cable car~. First time taking the crystal cable car, it was amazing! In the crystal cable car, you can see everything around you AND below you! You can take crystal cable car up to the island and a normal cable car back. You won't regret taking the crystal cable car. For those scared of heights, you will be scared at the start but you will get used to the heights, so just go ahead!

Cable car ride great experience. Cable car goes up to the Big Buddha - super value for the money. Grear views all round.Go during the week as week-ends are extremely busy with many locals going ( presumably for religious reasons as well as day out in park)

Must go. This is a must go attraction. It is near the airport but you can take MTR to get there. The most convenient way to travel there is take train from Central IFC- Hong Kong Station, Tung Chung Line can directly get to Tung Chung then you can start taking an other transport like bus or cable car(long queue always) to go up.Tung Chung Line stopover: Hong Kong Station(Central IFC) >> Kowloon Station(ICC/Element shopping mall, Ritz Carlton Hotel or W hotel) >> Olympic >> Nan Cheong (Transfer line to New Territories like Yun Long or Tsuen Mun, Tai Po or Hong Ham)>> Lai King ( Transfer line to Tsuen Wan Line) >> Sunny Bay ( Where you get off to Disneyland Line toward Hong Kong Disneyland) >> Tung Chung ( Where you get off and get to Lantau Island)Started from Tung Chung to Lantau Peak is a really good trail, 943 metre high and foggy and windy up there but a very nice walk, challenging as it is the second high Mt in Hong Kong. Then you can take a crystal cable car down even it cost a little more but it save the time for you to wait in a queue.

Sitting Buddha, Monestery and arial tram.. A must see if you are in Hong Kong. Walk the stairs to one of the world's largest sitting Buddha. This is a holy site and no pictures are allowed inside the temple. It s a beautiful drive from Hong Kong to Lanrau Island. and take the arial tram back to town for spectacular views. The Buddha is awe inspiring. Their is a Buddhist monestery on the grounds and the monks run a vegan restaurant. This is was best vegetarian meal I had on my trip.
Choose the day of your visit. Its better to visit on a good day when the sky is clear and you can see the beautiful things this island can offer.

Idyllic place. I just love Lantau Island and visiting the Big Buddah is an absolute must. It's changed a lot since my first visit 15 years ago and instead of winding roads on a dodgy bus being eaten alive by mosses this time we took the cable car. Great experience. A wander round discovery bay is called for to get away from the frantic pace of Hong Kong.

Good for hiking and to see the Big Buddha. Lantau Island is very good for hiking and to see the Big Buddha. I hiked from Mui Wo to the Big Buddha, which took 6 1/2 hours, so bring plenty of water. You can do it the other way around, and there's a nice veggie lunch at the monastery by the Big Buddha.

Worth visit. Beautiful green island.The monastery at the foothill is very nice. Big Buddha temple is
worth going.One can spent several hours doing this tour but avoid to go on holidays .
Cooler or cloudy day will be preferable .

Well worth a visit. Beautiful island, serene, green. The fishing village boat run was interesting. Buddha temple is awesome ! The monastery at the foothill is very very nice. Spent several hours doing this tour and came back super satisfied.

Wonderful experience, just choose the day carefully.. It can get really busy here, so pick your day of the week carefully and avoid public holidays at all costs.Take the ferry from Central and once on Lan Tau, you can visit Tai O, the Big Buddha as well as the Po Lin Monastery and Temple of Ten Thousand Buddha's.It will take up most of a day, but it's well worth it.A cooler or cloudy day would be ideal as there's not a great deal of shelter from the sun on the island.

Touristy, but different from the rest of HK!. Lantau Island is where the airport is. I will recommend to merge this trip with your departure/arrival at HK. We checked-in our luggage at Airport Express and visited Lantau before taking the flight back home. This island itself has a feel of holy and peace! The bronze statue of Buddha, and the monastery being the landmarks. Must visit, as this is unlike any other attraction you will see in Hong Kong.

Great place to visit. Beautiful beaches, breathtaking scenery, lots to see. Big Buddha is a must. Buses might scare you driving but are completely safe. Easy to navigate around & people are extremely helpful. Nice eating & shopping options.

highly recommended. Love the sky cable :) the view is breath-taking... to get the giant buddha, you have to walk hundred steps though so you have to pack lots of water with you.. but when you get to the top, its all worth it :) the view is incomparable, its so peaceful and quiet in some areas...
Family with young children. Went here to take e cable car rides.Great view especially e crystal cabin..Reached at Lantau island...n grest view of mountains n the scenery..

I would recommend The Cultural & Heritage Tour. We did the Cultural & Heritage Tour of Lantau starting with the amazing Ngong Ping Cable Car ride (25 minutes) which took us up really high and from which we had wonderful views! We could see the whole airport, all the vegetation and later the huge buddha statues. We were transported from the village we had arrived at, by an air conditioned bus, down to the Tai O Fishing village. We then had a Tai O Fishing Village Boat excursion where we saw the village on posts over the water and were taken out into the bay. Unfortunately the dolphins didn't appear that day but the breeze off the water was so good!

Develop Area of Lantau Island. This lantau island is a area where the big buddha located. To Reach this area we need to use the Cable Car. This Lantau island is really develop now, we can find many restaurant, coffee shop, souvenirs shop, etc.
Another side of HK. I thought HK was just all bustling city and skyscrapers. Lantau is so beautiful with its beaches, hills, the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery.

Worthwhile Discovery. We took the Ngong Ping cable car to go to this island and landed at the Ngong Ping Village. We proceeded to take the climb up the steps to see the Big statue of Buddha. The views up there were breath taking. From there we went to the temple of the Po Lin monastery. It has three bronze statues of Buddha which represent his past, present and future. We dropped by at the Stage 360 where stuntmen performed action sequences supposedly from Chinese martial arts movies. Along the village itself, there were interesting Chinese cultural shops and a range of restaurants. It was a worthwhile visit to Lantau Island.
A must. We took the MTR to Lantau Island. The gondola is quite expensive so we took it one way and the bus and ferry back to Hong Kong Island.
Recommended. it was my second trip to HK but first time to this. recommended to visit and take a tram to the top.

lovely day out. Busy day out here. Hotel bus to kowloon central, ferry to Hong Kong then ferry to Lantau Island before catching the bus to the Big Buddah. Would have liked to have gone on the cable car but it was closed for maintenance . Walked up the stairs to the buddah. Nice view around the island. Went inside and had a look. Not a real lot to see inside. After going inside you are given a free ice cream and cold water (included with your entry ticket)which was nice as it was very hot. We then went to the monastery and had a look there. Quite spectacular the gold room. We didnt purchase the lunch offer when we bought our tickets and when we saw what it was was glad we didnt. It really didnt look that appertizing. It was easy getting around as all modes of transport took the octopus card so it was just swipe the card.

Nice activity for a second day in HK. An activity to do on a second day in HK. Very enjoyable trip on the cable railway over to mountains to access the hill of the Budah. The Buda and the temple are ok but predictable and not so different to other temples and Budahs in China.
Must visit in Hongkong. Must visit to Lantau island, its very close buy from airport on same island, excellent ropeway cable cars , had a very nice time with family .

Trip to Lantau island. We took the MTR from central station ... its really quick and cheap . by car would take much longer and the MTR is very cheap. The island is quite big and unfortunately the cable car was under maintenance and so we used the bus which took about an hour. The Big Buddha is spectacular and the walk up the many steps worth the effort to get to the top. One attraction not to miss. Take the ferry back to HK island .. its about 40 mins but nice and leisurely ...
Awesome experience.. incredible site. a really awesome cultural experience. use Lantau tours for an informative tour as well as a side trip to the 600 year old fishing village
Beautiful island . We took Nong ping cable car to see the view around the island. It was a beautiful place to see. At the end of trip, the big buddha was there.

OK is the mist does not take over. When I arrived at Lantau Island the sky cable was closed due to a storm. I decided to have some lunch and whilst doing so noticed that it had started running again so I decided to do the trip.The wait in line was over an hour and just after we set off the bad weather set in and we had no visibility.Walking up the street with lots of rather tacky shops I found the steps up to Big Buddha and decided to view him this way. Unfortunately the cloud cover was so thick that I only managed to see the pate of his head.I then caught the bus to Tai O fishing village for a quick visit and then another bus to Mui Wo to catch the ferry back to Hong Kong. This was a nice little village and many of the local were on the beach collecting pippies by the bucket full.
a must see. did the day tour of lantau island was a great day worth every dollar to see it all the guides are wonderful

Tian Tan Buddha worthwhile. I found it a straightforward journey to get to Lantau Island via the MTR.I was a little disappointed that the cable car was down for maintenance and therefore had to take the bus ($27 payable in cash or Octopus, each way) there. It was quite a windy trip but we got there in the end.On arrival I hated the tourist village -overpriced 'cultural experiences', ie shops. I stormed past it to visit the Buddha and the monastery. The were both worthwhile.It is a busy place, so expect crowds! It is very exposed so bring protection from the elements.

Disappointed. 5 of us were in HK from 8/Sept/2015 to 11/Sept/2015. We did Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha - see separate reviews. We failed to cable car to Lantau as the line was under maintenance. Crazy. Some publicity on this shut down would have been nice.

A Must Visit!!!. Want to escape from Hong Kong hectic and sophisticated life, a visit to Lantau island is a must. not only the home of Disney Land, Lantau also a great hiking spot. The view from above was amazing. I visited Ngong Ping Village (only take the cable car if you want to but prepare for a long queue, otherwise, bus is the cheaper option), see the monastery and big Buddha and ended up hiking to Lantau Peak. It was amazing
Need some good exercise go Sunset Peak. I did section 2 in June. It's hot. Mostly steep climb up 1h 45 min and descend 30 min. It's a challenging climb. Fun but not the easy type of hike.

Great Experience. The gondola ride to see the Big Buddha was fantastic. It was one of those once in a lifetime experiences that I will always cherish. Lines are long to board the gondola and I would advise getting your ticket in advance and purchasing the express line ticket. We went to Lantau via MTR and it was not difficult to get there from our hotel near the Fortress Hill stop in Hong Kong. Had a great time on a self directed tour.
Must visit. If you are in Hong Kong, please find some time to visit this please. It's crowded during the weekend, but worth to see.
Scenic. Amazing place..Traveled to it by the cable car..Buddha statue is beautiful and scenic. Had drizzled before we got there so the weather was just lovely!

Touristy but less crowded than Kowloon and HK Island. Now that the MTR links Lantau, I decided to pay it a visit. The cable car ride gave brilliant views, but the area around the Big Buddha is just a new tourist village and there is so little there.

Worth a Visit. Lantau island is now more easily accessible than before the road and rail links were completed when the only option was a ferry trip. If speed is important then opt for the road or rail links, but a trip over on the ferry is well worth the extra time it takes.Lantau is a big island and has a lot of diversity open to the visitor. Beaches, hiking, many restaurants and traditional fishing villages and communities can be found there. Throw in the big Buddha and you have an island that has a lot to offer for tourists and is well worth a visit. You also have hotels and village houses that can be rented out so an over night opr a few days stay is also possible. Consider a visit if you're spending a few days in Hong Kong.

Boring. Don't bother with Lantau - apart from ngong ping, there are many more interesting places to go. Lots of Chinese tourists trying to make sense of what is essentially a European housing estate close to the airport.
Lots to do. Lots to do over there... Disneyland... Nong Ping Cable Car ..Shopping Centre with discount outlets ... beach
memorable trip. A trip which takes you to an island. Must visit place is HK where you can a spend a day in the village and visit Big Buddha. Scenic beuty and greenery on the way is imposing.
Giant. This island is giant in all means. Not just because of the giant Buddha at the peak, but since it houses Chinese authentic lifestyle from fishing villages to monk's life at the temples,,,

Lantau Splendour. The trip to Lantau Island was one of the highlights of my visit to Hong Kong. I went there as part of a tour and I shall never forget the Big Buddha which was a grand piece of architecture and a tribute to Buddhism. Inside the Buddha are many displays of the history and religious elements of Buddhism which I found enlightening. Surrounding the magnificent statue are now of stone figures which compliment the Buddha and the beautiful view. I was given lunch at the monastery below - the food was generous and delightful. The whole area was so clean despite the numbers of tourists visiting the site.

Mystical Mists. Lantau Island is the perfect antidote for the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong Central district. The mists that surround the island and the cable car that transported us to see the largest outdoor sitting Buddha was magical. The island itself had a peaceful vibe.

Well worth the visit. We did a tour of the island with Grayline Tours The tour was well organised and we had a great day seeing the island even though it continued to rain most of the day. This tour included a trip to the Buddha, lunch and cable car trip. A great time and well organised.

Spend the day!. Great spot to visit on a nice day. Take the gondola - the views are amazing. Once you have climbed the stairs to see Big Budha and visted the monastery, you'll find plenty of options for lunch and some nice options for souveiners.
Lantau, Ngong Ping. Wow what a view! A step into culture the isalnd is very unspoilt we travelled by ferry and coach through the island to Ngong Ping and then cable car back a definate must do!

Worth the time. Invest in a package tour to avoid long lines and wasted time. A bit too much tourist shopping for my taste, but the Buddha and the vegetarian restaurant as well worth the hassles. Try to go on a clean day to get the best views.

Lantau Visit. Great place to get away from the crowds. Take the MTR and then visit around the area. Take the gondola across the island, visit the Big Buddha or take any of the trails for an enjoyable hike

An oasis in Hong Kong. It was a very nice change from the city side.The cable car trip is fantastic and arriving on top was a nice surprise.Big Buddha visit and the temple one were great.Nice shops in the village.Very relaxing atmosphere and resourcing place.

A must if you are in hongkong. This is a beautiful place to visit...It is recommend to take the crystal car. It's amazing to see all things pass by underneath you!Takes you a good half hour to reach lantau. Once there its not tough to spend time.The atmosphere is serene..with the monastery and the big buddha statue...But you need atleast half a day to cover this.Worth a visit for sure

Lantau iceland. you cannot visit Hong Kong without going to Lantau Island. Try the traditional Hakken glutinous rice balls, both savory and sweet. we took a cable car ride to Ngong Ping 360 Village to view The Big Buddha.We really enjoyed the spectacular views along our cable car ride

Must visit. A full day excursion. A must visit. The Ngong ping cable car is one of the best in the world. A glass bottom would also make this 20 minutes ride awesome The giant buddha is one of its kind. It will make you feel as if you have achieved nirvana. Po Lin monastery is very serene. One of the five temples has 10,000 buddha statues which is the best. Walk of Faith is a 15 minute walk from Po Lin monastery and its a must do. Extremely peaceful and out of the world.

Cool place with tasty food!!!. Traveling to this island is a whole day affair. Make sure to take a walk up to the Big Buddha to get some close-ups. Also, you can talk a walk around the area to the (infinity pillar) walk which takes you through an abandoned village. And the best of all, get a veggie meal from the outside area in the monastery. Best veggie food ever (even for a meat eater)!
amazing. Amazing views, get the glass bottom cable cart if you can afford it, excellent views from the top and on the ride up there.

Ngong Ping 360 View. This is just one of the ultimate sky-land-sea adventure I made in HK. For 360hkd my partner and I enjoyed the nature of Lantau Island. This package includes standard ride for cable car (long ride aroung 20 mins I guess), big budha service bus, boat ride to see white dolphin, 20hkd gift certificate. One suggestion if you'd like to try the Ngong ping adventure and if you are in a budget, you may avail 180hkd standard cable car ride, plus you may also visit the big budha you just need to walk a little and just buy a bus ticket for 18hkd for a ride going to other tourist spot. I don't recommend the sea adventure to see the white dolphin because it's rare to see them. Gladly that we saw them by far when we went their. Overall it was a great experience.

Great Buddha. Must visit! Worth travelling Crystal class on the Cable car as it adds to the experience.Allow not less than half a day to visit this site as the shopping percent outside the Gates is worth a browse. Enjoyed the Tea ceremony, very relaxing. Would do it again.

Lantau via Ngong Ping 360. Been to Lantau Island via Ngong Ping 360 tour package. Hence we have been only to Po Lin monastery and the Big Buddha statue. Got an amazing view of the airport and Lantau Peak from cable car. Monastery was an excellent experience with its calm and serene environment.

Lantau Island. I really enjoyed my visit here, the weather was great & the views from the budda are amazing. The walk up to see the temple can be a struggle for the elderly but worth the trip. No photography is aloud inside & they are strict with this rule so please don't forget.

Great trip up in cable car with stunning views. We opted for just the basic cable car return, not the crystal glass bottomed one. Glad as the view below was not something you couldn't see looking out the windows anyway and was just trees and paths. Fantastic views though. Didn't do any of the other packages and did not feel we missed out on anything.Thoroughly enjoyed the trip and would recommend it.

Best on a sunny clear day. very interesting place but on our day ( Nov ) shrouded in mist Couldnt get to Buddha due to a medical condition which was a disappointment .Ok at most levels but higher reaches and especially on cable car saw nothing. Great view over Hong Kong Airport if your a plane spotter

The Size Of The Buddha and the Statues are Amazing. The beautiful Statues you see here are mighty and so amazing just a wondrous place to be what can I saw the whole place is so inspiring I have been four times already since 2009 up until 2013 and I am about to go again in November I just Love Hong Kong
Great place. Great place, great views, lots to do. Quite touristy. Aim to go when it's raining so less people. Restaurants smelled good. Hikes looked challenging but doable. Day very well spent!
Cable car ride to Lantau. Lantau Island itself is very commercial and the Buddah itself is modern. The cable car ride there make it worth going. It must be the longest cable car ride.

Lantau Peak. Magnificent view of the huge Buddha and the surrounding scenery, but the weather was very sunny and humid during the July period. Generally enjoy cable car ride. Sense of satisfaction after climbing the long flight of steps to reach the huge Buddha,
A good day's trip. A day well spent. Used Tram to reach there. Visited old Monastery and Big Buddha. There is something for everyone as it has a modern village
Perfect Saturday in HK. Great beaches, beach cafes and sights to see. When the weather is good - which isn't always in HK - this is a perfect way to spend a Saturday.

Lantau island - Well worth a visit. I travelled independently to Lantau Island and would recommend it as a place for a visit. It was very east to get to by MTR, you will need change to buy a ticket at the machine but this is very easy to do. Then I choose to access the village by cable car. I had to queue for quite some time for a ticket so it is worth booking in advance. Then at the top, the village has plenty of eating places and you can walk to the Po Lin Monastery, which was fascinating, and the Big Buddha statue. Be aware there are a lot of steps to climb to get to the base of the statue though the views from there are worth it!

Enjoyable visit. We reached at about 1pm on a Sunday and the queues were about 2+ hour long. We decided to get a private cable car as that would have allowed us to skip the queues. It was an expensive option but we had no regrets doing it as we saved a lot of time(considering that the queues when we were leaving was incredibly long as well). This island is wonderful. The views from the cable car was great and at one point you'd be able to watch planes flying off. I loved the Po Lin monastery and the big buddha. We skipped out on the village cause it was a really hot day and we didn't want to be out for too long but we would definitely head there the next time we are back.A great way to spend half a day out.

Blissfull Place!!!. This is a huge island near hong kong city. Just about 1/2 hr drive from the airport. Home to the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. Wonderful place to escape the hustle n bustle from the city.

So much to do here. I spent the day here. First Pink /dolphin watching, then the ngong Ping cable car ride. Long queues but get tickets in advance to save a lot of waiting time. I ended up in the fishing village and looking out of the buses window ride back to the metro, I passed some wonderful beaches namely, Sandy Bay not sure if this is a private beach?
Lantau island.. Family friendly. Very devine and peaceful. A must visit in Hkg. Spend half a day there , finish all your prayers.

Plenty of things to do. Take the cable car with a glass floor, the views are stunning. Book in advance on the web so you jump the lines. Visit the Budha.We then took a bus to Tai O, but check the timetable because they are not frequent. For HKD 25 a person we took the boat tour and saw the pink dolphins.The another VERY long bus ride to Mai Wo, a lively town with plenty of drinking dining options, and a 30 minute ferry ride back to Central
Big Budda. Enjoyable cable car ride from MTR station to the temple. Very busy in the morning, maybe go later in the day. very hot too! photogenic place
wow what an island. Wow what an island we visited all and enjoyed them all . quick ferry crossing , cheap and always on time . Great restaurants and all food was great

You must Go to see the Big Buddha here. Went there to see the Big Buddha and had the time of my life. The tip is a must do. Go early and plan all day there. Take the cable cars and you must get a glass bottom. It's worth the extra $. This is a must do trip if you go to HK.

Big Buddha. We had a great day on the Ngong Ping aerial cable car to Lantau to see the Big Buddha. Beautiful views on the tram and amazing first look at the Buddha. The village up there has plenty of eating places, souvenier shops play area for children. The manicured gardens lovely. I personally couldn't walk up the steps to the Buddha but my husband and girfriend did. Both exhausted especially later but glad they did it. The temples were ornate. We checked our luggage at the airport and caught the local bus to the tram. There was well over an hour wait but if you opt for the Crystal tour you go in the glass bottom trams and go on pretty much straight away. For the few extra $'s this was truly worth it.

Visit an outlying Island when in Hong Kong - there are 235. Around Hong Kong there are more than 235 outlying islands. Many uninhabited or home to small communities but Lantau is one of the major islands. It is full of fascinating contrasts and worth setting aside a half day visit. Start your exploration at the Outlying Islands Ferry Piers in front of the IFC and catch one of the cheap and reasonable priced ferries used by the islanders.The Lantau ferry departs from Central Pier 6 every half hour from early morning to late at night to Mui Wo (Silvermine Bay) from where you can catch buses if required to all parts of the island.Lantau is still tranquil despite the additions of the Hong Kong International Airport or Hong Kong Disneyland, so do not be put off as half the island is protected parkland. Hikers amongst you there is a 43 mile circular trail! Beach lovers there is the beautiful white sands Cheung Sha Beach, so take the No 2 bus or a taxi. The island is noted for its famous and world's tallest bronze statue of Buddha - 73ft (23m) Tian Tan Buddha. This can be reached by bus from Mui Wo or the Ngong Ping cable car. In other words, there should be something on the island for everyone and it is such a contrast to life in Hong Kong - try it.

A beautiful island.... you cannot visit Hong Kong without going to Lantau Island! There you you have the big buddha, amazing hikes, camping places by the beach and a huge outlet mall. Take two or three days to visit this island.. you won't regret it!

Worth a visit.. We stayed on Lantau Island for 3 weeks, the beaches are stunning, the people very friendly & the back drop spectacular. There is a fantastic Seafood court in Mui Wo & a great pub 'The China Bear'. The feral Water Buffalo wandering the roads & beaches give a definite feel of being in the wilderness & the Island can be easily reached by the frequent Ferries. There's lots to do & places to visit. The fishing village of Tai O makes for an interesting visit, the Buddah is spectacular & of course there's Disneyland too!

a place you can spend more than one day. Tai O allows you to see Hong Kong from a diferent perspective, known as Venice of the Orient. Clean and well-maintained traditional houses in the sea are homes of the fishermen. Some of them also serve as shops and stores. Try the traditional Hakken glutinous rice balls, both savory and sweet. Look at how shrimp paste is made though you may find the smell too strong. Go up to the old police station, which is now a hotel for an afternoon tea for relaxation and for a taste of history.

Dont miss going out to the island if you are in Hong Kong. incredible island where you feel like you are in the middle of nowhere except you are 20 minutes from the madness of Hong Kong (except for the airport is there). We took the cable car and it is incredible. The views are magnificent. Well worth it. You could easily spend an entire day here, hiking about and riding gondola.

Escape from Shopping. We visited the island to see the Buddha - it was a hot day so sun screen and comfy walking shoes required. The Buddha is really huge and worth the trip. We went by ferry and then bus (no 2). This all took a while. Our return trip was by cable car (expensive but fun) followed by train (MTR). We also paid to see the Buddha from the inside - interesting but not that exciting. The ticket gets you some water and an ice-cream for no extra charge. Great views from the top of the Buddha.The 250 steps down led us to the Temple which was in the process of being built or refurbished. Really impressive complex which I think serves as a monastery and a seminary.
Visitor. Good seafood and great scenery. Lovely walk about and experience some fresh air which is not common in HK

Hiking and can. I love Lantau island as there are more natural beauties. If you only have 10 hours transit in Hong Kong instead of going into Hong Kong island, it is more relax to stay in Lantau island at the airport. You can take bus or cable carts to big Buddha,but if you want to take cart be sure to go early! As it can get really busy! You can take bus from the airport to ting Chung about 15min. Then either take cable cart or bus from there! And in tung Chung there are places to shop and eat.

Absolutely wonderful!!. The trip to Lantau Island may require some travel depending on where you are coming from. For us, we took the Star ferry and then caught a bus. On the return we took the cable car and then the train...it was easy and directions were clear and everyone spoke English and helped us when we asked! Lantau Island is twice the size of Hong Kong and much less developed. The islands seclusion has made it a popular place for religious retreats. We visited the Island to explore the place of the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery( in separate reviews). The Hong Kong Disneyland is also on this island.There is a lovely little area with shops and eateries as you walk to get the cable car. The cable car gives you some terrific views of the area. The only costs you will have are for your transportation to and from the island.

A day trip of mountain view, big buddha and fishing village. We really enjoyed a day out to Lantau island. Start the trip with cable car, enjoyed the Big Buddha on top of the hill, then take the bus to Tai O fishing village. There's also a decent beach on the way, but we're running out of time and didn't stop by. If you decide to take the cable car, the wisest option is to book online the ticket. Trust me, it will save you at least an hour of waiting.
Ngo Ping 360 - Citygates mall. We can shop for very cheap price in citygates mall, and enjoy the beautiful natural scenery using ngoping 360 cable car
Most amazing Place to visit during Hong kong tour. one of the must seen heritage place of Hong Kong, most amazing view, full of nature and awesome place to visit!

Great Memories. You can catch the bus which is windy up the road and made me feel sick or go by ferry this takes longer but is more relaxing if you have the time. If you are going to eat there pay the extra for the better Restaurant as the soup can look like some ones old sock water. Views are fantastic and its worth the walk past the old English Tea Garden, once used as a Youth Hostel, now derelict. Keep an eye out for an overgrown roller skating rink of concrete with a metal pipe fence, should bring a smile. the view from the Hill walk looking towards the Dam is lovely. The Buddhist Temple is beautiful and its very satisfying lighting incense sticks even if it takes some time. choose the toilets that are new looking as the old ones are foot prints and no toilet paper. But when you travel its always advisable to have tissues always on hand. Also take bottled water as the weather can be hot. I was here in 1976, with my husband, 20 years later for my daughter's 18 birthday and 20 years on I was there with my granddaughter aged 12. I have a photo at the monastery for every visit, which makes me very nostalgic. Lovely place.

Must do N1 in HK !. Great trip to lantau Island ! We visited the big buddha and was fabolous ! It is gigantic! Prepare yourself well for a 3-4 hours of walk and bring water !Cost is around 180 $HK around 25USD by cable cab from tung chung station (blue Line).
Must Go. You will get amazed of wht humans can do and how beatiful it can be when we put our minds into it. Visit it and also enjoy the sky using the Ngong Ping 360.
Take the glass cable car - worth it!. We had taken the Glass cable car to visit the Lantau Island. It was a great experience! Lantau itself is beautiful and must visit while visiting Hong Kong.
Take the Cable Car to get there. take the cable car and go early . it can get very crowded especially at the weekend. had a very nice half day there.

Nice place to hike. This part of HK is so different to the rest of what tourists normally associate with HK - the shopping, eating and nightlife. If you are a nature lover, Lantau have some really great hiking trails - my favorite being the hike up to the Lantau Bhudda! The trail is long, it took me about 5 hours to get to the top but it was on an extremely hot day with little cover so I had to walk quite slowly. I think on a cooler day you can probaly cut an hour or 1.5 hrs off depending on your level of fitness, it is very steep in parts. Make sure you take plenty of water if you decide to walk this. Sunscreen and some food would help too!Once get up to the top you can go and visit the big Bhudda and walk through the little village they have built up there then catch the gondola back down :)

Terror in the skies! Or in the queue... but worth it!. Lantau Island is absolutely wonderful - however you need to brave the cable car to get up there! It's a steep climb and was fairly windy on the day we made the trip - let's just say that watching the car in front of us swinging at an angle in the breeze did not go down too well with all the occupants in our carriage. But of course it was perfectly fine and absolutely worth it as the views from Lantau Island are spectacular. The Big Buddha is absolutely majestic, sitting peacefully on the mountain watching over Hong Kong. There are a lot of little shops, restaurants and cafes in the village when you get up there - it's a little touristy but also handy to be able to grab a drink or quick bite to eat.The biggest tip would be to look at pre-booking a ticket for the cable car as the queues are HUGE, maybe that it just a weekend thing (we went on a Sunday). Luckily we had time on our side but we were waiting around for ages (well over an hour on the way up and about 45 minutes to get down again) - it seemed that some groups were with an "agent" and were able to bypass the exceptionally long queues so if we went again we would definitely pay a bit extra for that convenience.

Shifu Wong. Arrived at Tung Chung Terminal by MTR Subway, we took a cable car ride to Ngong Ping 360 Village to view The Big Buddha.We really enjoyed the spectacular views along our cable care ride.360 Double Cable Car is the longest cable in Asia Countries.It takes about 25 minits to reach Ngong Ping Village which you can experience with fabulous food and fun shopping at Ngong Ping Village!

Good day. We went on organised tour, starting with a feet from Hong Kong which takes 30 minutes. We went to a beach and then Tao O village to go on boat to see stilted homes.We went o Buddha site which was spectacular and had a veggie lunch in the monastery.We walked through the village to the cable car ride, plenty of shopping in the village. Great views from the cable car before returning to hotel in Kowloon by coach
A Glimpse of History. Go there when the weather is overcast to take very good pictures and start early as possible to maximize everything. There is so much in there that is worth the time.

Getaway from the hustle and bustle of the city. We took the Ngong Ping 360 to Lantau, it is a beautiful ride over the valleys and mountains of Lantau. The views from the rope-way ride are amazing, one can see the Airport too. Right at the end one can catch a glimpse of the Tia Tan Buddha. The walk from the rope-way to the Po Lin monastery can bring about Zen like calm, the buddhist chants playing all along the path add to the experience. It is a great place to spend half a day. Plenty of eating joints along the way.Book tickets for Ngong Ping 360 online to beat the winding queue of tourists. Warning the place gets crowded in the afternoon.

Worth the trip!. We visited Lantau Island to ride the Ngong Ping 360 cable cars and to see the Big Buddha. We started the day with a ride on the Star Ferry, then went up to Victoria's Peak, before heading to Lantau. We thought it was worth the 40 or so minute subway ride!For the cable car, we did the glass bottom, because that one had a shorter line. On the way to the island, they filled the car to maximum capacity (8 passengers, I believe) but on the way back, the two of us had our own cable car. The views are spectacular. Is it worth the extra money for the glass bottom? Maybe if that was the only benefit, I would say "no". But, since the glass bottom cars had shorter wait times, then it was completely worth it!We walked to the Big Buddha and took some great pictures before heading back. It was sunny and extremely hot that day, so we decided to leave after seeing the Big Buddha.

Great Day Out. Our family of 4 (two teenagers) agreed this this was our best day during our time based in Hong Kong. We booked tickets via the Red Bus tour company and this was great as we went straight to the front of the queue for the cable car and had glass bottomed cabins. The cable car ride was about 25 mins and this is an experience in itself. We had a coach tour to a fishing village including a boat ride which took us out into the harbour to find dolphins as well as round the village itself and then a coach to the Big Buddha. There is a small shopping village but nothing too cheesy or commercial. You can travel around independently and book your own boat, taxi, etc but the queues were pretty bad so pre-booking seems to be the way to go.
One of the thing to see at Hong Kong. Something about one our distance from Hong-Kong, but easy to access. And if you are lucky to use the Ngong Ping 300 to arrive at Tian Tan Buddha
Relax. A place for relaxation by getting out for a while in the busy district life. Surrounded by greenery and nice scenery, worth going

A great way to spend the day. Took my thirteen year old daughter on the greyline tour. We both really enjoyed it. Did the cable cars up to the big Buddha, vegetarian lunch was served by monks, saw fishing village and very short boat ride to look for dolphins. As I expected we didn't see any, but it was a nice ride. My teen told me I made a great choice for a tour which was high praise.
Ospreys. Walking from 1 side of island to other is very rewarding for the views you get, on the day we did it the Ospreys gave us a great airial display

nothing special.....boring? then you may want to try.. if you are really boring in Hong Kong, this may be a place to go. I am not impressed by the bug statue, but I just liked the cable car ride, world #2 I guess. Nothing special....

A village so beautiful. It was greenery filled beautiful place. The cable car view of this island this breath taking. There are shops for travelers. I went during the summer time & so it was too hot to walk around a lot.
Finally Here!. Finally made it here after seeing most of my friends and their photos on FB. This place is beautiful. The cable car ride was good. The BUddha was spectacular. It is a fun time.

Great trails, Buddha, Tai O. Spend a day, suggested itinerary belowFerry from Central to Mui Wo, takes 30mins to 1 hr depending on whether fast boat or slow boat. Then take a bus to Nan Shan Campsite, it's only a few stops from the ferry terminal. There is a great trail from Nan Shan Campsite to Tai Tung Shan, 2-3 hours, very nice views, no shades though, so bring water and don't do it in summer unless you are really fit for it (risk of heatstroke). The first half is mostly up but not steep, so you do not have to be very fit to do it, can pace yourself. About the middle there are some stone huts, apparently some locals lived there during WWII, and if you know the right people, you can get keys to the huts and camp out there: I've seen a westerner family there on one hike, kids and all, the views are unbeatable, but it's rough, you have to bring water and everything. The second half is mostly down and steep steps so would be a problem if you have bad knees (bring walking sticks). The trail finishes at the road, where you can take a bus to Tai O: buses are not too frequent so expect to wait a bit (15 mins). Tai O is interesting: like a shabby version of Venice I guess, instead of palaces you get shabby huts on stilts and the water can get quite smelly depends on the tide. Some small local restaurants where you can get seafood, nothing spectacular but you've got to eat something right.The other must do in Lantau is the Buddha, a world-class sight. Another trail you can do is hike to the Buddha: take MTR to Tung Chung, you need to figure out how to get from MTR station to the start of the trail, it's 10-15 mins through some housing estate. The trail was built for transporting construction materials when then build the cable car (I was told they use donkeys, like in Santorini?), so the trail actually follows the path of the cable car. The best part is towards the end whether you catch glimpses of the Buddha.

Awesome view!. I been there few weeks back. Staying for almost 12 days in honking just to discover and see in real cool places like lantau. It was a great experience for me to climb more than hundreds steps going up to big Buddha.View from up was so breathtaking you can see all island which is nature.A small village also for shopping and dining.Thank you hongkong for the great experience!

Getting over there via crystal cable car was exciting and seeing how far we were from the ground was amazing.. I would suggest prebooking the tickets it's faster to get onto the cable car especially on a very hot day,it cuts the waiting time
Nature & Heritage. great experience , in the top things must to do in HK, I think longest cable car in the world or at least in asia, you will enjoy the trip.
Nice. Shopping not as good as Hong Kong but far less crowded. Recommennd the ferry ride to Tai O past the new freeway being built to Macao. Cable car to big buddah.
Aiport and Disneyland. Lantau island is the island where airport and disneyland located. there are some historical attraction and the trams for tourists.

Lovely half day trip. Lantau island is a fantastic destination in the Hong Kong area. We explored it for half a day when we were recently in Hong and area. The Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery and gardens as well as the Wisdom Path and all the shops in the area are the places we were able to check out during our visit. The next time we are in the area we would like to check out the beaches that we saw in the distance as we are big beach fans.Lantau Island is affordable, accessible and good for a half day visit but remember that thousands of other tourists have the same idea as you so it can get pretty busy especially in the afternoons so plan to get there early.

Worth more than a fleeting visit. Unfortunately due to time constraints and the huge queues on the cable car I did not do the area much justice. The temples need more than a fleeting visit. The sings outside the temples are quite confusing, on one hand it says"no visitors" and then another sign asks for donations. There's also a "No Photo" sign but tourists were able to go into the temple and take photos within full view of security. The fishing village and sea excursion were awesome.

Must do. Loved this place. We went on a rainy day so lots of fog and felt like walking in the clouds. There is a vegetarian restaurant operated by the monastery and a must try,amazing snacks. Its a nice half day visit

Nice beach.. I was stunned when the ferry pulled into Lantau. It was like pulling up to an island in Australia. Obviously this is the place where a lot of expats live. We had an average lunch there and a quick look around. The beach looked nice. Unfortunately we didn't have a chance to explore the other side of the island which I understand is quite traditional and worth a visit.

Must see attraction with the kids. If Disneyland is not your thing, Lantau Island is the place to hit with your kids. You are taken up to Ngong Ping via cable carriages (enclosed.. if you're scared of heights make sure you don't get the one with the plexiglass seethrough floor) and truly get to see the beauty and hiking paths leading up.Tourist village is quite entertaining and convenient if you have kids to feed but there is also a food service at the monastery. From there you can either take the steps up to Lantau Buddha statue or take many hike paths along the island.Bring plenty of water, sun screen lotion and an umbrella because the sun is brutal.

Buy Online ticket is better because no need have long queue. Going to this Place Ngong Ping Village for Big Giant Budha Statue, take the cable car from Tung Chung Station. Better buy the ticket online from many agent offer at the internet. Because no need to long queue up, it has special counter for redeem the online voucher. If in peak holiday can queue up until morethan 1 hour!If have excess budget can try crystal cabin, have the special line for queue and it less people there.

so much to see and do on the island. lantau island has so much i don't know where to start.. the fishing village is amazing at sunset - we caught the bus.. although the bus took ages to get back to tung chung train station and the time was about a 2 hour wait !! but worth it... the big buddha is also awesome.. the discount outlet shopping centre just near the Tung Chung station is also def worth a look, lots of sporting brands and a big supermarket at the basement.

Love the Big Buddha. We did a tour to the Big Buddha through our hotel. It was excellent. It included a trip on the cable car - be warned if you're scared of heights - it's very high! But it was a great experience. The Big Buddha statue is amazing. Lots of stairs to climb but definitely worth it. You can get some amazing photos.
Wonderful place!. We did the Lantau Island Day Tour. Great value for money with a very nice vegetarian lunch. The Buddha is amazing.

A Nice Place..... Once an unspoiled island, this is a great place to visit when you are in Hong Kong. From the Big Buddha to the Tung Chung shopping district, Lantau has lots to offer. Easily accessible by the metro line MRT or bus, you can spend a few days discovering all the things that it has to offer. You should visit the Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery, Disneyland and if you want to do some shopping, Tung Chung has a lot of bargains as well. A great place for sure....

Beautiful place, nice change from the city. Lantau Island is a largely unspoiled island just west of Hong Kong city. It is home to quaint traditional fishing villages, and the Giant Buddha. The Giant Buddha is very striking, and you will get some good photos not just of the statue, but of the countryside surrounding it. You cannot photograph inside as it homes a sacred relic. Also on the island is the Lin Po monastery, which serves lovely vegetarian meals. There is also an outlet shopping mall near the monastery, and a cable car with great views.

Nice day 1/2 day tour around 8 hours at slow pace. We took the tram 1 way up lantau island catch it by the hotel Novtol City Gate { short walk}. Walked around.took pictures. Than on the way down took local bus {very cheap}. Found and took MTR to Kawloon walked some, ate something and took Mtr back to our hotel.

Worth the trip. Really enjoyed our experience the morning we went to Lantau Island. Caught the MTR from Wan Chai and then the cable car. Being summer you need to expect crowds and waiting in lines but these did move quite quickly and they do have fans and the odd air con to keep you coolish ( as comfortable as it is possible on a 32deg day with thousands of other travellers). Be prepared to walk heaps to get to the stairs that take you to the buddha and the I think I counted 260 stairs to the top.

Take the time to visit the island. The condol service from Tung Chung to the Big Budha was nice and relaxing. You can choose between 2 different cabines. one with glass floor and one without. We had the first one, however rather pricey. You can have almost the same views without too, Visit the Big Buddha and then take a bus to Mui Wo (runs every 30 min) and come back to HK with a ferry. And stop in the meanwhile in some other sights when keen. The beaches have some big waves so Stanley is a much better option for a nice swim. And Stanley has also showers which Lantau does not provide so much. So Lantau is mainly nice to see from the cable car, visit the Buddha and come back with a ferry. Kids probably like the Disneyland too.

Lantau Island - add to your visit in Hong Kong. Lantau Island is full of surprises. Do make the effort to get to Tai O fishing village. Very different to the hustle and bustle of high rises!The ride on the cable cars up to the Big Buddha is money well spent. There are plenty of places to eat and drink - and to find souvenirs. Clean toilets a plus.
Away from the bustle. A good side trip away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Catch a ferry from Kowloon or the Island and spend the morning, or the whole day walking around the island.
OK. Yeah, we did Disneyland, OK but not mindblowing, it is easy to get there using the MTR. Quite a number of attractions were closed for renovation.

Worth a visit if you have 2 days in HK. HK is a fairly small, so if you have two days, you can spend one day on the main island and one day on Lantau. The most efficient and fun way to explore the island, in my opinion, is to do a day tour. You will be able to take the cable car to Po Lin Monastery, view the stilt houses by boat and explore the fishing village. I took the one day tour with Grayline Tours and felt satisfied that I was able to view all that I wanted to see on the Island, which is fairly small in size and population. If you are limited on time and can't view all the attractions, the cable car is definitely a must as the view is quite spectacular. However, the line is long if you are not with a tour group.
Must visit. If you have time, you must visit Lantau Island on your visit to HK. It's a very interesting trip to get there and the views are astounding.

A Must See tour. Lantau Island is a beatiful place to visit. We took the tour and it was very memorable place. The tour included a vegitarian meal which was absolutely delicious and fresh. All the meals were produce on the Lantau Island. We also visit a statue of one of the biggest monks I have even seen. Its a must see.
Place of Peace. If there is a bit of peace and quiet you wish to have away from the shopping and touring, this is the place to go. It is easy to get to on rapid transit and very nice.

must go. the best was the crystal cabin, you should go to lantau island by crystal cabin as it is made of glass all around and the bottom too is made of glass. the view from the bottom of the cabin is amazing with forests, mountains and waterfalls, superrrrb

worth seeing. Easy to access from Kong Kong due to efficient transport system. Bought tickets before hand, huge queue in oppressive heat . Waited for over an hour before we could get on cable car, those without tickets waited longer. 15 minuet cable car ride with great views. Usual tourist shops /cafes at top. Big buddha impressive, not for those with poor mobility as many steps to climb to reach Buddha, however great views from bottom of steps also. Worth seeing if in Hong Kong. Go early. when we came down from cable car at about 1pm queues were even longer. The humidty is high so not comfortable to stand in long lines waiting

Worth a Visit - A Different HK. The island features various attractions: a cable care from Tung Chung with stunning views, the Big Buddha statue, the monastry next to it, numerous fishermens' villages, beaches and park trails. There are two main ways to get to the island: MTR to Tung Chung station and a ferry from Central to Discovery Bay or Mui Wo.It is a good idea to combine between the two from and two the island. Both ways take ~45 minutes. The island itself is well served by NLB, a network of busses inside the island and the daily pass is quite cheap. I made a mistake and bought two-ways ticket on the cable car - and I didn't use the returning ticket but used busses instead.In the Tai O village, it is worth taking a short boat ride, even if you won't see those pink dolphins - it is still very nice.

A large hilly island, most of which is still undeveloped.. One of our favourite trips is to catch a ferry from Hong Kong Central to Mui Wo (Silvermine Bay).From there it is possible to take a bus ride to various parts of Lantau Island.We usually catch a 3M to Tung Chung. This takes a fascinating trip around tight corners and up and down several hills. Very little of the quite lengthy journey has much in the way of human development, but instead beautiful vies over jungle, seascape and mountains.

Lautau Island the beauty of the mantouch nature Giant bronze Buddha statue.. It was the excellence experiment to visit the beautiful Lautau Island. We took the train from Kowloon Central Station to Tung Chung Station. We got some waters and pastries before heading to the Island to save some cost for lunch, it was expensive food there. The Christal Cable car worthy to ride you can see the bottom glass floor of the car when it is crossing the ocean scene. The journey with an impressive cultural themed village and easy access to the Tian Tan Buddha Statue, the world's largest, seated, outdoor, bronze Buddha statue.

Beautiful Buddha!. The trip takes about two hours from Hong kong/Kowloon area but worth it. The monastery is beautiful and the Buddha is amazing! The cable cars do not work if there are high winds etc but a bus is available to reach there.
Loved the contrast of the island. exciting contrasts between the old and the new, rich exclusive shopping and poor street markets. I personally preferred the street markets and it's population.

A nice place to relax outside of the city. It is easy to get to on the MTR and offers a change of pace from the city. There are some places to shop and get some A/C before/after you go up to the big buddha.

Ngong PING 360. Its a great place to go and visit the huge buddha statue , Scenic beauty is awesome and its been a great ride to this island... Negative aspect is the shopping in this area is very expensive and is very highly priced.. Although there are some beautiful displays which are unique and can be in the list of must buy... Some more improvements in directions, signages will add more defination to this place

Easy to get to - worlds different. I have been there a few times, mostly to take the cable car to see the Big Buddha. There is a small touristy village at the top of the cable car, as well as a temple. It's pretty secluded - you can't believe you are in Hong Kong.Make sure the cable car is running. One time we got there and had to take a bus to the Buddha. That sucked. It took 3x as long, and it's not a relaxing drive.There are also shopping areas and small fishing villages to visit on the Island.It's easily accessible via the MTR.

Beautiful lush mountains. What was most surprising about Lantau was the fact it is so close to Hong Kong, yet it felt like you were in the middle of a forest. Really beautiful place. Be sure to take the Ngong Ping 360 to get to the Buddha.

wonderfully tranquil. went to see the big buddha and the monastary. because of bad weather the cable cars were closed, but it is still a great day trip - a must see and easily reached via the MTR and bus/cable car.

Wonderful. Getting the cable car across was amazing. We could see people walking across the island but didn't fancy it ourselves in the heat. Climbing the stairs to the big buddha was enough! It looked stunning against a beautiful blue sky.

Super visit. Lantau used to be a sleepy, by ferry only, island with the bid budda. Now with the airport and bridges this is easier to get to. Budda is a must and the cable run from the airport side is worth the trip for the long trek and view.

Lots to do on Lantau Island even between flights. If you have 4 hours or more, you can catch the S1 bus from the HK airport to Tung Chung, then buy a bus ticket to the Big Buddha. Buy a combination ticket to go to the Big Buddha and lunch (buy the better lunch as the cheaper one is not great) at the Po Lin Monastery. Then walk through to Ngong Ping and take the cable car back to Tung Chung and the S2 bus back to the airport. A nice diversion rather than sit in the airport!

Nice and refreshing. We went here in the morning and were pleasantly surprised. Although people would suggest you to take the np360 cable car but the new lantau public bus journey to the top near big Buddha is a great option too. The drive up has good views, the bus is comfortable and not crowded at all and its significantly cheaper. There are beach stops on the way and if you have time you can halt at one of these beaches which are pretty secluded. A good half a day out. The np village at the top has a nice vibe to it as well. Although it's just a lane but it has various kinds of shops and eateries up there.
Lantau. Basically Hong Kong is divided into three islands-Hong Kong, Lantau and Kowloon. Lantau Island have many attractions like Disneyland, Huge Buddha, Beaches and airport.

Before your plane takes you back home.... ...Lantau's the perfect place to spend a few hours. Leave your luggage at the airport and head for the cable car to the mountain top. The big Buddha statue is amazing, also the views from the top! After being back on the ground there are quite some restaurants to eat before going back to the airport. It's a suburb of Hong Kong where lots of people live due to more affordably rental prices. So you can experience the real Hong Kong life. We even talked two really interesting business travellers (Germans) at the table next to us... Our plane left late in the evening, and we could have stayed longer...

A MULTI-ACTIVITY TOUR. Its a hotel pickup & drop full day tour.See Cable Hanged Bridge, which is probably the biggest in the region.Visit Tai O fishing village and see traditional style of living of a common resident of the area. You can buy dried fishes etc.Visit Big or Giant Buddha. You will have to take several steps to reach the top, but its worth. Weather up there is simply GREAT!Take Ngong Ping Cable Car ride down the hill. Its a 25 minute ride, and is very scenic. Hong Kong International Airport is seen best from the cable car.Back to hotel by coach.

3 hours in Ngong Ping. It was a quick tour as I was in Hong Kong for a business trip, I arrived in Tung Chung Mall.Rolled my hand carry and up to Ngong Ping 360 for a ride. I love the place. Went up to see the Grand Buddha and to the Temple of 10 thousand buddha. Bought small souvenirs at a shop in Ngong Ping.Don't forget to wear sneakers, sunblocks, or hat. Bring water to drink as well it's a long hike.
A great day trip from downtoan Hongkong!. A great day trip from downtoan Hongkong! Visit the Buddha, forts, Tai O fishing village and the disney land hongkong.

Very Scenic Cable Car Ride. We had previously done a day tour to Lantau Island but missed out on the Cable Car ride due to it being off line for maintenance. So on our return trip to Hong Kong we were keen to do the Cable Car from Tung Chung to Lantau Island.We booked our tickets on line before we left and were glad we did as even by 10am on a weekday there was a substantial line up for tickets and we were able to skip that queue. We also booked a Crystal Cabin which has the glass bottom and really added to the Cable Car experience. Even though when booking on line you specify a time, basically you just line up in the Crystal Cabin queue when you get there and they fill the cars as they come past.The views from the Cable Car ride are spectacular and the ride goes for around 25 minutes or so. You pass over the water and lush greenery with stunning views of the nearby airport, Tung Chung and Lantau Island.We didn't venture far once on Lantau Island having done most of the attractions there before, but we did enjoy some shopping in the small Ngong Ping village area before the return Cable Car trip. For our return trip we had a Crystal Cabin all to ourselves which made the experience even better, since we could freely move around and take photographs. Once we got back to Tung Chung we could not believe how long the queues for both tickets and for boarding the actual Cable Cars were, I'd suggest book online and go early to avoid the queues.
Must Do Cable Car Ride.... One of the best experience for cable car with amazing scenic view. Amazingly long cable ride with lovely view. If in Hong Kong do visit.
Love it!. I love this place - the experience of getting the cable car up there, the views, the theme park style row of shops and restaurants, the Buddha and the monastery - stunning place, I love it.

Lantau - why not. Chair lift trip out is an experience in itself. The island itself is bit touristy but still enjoyable. Climb up to the Buddha but inside is so-so. Eat some roast corn and definitely have a tea experience at the tea rooms before you go home - relaxing and informative.

Awesome place to vist and a great cable car ride :). I had my reservations about coming here after seeing the size of the queue to the cable car, the whole time my friend was moaning about the size of it and wanted to go elsewhere. I am glad I waited, because it was probably one of the best places I have seen in Hong Kong. The cable car was amazing. We selected the glass car. We could see the water below us. I loved the chopstick gallery shop here as well as the template. What I found interesting is that if you went to the meal area and specified a vegetarian option, you where given a plate of noodles and donuts. A healthy choice to be sure.A few things to note. My friend was taking pictures of the statues, which caused offense, but they didn't make a big issue of it. There are signs posted all over about not taking pictures in certain areas, so there is no excuse for being ignorant.
Must see in Hong Kong. Incredibly beautiful. This is a must see for travellers in Hong Kong just be prepared for the steps up to the big Buddha!

Main things to do are all around Ngong Ping village. Pretty island, most attractions (except disneyland) are around the Ngong Ping village. Tai O village isn't really all that fantastic and there's nothing much to do there so it's not worth to travel out far from the Ngong Ping village to go to Tai O.

cable car was awesome. Cable car was great, there are 2 different kinds one is a standard floor and the other is crystal clear floor its worth paying the extra hk$100 for it. Recommend to everyone who wants to get out of the city.

Big Buddha is awesome!. Catching the cable car with views of the island and HK airport are pretty impressive. Watching those walk up to the top even more so! The Big Buddha is awesome - yet more steps which were hard going on a very hot day! Recommend paying HK$38 which included a visit inside the Buddha and free ice cream and cold water at the end - well worth it! The view is great. Then did a bus trip to Tai O (on the number 21 bus). Interesting part of the island with traditional stilt houses. Went on a 'boat' around the harbour and out into the bay. Must have been our lucky day, because we saw some of the incredibly rare pink dolphins, swimming amongst the hoards of rubbish in the bay. Worth a look but would be a beautiful little spot if only there was less rubbish around!

Welcome contrast to busy Hong Kong.. Lantau Island was a welcome respite from busy, crowded Hong Kong. We rode the gondola/cable car to our destination, and the climb up to view the world's largest seated Buddha was an amazing experience. The adjacent monastery offered a quiet space for meditation. The shopping area at the subway line has a fantastic bakery! St. Honore, I believe. Great warm bbq pork bun snack after our journey to the Buddha. :) My husband had his Starbucks fix nearby.

Quit large Island with beautiful mountains and beaches.. We first visited the area where the Large Buddha is located. Both the Buddha and the surroundings where really worth the trip. Finally we ended up having lunch at Mui Wo at the Food Market. We had fresh fish and sea food that was absolutely incredible. A very nice half day trip.

Tian Tan Buddha in Hong Kong . Lantau island is a great experience when visiting Hong Kong! Must experience the cable car ride because this is the only fastest way. It took about 25 minutes. There's an option to ride the glass bottom for additional cost. About 35 U.S. Round trip. The regular way is about $20. Tho lines can be very long. We went on June 4. And it wasn't that crowded. Other transportation is by bus starting from Tai O Village. You can see the big Buddha when from far when riding the cable car. Overall it was great experience.

Enlightening. Had a great time on Lantau. Took the ferry from Hong Kong to Mui Wo, and then the bus to Piong Ning and the Monastery. It was Buddha's birthday! The place was teaming with people, which I loved. I explored the monastery, the Giant Buddha, did the Wisdom Path walk which is highly thought provoking, ate a fantastic vegetarian meal, went shopping at Piong Ning and finally got my Monkey King opera mask (tick on my bucket list). The bus ride up revealed to me that there are beaches on this island that are now on my bucket list to try out, and I am hoping to return one day to do the Lantau Trail as a day hike. Got the bus back down to Mui Wo. I recommend that you eat and drink at the restaurants to the left of the ferry station, food is great and the drinks are cheaper than the western style pub on the waterfront (avoid this place. Im not naming and shaming). Enjoyed the evening ferry ride back to Hong Kong.

Great Day Out. From the cable car to the walking trails on the far side of the island, Lantau has loads of things to see and do! The fifteen minute cable car ride offers some awesome views of the airport and surrounding islands which would look even better on a clear day! Once you arrive at Ngong Ping, the village you first walk through seems quite fake and touristy with all its gift shops and restaurants but once you get to the Tian Tian Buddha statue at the centre of the island, you're instantly brought back into Asian Buddhist culture! The statue is the centre piece of the island and is very photogenic from any distance or angle. There's also the Buddhist monastery nearby the statue where entry is free and you can see some really interesting artefacts and building designs! Finally the Ngong walking trail is a fairly easy trek through forests and up some very twisty hills which offer fantastic views of the various mountains and valleys of Lantau. If you want to complete the trail however, save yourself some time beforehand because it can take up to three hours! Overall though it's a fantastic day out and a must see if you're visiting Hong Kong!

Absolutely EPIC!. I recently spent an entire day at Lantau Island and it was an amazing experience. I went on a Saturday and only found out when it I got there that it was a holiday, hence the crowds of people on the MTR heading there. The main highlight for me was going to have an audience with the Big Buddha. It was definitely good to get away from Hong Kong island for the day just to experience something different and I would go back tomorrow if I could…sadly I can’t as I live about 10,000 miles away. Ngong Ping Village is an absolute must when going there so be sure to explore it fully when you visit Lantau Island.

Amazing Views. Enjoyed the views from cable car which were breathtaking of airport and ocean views.Big Buddah was very commercial and I had thought it was religious. My bad.Po Lin Nunnery Vegetarian lunch was the best. Very scenic area. Cable car worth while.
Great experience. excellent experience right from the cable car ride. Everything is meticulously planned and maintained.
Pleasant trip to the Island!. Must visit place! Cable car were looking a bit old, it did took us up there to visit the Big Buddha which was truly very memorable! Completely worth the trip!
Giant Buddha.. So worth seeing, massive and mind boggling how it was built. Loads of steps so get dropped at the top and walk down..so interesting
Big Buddha. Beautiful place. Big Buddha that you can see far off which you can reach via cable car through the mountains.

peaceful and tranquil place. i visited this via Ngong ping360. This is located at Tung Chung MTR and at a walkable distance, we have to get a ticket to Ngong Ping360 to be there at the top of the hill where Big Buddha is located.

peaceful place in busy hong kong. a peaceful island far from busy streets & concrete jungles of HK. Full of greenery all around you. Main attractions like disney land, big buddha & HK airport are on Lantau island.

Nice view. It was such a nice experience going to Lantau Island. We chose to ride the bus going there instead of the infamous gondola. I think it would be nice to ride in the gondola for you to enjoy the mountain view. But the bus ride couldn't be more beautiful because you get to experience the nice road going Lantau Island. With all the beautiful beaches your going to pass by and the building structures you'll get to see upclose. Lantau experience for me, tells something about the rich culture of Chinese people and one of the biggest if not, the biggest religion of Chinese. It's hard to go up to Buddha because my mom has asthma; nevertheless, the picturesque view that welcomes is so breathtaking that you'll forget all the struggles you had gong up. lol.With the side trip to the near buddhist museum, definitely a visit to Lantau island is a must.
a bit of greenery. Lantao Island is actually bigger than Hong Kong and with most of it natural park it is a great way to spend a day relaxing and let life go by

Must visit. A must see place when u visit hongkong.It's close to Airport and one gets good experience to Views from cable car.You have market to shop souvenirs and finally at the peak the Huge statue of Buddha.Ideally it's good to visit in the morning.

A magical island with lots of local Flavour and one big Buddha!. This island is easy to get around. The local buses take you to every little town and village. We went to the village on stilts, around to the nice beaches and over to high end shopping near the metro station stop. We enjoyed the gondola ride up the mountain which gave us incredible views of the Hong Kong Airport, but also the local trails, bays and scenery. Definitely worth spending a day!

Can't get enough!. An amazing trip just to get there. Very spiritual! We were lucky enough to be their during the Chinese New Years celebrations so saw traditional ceremonies and special events. Take advantage of the 'beat the line' offer - it will save you a very long wait to get on the tram heading up. Great shopping mall and nice restaurants and water parks at the base. Plan on a whole day.
Big Buddha. Went by round trip on the cable car to see the big Buddha, great trip and you can get a Starbucks coffee arter going up the 236 steps up to the Buddha

Lantau Island and Big Buddha - Must Visit. The cable car ride to the Big Buddha is just awesome. Do not miss it on your next trip to HK. The Po Lin Monastery as well as Nong Ping Village are also great places to be. Peaceful and certainly uplifting to the spirit. The big bronze Buddha on a lotus (seated posture in meditation) is a great treat to watch and pray. Nice place for early morning or evening trips.

Worth a visit. We caught the metro here, a few minutes walk to the gondola from there. We probably had to queue for half an hour to get on which was not ideal so maybe bus up gondola down would be a good alternative. Once at the top the big Buddha and monestry are amazing.
Pink Dolphins. Took a trip into the bay and saw 9 dolphins swimming beside the boat.It was a truly amazing experince

The Big Buddha, the Ngong Ping Cable Car, the Po Lin Monastery and the Tai O Fishing Village.. One of the most popular day trips from Hong Kong combines several of Lantau's most popular attractions: The Big Buddha, the Ngong Ping Cable Car, the Po Lin Monastery and the Tai O Fishing Village.

A most memorable day.. This was the only place in Hong Kong we went for a guided tour and don't regret it. The village was a slice of a disappearing Chine, since the government has decided to eliminate everything they don't consider modern. The temple and giant Buddha is something to see before you die.

Amazing view from sky train. This island has a lot going for it and very easy to acces by metro or ferry. Try a trip to big Buddha, It is a stunning view from your cable car over the mountains on the way to Tian Tan Buddha.

Monastery / Bug Buddha - In transit. I had a 6 hour layover at Hong Kong and I used the time to visit the big buddha. . Took a taxi to the place and took the bus back. Its a great view from the top and the steps . . . Not that steep . After visiting the Big Buddha u can walk down to the Monastery and see the hall of the 1000 buddhas . . . Not many options to eat and u can also choose to get down using the gandola . . . Worth half a day :) if u wanna spend more time praying then . . Decide accordingly

Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. Lantau Island was amazing. The ride on the sky lift was amazing. It was about 30 minutes and you can see awesome views of the island. Once you're at the top the Buddha is HUGE! There are many restaurants and souvenir shops at visit.

Largest Island of Hong Kong. There are now 3-4 entry points to the Island. Disneyland, which is restricted to Disneyland. Discovery Bay, which is a posh residential area for about 25, 000 developed and owned by one company Hong Kong Resort, which also owns and operates the ferry service to Central. Ting Chung, just besides the Airport, just as new as the airport. And there is Mui Wo, or Silvermine Bay, a quiet backwater village from where to take a bus to the Buddha and the hiking trails. There are two peaks on the island - Lantau Peak and Sunset Peak. The trip via regular ferry to Mui Wo and then the bus is for the nostalgic traveller. The train to Tung Chung and then the cable car are for the busy traveller who needs to tick off 25 attractions in 3 days and rather stands 2h in a queue than riding 2h on old transport.

Amazing and Powerful (family trip). We traveled as a family of four including our two daughters, 7 and 12. We decided to travel to the island on our own on a Wednesday. First thing to note is the incredibly hot, muggy weather during July. Traveling from Okinawa, we expected the same tropical, humid weather however HK must be reigning king of humidity. Umbrellas, sun block, and water are a must (we used camelbaks as our water source so that we wouldn't be lugging around bottles). (detailed travel below)Our travel began at about 10 a.m. from the Yau Ma Tei neighborhood in Kowloon via the MTR. Travel was easy (Tsuen Wan Line MTR: Yau Mai Tei < Lai King then transfer to Tung Chung Line MTR < Tung Chung). Follow the short distance to the cable car (signs everywhere).
