We decided to travel one way on a standard cabin and returned via bus to Tung Chung followed by the MTR to our hotel. The cable car ride is about 25 minutes but is worth it. My wife, who is scared of heights, also enjoyed it; no winds and amazing views!). The cable cars get filled with up to 8 people so don't think you will get your own cable car. We then arrived in Ngong Ping 360 (separate reviews) and walked to Ngong Ping Village. After doing research, we decided that we wouldn't waste our time in Ngong Ping Village due to their high prices (tourist trap). As much as we wanted to stop we stayed focused on walking through it without any stops. At the end of the village, we took our trek up the 268 stairs to get to the Big Buddha (separate review). The view were amazing with green lush everywhere. Before you ascend the stairs there is a small area where they seem to be selling tickets however don't be fooled into thinking that you have to pay to visit the buddha. What you pay for is to go inside the buddha and end up receiving a water and ice pop at the top (well worth going inside where you can cool down with cold AC after the heat).We did not walk around to the paths others recommend since we arrived later than we anticipated and instead walked back to the village where the public buses are located. We caught a bus to Tai O Village (worth it and separate review) then caught a bus all the way back to Tung Chung (about 35-40 minute drive). Once back at Tung Chung, we caught the MTR back to our place.

The Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. Excellent place to visit. I would suggest staying at one of the hotels in the CityGate area at the end of your Hong Kong trip for convenience. Go early and choose a "crystal" cable car. It is worth the extra money. Going early is advisable; the place gets mobbed later on the weekends and the cable car wait can be long. Avoid rainy days.

The biggest Buddha. It is worth taking a trip to Lantau Island because the view of Hong Kong from the bus is quite amazing. To stand right below the huge statue of Buddha, is a very incredible experience. During this trip to Asia I saw the reclining Buddha, the Emerald Buddha and many more, in different sizes and of different material,. They were all beautiful, but only this one will remain vivid in my memory because of his majesty and the fervor of the people that worship it.

It is not as good as like China. The temple is not big and glamorous like Budhas Temples in China.But if you go to Hong Kong you have to visit Lantau Island.You can visit in side of Budha sculpture.You have to use cable car to reach there.But there are some available taxies at the skirt of the mountain.During to journey view is excellent.

Lantau Island tour. This was a half day tour booked through the hotel concierge. The tour included the cable car which offered amazing views and is more than 5km over hills.then a monastery and the giant Buddha statue. Also includes a trip to a tiny fishing village. the guide was amazing. Slow ferry home to Hong Kong Island. takes 50 minutes but wonderful to see hong kong from the ferry. Tour worth doing and lovely to get away from the heat and the bustle of HK central

Giant Buddha Lantau Island. Train rides to Tung Chung and then return cable car transport to the Polin Monastery and the giant Tian Tan Buddha are a must for all visitors to Hong Kong. The return cable car journey takes about 20 minutes each way and the views are breathtaking,

Great Half-Day Trip. Loved Lantau Island as the cable car and bus ride gives a panoramic view of the island. Big Buddha was fun to climb up to and get another view of the island. This is a lovely half-day trip for visitors and worth the effort of getting there.
Worth a Visit. Lantau island is a huge island where there were many attractions such as Giant Buddha, Tai O Fishing Village and many more. You really need to use tour to get the best of here.
Buudda. Great day out, cable car to Island, then visit Big Budda onto Monestry. Peaceful surrounds make this a very enjoyable outig.

Best place to camp in Hong Kong. We camped at the Pui O campsite and had a wonderful time there. Get a pack of UNO to have fun at night with friends. Keep mosquito repellent handy. You can also hike the nearby cliff during the daytime.

Majestic Giant Buddha. The place takes a while to get to via the ropeway, but its an awe inspiring sight once you get there. The whole trip takes about 4-5 hours and a steep flight of stairs takes one to the base of the Buddha. Spend time here to soak in the views of the islands while admiring the awe of the bronze statue.

1day in Lantau Island. Either the weather is sunny or rainy you definetely have to pay a visit there!Go up by cable car (the crystal one is a little be more expensive but it can be a funny experience) you may have to queu 1hour or so but it's worth it. Otherwise bus n. 23 (27HKD) will take you to the bus station close to the Buddha stairs in about 50 min.Must see: Big Buddha (biggest in the world!) , Monastery and Wisdom Path (15min walk from the monastery)
A lot of walking up steps to the Buddha statue. Good for a day out. Its sad that it is so commercialised. The chair lift ride was good. The food in the monastery wasn't too bad either

I would try to spend a day here next time. If you like the outdoors I would come to this island and plan to do some hiking. We were on a tour so basically went around the island in a bus. We did go to the Big Budda and we rode the lift back. I would recommend doing this the view was wonderful. You might want to ride the lift up and take the bus back. You would get a better picture of the Budda going up.
Definitely worth visiting the big Budha. You not lonly have the Big Budha but the Monastry and just a bus ride away Tai Po with the houses on stilts a nice getaway from the hub bub of Hong Kong
Peace of Mind. Lantau island where lies the statue of Big Buddha gives you a the peace you need to relax. Apart from an enriching experience it also give you a lot to learn about the culture
A must see. What a great place, a number of ways too get to Lantau island, by ferry from HK side or by MTR to chair lift. Do the chair ride, easy to use great views. A great place.
Outstanding. Lantau Island has plenty of exciting things to offer. Aside from the HKIA airport located in the Island, Hong Kong Disneyland & Ngong Ping village is also in Lantau Island.

Worth a visit if you have 2 or more days in HK. We took the slow ferry to Mui Wo. Then, we took a bus to Tai-O. Nice scenery along the way. Locals getting on and off the bus. We walked around Tai-O. Then, we took a bus to Big Buddha and Po Lin. Took the gondola down and the MTR back to Hong Kong Island.

Great Tourist Location to discover. I went this place on Sunday, crowd is crazy. To save time, I suggest you to buy a package, so that u can get an express way to the cable car. If u never been here before, YOU MUST TRY THEIR CRYSTAL CABLE CAR to see the view. The view is STUNNING!!!

Forget the stairway to heaven take the crystal cable car. What a great way to see something out the the centre of Hong Kong, On a blue sky day this is the way to travel to Lantau and the Big Buddha. Some great photo opportunities all the way.

a number of things to be seen here. we really enjoyed taking the ferry here, and then the bus to Tai-O, a fishing village. From there we took a cab to the big buddha and then a glass bottomed gondola back into HK. Disney is on Lantau too, as is the airport - quite a few things going on here!

Hiker's Paradise. I visited Mui Wo on Lantau Island and friends in one the Mui Wo villages. I did some serious hiking too, Sunset Peak and Lantau Peak. Great hiking! I recommend The China Bear cafe/bar in Mui Wo center, a little pricey but has relaxed atmosphere and nice harbor view. Whatever you do don't go to Pui O Beach. Filthy dirty, trash all over the beach and in the water. It was disgusting.

Highlight of our trip. My sister and I traveled to Lantau for a full day visit on a cloudy day in June. The Crystal Cable Car trip to the top of the mountain was fantastically fun - we laughed and oohed and aahed the whole way up. Saw waterfalls and all kinds of great scenery. And the Big Buddha was a pretty cool place to visit, along with the little shopping village and the temple. Well worth the trip.
Great Island. There is so much on this island. Hong Kong int airport, disneyland, ngong ping 360. There were many attractions to explore, but i didnt have enough time, would go back again
Very cold. Make sure you bring enough clothes as it gets cold riding the cable car. Plenty of food in the mall and a lot of kids activity on the island.

an OASSIS from City's city hustle bustle,. Takes one hour to get here from Hong Kong Central. Take mrt train to Tung Chung station on Orange line. The Gondola rise doesn't start until 9 AM so don't go there too early in the day. Its a beautiful 25 minute rise in Gondola to get to to Buddha. Costs 165 HKD. If you want Glass bottom then it costs 265 HKD. Weather is beautiful there compare to HOng KOng City. Feels like you are in a hill station.

Wonderful island. You could better stay at Lantau Island as most of the attractions are nearby or within this island.We stayed at Auberge Discovery Bay and it was an amazing place to stay. We really loved it. There's a beach just near by.

Great days out. In many ways I always thought it was better before they joined it to the mainland. However there are endless possibilities for days out. The po lin monastery for a start. Lovely beachs including cheung sha beach the longest in hong kong. Tai o where you still see traditional houses on stilts. Great walking to be had too. An excellent bus service to most destinations but that is true of the public transport in hong kong probably the best in the world. Oh Disney world never been there not my cup of tea

Worth the trip!. Well worth making the journey early in the day - later the lines for buses and cable cars become extensive. Plan on walking and climbing the stairs for a full experience! Highly recommended!

Must visit place in Hong Kong. Superb place to get the best view of Hong Kong. We took crystal cabin to reach the Lantau Island. It was great experience. Feels like walking on water.....Its worth the price. The scenic beauty on the Lantau Island is just awesome. Very peaceful place. The statue of Buddha is a one of the biggest one. We took a bus from the Top to return to the base just for fun and we enjoyed the curvy roads. 5 star.

Great day out. This is a lovely day out for the whole family. There's a little bit of walking involved, but if you are mostly healthy and mobile you'll enjoy it.We went with a tour group. I would suggest that you also go with a tour group, because they skip the queues...especially for the cable car (Ngong Ping 360) going up to the top (the queue when we got there seemed as long as the Great Wall of China). The tour also provided more information about everything to see at the top.At the top you will find The Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery, Ngong Ping Piazza and the Wisdom Path that will satisfy your exploring curiosity. Make sure you go on a clear day as the Big Buddha can be coved in clouds because of the altitude. There are also numerous little restaurants at the top to stop for a quick bite to eat.This is definitely a full day out, so don't plan any other activity for the day.Have a great day out my fellow explorers!
Gorgeous Walks and Fab Food. Get over to Lantau for a lovely walk taking in the beaches and lovely scenery. Finish with a seafood lunch at the Rainbow Restaurant.

Buddha. We paid a little more for the crystal skyline tram and it was well worth it! They had entertainment live show near by the tram station and it was free and awesome! The walk up with the stairs to the buddha was not too bad for my two young kids. Do check out some of the souvenir shop and you will find some good deals! I bought all my souvenir in one stop and it only cost me US$50.
Don't waste your time here. Built in the early 2000's and is purely a tourist trap! Save yourself the time, money and day trip. There are plenty of other options.

Get away from the skyscrapers to see a very relaxing side of Hong Kong. Absolutely worthwhile. The Big Buddha statue is impressive. You can either go over with cable car or bus - either way is worth the trip as you get to see another side of Hong Kong, that is the natural, relaxing side.

Disneyland and Buddha. The disneyland is there, and the Big Buddha is there!Disneyland is not as big as the tokyo one, but is still quite interesting.But I like the big buddha more. I feel my soul being cleaned when I saw it.Can take the cable car from Tung Chung to there.And I think it will be much better if it is sunny. It's always rainy in May in HK.

Lantau Amazes. Catch a bus from the airport (3.5 HK$ correct change needed) to the village - great outlet shops and cafes) and ride the cable car over the mountains (spectacular views) to a themed village with a walk to Po Lin monastery and steps to the Giant Buddha - a truly memorable way to spend a full day (late flight allowed this visit, with the city to airport dash already done!).

Good views. We went via the ferry to the Lantau Island (from Central) & then took the No 2 bus to visit the Big Buddha. We had planned to return via the cable car and MTR but a mist came down so seemed pointless. The ferry gives good views of Hong Kong and the bus journey shows off other parts of the Lantau island, passing some beaches and camping areas. There are plenty of places to eat both outside and inside the temple. Inside the temple you can get a set meal, or there is a small cafe in the corner if you prefer something lighter. Outside the temple there are lots of cafes from various chains too if you don't want vegetarian. The Big Buddha is very impressive, try and pick a day when it is not too cloudy to see it at its best. Lots of steps up to the Buddha statue though, so not for the unfit.

Highlight of my weekend. My visit to this island was one of the highlights of my HK trip this weekend. Do not limit yourself to the Buddha though. We did what everyone else does not do and we started with a visit to the Tai O fishing village (bus 11 from Tung Chung). We got there in the morning and had plenty of time to see the village without any tourists and, because we got there early, we got to mix with the locals on a festival that we caught happening. We had so much fun that the time passed by and we only managed to leave by 15h. We then caught bus 21 to Ngong Ping to see the Buddha, the Wisdom path and the Po Lin Monastery. They were ok, but I was a bit underwhelmed after the hype of Tai O. From here you can catch the bus 23 back to Tung Chung.Didn’t catch the cable car, and we were glad about it. It is expensive and it was cloudy in the top of the mountain.

Great different world just minutes from HK . A whole new world there, out of the hustle and bustle of the big city, to get there u have to loads thru amazing bridges; it is the home of the Big Buddha and the cable car

Fantastic!. Fantastic place to visit, we recommend having lunch in the canteen. A truly amazing delight for veggies! Go on a clear day (as the clouds can obstruct the buddha), and take a tour from the mainland as gettting there by yourself can be difficult. Well worth a day out.

Fast Rising. one of the fast rising commericialize area of HK. they are becoming more and more commercialize with the Disney, and Airport. we saw new reclamation near the airport i think it would still be commercial area.

Different from the HK you know. This place is a little touristy, but it gives off a different vibe than the city areas. It is a must visit. You can take the cable car up, but I don't see the need to pay extra for the "crystal" cabins, because I have been there twice and on both occasions it was quite misty outside. Visibility was not that great. There is a temple that serves vegetarian meals right opposite Big Buddha. I really like this little "break" from HK and Kowloon.

Visiting the Giant Buddha. Caught the cable car up to the Giant Buddha which was great. it was windy but the scenery was fantastic you could watch the aeroplanes comeing in. well worth visiting the Buddha,lots of beautiful flowers temples restaurants and the Buddha spectular

The quieter side of Hong Kong. So many walks to do here. Roads are quiet due to permit restrictions which make this a really quiet place to visit. If doing by taxi, you need to take blue taxi as these are the only ones that can go here. (From airport or Tung Chung).

動靜皆宜. Lantau is one of the outlying Islands in Hong Kong I like most. I like it because you can have a lot of things to do, like swimming in Cheung Sha, wild camp in Pui O campsite, hiking in Lantau Trail which opened on Dec. 4, 1984. And of course visit the Big Buddha and also taste vegetarian food. If you want to eat seafood or visit a bar in the evening, you can go to Lantau Pier and near the pier there are also small inns which tourists like to have short stay. You can also go to Tai O, which is a fishing village and you could spend a night there and enjoy its peaceful and beautiful environment. Besides, you can also go to Tung Chung where there is shopping outlet and after shopping, you can enjoy afternoon tea in a comfortable hotel. Of course, you can also take a bus ride to tour around the area or in Ngong Ping 360 which gives you an aerial view of Lantau. All in all, Lantau is a wonderful place you cannot miss when visiting Hong Kong.

Recommended. All the place are very foggy when we reach there. There have a lot of shop and a lot of interesting item selling in the shop. The place was clean and tidy, If u are 1st time visit it really recommended others than that not much. Can try the temple food where u can buy the food voucher at the Big Buddha counter. It worth it.

seeing the big buddha. Taking the trip to Lanta Island was well worth it. We took the MRT and bought tickets when we got there. The cable car trip was amazing with fabulous views. However we went in the morning and cued for at least 90 minutes. I recommend going around 2pm there are no lines and you can get on to the cable's with a short wait. There is also a shopping area at the base worth a visit.

Highlight of our trip to Hong Kong. Lantau Island was probably my favourite place in Hong Kong. The Buddha and its surrounds were amazing and beautiful. It was clean and beautifully kept (apart from the sides of the steps leading up to the Buddha... disgraceful how much rubbish tourists had thrown over the sides) there was cows and dogs everywhere just wandering around (but they were friendly) The shops here were great as were the food place! Really loved this place - if we were to go to Hong Kong again I would spend more time here rather than the Mong Kok area.
Lantau Island. Very touristy and not that interesting . The same place that is now the airport. Get further out of Hong Kong for interesting sights.

awesome experience. Location :Its opposite hk airportHow to reach:Cable car ride... its worth it... nice view... plus in mat we experienced rains and lightening. .. so the thrill was wow...Whats der in island Lots of places to eat... only one for indian food... biryani is worth it... lots of places to shop too... but very expensive again.Time :Its a full day affair.. so ensure u reach early mrng by say 9 tp 10.. and explore d place nicely...

A must on any bucket list. Amazing place to visit with so much history! If you like visiting places that can be kitschy up to awe inspiring then be sure on your visit to Hong Kong to visit Lantau Island. Very rich in Buddhist history. I had a great time listening to the tour guides, taking amazing pictures, and just being part of the crowds.

Breathtaking views, feeling of peace..... Riding the gondola/cable car up to the Big Buddha was an experience alone! The views are incredible. It was a very windy & rainy day which caused the car to swing a little....was thrilling/scary but exciting!At the top of the Big Buddha are big views, great backdrop for photography.There is a real sense of peace even though you are surrounded by tons of other happy tourists.

Highlight of my HKK Tour. I simply loved the Big Buddha, the little disney landish village in Lantau Island and the Monastery visit and lunch. I took the Crystal cabin to and back from the Island. The cable car itself was a 25 Min ride and it was so serene and beautiful. The day i choose to visit was slightly misty with a light drizzle, but that didnt take away anything from the mystical experience of the place. If anything it added to the whole experience. Once you reach the top, you have shops and restaurants complete with a starbucks. Keep walking and you reach the big Buddha. Do not miss having lunch at the Monastery. I think the whole experience was simply beautiful. Climb up to the buddha itself was not a challenege. I'm not sure older people and parents with toddlers/ infants can do the climb, but other wise pretty much everyone else can. And while you;re here - DO NOT MISS THE WISDOM PATH. It was a serene walk and i could understand how it got its name.
Most unspoilt area of Hong Kong. Tung Chung outlet village. Cable car up to mountains and Buddhist monastery, huge Buddha. You can see the cable car from the airport.
largest budda in world. Enjoyable boat ride to Lantau Island with leisurely walk around temple area. there are many steps to reach the top but definitely worth it
A relaxing trip from Hong Kong.. A definite must see on a stop to Hong Kong. Lantau Island offers the giant Buddha as well as a fishing village on stilts.
Well worth a visit. Beware the toilets - holes in the ground only.We were amazed at the small homes in stilts, and how most had very little inside, but did tend to have enormous TVs!

Worth the Adventure. Although the weather wasn't cooperating, the trip to Lantau Island was definitely worth it. We took the ferry to the island, then boarded a bus to visit the fishing village then visited Buddha. Although we were in a thick cloud, it was worth seeing and the fog and rain brought a more ethereal perspective. Unfortunately the cable car ride back down was fogged in. But was we neared the airport, we had a great view of the airport and surrounding areas. Definitely go, but check out the weather report first!
Giant Buddha. Lantau Island is synonymous to the Giant Buddha. It was Buddha's birthday. Thousands of worshippers came to pay their respect and join the joyous celebration!

A Must Visit!. The experience is good. We took the Cable Car to this place, which is worth the time and money. Its a must visit when you visit HongKong. Nice serene place, either you would like the calmness and peace of the place or you will be highly bored!

If you will see other buddhas as well, then you can save the time. A big shopping center, a big buddha and a few other things to see. The cable car was closed for maintenance. I wasn't that impressed by the Buddha, saw a few of them in Vietnam. If your time is short in HK, save it and don't go there.

A Great Day Trip Adventure to see the Happy Buddha. This is a beautiful place to visit. You can take a Tran ride high in the sky from Hong Kong Island to Lantau Island for about 25 mins. You will be very high up! Its a nice ride when the sunshine if up, but when the sun is going down and the winds pickup, it's pretty cold on the ride back down. Even if its 100 F outside, bring a small something to cover up if you get back in the early evening, especially if you have kids with you. It's an amazing view and you wonder how is the world did they get the cable car of this high! Or you can take a local Bus from downtown from the Bus Terminal and you get the scenic view going through neighborhoods and seaside ride with lots of turns and zig-zag roads. My brother was scare of heights so we took this method and it was just fine to see another view of the Island. We you arrive, there are some street vendors outside the park area. I liked that they were not pushy. Inside the park is a beautiful design of sculptures, huge Buddhas in Chinese pavilions on the grounds. Some shops for tourists and places to eat both local Chinese fare and western-style meals. The main attraction is this monster-side Buddha that is on top of a hill overlooking the horizon. How do you get up to there to greet it? You walk up about "20 Flight of Stairwells" straight up to the heavens! There are a few open crossover points along the way for those of us who 'get it' that this is a longgggggggggg flight up!!! And it's a very longggggggggg way back down! Even my athletic sister felt it the next day. : ( It's the perfect place to take beautiful pics of family & friends and the scenic sites. You will get a workout walking around. It's a very beautiful place. A nice side trip if you are lucky enough to have the top to go. The arts at it's best!

Great option for a short layover. Our plane arrived around 8, so instead of going into the city right away, we rode the S1 shuttle to the tram station, left our bags and rode the cable car to Lantau Island. If you can, get the clear bottom + regular combination! Also, buy your tickets ahead - the line to buy one of the spot was extremely long.We explored the nearby temple and climbed up the steps to the buddha. For lunch we had sticks of fried fish balls, but there are places there with more filling fare. There's even a subway, but we were full from the fish balls.The baggage storage was expensive though - more expensive than we thought. Perhaps it would be cheaper in the mall next to the station, but if you're on a schedule, it's better than having to leave your bags and then go back.

Big Buddha. Take the tour of the Big Buddha and eat at the Po Lin Monastery. The vegetarian cuisine is excellent. Bring your cameras for the area's beauty. Traditional fishing village in Ngong Ping was authentically quaint. Temple nearby was ornate. We felt like we had been transported back in time. Souvenir shopping near the monastery was great too. Cable car ride had stunning views.

Lovely Beach!. I'm not a beach bum, but I must say that I loved the beach as well as the island itself. Island residents park in designated ares and other cars are restricted all together. Plenty of bicycles to rent. Friendly, warm people. The beach was small, but stunning. Extremely peaceful, even on a Saturday afternoon! Bar-b-q pit for those who like to bring their food and cook. Check the weather forecast this time of year! We got some drizzle, but luckily it was short lived. I would certainly go back!

A wonderful place to visit and to eat. Make sure you visit Lantau island - try to take the slow boat to enjoy and savour the day.There are so many great food spots with the most wonderful food. We decided to try something different and we ate pigeon! along with fish, prawns, squid and chinese greens.

Fun trip - did the circle tour (MTR > cablecar > bus > ferry). We did the circle tour: MTR to Tung Chung Station, short walk to cable car, one-way ticket on cable car to top (Great Buddha, Po Lin Monastery), bus to Mui Wo, ferry to Central. The prepaid Octopus IC card helps make it super easy - just wave the card to get on each mode of transportation.
So peaceful after the city. A lovely ferry trip to the island with either a walk to the beach or a fabulous local bus ride up to the monastery at the top of the mountain
Much changed. Village a bit Disney went before this was built and it was a better experience. Buddha was a good sight but lots of steps so you need to be able

The giant Buddha. The trip was booked at our hotel, a boat trip,then a coach through villages stopping for refreshments, then we reached our golden Buddha , amazing place, would go back again, so peaceful and the smell of insence was blissful .
Huge Golden Buddha. NIce 20 minute Cable car ride to the top. Lovely views of the airplanes from the cable car. Lovely Village with small shops on the way to the Buddha Statue.

Best place in Honk Kong. This place should be rated best in Hong Kong. The Big Buddha and Ngong Ping village are in this complex only. Reach this place by a cable car with astonishing view of Hong Kong city, Airport and Big Buddha. Here you will find Many eating joints, Chinese Mythology statues, Big Buddha's statue, shining golden Monastery, shows. Lot is there to visit. Take a cable car from City Gates Mall. Also visit Tai O fishing village from the Ngong Ping village.

Lantau Island - A Worthwhile Tour. We visited Lantau Island via a tour booked through Viator. This was a very worthwhile tour. We took a ferry to Lantau Island and visited the Big Buddha, an adjacent monastery (including a fine lunch) and Tai O fishing village. All were very nice and well worth the tour. The big disappointment was that the cable car was shut down for several days for periodic maintenance. we were notified about the shutdown and the tour company offered alternatives, but we couldn't find a different one that met our interest and schedule.My guidance is to be aware whether the cable cars are running and knowledgeable about likely weather obscuring the view of the Big Buddha from below due to clouds. The Big Buddha is still worthwhile in the clouds (entry to the inside of the Buddha is permitted, but the view from below is extraordinary if you get a clear view.

Well worth the visit but Buddha was hidden by fog. Visited on a foggy day so sadly did not get to view the statue.On arrival I went to the cable car station and received the heavy sell to buy a package including the glass bottomed cable car and priority boarding along with a guided tour. I took the package but it should be noted that you can travel to the monastery and the Tai O fishing village by bus from the bus station next door to the cable car station.The views from the cable car were spectacular - you can see the airport from above as well as the foliage covered hills, the sea and some of the Nine Dragons.On arrival you enter a reproduction village which is basically shops and food outlets. Our guide met us and transferred us by bus to the Tai O village which was interesting but felt a little intrusive as these are people's actual homes! A boat trip around the village and out into the bay was included and after that there was time to explore the village with its fish market and temple. There are cafés and restaurants if you have time.Another bus transfer to the temple and the stairway to the Buddha. The monks were holding a service and chanting which was beautiful and we visited the recently opened new temple with its Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas which was stunning - no photography allowed.There are a couple of attractions back in the initial village but I didn't bother.Overall interesting but at certain times of the year the weather could spoil the experience.

Nice day out and interesting but too commercialized.. The cable car ride was fun and interesting as you watch the jets take off and land at the airport down below.Bring and have your camera ready for the ride up and down.The Big Buddha was a nice attraction to visit, but I felt it was too commercialized with a Starbucks on hand, gift shops, restaurants, and other shops there.However there is some nice hiking you could try to get away from the tourist crowds should you choose.Lots of sleepy dogs lying around the area as they are not disturbed by the monks.It is difficult to think about Buddhism and serenity with the smell of candy ice cream and popcorn in the air and little kids running around unsupervised from any parents.

Beautiful. We have some beautiful memories from this place. Though the sky wasnt clear and lot of mist, we had a good time UP Above. The Cable car ride to the Lantau is a must try too and it will be a memorable one for any one trying it out.
Get a day out there. Lantau is very easy to go......Take a ferry... Very cheap but lots of fun.... Takes less than an hour and you get a toto different feel of HK

A must do when in Hong Kong. There are various ways to get to Lantau Island. We took the cable cars which were great fun.There's an attraction centre which as you would expect is full of over priced souvenir shops, but as you walk away and towards the big Buddha you can feel the calmness of the site.The Big Buddha is very impressive. If you have your camera take a photo with the street sign which says how many miles it is to where you come from. Makes for a great snap.Same again is getting a photo away from the bottom of the stairs looking up to it. Shows just how many steps you climbed to get to it.Various tickets are sold to go up, but you don't need to waste money on these it isn't worth the extra expense. You can get a ticket to get water, but if you don't have water with you its only worth it if you need it right then. A general ticket to get inside is all you need.

Tourist trap. This is a huge tourist trap. Look at the sky before you go. If it is foggy dont go. We got up and couldn't see the big buddha, not even an outline through the fog, that should have been sitting directly in front of us. There are shops and food but not worth it to hang out there
Awesome. If on a stop over this place is fabulous. From the cable car to the Big Buddha the views are amazing.

DisneyLand and Big Buddha. Lantau Island has the most prominent attractions Disneyland and Big Buddha. It is green so the journey via cable car to reach Nong Ping village is simply awesome.Something you cannot Miss!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Serene Buddha. The cable car journey in the glass cabin took my breath away. Later our visit to the Ngong Ping village which sells such wonderful stuff was the begining of the climb to the top. The climb to the top for the Big Buddha and later the temple nearby was amazing. The Po Lin Monestary is worth all the money we spent getting there. This was my second visit and shall visit again. Last time I went there during peak season and it was overcrowded but this time it was off season and I enjoyed the free walkways.

Lantau island Disneyland. Disneyland is the main landmark on this island and not many tourists miss this fantastic place for children and adults alike. Visitors can enjoy the other sight seeing places including the cable care ride to see the Buddha statue, if they are willing to spend a separate day.

Highly Recommend!. This is a must do while visiting Hong Kong. The cable car was shut down for maintenance so we booked an excellent tour with Splendid Tours. They drove us up to the Big Buddha Monument and the Monastery and then drove us down to the Tai O Fishing Village. When finished there they arranged a ferry boat ride for us to go back to Hong Kong. Their guides were knowledgable, friendly, funny and spoke very good English. They allowed enough time at each stop and explained everything in detail! This was a very enjoyable afternoon tour which we highly recommend!

Big Buddha, Breathtaking View, People. You can see the biggest Buddha in the world (they claimed it). After reaching the top of the area, you can see a very beautiful scene. Local people from the village.
Worth the day trip!. The weather was fantastic when we went so we took the cable car to Lantau Island. Loved the Big Buddha & the Temple + there are some great trinket shops.

Spend the day in Lantau Island. You can get the cable car or bus (if you are afraid of heights) up the mountain to Big Buddha from Tung Chung. Unless you purchase your cable car tickets the previous day, expect to stand in a line anywhere from 1-3 hours but the view from the cable car is worth it. You may even opt for a clear bottom cable car! After spending time visiting Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery, you can take the bus to the oldest fishing village in Hong Kong, Tai O. In Tai O, you can take a brief ride on a boat to see more of the fishing village or take a quick ride to the ocean to see the dolphins. Unfortunately no dolphins on our ride! You can buy most anything imaginable made of fish in Tai O. Have lunch or dinner there and enjoy the authentic atmosphere! When you get ready to leave, you can take a bus over the mountain (with gorgeous views) directly to Tung Chung or back to Big Buddha and then with the cable car back to Tung Chung.

big buddha. tian tan Buddha is a must see. easy to get to by rail. then bus, which is another 20 minutes ride. There is such a tranquil feel and bronze statue is perched so high which you can climb the steps to get a closer look.
great island. this is the island where the airport is and where the Budhist statue is. If we are going to disneyland we also gonna cross this island

Relaxing and Quiet place. Me and my wife stayed at Silvermines Hotel situated infront of a beach. We went to visit the Buddha Pink Dolphins and walk around Lantau cave and Falls. For travellers who prefer to stay in the suburb areas for relaxing and quiet place. We suggest Lantau Island. Its like Thailand or Bali Indonesia. Many things to do. Pui O Beach is good for surfing and you can rent tents for camping. Good for your kidsduring Summer. HK is great and quite affordable place to visit.

A Half-Day Tour at Lantau Island. The cable car ride brought us to Ngong Ping Village which signals the start of the land adventure. This is a culturally themed Chinese-style marketplace which offers a unique shopping and dining experience to visitors. Eastern and Western restaurants welcome you as you enter the village and there is also a complete line up of souvenir shops which offers a display of authentic Chinese gifts. The other side of the piazza paves the way to the Big Buddha. This is the world's tallest and biggest bronze Buddha who sits serenely on a lotus throne atop the Ngong Ping plateau. Pilgrims from all over the world pay homage to Tian Tan Buddha whose right hand is being raised to deliver a blessing to all. Visitors must climb up 268 steps in order to reach the Buddha. On top, six smaller bronze statues will be seen which is known as "The Offering of the Six Devas", posing offering of flowers, incense, lamp, ointment, fruit, and music to the Buddha. Overlooking the Big Buddha is the Po Lin Monastery. This is Hong Kong's largest Buddhist temple but it's not as big as Singapore's Buddha Tooth Relic Temple and Museum. But in here, I found the largest joss sticks ever! This monastery plays a major role for Hong Kong's Buddhist pilgrimage. The main temple houses three bronze statues of Buddha representing his past, present, and future lives. A row of eateries is conveniently located inside the monastery complex for hungry visitors coming down from the Big Buddha.

Buddha on lantau. Cable car, don't like heights then don't go on it but you can take a bus up the hill. Buddha is a sight to be seen, it is an easy walk through the fake village / shops to the base of the Buddha the up the stairs (a lot of them) to the viewing area that goes around the Buddha. We did a tour a couple of years ago which took you into the Buddha which was very interesting. The village was very average and included the "walking with Buddha intro short movie" Disney style cartoon explaining where Buddha came from "average"
Lantau hike. after sampling all the different cuisine in the city, this is the best thing to do. You will be rewarded with best view of the airport and the South China Sea.

Nature Walks and Mui Wo. Went on a trip to Lantau, which is much more than just Discovery Bay. You can make fantastic hikes on the island, visit the Big Buddha, and fishing village Tai O, but this day we just went on a hike from MTR station Tung Chung to Mui Wo. Beautiful views, waterfalls, lots of birds and at the finish a lovely meal and healthy vegetable juice (or beer) at the China Bear close to the ferry terminal to Central. Next time we're gonna rent bikes!

Fabulous Day Trip. Took the ferry across, the the bus to Tio O and the stilted village, unbelievable some of the poverty and conditions. Walked down one of the lanes to discover the best egg puffs made over a stone BBQ. Took a boat trip to the houses which we walked round later and the same boat trip to the pink dolphins which we did not see
Lantau island... Just about ok place.. a lot to walk around and shop. We liked the area outside the Lantau MTR station more.. which was very lively.

Lantau Island is a retreat from the crowds of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon. Take a ferry or road trip to Lantau Island which has a huge nature reserve topped by Lantau Peak. The trails are marked to the peak and along the way you will see flower encrusted slopes with colorful butterflies that were uncountable on my hike that began in the morning taking a ferry from Central Pier No. 5 on HK Island to the Silvermine Beach ferry dock. On reaching the summit, Lantau Peak, where cattle were grazing I had a view of the entire perimeter of Lantau Island including several beaches. Now that the New Airport and bridge to Lantau exists one can make this a road trip by car or bus as well but I would recommend the ferry trip to Silvermine Beach, lunch at one of the local restaurants and hike up to Lantau Peak. Hike farther down to the the north south Tung Chung Road and find a bus that will take you back to Hong Kong Island.

One of my favourite parts of our trip to HK. I loved Lantau Island - I loved Tai O, Big Buddha, Po Lin, travelling around the island on the bus, the cable cars and seeing the amazing views. Please visit the island, if you ever are fortunate enough to have the opportunity.

clean refreshing and enlightened!. Visited in Mar 2014. Actually my ultimate motive to visit this island was for the all transparent cable car....but of course as Buddhists we felt that it was necessary to visit the statue of Buddha to pray for some good luck and protection whilst being in a foreign land ourselves without family. It has also been more than 10 years since i last visited it, so it would be a whole new experience for myself. (: Love the air, love the look of the town, love the flora and faunas there! Climbed up the Buddha stairs to get a better view and have a nearer place to do our praying, as well as a challenge for us who hardly exercises XD Good to experience!

Got to go on the tour to Lantau.. We took a whole day tour to Lantau Island and it was a great way to see the entire island, including Ngong Ping Plateau majestic Tian Tan Buddha near the Po Lin Monastery. Make sure you take the cable car too - a great view (albeit a bit smoggy I suspect most of the time), and interesting to view the airport from above.

A great outing from Hong Kong. The ferry ride from pier 6 is 30 minutes by fast ferry. Many good restaurants at the ferry stop, then hike up to the big Buddha, tour the island, visit the beaches and come down by cable car!

Ferry, bus, cable car.. When going places I do not like to come as I go and another thing to learn in Hong Kong is if going to outlying islands by ferry is always go early.Populated islands workers coming and going early and late in day means more frequency of ferries.Go after 8am 8.30am and risk waiting nours.So I recommend this trip for Lantau.Between 7am to *am take one of half hourly ferries to Lantau and get off at Silvermine Bay.Walk to waterfall through village but before check departure time off bus to Tai O fishing village on stilts.Cacth bus after walk to Tai O and check there also time of departure of bus to Ngong Pong or Giant Buddah (Bug Bud).Catch bus up and then cable car down when fiinished to Tung Chung? and its MTR.Maybe stop off at visitor centre on bridge on way back to HK but think no time.Shopping centre at Tung Chung too and close to airport.Maybe last day evening flight check in bags early at Central for plane and do this trip.A walk I have yet to do goes from Tung Chung down coast to Tai O it is in HK Tourist Board Hiking Guide.Takes 6 hrs 16km?So if going to Big Bud on Lantau try doing this route for completeness
Beautiful. Absolutely stunning island, plenty of areas to camp, BBQ and picnic whilst enjoying the tropical island.
Lantau Island. Great place to visit. Secluded one of a kind, place of Buda statue. I went in a trip organized by a firm, but it was worth every penny.

Too often forgotten by tourists. Lantau Island is one of thoghlights of every trip to Hong Kong. It's a pity that many tourists never come to visit it. You can hike for days in a beautiful nature with great views on the Ocean and Hong Kong. And a trip is not complete without a good meal in one of the many great fish restaurants. Would recommend going there by cable car as the views on the Buddha are breathtaking.

Buddha is the highlight!. I booked a viator tour as it's an all day adventure but worth every cent. Big Buddha is amazing and the views are breathtaking. Tai O fishing village is interesting and the cable car ride was a lot of fun. Allow a day to explore the region preferably on a tour.

Beautiful, serene. Was about to tick it off my itinerary, but thankfully managed to visit. Its lovely. The cable car was under maintenance, so we took the bus....its a nice drive through scenic mountains and clouds. Beautiful place.

Calm away from the bustle of town. A must for anyone visiting HK. An easy tram ride from town to the cable car to the top The queue for the cable car can be long so either book in advance or be prepared to pay a bit extra to get fast tracked The views from the cable car are stunning ( you can upgrade to glass bottomed car ) At the top there's cafes shops and souvenirs but also the main attraction big Buddha and a couple of temples

Best Place to visit!. I really enjoyed by day trip over to Lantau Island. The sculpture and the Big Buddha is all worth seeing. I enjoyed the views and there is a lot to see culture wise. Can be busy.

Tour company spoiled this. Booked on the 6th May to travel the 9th, we wanted to do the half day tour as we were time poor,at no time were we told the chair lift was not working since the first of May. Our bus was 45minutes late ,then we changed to another bus,it took us to the chair lift venue,then we were put on another bus, still we were not informed of the chair lift until,we were on our way,we asked the guide to clarify as the chair lift was part of the deal,he explained ,but it was not his fault, Slendid Tours should have told us. Because of this we were rushed at each venue so we would meet the catamaran to return to Hong Kong Island. Our guide Ryan was fabulous & very knowledgeable of his tour.

Peaceful place. Highlight of my HK trip. One of the most peaceful and naturally beautiful place to visitThe visit will take the better part of the day but its worth it!The big buddha is worth a visit, and try to reach Big Buddha before 5pm or else it shall be closed.There is no fee as such, but one needs to pay for the transport (as it is far from HK city area) to reach over there which makes it a bit expensive
Day out. this is worth doing such a great day out.so much to see and do you will wonder if you will see it all.

Most valuable natural asset Hong Kong got. The great view there is the most valuable thing in Hong Kong. The country park in Hong kong should be protected and not for development. Visit there and enjoy how the nature given to us and you may rethink how small yourself and how great the nature. I love this place most.
A must do. The Big Buddha is worth seeing and the local village is quaint. You MUST take the cable car ride over the island back to Hong Kong Island. A real highlight.

Beautiful landscape. The Big Buddha was the highlight...such serenity. Ngong Ping 360 was a scenic trip via crystal cable car (must do!). the sights of mainland and travelling over the ocean and rifts of water are just too stunning for words to describe!
"peace ". one of the must visit place in hong kong, this island is so beautiful that you would not want to leave..all the statue here are amazing worth a visit to this place

A fantastic tour. We were in Hong Kong on a 2 night stopover and decided that an organised tour through the Novotel tour desk was the way to go. We usually organise things independently and were not really looking forward to being part of a large tour group. However, much to our surprise, we were the only ones who had booked Lantau that day so we had a personalised tour instead. Our tour guide was excellent. He had a huge knowledge of both the Island where he had lived for 13 years as well as a good knowledge of Hong Kong history etc. our tour van was allowed to park up the road so we didn't have to walk up the steps to the Buddah, just a few instead. The area was shrouded in mist which added to the magical feel. The visit to the temples was great as well and gave us an insight into Buddhism. The highlight was probably visiting the fishing villages where people live in these flimsy houses on stilts. By the time we returned to Kowloon via catamaran and ferry, we had had a worthwhile six hour tour and seen a lot more than if we had tried to do the trip as individuals. For those with limited time, a definite must do.
hiking trail. Great getaway place - just 20 mins by ferryDirty beaches though. But awesome seafood hiking trail leads through entire island

Wonderful for hiking. My first trip to Hong Kong, I actually stayed on Lantau rather than downtown. It's quiet and has lovely trails that make you feel like you're far away from the hustle-bustle of the city.

I last visited this place more than a decade ago. Of course, if u going to ask me if there are any changes to this place as compared to 10 yrs ago, there is! But it is worth a visit to this place after a decade.You cant compare the vegetarian meal (vip meal) which is quite pricey to other caferia food in hong kong, because it is in Lantau Island. Just go here to pray for family's health n safety.

Great place to visit. This has to be a must..Ryan our Lantau Tours guide was funny, informative and considerate.....We visited a small fishing village and went on a Sampan to view the houses on stilts before heading off to the giant Buddah....

A must visit. this island is so beautiful that you would not want to leave... all the statue here are amazing.. go in the early or mid morning... and don't forget to take a good camera... the cable car to this place is also amazing with breath taking views... and you can even see a plan taking off from the cable car as an airport is near by... all in all an amazing place to spend quality time....

A must see. Make this a priority, you have a choice of two ferries, one takes an hr and is about £2. The other takes 25 mins and is £4, I did both. I went to Lantau to see Big Buddha which is fantastic. Go mid morning as in the afternoon its difficult to take photos and it`s no fun climbing 268 steps in the heat with hundreds of other people. After the ferry you need to catch a bus which takes about 45 mins (I saw some people walking, not for me though) if you have time you can spend a day exploring the island.

Amazing island with a lot of hidden gems. The most typical part of the island is of course the Big Buddha. But don't miss out on all the other gems that this magnificent island holds back. You should also visit the authentic fisher village not far from the Buddha and of course the monastery.

Best part of going to Hong Kong. My favorite place in Hong Kong!!! Finally we found peace in Hong Kong. Loved the cable car ride up to the mountain. Once we arrived at the Sitting Buddha we were amazed at the peace we felt once we arrived. Definitely our highlight in Hong Kong. Would love to go back.
Fabulous afternoon. The monastery, the tram ride up, the bus ride down all really fabulous. Wish I had more time to spend relaxing.
Trip to remember. Ride in the cable car was very exciting for the kids. I miss for not climbing all the way up the Big Buddha statue.
Airport. A enormous airport the last time we came here it was just a island and we came by boat. Now it's very built up

Great experience. Taken a ferry from peir6 central to discovery bay . after 1 hour ferry reach lantau island . Cristal trolley to big Buddha is great experience .its a big island of hongkong .great experience and enjoyed being on This island.

Peaceful. We spent 4 days on Lantau at the end of our Asian adventure and had a fabulous time to chill and relax at the end of a wonderful and exciting, but busy, trip. Discovery Bay on Lantau Island is a perfect oasis of calm yet only a 25 minute ferry journey away. Lovely plaza with lots of eateries, free shuttle bus service between the hotel we stayed in and the plazas - nothing negative to say about the place.

Afternoon Lantau & Monastery. Our tour guide (Andy) was blatantly drunk and often popped off to refresh. The tour was rushed and his commentary and instructions garbled, which led mid understandings and one couple being late. If this is the standard I cannot recommend it.

Scenic Cable Car Ride. From Tshim Sar Tsui we took a MTR, changed train at Lai King to the last sop at Tung Chung.. AS the queue to the Cable was winding like a snake, trough the forum of Trip Advisor, we took a bus from Tung Chung to Ngong Ping Buddha Monastery.Walked up the statue & had lunch at Tung Chung shopping complex. It was a scenic view in an all clear cable car. One of our group has to close her eyes when the cable car was hovering above the sea.

Lantau - green Island. We stayed 2 nights with friends on Lantau. The fresh, green hills were a wonderful contrast to Hong Kong Island and we could observe beautiful birds and butterflies in tranquillity.A visit to the giant Buddha and Monastery is a must as is the Cable Car ride.

peaceful getaway. we visited family and enjoyed the peaceful surroundings of the hills,listening to the birds, seeing the wandering buffolo, and enjoying a beer in the relaxed waterfront bars and restaurants

Worth a visit. Get the MTR there and when you exit the station there is a factory outlet shopping centre with bargains to be had. The main attraction here is the gonada ride up to the Big Buddha. You MUST prepay for the gondola ride or you face a long wait at busy times. We waited in a line for nearly 2 hours. There are also lots of trails crossing the island for those who like that sort of thing. But be warned there are some very steep hills to negotiate.
Disney Hong Kong and the Big Buddha. Spend two days visiting Lantau Island. One day for Big Buddha, and one day for Hong Kong Disney. Wonderful!!!

Fantastic day. Loved the bus trip up the peak of the island to gaze at the big Buddha . Lots of stairs . We wrre there on a day of swirling mist , low cloud and winds . Added to the atmosphere ! We ate at the vegetarian café - excellent .
brave the steps to see the budha. after a ride on the cable cars, brave the many steps and climb to the top to the big buddha. Visit the temples for some gifts and bread candy.

Beautiful landscape. Great place to visit if you want to get away from the city. To enjoy it better take one of the local buses and enjoy the view. Many landmarks in the island, giant Buddha, Tai-O village...

Breathtaking views and atmosphere. This review is specifically for the hike up Lantau Peak which we did completely spur of the moment. Tucked in behind the Buddha near the Path of Wisdom is this beautiful trail that leads you up to Lantau Peak. It was very walk-able with no specialist equipment and the views along the way were spectacular. Although it is relatively long and remember you have to get down again so take water with you. On the day we went up there was mist around so it was very surreal to climb up through the mist layer and survey from the top the surrounding peaks. Definitely worth the time and effort if you are feeling like some physical exercise after the Buddha.

BEAUTIFUL LOCATION. Lantau Island is one of the most beautiful places as a part of the Hongkong islands. Its connected with the mainland though a bridge and can be reached across through water and by road. A taxi ride from Tsuen Wan takes about 200 hkng dollars. if you have time, its worth a visit as its away from teh city hub and crowds but beautiful scenic place.
Don't miss this. The cable car ride to this Lantau Island is superb. The view from cable car is excellent. One should not miss this while visiting to Hongkong.
Lovely to visit. Some great sights to see on this island. The airport bus is a good, cheap one to get for the journey from Sha Tin to the airport.
Tiger Peak Lantau island. Probably the biggest island after main HK , Lantau island has the famous Tigers peak a Hikers dream. You get there by taking a ferry and Disneyland is also based there.

Over-rated. Very commercial tourist site. Best to take one-way cable car ride up and come down in the local bus (runs every 15 mins). Don't waste money on the other attractions up there.
Everything is very man-made for commercial purposes.

Spend a day. Cable car from Chung Tung MTR station, lunch at Lantau, easy walk to Big Buddha, wow, must see, visit monastery a must, picnic areas if you want to take own lunch.
Get bus back to ferry, which will take you back to Hong Kong quickly.
Giant Buddha!. Lantau Island is a famous tourist attraction in Hong Kong. You can go there by bus, by MTR or by the 360 cable car.

an nice island with green area away from HK's busy life. I often stay at the Novotel City Gate when I am in HK for 24 hours. I really like this island that offers a lot of activities in a more natural environment than the center of HK.

A new airport...and a giant Buddha dominate the island. Back in the 1990, as a resident of Discovery Bay, I trekked up the highest point in the Lantau Island and was rewarded with beautiful views of the forested areas, long sandy beaches, fishing villages and other calming features of the largest Hong Kong island. On a recent trip, made by taxi from Tung Chung metro station, I saw several changes in the landscape. Chek Lap Kok is fully operational now. There is considerable property development. The Big Buddha and Po Lin monastery have now become a popular tourist destination. Just before the Ngong Ping piazza, the square one crosses before the spiritual attractions, today there are several little touristy stops including souvenir shops, a Hong Kong movie set and a large Oscar statue. Lantau Island’s other attractions include the cabble-car rides over the mountains, wooded areas and water, and of course, the Disneyland resort. A visit to Lantau is highly recommended - both for kids and adults.

well worth a visit. Having checked out of our Hotel early and with a late flight to UK, the trip to L an Tau Island was a perfect way to spend a day away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The Staff in the Hong Kong Tourist Board were very helpful in planning our day. And gave excellent info a out transport on Lan Tau. The bus trip across t h e Island to Lin Po monestary is spectacular as is the first glimpse of the Buddha.

Nice little island where you get the quite and fun. I love Lantau Island. We took a yatch here. The island has some really peaceful parts with a lot of nature, but also offer attractions if you are looking for something to do. Both the Po Chi Lam monastry and Disneyland on this island is worth the visit.

Wonderful days outing taking in Big Budda and fishing village.. The highlight of the day was the cable car ride taking 25 minutes across the island up to the monastery. We took a tour and while expensive meant we avoided the Hugh wait for the cable car. The museum under the Budda well set out and the lunch very tasty and plentiful. The visit to the fishing village included a boat ride to see the houses on stilts and out a bit to see if we could see a pick dolphin. Generally a good visit even if we had to stop for the inevitable jewellery store.

nice trip. We went to Hongkong and We took the ferry from Kowloon then a bus around the island. You feel likeyou are in a different world from Hong Kong. Life seems more simpler. All in all a nice trip.lets come to visit
Beautiful. Amazing place with great views of the south China Sea and Lantau island. Home of the Tian Tan buddha. Best reached by the cable car from tung chung

Fantastic. It is so easy to get there as the train takes you right to where you need to go. The cable car ride is amazing regardless of the fact that it was foggy and we could not see anything but it is worth it. The system is very efficient, the cars are clean and the views amazing.

Another view of Hong Kong. Much less crowded than Hong Kong Island. A beautiful lush island. The airport and Disneyland are located here as well as the Big Buddha which was the main purpose of our visit. There are wild buffalo wandering around. The Buddha and monastery were impressive. If you have time I would recommend spending some time on the island.
Hiking!. Great to get out and hike, have afood meal and go to the monastery! Enjoy a day away from the busy streets of Hongkong.

As impressive as represented. Take the ferry over, catch the local bus to Buddha, ride the tram down, and take metro back. Not as complicated or as hard as it sounds, and a wonder trip. You avoid entering the monastery by the awful little tourist trap city.

Giant Buddha. The giant Buddha is truly impressive, as is the cable car ride to the summit. the local surroundings however, make you feel a little bit like going to EPCOT, did Disney have a hand in this?

HK must see, as long as you book cable car online and go early. To enjoy Hong Kong to its fullest, you have to enjoy the surrounding islands and mountains. Lantau is a good example of this but very touristy. If you don't book your cable car tickets online then don't go because you'll be queueing for hours.
A worthwhile day trip. Plan ahead so that you can visit the temple, see the big Buddha and have a side trip to the neighourbouing fishing village. Of corse try the local dishes for lunch.

Big Buddha & Monastery. We ventured out to Lantau Island to visit the largest bronze Buddha in the world! Not disappointed. Take the subway directly to Lantau - cost about 24HK. Easy ride - not too many people. This is pretty much one stop away from the Airport. Disney is one stop before - most of the families got off at Disney stop. Once you get out of the subway - walk about 5 minutes to the gondolas! There is a huge outlet mall at the subway station - typical North American outlet mall - all the designers. The line ups for the gondola was not too bad - about 15 min and we got there about 10am. The line moves fast. The trip up is about 20 mins - 5.5 KM.. on a clear day very cool with beautiful sights of the mountains and of course the airport & ocean. Once you get to the end - there is a small little touristing gathering of store - we looked at a few - prices were pretty good and you are able to bargain. Make your way past the stores to the steps of the big buddha.. long way up but amazing when you get there. If you walk a few minutes past the stair you will get to the monastery.. It was recently renovated.. Very cool.. great photos with amazing buddhas inside - especially the main area. Had a great time and just before the rush of tourist! You can also take a bus from the subway station but spend the money the gondola is pretty cool.
An interesting day tour.. We visited the Big Buddha, the Tai Po fishing village and the Crystal Cable Cars. The tour we were on helped us skip queues and made the day very relaxing.

A memorable Part of our Hong Kong Experience. The entire island could be toured if you have the time...not just Bog Buddah. The island's occupants provide visits a glimpse into Hong Kong life outside the big city.
disneyland and the big budha. disneyland was great, the big buddha was wonderfull. also you must visit the fishing village. the houses are on stilts

More to meet the eyes.... You can take a minibus but the best and fastest way to do the crossing to Lantau island is by cable cars (Ngong Ping 360). And if you like a better view take one of the cabins with a glass floor (at cost). You will finally arrive at the "village" where it is possible possible to buy just about everything one could want as souvenir. Many shops have been added over the years but the village still keeps its friendly apperance.From there, it's a short walk to the centre place where you can choose to go to Big Buddha on the right, or continue straight to the temple rich in color and so profoundly soothing.Limited food choice is available around the temple but it is vegetarian only. Food vouchers can also be bought just before climbing the steps to the Big Buddha.One of the best way to enjoy your trip to Lantau is to start early using the cable car (one way only) and take the mini bus to return stopping at the fishing village for a late meal.Either way, Lantau Island is well worth a visit. Preferably, choose a day with good weather that will give you a clear and un-interrompted view of the bay and of Hong Kong.
Great source of history and culture. It is a beautiful island with local markets and a fishing village. It give an insight into local life and the Big Buddha is aw inspiring.

So Much to Do!. One day for Lantau Island is definitely not enough. There are two ways to get there and both ways drop you off in radically different spots on the island. The quick way is to take the subway. Yellow Line takes you to Tung Chung (where the cable car is) or switch at Sunny Bay to the pink line for Disney Land. Or take the slow way via ferry. ZOMG 45 minutes and you end up in a sleepy town called Mui Wu. It's loverly. Silvermine Beach. Excellent street food. I took the bus from here to the opposite side of the island and Ngong Ping. The island is hilly and full of trees. Every once in a while you can see the water peeking at you from behind the trees. Lantau is amazing. I was told there was a bus that would take you to a fishing village at the most western part of the island to watch the sunset. There is also a big Buddha on the island. You seriously need about 3 days minimum to explore everything on Lantau.
Fresh Fish. This quaint little island has a few restaurants that are filled with tanks of freshly caught seafood. Yum.

Worth at Least a Day Trip. It is hard to describe Lantau as an island as it is connected to Hong Kong via the freeway and the MTR. Hence it is quite easy and very worthwhile to visit Lantau Island (close the airport). The island offers an incredible mix of activities for those coming to Hong Kong. As an example, Hong Kong Disneyland, Tai O, and Ngong Ping are all located on the island.

Be with the Big Buddha. You can take a Metro or Bus to Tung Chung and go to Lantau by cable car. It is quite good. The travel by cable car, the Big Buddha, The monastery are all worth seeing. The souvenir shops and eateries are also good. You get all sorts of foods at reasonable price. a nice place to spend a day, walk around, rest and relax.

Great attraction. i spent a day here last year. Is a great visitors place and should be seen. Get great views as you travel the cable car. The history and attractions are great. It's kept spotless and the walk up to the temple is a good workout to say the least. Although my friend hugo made it look easy. Not bad for a 5yr old I guess.

Spent an entire there in Lantau island and want more. On my last day in Hong Kong i visited this Island.It has all one might want: restaurant's, views, hikes, the big Buddha...due to time restraints I only had time for Tai O and the Big Buddha. Things that could help you plan your visit:1. During weekends (have no idea how it is during weekdays) the line to buy tickets to the cable cars and the line to the cable themselves are HUGE. Save time by buying the ticket online in advance. Here is the link to the site where you can buy the ticket. http://www.np360.com.hk/en/booking/np360-tickets-buy.html2. Pay those additional 30-40 HK dollars and upgrade yourself to the crystal cabin with a transparent floor. It is AMAZING!!! (if you have fear of heights then this is definitely not for you. On the other hand, if you have the fear of heights you will not be taking a cable car, right?)The cable car in general is a great experience. It is very long. (takes approximately 30 minute to go each way )3. If the line to the cable car is too big, consider going there by a taxi or a bus and take the cable car on your way down. It seemed to me that the line to go back is way shorter (especially if you take the crystal care- there are two lines and the one to the crystal cable cars is much shorter)4. If you like hiking- the island has several great hikes. One lovely hike starts if you pass by the wisdom path and continue straight. It takes you up the mountain with stunning views. I stumbled upon this track by a mistake and have no idea how it is called. Near the path of wisdom you have big gates, go through them and continue straight and you will be there. 5. Tai O is a popular destination. However i recommend it only if you have spare time. In general, it is a market with shaky houses above water. I didn't find anything particularly fascinating about this place. If you do go there, take a boat ride to see the dolphins. You might not see the dolphins, but you will enjoy the ride and the view of the island. 5. If after visiting the big Buddha you want to go to Tai O ( the fishermen village) and you have a limited time (and the line to the bus is huge), consider taking a taxi from the big Buddha to Tai O ( or the other way around - depends on your itinerary). It costed me 50 HK dollars and saved the time of standing in the line waiting for the bus.The ride takes aproximately 20 minutes by texi6. If you decided to go straight to Tai O from Ngong Ping village (Instead of going first to the big Buddha) the bus ride takes approximately 50 minutes. I started my Lantau island visit by going to Tai O first. It was friday and Easter holidays. The line to the bus was extremely long and it took me 1.5 (!!!) hours to get to the bus. (The line to the cable cars that take you to the big Buddha were a bit shorter that day :) ). So check the two lines first and decide where to start your day (at Big Buddha or at Tai O). The lines from Tai O to the Big Buddha, and from the Big BUddha to Tai O are not that long so consider changing plans according to the length of the lines. 7. The cable cars close at 18:00. 8. The island is close to the airport ( took me 10 minutes by taxi) so consider taking your luggage with you and leave it in the cable care (360 ) luggage storage. It costs 80 HK dollars per suitcase. I first tried to leave my luggage in the mall near by (the outlets) but it was all occupied. If you don't have time going there and back with suitcases (which is also no fun) go for the cable car storage. The prices: In the outlets mall - for the first 5 - 20 HK dollars for each two hours for each cell. Then the price changes. In the cable car storage- 80 HK dollars for the entire day (until 18:00) for one suitcase. I wish i had more time to explore the island!Enjoy!

A must-see Village. To go to Lantau Island, one must ride the cable car. The cable car never fails to amaze me, indeed the longest i've ridden and not scary at all because you get to enjoy a good view of Hongkong. Climbing 196 steps to get to Big Buddha was a worthy challenge, really fulfilling. And there is the Po Lin Monastery to visit too. There are also a number of shops to look into, and restaurants to try out. Lantau Island is definitely a must-see!

Good even in bad weather. We took the cable car which must be one the longest5 in the world. Then we did the Big Budda and had lunch in the village near the v=cable car terminal. Also visited the monastery and surrounding sights. The weather was foggy and on the way back on the cable car it was like a movie but we enjoyed everything and I rate this a must for a visit to Hong Kong, much better than the Peak tram.
A nice island. We went there to visit Disneyland and big Buddha. We were amazed by the view from cable car to big Buddha. We made friends with local, they were really friendly.

Worth a visit - see the big buddha and Tai O fishing village. It is a nice outing and a enjoyable experience. You have to start early like 8 AM to avoid the crowd and long line for the gondola at the end of the MTR stop (take the MTR Tung Chung line toward Tung Chung, end of line and follow the sign to the gondola cable car). There are 2 difference ticket prices - the "standard" gondola or the "crystal" gondola. The latter has as crystal floor which you can see through hence it's more expensive - screw that, it's not worth the extra cost. Take the standard one which you can see the nice and better view through the window.After arriving at the top you will go through the Ngong Pi market street that leads to the big buddha statue. You will also want to take the 21 bus to go to the Tai O fishing village. Don't waste your money on joining any tours, you can do this all by yourself and take your time to enjoy.

Discovery Bay, Disneyland and Mui Wo. The best Thai restaurant is at Discovery Bay Plaza, two mintues walk from the DB Ferry terminal. Lantau Island has a few fantastic hiking trails. The hike from DB to Mui Wo is very easy and takes around 1.5 hours if you stop to take in the views. Lunch or dinner at one of the local seafood restaurants along the water near the Mui Wo Ferry Terminal is a great way to end your hike. Disneyland is great fun for the kids. Take the MTR to Sunny Bay station and change trains to Disneyland. You can stay at Disneyland Hotel. Great fun!

Cable car 5 star. The cable car ride was very enjoyable and we picked the standard cabin, and did not find much of a difference between the crystal and standard cabin. The seating capacity might be different i guess. The view from the cable car was really nice.
Quiet sleepy island. nice change from the hustle of Kowloon and H.K. Go visit the Big Buddhe and take the cable car. Can be crowded on weekends when mainland Chinese tourists abound

Nice view. This has good view in Hong kong. fulls of greenries hills, get to see mtr running on side of the road and beautiful sea along with it. Big buddha cable car ropes can be seen and the whole island feels like a vacation place.

Lots to do. Lantau is where the new airport was built so if you have been to Hong Kong you have been to Lantau. Ways to get there included the MTR, taxi or ferry from Wan Chai. The big Buda is worth a visit and if you have kids, there's a Disney resort, bit pricey but kids are worth it. I like the bars near the ferry port and there is also a busy fishing village where you can eat fish caught hours before, recommended

A visit to Lantau Island,. We took a 40 minute cable car ride to the Big Buddah and monastery .Spent a peaceful day here.Then went to Tai O a small fishing village where all the homes are built on stilts.Had a boat coastal ride here also.
A cozy quiet area to rest. I came here during my journey in Hong Kong, just to rest before I went to Disneyland. It's an average little area, but it's quiet, and have a little village feels to it.
Lantau - Fabilous. Take the Ferry from the Central Quay and a short bus ride when you get to the island. The Buddhist temple and Statue are a sight to behold.. Just wonderful

Take the cable car and visit Tai O. Although we were unlucky to have a foggy day when we visited, so much so we couldn't even see the big buddha, I would still strongly recommend this is on any visitors list. The cable car was excellent and the little shops at the top, varied with lots souvenirs and even a Starbucks! The visit to Tai O shows the other side of Hong Kong a boat trip to see the fishermans houses is a must.

Zen, beautiful . Beautiful scenery, a pity the weather was too hot! The place was filled with mainlanders and packed on weekends. Therefore, I would recommend to go early in the morning before the Weather gets too hot or crowded with people.

The 'big island'. Lantau is the biggest island of the SAR, bigger than Hong Kong island, where the CLK airport, Ocean Park, and Disneyland are located. But the interesting part may be the old fishing villages now turned touristic. Englsih is spoken as many expatriates live here. Despite much change and modernisation, the fishing village of Tai-O retains much of its old charm. The setback is that it is a bit far away.

"Wow". The journey from our hotel to Lantau Island was an adventure in its self the MTR is amazing and easy to use and the cable car ride up past the airport is a joy especially on a clear day as it was for us,if visiting allow plenty of time to que for cable car and be sure its a clear day,

A very good day out. This was a fairly relaxed ¾ day tour that incorporated lots of different things. Firstly, after collection from the hotel, a ferry ride to Lantau Island, then a coach ride to a lovely local beach (and toilets), then onto a fishing village with a very short boat ride to view the houses on stilts followed by a further drive to the largest outdoor seated Buddha and lunch at the local Monastery that although vegetarian, was surprisingly good. For me the best bit came last - a ride on the nearly new 2.4km cable car from the Monastery (normal price for a single trip of £11.50) over the mountain, past Hong Kong airport and over the inlet to Tung Chung on the northern side of Lantau then a crack ride back to Kowloon and our Hotel. A good day out.

Day on the Island. Initially planned to make the most of the tour of Lantau Island, including a ride on the Crystal Cable Car, a visit to the Po Lin Monastery and Tian Tan Budda Statue, a tour of the Tai O village and, finally, a splash on one of the Lantau beaches. However- as all best laid plans are- it went wrong due to the delay at the Tung Chung Terminal, where we had to queue for almost 2 hours.Later, when we arrived on Lantau everything went absolutely perfect: we visited the Big Budda, had lunch in Ngong Ping Village, caught the last bus to the Tai O fishing village and were just in time to book the last boat ride. The main idea of the ride was an encounter with pink(or white) dolphins; although our guide told us it's too late for the dolphins to appear we were lucky to get a glimpse of them splashing quite close to the boat. There were 2 or 3 of dolphins, jumping out of the water on both sides of the boat and it was impossible to predict where they appear next ; watching them was such a pleasure, it was definitely the highlight of the Lantau Tour.

This island have got everything!!. Yes, one of the best Airports in the world located in Lantau, Big Buddha? yes they have a big big one, a Monastery or two? yes, next to the Buddha, long long cable car with amazing views? yes all the way to the Buddha, Tai O? yes this is HK believed or not, this little fishing village is part of SAR, and you can get the cheapest dolphin tour in the world, yes for about 30HK you can go an see pink dolphins, I went 7 times with family and friends and I saw them 4 times, very good ratio for a wild life!!Discovery bay and some other beaches, plus if you passionate about trekking, you have got here more that 100klms of very challenging paths!!Enjoy
My favourite part of HK. It's an absolutely beautiful Island, an absolute must see whilst in HK. You will not be disappointed.

By far the best day we had . We spent half a day here. The very top where the big Buddha sits and the monastery is is calm and relaxed. We then took the bus to the fishing village. Loved this place. Felt like stepping back I time

Great cable car . Buy tix on lineDo self guided tourTake rain poncho or pay $hk40 for one.
