Vegetarian lunch at Lin po monastry is Huge. 96$hk pp. catch local buses to Tai O fishing village and do boat trip in little boat for $hk 25. Well wirth itSkip all the tourist crap at the pnong ping village Mtr back to hk Good visit

A fun-filled day!. We too a Greyline Tour to Lantau Island which included the marvelous cable car, the longest and most circuitous one we had ever ridden. We had a hazy panorama of the island, the airport and the Big Buddha. Then we toured the village after going to the Buddha and its museum the Buddha, found a wonderful gift store called the Chopstick Gallery where we learned about the differences between Chinese and Japanese chopsticks. We then purchased handmade teak chopsticks as gifts and they were big hits back home. We then went to the Po Lin Monastery where we had a fantastic and very filling vegetarian lunch- one of the best in Hong Kong, we thought. Then on to Tai O Village where we admired the locals fishing in their traditional hats and even got to see some pink dolphins! It was a jam packed day.

Lantau Island, a paradise. One of the most enjoyable places we visited. The first visit the cable car was closed for maintenance so we visited the Tai O fishing village by bus. We returned on the weekend and did the cable car trip to the big buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. It was well worth returning, the Ngong Ping village was a delight. Lovely shops and being a weekend it was a great atmosphere.

Those steps. Had a great day at Lantau Island, we were there the week cable car was under repair so had to take bus to the top which was ok my hubby was disappointed, those stair 290 something ) killer ) but had to be done

Amazing place full of culture and colour. Lantau Island was an amazing place to visit. Loved seeing the Big Budda (even though we're Christian) and taking in all the culture. The colour was amazing. It was everywhere. The visit to Po Lin Monastery for lunch was a highlight. They did a magnificent vegetarian lunch that anyone would be delighted to have. Our guide clearly told us where we could and couldn't take photos too, so that was helpful.A great day out and so much to see and do.

Escape from the hustle and bustle of HK.. We were in Hong Kong for four days and spent one of these on a trip to Lantau Island, including the Big Buddha and the fishing village of Tao O. Of course these places are all tourist destinations, and I'm sure they get very busy at the weekends, but a mid week trip in March proved to be a great get away from the constant busy-ness of the city. The Ngong Ping Monastery, which hosts the Big Buddha, is a hug complex which swallowed up the numbers and was well worth the visit. We chose to continue by bus to Tao O, and again there were other tourists but nothing too hectic and the village was traditional and peaceful.Unfortunately the 'skytrain' was closed for maintenance the day we were there, but we still had a full day out using the MTR and the bus system on the island.
A Day with Budha. Take a day trip to island, tour guides are local knowledgeable and very helpful. Day ended with Skytrain which was incredible.

A serene moment away from the buzzing city. When people think of Lantau Island, they probably would be thinking of the Giant Buddha Statue (a.k.a Tian Tan Buddha Statue). Since the airport is pretty close by, people would actually replace their bore transit time (if they have quite a few hours (5-6 hours) to kill) in the airport and take a mini trip down to visit this renowned touristy site.The 34- metres tall bronze statue faces the North, overlooking the sprawling land of Chinese people. This majestic statue is one of Hong Kong's most famous tourist hotspot. People from land near and far, the East and the West, would come to this place and immerse in the most galvanising cultural experience of a lifetime.For a detailed article with LOADS OF PICTURES on Lantau Island, The Big Buddha, and awesome walking trails to take, visit: http://travelwhenever.com/treks-lantau-peak-hong-kong/

Amazing and peaceful!!. Lantau Island is a must!!! u must go there!! the best part was the big Buddha and wisdom path!! Not much ppl know abt wisdom path but its the best part of Lantau island! I wish i could stay there fr hours!!!! Its peaceful and quite wid very few ppl up there compared to big buddha and po lin monastry!! The food was amazing. the best veg food i've ever had!!

Away from the city. A nice getaway from the hustle and bustle city. However, it is still a tourist attraction, so it can be quite noisy. But the air is fresher as it is up on a hill and limited transportation over there.

definatelly a must for HK!. this is a very nice place for 1 day trip! it takes you away from the busy life of the city to a more natural environment.Loved the green view, and the hills coming down into the beach/water, as well as the fresh smell of wild flowers/vegetation.take into account and investigate if there are maintenance works on the way to the Big Buddha, as this might make your trip longer by 2h at least.

Worth visiting the buddha only. Buddha is amazing big. Other than that there is nothing interesting too commercialise there is starbucks and subway there. If interested there is a "Lucky Cat" Or "Zhao Cai Mao" Bracelet shop worth buying.
Big Buddha . Went there to catch a glimpse of the Big Buddha but sadly it was misty but still enjoyed the cold air and the view up there nonetheless~ great place!!

A break from the city. We went to Lantau Island via the longest suspension bridge in the world, beautiful in itself. We visited a beach across the island, no people, just peace and quiet. Beautiful scenery and plenty to do. We visited the local fishing village, the Big Buddha and rode back to the main town via the cable car. a really good day even for the less mobile member of our party.
The ngong ping 360 wow. The 360 is one of its kind attraction. The cable cars take you high up in the sky surrounded by beautiful mountains and scenery. A must must visit in HK.

Lantau. Travel in 360* cable car, one of the longest in the world itself was enjoyable and nice journey. Ngong ping village where Big buddha is there is a nice place. Restaurants are available here for lunch. Nice place to spend 4-5 hrs.

lots to see in small area. we got the day bus pass 55 HK$ we saw the big budha, but sadly it was misty, then went onto the fishing village and boat ride to sea the dolphins, (didn't see dolphins) but the boat ride was pleasant, also a small market there, I think there were 2 other bus rides on the island , a pier and a beach , but we ran out of time as it was our day to fly home, but an easy and interesting thing to do,

Great day out from Hong Kong. Lantau Island boasts a number of attractions, and visiting a combination of them makes for a womnderful day out. Take the MTR to Tung Chung. From there take the cable car to Ngong Ping village. The cable car ride is absolutely breathtaking and it's worth the trip just for this ride. If you're scared of heights, you might want to look at alternatives though, but fantastic views of the airport and the harbour and just a wonderful all round ride. You won't know which way to point your camera. At the other end of the cable car you have to walk through Ngong Ping Village to get to the monastery and Big Buddha. They are very much worth looking at, even if you don't want to climb all the stairs to the Buddha. The village howver is just a commercial strip of shops and there is nothing historical about them at all. Quite tawdry in fact, but you can get drinks or a meal there. Once you've seen the monastery, catch a taxi to Tai O village. If there are a few of you a taxi is by far the cheapest option. Once at the village, its a wonderful walk through the traditional little fishing village. Once you've seen the village do the whole thing in reverse to head back into HK. This all makes a great day out.
amazing place. Best thing i visited in hong kong. It's really beautiful! It's very affordable - too bad the cable car was under maintenance. Highly recommended site.

Beautiful!. You definitely need a one day to go and enjoy Lantau Island. But believe me, if you want a different experience other than the city life, you need to visit Lantau island. It was so relaxing and peaceful. Tired, but nice. It was raining when we got there though. But we had fun taking pictures of the beautiful surrounding, as well as the Big Buddha (even though we didn't climb the stairs).
Hong Kong history. Try and visit the fishing village built over the water.This is an authentic slice of HK history, but be ready for some surprises in the fish markets.

Great escape compared to other attractions. Worth a visit. Easily accessible with the mtr then the cable car. Try to go in the early morning to avoid the crowd. Will take only half a day. Best part was taking the cable car with the superb view. Many others also hike all the way to the top. -_- wonder how long it will take though...

Great escape . This place is awesome escape if you are fed up with the city, skyscrapers, crowds... Just take mrt ti tung chung and catch one of the buses to get of the radar to the nature / big Buddha (much better / cheaper and, if you count waiting in the line, also faster way than cable line) /fishing village. Good mirror to the everyday Hong Kong.

Definetly worth a visit. Went to Lantau Island, it was so peaceful n relaxing, we enjoyed our visit to the big Buddha even though it was wet and cold. We were very impressed by the cable car ride, we took the economy car ride and were impressed that we didn't have to wait long for the cable car, it was a very relaxing ride up in the cloudes for about 1/2 an hour, but we were lucky we got there the day before it closed for maintenance.
Fantastic. I just loved the Lantau Island and the sky rail is amazing. Loved the way to reach the buddha. I have been in it 2 times and just cant have enough of it.

Nice outing but do not pay to get inside. This was a nice trip by train followed by a bus ride on line 23 as the cable car was closed till 30 March. When we were about to climb up to the Buddha a woman called us from a counter and we were sold a ticket to go inside for 36 dollars each. We did it because we thought it was obligatory but in fact it is not and the tiny exhibit you have to pay for is a joke - nothing worth seeing and no explanation in English. SO DO NOT FALL FOR THIS SCAM! Apart from that we enjoyed the trip and the views from up the mountain.
Big Buddha. Liked everything except the windows of the cablecar - needed cleaning! The whole trip was very convenient and not to crowded as we went in the late afternoon.
Very good place to visit!,. Lantau Island is a Very good place to visit!, in Hong kong, all greenery, Big buddha statue, you can spent whole day there with family
Amazing Cable Car. Nice place cold and especially used cable car to the island in the foggy condition and cold, I think really nice experiences

Daytrip recommended. A daytrip to Lantau Island is recommended. You can take the train to Tung Chung and take the cable car or bus to Ngong Ping village.We took the bus as it is quite cheap there are no queues unlike the cable car.So in the monastery area we hike a little bit to the top to find the giant Buddha. There is also the wisdom path.After we took another bus to Tai O fishing village. One can enjoy seafood snacks and meals there.

top ten most visiting place in hk. Lantau Island is the largest island in Hong Kong, located at the mouth of the Pearl River. Administratively, most of Lantau Island is part of the Islands District of Hong Kong.

Great Day Trip to the top of the mountain. From Tung Chung you can take the cable car or the local buses to get to the Monastary and the Big Buddha. Lots of small shops and things to eat from local food stalls. Vegetarians catered for at a few restaurants. Main attraction is the Buddha but the buildings in the Monastary are very interesting and have been refurbished in the last few years. Try to go on a clear day , be aware that in the summer it gets hot and up on the mountain the sun can be very strong so kids need hats and plenty of water. Not recommended if raining or very windy. You can hike around the mountain tops or take the bus up and return on the cable car. If you have never been it is a good day out. Fantastic display of flowers in Monastary in the right season.

Good Place to visit. Lantau island is really good place to visit in Hong Kong trip. You can reach there by MTR & Bus or by cable car also. Cable car is good experience. You can go in bottom glass cabin. About lantau is its a clean place and big Buddha.

A must visit in your Hong Kong itinerary!!. The cable car that takes you to the Lantao islands was the longest, steepest and most thrilling cable ride of my life!! The experience of riding this cable is unmatched. As the cable car leaves from the Tung Chung terminal, you will be transported to a different world completely. Within a few seconds, the entire HK International Airport becomes visible in a single glance. In the next few seconds, you find atleast thirty cable cars like your hanging behing you on the same rope. Soon you reach the top of the summit, only to see the next even steeper section of the cable ride ahead of you!! This part of the ride takes you deeper into the Lantao islands, and higher with each passign seconds. A stage comes, when strong lateral winds start swaying the heavy car , and this wind flows continously. As if this was not enough, the thirst section of the cable car, takes you almost to a point which is so high that is not visible at all behind the clouds , and for a moment when you see cable cars ahead of you entering and disappareing the clounds one by one , you are bound to say a prayer or two!!.Finally after 25 minutes of this fantastic journey , we reach the Ngong Ping village which houses the giant Buddha bronze statue which is a marvel in itself. The entire place is very scenic and on a sunny day it is the perfect outing. Man-sized candles being offered to the Gods can be seen.Then there is the Tai O Fishing village which can be reached by bus. Boating at Tai O is just ordinary. Visit Lantao Island for the Cable Car, the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery in that order!

Worth the time and effort. Lantau Island has the largest Buddha statue and monastery, both well worth a visit. It is easily access by taking the MTB (subway) to its terminus and then a gondola to the peak of the island. The trip up had great scenery, and the area around the monastery and Buddha had attractions worth seeing, and hiking trails for those so inclined. It is worth taking the day and immersing in the experience.

Big Buddha, Disneyland & Shopping. Lantau Island has a lot for everyone. From Kids to nature enthusiasts to Shopping. Visit Outlett mall at Tung Chuk for great shopping deals on big brands. Big Buddha, Ngong Ping 360 for nature trails & amazing views. The amazing Disneyland for a wonderful experience for kids...
Amazing Experience. The Buddha statue is the most amazing and the place is extremely serene. The cable car ride is one of the longest from where you can see entire Hong Kong Airport.

A nice getaway out of Hong Kong. Lantao Island is worth visiting to see the famed giant Buddha and a few other nearby sites of historical and cultural significance. In a nice hilly, wooded setting, it's a nice escape from the concrete jungle of Hong Kong for a couple of hours! The cablecar that will take you out to the island is easily enough reached by the MTR, but the downside is that the demand for the cablecar just completely overwhelms their capacity. We waited in a zig-zagging queue for just over one hour to buy tickets and then board the cablecar - so make sure you factor that into your visit! The lineup for the return cablecar ride wasn't so bad.

Absolutely beautiful. The cable car ride is worth the trip in and of itself. Once there, the village is lively and the monastery is a must see. Nice vegetarian lunch offered for a nominal fee. It's a long climb to the Tian Tam Buddha, but it's majestic. The view from atop the memorial are gorgeous. Also include a visit to Tai O, a small fishing village a short bus ride away.
Cable Car lovers heaven. Very exciting view from the Cable Car: The airport, the skyscrapers, and green hills with small paths in one landscape.

One of the worst tourist traps I've ever seen. Is just horrible! A concrete theme park with shops and snacks. Very close to this horror you have the very interesting fishermen village of Tai O, historical home to the Tanka boat people. Another world!

Hong Kong must see attraction, beautiful island, friendly locasl and the beaches, big buddy statue. Sadly often a place missed when stopping over at Hong Kong. The island has so much to offer, beautiful beaches with friendly locals. Lovely walkways through the forrests and the big buddy statue is truly remarkable. Defiantly worth seeing. I wished I would have spend more time on the island rather than Honk Kong itself. Will defiantly make a point of staying a couple of days when stopping over in Hong Kong again. Also good bus connection or you can negotiate a taxi fare if time is short. The airport is on the same island. There is als a ferry service from Central Hong Kong.

Awesooooooome !!. I loved the weather there as I visited in Feb and totally enjoyed Disneyland. It is connected by an MTR, and the place is isolated but dent feel so, with a lot of people and restaurants around.
Lots to see!. There is plenty to do on Lantau from Tai O fishing village, Dolphin watching, shopping and Dim Dum in Tung Chung, The Ngong Ping Cable car up the mountain to the Big Buddha.
Worth the visit. its worth to visit and explore whats in this island...u can hv evetything here...from food to clothes....much much fun stuff to enjoy....

Cable car ride. We visited Hong Kong at the time of Chinese new year. We choosed Saturday to go to lantau island by cable car. From hotel we took metro to reach the place. Starting point of cable car is in vicinity of metro station. But unfortunately because of Chinese new year holidays & also being a Saturday there was a loooong unending queue for cable car. But later after some time some employees of cable car were circulating some brochures about express pass to cable car. The rate was more than double the normal fair but we opt to choose it because we just didn't want to waste our time standing in queue whole day!That was really express pass..worth. so without wasting time in queue we went for cable car & the ride was worth.. spectacular views!!!Island has good options of restaurant, souvenir shops, entertainment shows & big buddha statute.So the place is good but consider the time (as the whole tour needs at least half day) & also the holidays cause of long queue!

Not to be missed.. Take a day trip to Lantau, The ferry takes you to the island where you visit a traditional fishing village, the Big Buddha and lunch at the Po Lin Monastery and the Ngong Ping Cable Car ride home to the bus terminal. This is a great day and the guides are very informative.

big buddha, lots of steps. bring comfie shoes, you will want them. A beautiful area, that's been kind of turned into a Disney experience. Lots of places to spend some money and get a souvenir. There's also a gondola ride across the top of the island that will take you to a very busy outlet mall.
Pleasant trip. We took the ferry from Kowloon then a bus around the island. You feel like you are in a different world from Hong Kong. Life seems more simpler. All in all a nice trip.

Excellent tour. Spent the day at Lantau Island - going over and back in the cable car - we upgraded to the crystal cabin (glass bottom floor) totally worth the upgrade!!! Beautiful island, with plenty to look at around the Buddha also. We had an amazing vegetarian lunch at the monastery - the best meal we had in Hong kong!! BRILLANT lots of souvenirs are available in the stalls at bottom of stairs. We then travelled to a nearby fishing village which was fantastic and one of the highlights of our trip. We got taken out in a boat to see the White dolphins - seen 2. Then had free time in the village - tried some local foods - cheesy lobster, glazed meats and almond biscuits - all well worth a try!!! A wonderful tour and well worth a look at!!

Giant Buddha. Decided to visit Lantau Island under our own steam, not with a tour. Used the Hong Kong metro system (very efficient, clean, spacious, easy and cheap) to get to Lantau Island where we had hoped to catch the cable car up to the Giant Buddha. Unfortunately we picked one of the two days that it was closed for maintenance checks so had to catch one of the buses. Worth the half hour ride though to visit this peaceful and spiritual place and we also got to see quite a bit of the island along the way. The climb to the top of the Buddha is not for the faint hearted. I've no idea how many steps there are but it felt like a million!! On the plus side, you get to work up an appetite for the snack or meal that's included in the cost of the ticket and which is served within the grounds of the Monastery at the foot of the steps to the Buddha. When you reach the top there are more bronze statues along with small exhibition rooms, 2 tiny souvenir kiosks and amazing views from this magnificent landmark. Enjoyed the tasty hot noodles and spring rolls whilst sitting next to giant incense sticks burning and listening to the Monks chanting their prayers - very soothing. Well worth a visit and by arranging the trip ourselves my sister and I saved over £100

Fabulous Day Trip. Well worth a visit. . We booked a day excursion that took us over on the ferry. Everything in Hong Kong is on time and this day was no exception. The island itself was peace and tranquility from a busy city close by. Beaches are lovely and while we had poor weather you can easily see how on a sunny day it would be beautiful. Obviously you visit the Big Buddha while here which is well worth while along with some temples and the old fishing village. Rounding up the trip with the cable car journey back to the mainland. It was really a great day out. We booked via Viator which was really good. They used a company called Tour East. Can't recommend them highly enough.

Amazing, magical place!. Well worth the trip, the views from the Ngong Ping cable car are amazing and the Big Buddha is just stunning. The temple at the top of the hill is very cool. The "town" at the hill caters to the tourists, however it almost has a theme-park feel to it, not necessarily fitting the Big Buddha that's right beside it.. but its a tourist attraction so it's understandable. Still I highly recommend it, great way to spend your day (or even half of it) if it's not too hot.

Nice place and nice way to get to work. We stayed in the Silvermine Hotel on the island, and what a nice place to be. We had a room with seaviews and a short walk to the ferry, which we took every day to get into Hong Kong (20 mins). The island itself is small but very well adapted for everyone, shops and bars are very close to the hotel. The hotel has been better days, but is maintained at a high standard and room are very comfortable.Its a way from the hussle and bussle of the main Island (HK) but near enough to get to when you want to.Nice place to be for sure.

Lots of shopping!. Lovely island to see the Buddah. Make sure you have time to shop for souvenirs - don't get the ones inside the Buddah. There is a small city before you get to the cable cars and it is filled with souvenirs of the buddah!

lots to see. Lantau island has the airport, the big buddha with the ngong ping cable car ride as well as disneyland amongst the many attractions. well connected in most parts by MTR. though some parts are slightly inaccessible adn thus hotel bookings on this island need to be thought through in terms of connectivity.

Lots to do. It is a wonderful place. Great beaches, lovely country side, home of the Big Buddha and Disney World. Remote and green; at any beach sit long enough and water buffaloes will come to greet you. Interesting walking and biking trails.Ngong Ping 360 cable cars will swiftly take you to the Big Buddah or you can ride the bus and you'll beautiful nature and beaches along a long winding road. End your nature day at Citygate and have a meal or put in some last minute shopping. Something for everyone.
MUST SEE. Make this a MUST SEE. Perfect holiday destination with true feel for the monasteries and fishing villages

A must see in Hong Kong. We all know the Big Buddha, which is worth going, but from there, take the bus 21 to visit the village of Tai O, which is a more authentic fisher village. To get to the Buddha, don't hesitate to take the Cable Car. It's thrilling.

The Great Escape from the Busy City of Hong Kong. after spending time in the big, bustling city, you may need a bit of a break. Luckily, there are a number of places that you can escape to quickly and reconnect with nature. One of my favorite things to do in Hong Kong is to escape the city and explore nearby Lantau Island! Lantau Island is a can't miss while visiting Hong Kong.Read more about our Escape to Lantau Island Here: http://www.peanutsorpretzels.com/things-to-do-in-hong-kong-lantau-island/
Well worth the visit.. Loved the Tai O fishing village. I initially thought there would not be much to see on the island but I think this quickly became the highlight of my trip to Hong Kong.
A must, don't miss it. The ride is fun, take a ferry across and come back by cable car. The best part eat in the monastery, delicious

Lantau. We went here by bus to visit the Big Buddha and Po Lin monastery. A lovely quiet place to rest. We also went to. Tai O village and strolled around the market. Then went on a boat cruise around the village on stilts and to see the pink dolphins. Amazing.
The Cable Car is a must. A number of items including the Cable Car i.e Golden Buddha the village Disney World and Theme Park. Well worth a day or more to visit
An experiance. We queued up to take the sky line over to Lantau island. The journey itself is quite long but worth it as you get some incredible views.
Big Buddha. Great place to visit outside of Hong Kong. They have a show to see and places to eat. We had the best tofu dessert there.
A grerat getaway. If you want to leave the hustle and bustle of HK this is a perfect destinationAway from the madening crowds! Nice shops and pleasant dining on the water
Island worth visiting. various modes of transport to get there. A ferry ride is always fun. Depends on the weather. The Big Buddha is a must followed by a vegetarian meal at the monastery.

Great Experience and Loads to do. We spent a day at Lantau Island, it was easy to get to from Central Hong Kong and we visited the Big Buddha, the fishing village as well as seeing the local White Dolphins during a short boat ride. Really friendly people and well worth the visit.

Spend a day to enjoy the beach and the big Buddha and Tai O. You can take an hour ferry to go from Central (express ferry takes 30 minutes). Sunday and public holiday will charge a higher fee, if you travel in a group, go during Monday to Saturday to save money. Other option is to take the Ngong Ping 360 cable car from in Tung Chung. You can take the MTR to Tung Chung Station from Exit B. Do check their website as if the weather is no good or too windy, they am suspend their services. One way is US$15, if you choose the crystal floor which you feel like sitting in the air, it is US$23. Queue can be long, better don't go in Hong Kong holidays. They also close at 6pm.If you choose to go by cable car, it take you to the big Buddha and you can have vegetable lunch at the temple and take bus to go to Tai O. Do check the time table at the bus stop, the ride is 20 minutes. If you have time in Tai O, go to the Cafe at the sea front across the bridge. Once you crossed the bridge, it is the wet market, turn right and walk straight down to the street. The Cafe is next to the tofu shop. The Cafe has a balcony built on the sea and has a spectacular view of the hill and you see the wooden houses built on both sides of the shore. If you go in the morning, you can take the bus to Mui Wo, ask the driver to drop you at Lower Cheung Sha beach. As it is far away from the city, the beach is not crowded even during summer time. There are also restaurants at the beach.You can take the bus to Mui Wo to take the ferry back to Central. The ride is 25 minutes.Pick a sunny day and go.

Worth to visit & being with scenery... I always visit there by cable car as it is the most convenient way. Walking up to see the big buddha and experiences many locals making me back to the old days. It is another sideof being in Hong Kong as well. The seafood and many more are waiting for us to explore!!

Peace and Pleasure. After a frantic intense week working in HK city the 40minute journey to Lantau transforms your time in to a peaceful and pleasurable break. with some of the best sandy beaches in HK and except eateries you can combine relaxation with some tourist attractions that are a must on this island.
Lantau is splendid. There is a lot here. The Big Buddha and the Fishing Village are my favourites. I like taking the ferry there and then buses. An easy and fascinating day.

Peace and quiet in Hong Kong. Lantau is wonderful if you are in to hiking in particular. You will find a cornucopia of hiking trails, and it takes no time at all to get away from people and out into the peace and quiet of the countryside. Sunset and Lantau peaks are well worth the climb. There are some lovely, secluded beaches on the island too.

Lantau Island. Great visit to this remarkable island. Stopped by the Po Lin Monastery. It was a great experience. I would recommend this trip to anyone who never saw this side of Hongkong before. Don't forget to bring your camera or camcorder because you will not want to miss the opportunity to capture the beauty of this place.

Great beaches. We were visiting the great Buddha and then too a bus to the Tai O fisher village. On the way back we just jumped out of the bus on South Lantau Road where you find stunning beaches. In February the weather was mild and there were almost no people. Really enjoyed a romantic walk before we took the bus back to the Tung Chung to go back to Hong Kong by Metro.

Relaxing Island. This island is very relaxing, quite and pleasant to stay. Beach is nearby, no private cars, only buses. Very beautiful due to located in a isolated place surrounded by mountains and bay.

Breathtaking views and cultural splendur. Lantau Island had amazing views and so much Hong Kong culture to experience it would be criminal not too!! It is a welcome break from the hustle bustle of the mainland but also has some western features like a Starbucks etc. Amazing and a definite recommend.

An engineering marvel. TAke the cable car it will render you speechless. The Buddah is spectacular and worth the climb to the top. The view from the top is stunning. Plenty of places to eat once your there.

Away from the Hustle of Hong Kong. Lantau Island, Big Buddha and Monastery were a wonderful experience for a couple of our age. The Cable car trip back was a completely different experience from the Bus trip that took us.

LOVE LANTAU!. My most memorable experience from Hong Kong. I send all of my clients to do this and they typically say the same thing. It is so unexpected in such a dense, bustling, busy city to come across such a peaceful, ancient place. Make sure that you go on a clear day so you can see the Buddha as you come over the rise in the hills. I noticed some walking trails and even saw some mountain bikers out there. It seems there is a lot to do beyond the monastery giant Buddha. Rest assured a very magical experience awaits you in this area of Hong Kong. I A tip: Pre-purchase your return gondola tickets as there is a typically a massive line to wait in.

A must do on a trip to Hong Kong. either jump on our tour or take a cab over here. Not sure about Disneyland (we had no interest), but seeing the big Buddha, the old fishing village and the Ngong Ping cable car are all a must. Take the full day tour if you can - it all goes by too fast and all three could be done a day trips by themselves.

Peace and Tranquil. Brilliant cable car ride. You have to chose the crystal ride, its amazing! The shops,the markets in the quaint island are cute, the way to get to lantau is the best. the big buddha at the very end of the island takes the cake

great hikes, local seafood restaurants. Hikes on Lantau are great and can be pretty demanding. The outlet mall at TungChung has dozens of top brands at - well - outlet prices. The Ngong Ping cable car to the Big Buddha is a nice excursion - especially on a fine clear day with great views of the airport. A daytrip to the old traditional fishing village of Tai O is another worthwhile excursion (take a bus from the bus station adjacent to Tung Chung MTR - about 45 minutes). And there are a few great seafood restaurants almost unknown to tourists - a handfull of good local and authentic ones are in Ma Wan Chung, a small fishing village just opposite the airport. There is a little shuttle van that goes from Tung Chung bus station to these restaurants.....

Simply a 'must do'. get the MTR to Tung Cheung at the end of the MTRs Orange line, then the aerial tramway up to the big Buda. The journey took us about an hour and a quarter in total. The Buda is impressive. It's not just a statue, there are multiple statues, a temple and a monastery to visit too. The detail and decoration are exquisite. There's a 'village' selling food, drinks and tourist souvenirs - some of which are quite tasteful. Next get the No 21 bus down to Tai O, a fishing village on stilts. We had ab 'eggy waffle' cooked on a barbecue as we watched, but there are also fish restaurants, Chinese style to enjoy. A great day out away from the bustle of the town.

A lovely, peaceful getaway. Lantau Island is easy to get to by MTR using an Octopus Card. Once you arrive at Tung Chung station it is well signed and an easy walk to the Cable Cars. By the way, you go passed an outlet centre with shops such as Nike, Tommy Hilfiger, Timberland and many more. We boarded a crystal gondala but there isn't really any need especially if you are using the gondalas up and down. We thought perhaps the queues would be quicker but they weren't. For every one crystal gondala there were 2 others. The views up were quite spectacular. You could look down and see the walking tracks to the top of the mountain and then eventually you saw the big Buddah in the distance. Once at the top there is a little village full of shops and clean toilet facilities so go while you can. Everything is well signed and the 268 steps weren't that bad! We wandered down the track to the Wisdom Sticks. There are quite a few walks and treks available. We then went back to the Village and caught the local bus to the fishing village. Once again, Octopus Card is accepted on this bus. It was a pleasant trip down. On arrival at the Village there are hawkers for passengers for the boat trips. We caught one that takes you past the houses on stilts then out to sea to see the white dolphins. And you do get to see the dolphins. A worthwhile boat trip. The Village is a fishing village so many, many shops with dried fish and other dried seafood. A bit smelly of course. An interesting little place. We spent an hour there which included the 20 minute boat trip. We then caught the bus back to the top of the mountain to catch our return gondala back however you could catch the gondala up and then a bus to the Village then another bus to Tung Chung or vise versa. We packed our own food for the day but there is pizza, Subway and other food outlets at the top. It is a good day out.

A must visit Jewel. Quaint, awesome pipe music, serenity natural to all Buddhist moasteries, the jungle walkways and the ropeways access... all make Lantau the best discovery for me in Hong Kong. To end it all, the outlet mall at the metro station gives something for everyone...worth spending a day even on a short visit
Must Visit. The Big Buddha, Disneyland and the airport are on this island. Plan on spending a day to cover the first 2 attractions.
Worth a look. The trip by cable car was nice. The Buddha itself was interesting but that whole area has such a commercial feel. We visited old fishing village which was interesting.
Lantau Island - great hiking!!. Fabulous hiking along the paths on the island! My best day in Hong Kong! Took the tram to the top and wandered the hiking paths!

A glimpse of old Hong Kong. To get to the Big Buddha by care involves a car journey n Lantau Island. This is a place where one can see a more traditional Hong Kong without the high rise. Sure family farms are slowly evolving into family housing compounds, but buffalo wandering the streets is a sight.

An island of surprises. The whole island is an interesting place with lots to to. The main attraction is Tian Tan the worlds largest cast bronze Buddha but there are other things to enjoy like the fishing village and the cable car ride.
Lantau. best part was the trM ride up. Beware of fog, it can obscure the view of the Buddha. The village atmosphere up top is delightful.

worth a visit but not on the weekend. Nice trip away from the city with the cable car giving great views of Lantau. The Buddha and Monastery are a sight to behold and worth the trip and queues.However, these are somewhat outdone by the Sunday hoards or mainland tours screaming at each other in a place of "serenity" as well as the tourist trap that is Ngong Ping. The thousand buddahs within walking distance of starbucks, pizza shops and I Love HK tat shops. Such is life in the new world I suppose.
Nice sights. Big buddha is amazing, the steps and painful tho haha. Cable car ride is amazing. the monestry was a little creepy walking around. Lots of food choices for people.
BIG BUDDA. Can you climb all the way to the top? I'm not sure how many steps it is but this is a neat way to get your exercise!

good weekend activity. I have visited Lantau Island a few times during several business trips to HK. Would recommend taking the glass bottom cable car across the bay (assuming you are not afraid of heights...). Good sight seeing and one must go visit the Big Buddha

Nice , just love it.... ...we came with the Ferry and take the Bus , tha walked around and under the Buddha, it was nice , very windy but good air.You can go to the Beach swim, go hiking or visit the Big Buddha , as most tourists do. Take the normal meal, not the deluxe option, you just have a better table, that's all.After stroll around and with the sky lift back. But you also can stay on the Island , as it is nice!

TAKE THE ROUND TRIP. It is easy enough to do this on your own. We caught the ferry from the Island - it was from Pier 6 or 7, then on Lantau it was a short walk to the bus stop to catch Bus No. 2. If you don't have a pass take some small change to pay cash as you board.After visiting the monastery you can either catch another bus from the bus terminal the number is clearly marked for the MTR or the cable car if that's your thing. Then onto the MTR back to Hong Kong.Monastery is interesting. We had the vegetarian lunch which was basic but OK apart from soup like dishwater!The island is beautiful and still largely unspoilt. Allow at least half a day. Fares are pretty reasonable.
Day trip. This was a very enjoyable day trip lots of interesting things to see all the figures & learning what they were & what originated from them.

So near-yet so far from the crowds!. Aside from seeing the Big Budha we found the bus trip there prompted the question "with all these beaches, where are all the people?!!"The views are gorgeous along the way and the serenity of the landscape and the water views beyond make you want to move there!

A welcome escape fro the hustle and bustle. Lantau Island is definitely worth the visit. The cable car gives you a great view of the airport (which I thought was pretty cool) and is just a lovely ride. The crystal cable car (glass bottomed) is not worth it. You're not looking out of the bottom anyway and everybody seemed to want to go on the crystal bottomed cars. That coupled with the fact that there are two normal cars to every crystal one meant that we had to line up for about 40 minutes while the normal car people just about walked on. But if you must take the crystal cable car take it one way and do it on the way back. A lot of people took that option but took the crystal car on the way up so the normal car line a lot longer at the other end. I got the snack voucher at the Big Buddha which allows you access into the Buddha. Not that much to see inside but the snack was worth it. More meal sized then snack sized. The meal voucher is expensive and I don't think is worth it. You can buy it up the top so I would wait until then rather than purchasing it at the base of the steps. I got it mainly for the access to the higher level viewing platforms but if that is the only reason you are getting it don't bother as people were just going up the exit stairs. There is so much more to do on Lantau Island though. Put a day aside. It's worth it
Take a Tour. This is one place you want to take a tour as most attractions are too spread out to see by yourself without a car. It's a nice day activity unless yo like to gamble (I dont).

Excellent. From shopping to cable cars. The city gates outlet mall is a good shopping place, if you are looking for brands and are ok with the last season trends. Otherwise shopping is spread throughout HK. The 360 cable car ride is not to be missed. This is the way to cross 2 hills to reach Nnong Ping where the Big Buddha is. The view from the cable car is amazing. you have the best view of HK international airport where atleast 10 flights land every hour. The greenery breaks the norm of high raised concrete buildings. And the destination is simply mind blowing. Take your time to explore and chill out for a while here.

An unusual journey.... Getting to Lantau is a bit of a journey but certainly worth it. Plan on at least a half day. The Big Buddha is really something to behold. Plan on getting a workout if you climb to the top!

Worthy 1-day trip. Will definitely recommend a day trip to Lantau Island if you have more than 3 days in Hong Kong. The 1-day trip was a refreshing change in scenery from Hong Kong Island with its mountain view and cooler weather. My parents even think that the island is the highlight of our Hong Kong trip as it's naturally calmer there. Lots to explore for the spiritual and common tourists alike.Besides, you can always stop by at the Citygate Outlet Mall before/after the Ngong Ping 360 ride to Lantau Island for some discount outlets shopping. Tip: We had our Peak tram passes with us and hence, were entitled for a 10% discount on the Ngong Ping 360. We were fine in the Standard cabin although kids may appreciate the Crystal cabin more. Alternatively, if your trip to Victoria Peak is scheduled for later, you may keep your Ngong Ping 360 tickets for a 10% for your Peak tram ride. Then again, the queue for tickets was really long and I would recommend to get the tickets online instead, if it reduces queuing time. Despite so, the trip was worth it but be sure to get an early start.

A planned village for tourists.. The lantau island was by far the best place in Hongkong. The trolley ride was around 30 mins on way.. with breathtaking panoramas on all sides. There is also the crystal floor trolleys which are basically glass bottomed to see the beautiful view beneath your feet.Beware everything on the island is super expensive as its designed for tourists, but its hard not to spend some money. Eg. they take your photographs on each side of the trolley ride and by the time you reach on the other side, they have souveniers ready with those photographs. We did buy those. There are people standing on the other side, matching your photos to the souveniers. They are little snowglobes, keychains and 3D photo-frames :) Amazing food, lots of things to do. Nice way to spend a relaxing day :)

Well worth a day trip. We stayed in Kowloon and caught the MTR to Lantau. Our hotel receptionist showed us on a map which stations to get on and off. It worked out without any hassles and the train trip was enjoyable. The station ( Tung Chung) where we got off ,was in easy walking distance to the Cable Car terminal. There were quite a number of other tourists there so we had about a 15 minute wait. The cable car ride provided lovely views of the bay and country side. The small village at the top is basically tourist orientated. Food and beverages are available and of course your usual gift shops. The walk up to the Big Buddha is via stairs. They are slightly steep but you can rest half way up. They are quite manageable. It is well worth the walk as the views are spectacular. If you have a day to spare while in Hong Kong, this trip is well worth the effort.

Space and Beauty a welcome change. We saw the stunning mountains and scenery of this island aerially from the cable car ride from The Big Buddha to Citygate. Other than the Buddha trio we did not visit other parts of the isalnd but the space and natural beauty sits in stark contrast to the skyscrapers of Kowloon
The rugged terrain.... is amazing. Lantau Island is hilly, with twisting narrow roads and beautiful. By all means, take a small bus day tour. See the Taoist fishing village and ride the cable car.

Worth a visit. A nice place to visit for all tourists and travellers. If you are looking for adventure, you can try hiking Lantau Peak or some other hiking trails available there. If you go for hiking, there will be lots of beautiful scenery you can enjoy. The cable car ride is awesome too.

Wisdom of path. We were there in January 2015 and had enough time to enough easy slow life. So we took bus instead of cable car and found that they was a good choice. The bus took us to see different scenery from top view and it passed many nice place. The journey was too long and we reach in front of the temple.We walked to the Wisdom of Path. I highly recommended that people shall take time to walk to this place and enjoy the beauty of nature.On the way back on bus, we still could see the path on top of mountain.
Exciting. too much person in a cable car if you travel as a couple you cannot enjoy much because like us we experience we share with the kids they were so noisy and they all yelling .

Big Buddha and monastery great but not lunch. The gondola trip up,the architecture and the big Buddha are a must see. We took the inclusive lunch option. The only thing that I could swallow was the rice! Then again it could just be my unacustomed taste buds but I found everything over cooked, oily and bland

Big Buddha is Here!. We took the sky train (glass bottomed sky cars) across the bay to Lantau Island which is where the Big Buddha resides. You can see it as you approach and it is truly magnificent. There's a way to hike to this location but we did not opt for that as our time was limited. Highly recommend the sky train, but if you are afraid of heights you might want to reconsider!At Lantau Island there are lots of shops for buying trinkets, anything from clothing to souvenirs. Also lots of food shops, coffee and tea shops and ice cream as well. When you are ready to make the hike up the 268 stairs to see the Big Buddha just make sure you bring some water with you. Take a break part way up if you need to, the view from the top is truly inspirational. There is a pathway from the village shops to the steps to the Buddha and you might find friendly cows wandering around. They live nearby and graze close to the Buddha's base. If you do not want to take the cable cars to Lantau Island there is also a bus that drives up, or you can do the cable car one way and the bus back to Hong Kong.Enjoy!
Excellent day out. This is well worth the visit. Need a full day to visit. Take plenty of time to enjoy the atmosphere.

Aerial tram with great views. take the MTR to the last stop on Lantau, past the airport - there are restaurants, a big outlet mall full of mainlanders shopping their heads off, and an aerial tram ride way out to the big buddha. the views make the ride woth it even if you just turn around and come back

A fantastic outing! Fun and thrilling cable car ride!. Firstly, we looked up the place at Discover Hong Kong website (recommended by official Hong Kong Tourism Board) MTR Tung Chung Station, Exit B. Walk for approximately five minutes to the Tung Chung Cable Car Terminal ( see official website: http://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/see-do/great-outdoors/outlying-islands/lantau-island/ngong-ping-360.jsp#ixzz3PZKGTwWy )Secondly, we checked the journey using the train trip planner of the official MTR website ( http://www.mtr.com.hk ) We bought Octopus ( http://www.octopus.com.hk ) , kind of passes for transportation and payment card for various stores in Hong Kong. A widely used prepaid card which you could top up in MTR stations, 7 elevens and many stores which accepted the card. Very useful, saved us from carrying coins! Must get one if you use their public transports!Took a train from Sha Tin Station (Direction Hung Hom Station); took underground from the station to Nam Cheong Station ; from Nam Cheong Station took the Tung Chung Line (Direction Tung Chung)We booked our tickets, Crystal Cabin through the official cable car site http://www.np360.com.hk/ So Glad we chose the tix for the Crystal Cabin!!!! We still had to queue but it was a lot shorter compared to the standard tix! It wasn't even during the weekend but there was a massive queue!I absolutely loved the cable car ride and views on our way up! Quite a distance for the ride! It was fun and thrilling- see the views beneath our feet! Scary!Once we were up the peak, we visited the Ngong Ping Village and shops see photos. We had a walked around and checked out various gifts shops. Took loads of photos of the Big Buddha and also visited and had our late lunch at the restaurant. We were their last customers and they had to turn people away after us. We were starving so any food would have been a bonus even for all non vegetarians! We were instantly converted for the day! Would definitely recommend the trip if you love culture and heritage.Make sure to check for their opening time before you plan to have lunch up there. Avoid weekends or holidays.Get tix for Crystal Cabin, more fun.
a must for all travelers in Hong Kong. Lantau island is one of the best experience i had in Hong Kong. if you are into nature, culture, this is the best tourist destination for you!

Tai O Fishing Village. The second place to visit after viewing the Tian Tan Buddha at Ngong Ping...a lazy quiet fishing village on a weekday...many shops in the alley way selling sun-dried salted fish, cuttlefish, scallops etc...interesting BBQ seafood snacks along the walk around the village.
Forget The Boat Tour Rides And Simply Explore On Foot. Tai O Fishing Village Is Absolutely Fascinating And Well Worth The Considerable Effort To Get There And Back.

LANTAU ISLAND. I joined an excursion to the island and it was delightful. We went over on the ferry arriving at Silvermine quay, and off we set in our bus. We visited Cheung Sha beach and Tai o fishing village. This was very interesting little place. The market was all about dried fish products and the village housing was on stilts in the water. On to the Po Lin monastry where you visit the enormous giant buddha in the middle of the mountains. Quite spectacular. We had a lovely vegetarian lunch and then took the Ngong Ping skyrail ride. This is amazing cable car ride over 5k and took 25 minutes. Truly beautiful views. Back to town.

take the bus to big buddha. If you're going to the Big Buddha, when you get off the MTR take the bus up. The cable car queue can be quite long. The bus only takes about 15 min more but you see lots of the island. But take the cable car down - it's a really long, interesting ride

Brilliant day. Went to Lantau Island on New Year's Day. A friend from HK drove us to Tung Chung on the island and we tried to take the cable car. However, because it was a national holiday there were queues of around 2 hours, so we decided to take a blue cab to the Po Lin Monastery and the Big Buddha. It was good because that way we saw a bit more of the island as well. The monastery and the Big Buddha are well worth a visit, quite stunning. We then took the cable car back to Tung Chung (no queues), a scenic ride of some 5.7km. It was a great day out and very peaceful, totally the opposite of Kowloon where we stayed.

Great views and sights. I quiet liked my trip out to Lanatau. I loved the statues and shrines. There are some amazing views... and apparently everything in Hong Kong is not totally built up. It is well worth the price of admission. Now, with that said... it is not as natural as I expected, or as spiritual. From reading I had expected unspoiled wilderness with a large monestary and shrine. I got all that but I also got a disney land like shopping and eating district complete with brick a brack and all the perfectly cleaned commercialization that that entails. Nothing wrong with that it just kind of took away from the experience for me.

Lantau Island. We took the MTR and the cable car, which offered scenic views. The Buddha statue is photographic and worth a visit. Plenty of trinket stands are available for those who wish to purchase trinkets.

A nice contrast to downtown Hong Kong. Ngong Ping village was a bit touristy, but the Taio Fishing Village, Big Buddha, and the cable car ride was worth the trip from Hong Kong. The views from the Fishing Village were outstanding. Has an amateur photographer, I really enjoyed it. I would caution also that if you have elderly or small children to consider whether or not to walk up to the Big Buddha since it’s over 250 steps up. It was foggy when we took the cable car ride, so we really didn’t get good views. You should try this when it’s nice and sunny. Overall, it was a great contrast to the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. We really enjoyed it.

Great Day out. Cable car journey to top of mountain stunning esp if you pay extra for glass bottomed car. Tour to fishing village interesting. Seeing all the varieties of dried fish good. No Dolphins to be seen I fear polluted waters have moved them out to sea. Giant Budda interesting be mindful to see him up close you will need to climb 260 steps. Visited the temples for some great views of gold buddas

Ngong Ping. We went up to Ngong Ping to the Great Budha.. Really something to see! Weather can be a bit unpredictable as it started getting very foggy while we were up there, making for obstructed views of the Great Budha. But even then, it was still worth it!

Great Day Trip. Easy to Access from Kowloon. MTR to the island and then Cable Car to see the largest Seated Buddah. After spending time at Ngong Ping Village we caught a bus to Taio Fishing Village. This is a Traditional Village with houses on Stilts and shops selling all sorts of fish including lots of smoked fish. Lots to photograph. We than got a bus to the Ferry which went back to Hong Kong Island.

Great day out.. Be sure to go to Lantau if you want to get away from the hustle of HK and catch the bus to Tai O fishing village.It's a very easy trip and the bus is waiting for you as you get off the ferry. It takes about 30 minutes to get to the village and it's well worth it.A short walk from the village takes you to the Heritage hotel ( the old police station) and a cold beer.

MY MUST VISIT OF HONG KONG.. It took 30 minutes to get to Tung Chung on the MTR and then it was easily sign posted to the cable cars. Get there at opening time as you wont have to waste precious holiday time queuing! We had the perfect day. The weather was perfection and the views were spectacular! You can pay extra for a glass floor cart which we did only one way my advice. Get it as a return, sun is in a better place after u spend 3 4 hours at the island than it is at 9am. Also everyone wants a see through on the way forward so the queue for that is then longer ;). You can pay £3.50 to go inside Buddah and up for a view a little higher. Not a bad price right? Also includes ice cream and a bottle of water! Why not hey!!? Have a great time just keep an eye on that weather! Download the Hong kong observatory app it really helped me shuffle my holiday in accordance to a day where i needed good wether and when i didnt!

Amazing experience. I would love to get back to this place! I love the cable ride going to and fro Ngong Ping. It's amazing looking at the giant buddha and the hundred steps to reach the top, this is our first stop on our tour and I can say this is one of the most memorable.

Lovely with lots to do. We didn't visit Disney, but it is there. Instead we went to the Big Buddha by glass bottom cable car, wandered through the little village, visited the monastery and climbed 250 steps to the base of the Buddha. The hall with 10,000 Buddhas was stunning. The vegetarian meal was adequate but could have used more seasoning. The receipt got you inside the Big Buddha. Great views from up there. You can return by cable car, but we chose to take the shuttle to the fishing village and then another public bus to the town where we picked up the ferry to Hong Kong. I personally didn't find the fishing village worth the effort. I would have been just as happy to go straight to the ferry. The scenery on Lantau is quite nice and diverse from being on Hong Kong. I found it interesting to have a Starbucks and Subway at the monastery village.
A must do. The Cable car ride is expensive but worth the penny..The Giant Buddha is really so huge... Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit. We spent a long day on Lantau island. We started off at Disneyland and late in the afternoon went to Teng Chung the next station from which we went to visit the Big Budda and the monastries. Well worth a visit.
Average experience. Average experience getting to the island and viewing sights on the island. One visit is good enough for me.

Lantau Island : Hong Kong’s largest Outlying Island. Lantau Island is Hong Kong’s largest Outlying Island with many beautiful features. It boasts not only HongKong International Airport, but also the much talked about Disneyland, pristine countryside, virgin hills and lush green valleys.It is a must do when you go to Hong Kong... there are many ways to reach the island.. you could take a ferry, bus (tour bus), MTR (train) or taxi (not recommended unless you are 3 or more passengers). There is a lot to do in the island... the most exclusive is the tour to giant bronze Buddha via a breathtaking cable car ride up a mountainside, Ngong Ping Village, the famous Po Lin Monastery, the historical fishing village of Tai O where Tanka boat people still live in stilt houses. There is so much to do so I will suggest you start early when you visit the island... TIP - take the CRYSTAL Cabin cable ride... it is a bit expensive.. but totally worth it.
Beautiful escape. Beautiful and peaceful place, green mountains, spectacular views from the bus going to Big Buddha. Great and long cable car journey. I'd come here for hiking if I had a chance.

Make a day of it. We made a whole day of going to Big Buddah. We were in the queue for tickets when the cable car opened at 0930 and waited for about 1/2 hour to get a ticket and board a gondola, the weather was good so we had fantastic views. On arrival we wandered through the various shops and eventually got to the base of Buddha. We climbed all the way up and had a good look around and took pictures and then came down and carried on exploring. Around 12.30 having missed the bus we caught a taxi to Tai Po and had lunch and a good explore, we then caught a bus to Mui Wo which took about 45 minutes and then caught the ferry back to Central and came into the harbour as the sun set and the lights came on. It was a fabulous day and I would recommend this if you have time. The stilt houses in Tai Po were very interesting and the bus trip to Mui Wo was a great way to see the island.

Green but very touristy. We went here on a day trip. Initially we'd intended to take the cable car but we would have had to wait in line for 2 hours so we opted for the bus. The countryside and the winding roads are beautiful but there seem to be tourists where ever you look.

Do it. Go to buddhe by cable car but only one way. After buddha go to Tai O fishing village by bus, then bus to Mui Mo and silvermine BAy - best beach in hong king, then fast ferry back to hong kong. Great day out. Get to the cable car by 9am lastest. We arrived at 10.45am and queued for 2hrs!!

Fabulous. we took the very easy to use MTR to Lantau Island and we're glad we did. It is a fab place. The cable car trip is memorable and everything flowed easily. We walked to the top of the stairs and spent time looking in awe at the size of the Budda.

Spectacular view. We took a train ride to Lautau island instead of ferry. Quite a long and crowded train ride since we shared the same line with tourists visiting Disneyland. Upon arrival we queued up for cable ride to the Ngong Ping village. Unfortunately everywhere you go in HK, crowdiness is unavoidable. Of course the queue would have taken hours but we decided to pay for tour package upgrade which means putting us on priority line and jumping queue. We got on the cable car immediately and landed at the village after 30 minutes ride in the cable car. Nice view from the top but can be frightening too due to lengthy period stucked in confined area. The village proves to be another mini mall with souvenier shops and restaurants scattered. As part of the tour package, we visited a historical fishing village Tai O, boat ride around the bay etc. I would have loved to stay at the fishing village a bit longer to taste the local food but unfortunately we had to board the bus to move on to our next destination. Overall quite good tour package but too rush. Money well spent for priority line catching the return cable ride back though. Otherwise would have been stucked since the last return cable ride was at 6.30pm. Long queue as usual.

Must see Buddha!. Take a ferry to Lantau Island, hop a bus and climb 100 stairs to the most amazing sight of the largest seated Buddha in the world, surrounded by other gigantic statues. Walk down and buy joss sticks and burn them in thanks. Pick up some Buddha beads at the gift shop for your friends. Revel in the extraordinary experience!

Do not miss Lantau Island. While we thought Victoria Peak was a highlight it did not compare with this full day out. While we have had differing experiences with Grey line previously this tour was Brilliant! Included;•Full-day tour of Lantau Island in Hong Kong•Ride an express ferry across Hong Kong Harbour to Lantau Island•Visit Po Lin Monastery and the Giant Buddha Exhibition Hall on a Big Buddha tour•Tai O fishing village and its traditional houses on stilts•Sky rail cable car from Ngong Ping Village to Tung Chung town•Vegetarian lunch at the monastery•Round-trip hotel transport from Hong Kong Island and Kowloon includedFirstly we travelled by mini bus out to Tai O fishing village where we took a step back in time wandering the local fishing markets and taking a boat ride out and view the locals homes built on stilts. Our local tour guide Ben was great told many first hand stories and was outstanding. From there we visited the spectacular Big Buddha and then off to the monastery for a full vegetarian lunch. The lunch was surprising and the plates just kept coming. Had no idea what I was eating but as it was vegetarian knew that there was no risk. Being a carnivore I was pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed the meal. I had not researched the cable car thoroughly and this took me by surprise by how long it went for and how high you actually are. The trip back down was breathtaking and certainly at times had my heart in my mouth but what a ride. While we had the standard you can for extra get a glass bottomed car. If you go to Hong Kong do not miss this Island!

Great Day Trip!. This was one of most memorable days in HK. Took the Ngong Ping 360 cable car out to the Island (long queues so try and book your ticket in advance). Once there, there is the Big Buddha and the Monastery and a brilliant range of restaurants and shops. It sounds commercialised but somehow it retains a very peaceful and spiritual aurora. We choose to take a bus from there out to Tai O fishing village afterwards - another brilliant experience which I would recommend. We did have locals with us who knew everywhere so well which was a real bonus but even on your own you could not fail to have a fantastic day out.

Mui Wo - Sleepy village in ultra modern Hong Kong. Quiet. Peaceful. We could cycle at our own pace. Enjoyed the beach. AND - clamming!
Seafood was good here. There is also a bakery - great to get those fresh ones!
Buffalo - yes, you can find it in Hong Kong here.

SIGHT IS JUST WOW. I love it here! Although there's not much to do really lol. The amazing sight is just something to pause and appreciate. Well you can walk around, watch people, go hunt for some bargain souvenirs or just feel the relaxing vibe of this place. It's so calm you'd wanna reflect your life here! :) It will be worth your while!

Great Day Trip!. This was one of our best days in Hong Kong. Be sure to book your cable car tickets in advance so you don't have to wait on the line! We took the cable car to Ngong Ping to see the big Buddha and monastery. Do not miss the hall of 10,000 buddhas - it was breathtaking. We then took a bus from Ngong Ping to Tai O fishing village and walked to the old police station (now hotel) for lunch. From the pier in front of the hotel, we took a boat back to the bus terminal. We then grabbed a bus to Mai O ferry terminal and took the ferry back to Hong Kong Island. Great day!

lovely country side, not too busy. Have just been on a hike on Lantau Island (stage 9 of Lantau Trail) and have to say that we felt it was so peaceful there. Not many people along the way once you manage to get a taxi away from the shopping centre - it felt less spoiled than e.g. Sai Kung Country Park (which is also nice, just feels so much more busy).Can't wait to go again and do some more exploring.

Perfect day to spend if you follow my instructions!!. Looking for a day to kill in Hong kong.1) Take the speed ferry from pier 6 (I think) to Mui Wo2) Go to the beach and relax a couple of hours (just go right when you exit the ferry terminal, you can´t miss it)3) When its lunchtime, take the bus to the Big Buddha.4) Eat lunch and stroll around the shops5) Visit the temple (go past the Buddha)6) Climb up the stairs to the Buddha and marvel at the views7) Take the cable car to Tung Chung8) You are now just minutes from the Tung Chung shopping centre (the best outlet stores in HK?)9) Go to the foodcourt and have a snack10) Shop till you drop11) Go back to foodcourt and choose between almost all the different asian foods you could think of12) Depending on what time it is, watch a movie at the cinema or go home and get a earned sleep

Great day out. The cable car trip to the island is incomparable. Has got a bit commercialised, but still a nice day out with spectacular views. Go early to avoid long queues, although went just after New Year which was a holiday here.
Tung Chung shopping. shopping is good and Food Republic there has good local food. very convenient. plenty of taxi and not expensive. take the green taxi.
Love the island. Though i had a short time in Hong Kong while transiting but manage to see Discovery Bay - love this to pieces
Lovely relaxing part of Hong Kong!. We stayed here 3 nights after spending 4 nights in the hustle and bustle of Mongkok. Loved everything about this place.

nice contrast to super busy Hongkong city. best is to take the cable car (quite some waiting queues) from MTR terminus Tung Chung, great view over the airport and surrounding landscape. For those who cannot stand the height can take a bus to the Big Buddha. The trip is really worthwhile !

A great place to walk - a satisfying day trip. I took the subway from Kowloon to the place to take the 45-minute gondola ride to the island - to see the Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. It was a great ride with fabulous views of the city and the island - and a really satisfying day, with lots of walking time.

Nature hidden away from HK. Lantau Island, home to HK airport & Disneyland, has little to offer, apart from the scenic beauty of mountains & sea. There is limited urbanization, near airport and at Mui Wo. Heard about trekking tracks & waterfalls. If you are in HK & want to catch some fresh breath, definitely this is the place.
Big Buddha. Buy the package from Big Bus Tours, you have to find your own way to Lantau Island but it is super easy and far cheaper. Plus you get rushed to the front of the line at every turn.

Day-trip to Lantau. Take the train from Hong Kong Central to Tung Chung.The cable car is a bit of a tourist trap but the views are amazing so get there early and avoid the crowds! Only get a single ride and avoid queues coming down and take bus No.2 from Ngong Ping bus terminus going down the other side when you have visited Big Buddha, the monastery and the village. The bus terminates at Mui Wo Ferry terminal where you'll find a range of seafood restaurants for a cheap and very tasty lunch before boarding the ferry back to Hong Kong Island. use your Octopus card or buy a single ride, stunning views of the city as you approach the ferry terminal in Hong Kong.
Closer than expected. Easy to get to via train. Prepare your feet for some exploration. Not recommended for those with walking aid.

Amazing views and breathtaking scenery. We took the bus up instead of the cable car as the queue for the cable car was massive! The bus is MUCH cheaper and we didn't have to wait hours in the line!The scenery is beautiful and the room with 10,000 Buddhas is incredible!! Worth a look!!It is best to go early before the crowds get to much!

A good adventure. We traveled to Mui by ferry and then took a taxi to Tai O fishing village. It was only about $20 for the taxi from Mui (a deal for a 40 minute trip). We enjoyed Tai O and ate lunch at the Heritage Hotel. It was walk there and back, though the food left a bit to be desired. We then took a taxi to Ngong Ping at the top (20 minutes). This area was very touristy, though the big Buddha was a sight to see. I agree that you should either get your cable car tickets ahead of time or by the glass bottom cable car tickets (no waiting). We did that and had a great ride down the mountain to Tung Chung. Then, we took a quick MTR train back to Hong Kong. All in all, an easy and interesting getaway from the main city (left at 9:30 a.m. and got back by 4:30 p.m).

More than just Disney. Lantau is a stunningly beautiful island. If you want to escape Central and enjoy a peaceful day out head to the Big Buddha. A couple of hours here would be fine and after lunch at the monasteries veggie cafe take a taxi to Tai O.Tai O made me feel like I'd completely left Hong Kong as we walked around the stilt houses and took a short 20 boat trip out to see the pink dolphins!

Serene, quiet part of Hong Kong. We took the ferry to Lantau Island, arrived there after nearly an hour ride. The pier area is where the small town square is, and where the businesses are, a few buildings, around 30 stores altogether. I noticed a lot of foreigners, mostly white people who are actually residents there.There are a lot of bikes for rent in the town square. Walk a bit off, and you will find you're in a different world, so quiet, so serene. We took the bus to the Tian Tan Big Buddha in Ngong Ping, Lantau Island. Entering the grounds, you will find a small stall selling some memorabilia, some hotdogs, drinks, and the most delicious steamed corn in the world! The corn was so sweet and the kernel actually crispy...I salivate every time I think of those corn.Took the steps up to the Big Buddha, the world's tallest bronze Buddha. Inside the Buddha, there are so many religious things to see.Lantau is a good daytrip destination.

Tiring but so much fun. It was a day of tiring yet very fun! First we went to disney land. We roam just a part of disney and then went straight to the big buddha using cable cart. All the stress and negatives vibes were gone we you see the peaceful view above the mountains.. It was our family's first trip abroad it was all fun and we enjoyed our stay in HK.

Lantau Island. Nice place, but just another "Americanised" touristy attraction, nothing ancient or historical - just aimed at tourists spending money on souvenirs and restaurants. Overall still a fun day out in HK!

Wonderful track to the Lantau Peak for the spectacular sunrise. Stayed at the Youth Hostel overnight (don't forget towel and toiletries). We skipped our dinner as the restaurants are closed by 6pm. Woke at 4.30pm and headed for the Lantau Peak. Trail is clearly marked and the hostel is right on the trail. The clime took us 1 hour 20 minutes and we are of above average fitness. The trail is safe with stones well laid out but steep. Need strong hearts on the way done. Cold and windy at the peak but the sunrise was well worth the climb. Dress warmly, remember your torch and camera. The view is breathtaking.

Breath-taking place. Go early.. A great cable-car experience. The island itself will appeal to some but not to others. Tourists into Chinese spirituality should appreciate the place.Crucial: Try to get to Tung Chung MTR **before** 10am (even then we had to wait almost 30 minutes for the cable car). Never go after noontime. When we got back to the MTR around 1pm we could see that the queue snaked longer than the Great Wall. I can just imagine people waiting up to 3 hours to even get **in** the cable car.

Po Lin and the West Coast Trail. We went to Po Lin one day- its probably the most beautiful monastery we've ever been too (mostly because its pretty new!) but its really shows what some of the more run down temples would look like many years ago. The trail runs from Tung Chung all the way to the fishing village of Tai O (about 16km). A lovely rural trail with lots of small wildlife (birds and butterflies!) and beautiful views (although they are marred a bit by the construction of the hwy to Macau. On the other hand, its kind of fascinating to see them constructing a 30km bridge.) There isn't much in the way of food or drink so you'll have to bring your own.

Great day trip. The Buddha was magnificent . You can bus it around the island and see a lot. I got the ferry and bussed it. Ende up then going to a fishing village and getting a bus back. There is a cable car but it ends early
Amazing journey but lacked history. Lantau is worth visiting but felt very modern. The giant buddah is impressive but the whole development leading up to it felt a little fake.

Quirky Tai O Fishing Village worth a visit. Got Ferry to Lantau Island then bus to Tai O fishing village.Tai O's main income other than tourism is from fishing and the pungent shrimp paste that you can watch being blended in large vats.Can still see traditional houses that are on stilts and wander through the viilage and see how the locals live.Lunch at the Heritage hotel was worth the climb.

Visit to the Monastery. Lovely. Peaceful, good attention to detail, meticulously built, very clean, nice gardens, good facilities and great views.Went over a fantastic bridge, huge span adjacent to the airport where there was massive development: a city in itself.Everywhere was very clean and efficient. The gondola gave spectacular views. Very impressed

Very beautiful!. This place is far to get to (about an hour away from the city), but it is worth every effort to get to. Upon arrival, you take a 30 minute cable cart to the Big Buddha, but the view is wonderful - you see the mountains of Hong Kong and the harbour. And that is just the beginning - the Big Buddha lives up to its name!! One of the most beautiful statues ever made with amazing 360 views around it. You can also do prayers which I would highly recommend. The only thing that I found unappealing is how commercialized the small town is before entering the Big Buddha (too many souvenir shops with items that aren't related to Buddhism).

Much better day than expected!. Awoke to overcast skies, but decided to head to Lantau anyway. MRT to Tung Chung then cable car option. Got persuaded at the ticket counter to sign up for the land,sea,Sky deal - which wasn't cheap - but didn't realise at the time that this gave you queue jumping capability... easily saved us 2+ hours is queuing, which with children was a great outcome. I enjoyed Tai O village immensely and the boat tour that was included was really quite interesting. When we first arrived at summit it was well clouded in .. visibility very limited (less than 50 meters) which made it quite spectacular ... it wasn't till we returned from Tai O that we saw the big budda. Great day.
Take a cable car for awesome views. The giant Buddha alone is enough of a reason to visit Hong Kong. The island is very picturesque. The Cable ride is a delight.

The Road to Tai O was long. We wanted to visit the Big Buddha but took Bus 23 (HK$11.80 one way) and landed at Tai O.. a small fishing village. We stopped for lunch at a popular foodshop (can't remember the name) selling Tau Fu Fa and noodles. Quite reasonable priced. And very nice..

A good half day destination. Though totally man made, the creators have succeeded in creating a replica mix of hong kong culture. The Cable ride is a delight. The views of Buddha from the cable car is worth the ride.

It has changed a lot but still okay. The last time I travelled to Lantau Island, there was no airport attached and you could only reach it by ferry. It seemed really far away and the locals were really bemused by you being there. Now you can catch the train and then ride a skyway. Still the best way to see some of the scenery is to ride the buses. There are beaches here and small villages still, so it's a nice break from the hustle and bustle of HK island or Kowloon/Mongkok.

Away from the Hustle and Bustle. We decided to take the ferry to Lantau Island to have a different experience. We took the ferry from Pier 6 towards Mui Wo at the Central Ferry Pier. The ferry took 50 minutes. Once we arrived at the island, we could see buses lined up to go to different places. We took Bus 1 to Tai O. When we arrived at Tai O, we visited the silt houses. We could see the fishermen houses on silts. The locals were also hanging salted fishes to dry. This place reminds me of Pulau Ketam. Then we decided to go to visit the Giant Buddha at Ngong Ping. It is the biggest sitting Buddha. We walked up the steps and the scenery is breath taking. This place is really different from the city, all peace and quiet. It gives you the calmness. If compare to the giant Buddha I visited Wuxi last year, it is really different. Then we walked to the Ngong Ping village which is filled with shops and fun activities. The place is pretty hyped. Then we took the cable car down. The view is pretty awesome and we could see the whole airport from our cable car. Watch out for discounts with credit cards as I had mine with HSBC.
