They also take photos for you when you get on the cable car and you may purchase the photo for HKD100 as a souvenir.

Amazing attractions, breathtaking views. I decided to go to Lantau Island on my last day in Hong Kong. The attractions are really amazing to see in person. From the Giant Buddha to the Po-Lin monastery they were truly amazing. But the views were breathtaking. Taking the cable car to/from Ngong ping yielded amazing views, and once you get to the Giant Buddha you realize it was worth the travel from Hong Kong to see it.Like others posted, it you want to travel to Lantau via the cable car try to arrive as early in the morning as possible to avoid long lines (10am weekdays and 9am weekends). And you can use the MTR via Tung Chung from Jordan or TST in Kowloon very easily to get to the cable car station.

Avoid the queue, take the bus.. After wasting too much time in queuing at other attractions and eateries, we decided no more wasting of time, we took the bus instead of the popular cable car. This turned out to be an excellent option. We took the bus no.23 at the terminus , it was around 10am and the line was not long at all. The whole journey was around 40 mins , slightly longer than the cable car ride. Once, the bus arrived at the top , the big Buddha was just nearby. The view at the top after climbing the long stairs was really nice. Taking the bus is another more economical way to see the Buddha.

Long lines; but breathtaking views!. We went on a Sunday; big mistake. The crowds were extremely long.... we stood in line for two hours just to get tickets. Once we got our tickets we got on the tram quickly. The views are breathtaking and the attractions are enjoyable.

You have to see this. One of those days you will never forget, train to cable car to top of the mountain ,to see this enormous bronze budda and then a temple to see the monks , give a fantastic display
Cable car ride. Cable car and tourist village was excellent, pity about the smog as limited scenic outlook! Pity about the length of queues for tickets and to await entry to a cabin.

Long cable car ride. What I didn't realize was how far the Big Budha actually is. The cable car is roughly 30 minutes long which seems liked an eternity. After all this time to get there (long MTR ride, walk to the cable car, cable car ride, walk along the island, the many steps to get to Big Budha), we realized the intense fog ruined our view of Big Budha. You could hardly see Budha as the fog was that intense. I suggest making sure you go you on a clear day as Hong Kong has many overcast days.

Tai O Market. Preferably visit Tai O on the weekend if one needs to see the bustling activity on the quaint fishing town. Visit any of the low-key restaurants and the seafood is about 50% off the main centres in HK, or Lamma Island. The fishing port is also a launchpad to spot the pink dolphin. Tai-O is about 45 minutes from Tung-Chung Town by bus.
Awesome. The trip to the island was a trip itself. very cool! Although the weather was not sunny, I had the most wonderful experience!
serene. situated a little far away, this place is a serene place. ideal for a half day picnic with family. nothing except the huge buddha statue and its history.

Enjoyable, but there's more to Lantau Island. If you made to Lantau Island to see the Buda, which is a nice place to visit, go beyond and explore the many places around the island. My preferred destination was the village of Tai O with the food market and the amazing experience of learning how the fisherman live - a cultural shock, an eye opening experience, humbling.To get to the Island I would suggest an early one way trip via cable car (another must do), then Tai O via bus, then another bus trip to Mui Wo to catch a ferry back to Central station.That makes an unforgettable day, completely different from what you get in the the buzz of the city.
Easy to get to. Clean and pleasant train ride. I suggest that you take the sky car as the views are amazing.Get there early to avoid ques

VERY ENJOYABLE. Very nice place for touring an recreation as well.It is recomended to go one way by Mtr and cable car and return by the ferry. Very recomended to walk around the fisherman village where thet preserve all sorts of fish and seafood

An unusual way to visit. We took the ferry from central to the Silver-mine Bay. We took bus to Tai O. We visited the small museum to review the history of Tai O(was then, a salt producing village). While passing through the small bridge, we saw boats carrying tourists to see the white dolphines. We took noodle lunch in a coffe shop at the water-side.(quite romantic). We then take a taxi to Ngon Ping(we did not visit the Budda). We took the cable car to Tung Chung.Then took E34 bus to Yuen Long. It was a One-day trip. We had the chance to see almost the coast line of Lantao Island.

Lantau Island. My main reason for going there was to see the Tian Tan Buddha or big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. Both the places are the main highlights for me in Hong Kong. Please do not miss them
holiday surprise. could,nt believe how commercial it had become since my last visit in 2006.so many shops and resaurents,but still very enjoyable.

Serenity. It is a short cable car trip from Hong Kong to go to this beautiful island and visit the big BuddhaThis was our second visit there and I always enjoy the beauty of the island and it's serenityThe cable car ride gives you a beautiful view of the island but try to plan your return trip back to Hong Kong well before the last cable car otherwise there is a very long line with lengthy waiting timesYou should also buy your tickets for the cable car in advance so that you don't have to wait in another lineIt is worth it to climb up to see the big Buddha as well as to go down into the monastery

Different part of the Island gives different levels of getaway. I visited Tai O, the western tip of the island, where was a fishing village with numerous residents still lived on boat houses. There are also quite some local snacks selling on streets after leaving bus or ferry. The feel of getaway is somewhat different when I visited Mui Wo, Tong Fok, Pui O or even Cheung Sha.

Another view of Hong Kong, peaceful, green. Take the ferry from Central to Mui Wo and then the bus to Tai O. You will get great views of the harbour and the 'Manhattan type' skyline. Once on Lantau, a week-day is better to avoid the crowds, you will see a totally different Hong Kong, lovely beaches, countryside and the fascinating fishing town of TaI O with its stilt house. If you have time you can also visit the Buddha.

Excellent & Perfect Transit Tour from Hong Kong Airprot. This is a perfect and excellent tour for the transit passengers from Hong Kong Airport who have about 8-10 hours of time.I took this tour from the Splendid tours (www.splendid.hk).I had about 12 hours of transit time in Hong Kong and wanted to go out.The Lantau Island tour was perfect for as it had Airport PickUp/Drop and for about 6 hours.The Immigration was quick about 10 mins, and the Pickup was from the Regal Hotel Lobby which is about 5 mins walk after you get out the immigration in Terminal 1.The cabin luggage can be dropped at the airport Terminal 2 (http://www.hongkongairport.com/eng/passenger/arrival/t1/baggage/left-baggage.html)The tour started exactly at 10:00 AM in a bus with a tourist guide nicely explaining the history of the places we're about to visit.First was Tai O Village, which gave an experience of local life of the fishing people of hong kong.Then we moved up the hill to the Buddha Statue and Po Lin Monastery which was a great view and took some great pictures. We also had a great Vegetarian Lunch that was included in the tour at the Monastery that gave the taste of the cuisine of Buddists in Ngong Ping Village.Did some shopping too.The we moved on to the Cable car that would take down the hill with breathtaking views of the Ocean, Hills and the Airport. This is so good, that you've to just experience it to feel it.We arrived down the hill and the bus was waiting for us to take back to the Airport.We reached the airport at about 3:30 and had plenty of time for the connecting flight.Overall it was a great short tour that was memorable and the arrangement from Splendid tours was just great and it couldn't be any better.The cost was about $100 USD per person and it's worth it.I'd recommend this, and would certainly take another tour from Splendid if I travel through Hong Kong again.

don't miss Tai O. nice ferry trip to Lantau Island, ride by bus along the coast line to Tai O, the old fisherman harbour which is likely to disappear since youger people tend to leave to the city. Look at the dried fish hanging in the streets of Tai O!Then proceed to the Great Buddha and Monestary and don't forget to take the cable car down with spectacular view on the airport

A Larger Island but Less People. We took part in a full day tour with Splendid Tours (booked through Viator) to have a better look at Lantau Island (where the new airport is based). The company picks people up from their hotel and takes them first to a view point of the fantastic new bridges built to link Lantau Island with Hong Kong's mainland and then onto the Island itself. A local bus company and guide take over from there and our trip took us first to a lovely sandy beach (of course in December somewhat deserted) and to an old fishing village with many houses built on stilts right over the water. From the village we drove up to the Giant Buddha and the Temple of the Thousand Buddhas right up on the hill tops, where we had time to look at the temples, the Buddha and also took part in a vegetarian lunch in the Monastry cafe. The last stage was by cable way from the Monastery down to the sea level, i.e. the place where we swapped buses in the morning, then with a splendid tour bus back to our hotel. It was a great day out and we learned so much about life outside the busy busy Hong Kong city area, the way the Islanders used to live and the history of the monastery and the Giant Buddha. Highlights included the bridges view point, the size of the Giant Buddha and the temple of the Thousand Buddhas - you have to see it to believe it. But more than anything else, we enjoyed and valued the excellent commentary of our local guide Ben; his considered Information (not too much - but all of it highly relevant - and its delivery (passionate, insightful, positive) were the absolute highlight of the trip. One bit of advice: If the weather looks changeable take an extra layer of clothing with you. It is much colder on the hilltops than at sea level and the cabins of the cable way are extremely 'well' aired.

Great place - just book your tickets in advance. The line to get the ticket of the lantau island cable car would be the longest i've ever stood in my entire life. We did the mistake of not booking online and paid with 1.5 hours of wasted time that spoiled the mood at the very beginning. Anyhow, we bought the to and fro crystal car ticket and found the ride to be amazing. The crystal car queues were shorter too. The ride offered a new experience of transparent cable car floor and some spectacular views of the mountains, sea and the airport. Upon reaching the village, we did some shopping too. There are good eating options and the shops sell some nice stuff. We did not climb up to the big buddha statue. The Po Lin monastery was beautiful and a must-visit place. We stopped at the Citigate Outlet mall on our way back too.
A nice nature hiking. if you are a hiking person you much see this place you will love it with lot's of amazing local food :)http://www.discoverhongkong.com/

Fun day but go early. My customer's nephew and I went at about 9 am and that was the perfect time. There were no lines at all. The way up is a bit scary - it was windy that day - but the views were exceptional. I didn't feel that I was in a huge city. Most of the island is protected and there are extensive trails all over. You can see some of them from the cable car. The airport is just off the island on another island that was leveled for the airport. I didn't notice noise from the planes - maybe because it was windy. The area at the top, near the cable car drop off, is a tourist trap. If you need a coffee, then Starbucks is there for you. The giant Buddha is another long hike up some stairs. It is worth it. Incredible views. There is a monastery and some Buddhist temples - they look fairly new and are quite large. There are some feral cows roaming around - they aren't the Texas size cows. They quite small for cows. They seem used to all the people. If you have time, walking around the trails would be nice. We only stayed until about 1pm and then left. The lines for the cable car was at least an hour or more long.

Loved it, worth 1/2 a day do-it-yourself trip. Took the train from Central to come here. It is about a 1/2 day's trip. I know that some tour companies offer trips from Hong Kong Island but this is something that is easy to do on your own. Catch the cable car at Ngong Ping 360 cable car station and enjoy a 25-min ride up to the top. There are plenty of places to eat/drink/shop once you get to the top. There are two options for cars, the regular and the "Crystal" which has a clear bottom, the latter is more expensive but you are moved to the front of the line (as are people traveling solo). You can pick up WiFi at both stations as well.
Go in past.. The islands, form spectacular view and take you back in times to give a moment to the earlier generation adn their struggles. Like it.

Stunning big Buddha and cable car is great. It is a bit far out of the centre so if you have time do this I would say half a day trip. Buddha is stunning. View when clear from cable car is also great.

Nice change from the city. Lantau is completely different from the city. It is quiet and peaceful. The ferry takes a long time, so I think if I was doing it again, I would take the metro. The bus from the harbour up to the monastery was fun - our driver seemed to think that he was in a grand prix!

Cultual do-it-yourself day trip to Lantau Island. Lantau Island is a fantastic day trip to get away from the hustle of Hong Kong. Here's how to do it:* Take MTR (subway) from Hong Kong Island (that's where I stayed) to Tung Chung station* Walk a couple minutes to the Ngong Ping 360 cable car station (Starbucks nearby) and enjoy a 25-minute soaring ride with spectacular views (standard car 115 HKD/$15 USD one-way) to Ngong Ping Village. Ngong Ping Village is very Disney-like (hey, they are close to Disney!) but has all the things that tourists need and appreciate - clean dining, clean free restrooms (with paper!), shopping and bus/taxis.* Walk over to see Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery - easy walk, climb the 260 steps to the Buddha. At both sights you will see many locals offering prayers and gifts (oranges, money) to the buddha and burning LOTS of incense. Both of these attractions are free.* We then took bus #21 to Tai O fishing village, about 12 minutes away. The bus runs every 20-30 minutes or so, so check the schedule. Very cheap - 6.60 HKD / <$1 USD. Nice coach bus. Tai O was my absolute fave part of this excursion because it is the real, rural China. You will feel as though you are in a completely different country than Hong Kong. This is a totally different lifestyle and people are very hard-working, simple and humble. They live in a very small community of stilt houses that teeter on wood 2x4s and it is amazing how they remain standing. There is a market of live and dried seafood products and their specialty is shrimp paste. You will see villagers making certain tasty treats so buy some, support them and enjoy!! My favorites - egg waffles (regular or chocolate)- 15 HKD/<$2 USD and a homemade donut, kind of like a beignet, hot and rolled in sugar - hot, slightly crispy and soooo delicious (8 HKD)! As we walked around, people go about their daily life - hanging laundry to dry, playing a dice game and just sitting with friends/family. Please respect these people and do not take their photo unless they approve. I wonder if (and hope that) this village and culture remains decades from now. It is something that you will rarely see!* We then went to Mui Wo to catch the ferry. Bus #1 (50 minutes, 8 or 10.70 HKD depending if the bus has a/c). We missed the bus and since there were 6 of us, we took 2 taxis instead at cost of 165 HKD per car (30 minute trip, so saves time) - very reasonable with multiple people in the car. Mui Wo looks like a cute little town with a beach so you could spend a couple hours here.* Ferry from Mui Wo to Hong Kong Central - 2 options: fast boat (30 minutes, 28 HKD/$4 USD) or slow boat (60 minutes, 14 HKD/$2 USD). Nice, scenic trip across the harbour.Awesome day! If you are a hiker, there are lots of trails on the island to enjoy and we saw many hikers. This was all very easy to navigate and plenty of people speak English if you need assistance. Enjoy!

A very scenic and unspoilt island. We arrived by ferry at Wui Wo from Central pier no.6. We then caught the no. 2 bus which took us on a very scenic ride round part of the island to Ngong Ping, We saw some fantastic scenery climbing into the mountains. At Ngong Ping there is the Po Lin monastery, and the big Buddha. Unfortunately it was raining quite heavily so we didn't spend as much time as planned walking around. The area was stunning. We then walked through the tourist village with all its shops and restaurants. We caught the cable car to Tung Chung. The cable car ride was amazing, such a shame it was raining but the scenery was fantastic, a great ride so much to see. From Tung Chung we then caught the MTR back to Kowloon. We really enjoyed the day and the island and would love to return and do the trip again. We got so much information from the brilliant website, Hong Kong extras.

GREAT DAY OUT AND FANTASTIC CABLE CAR. Had a great day out at Lantau Island. Went over to the island by the 25 minute cable car which was stunning offering fantastic views over Tung Chung Bay and the Airport island.Lots to do at the top and a stroll through the village is charming.Ling Po monastery is very interesting as is the giant Buddah but lots of steps to climb to the top of the giant Buddah so not for the disabled or elderly to tackle.Best to go early in the morning to avoid the long lines waiting for the cable car.

Last stop!. This was our last stop for a long trip in Asia and I think it was a great place to finish the trip! Beautiful landscape of small islands around the Lantau Island! The big Buddha is very impressive! It was rainy and windy but it didn't affect it's charm!

Cultural place away from the city. If you want to take a day to get away from the city. This is where to go to get some space. You can hike around and venture into villages where you see people live. Old rustic houses. The sights and atmosphere provide a very cultural feel; different if you come from a modern city.

Great cultural place. There are many British expats there so don't worry about a language barrier it least when you stop in one of the many little restaurants after getting off the ferry. Hop on the bus and take a ride to Po Lin Monastery. You won't be disappointed.

Special day out. Very well oranised day tour to Lantau island - ferry ride, bus ride around island, fishing village, Big Buddha, vegan lunch in monastery and sky car ride back. We loved it, guide is so funny and knowledgeable, we found many interesting details about island history, local habits, local nature and religion.

Colourful noisy smelly amazing!. Took the cable car up to Ngong Ping the caught the bus to Tai O. What an amazing place!!! Traditional Chinese village with so much to see. We walked all the way through and had lunch at the Heritage Hotel. Worth the walk. Then caught the bus back to catch the ferry back to HK. Take a peg for your nose though as the smell of the fish paste they make is overpowering in the heat to say the least!!!
Lantou tour 2014. very exciting tour and beutiful Buddha Statue. A must see when you visit Hong Kong.skyline tour was fantastic and very breathtaking.

Excellent day trip from Hong Kong. I have been travelling to Hong Kong for many years now and I finally got to visit Lantau Island.Caught the ferry from Central to Lantau Island - Mui Wo . This was my first stop and I strolled around the beach area for around 30 minutes to take in scenery. From here I took the local bus which can be found in front of the ferry terminal and headed to Tai O .The bus only takes 40 - 45 mins but once you arrive at Tai O there is plenty to explore.A fascinating place to visit, take in the many sights like the the old homes which have been on stilts.Taking a water tour is a good way to see the homes . Also suggest that you walk to the Heritage Hotel ( a former police station which has been restored to a lovely hotel) . From Tai O I took a local taxi which was only a 20 minute ride to Ngong Ping ( there is also a bus service available ) , to the site of the Buddha statue.The walk up the many steps is well worth it , the view from the top is amazing. From Ngong Ping one can either get the cable car or catch a bus to head to Tung Chung - train station plus a good size shopping centre. From Tung Chung you can catch a train and head back to TST or Hong Kong Island.A good day out with plenty to see and do.

Fishing village of Tai O. If you visit Ngong Ping village, don't miss this! We stumbled by chance, not expecting anything Take a number 23? bus from Ngong Ping Village. Charming unspoilt fishing village. A camera is a MUST. Can be very crowded but worth it! Lots of dried salted fish, if you do eat. to buy. For food, try small restaurant where locals eat, good and reasonable price.

Amazing Island.... I loved this side of Hong Kong. Was my first visit to the island and I was very impressed. It is very clean, extremely organized and has lots to offer. If you are into shopping, this is the only island in Hong Kong that has an Outlets mall with all famous brand names at discounted prices. Disneyland and the Big Buddha are also located on this island.

Beautiful and BIG. Green, big island, plenty to see and do. Surprised at all it can hold. Multiple small villages, though mostly tourist oriented, still can catch glimpses of what this area was like many years ago.
Don't miss. Easy to get to on the MTR, take the cable car up to the village and Big Budda. If you have the cash, go with the Crystal Cabin. Very enjoyable and loved the monastery.

View from the cable car stunning.. The cable car trip to the Buddha is worth it alone but I found the whole experience fascinating. The Buddha is however only very new so it is not an ancient monument but still quite stunning in itself.Although the site is fairly well commercialised the shops are not the top designer shops you see everywhere else in Hong Kong. The site still seems to retain an air of tranquility. Like much in Hong Kong these days the vista is spoilt by the smog that comes in from China.Whilst we didn't do any of the walks we saw from the cable car many folks enjoying the rugged forested slopes that surround the site. Its quite strange one minute you are in one of the most heavily populated places on earth and 5 minutes later you can be totally isolated.

Lots to see. Lantau Island is well worth a visit when in Hong Kong. It is easily accessible from Hong Kong Island or Kowloon either by ferry or using the Metro. Once on the island the main attraction is the Big Buddha/Po Lin Monastery in the centre of the island at Ngong Ping accessible either by bus or using the Ngong Ping 360 cable car. At the Buddha/monastery you can get a ticket that includes a vegetarian meal at the monastery which is tasty and filling. The trip on the Ngong Ping cable car provides spectacular views but takes about 20 minutes each way so can be a little unnerving for some.Also on the island visit Tai O village if you get a chance, accessible by bus, this small fishing village still has houses built on stilts and only takes about an hour of your time.We took a day to visit the island arriving by ferry to the port at Mui Wo then taking a bus outside the ferry terminal to Tai O for a short visit then a bus to Ngong Ping to see the Big Buddha/monastery and finally taking the cable car back down the mountain and then metro back to Kowloon of Hong Kong island. Well worth a day out
Very nice beaches. Just an half hour from Hong kong city center is very nice empty beaches. Fantastic. It's East to reach with bus, taxi or boat.

Not Worth Queuing 2 hours. Shushhh! Don't tell anyone! You can buy cable car tickets in advance and jump the 2 hour queue.
Buy lunch at the Monastery and share with your best friend.

A pleasant half day trip. We travelled to Lantau Island via the very clean, fast and efficient MTR and then took a local shuttle bus to the Big Buddha. This provided us with a scenic trip around the island which included lovely sea views. The Big Buddha was well worth the visit including the many steps to reach the top. On the way back we hopped off at a small seafront village and enjoyed a lovely meal overlooking the water.

looking for a day trip. If you have all day, come to the biggest island in Hong Kong. Also visit the big budda and take the NgonPing 360. We had a good time, we also had lunch at the Temple which was fine.

Please don't miss this place! . Dear Tourist, Please don't miss this place while u are in Hong Kong during this season. It cooling for a simple trekking. Fantastic view of sunset. Old village heritage that you will not be able to see it in the city of Hong Kong. A lot of self design shops and restaurants there for a good lunch or dinner! And also don't miss the lamma island and Cheng Zhou island too. You can swim there too! They have public shower service which is free. Don't be afraid of the water temperature. It is quite cooling in the sea. Really enjoying for my friend and myself. Try having seafood too. But try it at Cheng Zhou. Be coz it is cheaper than the other island. Check out my other reviews for Hong Kong.

A superb day out.. The efficient train service will whisk you to the cable car terminus, but be prepared to queue if you have not pre-booked. The cable car, which actually takes in two corners, makes for a stunning ride to the top of the mountains, giving panoramic views. From the top, there is much to explore, so please see my comments on the separate attractions

Must see the Temple and Buddha. Went on a day trip with Grayline tours which was very good, Seeing the Buddha from the gondola ride was very impressive, walked up to the top to see the Buddha, 300 steps but well worth it. Not keen on the lunch at the Buddha it was vegetarian

Great 1-Day Trip. Went there on a Monday to avoid crowd & to enjoy cheaper bus & ferry fare. I had planned my trip so that we got to take the cable car, bus, ferry in one go.Transport:MTR to Tung Chung stationCable car: Tung Chung > Ngong Ping (25min) opens at 10amBus: Ngong Ping to Tai O (15min)Ferry: Tai O to Tung Chung (30min) -last ferry at 6pm15min walk from ferry pier to the MTR station.Tips: buy the cable car 1 way ticket from tourist company (can easily find one in Mongkok, where we stayed), so we can skip the long line coz they have different counters for selling tickets & for tour company ticket collection.Earlier I planned to take ferry from Mui Wo but the bus ride made me sick coz of the mountain roads, so we changed to this plan.bus schedule: http://www.newlantaobus.com/road_21.htmferry schedule: http://www.fortuneferry.com.hk/timetable.php
Interesting. Great view from the cable car. The tour of Tai O was fun. Watching the sun set over the Big Buddha was amazing.

Great day out. we tried the following itinerary as recommended by the hotel concierge and find it interesting and it gives you a view of Hong Kong that is not commonly seen, plus you get to travel by air (cable car), land (bus) and sea (ferry). 1) take mtr to Tung Chung station. You can do some shopping at Citygate Outlet Mall. I don't recommend as it's not that cheap compared to where I come from 2) take cable car ride from station near Citygate to Ngong Ping Village. 40 minutes queue on a weekday and 25 minutes ride. Choose crystal cabin for a glass bottom cabin. 3) visit Big Buddha and adjoining temple. Vegetarian food is available in the temple for a price 4) take bus 21 from ngong ping village to Tai O, a nearby fishing village. Be sure to find out the timing for the bus as the frequency is one per hour. You can use octopus card to pay the fare. Bus ride is about 15 mins. 5) visit tai o. You take hire a boat for a chance to see pink dolphins, if not just walk around and see Hong Kong Ina village setting. Take a walk through the market and continue along the coast. Right at the end you will find a hotel which was converted from a police station. Not sure about the logic why the police station is located at the end of a road and looking out to sea. The hotel is close to public by 6pm. 6) take bus 11 from tai o to mui wo ferry terminal. The frequent is about one per half hour so no worries here. You can use octopus card as well. Ride is about 45minutes, if I did not remember wrongly. 7) from mui wo, take ferry to central pier, located near central mtr station. You can use octopus card as well. Journey is about 2 hours I think.Hope this help.

better than most of HK. it's a nice green space with some villages and beaches. the airport is here, but if you go to the end of the metro and take the cable car, you can visit the big buddha and some other villages. it is worth the time more than the average commercial districts of HK. tai o has some good curry fishballs

Good weather hiking in October - Decemember. I loved Lantau Island very much. It is an absolutely nature area for hiking, sporting, and know a new peoples. You can enjoy and breath a fresh air a while after working in crowd city in HK or somewhere else. TREE, MOUNTAIN, SEA VIEW, BEACH, BIRD - can find in there - fantastic place!

Lovely day out. I really enjoyed the day trip out to Lantau Island. My tip would be buy your tickets online! I spent wayyyy to long in line for the gondola. I also paid for the slightly more expensive ticket (in the diamond gondola or something) and that was well worth the extra price as I completely skipped the line on the way back. The island is awesome. The Big Buddha is impressive, there is lots to take in - other statues, history, souvenirs, a few nature walks. Part of the Monastery was closed when I was there, but it was still well worth having a look around. There are a few restaurants that were reasonably priced at the top - although I wish I had taken a picnic!

The cable car to the Big Buddha is a great experience. Expect to queue for an hour to get the cable car on the way up but its well worth it for a great view. The Buddha is worth a look but the little tourist village around it is rather tacky...the kids would probably like it though.

Great day out. We did the return journey from Sha Tin to Lantau Island by bus. Ok going but coming back was peak time with only standing room and packed like sardines for 40 minutes. We took the cable car to the big Buddha on top of the mountain. Take your time climbing the steps to the Buddha there's a lot of them but worth the effort.

take a great cable car ride above the greenery and clouds. To avoid the cable car queues on arrival I took the bus as it was way cheaper and I thought a ground level view to start would be a good idea BUT the speed, the sheer drops and the shaking about left most people glad to get off in terror and rid me of any scary thoughts about a cable car ride down the mountain later! Take a Crystal Cabin to avoid the queues and get the best views through the see through floor! The cable car ride alone is worth the trip for the terrific views of this beautiful green island. The giant Buddha at the top and a tourist village gives the whole family many options to climb or shop and of course to eat in either western or asian cafes and restaurants. Throughout your time there taking pictures or selfies is irresistible with tourist set pieces to the views up and down the mountain especially with the giant Buddha in the background.

Hong Kong Escape. Take the subway out to Tung Chung and either get on the gondola for the ride up to the Po Lin monastery and the Big Buddha - worth the trip for the views and/or take the bus out to Tai Ho for the great bus ride and walkabout in this old fishing village. You can combine both but set aside a day if you do. Tai Ho offers good seafood options for snacks or lunch. Lantau is quite mountainous and underpopulated so you will enjoy the break from the crowds and noise of urban Hong Kong.

A nice break from the hustle bustle of Hong Kong. My daughter and I took a ferry there (about an hour) and walked around the village and then took a bus to the temple to see the gigantic Buddha and his devotee statues. We enjoyed the scenery, and purchased a few souvenirs, and had a bite at the vegetarian cafe.

FACTORY OUTLET!. i enjoyed the factory outlet in HK, bought a lot of things and very cheap. i suggest you go there in the middle of the day because what happened to us is we went there at night time so we were kinda exhausted and there's a lot of people roaming around. it's a very busy place.

Saw the Buddha and monastery.. My memories from a child saw a much changed island, with so many buildings. Riding bikes along the shore alone looking for the big Buddha. We never did find it! 36 years later we did find it. And so worth the climb to the top.Easy to get to on the MTR, then cable car up and back.Would love to come back and see more of Lantau.
excellent. excellent take a day off and visit this amazing island with your family serene peaceful and one of its kind nature mingling at its best

A Hong Kong Must-Visit. This definitely is in the top five things to do/visit when in Hong Kong. Recommended to check out Lantau Island in the morning so that it's not yet crowded with tourists. Get here via the Ngong Ping cable car, a 25-minute ride that gives visitors a breathtaking view of the HK airport, the bay and the mountains. Once on the island, move quickly thru the Ngong Ping Village and proceed to the Tian Tan Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery. If you have more time, check out also the Wisdom Path, which has some of the world's largest wood columns.

Fantastic Day trip. Booked a day trip through viator with the Lantau tour company.Our guide was informative and friendly.We enjoyed the beach views,saw wild buffalo,visited the Big Buddha ,had a great vegetarian lunch at the Po-Lin Monastery,and the climax was the cable car back down the mighty hills.I have rarely been on a better tour.

Wow Big Budha and DFO. Went for the Big Buddha and found Tung Chung the DFO for big brands...Coach Furla etc...the Citigate Centre is right next to the train station..take the cable car to BBthen return $210HKG and let the shopping commence
One of my fav places in Hong Kong. Had an Amazing day visiting the buddah , such a beautiful place , the cable ride coming upTo the mountain was just amazing

Take the gondola with the glass floor!. The giant Buddah is worth the hike, but Start your trip with the gondola with the glass floor....just beautiful. We stopped at the temple, wonderful photo opportunities. The floral and food offerings were works of art. Food here wasn't as diverse, but this is a feast for the eyes.

Amazing . We got there early it didn't open till 9 we was there at quarter to im so glad we was as we didn't que and we were one of the first up there meaning it was so peaceful before it was swarmed with fellow tourists. The village you go through is well kept but a tourist trap the big Buddha was amazing we climber to the top and it was so surreal. Views from the cable car amazing and it was a really good way to spend a few hours.
Cable car and Big Buddha. This is a must for anyone. Magnificent views from the cable car and well worth it. The experience at the top of the mountain once you arrive is fabulous.

Great view from cable car ride. . The view via cable car was great. Can see the Hkia from the top with planes taking off and landing every few minutes. Budget about 2 hours to visit the village. Try the tau foo fah ( sweet tau foo dessert) and black sesame dessert.

Worth the trip, a beautiful day trip!. I loved my trip to Lantau island and I took a day tour to the island which allowed me to skip the ticket lines on the gondolas and also provided a bus service to the budha site. Just an amazing place, a monastery and shrine, very much worth the trip! Walking around the monastery grounds was very special, and the shrine to Budha was magnificent! It was na easy day trip from Hong Kong and something you will never forget!
Worth a visit. Take the N Gong Ping Cable Car for amazing views of Lantau Island and the airport. The cable car takes you to the Big Buddha, and Po Lin Monastery. Lots to see and do.

touristy, but still nice. Nowadays You take the impressive cable car from (approx.) ´Tung Chung´-metro station and so You end up high in the mountains. As You have to see the ´Tai O´- fishing village anyway, You should buy a ´package´ including (cablecar+) Bus to/from Tai O, boat ride around Tai O (You probably won´t see ´purple dolfins though!) and some time in Tai O with ´Kwan Tai´-temple. Back up the mountain have a look at the (rather new) Big Buddha, see ´Po Lin´-monastery (in the monastery there is a vegetarian restaurant and ´cafe´(?)) and maybe do some shopping in the tourisic (and new) ´Ngong Ping´- "village". In case You have more time, go to ´Tai O´ by yourself and carry on to one of the beaches in the vicinity

charming serenity on a great little island that packs a punch!. head up the stairs to the big buddha its well worth the visit and the views of the surrounding area from above are incredibly beautiful! when the clouds start to descent around the hills surrounding the area you'll be dying to get that camera out for some great shots!

Lovely island - get away from the busy Hong Kong. Just 30 minutes by ferry and escape the busy life of Hong Kong. Visit one the many beaches and / or enjoy a seafood dinner in one of the harbour towns of this island. And if you feel like it, combine it with a nice track around the island.

Great cultural site. I took the subway to Tung Dhung and then the cable car to the Monastery. The. Rey commercial village you have to go through to get to the Buddha and Monastery seems out of place but there seems to be lots of people shopping and going to the other shows. I just went to the Monastery and climbed up to the Bhudda. Spent about 2 hours there and returned to the city.

Maybe better in clear, cooler, weather?. I paid a brief visit to Lantau Island on a recent visit to HK. As the air was murky for the entire period of my visit, I did not bother with Ngong Ping 360. It would hardly have been my first cable car (the Matterhorn is spectacular – I get the impression that Ngong Ping would have impressed me rather less even if I could have had some clear air). And big Buddhas fashioned for questionable motives (religious, or commercial? . . some writers seem to ruminate over this quandary) have also been spotted on more than one occasion. The other theme park aspects of the hilltop also seem a bit off-putting. I spend time in Buddhist countries, and go to temples for solace and meditation. Not for selfies or other photo ops, nor for adjustments to bucket lists. City Gate mall is touted as an outlet mall. If one has read the assessments of the “industry” built up around outlet malls, one might wonder about what's inside (and avoid such places). I spent a bit of time there one evening. It wasn't crowded then. The place is clean. However, it didn't present itself to me as good for any shopping, with the possible exception of some foodstuffs on the ground floor. The bus & MTR interchange outside the mall is, however, handy.My wife and son visited HK Disney during its opening week a few trips ago. My wife's summary? Lots of people with bad manners. Poor crowd control compared with Disney Anaheim or even Disney Orlando.Aome of the residential sections are also pleasant looking. Some views from the Tung Chung MTR line, and maybe more so from the roadway and buses, are also nice. The Tung Chung (and thus the Airport Express) line, however, was clearly not designed to optimize views from the train. That's a pity.The countryside looks inviting. The networks of trails beckon for another time, when the air might be cleaner and cooler. If I get to enjoy any of those under favourable conditions on a future trip, I might submit a new, more positive, view.

EXCELLENT!. We had an amazing day at Lantau, the cable ride is awesome, it was very foggy and it felt like out of a Jurassic Park scene.The big Buddha Sculpture is very impressive, and so are the temples at the Big Buddha base. Definitely worth the long metro trip.TIP: We went to see the Big Buddha very early to avoid long queues, so we had time to spare, after visiting the Big Buddha, we went shopping to the Outlet that's just outside the metro station, it had great discounts.

Very interesting, glad I went. Did a tour from a bus company. Was a fantastic day, saw lots, the tour guide, Sydney, was great. If don't want to make it all day, just do the shorter tour to skip the visit to jewellery shop and promenade. By doing the tour, we got quick access to the cable car as the lines were very long both ways. The cable car ride took my breath away, good and bad ( as wasn't expecting it to be so high, am afraid of heights.!!!), but what a great view. the lunch at the monastery was fresh and delicious. Then a great tour of fishing village. Bus even dropped off near hotel. Well worth the tour cost....about $100 AUD.
Do the Lantau Peak Hike!. We did it and got poured on but it was fun! Really nice views if its not foggy, and lots of stairs! Cool to see big buddha get smaller and smaller as you hike on
Mui Wo is a charming spot. While it is not a flashy place, it is very charming and there is a safe, relaxed feel. The food was good and the locals are friendly. I could actually live there!

More than you think.. We use Lantau as a base as we have family in Tung Chung. The island has the airport attached to it but there are other little gems out and about.Shopping: Tung Chung City Gate outlets stores may be of some interest.Kids: Disney at Sunny Bay is slowly improving it's rides I hear.Local: Tai O fishing village is a lovely place to visit, if only once. Houses on stilts and a little boat ride between them is worth a try.Wildlife: The main white/pink Dolphin watch trip goes out from Tung Chung pier so if you're not in Kowloon for the main pick up you can catch the trip from here.

Visit to Scenic Lantau Island. Lantau Island is an excellent getaway from the city life in Hong Kong. You have the option to take the cable car or you can also take buses from the bus station next to the cable car terminal in Tung Chung. Officially it is also referred to as Ngong Ping 360 and has a website of its own which has a lot of details. Once you reach the island, you can visit the giant statue of Buddha by climbing around 300 well-built stairs. There is a monastery near by where you can go for lunch or snacks. You can buy the tickets for these from the counters at the base of the staircase that leads to the Buddha statue. Once at the top near the statue, you can see all around the panoramic island. You can also go around the island on different buses if you arrive earlier and see the traditional fishing village etc. There are combo tickets available. You have plenty of food options once you reach the cable car terminal at the other end. If you take the cable car ride, you also get a nice view of the Hong Kong International Airport at a distance and you can see planes taking off or landing. The cable car ride is also very beautiful.

Holy site. Beautifull, peaceful, magestic. Truly stunning ,you fell close to everything you belive. Spirituality charged place. Worth to see and spend time wondering around.There is very long stairs to see the statue. If you buy organised tour, bus will take you right up there, not many people know that and the stairs can hold you back to see this amazing statue.

Not a good value. This costs about $100. USD to have a guided English speaking tour to go to the island, see the large Buddha, have lunch and ride the cable car back to the bottom of the monastery. It was quite disappointing

Calm and serene . The place has such peaceful atmosphere that you feel you have travelled to another world. We took the crystal cable car (only for onward journey). Although the day was bright and sunny, by the time we neared our destination in the cable car, we were surrounded by misty clouds. This place really seemed to emerge from beyond the end of the world. Once there, the aura of the place can be felt. Loved going there.

Not to be missed. If you visit HK, visit Lantau Island/Big Buddha. It very easy to get there on your own. Take the subway to TUNG CHUNG and then follow the directions to the cable car. Purchase your admission tickets online before arriving, you will avoid waiting on line. Choose the crystal cabins, you will have breathtaking views of HK. If you can also choose the private cabin, these lines also move faster and the cost is not too much more than the regular crystal cabins. Plan to spend at least 3 hours on this activity.Do not miss visiting Lantau Island

quaint. This is a small village with some lovely shops dotted about. Considering the cost of getting the skyline over and paying to enter you would think some of the attractions here would be included but most things have to be paid for as well separetly. The giant Buddha is stunning, a great monument to look over the city.

Worth the effort. Lantau is well worth a visit. Staying in Kowloon it was a metro ride to Tung Chung. Once there it is signposted to the cable cars. Nice trip up and over the hills to the Lantau Buddha site. Seeing the Buddha was impressive to say the least. Po Lin Monastery was also fascinating. Only at odds thing is the theme park entrance to the site which detracts from the initial reverence of such a holy place. Really lovely though once you are passed all of that.

Urban Sprawl. The giant Buddha is a tourist attraction worth seeing. The small villages on the island are in some disrepair even though property prices are now silly.Still lots of countryside and some nice beaches.Worth a daytrip but no more.

Go by boat. Catch the ferry from Central piers to Mui Wo and then bus it around the island to see attractions. You get to see the activity on the harbour plus the bus ride to the big Buddha takes you through Lantau countryside. Taking the bus back down is more exciting as it negotiates the many corners to get down to sea level. The only downside to taking the ferry and bus is it takes a bit longer. There are 2 ferry's and the slow one seemed to take about an hour, a bit longer than the fast one. The slow ferry has the advantage that you can sit up the back in the open and observe the ships and the view without awindow in front of you
Great views and culture. Took the cable car to the Tin Tan Budha and enjoyed the whole area. Great views (on a clear day...not the usual HK days) of the airport area and parts of the harbor.

Hiking, great views, big buddha, fishing village, monastery, temples and more. What's not to love about a place with something for everyone. Whether you like to hike and enjoy the beautiful outdoors, sight-seeing or feeling like you stepped back in time 30 years, Lantau island has something for you. The Ngong Ping 360 (crystal cabins are the best) is a great way to start where you can get great views of the water, islands, HKIA (airport), the big buddha and more. Next, you can continue your walk to see the Big Buddha, Grand Hall of Ten Thousand Buddhas (newly opened) and Po Lin Monastery. 15min walk from there is Wisdom path and many other trails or a 15min taxi or 25-30min bus ride and you are at Tai O fishing village. Whether you are on a long layover in Hong Kong or visiting for days/weeks, Lantau should be at the top of your list. Opt for a clear day if you are here for more than 1-2 days but even on cloudy days, it is still an amazing place to visit.

Worth to pay a visit. It was a half day trip. My friends and I took the MTR from Tsim Sha Tsui station to Tung Chung station. We bought a travel package which consisted of going to Ngong Ping by cable car, bus ride on the island (from the Big Buddha to Tai O Fishing Village), a boat ride where you get to see pink dolphin and came back to Tung Chung MTR station by bus. It's worth to pay a visit to this place.

A Little Out of the Ordinary.. Ferry trip to Hong Kong Island (40 mins) . Dinner in the Hotel Restaurant. Leave plenty of time to call taxi for return to airport. Carpets need cleaning, bathroom grouting needs scrub, but hey!

HK's Green Lung. This is the place to come to get away from people. Avoid the slurpiness of overpriced D'land. Take a bus from Tung Chung to a mountain pass and start walking. With luck, you wont meet anyone all day. just watch out for snakes.

Get out and Hike. There are miles of hiking tracks on Lantau Island. You can walk for hours , some of the tracks are 10 km long with climbs of up to 700 metres. There is wild cattle to see and the most spectacular views of the city , the airport and the surrounding sea approaches. You can travel to and from by ferry, train or bus. I suggest a combination with overland walks in between. You will not believe you are in HKG.Take plenty of water and look out for snakes in the summer. But in the winter months it is the best thing to do in HKG.

Great outdoor!. It's a great place for those who love the outdoors. There are two high peaks - Lantau Peak and Sunset Peak, great beach in Cheung Sha, shallow bay for kite surfing in Shui Hau Wan, Po Lin Monastery and sitting Buddha and posh water front restaurants in Discovery Bay. All you need you will find on Lantau.

Must see attraction. This is a Must see attraction while you're in Hong Kong. I was amazed with the size of a Budha statue... great half day trip! Take the ferry boat yourself and save the money instead of taking a tour guide... Will come back again sometime in my life for sure!

An Outdoor Haven. If outdoors and family fun is you thing, Lantau is the place to head to. The magical kingdom of Disneyland, the resort-like Discovery Bay, the scenic hiking trails of Ngong Ping and the charming fishing village of Tai O - you could easily spend a good 2 to 3 days just discovering all Lantau has to offer. P.S. Most tourists confuse Lantau Island with the more famous Ngong Ping and skip visiting the other attractions. In fact, Ngong Ping is just one attraction on Lantau Island.Remember that Lantau Island is huge, even bigger than Hong Kong Island so be prepared for long transfer times between attractions, particularly if you're taking public transport. Taxis are easily available but the vast distances mean the fare accumulates pretty quickly. Lantau is connected by buses to the airport and subway, buses and boats to Hong Kong Island.

Make your own adventure. Hong Kong is expensive, but using the Mass Transit or Bus on Lantau Island is a cheap and adventurous way to get around by yourself or with a family. The Metro is easy to use.It is clean and fast. You get to traverse varied scenery of HK - Disney, The Great Buddha, Mountains, Shopping etc

Variety of activities on Lantau. Very scenic ride on the cable car. It's worth purchasing the tour package which gives you priority cable car tickets, tour of Tai O fishing village, boat ride including opportunity to see HK pink dolphins offshore if you are lucky and short tour of Ngong Ping village. Opportunity to see Big Buddha statue and do some walking trails including Lantau Peak for those fit people. Delicious vegetarian snacks available at the Po Lin Monastery

Lantau explorer tour. Great 7 hour tour. Good ferry ride to island. Back to mainland by 5km cable car.
Great views. Tai-O-fishing village on stilts - boarded small boat to get up close
saw large Buddha - lots of steps to the top. Nice vegetarian/chinese lunch at Monastry
Fully recommend. Costs about $130 aussie dollars each.

Worth a Visit. It is the greener part of the bustling Hong kong city. It is situated near the airport or 45 mins from the city centre. There is cable car to go to the Lantau island from Tung Chung staion. You have get down at Ngong Ping. You can spend the whole day at the island. You can see Tian Tan Buddha, Po Lin monastery, Wisdom Path, Tai O fishing village, shopping at the Ngong Ping village. From the cable car you can get panoramic view of the coastlines and green top mountains.
Food. Rainbow seafood restaurant was fabulous as was the Junk ride there at night - great experiencing the HK harbour at night
Value for money. We went on a day trip to Lantau island. Had a vegetarian lunch at the monastery which was good and tasty. The ride back on the cable car was an experience.

LANTAU ISLAND HONG KONG. It is one of the clean place and perfect infrastructure with disciplined rules for traffic whereby it takes less than 1 hour to reach from city to Airport.A perfect organized as per today's requirements of travel.It has scenic view.

Lantau Island. This is a must for everyone to visit! Was great seeing the planes taking off and landing at airport and Lanatau is so green and surrounded by sky scrapers which seems really strange.Its very quiet due to not many cars being on the island and most visitors go to Disneyland or to Big Buddha.Travelling by cable car is a must as the views are fantastic.

Love Lantau. When you arrive at Hong Kong you actually land here and then have to travel to Hong Kong on a very clean and efficient tram system. Lantau needs time because it has so much to offer. Besides the shopping for loads of name brands - rather do the other trips Lantau has to offer

Best kept secret. Loved being in amongst the locals and where they lived. Not as crowded. Very friendly. The best beach at Silvermine beach which is manned by lifeguards. fresh food markets as well as flea markets. Cooked food markets as well

Hiking is better in NT, save your trip here for Po Lin. The monastery is well worth a day trip, and the lunch is---ok--but well worth taking (the hall and monastic dining experience won't be equalled anywhere). Be sure to go with your family if you have one--the kids will sleep well at night after they hike to the top of the buddha! the boat crossing is beautiful as well

Land of Buddha and nature trails. Lantau is a quiet island closer from Hong Kong airport. Big Buddha, spiritual path, Tai o village are major attractions on island. The trail to the spiritual path is very pleasant & calm. Hong Kong experience is surely incomplete without a day long visit to Lantau.
Excellent tourist spot. The best part about the spot is that. There is nothing there but the artificially made features like 360 nonping and tourist spot made in Lantau island is excellent

Worth the long queue for the cable car. We waited in line for at least 45 minutes just to get over to see the Big Buddha on the island- well it was worth it.
We noticed that it is possible to hike rather than take the cable car - I'd love to try that next time... doesn't look easy though!

The Journey. I gave this a low rating because we did not know that after a somewhat long MTR ride to Tung Chung, that it was another 45 minute bus ride to the Big Buddha. It was late afternoon, very hot and humid, and we did not allocate enough time so discontinued this point of interest. So the low rating is not for Lantau Island nor the Big Buddha, but more for our lack of homework on the logistics and planning. If you go on your own, I would recommend an early start.

Go DIY, it's easy and worth it.. We took the metro to Lantau, found the cable car to Ngong Ping right outside, then caught the no. 21 bus to Tai O, from where we got a ferry back to the metro. All very easy and economical. A super day.

A must visit with family. the only best experience our family had was going to lantau island. a good experience starting from the ropeway fromm ehere you also get to see crocodiles beneath and breathtaking experience of greenery and nature. kids will surely love it.

Beautiful. Went here purely by accident on star ferries,did not dissapoint,beautiful day,the boat trip was great so many islands to see,Lantau has a lovely beach with shark netsand lifeguards for safe swimming,real escape haven from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong

Great day. My wife and I went on a Sunday, which was a great idea as catching the MTR from Kowloon there was no crowds at all. Tip is to get thete by 9.00am. The afternoon lines for the cable cars are crazy. Great view from the cable car. Good food spots at the top near the big budda. Well worth the trip down to the fishing village to see the pink Doplhin and to try the local food.
Worth the trip. Make sure you take the cable car there, book tickets online first as there was a big queue to join. You can take the bus back as it's cheaper!
Buddha amazing. Really worth the 15 minute cable car ride out to the monastery...the Buddha is an amazing structure. Take a cab up if tram is busy (only blue cabs can go up...not real cheap)

good if you spare day. It will take the whole day. Plan only if have a extra day in HK. There are many other place in HK for priority. Queus are long and take a hour or two at cable car station in peak hours which is tiresome

Worth the trip. Great place to visit recommend the crystal cable car for the ultimate experience, views are fantastic make sure you pick a clear day for the ultimate view. There is also a great shopping mall

Fantastic!. This was the best part of our visit to Hong Kong!The ride up to the village was spectacular. And one you're up there, it's simply breathtaking.The little souvenir shops, great food, gorgeous Po Lin Monastery and the crown of it all - the giant Buddha statue.This is a must if you're in Hong Kong! You won't regret it!

Worth a Visit. Did a tour to Lantau Island with a coach ride there, cable car to the Po Lin Monastery and Ferry back to Central on Hong Kong Island, all included. The cable car ride was great, even though the haze meant the views were not as good as they could be. We found the monastery very interesting, especially the huge bronze Buddha. The little shopping street is great for souvenirs and Ice Creams and the best place of all was the shop that specialised in chopsticks of every kind. We bought some of their lovely chopsticks for family and friends. From the Central Ferry Terminal it was a quick ride on Star Ferry back to our hotel in Kowloon, watching the lights of HK on the way.

Amazing ride. Take the crystal botton cable car if you are not scared of heights. The crowds are also less on that one. Shop for brands near the cable car office. See all the sights. Eat in the monastary.

You don't feel like it's in Hong Kong. The best way to get here is by Ngong Ping Cable Car from Tung Chung. To get to Tung Chung you have to take MRT (Tung Chung line/Disneyland Resort) from Kowloon Station, Hong Kong Station, Tsing Yi, Lai Keng and Olympic. One trip from Kowloon station to Tung Chung is HKD 18. The journey will take about 30 minutes. Once exiting walk toward the Ngong Ping cable car station. I strongly suggest that you avoid weekends and public holidays (if possible), but if you only be able to visit during weekends or public holidays I strongly suggest that you pre purchased the ticket through it's official website. The queue can take as long as an hour to purchase the ticket (if you purchase the ticket on site). The standard cabin will set you back HKD 150 (return) while the crystal cabin (the floor of the cable car made of glass) will set you back HKD 235 (return). They also offer a bundling package that will start at HKD 250 (depends on the package you want to take). The cable car journey takes about 20 minutes (roughly) from Ngong Ping lower station to Lantau Island. Once you get to the island there is a ngong ping village which consists of shops and restaurants. The main attraction in Lantau Island is the Po Lin Monastery and the sitting Buddha statue. The last cable car to leave Ngong Ping village is at 6.00 pm during weekdays (Mon-Fri), and at 6.30 pm during weekend and public holiday.

Discovery Bay. First went to Discovery Bay 20 years and went back to check out the changes, of which there were many. However, it is still a lovely place and we had a really nice meal before heading back to Kowloon. Would have liked to have spent more time there. Lovely beach area close to lots of reastuarants and eateries.

Find the infinity pools..... I can't speak for the rest of the island but I know I had a wonderful day here. I'm not sure what stop it is on the Tai O bus but it looks like a little fishing hub/pier with a long walk way heading out to the coastline. Take that pier walkway out and walk all the way to the end and follow the walkway. Ask some people you cross where the pools are and it's only a 20-25min hike up to them. My friend and I hiked pretty far up past the main 2-3 pools and you can make it all the way to the ridge line if you like. If that's something you want to do I strongly recommend bringing something sturdier than flip flops... There is flagging that shows you the best path up until the last little chunk before the ridge line. I will say that the best pool we found was about 1/2-2/3 the way up to the very top so continue on only if you are really keen on the view point.
Nice experience. The glass floored cable car is highly recommended. The walk up to the buddha statue was great. Also, if you are lucky you may get to see the dolphins if you opt for the boat ride.

Good Half-Day Trip. *) Nearest MTR: Tung Chung MTR Station, leave the MTR station via Exit B and follow the signs for a 2 minute walk to the Ngong Ping 360 Cable Car, this will take you directly to the summit, from where you can climb the stairs to reach to the Big Buddha. The cable car ride of course gives great views over the island, and takes about 20 or 30 minutes.*) We bought the ticket for the cable car, single-ride on the spot itself. Costs 105 HKD for a Standard Cabin. Pick up a map of Ngong Ping Village from the Ticket Office. Cable Car ride provides amazing views and is a must-do.*) The cable car drops you at the station on the other side, from there its a small walk to Po Lin Monastery and to the foot of Big Buddha, through the village, which is more like a road with lots of restaurants and shops etc. On the way while going you will see Public Transport Interchange on your right side, from here you can take the return bus Lantau Bus No 23 back to Tung Chung MTR instead of Cable Car. The bus drives through steep hill and takes around double the time of Cable Car approx 45 mins. Try to sit on the upper deck of the bus, gives better views.*) Toilets are available in the village road.*) There is a Subway (Shop No: 9B), Starbucks Coffee (Shop No: 10) and Seven-Eleven as well, both at the cable car station, outside MTR, as well as in the village road.*) Did not see Indian food options, but Vegetarian options are available in the Po Lin Monastery itself. While visiting the Po Lin Monastery don't miss the chance to dine on some authentic Buddhist Vegetarian food either at the dining hall or the deli/snack-shop. All foods here conform to Buddhist Vegetarian principles and contains only vegetables, bean products and oysters. Outside at the deli/snack-shop similar vegetarian delights can be bought to take away, or to eat at the outdoor tables. Focusing more on snacks size items there are daily freshly made bean curd deserts and most famously the mango filled rice dumplings. The dining hall is open from 11:30 to 4:30pm and is to the left of the main Shrine. *) Did not see Drinking water fountains, so best to bring your own water.For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://hongkongandmacauitinerary.blogspot.in/2014/10/hong-kong-macau-itinerary.html

do it on the way. the island hasn't got much to offer: a big outlet mall, the big Buddha, Tai O. If possible, combine it with your flight as the airport is also located on the island and they have a very convenient left luggage service

A must visit place. The island itself is green and beautiful but most people come for the big buddha and they are not disappointed. If you arrive by cable car, you will see the buddha appearing in the distance out of the trees.Make sure to have lunch at the Monks' kitchen. The food is so exciting! Even if you are only in HK for a few days, make sure to find time to get to Lantau. I would suggest at least a day be set aside but you could probably manage in half a day at a push.Why not head by ferry to some of the fishing villages on the way back to extent the experience!

pretty cool. good place and very decent. Just advice when you go here dont forget to bring your umbrella. Make sure the cable car is open one day before or you have to get public bus to go to lantau island.

worth seeing - but a tourist trap. Visited in October 10, 2014. First recommendation, if you plan on taking the cable car, purchase your ticket in advance so that when you get there you can get it the line for those already with tickets. When we arrived (around 10:30 am) we followed the signs from the train station and thought it looked like a short line, but it snaked around and then once you finally made it to the ticket booth, there was another snaked line hidden from view behind the ticket booth. We ended up waiting in line for over an hour. The view was really great though once we were on the car.We would recommend taking the bus up and the cable car back but we did not take the bus so that may also be a long wait.Upon arrival, it felt like the Asian version of Florida's "Holy Land" theme park. Lot's of opportunities to buy stuff, "walking with Buddha" movie, etc. The good part is that there is an actual monastery, Po Lin. It was nice and it is a good idea to be quiet and respectful as visitors worship. The steps to the Buddha are pretty steep if you are not in good shape. The Buddha itself is a little difficult to photograph (kind of like being next to the statue of liberty). For Photographic reasons, choose the time of day wisely. We ended up getting there later than we anticipated due to the long lines for the cable car. So roughly around 1:00 PM. The sun was making it so difficult to get a decent photo.Keep a close watch on the ground below and you can see the amazing hiking trail and animals. It is worth going to after you wade through the tourism zone.

Brilliant!. It was great! First you get on cable car that takes you to Lantau Island. On the way you can see Big Buddha in a distance. We didn't get to spend a lot of time on the island because we got there quite late, but I would recommend going there for 2-3 hours, maybe for some lunch or a drink.
Good for Sightseeing. Can visit the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery, Ngong Ping Piazza. Take Ngong Ping 360 for a good view of Sightseeing and nature.

Not to be missed. Even it a typhoon threatened to put a damper on our holiday plans in HK, hubby and I still went for it and our first stop was Lantau Island. The bus ride to the top (the cable cars were not in operation at the time due to the storm) was picturesque. You see greens everywhere. Although most attractions were closed by the time we got there, we were able to check out the the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery and the Ngong Ping Plazza. There's an inherent sense of peace and tranquility in this place. But maybe it's also because we were almost alone there, thanks to the bad weather.
A must do place to get out of town. Get away from the city and experience the countryside of Hong Kong. Cable car is a must, but buy your tickets in advance.

Very touristic but still a good visit. It takes some times from central to access the island with public transportation, crowded place over week-end however still a good visit. Right at the MTR station, you will find outlet stores good place for place for shopping therefore. Then, you need to queue up to either to get a bus or cable car to reach the Big Buddha. We preferred to catch the cable car to catch a great view of the hills and it was really impressive since the cable car goes up and down according to hills and you can even watch the brave hikers underneath. At the final stop of the cable car, it felt a bit like Disneyland with various touristic activities: tea ceremony, shops, movie theme show, Buddhist temple, the Big Buddha. If you arrive there early, I guess you will have the chance to visit a beach, a fisher village, see dolphins.

Part of the buddha experience. Taking the Ngong Ping cable car puts you firmly on Lantau Island, and this ride gives you a nice overview. You can see the airport but also the sea on the other side. That gave me many inspirations for my next visit there, like actually hiking up to the big Buddha, or exploring more of the hills and forests on this nice island. Easy to get there with MTR to Tung Chung, and for the shopoholics, there is the citygate outlet mall close to the MTR station.
visit the Buddha. Traveller by MTR and then took bus around island, very easy to use. Queue too long for the cable car, and you need to get bus then to see the rest of the island
Very commercial.. Liked the cable car ride...amazing, but way too many cheap and junky shops. Very crowded with long waiting in ques to get on cable car.
Budda. The cable car was great! Remarkable views. The village was lovely and the Budda was magnificent! Loved it.

Nice chance to get away from the busy city. There will be people selling a package for hkd360 which includes the cable car up to ngong ping..boat ride to the fishing village and walk to the big buddha..everything took bat 3hrI took the package and it was worth it..the cable car ride provides nice scenery of the hk skylineafter the visit..rmb to shop at city gate outlet store located just at the bottom of the cable car station..there are good deals at coach, burberry and kate spade etc..

Nice Island. The airport is located off this island as is the Big Buddha statue. For shopping, there is the Cityscape Outlet is located. The fisherman's village is a nice, quiet place to explore. I like this Island. easy to get to and a nice place to spend a day. also. for hikers, one can hike out in the rural sections of the Island. there is a park located on the far end where one can hike to the ruins of an old Qing Dynasty fort.
Great place for one day visit. Sometimes the lines for the cable car are too long and it takes one-two hours waiting...Great view, it is not necessary to buy a crystal cabin ticket

Big Buddha. This is one of my favorite places to go to whenever I travel to HK. I have listed a number of things that I like for easy reading.1. Weather - I always make sure that I go to Lantau Island during the cold season. Since I am from a tropical country, I always appreciate every chance I get to experience a nice and cool breeze2. Accessibility - Walking distance from Tung Ching MTR station (this is where the Citygate Outlets mall is located; a plus for me)3. Village Food - Good number of restaurants in the Island when you step out of the cable car bay - Da dolce Gelato Italiano - Starbucks Coffee (go in the morning and enjoy a cup of coffee in a cool weather with a great  scenery)4. Cable Car - differnt types of cabins you can choose from. - I opted for the Standard Cabin (doesn't quite make much of a difference from the Crystal Cabin) Standard price: $HKD 150 Crystal price: $HKD 235 (glass floor)I recommend this place for those who wants to experience the cultural and historical side of Hong Kong. It has a scenic view of the Big Buddha and the temples.

Airport. The airport is huge and it's kind of confusing if you travelled alone because I travelled back to Manila alone that time. Well I asked around and they were really accommodating so I found my way to go home without delay.

The Budda. The main reason to visit Lantau Island is the giant Budda. Very impressive and well worth the visit. There are loads of steps up to the Budda, but if you are lucky your bus will drop you at the top so will only have to walk down.

Our best day of the week.... We caught the MTR to the end of the line & then got the Cable Car (over 4km of it) to the Big Buddha etc... Absolutely astonishing ride especially if you get a crystal bottomed car on way up. Awesome views of the water, greenery and airport. There is some pretty good shopping at the end (and at the beginning with Gateway Outlet Mall) and of course the Big Buddha and Monastery where you can have a vegetarian lunch (not buying ticket for this also gives you access to the museum in Big Buddha). Highspot for us though was the tea house at the bottom of the hill which featured on Dubai One. Here we saw the tea ceremony with flowering tea and got some tranquility. This is the tea house near the Cable Car station.

Small Fishing Village. Off the tourist belt is a small fishing village Tin O. Take bus no.21, pay just HK6.60 adult fare. Visit the smallest of market, buy some fresh seafood if you like...while walking just past the bridge, lookout for a hanging shark that is about 1+half the size of any adult. Try the seafood fried rice HK40 enough for two...try the egg Ball cake -HK15 fix price, roam around thirsty buy a drink that is reddish in color (sour plum ++) not too sweet & pleasant tasting. Go for a 20 minutes boat ride, HK25 but you may not get to see any dolphins if the water is too rough. Your next bus No.21 leave for the Big Buddha at exactly on the hour ....enjoy be happy.

ok to get some fresh air. The gondola ride offers stunning views indeed, but it doesn't end on a mountaintop as some might expect. The village is out in the green, somewhat artificial and quite pricey. There ist not very much to do for a traveller however. The place is designed for locals. What a paradise , when you live in the busy city all year. We got there on a Sunday and it was packed with queuing times at to get in and again to return with the gondola.
Cable. Car and ferry. We travelled to lantau by mtr. Took cable car to see Budda then no 2 bus to mui wo and ate at excellent Turkish restaurant near macdonalds.

Glimpleses of mixture of rural n urban Hongkong. During my Hongkong trip with my family last month,we all went there.After arriving at the cable car station we purchased the vip tickets,so tht we avoided the waiting lines over there.Had a great cable car ride.After reaching there the guide took us to the villege.There they took us in a boat.We got to see the old fishing village.Then the boat took us in to sea,where we got to see the red dolphins playing there.Lovely view.Then from there we went to see the Big Buddha n Po Lin Monestry.Realy awasom.If u r at Hongkong,then its an must

Highly recommend, buy the tickets online . The experience in general is extraordinary! I love it! The ride is beautiful, simply spectacular ! The fusion between nature n technology. If u are not willing to expend an hour queuing but the tickets online. Don't forget to get at least one way using the Crystal ride. So much nicer!

Our day on Lantau Island. We caught the ferry over to Lantau Island, then a public bus to the tiny fishing village of Tai O. We wandered around just taking in the daily life and went on a twenty minute boat ride. It was very interesting seeing the stilt houses, and we were lucky enough to see the pink dolphins. We caught another bus to Tian Tan to see the big buddha and then the cable car ride to an mtr station. Cable car takes about 30 minutes, it is a great way to see the view of Hong Kong. It was a little hazy the day we were there, but well worth it. A great day seeing the sights.
Cable car is worth it. We really enjoyed the cable car journey across the mountains, the views were amazing but found big Buddha very touristy
Quaint and spiritual. Travelled on metro to cable car which has fantastic view of Lantau Island to the Budda. Really pretty at the top and interesting, so pleased we went.

You just can't miss Lantau Island, wonderful and unique experience. One of my favourite part of Hong Kong, the best part about Lantau Island is Big Buddha. To get up to the top of the mountain to see Big Buddha you would need to pay to get on a cable car I've got height anxiety so didnt take the cable car but good news for any one with height anxiety or phobia is that there are coaches that go up to the top of the mountain as well. Take abit longer than the cable car but ticket is really cheap. When you are up at the top you would be witnessing one of the most beautiful sight that exist in this planet Big Buddha along with the stairs that lead everone to him. The temple at the bottom of Big Buddha has a restaurant which serve vegetarian food which I found delicious. This is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen and would recommend anyone going to hongkong not to miss. Also at the bottom of the mountain at the coach station there is a shopping outlet with many great clothing store with decent price also restaurant like Star buck or Mac Donald it will be your great day out.

Beautiful beach with cows. Lower Cheung Sha Beach is a 10-15 minute cab or bus ride from Mui Wo Ferry Pier and is worth the trip - we got the high speed ferry from Central and the whole day was v efficient. There are restaurants, sand, strolling cows (some with v big horns), showers, toilets and a shark net - damaged on the day we were there which led to life, death and swimming discussions and decisions! We survived and the net was fixed and the bus leaves across the road from the beach turn off on the main road. Highly recommended as a day away from air conditioning and shops selling things that you neither want or can afford.

Great day tour. The cable car ride is very good and enjoyable. The nice village like atmosphere on the other side is quite quaint with some fancy shopping options as well. Good say to spend a day with friends ire family.

Something different. Cable car from next to the MTR railway (takes 25 minutes) is almost frightening - is so high that you are looking over the airport way in the distance. Absolutely massive Buddah at the top of the cablecar
Tranquility in HK. I find Lantau Island to be the calm in amongst the business that is Hong Kong. The MTR (public transport network) makes getting around easy and economic.

Take the Bus. Took the ferry from Central to Lantau Island and a bus to Tai O, a small fishing village. Interesting ride through the hills on the island. The quaint fishing village was fun to walk around. Check out the houses on stilts. Good bus service, easy to get around.

Giant Budhha. I went straight to lantau island after landed at the HK In'tl Airport as it is only 5 to 10 minutes away from the airport. You could deposit your luggage at the nearby Citygate Outlet Malls or near the Cable Car.The two-way cable car ride was expensive. Scenic view of the island from the cable car was fine but I got bored after awhile as the ride was pretty long. It I felt that there wasn't much to see at the island itself. Access to the temple for the giant buddha closed at 5pm, i think, so check your time before going.

A must see in Hong Kong.
