Beautiful place, we booked a tour in our hotel and drove to the cable car terminal, the cable car takes around 25 mins to get to where the big Buddha and the temple are, totally worth the ride! Once there you'll have to do a vegetarian lunch as it is not permitted to eat meat and then climb the 262 steps to the Buddha, inside it there is a beautiful museum. After you finish the Buddha make sure to visit the fishermen village, the dried fish market is an experience.

Highly recommended, a sight not to be missed!!!!. What a lovely way to spend a day. The cable car is not for the faint hearted but the views are stunning from such a great height. We arrived on a misty day and it was eery going up in all the mist. When we got to the top the sun came out and oh boy!! What a suprise as the big Buddha is gigantic. The Big Buddha is beautiful. The temple is lovely and serene.

what a beautiful sight. lantau island was such a enlightening experience, the cable car line is a bit long but if you purchase a crystal cabin not only can you speed through the line but you also get the best view of lantau island at its finest. The island itself looks amazing a nice mix between rural and urban. Theres a good range of food available.Theres livestock walking around as well as dogs, although they are friendly.really unique souvenirs and the opportunity to eat vegetarian food made at the templesoverall a really nice experience
Discount store. Worth the trip. Just jump on the underground - it's super easy and quick. Some great discount store, which you reach the moment you arrive on the underground.

Amazing day out. We went to Lantau Island on one of the country's public holiday and although the queue from Tung Chung terminal wasn't too bad for 10:00 in the morning, advance purchase is recommended. There are choices of a variety of packages available, if you want to make the most of the experience on the island. Taking a cable car is not only the most quickest way but offers great views of Hong Kong International Airport and the surrounding land and sea . There are plenty of shops in the village selling various souvenirs, so there is something suitable for everyone! There are various shows available to keep everyone entertained. A walk up the many steps to see the Buddha is tiring but well worth the effort where there are spectacular sceneries around. For those who loves a walk, there are guided trails for short walk in the countryside.If you are planning to return to Tung Chung by cable car, remember to buy a return ticket so you can be fast tracked to the front of the queue. When we were leaving the queue was do long and were glad we purchased a return ticket!
Great, once you're there. We really enjoyed Lantau island...once we got there. Queue for cable car was horrendous but once there, the whole family enjoyed the experience.

Beautiful. What a lovely way to spend a day. The cable car is not for the faint hearted. But the rewards are amazing. The Big Buddha is beautiful. The temple is lovely. It would have been nice to w
Have time to wander around the shops. We were also lucky enough to see the pink dolphins playing.

Must see but do it on your own. I did a full day tour but we only spent 4 hours on Lantau Island. If I went back again I would travel to Lantau Island myself to see the big Buddha you can catch the cable car up to the big Buddha and then have as much time as you want to look around in the nearby area. The crystal gondola was definitely worth the extra money.
LOVED IT. We stayed at HK Disneyland Resort and travelled on the Disneyland train to several touristy destinations - including the Giant Buddha, the Ngong Ping 360 and others

Lantau Island. We loved Lantau Island. Travelled fist to Big Budha, and then, by bus to Tai O. Due to typhoon approaching, there were no trips to see the dolphins so we went for a very long walk through the seafood market and the village - after a while there were no tourist there. Came back by bus. Definitely worth going to.

Don't miss this treat. We took the Gong Ping gondolas to the summit. On the way you pass over a bay, get a view of the airport, and then have a short walk to the Big Buddha. You have a choice of a regular gondola or a crystal gondola. The only downside was that very other site offered us a senior discount. This site only site offers it to those have a Hong Kong resident card.

Stunning rugged beauty. I've been to Hong Kong many a time, but did not spend much time on Lantau outside of the airport. I took time to visit Lantau recently and am amazed at its rugged beauty, far removed from shopping in Mong Kok or Central. To get around, I took the NP 360 to the big buddha followed by a bus to Tai O and then bus back to Tung Chung. While the destinations were interesting, the best part was the journey on the gondola and buses.

Worth the effort just for the views from the cable car. We took the MTR from Mong Kok to Tung Chung and it was a very short walk to the cable car. The MTR is fast, clean and economical.Go early and if you come back early you may even get a cable car to yourself - great for taking photographs. We did not see the value in the glass bottom cable car. At peak times they put 10 people in each cable car.Amazing views of the airport on reclaimed land and the new bridge being built from Lantau over to Hong Kong.

Beautiful island. Lantau Island is almost tropical. We had lunch at the monestary and it was just beautiful. The lunch is vegan and there is no alcohol but it was all amazing. Lantau is definitely worth a visit.

A sure must do in HK. Missed visiting this place the other 2 times I was in HK due to tight schedules. Had a lot of time to spare with my family and got a great time at the island. The people were friendly and met some locals who gave us good advice for toddler friendly restaurant.The sights was beautiful and gave us a different sight a way from HK itself.

Worth a Trip To Experience Another Side of Hong Kong. We spent a day touring the island and monastery. I'd suggest arrival at the monastery early in the day, as the crowds are less, and the atmosphere more calming. The vegetarian lunch was quite good at the monastery also. Well worth the trip out from the city - you can take the MTR subway train directly to the Tung Chung station and walk just a short distance to either the cable car or buses. It's all easy to navigate.
Great island. We enjoyed our trip here. Tai O fishing village, is a sight to see and the Giant Budda was amazing. We enjoyed a delicious vegetarian meal at the Monastry.

Very interesting day out.. Lantau island is quite different to HK island and Kowloon. We went on a pre paid day tour including pick up from and return to hotel in Kowloon. We went on a mini bus to a beach on the south side, into the mountains, to the Tai O fishing village on stilts on the river, the short boat trip, the village market with dried fish and undiscernable other items, then to the top of Ngong Ping where sits the Big Buddha. Because we were in a mini bus we could be driven to the top. Large buses cannot fit and have to stay at the bottom. So we only had to walk down the 265 stairs, not up as well. At the bottom of the stairs, remember to stand in the centre of the circular structure and speak to hear your own echo - natural accousitcs because of the circle. Quite remarkable. The meal at the Monastery (vegan only) was fantastic ! We were unable to go by cable car that day as it was closed for regular maintenance (closed for a whole week every 2 or 3 months) so had to return by mini bus. However, as the cable car (called Ngong Ping 360) was open again a few days later, we returned independently (no tour) and discovered the themed village as well. It was all so very close to the Monastery and the Big Buddha. Well set up for tourists, clean and appealing. Easy to get the MTR train to Tung Chung station from HK. Get the cable car up to the Big Buddha, Monastery, Themed Village and back home same way. If visiting Lantau Island independently (not on a pre paid tour) you can pay at the Cable Car terminal at Tung Chung for optional extras to go to the fishing village and have the Monastery meal if you want. Allow a whole day. Very enjoyable.
Less busy. Lantau seemed much less frenetic than H.K. Island. Proximity to Disney land would be a plus for many.
Great touch of historic HK.. Visited a Taoist temple and Tai O fishing village was like stepping back 500 years! Walking through the local fishing markets was a neat experience.

Hong Kong Countryside. We just spent the day on Lantau, visiting the Giant Buddha, the Po Lin Monastery and the Tai O fishing village. I felt all were worth the time and effort to get there by subways, ferries and buses. Make sure to walk behind those fishing boats so you don't miss out on the fresh and dried fish market. We ate with mostly locals at air conditioned Fook Moon Lam restaurant having fresh scallops and squid. Lantau is a beautiful island with huge green mountains and beautiful scenery.

A visit to Tai O village is recommended. Whilst on Lantau Island a must see attraction is going to the fishing village at Tai O. Taking a boat trip through the village with all of the houses on stilts is totally fascinating. Venturing further out on the boat to see the pink dolphins (if you're lucky) in the open sea is an added bonus. Wandering through the land part of the village to see all the different cooking stalls was also quite amazing. The actual boat trip is fairly short but is still worth while because it is a wonderful experience to witness the daily life of other small waterway craft traffic and how people live on the water in this part of Hong Kong.
Beautiful. Lovely day trip even when the weather was less than perfect. Stopped at many little towns on the coast as we were traveling by bus. Very accessible.

A Must See. The ancient traditions, culture and religion are detailed here on the Island. Easy transportation, and phenomenal detail in the Monastery. Will review this island separate and in detail. Sounds like it is old and you travel back in time and nothing could be further from the truth. The monastery is preserved but the mall and modern cable car transports are as good as you will find at any North American mall, just not the scale we are used to. Everything in Hong Kong is small foot print and vertical, Except the Big Buddha.

Beautiful. A big contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city. Here it is peaceful and calm, green and less humid and stuffy. The fishing villages are a step back in time and you see a different way of life. Easy to get to either by bus or mtr and cable car...but be prepared for big queues, and they do close the cable car for maintenance.

Very nice day trip!. I definitely recommend a visit to Lantau island, when you are in HK. You have big choice of sightseeing places, beaches, good food, nature and nice areas for cycling! Explore according to your interests!

Worth a look. Quite a few things to do on Lantau apart from going to/leaving from the airport. Discovery Bay has nice open air eating establishments with a mainly European flavour. No cars allowed, only local buses and golf carts. Take the ferry from HK island to Discovery Bay then take a bus to a point where you can pick up the MTR, Try a hike, visit the monastery and see the Big Buddha.

Great day including Tai O, Big Buddha, Ngong Ping 360 and Ngong Ping Village. A really full day, so start as early as you can manage -although bear in mind that the Ngong Ping 360 doesn't start running till 9 am on week-ends and 10 am on week days. In order to miss the queues to the gondola we decided to start the day at Tai O fishing village. We travelled by train to Tung Chung from Wan Chai (that's about 50 minutes) and stopped at the discount outlet mall for coffee and a cake at Starbucks, as well as stocking up on some Subway for our two young teens who had decided that they didn't really fancy eating exotic authentic Chinese fare at Tai O for lunch and preferred a western style picnic! The number 11 bus to Tai O runs every 15 minutes - it's busy with very orderly queues which see most buses leaving full. The trip to Tai O involves quite a lot of stops for locals and walkers -takes about 50 minutes - lots of steep inclines and twists and turns. On arrival at Tai O you will be greeted by the local sight-seeing boat offering tickets at HKD25 per person. If you pass them by and walk down the little street and to the left over the bridge you'll get the same tour for HKD20 (position counts it seems!) The boat tour involves about ten minutes seeing the stilted houses and businesses, then heading out to sea (not far) for about another ten minutes to (hopefully) spot the pink dolphins - which seems to be a matter of luck. We saw a few leaping in the distance but couldn't get any decent photos, but a friend who was there recently said there was a whole school of them swimming around their boat!The Heritage Hotel on the peninsula to the west of the village dates back to its origins in 1902 as a British police station - we cruised past on the boat but didn't have time to visit. You can get a boat ride from the bus to the hotel for HKD10 or take a leisurely stroll around the shore. It looks like a great spot for afternoon tea or a cool drink on the veranda.The Tai O Village itself is fascinating - a real working fishing village with the most amazing array of dried fish and crustaceans, as well as various shrimp pastes and other exotic ingredients. The displays at each little shop are quite lovely, but the smells are interesting to the western nose! There are numerous little restaurants selling everything from very good looking scallops and grilled prawns and fish to other more suspicious looking local delicacies. We bought several cans of icy cold beer and soft drinks from one of the restaurants and had a great picnic lunch in a square outside a temple, before heading off for the rest of the sights.The number 21 bus takes about 20 minutes to climb up to Ngong Ping Village which is pleasant, but very touristy. There are some nice shops, as well as the to-be-expected concessions, but the souvenirs are at the upper end of the scale. There are others along the walk from the Village to the giant buddha. We wandered along the avenue bordered by the twelve warriors and hence up the many steps (well over 250 I think) to the Big Buddha. Unfortunately the day was hazy but the views were nevertheless spectacular. Well worth the climb up and back.We ran out of time so didn't go to the Po Lin Monastery. The queues to get back down on the Ngong Ping 360 took about20 minutes to wind through the turn styles (this was about 4 pm). You will be much quicker if you pay about 50% more to use the "crystal gondola" which has a glass floor. We went on the standard one, and believe me the views are amazing over the very heavily vegetated hills, and then down onto the Hong Kong International Airport. When you go over the switching stations some of the drops are spectacular so a good head for heights is important.

Best part of Hong Kong. this was my favorite sight while I was in Hong Kong. seeing the giant Buddha and the monastery was amazing. riding the cable car and seeing the natural scenery from way up high was incomparable. I would definitely do a tour to get there. Then staying to shop at the only outlet mall in Hong Kong.

Wonderful views. A very enjoyable morning with a wonderful 20 minute ride on the cable car. This was the highlight of the trip. Make sure you face forward when returning from the village as you get the whole picture. The walk up to the budda gives you a cardiac workout at he same time.

Lantau is a nice respite from the main islands. We stayed in Lantau island for a few days and will definitely be back. Lantau is where the airport is situated but much of the island is still forested. We took a bus up to Po Lin Monastery and it went through many hills and valleys and along the coast to get there. We saw some pretty spectacular scenery including some very tall waterfalls.The island is well connected with the rest of Hong Kong through the MTR Tung Chung Station. At that station, there is a very large up-scale outlet mall with restaurants, a large grocery and a wine bar. We are going to explore the fishing villages next time.

Lantau Island tour. We were collected promptly from our hotel in Kowloon at 08:15 and then driven to Hong Kong Island to meet our rep (Quinde) and catch the ferry to Lantau. The ferry ride took about 30 minutes where we were met by bus and driven to Cheung Sha Beach where we stopped for a comfort break and to take photos. It was okay but nothing much to see and 10 minutes was certainly enough time to spend there. We then carried on to Tai O fishing village where we walked through the Market selling dry fish (be warned not the most pleasant of smells but bearable) and then had a 20 minute boat trip around the harbour observing the old fisherman’s huts on stilts.Then it was on to the main event and we were driven up to the Big Buddha. The drive was very scenic and it is certainly a lovely island with lots of greenery. There were only 7 of us on the tour which made it a nice group and we all got on very well. Our guide Quinde was informative, however her manner left a lot to be desired – eg. She had no interest in any of us and talked down to us and was very abrupt if we had any questions. She also spent a lot of time telling us about her apartment and how much it was now worth and rest of time was glued to her mobile phone even to the point of ignoring a question from one of the group altogether! We drove right up to the back of the Big Buddha and went and viewed the exhibition hall which was very interesting and then made our way down the steps at the front before going to the Po Lin Monastery for a vegetarian lunch which even though I am not a huge fan of vegetables was very nice. Even though the area was very busy with tourists it never felt crowded and there was plenty of time to walk around.We then got back on the bus for a short trip to the Ngong Ping 360 sky cable car where we had 30 minutes to look round the small shopping mall before going on the cable car. This was a good place to buy souvenirs as a good variety of shops and of a good quality too. Particularly liked the shop that only sold chop sticks. There was also a nice square to sit and a good selection of cafes and ice cream sellers.We were given the option to pay extra for a cable car with a glass bottom but as none of our group were interested in this we just had an ordinary car which you could still get great views from all the way round. Did not really see the point of a glass bottom as you wouldn’t see much else but grass! The cars all seat 8 so we could all travel together and it takes about 25 minutes to descend the mountain. A couple of us were a bit apprehensive as not too keen on heights but it was a very pleasant journey and the views were great. You certainly got an idea of the size of the airport and how busy it was with planes landing and taking off every few seconds and could see all the work that was been done to reclaim more land from the sea. At the bottom we were assaulted with the dreaded obligatory photo that was taken as we boarded and politely declined and we were then transported by coach direct back to our hotels.All in all it was a very good day, Lantau Island is well worth a visit and nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city for a few hours. Apart from our guide we all had a great time.

Secluded, remote and beautiful. To walk along the waterway of this isolated part of HK is a treat.I had never been until I picked a hotel that was here.I got to watch a nice sunset and the sunrise over the water. You can get this in many part of HK but because this is not jammed with people and cars it feels so much more relaxed that on the island.
Good day trip. Going to Lantau Island is a worthwhile trip. Riding the cable car gives you a fanatic view from above. The big Buddha is impressive.

So much to offer. We enjoyed a wonderful day on Lantau Island. Took the MTR From Kowloon station, about 35 minutes to Tung Chung. A center for many places to see, the Big Buddha, Tai O, and Mui Wo. Definitely a must on your what to see while in Hong Kong.

Great place to visit and escape from hk . It is a lovely place to go and just escape for the day. We took the Cable car over to the Buddha which have us done great views. The Buddha village is very commercial now with shops and restaurants but we still enjoyed our time wondering about.

Great place to hike and eat. I could not think of a better way to enjoy a nice hike through the hill side then mosey into a local restaurant to enjoy a fantastic, authentic, Chinese meal overlooking the ocean.
seafood galore. tons of fresh seafood restaurants, good quality food and good service. took the boat over for a few hours and pretty much walked the entire area.

largest and best for longest trip to islands. there are many attractions on this island; ngong ping (tourist village in the mountains) cable car up the mountain, big buddah, temples, Tai O Fishing Village, Mui Wo,...a real variety of activties. Transportation includes buses to and from each destination which interconnect, the inter-island ferry and the metro which stops at the bottom of the cable car or bus stop to reach your final destination. The buddah is the biggest sitting buddah in the world apparently and despite the 200ish steps to climb, the mountain views are incredible and it'll be a memory of a lifteime.

Beautiful island, even in the fog. Visited this island when there was a thick fog, came via Ngong Ping cable car. But the scenery here was so beautiful and great. The greatest thing of this island is of course the Big Buddha statue, which is iconic and is a great site of taking photograph. Getting up the stairs would be a challenging thing to do, but when you're up there, the scenery is more beautiful than what you have watched from below. Don't forget to buy some souvenirs, because there are a lot of kiosks and stores in the area.

Scenic, beautiful, worth of money and time!. I and my friend went there for the second time because during the first time it was temporarily closed due to the heavy rain. The view from the cable car or gondola is very nice! U can see modern buildings as well as the majestic Great Buddha statue and the greenery view of nature.
Big Buddla. Easy to get to by MTR and cable car. Take a local bus afterwards down to Tai O - a little fishing village.

Great day out. Loved the Big Buddha and Monastery here on Lantau Island. Caught the gondola up to the top, cool views out over the airport and its man-made island. Must do - head in to the monastery and pray with the incense sticks, experience the culture of Hong Kong.

Nice and Scenic!. Nice and Scenic - and such a nice break from the hustle and bustle from the main city. The trip start with a cable car ride to the island. Its hilly so it goes up - view isn't quite really one that the faint hearted will enjoy. Upon arrival, the walk to the main temple area is dotted with tourist shops - nice to walk around to enjoy the culture and history of the place. Take your time and relax, we visited in Jan when the weather was still cool - a light jumper will suffice. Its get slightly chillier at the told of the temple, so those that are not well adverse to the cold, a wind breaker is better suited for the climb. The hike up the hundreds of steps was tempted with a nice vegetable lunch...so up we went....all hundreds of steps. We walked around a little (there were memorials for some famous people that I didn't recognise - local talents) the view atop the peak was simple wondering and fresh (compared to the crowded streets of HK).Worth the trip up!!! Peaceful and quite - quite nice indeed!

Away from the busy city. I am glad to visit Lantau Island with my friend. I enjoyed the quiet and peaceful time, away from the busy city for a while. It was really worth it.If you come to HK, you have to go to Lantau Island. The cable car was really exciting. We chose the glass bottom cable car once we reached there, we walked over to the Giant Buddha. You have to climb 280 over steps up and once you reached to the top, you will be rewarded with a view. We donate a little and we get to enjoy some vegetarian meal with desserts. It's very nice meal.We then walk over to the bus terminus and wait for bus no 21 to Tai-O. A fishing village selling lots of dried seafood. We had some snacks there but was unfortunate that time was not on our side. So we did not managed to take a boat to see the dolphin. We took the last bus, bus no. 11 all the way back to Tung Chung. This trip will take up the whole day, so go earlier to avoid the crowd.

Took the Full Day Bus Tour. This tour was excellent with two great guides (bus changed at Lantau). The Big Buda and cable ride were great however my favourite was the Po lin Monastery and the Vegetarian lunch, it was very tasty. The little Tai O Stilt Village was amazing with a small Taoist church worth a visit, also cheap shopping in the village market for things not seen anywhere else. Also had a stop at Tsing Ma bridge visitor centre which also was interesting and a beach stop. The commentary throughout was excellent and informative. The Bus arrived back at the Hotel at 4:45 and we were last stop on HK island. The bus takes you right to the Buda level, you can also walk the 300 odd steps from the monastery if you feel up to it.

Close to nature, it will never fail you. I just love strolling around this place! It's a perfect getaway for me to relax and enjoy. The best scenic and relaxing way to get to Lantau Island from Hong Kong Central is to take a ferry. Ferry rides from the main harbor in Hong Kong Central takes about 30 - 50 minutes, then you will need to hop on one of the buses to get around the island.

Good day out of the city but maybe not at weekend.. We travelled from Central to the cable car on the MTR. This combined with the 45 min queue for the cable car made it quite a slow morning and it was a weekday so you may want to think twice about going at the weekend. The cable car was good to see all the small islands and the new airport with all the planes taking off. The 'village' at the other end of the cable car is poor and just full of tacky souvenir shops and we bypasses them as quick as possible.We had lunch at the monastery where you get a good value vegetarian set lunch. It's very simple but has its own rustic charm. We visited the Big Buddha which was exactly what it says on the tin!We then took the bus to Tai O traditional village which took about 15/20 min. We really liked this place as the village is in an island and there's lots of stalls selling dried fish which is quite interesting and not too smelly! We took the boat trip around the island and took some good photos of the traditional houses on stilts. The boat trip was a good length circling the island and pointing out all the main features and good value.

Watch the Weather. I used the MRT trains and made my way to this adventure. Please understand I have a bit of a fear of heights but decided I would take the cable type gondola up and down. I went late in the day and into the car I went by myself. The ride last about 25 minutes and the wind that shakes the car was very strong so I felt i might go down at any time. Once up, the area was very touristy and it took little time to try and go down. The line to go down must have had a good 500 people in front by this time and was moving very slow. Also, those who had paid the higher dollar scenic fare were able to proceed ahead of all of us commoners. After about 1 1/2 hours I was nearing the front and they had to shut the cable cars down due to lightning. Buses were slowing coming up and getting people off the mountain. It took another 1 1/2 hours before loading on a bus and making it down a dangerous mountain road. When I left there must have been another 800-1000 people behind me. All in all, not a real good time!

Major attraction with not much to do. I joined a tour out to Lantau Island and looking back, I was really glad I did. The highlight with out a doubt was the cable car ride up and back to the big Buddha. Once you are at the Buddha, besides taking a couple of photos and having a general wonder around, there isn't much to do.However, the visit at the end to the fishing village was fascinating and this is what I would like to have seen more of. From the cable car, you can see that there are some hiking/walking trails (over some pretty steep hills admittedly) which I think I will try and get a guide to on a next visit.Was it worth it - maybe. I could definitely have done without the visit to the Disneyland Hong Kong hotel!

Get away from the hustle and bustle.. I took a group tour to Lantau Island that included a visit to Tai O fishing village, Pp Lin Monastery (thatincluded a delightful vegetarian meal) and a ride on the cable car, I highly recommend this way of exploring the island by leaving the transportation to someone else, I found the guide to be very knowledgeable as she grew up on Lantau Island. Amazingly, Tai O maintains much of its original character despite the enormous of tourists who visit. Most of the residents appear to be over sixty and I saw very few children in the community. It made me wonder how long this community would continue to exist.

A diverse experience. There is the airport on a reclaimed "accessory" island, there is the biggest brass Buddha, there is Disney land, there is fishing village, there is white sand beach, there is a huge outlet, there is hike, there is trek, there is mountain bike trail. You just can't ever get enough on this island.

forget the uphill sky thing.. after queing for 40 mins we remembered an entry in a handbook, bailed and caught the ?#23 bus up and was so much faster and cheaper. caught the sky rail down - no waiting at all.

Serene, natural and convenient. Blessed with the Lantau Peak, endless coastline, gorgeous sunset spots, cultural heritage and modern convenience, this biggest island of Hong Kong is a treasured breathing space of the city. As your plane lands on the ground of Hong Kong, it is the land of Lantau Island. Go to downtown like Mongkok, Causeway Bay or Tsim Sha Tsui and feel the vibrancy of the Asia's city, but don't forget to save some time to explore this gem. Though no longer a hidden treasure, it combines the beauty of nature and contemporary necessities. You will find a wide selection of food and beverage outlets to choose from, and the MTR is right next to the shopping mall. To get closer to nature, simply take a bus a few step away from the MTR station. It's worth the trip and time for sure. Please, however, help protect nature and the environment - don't leave your garbage behind, and refrain from smoking. Many thanks and welcome to Lantau!
Beautiful. We took the trip up here, and I loved the gondola ride. I wish I'd known there is some lower cost shopping near the Big Buddha, so I'm telling you now! :) Enjoy!
Relaxing area. Nice ferry ride to Lantau and lovely restaurants in the PlazaAlso go on the ferry to Mui Wo and use the Turkish restaurant near Macdonalds

A Taste of the Traditional Hong Kong. I took a guided tour of Lantau Island. It was very information with the history and culture of the island and of area. We had a stop at a beach, fishing village with housing on stilts and a dried fish market, Buddha Park and the Monastery. We learned the island is comprised of granite stone and the only native plant is the grass. Everything else was seeded via airplanes and transported in and planted. Many of the plants are native to Queensland, Australia since they have similar climates. It was a nice way to spend the day away from the fast pace of Hong Kong Island or Kowloon.

It's a full day trip. Be prepared to exercise patience when queuing for the cable car, however, once on, it is worth it for the absolutely stunning views. If your budget allows, try to purchase a day pass which will get you on the cable car (we were in a 'crystal cabin' - with glass bottomed floor), a bus to the Tai O fishing village, a boat trip to see if you can spot the white and/or pink dolphins, and a bus back down to Tung Chung (where we started the day). The giant Buddha is the main tourist attraction and looks quite majestic set up high in the hills.

Nice place to visit. There are a few tourism sites located in Lantau Island, from Disneyland, Ngong Ping, Wisdom Path,Tai O fishing Village and more. If you want to experience a great view from above you can ride a cable car for about half hour, beside cable car there is also bus to reach Ngong Ping. Well, I experienced cable car during transition from Winter to Spring, it was windy and foggy :((. Better going to Ngong Ping while Sunny guys !

Nice taste of the country so close to the city. Loved the tram and the buddha and the fishing village but it was a little hard to move around the island sometimes. The public transit seemed to take longer than it was supposed to

Buddha Experience. Easy access to the island via the Subway and only about 25 minutes. If you go alone beware the queue for the chair lift ride. About 30 minutes ride but goes quickly as you view the sites and watch the planes come and go at the airport. Lots of shopping at the hill top village with a good climb up stairs to the Buddha which is quite grand and very BIG. Some great workmanship at the temples and shrines and well worth a visit which will probably take up a good part of the day.

The hong Kong many miss. This is a hilly green oasis on the outskirts of an over crowded city. The waterfalls, beaches and mountains are lovely. It was too hot to do much walking but the hikes would be great in a cooler time. Take the local buses and do go to Tai O fishing village. Very interesting with its stilt houses and fish market. A short boat trip out into the harbour allowed us to see the pink dolphins who luckily were there that day.

An awesome experience. We took cable car from Tung Chung MTR station and I must say the cable car ride itself was an amazing experience. It goes through a valley with some amazing views. The Big Buddha statue is really magnificent and it required climbing 200+ steps to reach near the statue. We took a snacks coupon which allowed us to visit the attached museum. I think only those holding snacks or meal coupons are allowed in the museum. The snacks itself was good though. Overall an awesome experience.

Lovely Day trip. Nice day trip or 1/2 day trip just depends on how much time you want to spend on the island. We did the cable car to see the Big Buddha and spent a few hours there, then took the bus to Tai O the fishing village. It was great to get out of the city and see a different side of Hong Kong at our own pace.
Excellent. It's worth spending 4 hours at Lantau IslandEnjoyed every momentTook crystal cabin on returnWill recommend to all age people

PERFECT DAY TRIP. Our itinerary was two days at Hong Kong Disney then one week in the city (Mong Kok). Lantau is closer to the airport and Disney, so we decided to visit Lantau after our first two days at Disney.It was only 2-3 stops on the MTR (subway) from Disney. It would probably be 30-45 minutes from the city. Tung Chung is the MTR stop for Lantau. From there you jump on the Ngong Ping 360 (cable car/gondola) for a scenic ride up the mountain to Lantau. The ride is 25 minutes.After arriving in Lantau, you will walk uphill through an area of shops and restaurants for about 10 minutes before reaching the base of the big buddha. From there it's 268 steps to the top. Recommend going early to beat the crowd. I would walk straight through the area of shops and restaurants and visit the big buddha first … then have lunch and shop after descending from the big buddha.

A great escape from the city.. Take a ferry from central to Mui Lo and you wouldn't know you are in Hong Kong. You step off the ferry into a different world. The pace is slower and you are in a tropical paradise.(well almost)Lovely place .Well worth a visit.
Great escape. This is a lovely place to escape to from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. A definite must on a trip to Hong Kong.

Good hiking trails. If you don't mind hiking in hot and humid weather, Lantau has some good hiking trails...along the way, we found green bean ice cream and heard Buddhists nuns chanting. Washrooms are not easy to find. Bring bottled water and a camera!

An extraordinary day. Out of the time and out of the world...
A wonderful experience...
The approach there with the "crystal cabin" is an experience... You are leaning over a wonderfull view of Honk Kong airport at the beginning, the bay, and finally you approach step by step the "Big Buddha", such an experience.
To see before you die :-)

loved the cable cars!. Brilliant! really loved the cable cars the view is fab! the village/ landing area is modern and not a real traditional village, do see this take the bus ride out to the fishing village Tai O, very smelly (fishy!!) but good to see the local people at home and work

Say What. Lantau Island a 30 minute ferry ride quaint beach smacks of yesterday Hong Kong but in reality there's nothing there of interest unless you just want to get out of Hong Kong for a few hours. The only landmark appears to be McDonalds at the wharf
that's when you know you're in trouble as a tourist destination.

Interesting adventure. A bit away from the center, so quieter. The cable car trip offers nice views, the Buddha statue and nearby temple are worth seeing. Buy the deluxe lunch tickets when you get the temple tickets and you will have a nicer room and better service for lunch. We also went to the fishing village,Tai O, which was very interesting -- a different world. Take the bus from the Buddha temple area to get to the village, then a bus to the ferry to go back to HK.

Nice trip out of the city. Visited last May. We had a hectic schedule in HK so booked this to take it easy. It was a lovely day out - we had a good look around at our own pace. Went on the Crystal cable car -looked around the tourist village and went up to the Giant Buddha! Lovely scenery and views. Less crowded than in the city. Lots of places to eat. Made a really nice change from racing around.

Lantau Island. About 30 minutes drive from Hong Kong Island, we enjoyed the Bid Buda on top of the hill and lunch at the monastery. great ride on the 5.8 miles teleferic joining Lantau with Hong Kong island

Perfect get away week end place. Lantau Island is so refreshing. It is a great way to escape the hectic life of Hong Kong.it is the perfect get away week end.Fresh air, good sea food.Hop on a ferry and leave HK behind you.

Worth a visit. Lantau Island was a nice change to the hustle and bustle of the city. We took a day trip over and this took in the Big Buddha, lunch at the monastry, a fishing village and the huge cable car back down the mountain.
Nice change from the noise and pollution of Hong Kong and Kowloon.

Nature. The cable car was a great ride, with fantastic view over the the bay and airport. On top of the hill theres the large buddha statue with a few temples. really worth the trip. Train ride from city center approx 45 mins.
Great walk. Got the ferry down to Lantau and had a lovely walk up to waterfalls - glorious day topped off with fish and chips on the bay

Silvermine beach resort. Worst hotel I have ever stayed, reception staff were horrible and not helpful. Room was dirty, spa was a joke. Restaurant staff were a little helpful but under staffed so if busy could be sitting 45 minutes waiting to be served.

If you're passing through Hong Kong and don't want to go into the city!. There is definitely what to do on the island of Lantau when in transit in Hong Kong. 1) The City Gate shopping mall for those who like modern shopping 2) The Tung Chung market which is a local market - definitely interesting to explore 3) The Buddha which you can reach via cable car from Tung Chung 4) Tai O fishing village about 1 hour from airport (bus 11 from Tung Chung terminal)

Cable car ride was amazing and good view.. I loved the cable car ride (Ngong Ping 360) and the fantastic view from above. The island was just a normal island with the statues of the Buddhas and overall it's okay. Actually visited there in March 2011.
Lantau Island is worth it.. My first time on a cable car was a worthy experience and the views were beautiful. Big Buddha was also nice. Lantau Island was beautiful.

If you have done all other activities in Hong Kong, then you can go to Lantau. Of course the beaches, The Buddha Statue and the different lifestyles of locals are quite attractive to visitors and tourists, but to me it is not the first option. I would recommend even see first Lamma Island than the Lantau. If you are only prone to hiking and nature, then probably is is the best place in Hong Kong, but not if you know nothing about Hong Kong and you stay only 3 days.

Nice ferry ride across, but nothing fantastic. Lantau Island is an experience if you are a tourist. The Big Buddha is on Lantau and it's worth a visit. Remember, there's not much else going on by way of hotspot attractions, but the ferry ride is worth it.

A Place to Visit when in Hong Kong. I like Lantau for it is peaceful. It's the other face of Hong Kong. It has preserved its natural beauty. What I dislike is the way going to the Wisdom Path. It was kind of creepy for you are walking in the forest. It was very quiet. Make sure you are in a group before you are going to decide to go there.

Transit experience. We had an 8 hour layover between flights on the way home from Europe and decided to get out and head to Lantau Island via the Cable Cars as we did not get around to doing this when last in HK. After exiting immigration we headed downstairs to the bus area and for HKD3.50 caught the S1 bus out to the terminal where the cable car departs from. A very short bus ride and we were half an hour early which was excellent to start the queuing for the ride over. Opening at 9am it cost HKD150 per person to get over to the island. Once there we found everything still just opening really. Which we did not mind. The place is very touristy but surprisingly loved looking at the shops there, one that caught my eye was the Chopstick shop...could have easily bought a heap of these had I room in hand luggage. Saw the Big Buddha, very impressive and a reasonable climb. The temple had a lot of restoration going on so not much happening there although able to pray and light incense in the grounds. There is a vegetarian restaurant there if hungry. Basically once seen we hoped back on the cable car for the 25 minute stunning ride back to the mainland. So glad we took a stretch out of the airport after a long flight.

Great day trip to enjoy!. It is wonderful that there is such peaceful place in fast moving Hong Kong. Although crowded with tourists but I managed to enjoy it a lot! Be prepared for the long line to get the gondola so taking a bus might be an option. Nice that they had wifi while waiting in the areas to get to the gondola so could keep myself busy. Indeed, note that they start operating since 10am and on weekends on 9am but better always check the website for the most update schedule.When arrived at Po Lin monastery you may want buy incense sticks to burn but note that they are a little bit cheaper on the way rather than inside the monastery. Give so yourself time to enjoy once you get there - I was a bit on a tight schedule to catch my flight but otherwise possible easy to spend 4-6 hours there with walking around, checking souvenir shops, eating.

Is more than the big Buddha. This is our third visit to Lantau Island. We are lucky enough to have family who live here in Discovery Bay, a beautiful mini city without cars. The Big Buddha is certainly worth a visit, for us preferably by cable car from Tung Chung.(right opposite the bus/train stations) it is a long ride, some 5.7 kms, and it does sway a bit if windy. The Buddha himself I think very impressive, he is 110 feet tall and weighs 250 tonnes. There are a lot of gift shops and restaurants up there, all worth a look.If you are into shopping, the mall in Tung Chung has lots of designer shops, as well as a lot of other outlets including coffee bars etc and across the walkway is a Chinese market.

Challenging to climb up to the big Buddha but for the view, it's worth it!. Do purchase your cable car tickets online in advance for priority queue. Its China summer holiday now and HK island is flooded by PRCs! The PRCs crowd were simply crazy...buying online NP360 ticket will help you cut waiting time from the long domino line.Weather was super humid and hot under the blistering sun, I was practically drenched by my own sweat when I eventually reach the top. However, the view of the pristine shoreline on a summer’s day from the top was SPECTACULARA, !!! It will be a better time to visit when the weather is cooler.

Timing is key!. Unfortunately the cable car doesn't really open early enough to give people time to beat the heat nor the crowds, we ended up waiting 2 hours to get to the village (book online to save the hassle!), our mistake! Once there, the scenery is very tranquil and the island is impressive. Unfortunately the Po Lin Monestary was undergoing construction so we did not get to see it. We did however try the food at the vegetarian cafeteria which was pretty delightful and inexpensive!
YEs, so much to see and do,. the Big Buddha, the cable car ride, the views and the greenery, many walking trails so take the MTR and go visit for a day or two.
Spacious surrounding. Great scenery once hiked up the big Buddha. Weather was too humid and couldnt stay too long under the sun.

Simply Beautiful. Was in Hong Kong for a small period but got the chance to visit Lantau Island. Would recommend taking the cable car up to the Big Buddha as the view is just breath taking. Its a beautiful place to see. The climb to Big Buddha has a fair amount of steps but it totally worth it as the view at the top can't even be described in words. I saw there was a walking trail to also gt to lantau island. haven't tried it but would like to next time. Would recommend it for those who like hiking as such.
Take the Cable Car for sure. Best way to get to the Big Buddha is to take the cable car versus the bus. The view is so scenic. Get there as early as possible as lines are very, very long.

Very full and fun day!. We visited Lantau Island on our own, did not do a tour, and found it was not necessary. We were told by our hotel to arrive by 0900 for the cable car, and then found it did not open until 1000. Right next to the cable car is a large outlet mall, with great stores and good sales, so we saved it for the end of the trip. The lines started at the cable car by 0915, and it took awhile to buy the tickets. We bought the combination of all of them, and it probably was a bit more expensive than doing it per piece, but this was more convenient. The cable car was a nice ride up to the village by the Buddha. It is all nicely laid out, rather touristy, but very clean and well organized. The Buddha is visible on the way up, and well worth the 200 steps up to see up close. The movie prior to the Buddha was a bit disappointing, as we expected to hear the history and learn about the statue itself, and instead it was an animated film about the history of the worship of it, but was still worthwhile. After the Buddha and having a nice lunch (brought our own, but there is a nice veggie restaurant on site), we took a bus to Tao O fishing village. This was great, it gave an idea of how the villagers manage, and we took a boat and saw their homes, and were able to see some of the pink dolphins jumping in the water. From here you can take a ferry back to transportation to Hong Kong, but we went back on the bus to the Buddha, took another ride back on the cable car, and then shopped at the outlets. Then, took the MTR back to Hong Kong, which was about 45 minutes. It was a full and very fun day (about 12 hours total) and we did it on our own time schedule, which we preferred over an organized tour. Highly recommend visiting Lantau!

A number of experiences in one place. The cable car ride gave us some lovely views, the village near the Big Buddah was quite new and commercialized however interesting It was difficult to actually see the Buddah even after climbing the steps due to smog and low cloud. The monastery was undergoing renovations and what we did see was well signed and very ornate. There is a path for people with disabilities who cant manage the stairs but this wasn't signed. The bus to the traditional stick village stopped just out front and this was an interesting place. Overall worth the visit as it was easy to access a number of interesting sites in the one place.

Lovely island. Lantau Island if probably one of the best Islands around Hong Kong, if you're a keen hiker there are moutons you can trek for hours near Tin Tian Buddha. The old villages such as Tai O at the bottom of the island is one of the original traditional villages left in Hong Kong. There's plenty to do around this island.

beautiful,and see the Big Buddha. the Island is incredible, and fun to visit, and of course the Big Buddha is the high point (pardon the pun). The views are spectacular, and you can see the harbor, and city from the top of the island.

Nice place and wonderful view . On 4th june I visited lantau iland. One of the silent and awsm place . Theres a big buddha statue. And the view is so nice from diffrent angles. From each side the view is diffrent like mountains, sea etc. One of the best place for photo shoot lovers. And the cable car is also 5th longest in the world. Where by different ilands airport and city can be seen. One of the best place.

Ok visit not as awesome as I expected. Enjoyed the cable car ride up there but was a bit disappointed when we got there, expected more. The big Buddha was fine but wasn't as fantastic as I thought. This was offset by the fact there's heaps of restaurants to choose from
Worth trip. Lantau Island hold several best Hong Kong attraction. My favourite are Ngong Ping Village. You can find the famous Big Buddha here. The cable car ride is a amazing experience itself.

A great escape from the city. Lantau Island, especially the south part, is very different from other places of Hong Kong. The island is green, peaceful and not crowded at all. There are some nice beaches. We also spent half day in Tai O fishermen village, for dolphin watching. Highly recommended for anyone that is tired of city life and wants to explore nature.

Beautiful and quiet area, definitely worth a visit. Our trip to Lantau Island included Tian Tan Buddha, the Wisdom Path, the tea plantation, Po Lin Monastery and Tai O village. I recommend that you reserve an entire day for this.We went to Tung Chung by subway and when we arrived at Ngong Ping Cable Car we took the Crystal cabin to go to Lantau. We had bought our tickets online in advance, although there was almost no line at 9.00 a.m.The island is incredibly quiet as compared to the hustle and bustle of Tsim Sha Tsui, for example.After we went up the stairs to see Tian Tan Buddha and the views, we decided to go to the Wisdom Path and the tea plantation. The walk is quite enjoyable and we also saw butterflies, caterpillars and beautiful flowers. The China Sea sights are amazing. Do take a break and enjoy the fresh air!After we visited Po Lin Monastery, we took bus no. 21 (14 HKD/person, payable by Otopus Card, buses leave very fast) to Tai O village and bus 11 (19.2 HKD/person, payable by Otopus Card, buses leave very quickly) back to Tung Chung subway station.Tip: If you want to buy Hong Kong souvenirs, there are a few stalls which sell nice magnets (20 HKD/piece) and postcards near Tian Tan Buddha.
Good cable car ride. Definitely take the cable car ride to the island. The views along the way are very scenic. The island has a large Buddha and is a great backdrop for photographs.

Worth the trip. Nice view from the cable car.....one must take the crystal cable car one way as it is a nice experience especially for the kids.......very clean place and lovely weather since it is on height

Outlying Islands Surely Worthwhile. There have already been hundreds of reviews of this island here on Trip Advisor, so I really won't be able to offer that much insight into Lantau that will differ from erstwhile postings. For certain, Lantau is worth visiting, for its hilltop-straddling Big Buddha, quaint (yet a little rough around the edges) seaside villages, and surprisingly-mountainous interior scenery are all splendid ways to pass time on a day trip from HK. However, with that said, be prepared for quite a bit of tourist traffic. On my trip there in February, a low season experience--yet on the cusp of CNY (Chinese New Year), I was startled by how many 'mainland' tourists were there, and at one point, my jaw dropped at how long the line was at one seaside village's bus stop. With more and more Chinese tourists traveling nowadays, this will, guaranteed, be the scene globally. Thus, the only suggestion I could make here is to get away from that all! Although I didn't do it myself, and though I haven't done any research into it, I'd recommend renting bicycles or scooters/motorbikes to get into the more rural areas of the island instead of tagging along on a tour group or taking one of the tourists buses from the peer (I'd taken the fast ferry from the Outlying Islands Peer in Central). I'd taken one of the latter, and I must say that the views along the mountainous roads were outstanding, but being trapped on a bus and not being able to explore more was troubling. So if you go, do some research on renting bikes or scooters so you can see more than the average tourist. If I go back, I'll surely take that option to get off the trampled path where everyone else seems to tread. You should do the same!
Long ride. Love the ride on cable car to get to the island,and once i get there i see a lot of store,and traditional culture of gate..don't forget to get to the Big Budha statue.
Cable Cars..... The cable cars were exciting and scary at the same time. We knew it would be high, but wow that was high. (The water part was fun lol) Not to be missed!

Best Trip. We visited this place because we wanted to relax from busy Hongkong shopping.It is cheaper to go there from tsim tsa tsung by boat/pantun (s/p) or ship . We managed to see bhudda ,and ride cable cars and so on . Its worth going there though the queue was very long as it was unplanned trip..
Worth a visit. Take a trip to Lantau Island, go on the glass bottom cable car but book prior to your visit if you want to avoid the very long lines. Well worth a visit....take the time to go.

Amazing. My friend and I recently did a half day tour with Splendid Tours to Lantau Island to see the Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery and Tai O fishing village. This was our favourite day trip. The local tour guide was fantastic, he was very knowledgable and engaging. The afternoon began with a bus ride to Lantau from Kowloon, to the Ngong ping cable car. This had spectacular views, it takes about 25mins using the cable car to reach the big Buddha. We then also could look at the monastery. Our group then continued to tai o fishing village about 15mins by bus. Our guide once again continued with interesting commentary of the village, before taking us on another drive to the first ferry, which we caught back to Hong Kong island. The only suggestion I would make, is it would have been nice to have more time at the Buddha/monastery, rather than more time in the village. But I suppose if you did a longer day tour or went on your own that would be possible. Also, our guide was telling us about pink dolphins off tai o village, but we weren't given the opportunity to take time to view them. This might be a nice thing to add into the tour or try and find a tour that does (keeping in mind we only had a half day tour).Lantau Island itself, is very different to Hong Kong/Kowloon. Extremely scenic, much less populated. It makes a lovely change from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Best day trip in HK. I did this day trip recently on a Saturday morning. My best decision was to go ahead and start early. I was on my way at 9am and the cable car line was about 10 min. The views from the cable car are great. I took the crystal floor and in the end I'm not sure it was worth it except for the fact that the lines for the crystal bottom are always shorter (fewer people pay for it). I also took the whole package with the Walk with Buddha, the boat trip to the fishing village, etc. it was all worth it. The boat trip was nice, the hike upstairs to the the Buddha was great (not that difficult at all), and the walk with the Buddha show was ok. I'd recommend to start early to avoid the lines and the rain. But if you have a day in HK (started at 8:30 and finished about 3pm), go ahead and do this. The views from up top are great and the fishing village and boat ride are great as well.

One of my favorite places to visit. Fastest way to arrive is by mtr, but fast boat from the harbor is definitely the most scenic (from port #3 every half hour). Even if you arrive late, the cable car is well worth the ride for a beautiful view that brings you up to where you can see the big buddha.
Beautiful Mountains and seaviews. i liked the view of the Lantau island mountains and bay while i was seating in the train , it is splendid and unique .

Day Escape. Lantau Island is easil reach from airport by using bus S1 and continue to use the cable car from ngongping. It was a good place to escape from the busy street of hongkong enjoying some fresh air and beautiful architectures. Recommended if u visitingg hongkong
A slice of paradise. Lantau, with the beautiful mountains, forests, exotic plants, the giant Buddha, the monastery, is a truly idyllic place. I strongly recommend!
Worth a visit. Catch the bus over - lots to see including several beaches and of course Stanley and Aberdeen. Markets are great and worth a visit too.

Amazing. They say its not the destination but the journey which matters... And hold so true for Lantau island.Take the crystal cable car and there is a world beneath you, world so beautiful. the journey had everything - water beneath, huge trees could be seen from the crystal car, road. What a ride. a ride of a lifetime.The place was also very nice. Lantau was an experience in itself. Budha all around.Again a must see!
Awesome Experience. It was a awesome experience. most of the visit places. good food options and nice place to be once. do plan if in hong kong.

Lovely views of the Sea. Went to the Big Buddha Statue on Lantau and on the bus back to the Ferry caught beauriful glimpses of the beach.It was tempting and would have liked to go back.The hour long ferry ride to Central was also cheap and enjoyable.

BEAUTIFUL!. Take the Crystal Cabin on the cable car both ways. The views are amazing. If you have vertigo, close your eyes. You can also hike it but it does take a while. So much to see and do on this island.
Great place to visit. Beautiful place, got to get the glass bottom capsules on the cable car ride, what a ride this is, about 25 minutes,with a great view. Good restaurants in Lantau.
Must Visit When in HK. Visit from central HK on the ferry or the RMT. Go up to the Buddha on the cable car. Lots to see and very interesting.

Must do day trip. A tour/day-trip out to Lantau Island was the highlight of my trip to Hong Kong. It was refreshing to get out of the hustle bustle of the city and see the laid back island, the beaches, the Tai O fishing village, the Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha, and the Ngong Ping 360 Cablecar. Definitely recommend!
Alternate place to stay in Hongkong. Just knowing that this island have a good place to explore such as : Discovery bay, Disneyland, Citygate outlet, Ngong ping cable car.
Surprise Gem. Loved our stay at the Novotel & the food court @ Novotel Citygate. Perfect cable card ride!!!! And the view was just unforgettable.

Island Wonder. Bit of a hike but otherwise so wonderful to visit! The cable car is awesome, although I would love to walk the five hour trail one day! The park and the Tian Tan Buddha are not too be missed. Beautiful mountains surround the peak of monastery. There is a chance to see monks and pilgrims circling the buddha. There are plenty of souvenirs to buy here around the complex. A few restaurants are available in the village as well as a bit of shopping. There is even a corner shop and Subway as well. A great excursion from the urban setting of Hong Kong. Public transport links the MTR with the Ngong Ping 360 cable car. The cable car is not in the station; there is a little walk from Tung Chung Station but it is not far. Just follow the signs.

Its an Island.. Make Lantau Island as your final trip if your flight is late at night. Why? It is closest to the airport. Places to go:Tsing Ma Bridge (at night)Ten Thousnd Buddha+Ngong Ping 360+Big Buddha Disneyland HK

Cable Car amazing. I stayed at the Citygate hotel which is near the start of the Cable car and so on my first day, feeling a bit jet lagged, the cable car ride seemed a good sedate thing to do and indeed it was a good choice. Amazing views and when you get there you have a pleasant tourist village to walk through up to the Bhuddha. The 'Crystal' cars are the one with the glass bottoms, think before committing as you are stuck in it for 25mins!

A MUST VISIT !. Since we were in hongkong for a shorter period of time , this was once place where we could visit . The nnong ping 360 is amazing and is amazing if you take the crystal cable car instead of the regular knes though they are a bit expensive as much as twice the rate(150 HK$) of a regular cable car plus the waiting time of the crystal cable car is pretty much less .The lantau island has a great connectivity of the metro and as soon as you get down at the Tsim sha sui line's last station then its a walkable distance from there . A must visit to the local shops over there for buying local stuff ! You can spend about 4 hours over here , you even have a good chain of restaurants both on the island as well as near the station .

WOW!. Getting here we took the cable car, this freaked me out as I am very scared of heights, but the views are beautiful and when you are approaching Lantau it takes your breath away. It was very busy when we were there but we my partner and I still enjoyed every bit of it! I loved the cows wondering around and all of the lovely and touristy shops! ended up buying lots of things!! The whole place felt very special.. We got there later than we should of and things were closing before we had got a chance to look at them so make sure you leave plenty of time. Getting back I couldn't stand the thought of having to get on the cable car so we took a coach back. Definitely worth a visit.
Very pretty. The cable car trip is a must. We went as part of a half day tour eager to avoid huge waiting time. But in reality the line was not long.
Wow!. Beautiful place with wonderful views. Very good to get some positive energy: the island has the Tian Tan Buddah and centuries old monastery. Breathtaking!

Spectacular views, special place. While I really really don't like heights and getting to the Giant Buddah the first time was via the cable car, the views were great, once my hand unfroze from the seat and I focussed, views while we travelled and when we got to the Giant Buddah were well worth it. The climb to the Buddah is steep, but again DO IT.Food at the temple and the serene environment capped of a great day. 2nd and 3rd trip - by bus .
What a view?. I think lantau island was worth a look. The cable car gives great view of the harbour, airport and the hills. But like all these rides, get there early and beat the queue and the heat!

Nyong Ping cable car ride. The cable car ride on the crystal cabin was exciting, the boat ride to see the Dolphins and the visit to the fishing village could be rated as OK. The ride back to the ferry was a very long one.by bus. Overall not something I would lose sleep over if I were to miss it.

Lantau Island. Cable ride up to the big Buddha is a great way to take in the HK views. Lines were about 30 minutes for the regular cable car and because there were a lot of visitors on the day we visited, they were putting about 8-10 people in each car unless you paid for a different type of car. From the cars you can see the planes taking off & landing @ the airport, see visitors actually walking the path to/from the Buddha and everything in between. There are over 200+ stairs (1 way) to the top of the Buddha so come in comfortable shoes and with plenty of water. If you are staying @ the airport Marriott, the shuttle will take you to the cable ride. The shuttle run every 20-30 mins. There is a huge outlet mall where you can find just about every store you want, eateries and a grocery store on the bottom level. This area has a lot of walking but it's a lot quieter than downtown HK.

wear comfortable shoes!!. its an extremely long walk, so please ensure you are in you most conformatble shoes. Plus go to all the shops, you ll get nice stuff, even at the tung chung outlet mall,you might find good bargains!

Nice excursion to get out from the hustle and bustle. If you have time and are a little bit tired of shoppings, noisy streets, subways and so, take a trip here. You'll be relaxed and your energy charged.

Supermarket in Lantau Island. It's a nowhere island, but if you like to shop for a little grocery, you could go to Ngong Ping area. They have a good supermaret on the the City Gate Outlet. Only 1 stop from Disneyland.

Perfect Scenery and great experience. Lantau Island is a great trip to take to change from the hustle and bustle of the cities in Hong Kong. Easily accessible by Ferry too should you want a change in mode of transport that costs around HKD 16-20 (i think)The pier that you land at is easily accessible to main attractions like the Big Buddha. Buses are lined up outside the pier with clearly written signboards on each bus. The trip up to the Big Buddha was accompanied by spectacular view of the steep hillside/mountains.Definitely worth the time to visit Lantau Island. One of the main highlights of my trip to Hong Kong

Worth a full day. Visiting Lantau island was definitely a highlight of our Hong Kong trip. The big Buddha has trails by the monastery and the Tai O village was extremely fun to explore. We decided not to take the lift and instead took the bus around the Island. Much cheaper and not terrible but a few kids on the bus got sick due to the windy roads. Anyways, just know that's a much cheaper, less touristy option

Nice get away from the city. we went to take the cable car a bit late just after noon. The queue was long, if you want to jump the queue, you could take the 3 in 1 combo ticket. We didn't and was advise it may be a bit late to see everything, the last bus out of the Tai-O village was 4.30pm and last cable car was 6pm. ended up getting only the cable car ride. Enjoyed so much on the cable car for 25min. just chill and relax to see the nice surrounding. While up the hill, we check on the public bus to Tai-O and was lucky they had extra services thus we don't have to wait another 30min. Jumped on it and off to see the fishing village.Once arrived, there are lots of people to ask you to take the boat. Do check if it's low tide now, we got con to take the full boat ride and was told it's low tide and can't go into the pole houses.But we were just as happy, we saw lots of pink Dolphins, magnificent! Back to the hill, we managed to climbed the 200plus steps up to see the big Buddha. Say a little prayer for my family on the way up. Looking at the Big Buddha and surrounding, it's just breath taking. In order to avoid the rush to get to the cable car before 6pm and took another scenic ride back. Advise to go early. We took around 1 hr on cable car. 1 hr plus to Tai-O, spend another 1 hr at the Big Buddha. No time for the rest of the island.But still had a great time there!

Big Buddha, peace. I went to Lantau Island with my family. We took the crystal cable car up to the mountain. You can see the scenery under your feet. It was not scary at all. We shop all the way till we reach the bottom of the big buddha. It took me around 20 mins to climb (and down) the staircase to the big buddha. (I dont have good stamina but was motivated when the elderly in front of me doesn't seems tired at all)

Lantau Island with many wonders. This island is where u will see the famous Big Buddha, Tai O and Mui Wo.. plus many hiking trails.. Even hike over to Discover island. You can easily spend a day there.. And more days if you want to cover the whole island.
Stunning View. Its was beautiful and the place was so lovely we felt fresh and scenic was fabulous. surely recommend and take the crystal cab.

Lantau & Big Buddha. Try something different, use your Octopus card and take the ferry from HK Island (outlying island piers - Central Pier 6) to the Mui Wo Pier on Lantau, Then take the bus from the ferry terminal across the backbone of the island to the Buddha. Scenic, perhaps yes and no, but you see how the people of this fairly sparsely populated island live. The island is quite unstable geologically with a lot of road reinforcement over the steep hills. Yes you get to see dams and HK's main prison, such a bonus. It's not Disney it's just the real Hong Kong with real people. As for the Big Buddha, yes worth a visit, take some tablets for the long stairs up. The local Buddhist vegetarian cafe in the Po Lin monastery, take a punt and don't ask exactly what you are eating, we couldn't figure it out, tasted OK though. On the way back again use the buses with your Octopus card, cheaper than the expensive cableway down to the main town Tung Shung where you can hit the DFS shopping. All in a good day out.

I'm surprised!. I wasn't much interested when my travel mates suggested we go Lantau Island and visit the monastery, but I'm so glad I made the trip. I love the cable car ride up to the hills and the air was surprisingly fresh and cool in a hot summer day! Once reaching the island, I'm surprised that there are many interesting shops along the walking path to the monastery. Once we arrived at the monastery, we had a vegetarian meal which was ok. Tickets for the meal can be purchase just right outside of the monastery. We also took the stairs all the way up to see the Tian Tan Buddha and also the relic of Gautama Buddha. Up at the tower you will have a good view of the part of the island and the air was fresh and cool.I wouldn't mind going back to the island again for second visit.
Magical Hotel. We stayed at the Disney HotelWe have never stayed in a hotel like this oneCan't wait to return to stay there again and return to Disneyland.

Lantau Island. The one and only way to get to Lantau Island is by Cable Car. The cable car is an attraction in itself. It changes direction 3 times on the way to the island. You can reach the cable car by subway. If there are lines then just wait. It's worth it. Don't bother with the bus. You will miss a great attraction on the cable car.

Huge Buddha. The entire area is something of a temple-even the stores are somewhat subdued, meaning quiet. The Great Buddha is a world class icon and piece of art, as well as a place of worship. I took the tram, which was cool, and better than all of those stairs! Well worth seeing.
Big Budda. Beautiful scenic cable car ride up. Very interesting visit, nice walking trails and good food to eat.

Big day out. We were staying in HK so we took the MTR to Tung Chung, then walked over to the Cable Car. We took the package that included a tour and also an express pass so there was no long waits in the heat. The ride up to Gnong Ping is a great rip through the clouds to the Big Buddha. The tour then took us by bus down to Tai O fishing village, then a boat ride looking for the Albino Dolphins, we had some lunch and bus ride back to the Buddha. The tour guide then walked us around the Palace and Temple explaining in good English and answering all our questions and we finished at the bottom of the 200+ stairs. Yes we did the climb, and were rewarded with stunning views and cool breezes.We could have taken the cable car back to down the mountain, but decided to catch the bus to Mui Wo and a ferry back to HK. This was a great choice and was a very picturesque and relaxing trip back to HK central. Then is was a short MRT trip back to our station near the hotel. It was a great day out and we would highly recommend it to anyone with a spare day in HK.

Theres a massive Buddha? I'm in.. Its incredible. And the pictures your going to get both of the Buddha and on the ride up will rock. Take the cable car for sure, and if you have to courage...take the glass bottom version. Its a bit off putting being up that high at first but when you see the view below you...its worth it. The Monastery that is near the Big Buddha is also worth a look. Just remember its an active monastery and there is no meat allowed in the picnic areas surrounding it. Theres a "village" that you walk through to get from the cable car to the stairs up to the Buddha and its your typical Western mall experience - so if you're looking for "normal" food..thats your best bet. If you're willing to be more adventurous, hit up the little bbq place just past the village. The rest of the island is great for a wander. There are gardens and villages to explore. You can spend hours just working your way around the island. Its worth it.

Loved the Buddha, chair lift not as fun as the bus. We visited Lantau June 2014 specifically to visit the Buddha. The train trip from the city was very pleasant. I was actually not prepared for the length of the lines to access the cable car and if I had of known the length of the wait to access the cars I would have opted for the local bus from the start, yes it is summer and high season but the crowds were hidden away from where you buy your tickets. I upset the staff when my husband and I were placed in a car where we could not sit together and I didn't want the other occupants moved so we could sit together. The reason this upset them was because we wouldn't be together for the souvenir photo that the cable car tries to entice you to buy. The shopping village on the way to the Buddha was lovely without being hassled to buy anything. One of the highlights for me in the market stalls closer to the monastery was that I was able to replace some wooden beads that I have been trying to replace for 12 months, again there was no hard sell. We ate lunch at the monastery restaurant which I can now say was the best 3 course meal we had the whole 3 weeks were away. I highly recommend the food there. The Buddha was originally shrouded in cloud when I first saw it which only increased my desire to get there. The day we were there the Buddha bw as clouded in, in full sun and later it looked like there was a storm brewing. Each and every different look of the Buddha was beautiful. The climb up the stairs was difficult in the humidity but to get to the top was so exciting and well worth it. The free wi fi in the village was a bonus and allowed us to pick up some email messages and send some facebook photos. The bus ride down the hill and into the town was much more exciting than the cable car ride and heaps cheaper. We got to see the cattle, the beach, and meet some locals all while hurtling down the hill and then exceptionally slowly up the other side, all the time, thinking we were in the little train ghost could...I think I can, I think I can. And we did make it on the bus. I had waited since my first trip to Hong Kong in 2006 to come to Lantau Island and visit the monastery and this day did not disappoint us. We will return again in the very near future.
Fishing village. Went passed the big Buddha. Took a visit by bus to a fishing village. Seen the houses on poles. Great Gondla ride as well

Worth the trip. Overall Lantau Island is something that you really should do whilst in Hong Kong. The island is super touristy though. Be prepared for a bit of a wait for the cable car and don't get angry when over zealous (possibly mainland) Chinese tourists push in front of you for their photos etc.You get to the island by either MTR or by ferry then a bus. We decided to take the ferry to the island (a one hour voyage with good views) and then a bus from the ferry terminal to the Cable Car. On the way back we took the MTR. Having said that, make sure that when you do the cable car ride you have your own camera at the read, the views of the surrounds are rather good. I went on a particularly overcast day so visibility was not great. I was expecting something laid back and rural feeling when I got to the top of the mountain after the cable car. I was wrong, expect Subway, Starbucks as well as many clothing and food stores. Overall, though very very tourist orientated it is a good way to spend a day. Wear good walking shoes though.

Too crowded. Lantau island used to be a quiet place to visit. Nowadays with the convenience of cable car, the place is super crowded with tourists especially during holiday season. Overall nothing much left to see with so much tourist crowding the place

One of the Longest Cable Car Ride. The journey is easy via MTR to Tung Chung Stn & walk to Cable Car Stn. Suggest going during the weekday > still there is a queue, but 15 mins which is acceptable. The staff will come round the queue line to suggest you to take their 3-hr package to avoid the queue which is triple the price, but with coach & guide. Actually, there is no need to have a guide because the place is not very big & you can take a bus to Tai-O Fishing Village at the bus stn on the right as you walk along the footpath to the Big Buddha. The bus is every 20min pass the hour & you just have to plan your time, but the staff will use this as their selling point for the package. Many restaurants & eateries up here & tea house. Citygate Mall is at Tung Chung MTR Stn where the facyory outlets are located with many restaurants, supermarkets & cafes.

Tai-O and Cable Car ride. Those were our 2 favorite things about the island. The cable car ride was about 20 mins, we did not take the crystal cabin which had transparent bottoms because I had a fear of height (haha). The views were beautiful from the cable car cabin and it was magical to pass through clouds. When we were approaching the final stop Ngong Ping, we could see the Big Buddha statue in a distance. From Ngong Ping, we took a bus ride of 20 mins down the hill to visit the fishing village of Tai O. It must have been a busy place during the weekends, but we were there on a Tuesday, so it was more quiet and quaint. We spend $20HK on a 15-20 min boat ride out to see the wild dolphins, but it was too hot and probably too many boats around, so we did not see any dolphins. Still the ride was nice with the sea breeze and a quick look at the village from the sea. I guess I would recommend going early in the morning if you want to see the dolphins, but I am not sure if there really would be any. This makes a good day trip to get away from the city life of HK.
