Nice view!. First suggestion : try to go on weekdays, so there won't be a lot of people :) We took the MTR to Tung Chung where you have to continue to ride a cable car up to the big Buddha. There are two types of cable car; the standard one (normal one) or a Crystal one. The standard one costs 150 HKD for round trip and Crystal cable is 230 HKD. The crystal cabin, you can see through the glass under your feet to see the scenery, not suitable for anyone who scares of height though, so have a look which one suits you the best.The ride up to takes around 30-40 mins (if I am not mistaken) quite a while.. you can enjoy the view :) it's actually nice. People suggest us to go in the morning, but in the morning we have others things to do, so we went there in the afternoon. Turn out that it was a great decision! we went there like 2 pm and there was no line, not a lot of people. While we were going up, there's quite a bunch of people coming down the hill. So, afternoon is not a bad idea at all to pay a visit, but one thing you must consider is that it is really heat up - the sun and everything - so in the cabin it is really like a sauna! and don't forget your sunglasses! because the sun is really really strong! Once you arrived, you will be in a small village filled with shops and activities for you such as walking with Buddha (as far as i remember) it quite a lot of activities and things to do though apart from going up to a very famous big Buddha. Unfortunately, we didn't try that..so can't really comment :( To get to the big Buddha, you have to take the stairs, which is quite a few steps; 100-200? not sure. Make sure you wear a comfortable shoes, it helps :) (I saw someone walked with her high heels up to the Buddha, and it seems really hard!!) up there you will get a spectacular view :) it is really really nice and really really a hugh Buddha!!! :D worth a visit :) Take a bottle of water with you, you might need it after a walk-up or if you don't mind to pay - there is a shop up there with the water costs 8 HKD that is acceptable.Pity didn't have time to explore an island much, but for sure next time! It is a great place to visit even though for short-time visitors. You can actually spend a whole day exploring Lantau island! Amazing view!
Misty and cosy. The island was covered in a low mist when we went and gave the Buddha and surrounding area a strange cosiness.

Tai O, Big Buddha, Nong Ping - on this island. Other than the big Buddha and Tai O, the rest is newly built... So just make sure you cover the big Buddha and Tai O. The rest can skip if you don't have time,But the cable car, pretty worth to take the ride if you are not afraid of height. Go for crystal cabin, it's costly but worth it since it's 25mins ride.

Must visit. If you are going to the Big Buddha, take a bus from the small terminal to the Tai-O fishing village, you will pass by some beach area and small local restaurant. You can stop along the way, if you are not in a hurry, take in the sight, enjoy a cup of tea.At the fishing village, you can get some really localized fresh salted fish, oysters, fishy items (Must bargain!!).You can also take a chance to take a boat to the sea to look for dolphins (the vendors will tell you, some tourist saw the dolphins ???, but we did not see anything nor did many others that we asked) It is also a good place to stay away from the buzz of HK.

Amazing Views. I was told by co-worker that Lantau Island by the cable car was a most in HK. I did lots of reading before the trip and it was great. Getting the opportunity to see the current reclaimed land for the expansion of the airport was pretty cool, the price was not expensive and the food was good.

Sky, land and water adventures. So many things to do in this island. If you’re a little bit drowsy and confused (especially after Disneyland and Ocean Park), just go lifted by a gondola to the island. Once there, anything goes is just pleasurable.

Surprise for us in store. There is a beautiful white sand beach on the island with a restaurant called The Stoep ( an Afrikaans word meaning The Terrace) owned by South Africans and there for 25 years already. Serving Tipsy Tart and other South African dishes, it was a very nostalgic moment. We also found out that almost 70% of HK is made up of nature parks and protected, and got a greater and positive glimpse on a bigger Hong Kong than what we ever expected

Worth a visit. We stayed at Discovery Bay for our trip to Disneyland. Island is easily accessible via metro or ferry. Lovely setting, very green and a nice contrast to the hustle and bustle of the city. Take the cable car to the Big Buddha. Getting from Disney to the airport is easy, but requires 2 intermediate stops.

A Lovely Day Trip!. We started the day late around 10am after a scrumptious breakfast at the hotel and considered the various options to get to Lantau Island. We eventually decide to take the MTR to Tung Chung then a cable car ride to the island as this is the best way to let our young kids experience the public transport and also enjoy a ride in the crystal cable cars. The MTR was a breeze to use and we were in Tung Chung in no time.When buying tickets for the cable car, the salesperson recommended we take the 3-in-1 land-sea-air package. This gives us access to the cable car, short bus tour and boat ride at Tai O Fish Village. But the best part was the pass enabled us to skip the crazy cable car queues in the blistering hot weather! We were so thankful!So we started by taking the crystal cable car (transparent glass bottom and sides) to the island. It was a fun experience for the kids, they enjoyed the ride which offered spectacular views of HK and its airport from above. Upon reaching the island, there is a rather commercialized retail strip with souvenir shops and eateries. Nothing spectacular. After walking around for abit, we took a short 15 min bus ride to Tai O Village. There was a guide on the bus by the name of Ricky, who was entertaining and knowledgable. He shared some short stories about the island and the village. Upon reaching the village, we boarded a small speed boat which took us on a ride along the coastal strip of the village to see the houses on stilts and its occupants. It was interesting to see and experience the lives of these fishermen and their families. Then we entered the main seas to see the famous pink dolphins. We caught several glimpses of the pink dolphins, although not a fantastic full view of them leaping out of the waters,but it was enough to satisfy the kids and the adults alike.After the boat ride, we were given 45 minutes to explore the island, which were mainly shops selling dried seafood. Also there were eateries and convenience shops. It was a truly authentic experience. The tour bus then took us back to the point where we boarded it, and we were led by the guide to visit the Big Buddha. A very large and majestic statue where you have to climb more than 200 steps to reach the top, and enjoy the views. At the bottom of the statue if you do not wish to climb, there is Po Lin Monastery. After that you can walk back to the cable car station and take a ride back to Tung Chung MTR, which was where we started. Along the way, we spotted a small eatery which had a huge banner advertising its famous "homemade beancurd made from spring water". We stopped for a dessert and drinks. It was delicious! Lip-smacking good!!!The entire excursion took us about 5 hours. I enjoyed the idyllic and authentic experience and would urge anyone with kids to take this tour. Something fun and away from the noise and bustle of HK!

Interesting worth a visit. Well worth a visit the food market is good,definitely try the waffles also the fish is worth a try, good views from the cable car and the boat ride is interesting but unfortunately we didn't see the dolphin days it was raining

Big Budda. Got the ferry from Hong Kong island to the port on Lantau. You then get a bus from the front of the ferry stand but make sure you have the correct money or an octopus card as drivers don't give change. There are quite a few shops across the road if you need to break notes. I would strongly suggest the octopus card which covers most public transport. Bus ride is a fantastic 40 minutes through lush countryside where it stops up near the monastery. If it's cloudy it can be difficult to see the Budda but it worth seeing the statues and the Budda itself is huge. You can pay to go inside and get a free ice cream at the foot of the massive stairway, it is a long way up. Defo worth a visit.

Fantastic place to visit when in Hong Kong.. We love Lantau Island and always factor at least one trip to it every time we go to Hong Kong. It is easily accessible via the Fast Ferry/First Ferry from Central Pier on HK Island. It takes around half an hour. The trip out there is brilliant and the island has so much to offer, bars and restaurants on the Harbour front plus the famous 'Big Buddha', Po Lin Monastery, Tai O Village, Silver Mine Bay and Discovery Bay. You can get buses to all the major attractions on the island immediately you get off the ferry. Visit the China Bear bar and Deeer Horn Nepalese restaurant - both brilliant.

Fantastic Cable Car Views!!!!. We opted to do this sightseeing on our own - so glad we did! We took the metro all the way to Lantau Island from the Tin Hau station and purchased tickets for the cable car ride upon arrival. This is a marvelous island for hiking, viewing the giant Buddha and simply enjoying the beauty of the surrounding area. Take the time to visit the monastery and the local village.....its worth the trip. The highlight of the day was, without a doubt, the cable car ride - simply incredible views and it shows the massive size of Hong Kong airport. We spent the extra few dollars for a glass-bottomed cable car....absolutely do this....you will get photographs from between your feet!
Jump on a bus from Mui Wo to Nong Ping.. A great little sight seeing trip and a good way to see the island and work out where you would like to visit

Great day out. This is my first time to Hong Kong and I was advised to go to Lantau Island and I am so glad I did. I did a day tour, the New Lantau Island Tour. After being picked up from my hotel we were. taken to Central to catch the ferry to Lantau where our bus was waiting. We were told Lantau is 95% country park and 90% government-owned (or is it the other way round?). Anyway most of it being owned by government is why there are four prisons on the island. I gather the reason it isn't like Hong Kong Island and Kowloon re development is primarily historical as it and the new territories were designated a buffer zone for the Brits against China and the deal was they would not be developed.First we went to Ceung Sha beach then to Tai O fishing village where we did a short boat trip through the village on stilts and our guide took us to a little but old temple there. Apparently many of the village's residents have government-provided accommodation on land but most prefer their village on stilts. Next we had a beautiful drive up through the jungle to Ngong Ping where we visited the Giant Buddha statue. Apparently this bronze statue was made in enormous sections in Nanjing and welded together at its site on Lantau. And it is one big statue! You can go inside the base and see 4 large pieces of artwork on Buddha's life. From the viewing platform and the lower viewing platforms with the statues, you get a lovely view down to the coast on a day not too smoggy. We had a great vegetarian lunch at Po Lin Monastery and time to have a look round and a walk through Ngong Ping village to catch the cable car back down to near the airport, then bus back to hotel. The cable car ride down was spectacular. Great views and you see planes take off and land below you.

Beautiful, Natural Scenic. If you want to stay away from the busy traffic, crowded street and mall in Hong Kong, this place is absolutely worthy to visit. Fresh air, green mountain, and hiking trial around the island, all of these you can enjoy.

Peaceful and serene!!. We took a transit trip to the Lantau Island in 2011, since we had been to the city in our previous trip. This was a much better trip to take, the cable car ride, the giant buddha, and the city view, along with a visit to the monastery, it was all a great experience.There is a peaceful aura around in the monastery and the buddha statue. The food (all vegetarian, no meat), at the monastery is great too !!. Overall, the lantau island tour experience was great !!

local culture with breath taking ride.. The day we visited was a day of the local dragon boat race. They said it is mostly for bragging rights and no betting at all... yeah huh uh. But we got to visit this last fishing village on this island. Use to have 60,000 people fishing but now down to 2,500 as fishing is a hard life.In this village has this very old temple, dating back to 1489 (?). The architecture/ engineering was pretty cool on how they put together this building and how it looked. After our 256 steps to visit the great big Buddha, we went on a gondola/tram what ever you want to call it. From way up high (few miles) to traversing down. And they made a stone paved walk way if you want to walk. Anyway, the ride was breath taking and you go over streams, valleys and even the last part is going over (way side) the airport. You are way above the planes! This is how high you are. This tour was a very good one indeed.

Great Options!. Lantau Island has many wonderful options for casual lodging by the beach and other nice attractions. The beach has clear water and it offers also many options to have fun and or relax.

Nice place away from Crowded City. Very nice place, away from hustle and bustle of HongKong City. You can feel the fresh air coming from surrounding mountain. Viwes from Lantau Island are brilliant. You will feel you are back to nature in a slow paced environment.If you are visiting HongKong, its highly recommended you go there, take cable car from Ngong Ping station to reach there. Plenty of food-drinks option available as well as clean toilets.

Island in the sun. On my last visit to Hong Kong which was 2012 , we had planned to go to Lantau but somehow it did not happen , we had been here of course in one sense as it is where HK airport is situated , but this time we took the ferry which was lovely as you see all the HK skyline as you are sailing out to sea & then all the surrounding Islands of which there are so many . When we arrived we took a bus ride to the other side of the Island & that in itself was very interesting passing some lovely beaches & countryside.Our destination was to see the fishing village with the houses built on stilts, quite amazing. Then up & down the narrow little streets where most of the stalls were selling guess what.... fish , most dried but not all . Here on the Island we saw many , many cats which I thought strange as we only saw one cat in all our time in HK but then when we saw many rats beneath the stilt houses we realized the reason for the cat population.Finally after quite a lot of walking we boarded the bus back , but then instead of taking the ferry we caught the train all the way to the center of Hk again . I would recommend this trip to anyone who has the time to do it , as it is a completely different face of Hong kong away from the high rise buildings & shops & markets. A real breath of fresh air.

Big Buddha. We visited this attraction by Mac 2010. Most of the tourist come here for Big Buddha. So we too. We took the cable car and arrived the cable station. The street is crowding and a lot of shops beside the street. The famous snack here is bean curb （豆花）They called it 山水豆腐花

Well, I can check it off the list. Paid extra for the 360 View experience to get to the island via cable car - which is almost like double. All this meant was the floor of the car was glass. Crammed in to the car with other travelers - ugh, felt like a sardine can in the sky.. In fact, we paid twice as much to wait in line twice as long. Never again. Cable car dumps you into the tackiest souvenir shop. Then you walk through a line of tacky souvenir stores to get to the Big Budda.. ok, he is big - but meh - no big deal.. don't know if there were other things to do on the island - I was done, done, done after this experience

Tai O. Traditional fishing village, well off the beaten track. From Hong Kong take the ferry to Mui Wo and No.1 bus to Tai O. Excellent photo opportunities - and do take the local boat ride around the estuary.
Great trip!. Had to catch the ferry and a bus up to the Giant Buddha. The weather was not so great but restaurants, souvenir shopping and the cable car ride back was worth it.

Stay here if you can. There is so much to see and do on Lantau Island. Disney Land, The big Buddha, beaches, nature walks, asia's Venice, shopping malls, cable car and the list goes on. If you hate big bustling cities, book your accommodation on Lantau Island and make a daytrip to Kowloon and Hong Kong city.

A great day out from Kowloon. I took a bus tour to Lantau Island and had a great day out. This is an entirely different world from busteling Hongkong/Kowloon and very recommendable.
The food at the monastery (vegetarian) was excellent!
A great photo opportunity, especially going back across the island by cable car!!

Lots to do. Ok Lantau island , my favourites; 1) big Buddha, catch the bus from tung Chung or catch the cable car up.2) do a hike, there a lots of fantastic hiking trails all over Lantau Island.3) go to Mui Wo, catch the bus from Tung Chung, there are lots of fantastic restaurants in the little town, namely 'the kitchen' or there is a Turkish restaurant which is also very good. There is a ferry which takes about 45 mins from central pier (30 mins for fast ferry).4) go to a beach, Cheung Sha beach is really nice, if you need directions to here type in the Stoep restaurant (a very good South African restaurant) in google maps. Bus 11 will take you here from Tung Chung.5) IMAX at the airport is good, never full so it's easy to get good seats. Book online to select seats. 6) send the wife to city gate outlet mall to do the shopping while you enjoy the sights.Enjoy!

Excellent daytrip. Lantau is a wonderful island just outside of Hong Kong proper. The island offers a variety of activities for its visitors. From hiking to swimming, or visiting temples and eating, the island has it all. Worth a day trip, but I think next time my wife and I will plan a stay on the actual island to enjoy it fully.

Missty. Next day caught the metro to Lantau Island Tung Cung line to visit Big Buddha. Train fast and cheep, at the station Jump on the cable car up to the site. Great views of country side and HK airport. Unfortunately as we got higher so it got cloudy misty so by the time we arrived at the end of the journey walked through the retail area climbed 315 steps to the base of the statue all we could see was a faint outline. See picture. So be warned.

A good day out. Lantau Island is easy to get to on the MTR system. You then take the cable car (great views over the island) to the top where the Big Buddha and the monastery are. Take a bus then to Tai-o village and do a boat trip to see the houses on stilts then out to sea to see the pink dolphins.

Very Disappointing. We were last here in 1982 when you could wander round small fishing villages and see locals in there homes. Now you get off the ferry to a sanitised version. There are plenty of hiking trails but if you are seniors your options are limited to waiting for the next return ferry.

Smart budget visit of Lantau Island. Fellow traveller, if you are short on cash/time and you don't need to act all touristy then I can suggest to do the following. 1. Buy Octopus card (in every metro station), with this one you can pay in all kinds of public transportation and it's very cheap. 2. Take the metro to the end of the yellow line (hard to miss as on every metro map you'll see an icon of cable car next to the station's name...that's how I navigate)3. Take one way trio in standard cable car to giant Buddha (you can take a crystal one but they are fewer of those so you'll end up waiting longer than standard cable car and all you see just some green under your feet...and almost price is almost twice as much than standard). Unless you are really want to take the boat tour don't take the combo ticket, you'll end up paying more.4. When done with the Buddha just take bus 21 to Tai O (fishermen's village). It'll cost around 7 HKD and you can use your octopus card.5. In Tai O you can either take the bout tour (which is still cheaper if you buy it there) or just walk around and actually feel the atmosphere. For food go to local places (nothing with wester touch in the name or you'll pay twice the normal price)6. When done take bus number 1 to Mui Wo pier to catch a ferry to Central (again can be paid with Octopus card and takes around 30 minutes)To summarize: don't be afraid of using public transportation and pay at the moment as it gives you huge flexibility of destinations and goes easy on your budget.Good luck out there!

A glimpse of China. The train to The island is straightforward and from there get a cab or bus or even a tour to the villages. It really is a delight, all you need are good walking shoes, drinks and a camera. A good hat and sun cream were also essential for us this week.

Nice Place to Visit. Visited Lantau Island in May 2014 (during the raining season) mainly for the big Buddha. However, it is very important to know when to visit Lantau - ie. depending on the season as this is badly impact the visibility. The ride into Lantau Island through the cable car was interesting and luckily we got on the glass floor cable on the way up when it was still not that misty/foggy. So we manage to see the view of the island and the greenary was just fantastic. Depending on what you would like to do at Lantau, you can get the package tickets with the cable car trip.I didn't find the food any good at the main eatery area. I guess that is what you have to manage when its a touristy area. Try the hot sausages on the way in or out from the temple / Po Lin monastery. Its pretty expensive but really nice! :)

Green island. the island is all green,real tropical forests. the fishing village is nothing intersting. Buddha was completely in fog and it was raining,i think rarely there will be sunshine. went up by bus and down by cable car which was very nice and thrilling.

Great place. Take cable car from Tung Chung to Lantau Island. Reaching up to the big Buddha statue is a wonderful experience . Must go in further to the wisdom path. It is another nice place. Remember to try their famous beancurd, it is the best and smoothest beancurd I ever tasted.

Visit the Giant Buddah. Don´t pay the overpriced teleferic. After arriving at the main central station got to the buses outside, same direction than the Teleferic. There ask for the all day ticket and you pay only 35HKD for the bus fare to the Temple on top of the hill (amazing), then get the bus to the fisher village and from there back to another bus to the main train station. Cheap and perfect.

Adventure Island. Lantau Island was great for a adventurous personality, try to experience the 360 cable car that makes your breathe hold for a while, seeing the beauty of hong kong around with the nature, good sightseeing, monasteries, and the Big Buddha
Tramping. Excellent walks and beaches. Just avoid the large cow droppings. You can take a bus to the end of the island and go dolphin watching for a small cost.

Worth spending time here. Brilliant! We loved Lantau Island and would spend more time here next time. Lots and lots of awesome walking trails, and the Big Buddha is certainly impressive. The gondola makes an exciting way to get up to the top. And if you're keen you can walk down.
Great outside Hong Kong Island. If you like beaches, fresh seafood, local shops and restaurants, here has nice places. You can walk around and so easy to go.
just to walk around. it was nice just walking around soaking in the atmosphere. worth the climb up for the scenery. cable car ride to the lantau was quite enjoyable.
Peaceful Island. It is a wonderful escape from Hong Kong City. Simply enjoy the nature and the silence. You can reach there by ferry or gondle. Both will provide wonderful views on the way.

Fantastic views. Interesting place to visit with a range of shops. We spent about 5 hours wondering around and seeing the various sights and generally taking in the ambience. Would recommended a visit.
love it. great night out more so when friends in town also eat up in one of the boxes you can rent not bad value and always fun its a hong kong must go if your a visitor

Best Chinese. What a lovely day we had on Lantau Island and a great cable car ride across the straits.
One of the best Chinese meals ever at the top of the cable car .
Go to Tae O if possible lovely old village

An island to enjoy. Its good to a place for relaxation and blessed with natural beauty in a buisy place like Hong Kong. Lantau Island certainly is such a place. Its variety of plants, animals and sea beaches is numerous. Several small villages invite to stay for a while and enjoy a meal in one of their coffee shops or dining places. The parks have special designated place where car owners can stop and eat out in the free. The ways to travel on the island are comfortable as shuttle buses connect the whole island to each other. Although it hosts the airport unless you are nearby, its in the north of the island, you won't be annoyed by it. Several authentic fishing villages in the west are worth visitng as the big buddha statue is and the small beaches at its south coast are. For a day in Disneyland go to the east side from Hong Kong easy accessable by the public transport MTR. To cool down have a swim in the sea in nearby discovery bay. Ones does not have to go far with such a place in front of the house, holiday and recreation can be so nearby.

Airport, Disney and Big Buddha all here.. You can not avoid going to Lantau Island. The airport is on Lantau. Disney is on Lantau, and Big Buddha is also, so you will visit this island. If you are going to Disney or Big Buddha, from the center of town, take the MTR subway line to Tung Chung for Big Buddha and then take the cable car. See my review for Big Buddha for exact directions. For Disney, exit at Sunny Bay and change for the Disney train. Of course the airport express train will take you to and from the airport. Not sure tourists will want to do anything else on the island, although there are attractions more for locals, like a beach and natural park.

Tour of lantau island with " splendid tours". I am currently working in Hong Kong and living in Kowloon. Not having much spare time I decided to take a tour of lantau island. This was a full day trip by coach to the island. Started at 8:15 and finished back at hotel by 3:30pm. I can thoroughly recommend this tour to all age groups and types. It was informative the guides spoke good English, they were funny . The tour includes a visit to Tai O fishing village with traditional stilt homes and it's still occupied by traditional fisherman regardless of the tourist visits. On toPo Lin Monastery and the huge bronze sitting Buddha . Whilst on the mountain the mist rolled in adding a eerie and mystical feel to the surroundings the sun came out again in time for some good photo shoots. Then it was down by cable car with great views of lantau. Nothing was too rushed or too lingered and we also had a great vegetarian lunch at the monastery . Really enjoyed the scenery , is was a good relief from the concrete jungle of kowloon. Thanks again Splendid Tours.

Fantastic Ride!. So calm and quite.. really loved it. Start early and take a return Crystal Cabin ticket so that you don't have to wait long in queues. A very nice village like setting after you reach at the top.. there is also a walking trail which can be seen while doing cable ride but I didn't inquire about it.. So no ideas for that one.Indian food is available in plenty... Dal Makhni with Naan what else do u want :-)Very easy to reach also as its last station on red line 'TUNG CHUNG' and it's very clearly marked from where to exit.NJoy your day in Lantau!

Nice afternoon. Really enjoyed my trip to Lantau Island and the Big Buddha. The whole cable car ride was an experience itself and people there were really friendly and helpful. Additionally, it's not very expensive which is a big plus.

Beautiful island with lots of attractions. I love the houses on stilts. They are unique. It was raining like cats and dogs and I was told not to go up to see the Big Buddha because the ground could be too slippery for me. Instead I went out on a boat ride to see the seals. I was rewarded with a baby seal that kept on showing its head!
Take the Star Ferry over. Lots to see and do; Discovery Bay has a beach, shops, walks, restaurants. You can also take the train to Hong Kong Disney or to shopping Malls.

very relaxing and pleasant trip to Lantau Island!. I took the ferry over from Hong Kong which took an hour and then a 30 minute bus ride up to see Big Buddha. Once you get on the bus from the ferry port the scenery is beautiful and you arrive at a beautiful alpine village. From there you can walk to Big Buddha and walk around the many stalls in the village. A TIP - there are cable cars there which take you back to Hong Kong, they are faster than the bus obviously but very expensive when in fact you can take a bus from the village (same one you came on) and pay next to nothing and get the benefit of the nice views:-) Take your time on Lantau Island, it is pleasanf and a trip to be savoured and not rushed :-)

Great day trip. A great outdoors day for us as the rain has stopped, cloudy day. We took the train and alight at Tung Chung MTR Station, follow the signs for exit towards the Tung Chung Bus Terminus / Cable Car. We chose to take bus to Lantau Island, there are signs for going toward the interchange easy to spot, we took Bus 23 which goes to Po Lin Monastery, Big Buddha. They have shops and restaurants after you alight where you can buy some souvenirs or grab some food/drinks. Public toilets are available. You can try the soya beancurd 山水豆腐花 which they have several stalls selling. We went to one where there are seats available under shade. Next, we took Bus 21 from Ngong Ping terminus to Tai O fishing village. The village is lovely and you can hop on to boat for dolphin viewing which is not expensive. Top up your Octopus card and you can travel using buses within Lantau island which is very convenient. Will go back again in future to explore other parts.
Height conquered!. Height from cable car may be scary but view was fantastic. Very efficiently operated including the marketing skills of presenting our photos plus plus!!

Pak Kung Au - Lantau peak - Po Lin big Buddha. If it is not misty, the cable car should be a great view, it was so misty so I did not take that down to Tung Chung.It was a hike from Pak Kung Au - I took #11 - exit b from MTR and at the opposite end of the terminus. You can also take 23, 3M. You have to tell the driver where you want to drop as it is not obvious, it was at the top of a long climb for the bus before it starts going downhill about 15min off from terminus. My driver forgot about me and I ended up walking up the slope back to the starting point. The stone sign on the ground at the start of stage 3 trail for Pak Kung Au is relatively small. There are some picnic benches behind the bus stop in the return direction, I.e. On the right when you are going there.There you start distance post L018 and you just keep going up and up and up heading west. In the mist I don't see where I am going and the wind is pretty strong, which worried me that I get lost. I was alone on a weekday. Not the best day but it was the last day possible for me on the trip.Fairly challenging, it took me 3hr to reach ngong ping as I was going slower since visibility was poor, you stick to the trail and you would not get lost. Took a lunch break at the peak. It was rather wet with the mist, I was with baselayer top and bottom which helps with the sweat, hiking boots, walking sticks, knee guard.Reached wisdom path in the mist and it was quite mystical since it was so quiet on a weekday. Only met 2 persons during the hike.The steps to the Buddha felt so easy comparatively, with the face covered in mist and occasionally dispersing to show. Got some incense at the temple on the other side for hk$20, it was a huge bunch and 3 larger pieces of joss stick, took some time to light them up. Inside the temple there is a food place, you can get a beancurb pudding and some dessert, food - inexpensive. Beancurb for hkd$10Would be great if the weather is better. Safer not to go alone else be prepared with mobile phone, whistle and other emergencies necessities.

Great Day out. Loved out day at Lantau. Lots to see and do, recommend that everyone finds time to do this. Incorporated visit to Tai O and the Big Buddha along with a trip on the cable car. The Tai Ofishing village is lovely, try to spend some time there, we only had a half hour and it was not enough. If there is one thing only that you do in HK this is it. You can make a day trip out of it as there is plenty on the island to do. Great Beaches, a different view of HK life, the fishing village, monastery and Buddha are all interesting. Unfortunately we had massive cloud cover so the views from the cable car were not great but it is an amazing trip anyway.

Take a side trip to Tai-O. If you have taken the cable car over to Lantau and have finished the climb to see the big budda, hop the bus (21) from the transit center over to Tai-O fishing village. Take a cheap boat ride to see the famous stilt houses built over the water.
Checked off my list. I had a list of things to see in HK - Lantau Island and the Big Buddha were on my list. The best part of visiting Lantau Island is the tram that takes you there.

This is a must see for Hong Kong. We loved this experience! We opted for the car with the glass bottom which was interesting to see things from that vantage point. We marveled at all the stairs people below were maneuvering to visit the Buddha. The photographer leans in to take your photo just before your begin your journey - nice photos but expensive. The ride is pretty. Once we arrived at our destination of the big Buddha we were impressed but didn't feel like climbing up the steps when we heard all that was up there was basically vendors to purchase fruit for the Buddha. We enjoyed walking over the monastery and seeing the monks perform a ceremony. We would highly recommend this activity while you are in Hong Kong! One word of caution - if you (like me) prefer western toilets - wait in line for the western style handicapped one. The others were all hole in the ground.

Great Cable Car Journey. A great cable car journey with views over the Airport and surrounding area. While not a fan of heights, this cable car was Ok. The top is very nice with restaurants and shops and the walk to the Buddha is not too far. It was very busy because it was Easter Weekend, but being well organised the queues went quite quickly. The fishing village was very busy and with the small streets was really difficult to get round. Generally a nice escape from the High Rise buildings of Hong Kong island.

Nice Island. The cable car ride is a 25 minute ride to Ngong Ping Village and the scenery is amazing on the way with great views of Lantau Island, the airport, the greenery and the ocean. At the top is a tourist village with a few restaurants, souvenir shops and ice cream stands.
Nature. Didn't expect the nature to be like this. Nice to escape the hussle and the fussle of the city and to enjoy the nature.
cool Island. from DB to Tai O to Big Buddha... much to do and see... crazy bus drivers though that hurtle through the island like maniacs
Just as your expect. It's pretty well known that this is a must see in Hong Kong, so it's definitely going to please your eyes. A great day excursion for sure!

Fantastic day trip!. Having travelled to HK numerous times over the past ten years, and always been tempted by the sights of Lantau Island, this time we finally took the plunge and visited. Travelling to Lantau Island is possible in a variety of ways. Indeed, lots of people say that the best was is by taking the MTR to Tung Chung, but by doing so, I feel that you will miss out on lots of other sites.I think that the best option is to take the ferry from Central over to Lantau Island. The journey takes around an hour and again offers great sites of the HK coastline. Upon arrival, take the bus which winds through the countryside up to Ngong Ping. This offers a great insight into lots of other things that Lantau Island can offer...the beaches and nature trails in particular are worth a mention.Upon arrival at Ngong Ping, take a couple of hours to marvel at the Giant Buddha statue and the sights from the peak, especially if visiting on a clear day. End the trip with the cable car trip back down to Tung Chung from where you can board the MTR back to Kowloon/HH Island.
Nice place. It is a very nice and comforting place. The place is very peaceful. The weather is nice. Even you are not a Buddhist, you should visit this place.

Beyond expectation. We were awed by the statues surrounding the temple. Being first time exposed to an interesting place such as this, both our teenage boys thought it was a day well spent. Lots of eatery everywhere and the souvenir shops are sure worth visiting. Definitely spend all day there, take your time to browse and walk around and discover. So much to see. Good exercise too when climbing up the steps to the top of the temple. You can also choose crystal clear glass cable car with extra fee on top of the normal price which is definitely for the brave. Fees are for the tickets to ride on cable car. Other than that, the entry to the temple is free. Lavatory facilities are well kept.
Beautiful space outside the city. gorgeous way to spend an afternoon! If you are not afraid of heights take the gondola ride for great views of the island!
A quiet island. The next decade will be interesting for this small, sleepy island. The residents are aging and I fear the way of life will change (probably not for the better).

Great place for a day trip. I went here last year and it was all clouded in. It was great to return and have a clear fine day. We enjoyed the cable car up the hill from Tung Chung. The big Buddha is amazing. So is the Monks vegetarian restaurant. A great experience. Well worth going. Easy to get to on the MTR.
Sighhh. Very lush and green. Much quieter than the main tourist areas but still great shopping and things to see and do.

Mixed. Lines and wait at chairlift were awful (get there earlier than I did). Id say if you got there when it opened it may be better or do with a tour to avoid lines (maybe). Buddhas area and chairlift (ride is good -great views) were too commercial. Tek O fishing village I really liked. Didn't stop at beaches but they looked great. Got ferry back to Central from Mau (?) ferry terminal which was good.

Serene and scenic. After all the city visits and shopping, this is a perfect spot for some soothing, scenic sights and serene relaxation.Lantau Island is reachable by the 360 degree cable car - which already provides amazing sights along the way over here. It travels over mountains and waters, leaving one anticipating for more.Lantau Island is spacious, a lovely nature spot offering magnificent sights. The closeness to the skyline makes one feel tranquil and at peace, and even magical as though we could simply reach out and touch the clouds.The grand Buddha statue is lovely, and imposes a sense of halcyon in us. Many people come up here to relax, worship, take photos and simply seek solace from a stressful lifestyle.This is a lovely spot and a must-see for all tourists.For more detailed information and photos, do visit:http://thearcticstar.blogspot.sg/2014/01/cruising-china-shenzhen.html

Interesting and enjoyable trip. Went there for a day. The scenery is awesome. Took the glass bottom cable car. Quite scary tho cos you can totally see everything down under. Prayed at big buddha as well. The breathtaking scenery up there. Overall, it's a must-visit place in Hong Kong.

Lovely Island. This was a lovely Island. We went to see the Big Buddha which I would definitely recommend. Also went to see the fishing village on stilts, amazing to see people living in homes on stilts in the sea. We took a boat trip through the fishing village which was interesting and then out to see to see the pink dolphins, these we didn't see. Very reasonable price though for a boat trip around £2. Buses were very good and again extremely cheap to use. My daughter and I enjoyed our day at this Island.

Big Buddha & Airport at Lantau island. The Lantau island in Hong Kong is one of the bigger islands and houses the Hong Kong international airport & Big Buddha statue & Po Lin Monastery situated on top of a hill. The journey to Big Buddha by 25 minute cable car ride (Npong Ping cable car) is one of the must do experiences. Lantau island has other attractions also for the visitors such as fishing village & hiking trails.

Enjoyable day trip. We reached the cable car station in Tung Chung early around 10am since it was a Saturday n we had heard about the weekend rush. We had done online booking of the glass bottom cable car. We felt its a good option for a few extra bucks. The cable car ride n big buddha were amazing.Next stop was the wisdom path, monastry n the lunch. All of these were ok but it was very sunny n left us all quite tired. Next we took a bus to tai-o village. It had gotten pretty crowded by then n it took us 30 mins of waiting to get the bus. The lady conductor on the bus made us pay 50hkd n didnt give us a ticket or change. The tai-o boat ride for the stilt houses was strictly ok. We didnt get to see any dolphins. Finally we took a taxi back to our hotel in Shatin as kids were exhausted. The big buddha n the cable car ride were the high points of this trip.

one sunny day.... Big Buddha, a major cable car, good views, easy access from HK. The fishing village of Tai O is unchanged in 50 + years by my guess. Not much English spoken but everyone very friendly. Stoep restaurant on the way to Mui Wo is worth a visit.

A getaway from the city.. When my husband and I came to Hong Kong we actually stayed on Lantau Island and it was amazing. Even though we were on the island for their winter time is was amazing!!!!!!  The island is so easy to get. You can cab the airport or even take the MTR no probably to island. Also there are ferries leaving all the time to the city for super cheap. The island itself is so easy to get around, the bus seems to go everywhere.  We spent our time there going to the Big Buddha, taking the cable car ride down the mountain and then we also visited the little fishing village Tai O. There is also alot of Temples to Visit and also in the summer Pui Beach is a must!!!!You gotta come here just for the day at least when your in HK it's an amazing little get away right across the water.

Gray Cloudy Day. When we arrived via MTR, we decided not to spend money on the cable car ride because we wouldn't have been able to see anything through the gray haze and the low clouds which covered the tops of the hills.We also decided not to tour the temple, after touring more than half a dozen Asian temples in the past couple weeks. They all start to look alike. That left a visit to Tai O and the outlet mall at Tung Chung.We did ride the bus 45 minutes to Tai O, which was disappointing after all the hype. The journey itself was pretty, riding up and down the hills of the island.We spent about an hour walking the mall, which has a lot of the same stores you find in North American malls. I almost bought some unique mint chocolate malted balls from a chocolatier and then put it back after the cashier wanted to charge us about $14 US for 3 ounces of candy. That's $90 US per pound !!!!!The mall's food court was disappointing (nothing but Asian cuisine), as were the handful of restaurants outside the mall.  If you're going to Lantau, be sure to go on a sunny day because, without the cable car ride, there isn't much else to do.

Something a bit special, very special.... Paid $500HKD for a trip in a cable car with a glass bottom, a personal guided tour of the Buddhas and Po Lin monastery. A coach trip to the idyllic little village of Tai O and then a 30 minute trip in a speedboat, afternoon lunch at the old Police House and VIP 'fast track' queue jump back down the mountain in the cable car. This was one of the highlights of my trip to HK. Very well organised and a real gem. Everything about this half day excursion was fantastic. Great value and well worth doing.

Go early or wait hours in line. Best advice - no matter the time - get their early!!! There is a bus that goes up as well that is cheaper than the cable car - it does take a little bit longer though. However, it seemed not as many people knew about the bus, or they liked the prestige of the cable car. There is nothing stopping you from getting the cable car back down. the big budha is quite cool. there are a few hiking tracks around so make sure you have the right footwear. Also, bring plenty of water it gets very hotThe food package the offer at bottom of big budha is ok, nothing to rave about.

Great. The cable car to Po Lin is a great way to get to Lantau - the views from the car are great, including of the airport and the mountains. It's a pretty long journey and some of the cars are glass-bottomed. For variety, take the cable car one way and then get a cab or bus to Mui Wo and take the fast boat back to HK.
Peaceful Island. One of the perfect escapes from the busy city life of HK island.Beaches,waterfall, giant Buddhas & Tai O fishing village!

A great day trip from Hong Kong. If you're looking for a fun day-trip from Hong Kong, catch the express ferry to Mui Wo from Central (outlying Islands), to Lantau Island, which is the largest island in Hong Kong. There are lots of attractions, including the Big Buddha (the largest seated bronze outdoor Buddha in the world), the Po Lin Monastery, and the arial cable car between Ngong Ping and Tung Chung. Very reasonably priced restaurants, souvenir shops, exhibits, and lots to see and do without spending a thing.

Great place to spend half a day. Easily reachable through MTR and then cable car. We took the glass floor cable car but wished we just saved the money - it's not as excitable as you think - after awhile staring at the tops of trees gets kind of boring. However the island itself is tranquil and it was a nice exercise to walk up to the look at the giant Buddha even though you have to pay to go inside the Buddha (which we didn't do). Food stalls around Giant Buddha also have some of the best "do fu fa" (a sweet tofu dessert) that we have ever had which is supposedly made with their "mountain water." Great way to spend half a day. We took cable car only one way and then caught a bus from Ngong Ping (#21) to Tai O fishing village, Hong Kong's oldest fishing village (we joked that it was HK's version of Venice with its stilt houses), then another bus (#1) to Mui Wo, another low-key town to catch a ferry back to Central. A nice way to spend the day.

A scenic option. It about an hour to get here and it is the biggest of the outlying islands but there isn't much to do! Yes, it's very scenic with a couple of good beaches though, compared to Hong Kong Island there's just no buzz.

The question is was it worth doing - probably not. Not a tour if you like your history, we stopped at a beach for 15 minutes tho I'm not sure why? Wasn't either interesting or nice. Our tour guide spoke well but we weren't interested in the several prisons on the island, to be honest it was a bit off putting. We did enjoy the fishing village great boat ride amongst the old stilted houses. Interesting to see the fish stalls .The big Buddha was a waste of time only 20 odd year old and not much to interest anyone sadly.What a poor vegetarian lunch , o my god why bother. Rice , spring rolls and a couple of vegetarian dishes. Cable car down mountain was nice.the tour was prompt and efficient but boring. Nice to met some interesting people. Don't waste your time and money

Tranquility. At Lantau island there are numerous things you can really enjoy:Ngong Ping 360 which is a cable car with amazing views that can take you there.The Big BuddhaPo Lin Monastery which is where the Buddhists in Hong Kong come to pray.The Wisdom Path which has pieces of wood sticking up from the ground with words of wisdom on.Lantau trail which is a really quiet trail that hardly anyone goes on but has amazing views in a tranquil settingAll of this is away from the hustle and bustle of the city with lovely trees and beautiful mountain views.

A bit of a tourist trap but for a good reason. Lantau is an amazing place. We took the glass bottomed cart up and the view was extraordinary. Our daughter loved the glass bottom and it was well worth the extra money. Our ticket clerk was Jackie Chan! Well, not THE Jackie Chan, but A Jackie Chan.

A more relaxed pace. From Discovery Bay, Hong Kong downtown is a mere 20 min ferry ride away, but it is so relaxed. There is virtually no traffic and the bus service will get you where you want to go with ease. It's not a shopping destination, but if you need the "in your face" Hong Kong then you can turn it on or off like a tap.

Epic Picture Perfect. Love this place it was a scenic coach trip to the actual Buddha we paid a small fee to have a meal in the monastery type building that sits at the bottom of the mountain which you have after youve been to see the Buddha, theres a photographer who takes your pic at the bottom aswell it looks epic when you are there. The meal is quite strange its fairly bland but feels ritualistic its all part of the experience

Great Way to Spend a Day in HK. From Central to Tung Chung Station takes 30 minutes via MTR. From here, follow the signs to the cable car station. You can buy your tickets there and choose a glass bottom or not. The glass bottom was an extra 10-15 USD so we just opted for regular cabin. The views from the cable car were great. There are restaurants in Ngong Ping Village near the large Buddha, but they are pricey. There are also plenty of restrooms. We spent one and a half to two hours checking out the area around the large Buddha and taking pictures. I was a little worried about figuring out how to visit Tai O fishing village, but the bus area is clearly marked with signs and bus times are posted at the stop. The ride to the village takes roughly 15 minutes and exploring the village takes an hour or two. We did the boat ride to see the Chinese white dolphins and the fisherman fishing. We also ate some egg puffs and glutinous rice cakes stuffed with crushed peanuts (really good). Lantau Island is a must visit if you are in Hong Kong.

Great views, worth a visit to Lantau island.. We took a one day guided tour to Lantau island and thoroughly enjoyed the day from beginning to end. Journeying to Lantau from Hong Kong takes about an hour on the bus, passing skyscrapers and busy industry on the way. But once on Lantau, all is quiet and peaceful and green. We climbed to see the giant Buddha perched on top of one of the mountains, not on foot, (which is possible but would take many hours), but on the Ngong Ping Cable Car 360 skyrail cable car. The views are stunning all the way. At the top we not only visited the giant Buddha, but also were entranced by the Po Lin Monastery and the delicious vegetarian meal offered there. A further highlight of the day was our visit to the Tai-O Fishing Village which is built on stilts and is still a busy working village full of atmosphere. Our tour included a sampan ride out to where the fresh water and the sea meet. There we were thrilled to see the famous pink/white dolphins frolicking in the sea. They put on such a fantastic show, leaping and swimming quite close to our sampan. Then we returned to our Kowloon hotel, descending via the cable car once again. Rodney, our guide was keen to tell us about every place that we visited. Go if you have the chance.
Beautiful. Really sleepy little village place. No taxis so take the bus really easy. Hair raising journey to big Buddha. Great fun.

Undiscovered HK. Booked a tour from my hotel. Visited the beach, the buddha and had lunch at a monestary (excellent vegetarian food). Guide provided excellent background on the island's history and preservation.
WOW!. Don't go swimming, more than one shrk death here. Otherwise great to see the Great Buddar if you have the lungs to copewith the steps.
Must visit. Great view with fresh air and interesting findings within The Buddha; a place of serenity and peace ... Many interesting shops around and great food as well

Wonderful Day. Much variety, from the Giant Buddha to the architecture to the lovely scenic ferry ride to the cable car. Beautiful, natural place with a serene atmosphere. One of the highlights of our trip. For people not able to walk the steps to the Giant Buddha, it is still worth visiting as you can see the Buddha well from the ground also. Lovely snacks too...the turnip cake and lotus buns. All vegetarian.

big buddha. took train across to Lantau and went on the cable car a must for anyone visiting Hong Kong right up to the lin po monestry and the Big Buddha statue the view 160degree was fantastic as was the village and monestry again prices very reasonable for eating ect

Worth a visit with family or as a couple for romantic dinner. Catch the ferry to Discovery Bay from Central (25mins). It's a nice area with great dining and a nice atmosphere. Can use your Octopus card but make sure you have enough credit. Lots of ex-pats (French, English, Australians, Germans) live in the area, especially pilots and other airline staff. Not far from Disneyland. Great for French and/or English speaking children to make new friends with other kids who speak their language. Equally great for a dining option away from the crowded Kowloon and Central areas. Loungy bars frequented by groups of ex-pats.

Definitely a must - go whale watching if you can!. It was a bit chilly when we went which is expected in February/March, but still a fun experience. I would imagine that it's much better if you go in the Spring...it was a tad foggy when we went and rainy unfortunately.. but that didn't stop us from having a great time. I recommend whale watching while you're there!

Great day. We took the ferry from Hong Kong and arrived at a little fishing village and was bemused at what to do. After walking around for half an hour we headed back to the ferry a little disappointed until we saw buses and asked where they go to. Being told they had great shops we headed there. The views on the bus were great but I couldn't see how there could be any shops in such a sleepy little island until we arrived at the Citygate Mall. We looked around the shops which were impressive but still quite expensive then we head across the boulevard to the Cable Cars and took the ride to the top. We then debated whether to come straight back but thought we would get off anyway for a look. We were glad we did with monastery's and the big Buddha up the top. We spent about three hours walking around then we returned to Citygate and caught the train back to Kowloon Central. I would recommend taking the ferry to see the fishing village then returning by train for something different both were cheap and easy to do.

Very nice getaway. There are several attractions on Lantau , we only went to the Po Lin monastery (with the Big Buddha statue) and it was really good.Nice things: The monastery is a nice place for walking.The place where the statue is situated offers a nice panorama.There are short trails around the place.The cable car also offers a nice 20 mins panorama experience.Did not like: - very long queues for the cable car - we lost more than 2 hours queueing to get up there and then to get back down. Maybe with combination tickets or by buses is quicker.

An absolute must-do!. Lantau Island trip is an absolute must while in Hong Kong. Cable car to get there (keep your eyes closed!) Amazing statue of Buddha (up hundreds of steps - don't worry, you can see it from miles around if you don't fancy the hike!) set in a sort of traditional village with a beautiful monastery too. Plenty of cafes and shops to browse. Then you can take a river boat to see Tai O fishing village, a real eye-opener as you experience the sights, sounds and smells of the real old HK. Shocking to some maybe, but a glimpse of a fast-disappearing traditional life-style. We were lucky enough to also see the white dolphins which live in the sea in this area alone. Fantastic experience.

Go early. The earlier you go the less queueing for the cable car you have to do, but its all very efficient and the queues move pretty quickly. Big views of the main airport when going up in the cable car. Wouldnt bother to get one of the cars with a glass bottom as there are less of those than the normal ones.Once youve done, then there is a limited outlet mall before getting back on the train.

Lots to do on lantau island. Lots to do on lantau island. Bid buddha in itself is worth at least a half day. Disneyland if you've got small kids. Lots of nice restaurants, plus the ark and some nice hiking trails and conservation areas.We saved lantau island for our last day in hong kong, when we were due to fly out just before midnight. We got to the airport early in the morning, and stored our luggage at the airport, then doubled back to explore the island.A great day out, highly recommended !!
OKB visit to Lantau Island. Lots of things to see on this Island, incl. Disney World if you like that!. Getting to the island by Ferry and back via the cable car is great!

Highlight of my time in Hong Kong. I would definitely recommend a visit to Lantau Island, it was a highlight of my visit to Hong Kong. Cable car ride is amazing wih stunning scenery and your first of the Big Buddha from eye cable car is fantastic. Po Lin Monastery was worth seeing before getting out close to the Big Buddha. We went on an organised tour which made it really easy, no waiting in queues for the cable car. You can get to Lantau Idland by public transport but the queues to cable car can be long at certain times.

Wonderful with kids. We loved Lantau island. We travelled across by the cable car in a group of 6 adults and 4 children. Our children aged 4 and 6 loved the whole day. The giant Buddha was amazing and our children were happy to walk up and down the steps themselves. We stopped for ice creams before going up all those steps. The view from the top was great.

Pleasant surprise. On a clear day like today - well worth the visit. My wife persuaded me to take glass bottom cable car (I have a fear of heights) - it was superb, great views, much longer than expected. The steps up to The BigB are well worth it and not too hard. In all, a good afternoon.

Well worth a visit. You get to Lantau via a cheap ferry ride from HK Island. Be sure to have plenty of coins as the ticket machine doesn't accept notes. The ferry ride is part of the fun, and the island is very different to the rest of HK, being peaceful and quiet. The absence of cars helps. You can catch the ferry to one side of the island, then walk across a well-maintained path to the other where the ferry will pick you up again. At both ends there are seafood restaurants competing for your business. Don't be put off by the powerstation - its not hte most attractive viewonthe island!

Worth a day after you have seen the city.... We took a full day tour by bus first, then cable car. First stop was very interesting fishing village..houses on stilts, dried fish, live fish, food stalls, shops etc. Very worthwhile. Next was the Big Buddha...Unfortunately hidden by fog, but a very solemn and impressive spot. Next vegetarian lunch at the monestary...very good. Visited the temple, wandered into the shopping area, then took the cable car down...Also in fog. Worthwhile day.

Nice ferry ride. Nice island. Some buffalo roaming around small villages - my son said it reminded him of Thailand. Was recommended to go to Tai-O to see pink dolphins but didn't manage to get there - maybe next year.

Lovely Lantau. Take the cable car up and don't be put off the steps up to the Big Buddah - it's worth it for the view - all 296 steps. They are in blocks of 16 so you can stop on the way for photos and catch your breath. Toilets can be found near the restaurants which are clean and western style. Plenty of places to buy lunch and a drink - well worth the trip. We paid extra and had a "crystal" cable car which gives you a cable car with a glass see through bottom. To be honest the views from outside the car were better than looking down but still a nice view either way. Highly recommended

Large island. We missed the cable cars, they were down for maintenance.The Bug Buddha, monastery and the vegetarian restaurant was very unique. We visited a fishing village that was run down, but the inexpensive boat ride was fun. The island looked beautiful from the bus rides. If we had time would explore hiking options.
A must see. Great journey by ferry to get there with in 30 mins and really cheap at 35HKD. It is a nice break from the built up Kowloon or HK island.

Worth a visit - just. Depending on the time of day, the views even from the Crystal cabins were very poor. The weather made the visit worst than than it should have been as normally it is a lovely place. The toilets need updating.

Great Day Visit. Took the ferry, did the bus to the Big Buddha, then the cable car and train back to Hong Kong Island. Really a great way to see everything. Very scenic.Cultural, shopping, people watching,historical. Highly recommended.

Lovely peaceful trip away from all the crowds. Get there from HK Central Pier No6 for HK$12.50 on your Oyster Card. Beuatiful ferry trip among the world's busiest harbor and all the beautiful little islands along the way. When you arrive, eat very well at the local cafes next to the pier - dim sum, stir fries etc, and then relax and cool out at the lovely sandy beach around the corner in front of Lantau Silvermine Beach Resort Hotel - which is not a bad place to stay if you book up on-line in advance.
Oasis. Lantau Island is a bit of an oasis in Hong Kong. Beaches are amazing and quiet. Getting there in public transportation is easy.

An experience. When travelling to Lantau I would suggest going by ferry and leave by metro. We took the ferry to Mui Wo from pier 6, you van kist check in with your octopus card, and it takes about 30 minutes. The bus ride is really an experience. Most tourists take the bus directly to Ngong Ping (where the big Buddha and the monastery are located). Once arrived at Mui Wo we took bus 3M, also check in with the octopus card, to Tung Chung. Over there we took the cable train to Ngong Ping. I would suggest booking your ticket on the internet, on a Sunday it will save you 60 minutes waiting. The cable train takes you to Ngong Ping and also offers an awesome view over the airport. When you've seen everything at Ngong Ping take the bus (21) to Tai O. An old fishing village, you can take a boat trip to see the dolphins and sail between the old houses. From Tai O take the bus back to Tung Chuck and travel back to Kowloon or Hong Kong by metro.

peaceful haven. I was thinking of doing the organized tour but happened to seethe ferry terminal for Lantau next to the busier Star Ferry. Theferry leaves every 50 mins (about) and gives you an excellent fulllength panorama of HK Island waterfront. The trip takes an hourand arrives at little port of Mui Wo . Its car free but people canrent cycles. So quiet. calm and peaceful and the view a cross thebay just amazing. Despite being 25 degrees and sunny, there was not one person on the lovely sandy bay. Others could takethe walk up the hill to a Buddha Temple (being unwell I had togive it a miss). There is a little café/bar on the waterfront andtiny outdoor market.So a pleasant morning for as little as 28HK$ (about £3 UK)

A peaceful place. Lovely place with a huge statue of Buddha .We did not climb the stairs but people were enjoying climbing.A picnic spot with many restaurants.We loved the cable ride as our cable car was of glass and we could a lovely view from a height.The best part of this island was the theatre where they showed us a video of Buddhas life.It was very informative and in the end they gave us leaves to make a wish also.A must place to go when you are in Hongkong.

Loved it but don't go on a weekend.. We were forced to visit on a Sunday as the cable car was closed the week. Luckily we pre booked seats online so we could by pads the 3 hour queue. I would very much recommend you do this if this is the only day you can visit. It's a fantastic place to visit and the journey in the cable car to the bug Buddha is something special, you do need a clear day though as the views are spectacular, not for people who don't like heights.

Loved it! Good day away from hustle and bustle of honk kong:). We planned a day to visit this island & so glad we did! We took the cable cars up(and took bus back down bc it's A LOT cheaper). It is a cool place to walk around and see the more nature side of Hong Kong. We also visited Tai O fishing village as other reviews have stated. It is super easy to get there..you just have to go to where the buses are located &I get on bus 21 I think? It runs every 20-30 mins and it takes you right to the village! It was so neat to see the way people live on the water & the slower pace of life. If you do visit Lantau island I hope you make the short trip to Tai O bc it is so worth it! After we were finished at the fishing village we just took another bus back to the subway where we started the day! Some people say it was an all day event but we were there maybe 3 hours:) if you go early in the morning there isn't that long of a line for the cable cars so that helped a lot!

Wonderful one day tour in Hong Kong. Must visit place in Hong kong. Its very beautifully structured. The statue of Big Buddha is really amazing. If one wants the fun of cable car, please go ahead. The cable car station is just outside tung chung metro station. However, need to have patience because of long queue. The Lantau island has very good eating joints covering different cuisines. Food is good.

big buddha. if you have extra day in hong kong, it's recommended to visit the island lantau. we visited there in the summer and it was very crowded. we waited 2 hours for the gondola ride. the way up takes about half an hour and the view is beautiful. hong kong is often foggy so try to go on a clear day if possible.

Great All Day. Go see the Big Buddha, the varies Monasteries, and relax and enjoy the peaceful island. I recommend avoiding the Cable Car unless you like waiting in long lines. You can catch buses from Tung Chung to see everything and for a lot less money and hassle. If you do insist on the cable cars, pay the extra $50HKD and go for the Crystal Cabin. The lines are much shorter, or travel alone as they like to pull single travelers from the line to fill up each cabin. They try, just too money people. So much to see and do, plan on spending all day there if you want to see most everything.
A perfect all day tour. The big Buddha and the genuine fishermen's Village were most pleasant . Take the 22 bus from main st in Budha village and u won't regret it !!
Go to see the Big Buddha. A great place to visit to see the BIg Buddha and the other sights in the area. The sky tram is amazing and the views superb. Really a must see if you're in Hong Kong.
Discover. ... where in the back rooms they make all those plastic things one gets in Christmas crackers. Good food, fascinating location and interesting culture. Worth a trip once.

Worth the visit - Big Buddha!. Lantau Island is one of those places with a lot of history and tradition such as Tai O Fishing Village and the Big Buddha. Try those stairs to get to the big Buddha - it will test your fitness that's for sure!

Natural side of Hong Kong. A group of friends and I walked up to Lantau Peak at 4am Christmas Day and we wanted to watch the sunrise. To our surprise when we reached the summit, there were about 50 others people ready to watch the sunrise. The experience was amazing and the mountain view was very worthy. Down at the village as well was very interesting and the Big Buddha is also found there, and can also be reached by the cablecar.

Lantau for solid shoes. The island is a vast change from the H K life of being offered shirts, suits, and fake watches at every turn on Nathan St! We had a most enjoyable time there and a memorable lunch (if you're a vegetarian you'll love it). the ride up was awesome. allow yourself plenty of time as the queues can be a little exhausting if the weather is good.

History on stilts. It is an interesting little fishing village and the houses are almost falling down. I liked seeing them in a short boat trip with houses on either side and I wonder how long they will survive. Some have flower pots on the porches, laundry hanging from haphazard ropes and puppies sleeping at the door. This is a must see. There is talk that the government wants to tear them down and built more towers!
Must go. A must go for tourist! Beautiful place. Besides the Big Buddha, must see to the wisdom path as well. Just follow the direction, abt 10-15 mins walk there and its totally worth seeing.

Worth a trip. It really depends how long you have to spend in HK and what is your interest. If you want to shop then don't go to Lantau. Lantau will take you bac into traditional HK village life. The best place to visit is Tai O. You can do it afte visiting the Big Buddha if or just on its own. Go to the original police station by boat (now a hotel and restaurant) then walk around the village. nIce

A very enjoyable day. Having sought advice from HK tourist office, we visited Lantau Island independently. MTR to Tung Chung, cable car to Ngong Ping, bus 21 to Tai O, then bus 11 back to Tung Chung. This all worked perfectly. The cable car was superb. Ngong Ping was just a modern tourist area with shops, cafés and the atmosphere of a theme park. The Buddah and the monastery were impressive. Tai O was different! We enjoyed the boat trip but no dolphins. Boat fine on calm day but wouldn't fancy it otherwise. Market full of strange fish related items! Buses were full and sight of water buffalo grazing at bus stops was a surprise. Felt that we had experienced more at less cost than an organised trip. Beware of queues at cable car. (45 mins for us).

Another island, so close!. We got there in 30 minutes, by metro. Amazing how near a neiboring island can be! It is much bigger than Hong Kong. There you will find not only the International Aiport but also Disneyland! Do not miss the Giant Sitting Budha and the monastery. You get there by a cable car, 7km long, in 25 minutes. You can see the Giant Budha from distance (34m tall), shinning with the Sun. They have a touristic complex up there, with many restaurants and souvenier shops. The monastery was refurbishing and the visit inside the Budha, which you have to pay extra, was not worth it as the only thing that you will see are scripts and the teeth of the one they believe to have been the very first budha!

Budda in the clouds. We were unlucky enough to be in HK for a few days when the weather took on a very British style - wet and cold!Nevertheless we still went to Lantau to see the Buddhist Monastery. The cable car would have been great if we had been out of the clouds for any length of time, and it was freezing!The monastery was still well worth the visit. On a nice day it must be amazing. .

Worth spending 3-4 hours. I had almost decided to skip this, but then am very glad I did not!I stayed in Hong Kong for 3 days & just in 3 days I was feeling 'cramped up'. Having a little extra time, I decided to drop by Lantau on the way to the airport. Tip: I checked in through the Airport Express terminals in the city (Love this service!) and went to Tsing Yi via the Airport express (hardly 15 min) and then to the Tung Chung station via the orange line. From there, Just 5 mins walk to the Ngong Ping 360 Cable car.The Crystal cable car was amazing. I have done many cable cars in the past, so wasnt looking forward to the normal (non crystal cable car). But Crystal Cabin is a good difference. We took many photos sitting on the floor of the cabin. The idea of floating in the air and seeing people, trees, water below you was very nice.After the cable car, we walked to the big buddha. It was mid february & very very cold. But the feel was very 'country-side', which was a delight after 3 days in Hong Kongs Hustle bustle. I got the feel of China (I suppose - since I havent yet been to Mainland), with mountains on 1 side and the big buddha on another, with chinese architecture and small country side shops. Even the dogs there looked like lions with all their thick fur. There are quite a few restaurants too - perfect tourist spot but not very commercialized, keeping the calm & serene feel!On our way back, we took the bus back to Tsing Yi - goes every 20 mins and takes around 40 mins to reach there. This was good too, as we could see the sunset all the way, turning left right, up & down the hill. Tip: There is an express bus to the airport - A1 - takes only 10 mins from Tsing Yi to the airport - super convenient.In brief, with the Lantau Island, I left Hong Kong with very nice memories!
nice too see old style place. nice too see what Hong Kong was before they haven't gone to crazy n fixing up the place the old fishing village style looks oldish and had nice lunch there

Speechless. View from cable car is amazing scenic, Giant Buddha statue is very nice, location is very nice, it seems he is looking all over hongkong and taking care of all people like protector. trekking path also available ,which is built very well, safe, take guide you get 360 view and feel top of the world
awesome. were just walking here and enjoy this place. don't forget to bring your camera :)) make a wish when your with the giant buddha.

Splendid Tour to Lantau. The trip to the island will give you a view of the hidden Hong Kong.Our tour included a trip to a fishing village, the big Buddha, a monastery and finally a ride from the peak down in a cable car.The fishing village gives you an idea of how people may have lived in earlier years. It is quant with lots of photo ops and time for a quick nibble in the market.The visit to the big Buddha is amazing for its sheer enormity and the follow up with vegetarian meal at the monastery was very cool. You may find this area a little more commercial than enlightening.The cable car ride will take your breath away.Well worth the $800 HKD ($100 Canadian)

Enlightening. Coming here was the highlight of my trip! Be aware that you may have to line up for quite a long time to purchase a cable car ticket. It took us approximately an hour. Make sure you purchase a ticket for the crystal cabin cable car! It has a transparent floor, and lets you be surrounded by the amazing views of the airport, mountains and grasslands. The ride takes around 25 minutes.Once you step foot into the place, it is so soothing and peaceful, especially compared to the noise, lights and crowds of Hong Kong. Everyone is quiet and very respectful. Before walking the steps towards the Big Buddha, purchase a ticket that allows access into private areas of the temple and it includes a meal ticket as well. The meal was very satisfying and included so much food. You can also buy incense to light as blessings to the Gods and for your loved ones. I suggest people to drop a small donation in the donation box as the temple is going through renovations. Walking down the steps, and around the area, you will see a lot of souvenir shops. We bought a wishing plate, which was similar to a wooden square, where we could write a wish, and hang it on a special tree. In return, you get to keep a small bag of crystals which symbolised keeping the wish safe and true. Overall, visiting Lantau Island was a great experience. It was the best attraction where you could get to see the cultural side of Hong Kong, and have a relaxing and valuable day. Will definitely keep coming back on future holidays!

Ngong Ping cable car ride. Eye-catching views, breathtaking landscapes.I reccomend spend all day there, visit Wisdom Path and Lantau Fun walk. Must see Tai O village and take there the boat trip to see dolphins.
Recommended. Recommended if you are adventurous kind of person, there are different trails to different level of view. Definitely gonna try it!

Highly recommend. We did the Great Lantau Enlightenment tour which included Ngong Ping cable car ride, a visit to Po Lin Monastery, then toTao O fishing village with a boat ride to see the houses on stilts & a visit to Tai O Heritage Hotel which was the former Police Station. What a wonderful day. The Po Lin monastery, known as the "Buddhist Kingdom in the South" has the worlds largest outdoor Buddha was wonderful to see. An amazing site set up so high on the hill. Would recommend this day tour to everyone visiting Hong Kong

Had to do something that day. My first day in Hong Kong, I took the MTR to Lantau Island. At the advice of a nice lady (volunteer) in the tourist information office in Kowloon, I took the cable car ride which was very pleasant. It lets you off in a tourist village which, if you are not into shopping for schlock, is about all that was offered other than food and a film on Buddha which should be called "Buddha 101"At the tourist village you can see the Big Buddha which may say more to someone else than it did to me.From there a public bus to the fishing village on stilts which I walked around for an hour or two and then a bus back to the outlet mall which is adjacent to the same MTR station at which I arrived.All in all a pleasant day

Worth a day's trip. I took the 3 hour package tour which not only brings you to the fishing village, it also includes a boat ride which we were lucky enough to see the chinese white dolphins. Best of all, with the package tour, you will be able to hit the express queue for the cable cars saving you a hell lot of time (two hours maybe, given the length of the queue especially in the evening). Since the meeting and ending point of the tour is near the buddha sculpture, it will be up to you to plan the timings of the cable car ride so it really felt like a guided-free and easy :) Just approach the staff at the bottom of the shuttle bus/ cable car queue and you'll be ushered to the express lane for purchase of tickets; you do not have to queue up in the main line.

I"M LEAVING ON A JET PLANE !!!. THE part of LANTAU ISLAND that is my favourite is the airport . Well planed, this feature is non stop , departures and arrivals twenty four hours a day , The brand names , and even a Disney outlet, they are all there before jetting out bound ...

Island tour. Very good tour. shopping boat ride and cable car was spectacular.
Visit to buddha and lunch provided. Very good value for money
