My favorite place in China. When I went, it was quiet, the weather was clear and beautiful, and it was clean. Aside from some barbaric tourists from the Chinese mainland, one of whom sneezed in this poor local girl's face and didn't apologize, the entire experience was very pleasant. Expect to spend long hours taking photos and exploring.

Haven. Lantau Island is a beautiful and peaceful place. The Ngong Ping 360, the adventerous mode of transport to this island is the best experience.we ever had. This place is very peaceful and so close to nature.

Lantau Peak - a wonderful experience. We came by MTR to Tung Chung. From here we took a taxi to Pak Kung Au. it was very cheap like all the cabs in HK From here the trail starts towards Lantau Peak. If you have no hiking experience or you hate walking "stairs" i advise to skip this hike.It can be hard at times and it is very important you bring enough water and a jacket for the cold air when you are walking "in the clouds". After 2 hours we were above the clouds and that was a spectacular view. After we reached the top we went down on the other side of the mountain towards Ngong Ping.(Big Buddha)It is a long hike down and after you reached Ngong Ping you can take the cable car back to Tung Chung.We enjoyed this walk very much.

Big Buddha. We took an organised bus tour from Hong Kong Island to Lantau Island. The tour bus picked us up at the hotel and then after a couple more pick ups we were dropped off at the ferry terminal to board the catamaran ferry to Island. There we got on another coach and had a great tour of a beach, where they have a flag warning about sharks in the water! Then we went on to a fishing village built on stilts and boarded a smaller boat for a tour between the houses then back on the bus to climb the hill to the giant Buddha. We then had veggie lunch at the monastery before saying goodbye to our guide and boarding the cable car to take us back to another coach that took us back to Hong Kong Island.I would recommend a guided tour. You can get to the giant Buddha via the cable car but with a guide you get much more out of the trip. Taker advantage of all the recommended toilet stops as some of the loos can be a bit hit or miss literally. Plan for a long time at the giant Buddha and monastery to take in ambience. As usual there are too many trinket sellers there but this is to be expected I guess. Things tended to be more expensive that at the markets so take care.Be prepared to be jostled and to be photo bombed by people who cannot see any further than the end of the nose but once they realise they have ruined a good shot most will apologise. Best remedy is to offer a big smile and retake the shot.We found people only to keen to take our photograph but remember to act with decorum as this shrine means a lot to some people.Also it tends to be a cash only place unless you venture Into some of the more quality shops and then visa is okay.Finally so much can depend on the guide. Ours was witty, knowledgeable and kept the day rolling along. We used Lantau Tours Limited booked through trailfinders but most hotels have their brooches.Make friends with your fellow bus buddies and share a tail or two. In our cable car we had four Aussies, one kiwi, one German and two Brits.

A good day trip. Love the views along the journey on the cable car, even though the staff squeeze 9 people into the cablin and I hardly can sit. Don't know why they allowed one more person to board even though 8 people is already considered packed! We tried the vegetarian meal at the Big Buddha. This is my 4th time here over the last 10 yrs and I would say quality of the food has dropped tremendously and prices have increased a lot. Anyway other than these, Lantau island is a really a nice place and you can take some awesome pics here. Try visit Tai O when you are here. The small fishing village provides an escape from the busy city life

much to see. liked: Tian Tan Buddha, Po Lin Monastery, Ngong Ping sky car.dislike: water buffalo roam free around monastery and stray dogs chase them often into crowded areas, I had a near miss of being gorged by a running bull with large horns.easy to get to from Hong Kong island on the MTR.

A must visit place in Hong Kong. We traveled by cable car and is a different experience and you can see the awesome view of Hong Kong. Also must try the famous beancurd made by mountain water, known as Shan Shui Beancurd!

Lots to see and due. The island has lots of things to due and see. If you are stuck at the airport and want something to due. Go to the City Gate Mall and take the cable car over to the other side of the island and see the Big Buddha.

Not too crowded, relax and even able to shop here!. Well surprising there are shops that offer some unique & nicely design sourvenir that represent HK, I grabbed quite a lot of fridge magnet here :P The cable car experience was already pretty awesome (stable and offer some great view). As my mum couldn't really climb the staircase, we just wonder around the area and there is this nice tau fu fah that it's a must try! (Well this one is really nice), we also ordered the fish ball (which generally HK's fish ball is just very nice, this one is no exception either). If you hike up to the Big Buddha, you may want to consider the vegetarian lunch that cost in in the ticket, I tried it many years ago and the food also very nice (not too sure now)

Another side to Hong Kong. Lantau Island revealed another side to Hong Kong, I enjoyed the fishing village of Tai O, where we had an excellent meal at a local restaurant. The Big Buddha is kind of overrun with tourists, but kind of interesting nonetheless.

Magical Experience. Getting to the island can be a bit difficult but the wait is totally worth it. I happen to be trekking along on my journey and had a very magical/spiritual journey navigating the island and finally climbing the large Buddha statue and looking back out over China. This is a must do while you are in Hong Kong.

good but lots of queues!!. Lantau was my favorite part of my stay in Hong Kong. The big Buddha is a must see but it is the fishing village that i loved as you get to see a completely different side of Hong Kong. But make sure you leave your hotel as early as possible, because modes of transport to the island have long queues for most of the day- I queued for the cable car for 3 hours!!! pre-booking might also be a good idea as it gets you ahead in the lines.

Tram ride was great!. The 25 minute tram ride provides great views. Also the village at the top offers a temple, the large Buddha, shops and places to eat. There's a gelato shop that has excellent gelato - right, real gelato! Unfortunately we had to queue for 75 minutes to buy our round trip ticket and board the cable car, and we queued 45 minutes coming back. There's a higher priced express option to pass the line, if it seems too long. Maybe go in the morning, instead of early afternoon, like we did.

Trip to see the Big Buddha. Booked with Gray line tours to see the sights and included the Crystal cabin for the cable car, spoke to others who DIY the tour, and they also enjoyed themselves, but the 268 steps at 1 deg was not an option for us...We were escorted , while a bit pushed for time,as you get with tours, we enjoyed an extremely enjoyable variegation lunch at the temple, go with an open mind and taste buds and you will be amazed...OK the 268 steps a worry, but with the tour, a bus ride to the top a walk around the Buddha and plenty of time to enjoy, a trip then to Tia-Po fishing village, the 20 minute boat trip, well your call, Me , boring, but they say when the weather is right white dolphins, ?? there are some stalls you can try the local treats, like giant fish balls? Then the bus back to the cable car, and a trip back to your door. TIP, if your ring the company the day before they will pick up/ deliver to your hotel despite the central pick listed on the ticket
take those cable cars. Awesome view, even though was foggy that day. Take the crystal cabin for an exciting journey! Buy the tickets beforehand to avoid the queue!

A must visit don't miss it. What a great place, specially 360 degree via cable car. Walking with Buddha. Visit to Ngong pong village. All very very nice feelings. One can get all kind of food Indian food is also available good & tasty. One need to spend at least 2 to 3 hours there if you want to enjoy it.

Don't get the day pass. We purchased a voucher at a 7-11 near our hotel and were sold a day-pass. We still had to wait in a line for 30 minutes. So buy tickets if you can instead of vouchers. Do not get a day pass an do not waste two hours visiting the fishing village. Just get off the cable car, enjoy your visit to the statue and take the cable car back. Avoid going during high noon if you want good pictures.

Beautiful. Really enjoyed Lantau island. We drove around part of it on our first day in Hong Kong. The scenery was amazing, mountains, sparkling sea, National parks, Big Buddha & Tai O fishing village.

lantau island. I went on the eve of chinese new year and queued for about 2 hours for the cable car across to the island but well worth it the views were magnificent, then caught the service bus back to see a different view,
Big Buddha. Very interesting trip to the monastery and the big Buddha but the highlight was the cable car from Tung Chung - especially the Crystal car

Industry is taking over. I went expecting nature and mountains. Got a great view of the airport, ship yards, and there is a huge mall there off the last mtr stop. Maybe it would be better in the summer with warmer weather and no rain... But I just can't rave about this excursion.

Big Buddha. Excellent place to visit, it took about 10 min to queue up and buy our tickets and get on the cable car for 150 HK dollar per person. It takes about 25 minutes. We went today and it was freezing as cable car has air vents. Wear layers. We stayed around 3 hours. Lots of steps so not accessible for anyone with walking difficulties. We'll worth a visit.
Lantau Island Monastry and cable car. This was excellent and luckily had some good fellow tourists. We were sheparded with transport but also had time for ourselves

Beware of cold weather. This is a great thing to do. All the reviews are accurate. You can't go wrong...unless it is cold. It was around 8 degrees today but when we got to the top of the mountain, it was 2 degrees. Absolutely freezing and probably colder with the windchill factor. If you're planning to go, make sure you factor in that it will be several degrees colder on the top of the mountain.
Nice day out. It was a quiet day out of the city and it was great to seethe Buddha even though there are 500 steps to the top!

Not to be missed.. This tour was the best on our holiday. We travelled by boat over to the beautiful Lantau Island. We went to a lovely beach, then to the amazing Budda, had a chinese lunch and then went on the most spectacular cable car ride ever. Superb.

One of my fave places I've visited.. The cable car ride to the Po Ling monastery alone was worth the trip. Scary but exhilarating. Awesome views of the island from the cable car. The village below the monastery was cute and had some great little food places and shops to buy some knick-knacks. The monastery itself, with the Tien Tan Buddha, is incredible. It is a bit of a hike up a well-made and wide staircase with rails, but worth the short breaths and sweat to get to the top to stand and stare up to Buddha.

Great trip to take. I loved my tour of Lantu Isalnd, our tour guide was very knowledgeable, the tour included a boat trip around the fishing village which was fascinating. The trip back on the cable car was just one of the best experiences of my trip, the views are just amazing, a 25 minuet trip on a cable car over mountains and the sea, where else in the world could you do a trip like that, breath taking.I would have loved to have stayed longer on the Island as noticed lots of walking trails, being an avid walker it would have been fun to explore these, maybe next time!

must see. I went by mtr although you can take the ferry but they only go hourly; from central mtr change and 20mins you are at the terminus, across the square and there are signposts to the cable car. It cost 150 hk$. Sadly the weather was very wet and misty but the trip was well managed and well signposted to the Great Buddha site. Be warned there are about 260 steps to the top but a magnificent thing to see. Down below you can eat at the veggie café and there are a number of shops selling trinkets and souvenirs.

Must see. The second important place to see in Hong Kong , The cable car ride to Big Buddha is one of the very few cable car rides across the world .The view from the cable car is breath taking , must see

Big Buddha, a great mall and lots of places to hike. Make sure you visit the Big Buddha by taking the Tram one way, then take the bus back....and visit the fishing place and eat at the Monastery. When done, you can shop at the outlet mall next to the Tram.

Eclectic Combination of VintageRural & Modern Kong . Ranging from the vintage Tai O fishing village which provides stark contrast to modern, urban Hong Kong, to the outstanding Hong Kong Airport and the Po Lin Monastery with its 34 meter Giant Buddha, Lantau has moved well beyond the huge largely undeveloped island, unconnected to primary Hong Kong except by ferry to an easily accessible and fascinating tree covered, mountainous spot with accessible and interesting sights. The cable car to the monastery is about a 25 minute journey with great views of the natural landscape, modern airport and hikers making the arduous trek across the island. The cable car is a short walk from the MTR ration. Lines can be very long on holidays but a small extra fee can give you VIP access to avoid the lines. The 360 tour is worthwhile for first time visitors as it gets you down to the fishing village and on the water as well as gives you background on the monastery and Giant Buddha. From the general monastery elevation, you can also access the Buddha statue directly via a 268 step climb. Plan a full day. The day we visited the last cable car back down the mountain departed at 6:30.

Great day out. We visited the big budda - great and the whole area is done very well. We then took a taxi to Tai O fishing village, when we arrived the village has 60's style buildings and thought we had wasted our time, but followed some other people and found the fishing village, really worth going to visit, lots of places to try some local food if you wish and just so different to see.

Lantau Island. I took the MTR to Lantau Island it’s where the cable car and Giant Buddha are, I changed 2 stations then I finally arrived to Ngong ping 360! I took the cable car and the view was spectacular its breath taking the journey last for 45 min then I reached Ngong ping 360 village from there you can walk to the giant Buddha they call it walking with Buddha and the road of enlightenment ! Well walking with Buddha is full of franchising corporate there were Starbucks, MacDonald, Italian ice cream and restaurants, subway and much more!! Anyway to get to the statue you have to take the stairs and its only 260 steps :( and I did it but it’s the first and last exercise I’ll have for the next 10 years! It was exhausting! The souvenirs shops there were amazing it’s everything I dreamed of. afterwards I visited the monastery then I returned back and went to city gate mal

Oasis of silent and spirituality. If You are tired of Hong Kong crowded streets and shops take a trip to Lantau with famous Buddha sculpture on the top of hill with view to Macau Tower (by clear air)! try to get there by subway and continue by cableway or bus. Take Your lunch in next door Buddhist temple vegetarian restaurant.

A trip through beauty. This was one of the attractions of our day tour and a highlight, the Buddha sits majestically atop a beautiful temple of rememberance with a peak into the reverance held for the past and the ancestors. A shared lunch in the monastery styled dining area a delicious vegetarian feast destined to change your opinion of Tofu. Worth the trip on windy roads.

Get off the main tracks. There are plenty of off track places to visit on the island. Look at the historical sites and old gun implacements as well as the small villages where life still goes on outside of the high rise buildings. You can also enjoy the peace and tranqulity of the wild life in natural surroundngs.

another side of HK view~. If u love travel area like countryside, agriculture , fisheries and conservation vegetation area (as country music artist, this area gives me lots of inspiration and burst of creativity) ...!!! Then this would be perfect places as your playground (places like Lantau peak, Tai O, Mui Wo etc..), enjoying all the perfect scenery & remembering them always thru ur capturing device.. Even u cant afford to hike at Lantau Peak due to time constrain or lacking of needed enegry. Take note that @ Tai O along the trail, that is the perfect area for you to enjoy sunset with your love ones or had sense of self-fulfilling journey if you're solo traveler...!!!

You MUST pre book your tickets!. Our visit to Lantau Is. was made all the more enjoyable by the fact that we had pre booked and paid for the cable cars over the internet. This is easy and it will save you, in some cases, hours of waiting in ridiculously long queues AND it will actually save you a little dosh too!We only had an afternoon to visit The Big Bhudda and it was absolutely lovely. We managed to walk around and walk up the steps with hoardes of other tourists with the same idea.We also visited Citigate Shopping Centre on a different day however, but this is not too far from where the cable cars depart.Lovely cultural and historical centre. Great for families. Really should do if you are in HK!

Beautiful and different side of Hong Kong to see. Get away from the urban hustle and bustle and take the cable tram over to Lantau Island to see the big Buddha and monastery. Take the local bus to the fishing village Tai 0 to see a different way of life. Be sure to take the tram back - the local bus back takes over an hour and is crowded.
so much in a day. Recommend: ferry from Pier 6, then bus to Tao O for a walk, lunch and boat trip (don't expect to see pink dolphins). then a bus to Buddha and get the cable car to MTR

Great day trip from Hong Kong Airport. Hop on the S1 bus and make your way to the Cable Car terminal. Head up to Ngong Ping 360 and pay a visit to Big Buddha. A great way to kill a few hours between flights while in Hong Kong

Land Sea Air. This was a day well spent by our family. We purchased a Land Sea Air pass which allowed us premium access to lines travelling in a crystal cabin (see thru floor) - hard for people with height issues - however, I survived and what an amazing trip and cable car journey was amazing. We went to the walking with the Buddha show (give it a miss - you can read all about it) - Buddha is a lot of step stairs but with rest areas easy to make the journey - buses can drop you there at the back of the Buddha. The temple was undergoing a makeover so only a small portion was available to view - this makeover will be undertaken for a while yet. We then made our way by bus to Tai O (fishing village) - and took a ride on a boat and it really shows the harsh conditions people live in. The boat ride also took as out to the bay and was not for the faint hearted. Then we travelled throughout the island on the bus networks and found some beaches which would be nice during the summer months - this also was included on our pass. We definitely saw a lot more than other people did. Recommend this as a definite.

A day trip to Lantau Island. We caught the cable car (crystal cabin so the floor was see through) to Lantau Island. The line up was long but the view was amazing. Once there we visited the Giant Buddha and had lunch in the small town. There were some lovely shops to visit and a small market too. We stopped at the Monastery while there also. Due to the lines we missed the trip to the fishing village as we were too late so allow a full day and go early!

Self tour (Lantau & Tai O) by MTR and bus. We took an MTR to Tung Chung, showed our prepaid online ticket print-out for the normal cable car ride (no queue at 9am). Fast & effortless line-up for our turn to board the car (we were 5th in line). Scenic view on the way to Ngong Ping and many stairs climb up to Big Buddha, but not too tedious. Take your own time. The air was cool and chilly, making the climb quite pleasant. Not sure if there are wheelchair access though, please check. We skipped the entrance fee to "Walking with Buddha" and gave the vegetarian meal a miss. You can pay to see the Buddha's relic if you want. Po Lin monastery was closed for renovation, only did a 5mins quick tour around its ground outside. We bought a souvenir magnet at one of the shops and then hit the bus 21 to Tai O fishing village using our Octopus card. Total time required for Lantau: (+/-) 1 hour just to sight-see, snap some pictures, buy some souvenirs. Otherwise, not much to do here (in Lantau) and there's no need to pay for touristy gimmicks in my opinion.

Peaceful island. Before coming there, I had checked the island on the map and been disappointed because almost nothing except mountains and bays. However, I was immediately surprised with the peace and beauty of the island. Not as noisy and crow as other islands of Hongkong, it is a best place for taking a rest vacation. The Ngong Ping and Disney Land are the famous places for visit.
So much to do.. Such an amazing island. We took the cable car out to the bug Buddha and it is defiantly worth doing. Get the three in one pass so you can go to Tai O

Not the best place for the disabled. Calm and tranquil with beautiful views and a monstrous big Buddha ... Well worth a visit....downside was the toilet facilities, a hole in the ground and the smells !!!!But don't let that put you off ....Just go !

Cable car ride & fishing village on stilts. An amazing cable car ride takes you up to the top of the world, well maybe just to the top of the mountain. From there you can climb the 269 steps up to the Big Buddha with a great view. Once you come down you can visit the Monastery which unfortunately for us was undergoing a refurb. We also took a bus ride down to the fishing village on stilts. They dry everything they catch from the sea and even dry egg yolks! I think it's a must see. There's also a boat ride to take you up the inlet a bit to see the stilt houses from the water and then out to see the pink dolphins but don't count on seeing them. I think it was cheaper to catch this bus using the Octopus card then buying the tickets when you buy your cable car ride.

Nice hiking, good dining in Mui Wo.. Nice hike up to Lantau peak or on the coast between Discovery and Silvermine bay. Well signposted. There is a lot more hiking to do on Lantau. My favourite place is Mui Wo (Silvermine Bay). Good starting point for hiking, well connected (ferry to Central, buses to other places on the island). Nice beach, no high rise buildings, good seafood. Try Fook Chui Loi Seafood Restaurant on Chung Hou Road (little walking path above main road between roundabout and beginning of the beach).

Awesome Buddha. The entire Lantau Island is a must see if you're in Hong Kong and have some time to spare. It was actually my favorite part of our Hong Kong stop. The Buddha is awesome, the cable ride is cool, the market smells fishy and like everywhere in asia they had really cold beer!

Gorgeous - Taxi up (important). Absolutely stunning island this was one of our high points of our 2013 SE Asia trip.TAKE A TAXI UP THE MOUNTAIN - The line ups are absolutely ridiculous thankfully I read up about them before heading here and we even managed to share a taxi up with another Canadian couple for a fraction of the price of the cable car and no line up. It is literally 3-4 hour wait in line.In addition to saving money and not lining up (which I hate for anything) the Taxi ride to the top wraps itself around almost the entire island for a super cool roughly an hour tour of the island. We were really really happy we took the taxi up. However you absolutely must take the Cable car back down it is not to be missed. Attractions and views at the top were great. Loved the old temples (not so impressed with Big Buddha, built in 1993 really?? see my review of it) No line up at all for the Cable car back down and incredable views the whole way down with a glass bottom cable car. Was a great say trip. Do not miss Lantau Island on your trip.

Traditional fishing village and giant Buddha on the peak. Took a tour with the Big Bus in conjunction with NyongPing360 tour company. To take this tour you can either take the direct route by MTR rapid transit line from the Olympic City stop, to the end of the line which is termed Lantau island cable car stop (this stop is also where you'd get off to visit the outlet mall for all the major high end retailers ). I'd suggest you buy your tickets in advance with the Big Bus tour company instead of at the tour site itself so as to avoid the horrific throngs of people lining up to buy tickets; getting your tickets in advance will help you bypass this craziness and speed to the front of the line ....in Asia, bypassing any line-up will make you feel like a celebrity (trust me on this).Upon getting to the tour location, you'd take the cable car to the top of the peak, where you will enter a village of sorts - this makeshift village was constructed to entice shoppers to buy trinkets etc. before you get to your tour bus. The tour bus takes you to the traditional fishing village which is very rustic, with houses built on stilts in the water. There's variety of shops selling dried sea creatures, herbal stores and bar-b-q stalls selling wares - I'd definitely suggest the Bar-b-q pork or beef which is delish!!After returning from the fishing village, you can tour the monastery right beside the second largest Buddha in Asia. ( I forgot to mention that you will see stunning views of the statue from the gondola when you are about to enter the tour destination).To get to the Buddha! you'd have to climb 260 steps which is not too bad and definitely worth the view of the surrounding hillside when you reach the summit.

An other vision of Hong Kong. Go there with the crystal cable cabin (try to reserve it advance on internet website www.np360.com.hk)..a real journey and after take the bus (one each hour) or a taxi (50hkd) to Tai O, a really scenic fishermen village. Go at the end of the village to see the old police station which became now a nice hotel and come back by bus 1 to Mui Wo. Here you will take a boat to Central and arrive at night with the lights on Victoria Harbour.A really pleasant one day excursion.

Great place for a quite getaway from the city. Quite place with a " cozy" kind of feeling of staying in a small island with friendly people . Well connected by ferry , bus and taxi to nearest MTR . Choice of food quite limited but good enough . The BBQ DIY spots next to the beach was a pleasant experience. Would advise this for people looking for a quite and quick getaway from the city. Proximity to disney and the giant Buddha is also good . So you can enjoy the cable car journey as well . Surprising to see how the HK admin has ensured they retain the natural scenic environs inspite of the airport built very close to this place. Definitely a must see and do while in HK.

Lots to experience- great place to visit. Hint; take train to Lantau and then take bus to Ngong Ping and the cable car return. The queue for a cable car up first is enormous and slow.Took local bus from Ngong Ping to coastal town and caught ferry back to Kowloon - marvelllous.
Great views. The roads can be a little curvy for some, but great views of the valleys and the Southern harbor out to sea.

Go there to see How HK has really developed. I hear that not very long ago entire HK was such...a fishing village!Amazing growth and infrastructure is sky high ( with the scarcity of land they have around them, the was they have planned the city is great)...having said that, Lantau is for experiencing fishing village, stilt houses, and a wonderful motor boat ride into the sea! Big Buddha is smashing but one needs to walk up atleast a 1000 steps ( an escalator to this place would have done wonders).Icing on the cake is, how you get there...the 25 mints cable car ride showing you the HK 360 degrees...we chose to ride in a crystal cable car, which is transparent from the bottom too...making the view all the more enriching!

First time certainly not the last. Coming to Hong Kong for 9 years this was my first time visiting Lantau. I enjoyed my time there, a much needed escape from the hustle and bustle of touristy Hong Kong. Came back re-energised

Hong Kong Delight!. As newbies to the city, we only had 5 days to experience as much as possible. Make sure you don't miss out on visiting Lantau Island. We forgo a trip to Macau to ensure we took in as much as possible. Definately no regrets! The bonus was finding the outlet centre! ;-)

Vegetarian Dishes are overrated. On Monday, 12/30/13, my girlfriend and I travelled to see Lan Tau Island. We read several reviews about how to get there as well as what to eat when we arrived.How to get there:We had read that the cable car ride would take a long time if we didn't leave early. We were on vacation so we didn't want to leave at 6am. We left from Tseung Kwan O MTR around 9:15am and arrived at Tung Chung MTR about 10am. We took the MTR to Central and then took the Tung Chung Line. When we arrived, the line for the cable car was completely full to go up to the temple. It was not going to be an hour wait in line. There was a bridge completely full of people that lead all the way down and wrapped around itself 4-5 times. Then the place we were going to stand in line was on the ground and wrapped around itself 2 times. THE LINE DID NOT MOVE. We were looking for buses that would take us up to the temple but there was no where to purchase a seat for these buses. We saw about 20 buses parked around the lines but they were all empty. We nearly left to go do something else. However, we found a blue colored taxi that would drive us up to the temple. It costed us $158 HKD. It was well worth the money. The drive took us approximately 30 mins. ****Tip**** I would suggest anyone travelling up to the temple to take a blue taxi or stand in line for 2-3 hours to buy a cable car ticket. On the way back, pay for the Crystal Cable Car ride and you will be put in a short line to take the cable car down.Food/Attractions:I initially thought that this venture would lead us to an austere, reverent holy place but I could not have been more wrong. Before we could get to the temple and the Big Buddha, there were a lot of shops, restaurants, and even a Starbucks. We walked up to see the Buddha. It looked very cool. The photos we took were iconic. The views were amazing. Then we headed to the temple. We had read that the vegetarian food at the temple would be amazing. After reading several reviews, it appeared there was only one vegetarian restaurant at the temple to eat at and we would have to purchase a ticket at the entrance to eat at it. We spent about $300 HKD for admission and the preset vegetarian meal and we received a yellow ticket to show the restaurant. BIG MISTAKE. DON'T BUY THIS MEAL TICKET.The temple itself was under some construction and looks no different than any modern temple you could find around the world. When we went to eat the vegetarian lunch, we were directed to a restaurant where they gave us 4 dishes. We first got a potato soup. (2/5 stars) Then we received 4 dishes. There was a tofu dish with corn and other vegetables. It tasted just like canned corn. (1/5 stars) There was a deep fried dish that looked like big egg rolls. It tasted like the oil it was fried in and had no other taste. (1/5 stars) There was an assorted vegetable dish of baby bok choy and mushrooms. (2.5/5 stars) There was a cucumber, celery and tofu dish that was bland. Completely tasteless or if it had a taste it tasted bad. (0/5 stars) There was a Vegetarian Deli right next door to this restaurant that had amazing dishes for sale. There was an amazing assortment of vegetarian dishes to select from and you could choose what you wanted to eat. The curry tofu dish looked amazing and I would have had some but I was already full from the crap food above. ****Tip**** Don't buy the preset meal from the temple. Buy food from the Vegetarian Deli. FYI: The bathrooms are generally holes in the ground.

Beautiful. We went on a tour organised by the hotel.. I believe the company was splendid tours.. Was very well organised saw the big Buddha, rode the cable car, stopped at a beautiful beach and the tour guides were pretty knowledgable and good English too.. Was fun

Great place to see. I visited this island on a short visit to Hong Kong and thoroughly enjoyed it. I found it very interesting with lots to see, I was totally gobsmacked at the size of the big brass Buddha! Would highly recommend this place to anyone, ps comfortable shoes are a must.
Lots to see here!. Lots of activities here and away from the hustle and bustle of the city. This bit added because TA requires 50 characters minimum for these reviews!

Very scenic. In order to experience this landmark, you should be there before 8 am. As there are many tourists from all over that visit and will disturb your chance of getting good photos. Wev went in early December, it was a tad chilly on the tram ride up, so bring a light jacket and good walking shoes!
Very Interesting place to Visit. Interesting Island many to do and see but we went a little too late, would like to visit again if I go back Hong Kong.

Cool, Clean and Serene !. We had been to Lantau Island on 15 th. Dec.'13 during our trip to Hong Kong ! We spent a whole day there enjoying the pleasantly chill atmosphere and had a lot of mental peace and happiness on visiting the highest Buddha Statue in the world ! We would highly recommend this trip anyone who visits Hong Kong ! Dr.K.Sundar, Dubai.

Makes for a great day. You'll likely see sights you've never seen before; what more can you ask in a day of sightseeing?!Allow a lot of time, at least 6-7 hours. From the Tung Chung MTR station, take the Ngong Ping Cable Car one way into the village; there is a rush to get back on the return trip, so avoid this. Take a crystal (glass bottom) car, if this won't bother you. Enjoy Ngong Ping Village, but there's no time to spend much time there. Do buy a vegetarian meal at the temple restaurant. Go for the air conditioned VIP room to beat the heat, if you can wait. We visited during December, so this was no problem. Take at least a couple of hours for the Big Buddah and Po Lin Monastery. There was a big addition to the monastery during our visit, so this section might take more time in the future.Take a hike along Wisdom Path. There are longer trails available.Take the bus to Tai O village; walk the markets there. A trip via one of the numerous motorized boats of the stilt village is a must do! After this, continue walking along some of the streets if time allows. Then, take the bus back to Tung Chung.Of course, this is just one itinerary. We had a day and felt it was very well spent!

Get there early!!!!. Lantau is a good day trip. The cable car ride is fantastic. The scenery is OK, not fantastic. Probably a few too many stores selling cheap crap.Make sure you get there early! We arrived at 10am and waited about 20 min for our cable car. We were done shortly after lunch and there was nobody waiting to go back so we got a car just for ourselves. But when we arrived, the line to get the cable car going into the island must have been at least 3 hours long.

Big Buddah. A very nice day out to get away from the hustle and bustle, and the concrete and glass.About 50 mins on the MTR to the cable car station.I booked a glass bottom cable car well worth the extra 100 dollars. The ride is about 25 mins and 6km long with fantastic views of Hong Kong, the airport, and then up and down small moutains covered in greenery. A lovely trip.We were impressed with the Buddah and the monastery and spent 3 hours there. There is a large flight of steps up to the top, I wouldn't recommend to the elderly or unfit, I believe you can get a bus or taxi to the top.We then took a taxi to Tai O fishing village $50 each way, you can do it for a little less on a bus.The village is very old and built on stilts, the selection of food is pretty good, try out the shellfish and lobster we took a boat ride around the village and out into the bay to hopefully see white dolphins.....but they were elsewhere that day. It was only $20 each, worth it even if you don't see the dolphins.A great day out, well worth the visit, I would say a must if you have time.

Tsing Ma Bridge, Tai O Village, Po Lin Monastery, Ngong Ping Cable Car. Thor Chan, the concierge at the Langham Hotel Kowloon, recommended this tour to Lantau Island to see the big Buddha.The tour included a visit to the Tsing Ma Bridge that is the longest road/rail suspension bridge in the world. From the Visitor Center, the views are fantastic and the gardens peaceful.From the stop at the bridge, we continued on to Lantau Island which is quite the contrast to Hong Kong Island and Kowloon in that it is sparsely settled and quite mountainous. Disneyland is located on this island though we did not go.Once on Lantau, our guide took us to the Tai O Fishing Village to see the stilt houses. Part of the tour included a ride on a sampan to see the houses from the water side. At this stop there is time to shop in the market and visit a temple that dates back to the 1400's and another tiny temple dating back to the 1700's that is adjacent to the older one.The tour continued on to the Po Lin Monastery where the world's largest outdoor seated bronze Buddha is located. I have to say that the Buddha is quite impressive. Be sure to go inside and up to the third level where you can catch the views. We also had an included vegetarian lunch that was very good.From the monastery you can walk through a small village for shopping and instead of taking the tour bus back to Lantau town, we took the 25 minute ride through and over the mountains on the Ngong Ping cable car. The cable car takes you over the international airport.Message me if you'd like to know the name of the sightseeing company that the hotel used.

A Day Trip to Lantau Island. We took the MTR to reach the island at 东涌 station at 11 am. We waited for nearly an hour for getting tickets to take the cable car ride. It was a scenic journey on the island that took about 25 minutes. The 大佛 is just next to the cable car terminal. It took us to climb more than 200 steps to reach the 大佛. The wind was strong up there. Later, we took bus 21 to 大澳 which is a small fishing village. Took some delicious grilled cheese abalone, oysters and snails. Since the last able car ride is at 6pm, we decided to proceed to the cable car terminal at 5pm where we realised that a long queue for the cable car had already starting forming. We waited in the cold for about one hour plus before finally able to have a ride back.

Perfect Getaway. Lantau Island in Hong Kong is one of the largest islands in this world city! I visited the island with my parents and my sister two months ago, and was blown away by the stark contrast of the city life and this apparently secluded island. It is great for sight-seeing and whale-watching. The hallmarks of Lantau Island include the Big Buddha and Po Lin monastery. It gives you an understanding of the rich cultural heritage of Hong Kong and a sneak peak of its history. For those of you who are not interested in sight-seeing, there are shops and restaurants dotted around the island for a more urbane experience. Lantau Island offers everyone something.

Big Buddha in the Smog. We took a day trip via cable car over to Lantau Island to visit the Big Buddha and the Lin Po Monastery. It is well worthwhile doing. The only negative was the air pollution that was blowing in from the mainland. Taking pictures was often impossible or a challenge at best.

Paradise in Hong Kong. What strikes you about Lantau Island is its contrast with the concrete jungle of Hong Kong. I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the island is the largest in Hong Kong and even more incredible is the fact that over half of the island consists of gorgeous Lantau North Country and South Country Parks. Lantau Island is also quaint, could you ever think of Hong Kong as such, with its fishing villages and the most secluded beaches. You even have walking trails. You must visit this island and though there is a ferry service I recommend the Ngong Ping 360 cable car. Lest you think the island is devoid of modern life, don’t fret, many lovely seafood restaurants dot the island and shopping buffs can feast on the lively shops. While you are there do visit the Big Buddha and the PO Lin Monastery.

good walk in an afternoon. A little afternoon getaway in this peaceful and gorgeous island. I tried one of the vegetarian restaurants but forgot the name. Many tourists on a Saturday afternoon and if you have the time walk up those stairs to see the Buddha. It's well worth the transportation time and be away from the crowded city.

Tai O Village. Wonderful boat trip along waterfront of the fishing village. Mosaic of surprice: fish, dried fish and a lot of sea living organisms. A lot of various shops, just to have a carriage to try the fishy stuff.
Relaxing getaway from HK.. Really lovely, relaxing little island. Had a nice time visiting coffee shops/restaurants and hiking to a little waterfall.

Nice vegetarian snack. Go direct to the bus and pay on boarding if you do not want a tour from the booth near the bus terminal. There are 2 types of vegetarian meals here the normal and the premium. The premium also allows you to sit inside the VIP room. You have to buy tickets first. There is also a ticket for the vegetarian snacks set. But I think it is better to just go and pick whatever you like. They are famous for their soya bean curd. Try it - real smooth, Their snacks are pretty soft and good.

Excellent. Easy to reach by metro. Than you take cable car with amazing views over the bay and HG airport.Nice walk through the monastery, than you can climb to Buddha hill.After that take a bus to the Tai-O village. There you can get a cheap boat ride to see the houses on the poles and the same boat will take you to watch the dolphins. There is a market n Tai-O so you can buy some small gifts or eat some fish.Perfect one day trip from HG.
Don't go on a Sunday. Don't go on a sunday, we had to wait 2 hrs to catch the cable car but it was well worth it. The views and climbing up the steps to see the big Buddha was just amazing.

Amazing trip - A Must See. We travelled to Lantau Island with Grayline Tours This was a great way to get there with a tour guide who was very informative along the way.The cable car is around 20mins each way - the view is incredible while travelling up. You can pay extra and book a see through cable car that has a glass floor - little bit scary!!!With grayline you dont have to join the long queue, you get straight on the cable car and head to the top.The Buddah is what you will first see and a small museum inside.There is a lttle restaurant up by the monastrie - to be honest wasnt very nice and looked and a little bit dirty.They have a few bars and places to eat up.
Cable car trip to the Big Buddha. Astounding views from the cable car and the walk around the village was good. Climb the steps up to the big Buddha and the views are awesome.

a must to see away from the city. great boat ride, good to see another side on hong kongtemple,s are great, but take your walking shoes.go with a well known guide, we missed the ferry back, however as the ferry was owned by the tourer company to our supprise the captain turned the big ferry around to come back for us what an experience. only negative poor toilet facilities on the island

Brilliant. Loved this place! The highlight was te vegetarian lunch at the Monastery and seeing the worlds largest sitting Buddha. Take comfy shoes for trek up the stairs to the Buddha. Maybe oh early in day for best photo ops and less crowds.
Lantau. Went by bus - which as agreat way to see some of the island.Island looked like the ideal place for a romantic break.

Tai O. Visited this small fishing village. Apart from the poor housing on stilts, there is not much to see and I fail to see what the attraction is. Swarmed by Chinese tourists, doing a boat trip along the small river.

Worth staying 1/2 nights here as there are several attractions here for families.. Ngong Ping 360, Tai-O, CityGate Shopping, Noah's Arch & Disneyland are here! So it is worth considering staying on this island if you intend to visit these places. Only grouse for this trip is it is too far from town for us to buy fresh wife biscuits from Heng Heung on our last day.

More to do than I expected. I enjoyed seeing the Wisdom Path (to the right when you come down the stairs from the Big Buddha). Make sure you don't miss it when you spend the day on Lantau! There is also a great 2.5 hour hiking trail up to Lantau Peak. In good weather, you can see some beautiful views of the South China Sea. You might even encounter some cows.

A fun excursion out of the City. This was a really fun excursion out of the Hustle and Bustle of HK. We used Hiong Ping 360 and bought the guided tour. The benefits of this are, no queueing for the cable car either direction, provided you book in advance. We never did and queued for an hour to get to the cable car but we managed to avoid a 65 minute queue to get back at the end of the day.The Cable Car ride was great but bring a sweater if you are returning late as it is air cooled and gets cold in winter. The walk to the Buddha was quite something and he is impressive. The Dolphin boat ride in winter is not great and you want see too many Dolphins but the fisherman's village is interesting. We really enjoyed the experience all in all.

must try...!!!. nice cool place! but please take the cable car ride as early as it opens...unless u don't mind q-ing for at least 2 hrs! booking online earlier doesn't help very much...simply reach early to get the tics from the counter...easy.. and the morning breeze is great on the cabin! enjoy the cool air!price diff not great for normal & crystal cabin...choose the crystal one if u can...worthwhile... long ride to reach the island...plenty to eat on the island...and the best souvenir shop is the chopstick shop...very reasonable priced for a set of chopsticks & rest...come in nice box...though its abit bulky but looks great for a gift!

Amazing cable car experience & beautiful island experience. To reach the Big Buddha on Lantau Island, one has to take the cable car. Unless you have major vertigo issues, I highly recommend the 'Crystal cabin' experience. These cable cars have transparent floors, which gives you an amazing under the car view too! You feel as though you are flying! Amazing experience. (Only wish it was longer, but the experience was the best!)Once you reach the Island, you can walk around the Ngong Ping village, which has stores selling some beautiful local merchandise. The walk upto the Big Buddha could be a little difficult for people with knee problems due to some steps, but if you can try, its worth the climb. You will not be rushed, so take all the time to climb up.Once at the base of the Big Buddha statue, its a beautiful & serene view ... you see green/blue ocean, small islands, mountains/hills full of greenery, fog/mist. You will have to see the view to experience it, words cannot do justice! The whole experience was amazing, even though people & kids were screaming all over, it was still a place where one can feel peaceful from within.While returning back, try to time your return cable trip along with the sunset time, the views are unparallel!Highly recommend this trip!Note: The wait time to get a ticket & then board the cable car could be pretty long (1.5-2 hours), so ideally try to reach there early.There is no fee to visit the Big Buddha, but the cable car costs about HKD 230 for Crystal cabin.

A good day out. Fantastic cable car but make sure you book online before you go unless you like standing in long queues!! Some really good views of Lantau and it is a good long ride in both directions, it’s not for any vertigo sufferers though as it does go pretty high up! The Tian Tan Buddha is worth a visit and the 300 steps to the top aren’t really that hard. My 2 1/2 year old daughter managed to climb them both ways with no problem and I make a point of saying this because she’s lazy and normally has her mum carry her everywhere!! The bus/taxi to Tai O fishing village is relatively inexpensive and it is a good opportunity to see a side of the country which hasn’t been taken over by shops!!! I was a bit gutted to have made the journey to Tai O with the specific intent on visiting the Shaolin Wu Shu centre only to find it empty. So if you are making the trip for that reason, it might be worth checking prior to going there to avoid disappointment.

A must-see. Did the Gray LIne daytrip to Lantau. You must see the obligatory Buddha giant bust at the mountain's top, dine for vegetarian lunch at the monastery being served by monks and their staff, and ride the tram the looonnnggggg way down the mountain, back to your bus to HK or Kowloon. What a great trip.

Visit the fishing village. Not need to buy the 360 sky-land-sea day pass. the so-called "unlimited bus ride" probably you only need to take 2 bus trips and the bus trip is not frequent. It is better to take a cab which cost only $50HKD rather than waiting for an hour for the bus.

Cable car was good. I was really looking forward to visiting the Big Buddha on Lantau but I found it to commercialised. The Buddha was impressive, but unlike other peoples comments I did not feel anything spiritual. The cable car journey made the trip worth while. The views are impressive. We arrived for opening at 10am to try and beat the queues but still waited 40 minutes for a cable car. We wanted to do the guided tour but was fully booked by time we got to the front of the queue. I would advise you to book online or buy tickets from a 7 til 11, that way you can walk past the queue. Although I found it commercialised I am still glad I went. It is very easy to get to on the MTR.

Over commercialized. We only went there to see the giant Buddha, which is amazing. Apart from that, I did not really enjoy Lantau Island. The Ngong Ping cable car was an OK experience. Everything else in there seems to be over commercialized. We just came to see the big Buddha, we also went to one of the beaches (which is actually quite pretty). It was on Sunday and it was really busy. We had to wait for a long time for the public bus to get us back to Tung Chung MTR station. Most buses did not even stop as they were full of passengers.
Cable car journey is good. The cable car journey to the Lantau Island is not to be missed. Take the crystal car one-way. It's worth the extra money.

Ngong Ping Village/Buddha. The Ngong Ping Village is a tourist village on the peak of the Lantau Island. I truly recommended to use the Ngong Ping 360 cable car, the view from inside was spectacular! Though the queue to buy ticket for the cable car was very long, but worth it afterall. November mark the beginning of the winter and temperature being to fall, so it will be cool and comfort atmosphere up here!

Take a trip. We book a trip though our hotel, which did cost more than making our own way the buddha but was worth it for ease and avoiding the queues. It also stopped at a small beach and took in a traditional fishing village, with interesting commentary on the islands history. Nice contrast to Kowloon and Hong Kong island

Attractive part of Hong Kong. This island is full of natural beauty and worth visiting. Disneyland, the Giant Buddha, fishing village and dolphin spotting are some of the attractions here. Take MTR to Tung Chung station and then the longest cable car to the base of the magnificient golden Buddha statue, from where you can get a good view as well. There are lots of stairs to climb up to the top of the hill where this Highest statue is situated. Unfortunately, the cable car was closed due to typhoon on the day of my visit, so I had to take a long bus journey there. (No. 34)There are gift shops, food shops and a Po Lin monastery here as well

Buddha breathtaking. Breathtaking when the Buddha can be seen, sometimes there might be a fair bit of cloud in the sky which will mean that it will not be visible.But when on a clear sky it is amazing.I took the Ngong Ping 360 up to Lantau Island and glad I did as the roads are quite windy on the way down!230 steps up to the Buddha so hope you are feeling fit like I did and ran to the top!

Getting too commercialised. We were here 6 years ago and thoroughly enjoyed our discovery of the Buddha and the locals who had minimal low key shops in the area. However it is now a commercial venture unfortunately with the gimmickry being sold in all modern shops. The pathway to Buddha from the Ngong Ping Cable Car was interesting with the General Statues a highlight, but the commercialism left us cold.

Queue queue queue. Not my first visit to the Budha and cable car but certainly my last.The online booking system which is essential is down, apparently under reconstruction, so reservations can only be made by fax. Who owns a fax machine in 2013 ? And then 48 hours in advance. Telephone booking is impossible the standard of English ( option 2 ) on the automated system it is impossible to decipher and a total waste of time.So you must queque. I did for 3 hours and I would certainly not recommend it for families.Once aboard the cabin which was crowded and far too hot the views are magnificent of Lantau, Macau and the airport. The Budha truly awe inspiring but the shops and coffee houses a total rip off.This attraction has lost its attraction because it is just too hard for the average tourist to arrange. Take my advice and take the bus up and maybe all down.

Disneyland on an island. A small version of the Forbidden City filled with gift shops, and a few fast food places. The Very Large Buddha was impressive. The cable car ride was the best. Wonderful vies of the harbor and the sea.
Nice Place. This island contains many places, must see places... like Big Budha, disney world etc... worth to spend couple of day here

Definitely worth a day trip. Only 30 mins from HK but feels a world away. The cable car ride, big Buddha, dolphin spotting and traditional cuisine make this an excellent day trip which is well worthwhile.

A must see but avoid Sundays and Public Holidays. Good access to the island via the MTR system (we did not book a tour).To avoid lengthy queues for the cable car (do this rather than the bus to the Budda), pre-book on line and avoid Sundays!Try the glass bottomed cable car - worth the extra ticket price.On the negative side the temple area is getting commercialised as you walk through the mall to the site of the statue of Budda and the temple!!Spend some extra time time going to the fishing village whilst on the island (no 21 bus from the top of the cable car)

Long Queue! Be super early or buy tickets online. We reached Tung Chung Station after our breakfast arounf 12pm. There was already a long queue just to purchase cable car tickets. It took us one hour to queue for the tickets and half an hour for the cable car. the journey took around 20 mins to reach Lantau Island. By then it's already 3pm when we reached there. Luckily we scrap off the plan to go Tai-O village, if not we might not be able to catch the cable car back which closed at 6.30pm. It's another long queue for the cable car back. We queued till the sky turned dark. We were very tired after that.Suggestions: Go early to avoid long queue or purchase cable car tickets online one day earlier. Start the journey super early if you want to tour Tai-O village. Take crystal cabin to the island and take standard cabin back, cheaper price as there's is nothing to see in the cabin at night, but if you want to avoid queuing up, take crystal cabin back, the queue is shorter.

Shopping. Apart from the cable cars, there is a big discount outlet on Lantau island, you can get the MTR from most stations directly into the outlet centre, its actually the last stop after the Disneyland stop on the MTR, some nice shops Ralph Lauren, coach etc will take about two/3 hours to get round

Nice - what a view. We took the MRT. Very easy to get to and not expensive. We went early and had no lines. The cable car ride was awesome. Long and great view. We had the clear bottom car - very cool
great island. brilliant island in HK.took cable car to see buddha, saw buddhist monastery, excellent eating facilities such as subway, ebeneezers kebab,great place to visit

Majestic Buddha - Amazing destination. Brilliant. 5 tons of metal at the top of a mountain...simply breathtaking. Atmosphere is so serene you can spend hours looking at the marvelous statue and the mountains. If possible, take the cable car to reach this destination.

Must must visit!. Tourists generally skip Lantau Island whenever they come to Hong Kong due to time constraints. What they don't realise is that they miss an extremely integral part of their tour. I loved this place. Firstly, we took a cab to the cable car base station. Then up we went to Lantau through the cable cars with gorgeous views all around. One can see the whole of Hong Kong airport with a bunch of jets littering around. I have to admit, these views pretty much make up for all the travel. Once we reached the summit, we were greated with the beautiful giant statue of Buddha. The weather was amazing up there and it was cold, so I'd suggest you carry a jacket. There are plenty of options for food like Subway, Pizza Hut and others. Avoid the lunch at the monastery if you're not chinese, found it really average. And do climb the stairs up to the Giant Buddha statue, you'll be rewarded with pristine views of nature. This is a must visit for everyone out there in Hong Kong.

Lantau island-family fun. You can take MTR (HK subway system), a ferry, or a bus (# 34) to Lantau island. There is no entry fee required. But it does cost you to ride the cable car to the top and return. The Giant Buddha is impressive and the temple is beautiful. After visiting the Buddha, take the bus to Tai O fishing village and spend the 10 HK$ for a boat trip. We were so lucky, we saw quite a few few dolphins. Also the fishing village is unique and interesting.

Can't leave HK without a stop here.... You will not regret it! If you have a day to spare, do hike up to the buddha - a well paved trail with steps from the lantau station up to the village. Do pay 100HKD extra on top of the r/t cable ride to add on a tour to the tai O fishing village and enjoy the boat ride in the village canal and out to the harbor for the chance to meet the pink humpback whale (dolphin really) that purportedly lives there. The tour also gets you a speed pass through the queue for the cable ride which mustve saved me an hour + on the busy sunday. Don't forget to take the 200+ steps up to the Buddha, it is quite impressive. I was not successful in the thrashing rain & wind but i think Mr. Buddha there wouldve made for a great optical illusion photo, so hopefully you have better luck. Lastly dont forget to try some of the local delicacies - tofu flower (literal translation) desert. It WILL change all your preconceptions of tofu. Try the tea cake (which I missed), fresh lobster, scallops grilled in your local stands...

Lan Tau. A must see attraction if one is visiting Hongkong. Beautiful, serene and beckoning Buddha seated on top of the mountain. The Cable Car ride crossing the mountains to approach the Buddha is a technology marvel. The only drawback are the long queues at the counter for booking tickets for the cable car - this procedure needs to be improved as it takes easily an hour. Nevertheless Lan Tau island should be a MUST VISIT on your trip to Hongkong.

Peaceful. I loved the serenity of Lantau Island after going around Hong Kong's shopping districts. We took the MTR to Tung Chung then rode the cable car to get to the Big Buddha. Afterwards, we had lunch at the Po Lin Monastery. Although the Ngong Ping Village was obviously a shopping district, it was still a nice place to look for unique souvenirs. I like the shop that sold cat figurines. :-) We were not able to visit the fishing village anymore but the bus ride back to Tung Chung was really nice. We got to see a different view of the island.

"Not to be missed". If you can't go very early in the day, make sure you pre-book in order to avoid the queue for tickets for the cable car which takes you over the bay and up the mountain en route to the Big Buddha. We travelled to Lantau Island by MTR from Kowloon which provides frequent trains and a system which is so easy to use. The walk from the cable car is lined with shops selling mainly souvenirs and once you are there be prepared for the steps up to the Big Buddha. A beautifully maintained area with gardens and statues at the base, indeed an attraction not to be missed. Remember though, later in the day it becomes extremely crowded.

Lantau Island. The kids enjoyed the ride up the mountain in the cable car it takes at least 15 minutes and going over the bay then up the mountain. Book online it took us over an hour to get tickets we got there at 12 and the online line was 10 mins wait. We took MTR from in town and easy to get to once you get off train 2 minute walk from station.
First place to visit in HK. The home of Hong Kong Disney Land, Ngong Ping 360, Big Buddha, and Tai O Fishing Village. Make sure to visit this island first, because it is all worth it!!!

Fun Cable Car Adventure. We booked the Crystal Cabin online in order to avoid the queues that we had heard about, but we still ended up waiting about an hour to board. (The wait for a standard car would have been even longer - prebooking is essential.) The views from the cabin were outstanding. We took the MTR round trip from Kowloon for roughly $25 HKD using the Octopus card rate. The round trip crystal cabin cable car was $213 HKD, so this worked out to be a very reasonably priced excursion.I must say that having very well maintained public bathrooms was also a nice feature.

amazing. peaceful must see!. Once in Hong Kong it a short trip to Lantau island better to take an organized tour no wait on lifts , once you take the lifts you have an amazing ride for 35 mins wonderful views then arriving a bus takes you to the top of the mountain the main Budda is at the top of the mountain there a small museum and shop inside more Buddas outside quite impresive, you can have a wonderful vegetarian lunch at the monastery then you can either go back to Hong Kong or visit a fishing village close by loved the tour!
interesting. fascinating cable car ride in the so called crystal cabin as it had a see through floor. Took a day tour. Vegetarian meal at the monastery was forgettable and regretable.
Home of the giant Buddha. Lantau Island is worth an afternoon walking tour if you find yourself in Hong Kong. The island is lovely, and the staircases and statuary quite impressive.

So much to do here. Lantau Island is the home of the Giant Buddha, Ngong Ping Village, Tai O fishing village and even Hing Kong Disneyland. I have had many great days on Lantau Island but still have not finished as each time I return to Hong Kong this place is always on my to do list.

Mixed feeling. Be prepared to queue (to the ticket office then to the cable car) over an hour even on a weekday. Best strategy is to go up by a standard cable car and down with a crystal cable car cause the majority go the other way around. The locals tend to be rude if you look asian but don't speak Cantonese.The scenery on the other hand is more than pleasant. Watching the path, the river and the mountain through the glass floor was amazing.

long Day.. Mainly went to see the big Buddah as we had heard so much about it and was disappointed for there was no temple nor did we see any monk. The whole thing was a bit of a big yawn really with a lot of wasted time doing hotel pickups etc. A total of nearly two hours before we left on the ferry. Cable car ride back down was probably the highlight of the day.

Go there early in the morning !. Getting off the plane early in the morning we took a shower in the lounge, locked our luggage and took the regular bus up to the Po Lin Monastery (40 minutes ride, the Ngong Ping Cable Car only starts at 10 am). So we were early birds there - and the first ones to climb up the stairs to the Big Buddha. What a treat for our camera, we took the nicest photos ! The statue itself and the monastery area is really worth a visit, the village there is nicely built but a tourist-trap. If you take the Cable car you have to pass through the village - not for us but it is built in a way that it doesn't disrupt the monastery area.We strolled the "Wisdom Path", a nice thing to do up there too. Being tired from the overseas flight and troubled by high temperatures and extreme humidity we didn't hike back down although it is recommended - but took the Cable car which gives you stunning views of Lantau. Definetly worth a visit !!
Buddha and Nin Pong. Walked up the 250 steps to the Buddha and then had a vegetarian lunch at the Po Ling Monastry. The took a cable car from Nin Pong and went across. Great Trip

Cable car ride. The ride up to the peak is lovely but is spoiled by the one hour plus wait to get a car. Once at the peak there is a charmless area designed to get you to spend more. There was no wait for the return journey.

Big Buddha!. We enjoyed the visit to Lantau Island during the cool weather. It's a nice ride on the cable car for about half an hour, with photo takings and chit chats throughout the trip. Efficient and nice cable car staffs will put our family into 1 cabin (6 of us). It's a nice Ngong Ping Village where we stopped by to have some 'shan sui tao foo fa' = Mountain Water Tofu Pudding. Tips: Do buy the tickets prior to the visit; e.g. buy from Hotel agent, buy online...

So much smog. We caught the cable car to Lantau Island and it is such a shame that there is so smog around as the views would have been so much better. There is the airport, Disneyland and the Big Budda on this Island and well worth the trip.

Cool vilalges throughout. We had a full day tour of Lantau Island on our 3rd day in Hong Kong. We boarded the ferry with our local guide and headed out for the 45 min crossing to the island. Once there, we transferred on to our own private coach. 1st stop was a beach stop for photos. It would have been nice totake a dip but we were on a tight schedule. Next we headed to a fishing village for an intimate tour of the village and some very old temples. Along the way we crossed the reservoir for the island. Beautiful. After a short boat ride thru the fishing village and then a short stroll around the village, we were back on the bus for our final stop, which was the Big Buddha. Lantau island was a wonderful excursion. Plan for it to be a full day trip.

high in the sky over Lantau Island. The Buddha and history surrounding it is quite interesting. The cable car ride is spectacular. Five and a half km. and 1/2 hour ride - up down and around corners...the smoothest cable car we have ever been on. Unfortunately smog was the order of the day so the view was affected by this, but it was still very enjoyable.
Short Visited to Hong Kong. We had a short visited in Hong Kong just 1 day 1 night but, overall was very happy and memorable special to Lantau island

The Big Buddha chair lift. Near the Lantau island water bus terminal is the access gateway to the chair lift. This takes one to the Big Buddha via a 25 minute chair lift journey giving fantastic views of the island.

worth the visit. this is something worth visiting just for the views alone! you get a 360 view of the whole island from up there. Yes it is FULL of tourists and if you don't want to pay to go inside there isn't much to see, but just walking up all of those steps is an achievement!

Don't Go on a Sunday !!!!. Left the hotel in Kowloon at 11.30. Got back at 4.30. Time spent actual sightseeing 30 minutes. 2 hrs to get up after spending 90 minutes queuing & half hour on a cable car. As I said don't go on a Sunday. The big buddha's up there but not a lot else & I wasn't massively impressed by the Buddha or cable car ride.

Unique Experience. We had pre-purchased our crystal cabin tickets which permitted us to skip the ticketing queue. Highly recommended to do so especially during peak periods. The crystal cabin (glass bottom) is also a must for a unique experience. The views were fantastic throughout the whole cable car ride and we even saw runners below on the trail to Lantau. Great vantage point of planes taking off and landing at the airport. And before long the Big Buddha was also in sight.If you are there in Summer make sure you go earlier when it is not as hot as it is quite a hike up the stairs to see the Big Buddha. For those who are fans of Anita Mui, there is a memorial for her there. If you had purchased the vegetarian meal ticket at the booth at the foot of the stairs, you could get free entry into the upper level where historical relics and paintings are displayed.We made our way back down for the 6 course vegetarian lunch which was not that cheap (HKD312 for 4) but was plentiful. Alternatively, as we later found out, one could actually purchase food at a vegetarian stall there. Since, we still had time, we decided to catch the bus to the Tai-O fishing village. You can use your Octopus card for the bus and it is definitely worth a visit. Here the homes are built on stilts and nearly every stall sold dried seafood. One can take a boat out to see the pink dolphins but we did not opt for that. Another different experience and recommended.

Lantau Island Buddha & Cable Car. A highlight of our Hong Kong adventure was a subway ride to Lantau Island. There we took a fantastic cable car ride to the giant Buddha. The views from the cable car of Hong Kong, the airport and the seas beyond were outstanding. Be prepared for a hike to the Buddha itself, especially the stairs that must be climbed near the end of this side trip. A journey to the Lantau Island Buddha and cable car should not be missed!

Worth to go....if you are a foreigner!. It's all about the culture of Hong Kong/ China. It's easy accesible through MTR/ Bus. They feature it's 360 view cable car-must go and you can browse the whole view of lantau island. Besides, hiking, cycling and shopping could be done over there! It's a great day trip experience. Remember to check for season specials.....they have sales (cable car) during some major holidays,! Go to check DiscoveryHongKong website!!

Lantau Island Tur. This tour is excellent from start to finish. Ferry ride very good, bus trip also good, Budda site exceptionally good, best of all is the Sky Train back. Awesome. The tour guide very nice and entertaining. :)

Great Island. I am amazed with the Lantau Island. It is a fantastic place with anything you may want, beaches, shopping, eating, hiking, cycling, trekking, sightseeing, cable car, not to mention the Big Buddha and the Disneyland. I suggest visitors to go there by a ferry and return by the cable car or vice versa. Too many things to see in both ways. I wish I could spare 1 week just for Lantau. The time was really not enough to enjoy all.
Visit the Fishing Village. Excursion to Lantau Island very interesting and an eye opener to see and learn about life, economy, trials and tribulations of the locals.

a day out. we loved this place the giant Buddha was one of the sight I wanted to see since we arrived in hong kong . Be careful when you take the the trip across as at the bus station they will try and conviced you the cable car you take across you have to take the crystal cars this is false nice trip across and after the Buddha their is lunch at one of many place here and there is plenty to do here and shop well worth a visit

Tranquil. Lantau is a refreshing break from busy Hong Kong Island or Kowloon. Tung Chung has shopping and the cable car to the Big Buddha, Disney is on the island and there are more natural spots like Tai O. Worth a visit.
Awsome. Loved the Tai O fishers town, great food. We saw pink dolphins, which are hard to see. The Buda is impressive, it's huge.

A good day out. A trip to Lantau Island is a great day trip, you can catch the train but the ferry ride is nicer, a visit to the Po Lin Monastry will take up a few hours visit, the vegetarian restaurant has great foodtoo and if your feeling fit the walk up the many many steps to the Bronze Tian Tan Buddha good view from up there once you catch your breath, take the 25 minute cable car trip will save your breath to see the Buddha, if time permits see the Tung Chung Fort, before you realise it the day has gone

Bad Timing.. Don't hit this on a weekend, especially a holiday one like we did! There was over an hours queue for the gondola ride, and even for the bus, so we didn't get to see the Big Buddha this time! Discovery Bay was pleasant enough and we had a good lunch.
Lantau Island. A great place to walk or experience the giant Buddha..not to be missed part of a visit to Hong Kong. Don' t forget to allow time for lunch at the vegetarian in the monastery.

Lantau by cable car. The trip and the cable car were very good.However,as it was a Sunday the crowds were huge and we had to wait nearly 2 hours in the queue to get in to the cable car.The vreturn trip was not so bad.

Great urban escape. A visit to Lantau Island is a wonderful way to experience another facet of Hong Kong life. I took an excursion that took me to a beach, a quaint fishing village, Big Buddha and a monastery. We went over via the ferry and took the Nhong Ping cable car back. It was a fun way to spend the day.
don't miss. we took the ferry to the island and the MTR back. the island is fun, the big Buddha is not to be missed. It's a great day to see some of outer Hong Kong.

Diverse. Everything from outlet shopping to seeing wild dolphins, wow! Catch the train to Tung Chung, which stops at the outlet mall. Then do the 360 tour which will take you from the Big Buddha, out to the fisherman's village (don't forget to find the egg waffles) with a boat trip to see the dolphins, thn a cable car back to the mall

A good day out. We caught the MTR to Lantau Island and was a short walk from the station to the cable car. We had pre-booked so no queuing, a special offer price of 171$HK enabled us to take a crystal gondola on the upward journey and return in a standard gondola. Was a unique experience in the crystal cab looking down on the world beneath our feet. On reaching Ngong Ping we wandered through the gardens avoiding the souvenir shops and stalls then climbed the steps to see the Big Buddha up close. We then decided to catch the bus to Tai O fishing village (6.60$HK each way) this took about 20 mins down the mountain. Was really interesting to see how the locals lived and plenty of opportunities to purchase dried fish should you feel the need! We also took a boat trip (20$ HK each) to see the stilt houses from the inlet and then headed out to sea a short way in search of the elusive pink dolphins. A return bus trip up the mountain before catching the cable car back to the MTR. There is an outlet mall at the station exit which was packed with Saturday shoppers looking for a bargain. All in all a very enjoyable day and although geared up for tourism you felt you were getting a feel for how the rural people live, we even saw cows wandering freely along the roads. The scenery was spectacular.Independent travel in Hong Kong is very easy, the MTR is straightforward and the buses well signed, you do need the correct money as no change given.

Worthwhile visit. Spent the day on lantau island. I highly recommend getting the round trip tram package with unlimited bus use and the dolphin boat tour. Definitely choose the glass bottom tram. Much shorter line for it and really cool to see the trees beneath my feet.

Excellent trip - we'll worth it. We took the MTR to Lantau Island and then the cable car up the mountain probably the easiest way to arrive. The views are superb too. At the top there's a few shops, even a Starbucks! Then you walk to the Big Buddha and monastery - again views from the top are pretty amazing. Monastery was undoing redevelopment so limited what we could see. Great trip.

A great place to visit. We caught the farry from Hong Kong Island across to Lantau Island and caught a bus up to the top to the buddha. It was amazing! The buddha is massive. We caught the cable car back down. There is a mall not far from the bottom of the cable cars with plenty of choices for lunch. The transport system is excellent, so you can easily get back to where you are staying. The Buddha and cable cars are a must do.

very good place for a day trip. you can arrive by MTR +bus/cable car or by ferry + bus. We went with the Ferry and then took the bus, visited the big Buddha and the Wisdom path (recommended too). On the way back we walked down from the mountain all the way to the MTR and the mall. This is a 7KM VERY easy walking all the way down. It took us 2.25 hours just like the signs said it will. The path starts right next to the Wisdom path.overall it took us 5 hours from the central in Hong Kong and back...An enjoyable day!

Big Budda Lantau Island. What a wonderful experience this was visiting the big budda on Lantau Island, a must do while your in hong kong.Take the Lantau Ferry from the main Star Ferry Building, then there will be buses waiting at the the other end, bus number 1 from memory, goes to the big budda and monestary. coming back take the cable car, whow what a view and its quite a ride, then train from the shopping centre you arrive back in, back to hk island or kowloon.Just to remind you there are a large amount of stairs to climb up to the budda, BUT you can still see, feel, from down on the flat

Something for everyone!. Lantau Island, the largest island in Hong Kong, is only a 25 minute MTR ride from central Hong Kong, but it feels like a world away because of its uncrowded green hills and gorgeous beaches. It truly has something for everyone. Head over to Pui O or Cheung Sha beach for frolicking in the sand while enjoying food and drink from restaurants on by the water. If it's the best beach you're after, Tong Fuk is your destination. Although there are no restaurants on this beach, the water is always clean, the beach is never crowded, and the scenery is beautiful. The Gallery, one of the best pizza and BBQ joints in Hong Kong, is a five minute walk from the beach. For those looking for a more active time, Lantau has hikes and walks to suit all abilities. You can climb the steep (and challenging) Lantau or Sunset Peaks, or walk from Pak Kung Au to Mui Wo with your kids.For shopping lovers, Tung Chung on Lantau has Hong Kong's only outlet mall.
