It is full of tourists on weekends so head there on a weekday if you can. If you're too lazy to do anything on Lantau, just hop on the train to Tung Chung and back for one of the most scenic subway rides anywhere.And last but not the least, Lantau also offers three of Hong Kong' s biggest attractions: the cable car, Big Buddha and Disneyland. Overall, it truly has something for everyone.

Serene, peaceful, beautiful place to visit. Very distinctly different from the hectic life in hongkong....indeed, it is a place no one should miss so you can see and feel the different aspects of life in Hongkong.... Beautiful place....delicious vegetarian lunch!

Wonderful Experience. It was my first time in Lantau Island. The weather is really perfect most especialy if you are doing to ride the cable car. The panoramic view will really takes your breathaway. When we arrived going to the Statue of Buddha we saw some vendors selling come cool stuffs. We climbed like 80+ stairs to reach the peak and gosh it is worth the sweat. There is also a Martial Arts presentation were children and adults was ''wow!'.

Worth a race to the top of Big Buddha !!!. Fantastic 4 night stay in Hong Kong with friends and the girls threw the gauntlet down before the trip saying they would beat the boys to the top ! Well needless to say they were blowing by a third of the way up !!! No contest and yep you guessed it ....They weren't really racing !!! Beautiful place and not to be missed if you visit Hong Kong

Great day out!. i spent a day on Lantau island - visited the Big Buddha, had lunch at the monastery, took a ride in the cable car and visited Ngong Ping - a day well spent. The island is peaceful and quite and can be easily reached using the MTR. There are loads of shops in the outlet mall next to the MTR station, which allow the shopaholic to enjoy the day as well. There are a few hiking trails to the Big Buddha, but they seemed a little tedious. The views from the cable car are lovely. I understand that there are a few good beaches on the island as well, but could not visit any.

Worthwhile Visit!. A journey over to Lantau Island is a must - there's so much to do. I probably only conquered half of it, but there's no harm in leaving some for next time. Lantau Island is home of the Ngong Ping Village, which houses the Tan Tian Buddah, Po Lin Monastery, the Wisdom Path, and Lantau Peak. If possible, take the cable car up to the mountain - the city bus is long, lame, and uneventful.Check out my blog for photos!http://www.vagabondingheights.com/2013/10/a-new-discovery-new-experience-hong.html

Cable cars!!!!. We rode the cable cara to the top of the mountain to see the big buddha. AMAZING views. You can also hike but since we planned a Disney day didn't want to exhaust ourselves. Beautiful mountain and sea views

Very nice place to visit. We for the train to Lantau from Kowloon. Lantau is a very nice place, cable car up to the Buddha and the Ngong Ping Village. There is also a shopping centre with a cinema and restaurants by the station as well.
Very peaceful. I have been 3times, I love the peacefulness. The vegetarian food is great, I love it. Small shopping area which is just nice.

Great place to visit but buy on line the cable car. I strongly advise that you buy a ticket on line for the cable car and don't get a ticket as you have to wait for 45 minutes in the line for the tickets. The crystal cabin is a bit of a rip off as the crystal cabinb cars occur only one cabins per 3 normal cabins and therefore the line is 3 times as long and the attraction to look down through the floor isn't all that great. Once you get there it it worth while the visit. There is a great Kabab place to eat and the food is not only tasty but reasonably priced for a tourist area. The tourist shops are also reasonable and the items for sale are reasonably priced. You should go up to the Budda statue and go up to the top for a small price as the views are amazing.

Clicking Away. I started my day with going to spot the pink dolphins which was very interesting and afterwards decided to stay in Lantau and visit the famous Big Buddha and other places.I did not really enjoy standing in a line for more than an hour to get to the cabin but the ride in the crystal cabin was rather enjoyable. I recommend to get your tickets/vouchers ahead so you avoid the wait.The big Buddha to me was just what the name suggests plus a million souvenirs to empty your wallets. Do take tour time to explore different angles to get a more interesting shot.The monastery was under renovation but I enjoyed taking a few shots of people as they were lighting the sticks with a very unique smell.Tai O village was a bit more interesting and more suitable for candid shots. Do head there if you don't mind the strong fish smell.Avoid going back too late so you wont get stuck waiting for a cabin. Enjoy!
Cable Car. The cable car ride was excellent. View was out of this world and the Big Buddha should nit be missed by anyone goung to HK

Camping in Hong Kong!?!. I did! Located on beautiful Lantau Island, one of Hong Kong’s diverse islands, you will find Lantau Island Campsite. Led by our tour organizer, Dragonfly, we began our hiking in a small village and go through the mountain rugged rock pathway. We were rewarded with fresh mountain air, clear, crisp breezes, and breathtaking views. We awoke early to see the sun rise and enjoyed the outdoor activities organized by Dragonfly. They did an excellent job making sure we had an enjoyable time - highly recommended! At night, we sat around a cozy campfire where we barbecued, made smores, and spent the evening chatting. The crackling sounds and the warmth of the fire only added to our fond memories of our time there.
great day out. spent the day travelling around lantau on the bus. lots to see and do. if spare time in Hong Kong would be easy to spend 2 full days looking around.
Time well spent. Visited the Big Buddha and stayed at Silvermine Bay. A lovely wind down after almost 2 weeks of Hong Kong, Kowloon and Macau.
Fun on lantau. Giant Buddha, po Lin monastery, ngong ping and tai-0 fishing village.All great make sure get on the bus back from tai o, the taxis sometimes are an hour or more between trips.
Rainy day visit. The cablecar is not to be missed - visiting Big Buddah - though the view was marred by the rain.Organised trip that also took us to other points of interest.A good half day out.

It's worth coming back. We used the cable car going to this place. It was closed the last time I went here, unfortunately the temple of the lying buddha is under renovation today, I climbed up on the 249 step going to the Buddha temple which I failed to do the last time,,,, super cool!!
We totally enjoyed the place
Breathtaking... If visiting Hong Kong you must take a trip to Lantau Island and see the big Buddha, its size is breathtaking and a once in a lifetime experience.

Amazing Experience. A lovely cable car journey and a beautiful island, well worth a visit.It gets really busy here even mid week so I would suggest pre-purchasing your tickets on line that will save at least an hour waiting in line, we went for the glass bottom cable car and had to wait 2 hours in line once we had purchased the tickets, in our opinion isn't worth it, the glass on the base is pretty scratched.
go see. Beautiful place to visit. has quite a few stairs to climb to the Buddha but well worth the visit.stairs a little challenging but well worth the effort. Coming down easier for you.

I'd live here if I could. Beautiful beaches, beautiful mountains, beautiful people! I love this island. I'd live there if I got the chance, hop on the ferry to HK central to work / shop and coming back to this beautiful island would be so perfect. HAVE to take a trip here, definitely a must see!

Old school HK - so worth a visit. Hong Kong Island has very little history left amongst all the big buildings, so we took a Gray Line full day tour to Lantau and it was such a lovely day. A trip to the fishing village, a boat ride to the stilt houses, spotting pink dolphins and visiting the impressive Big Budda - such an excellent day trip. Lantau is definitely worth the bus ride and early morning!
Many things. you could visit many things in Lantau island and one important thing for sure Disneyland ,, plus there is a special village there ,, must visit really

Recent visit to HK. Back from a week's vacations in HK recently. Went to Lantau Island during my stay. Took a cruise from Central Pier # 7 to the Island and from the island ferry terminus took bus # 2 to get to the big Buddha and the NP village. Beautiful island indeed. Plus visiting the big Buddha is a must for any HK visit. Greatest disappointment was that the cable cars that take you to the NP village and big Buddha were closed for annual maintenance during my visit (they are closed from 2nd Sept for three weeks atleast). Anyone going to the island should definitely take the Cable car for scenic views (caution: if someone is afraid of heights, then better skip). A must place to go and spend a relaxing half day, away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Trip to Tai O. This is a wonderful little fishing village and is easily reached by ferry from central and then the local bus. Some of the houses on stilts remain and many of the traditional foods are still avilable

Great view.. We went early September which was unfortunate timing as the cable cars were closed for maintenance. The bus ride was not too bad though - a 35-min ride up. Only complaint is the seats are small. We climbed the 280-steps to the Big Buddha and the view was awesome - it was sunny and windy that day. Some relics were displayed in a no-photography section. We had the vegetarian lunch at HK117 each and the spread was really good. It is definitely worth a visit.

Amazing resto. The resto itself is amazing once u land right from Hong Kong central. I went with my friends and it was just amazing. A lil expensive. But its amazing.. Quite catchy. The restos are just at the sea side and u may choose what all you wanna have from the menu and enjoy the sea beauty. I would rather comment to be at the place with friends or as couples .. especially during evening.

i know because i live here. plenty to do in lantau; especially if you want to get away from hong kong's hustle. get to the tung chung plaza and get out of there asap. 2 easy things to do in lantau.1. big Buddha. either take the bus or ride the gondola (nongping 360) I'd recommend taking the bus up and riding the gondola (one way) down. line for it during the day are a bit silly.2. Beach. There are a few beaches on south lantau that are work visiting. so if you are coming from mui wo side or tung chung site have a gander at a map and figure out your bus route to a beach. Cheung Sha has a few nice restaurants attached to their beach. upper Cheung Sha is a beach that most likely you will have to yourself as few go to it. Pui O is a beach a lot of locals and expats go to because it has free camping and bbq plots on the beach. plus there's a little shop there to buy stuff (charcoal/ice/drinks/etc).
Serenity!. sadly we couldn't ride the Ngong ping 360..so we took a bus ride to Lantau. Lovely place... calm n peaceful compared to the city we just left behind!

FUN!!. We went to the Big Buddha and to Tai O and had a great time. We took a day trip from HK to Lantau. We were disappointed that the tram wasn't working but it enabled us to take the local bus. The road is extremely windy with switchbacks and curves so sit in the front if you get motion sickness. I was ok. The big Buddha was fun. We ate at the monastery (vegetarian lunch) which was just OK, as to be expected. They didn't have napkins so although we ate some food with our hands, we had no where to wipe them. We took the local bus to Tai O instead of heading back to HK. It is a small fishing villiage built on stilts over the water. Worth a visit if you are taking the bus. Probably not worth going out of your way if the tram is running.

Beautiful. Tropical beaches and gorgeous fishing villages, Lantau Island is not to be missed and well worth a day trip. Take your camera and enjoy exploring the character of the small villages and beautiful island coves.

Wonderful place in Hongkong. I like the MTR and all around Lantau. Maybe Disneyland is the famous icon for Lantau Island.. But, I think that before we arrived at Disneyland, there's a MTR station that the location is very wonderful. Maybe there's a lake/whatever. It's cool!

Highlight is Tai-o. As the title says, the most impressive place I went to was Tai-O. I took the bus to Tai-O first at about 9am and there was hardly anyone around. If you want to go back in time to see classic China, it's worth a look. I did the walk up the hill to the lookout to see if I could see the White Chinese dolphins and much to my suprise, I did! From Tai-O I took the bus to Ngong Ping and saw the big buddha. It was raining and we were in the clouds so I didn't see much but it was still pretty epic. I wouldn't recommend going inside the buddha as there is bugger all info in english so it was a waste of time for me. On the plus, you do get a free ice cream and water haha. The cable car was shut down for 3 weeks so had to bus back to the train station but they had extra buses going to compensate.

Nice day trip. On Lantau Island there is much to see and do. Go see the Big Buddha , Tai O fishing village, Ngong Ping cable cars, and the Po Lin Monastery. For serious shoppers there is an outlet mall by the cable cars. Allow yourself a full day to see as much as possible.

Peaceful island. Parts of the island have a resort feel. Suburban areas all filled with high rises. Discovery bay has good resturants. Doesnt feel like Hong Kong. $10 each for the bus to or from Tung Chung. Buses very easy to catch. You can pay cash or octopus.

Went to see the Big Bronze Buddha. The ride up there was just great in the 'crystal bottom' cable car. I kinda wish we would have came back down that way tho. Drivers here scare the daylight out of me coming back down that hugh mountain. The Buddha is ginormous and it faces China because that is the country that made it. We took a tour and it was good, probably better and cost effective because of the amount of energy you would spend trying to figure it out on your own. The small fisherman's village was quaint but not exciting unless you are from China or Hong Kong and are willing to eat what they have awaiting you.

Disneyland Adventure. No matter what your age is, Mickey Mouse will bring the child in you. HK Disneyland is located here in Lantau Island, a very nice place with a lot of smiles you can see. Aside from Hk Disneyland, there's a lot of Beach sites here in lantau where you and your family can have fun under the sun and swim in water. Very nice place.

The gondola is something not to miss. Fantastic experience not to be missed , but allow for a day out of your vacation , food ? well not my taste but hey we are in another country , traveling in the gondola was another exciting experience , all our trips were recommended by the Rhombus travel desk ,well done

Over the Water. From the trip via underground to the ride in the gondola over the sea, it was action packed for a pair of newbie holiday makers on the way home from China. It was the autumn festival time when we went across to Lantau and the crowd was amazing. The walk up to the golden buddha was worth every step.

An Enjoyable Day.. There is a lot to see on Lantau Island so you will need a full day. One of the most interesting attractions is the Giant Buddha which is just that - a giant statue with a museum inside. There is a mix of sightseers and sincere religious Buddhists.It is situated on top of a hill with wonderful views and down at ground level there are a number of interesting exhibits and restaurants.The long cable car ride is a great experience on its own. The glass floor of the cabin allows you to view the hiking trails below and as it takes you over the sea you can see many of the locals searching for seafood in the shallows. I would go again just for the cable car ride.
Good Morning Trip!. We traveled to Lantau by ferry and spent a good portion of the morning there. Big Buddah was a cool sight as well as the gondola ride down the mountain. Cool sights!
Cable car experience. Liked the cable car ride going to the big budha and see the shaolin monks perform their martial arts show.

A beautiful small little island. I am amazed by how many tourist this little island can attract. The queue was madness, maybe it is due to chinese new year. But stil,i think the visitors that visit this place, are more than the people staying in the village.There are some quite interesting food to try. It is definitely the best that i have eaten but i think if you go during off peak season, it would have been much better off.The day when we were there, the weather was just way too hot and it was a killer to wait and queue for the bus to get there....Would i come back again? Probably not, unless i go for dolphin trip.

Save a day for Lantau. Firstly, avoid summer months to have a sweat free run around the island. There are three must visit places in the island, Big Buddha, Disneyland and Tai O village. Take the tour package sold next to the cable car entrance. My suggestion is to go to Tai O village first with a bus ride. The tour also includes a boat tour in Tai O village where you can see fisherman houses, if you are lucky pink dolphins. then take another bus ( all bus tickets are included in package cost) to Big Buddha, stroll around and take the cable car(cable car ticket is also included) back to where you had bought the tour package. Take the metro to Disneyland from the nearby station, and spend rest of the day enjoying the rides.This route is time saving, cable car starts at 10 am, so you can start your trip earlier by bus to Tai O and avoid long Cable Car queue.

Don't miss Lantau and Big Buddha. Where you are staying in HK or Kowloon, take the underground to Lantau then take the #23 bus to the end of the line to see the giant outdoor sitting Buddha. It's a wonderful experience. When you're on bus line #23, you will sort of leave the city and climb up the circular high way to the top of the mountain to the Trappist Monastery. On the route with the locals, you will look down on FANTASTIC BEACHES and OUTSTANDING vegetation, AND along the road side you will see cattle grazing. IT'S THE BEST trip for simply the cost of transportation. Once you get to big buddha, take your time and take the set of 15 steps up to the big buddha. It will we the cleanest freshest air you breath anywhere in China and HK. It's a must! I was impressed to see the remarkable similarities between Christianity and Buddhism: the offerings of gold, mir and incense by the three female statutes. It's a great and must experience. If you have time wander in to Lantau village. Tame cattle roam freely. You shouldn't miss the paradox of high tech and ancient culture and rural live in a mega city setting. You WON'T BE SORRY!

Lantau Peak Sunrise Hike. Hiking the peak during the night to watch the sunrise is an amazing experience that will overload all your senses. It's not guaranteed you'll see the sunrise (I managed to get some rain instead...) but the hike is a journey you won't forget. You should do this hike with someone that knows their way, don't forget a torch, spare batteries and plenty of water as there is no way to replenish.More details at http://www.lifesauntering.com/2013/08/what-to-do-in-hong-kong-lantau-peak.html

Lovely tea room, plenty to do. The cable car is amazing, and higher than you think. Very well organised, though you do have to queue for a bit when it's busy. They seat people very well and considerately. At the top, there is a little tea room that gives a tea ceremony demonstration (can't remember the cost, sorry, but worth it and not expensive). The ladies running the shop are just lovely and the tea is good. There is also a kung fu display and little shops. Great walking around.

Beautiful Lantau. Starts with the cable car ride up to Lantau island, scenery along the way is beautiful. The giant Buddha on the hill is the biggest sitting Buddha. Took some snapshots even as we were approaching the island, you can see the Buddha from your cable car already. Many souvenir shops for you to do shopping and the Octopus card can be used in the convenient stores too. Spent a whole afternoon just walking, snapping photos and relaxing. The weather was fine too, slightly chilly though.

Disneyland Hotel & Park. Hong Kong Disneyland is the first theme park inside the Hong Kong Disneyland Resort and is the fifth Magic Kingdom-style park. Located at Penny’s Bay, Lantau Island.Come & experience the wonderful magical moments with your special ones in Disneyland

Location of Big Buddha. We took the Subway to Tung Chung Station and then stood in line for the Cable Car to Lantau Island. Great views of the airport, and Kowloon along the way. There was a small village of shops, and typical Chinese demonstrations and dances at the top also.

cool place. We visited there after the storm was over so it was very cloudy. the whole village was covered by thin fog which made it looks very dreamy. Plus the music played which reminds me of old Chinese films was pretty relaxing. Nice setting and arrangement too.

A must. You can get there by ferry, but best done by the skylift. It is part of the experience.Once you arrive, there is a "vending Village" that you go through. Think Starbucks etc and you're getting there.There are hiking trails which are worth thinking about. I did a bit of one and enjoyed it. There is more to Lantau than Big Buddha

Great place to be. So many things to do.. Took the MTR to Lantau Island and then the cable car to the Giant Buddha. I think 45min to 1hr over the island in a cable car was an amazing experience. And the sight of Giant Buddha was just great. Spent some idle time seeing the Buddha and Po Lin monastry.

Out of the world!. Lantau island is a far cry from the hubbub of urban Hong Kong. When I visited, it was overcast and mildly raining. In a way, it was hampering. But, to me, this climate made the Lantau island even more enchanting! I visited Ngong Ping village and Disneyland on Lantau

There is nothing much to this island other than the Airport. you can see the big sitting budha, visit the Disneyland or may be the expats residential and hangout the Junk Bay, but there is really nothing much to it unless you wanna visit the above. When you firstly arrived in Hong Kong, you are in Lantau Island.
Wonderful sights. I have been over to Lantau Island many times and always enjoy the cable ride up to the Big Buddha and then to catch the bus back down and seeing the sights on the way.

worth the money. Day trip, pick up at hotel with English speaking guide. first stop to walkway of HongKong film stars. Then a visit to an expensive and un-interesting jewellery factory and then to the Bronze Buddha via cable car ride, that's an experience itself and side trip to a fishing village on stilts with good local food.

An Enlightened Journey & Experience. Mention Lantau Island and the Big Buddha naturally comes to our mind. Climb 268 steps for a closer look at the serene appearance of the Big Buddha and immerse in the spectacular view of the surrounding mountain and sea views that can simply take your breath away. Elderly who are unable to climb the steps could take the free transport provided but do check for availability from the ticketing booth at the foot of the Big Buddha. Another not to miss in Lantau Island is Kwun Yam Temple, which is reachable via bus 21 from Ngong Ping bus terminal. Upon reaching the upper hall of the temple after a short climb, you are greeted with a magnificent sight of the ceiling, which is decorated with 10,000 small Buddhas. In the centre of the hall are 5 big Buddhas seated around in a circular altar. A word of cautious though, remove your socks before you start the climb as the wooden staircase could be a little slippery. Also, shutterbugs like me can keep your cameras away as photography is strictly not allowed here.If you want to see the charm of old Hong Kong, head off to Tai O Fishing Village which is a short ride on bus 21 from Kwun Yam Temple. Over here, you will find stalls selling dried seafood and small eateries serving bean curd, osmanthus jelly, cha kwo. Vegetarian dining is not a problem on Lantau Island, as both Po Lin Monastery near the Big Buddha & Kwun Yam Temple serves equally good vegetarian dishes, though I prefer the latter which is more simple yet tasty. Do take note that Po Lin Monastey's restaurant closes at 4:30 pm while Kwun Yam Temple's dining hall closes at 2pm. Start off the day trip early, catch the earliest cable car to Ngong Ping and by evening you would have attained an eye opener experience. This was in fact, our best & most enjoyable day trip during our 5 days in Hong Kong.
A Different Side to Hong Kong. Lush, green island with a lot of history to take in. Take a bus trip and climb the stairs to the biggest hand made bronze buddha.

Go during the weekday.. Please book your tickets online to avoid the 1 hour queue. Go early if you didnt book. Leave place at 4pm if you plan to go back by the cable car. Or else it will take you another hour of queue. We took the bus which was 45mins drive back to the cable car station. Only HKD27, HKD12 if it is a weekday.
The Mountain side of Hongkong. Mountain area of Hongkong, here you can find Big Buddha with cable car service, Disney land Resort & airport
Lantau Island. The Big Buddha is huge, there are 250 to 300 steps up to the tops, very peaceful place in the wisdom path.The cable car provides amazing scenery.

LOVED Lantau Island. Perfect was to spend an entire day! We took a bus to a fishing village that was AMAZING, had a boat ride and saw pink dolphins, then took another bus to the big Buddha and walked through the little shopping village. The we enjoyed an amazing cable car ride back down to the outlet mall, where we found some great deals.

time well spent.... we had included it in our 4 day stay after having read all the reviews here .... and we were not disappointed .... just start your day a little early and reach there by 9-9.30, even better if you can make it on a weekday like us.... take the cable ride at least one way (we took a return ride by crystal and standard car,$190 for two) .... once there leave for Tai O by bus, take a boat ride there for seeing the dolphins and after a strawl in the markets and a snack get back by bus to visit the big buddha, po lin monastery and then a nice post lunch walk along the path of wisdom .... we got back to our hotel after this by 4 for a couple of hours break before exploring the city in the evening, you can take your time and plan accordingly...

Peaceful. This was a nice place very different to the hustle and bustle of the city of Hong Kong itself.It was like a different world the boat trip was excellent and the boatman took us out to see the yellow dolphins which are extremely rare and I actually got a picture of them.A good way to see the island.The fishermen s homes were just so basic and looked extremely vulnerable being supported by what looked like cane stilts but the interesting thing is they came complete with television.

Lovely Lantau. A great day trip when staying in Hong Kong. Lots to see and do. The Big Buddha is very impressive - there are hundreds of steps up to the top. You might want to avoid the climb in the afternoon sun. The cable car provides amazing views and photo ops.

Up the Big Buddha!. I went to Hong Kong with my boyfriend, cousin and her boyfriend this past February for the second time in my life. This was my first time going to Lantau island. We went up the cable car and then climbed the stairs to the Big Buddha and purchased the ticket so we could go inside where you can see all of the old Chinese scriptures and also get an amazing view! It was truly an amazing experience especially being with my boyfriend and seeing his reaction to everything since this was his first time out of the US! I recommend purchasing the inexpensive ticket to go inside the Buddha. Not only are you donating to the site but you also get a good luck "quote" and ice cream at the end! Not a lot of money for an amazing experience!

Great view of the Giant Buddha. Climb up more than 300 steps up close to the Buddha under the hot sun. It was definitely worth the experience. It was calm and peaceful u there. Walk around the shops and you will surely buy something back.

Great view. Using the info i got from this web (thanks guys for your info), i take my brother and friends come here. They enjoy it very much. The view is amazing. We use bus to go this place, and use cable car when go back.

A heavenly place. We escape from the hectic pace of Hong Kong itself to the peace of Lantau. That may sound strange being close to the airport, but there is a magic to this place. There are many footpaths that you can follow, some more energetic than others. Two we would recommend would be from Discovery Bay follow the path to Mei Woo and Silvermine, a fascinating walk, take plenty of water and be prepared for some steep climbs. Or leave Tung Cheung and follow the Olympic trail over the island to Mei Woo. We always end our trip near the ferry and a beer and snack at the legendary China Bear. Then a ferry tip back to Central, or back to Discovery Bay, or bus to Tung Chung. Get one of the passes and visit the other sites to this get away destination.

Love Discovery Bay. Loved the cable car ride to the big Buddha, well worth the queues, the views were great and even saw a BA plane coming into land, and well worth the long steps up to the big buddha, amazing views, the whole thing is very nicely done

Take a tour. The "interest points" of Lantau Island are quite far apart from each other, with nothing in between. Easier to take a tour than wait for trains/busses/cable cars & ferries etc. Big Buddah = great, Monastery = interesting, Tai O Fishing Village = bit slummy, not picturesque, Cable Car ride = great fun (big queues, fast tracked on tour) walking trail underneath looked great, shops & cafes at end of cable car looked interesting but not time to look! And outlet shops at start of cable car not on our itinerary. loved the "wild" cows and fun ferry ride back to Central.

Amazing!!. I was in Hong Kong for 4 days and this was definitely the highlight of the trip.It was easy to get to, you don't have to worry about booking a tour, although you may prefer to do that. We didn't, we went by ourselves.We took the cable car to the island which I think at its highest point is 500m above sea level! The cable car journey in itself was a real highlight. I'm ok with heights but felt a little nervous as I queued up and saw cable cars in the distance. Really glad I didn't chicken out as you get to see some great views. You can even pay extra for a cable car with a glass floor if you're brave enough!When you get off the cable car you arrive at a really pretty area with some gift shops and places to eat.Then you can walk to the Tian Tan Buddha. There are many steps to climb to get to the giant Buddha but it is definitely worth it. It was a very humbling experience. There is also a small museum at the top. There is a fee, I can't remember how much but it wasn't expensive. The museum was OK we thought we may as well go seeing as we were at the top anyway but I don't think you'd be missing out on much if you chose not to go to the museum. If you are planning to go to Hong Kong then put a day aside for this.
nice island. i catched a MTR to reach here.and its a nice place to see.its a different part of hongkongpeaceful and relaxed.MTR is hugeand has lots of option for shopping and eating

From modern town to fishing village. It's worth the while to take a one day tour to this northern part of Lantau Island in Hong Kong. Take the MTR Tung Chung Line to Tung Chung which itself has a shopping outlet (Citygate Outlet) where you can shop half a day. But do go straight to the 360 Cable Car. Recommend buying tickets online to avoid waiting in the on-site ticket line (which is always very very long!) For thrill of the ride, buy ticket for the crytal cabin which has a glass bottom allowing you to see thing like in a bubble helocopter. On the way up and toward end of the cable car journey, you can see Macao on a clear day. Spend some time going up the great Buddha,visit the monestary, have vegetarian lunch there before heading for Tai O -- the fishing village.Going to Tai O is a 20-minute bus ride. There you can pay for a boat ride to see the pink dophins (with some luck). Walk through the small street towards the hillside and you'll find a cafe by the water where you can have a nice afternoon tea.Check the kai-to (small ferry boat) schedule. There is a 6:00 pm ferry back to Tung Chung. Enjoy the sun-set ride before having dinner in Tung Chung and finish off you day with late evening shopping.
Well worth the trip. Travelled on train and coach as cable car closed due to bad weather. Well worth the trip. Correct money required for coach up to monastery on Lantau island.
Unmissable. The Tian Tan Big Buddha on Lantau was the highlight of our trip. We took the Ngong Ping cable car to see it and then returned to Hong Kong via ferry. A perfect day!

Fab restaurants. This is authentic Hong Kong as it was in the past , a great gem. Take a boat out to one of the restaurants for a wonderful seafood meal with all the locals . The trip in the harbour with the Hong Kong skyline in amazing.

Largest Island in Hongkong.. This is where the airport is and the famous disney land lies.
lantau means a largest island. They have the Great Buddha and the Nong Ping 360 degrees cable car ride.

Great day out. Caught the MTR to Lantau Is. Didn't take long at all and so easy to use the MTR with your Octopus card. Decided to save money and not take the sky lift. The lady at the bus terminal directed us to which bus to catch to the Buddha. She advised not to use our Octopus card as it would cost more. For $35HKD we bought a bus ticket that took us to the Buddha and then down to Tao Fishing Village and back to the MTR. This took about 3 hours to complete. The Buddha was great to see. It was a 50 minute wait for the bus to Tao so we just waited at Starbucks and used their free wifi. The fishing village was fascinating to see. Nice day out

Mui Wo. If the city bustle is starting to get to you, take the ferry from Central Piers to Mui Wo on Lantau Island. It is a step to a more rural China. Once you are off the ferry you can walk to the right for about ten minutes along a pedestrianized promenade and come to a sandy beach, with a lifeguard and changing huts. If you want to be more adventurous, head to the hills on well marked trails and find the old Silver mine, from which the bay takes its name. A lot of Lantau is a country park with people still living traditional lives and restricted development. You can hire a bike or a bicycle rickshaw by the hour or half-day to take you a bit further and there is also a reliable local bus service serving the whole island.

Must do in HK. Visited back in 2008. The place is worth a visit and you need more than half a day to enjoy this attraction. the cable car ride to the island is fun. We took the one with glass bottom. Lots of eating options and small attractions on the island. A 100 percent touristy attraction and very kid friendly.

Great day trip. Lots to do, but I think the popular itinerary is to start at Tung Chung MTR then take the cable car up to see the temple and the Buddha, then take a bus to Tai O village where you can find some locals with small tour boats to take you out to see the pink dolphins! Great views from the cable car and the top of the stairs to the Big Buddah, along with some little souvenir shops in the town around the Buddah. But seeing the pink dolphins at Tai O was probably my favorite part!

it did not stop raining but it was fun. went for the budha, one can go from the shopping centre last stop before the airport on the metro line, and take a cable car, saves a lot of climbing. or go there by ferry from Hk island and take a taxi to the monastery - soak up the good athmosphere there, away from the hussle and bussle of HK city , even with the soaking rain it was fun to do, a real advisor for your HK trip

Buddha, Fishing Village and Shopping. You will need a full day to enjoy Lantau Island. Go to Tung Chung on the MTR's Tung Chung line, take bus no. 23 or the cable car. There are combination tickets (cable car and bus) available.Continue your trip to Tai O. It's a traditional fishing village and a nice contrast to the buzzling city. Take a boat to view the pink dolphins to make your day perfect.

Good way to spend a day. Take the Ngong Ping cable car over from Tung Chung Town Centre. Get the Crystal car if you're not afraid of heights and get ready for a very scenic ride over to Lantau.There are lots of souvenir shops and restaurants. You can also walk over and climb the stairs to the Big Buddah and rub his feet for good luck... if you can find the stairs up to it!
Just a short boat trip away or travel by land. Just a short boat trip away or travel by land. Great place to get away from the busy shopping areas and get some fresh air and peace.

Big Buddha. We visited this icon in 2002 and found it to be a great experience. There were many many people there. The walk up the steps is a long haul, but enjoyable.
On the whole Lantau is a beautiful island and the trip is very worthwhile.
I l u v Hong Kong.

highly recommend if you're in HK. the giant buddha alone is enough of a reason to visit Hong Kong!
The island is very picturesque.
Take a cable car for awesome views (even in the rain)
What a trip. Try the cable car, amazing ride especially in the glass bottomed cars. Take the MTR from town which is also worth it.
RAIN. We were here in July. It was beautiful, but it was raining constantly. Visit Tai O, it is worth the trip.

Must Visit for the Big Buddha and Cheap Souvenirs. Great Place with many things to offer. The cable Ride with stunning views of Airport and Surroundings, the Majestic Sitting Buddha, the Entertaining Live Martial Arts Show were my favorites. Enjoyed the place as it seemed to have the least amount of tourist in Hong Kong and gave a feeling of Serenity. Unfortunately due to rains the Buddha was covered in clouds. The Monastery was also under renovation so missed seeing the architect. Do plan a Lunch visit so you can indulge yourselves to some local monastery cooked vegetarian food. Wisdom Path Looked Great but was a disappointment as the wordings were in local language.Best to visit when you are near the Airport as will save time in travelling. Locker Rental Facilities are available. Book your tickets for the cable car in advance or be prepared to be waiting for 30 minutes for ticketing and then about 10-20 minutes to get into the cable car.This place had the best souvenirs shops in HK. The prices are cheaper and of better qualities then those found in Temple Street/Lady's Market

Buddah worth the trip!. With the exception of the majority of this island being a GINORMOUS tourist trap, but Buddah was very very cool. The line to get on the cable car was also very long, so I would recommend getting there as early as possible or towards the end of the day. We got in line around 10:00am, and it was around a 2 hour wait. I wouldn't bother doing any of the other "attractions" they offer, because as I stated, it's all just one big tourist trap surrounding the actual reason for visiting, the Buddah.

A lot more to do than expected. From Tai O to the Big Buddha, this island packs a lot. It is a bit tough to get from point A to point B (mostly coast driving), so add more time than you might have thought to visit it, but it's well worth the trip.

ISLAND GREAT BUT NIGHTMARE WAIT FOR CABLE CAR. Please read carefully if you go here. If you really want to experience the long cable car ride then do it this way. Firstly you need to go very early about one hour before opening time and even then expect to wait a while. Or better still take a number 11 bus from Tung Chung mtr station to go to the Fishing Village of Tai O. You get to tung chung via the orang line from central mtr. Journey time about 30 mins and can be quite busy.the Fishing village is quaint and well worth a visit, not touristy at all as it remains as in olden days. Locals are friendly and you can sit on one of the wooden balconies overlooking the river and enjoy a cool beer or try homemade doughnuts from the local bakery. Locals are friendly and there are plenty of good toilets. Take a boat ride of about 20 to 30 mins out to see to look for the pink dolphins and even if you do not see any it is a nice trip for 20hkd.Then take bus 21 to the top of the mountain to see the Buddah etc. buses run frequently and it is nice trip of about 25 mins. If you do the trip this way round you will be the opposite to all the tour groups and you should find it quieter and easier in the heat.At the top it is all free, some karate type demos and other things to do and lots of nice shops and places to eat not to mention the fab views. the Buddah is impressive and it is free to climb the steps to get up close. At the top there is a museum and it is only a few hkd to enter. There is also a temple but it is under huge reconstruction but still worth a free visit.When you are finished you can go down by cable car at leisure and no queues usually. A single trip is about 95hkd. return is 135. Do not bother with the crystal cabin with the extra charges as there is only forest beneath you.There are various tours offered but they cost at least double what we paid and we did all plus maybe more than the tour groups at less than half the cost and we did not have to worry about meeting times etc.if however you want to travel cable car both ways and maximise your time then DO a tour as you get on the able car much much quicker. We had to queue for 2 hours and 20mins and had almost collapsed in the heart by then time our turn came. if we had been correctly advised about the waiting time we would have definitely paid the extra. there are waiting time signs but you can ignore them as they are in no way accurate. As you reach the ticket office do not get excited as you will have at least another 80 mins to wait.It is a full day out and well worth a visit though.
privileged to enjoy the views from the cable car. It's best to go here via the cable car and enjoy the view. It's so peaceful up there. I liked the scenery very much.
Big Buddha!. The climb up to the Big Buddha is worth the effort.Great views from the top. We went by bus from the city. You can go by boat too.

Worth a visit. Definitely enjoyed riding in the cable car, the views are spectacular. I liked that you can experience both riding on a glass bottom cable car when you go up to Lantau and on the way back you can just go on a normal one. Definitely worth a visit.
great island. there is a outlet mall near (great for shopping) see the giant Buddha, visit the temple / monastery and try the ngong ping 360

A pleasant surprise!. A lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. The cable car is fantastic! It's the longest and most exhilarating ride I have had - beautiful. Allow a couple of hours at least to wander around and explore the area.

Worth it for the journey. Riding the cable car to the island provides breathtaking views of the whole area. The statue at the top is pretty impressive and ther are plenty of places to eat, drink, shop or just take stunning photos.

walks and general. there are walks to be done all over the island, with some great sign postings to help you along the way. Some sstart from Silvermine Bay, others from Cheung Sha etc. I lived in HK as a child and my dad used to always take us for a 'hike' around Lantau. There are many different walks, taking in the scenery, the ocean, the water buffalo, tending the fields. A great escape and beautiful views. Im sure that online or at the tourist info you can find a list/map of all the walks. Everytime i go back (approx every 2-3yrs) i always take in a walk either on Lantau or Cheung Chau Island

Luscious Lantau. The cable car was a fabulous way to see the island, not least because one could see all the walks/walking tracks available below to keep for future reference! The views were spectacular, culminating in the first sighting of Buddha - something I will not forget. (My only suggestion would be to try and visit early morning; we went around lunch and the queque, and the consequent wait, was very long).......

Impressive cable car trip to see Buddha. The cable car ride was long and impressive. The village at the top interesting to walk around and prices not too bad. Worth the walk up the two hundred and something steps to see the Buddha and the views. Taoi o was disappointing. Just a fishing villages with hous on stilts but nowhere really to done or rest. Outlet mall on Lantau island very disappointing as prices still extraordinarily expensive but there is a cinema there and the restaurants and food court were good. Rating is based on the cable car trip rather tha the other Lantau Island attractions.

My Paradise. I cannot forget you dear Lantau island. I always remember you and miss you and dreaming all those days that i spend with and in you. The lantau island is huge and green. It has big Rocks and beside a great pacific ocean. God give all necessary beauty in it during invent. It has the main airport, HongKong INT APT on the pacific ocean. A big Bronze Buddha you can watch it from Aircraft during landing in APT. It is filled with lots of good pepole, lots of posh and budget hotel, various mall, food court, Big Buddha. Airport itself have all necessary for your needs. A metro rail system different no public buses for city and frequent taxi is available here. I cannot express even i write a story but you see a huge airport with lots of different plane, different people during eating, a big cathay pacific and dragon air town and also pacific ocean is running close to you .Lots of beaches.Just chill and enjoy the heaven.
Great for a day. Very good....spent a whole day there with 7 yo daughter and could have gone back for another day easily!

Awesome for panoramic pictures!!!. Had just a short crisp visit to it, just before leaving hong kong. The views from NP360 were just breathtaking, hills, crevices, mini waterfalls and the giant Buddha statue too! Got a bit too touristy with all those overpriced souvenier shops on top, near the Buddha statue. The visit to Po Lin Monastery was worthwhile and the vegetarian food they served was tasty too!

This got to see cause its a hong kong landmark. I enjoyed the trip up here. The only bad thing i would have to say bad about this place is that they are westernizing the place by adding these stupid franchise stores that did not exist before. One thing i would have to say is save your appetite and eat at the famous vegetarian restaurant when you make your way up to the buddha.

Beautiful. Easy to get there, pray it's not windy! Bit hectic when it is. Beautiful views on the way up and down.The whole place is lovely, some pretty shops. We had lunch there too at one of the many places, cheap and tasty. The climb to the big buddha is a bit of a trek but has an amazing view and perfect for photo's.
Serene and spiritual. Beautiful trip by ferry, tranquil and great food. People take daily trips; this place is so rich in history.

Half day tour. It requires 3 -4 hours including the ride. We used the metro. It is very well connected.Cable car ride is a must... do not miss it. We cldnt go to the fishing village, it started to rain as there was a signal 3 warning for rain . came back in bus from the big budda .the outlet mall is the MTR , food court is good :) but the price isnt .... Lovely veg food at the Po Lin Monestry in the top. A MUST VISIT
The big Buddha. Come early to avoid the crowds. Great view and impressive statue. The cable car ride is fantastic in the crystal car. Don't be scared you won't fall.

Worth the time but be prepared for the long walk physically!. We left from our hotel at 12 noon via mtr and reached ngong ping cable car by by 12:30. We waited for an hour to get out tickets. We did not buy online because we didn't know what time we would reach the station. And it was worth the wait. We took the crystal cabin and we saw a complete 360 view. Up ,down and sides. It was pricey. Check it out on their website. Pls buy to and fro tickets. The return queue was just as long. As we went higher and higher we saw the airport, jungles, mountains and also the majestic tall buildings which HK is famous for. The ride took about 20-30 min I think. And when u see the Buddha then u know you are almost reaching the top. You will be bombarded with pictures and souvenirs of pictures they took of you earlier inside the cable car.The were air islets inside the cable car which ventilated it very well. But our journey downward was hot.Just a reminder the cable car closes at 6pm. And you can get busses from the top. The big Buddha requires 200 plus steps to reach there. Once u reach there u get a bird eye view of the mountains around. But there is a small fee to go all the way inside the statue. Which is not worth it. I don't remember what I saw.We skipped on the poh Lin monastery and tea house due to time constrain. Food shops were abundant. We are at ebeneezar and the food was good. Overall u need to walk a lot and bring along water. It's expensive there. Ps- china Summer holidays start on the 1st July. You will see the highest crowd during the holiday period.

Nothing spectacular. This is okay if you just want to get away from the city for an afternoon but it's basically just an expat area with expensive cafes. I would recommend one of the real Chinese islands if you are sight seeing.

fun day trip. you can easily spend a day on the island. We were lucky enough to have my boyfriend's family take us around and it was a very fun day trip. The Buddha was nice, there are some steps to take to get to the top. The lift to go all the way up was very nice as well. We went on a nice day so you got to see pretty far as well. The lift with the glass bottom was more expensive but i honestly don't think its worth it because there's not much to look at besides trees and water looking down and you can already see those as the cabin moves up. Definitely suggest going to Tai O the fishing village though. Very good experience and its very different from city life so i definitely appreciated that. Don't really need to go tour or find someone to lead the way if you've done research before hand. Everything was pretty easy to get too but of course we had the leisure of not doing any research because my boyfriend's family took us there.

Great memories from Hong Kong. You should save one full day to visit the island.We arrived there by taking the cable at Ngong Ping 360 and having a spectacular view over the bay, then once arrived on the plateau we visited Po Lin Monastery, we looked to the biggest bronze statue of Budha and we took a trip to Tai O fishing village.Tai O is preserving the way of living of the traditional fishermen in an old village. You can walk through the village, you can take a boat to see the fishermen houses on the water, you can buy salted or dry fish or many other specific sea food from the open market.You will have in the end an unforgetable day.
lantau day trip well worth the visit. a great day trip with lots to see and do. the Big Budda was a fantastic visit and the cable car ride back was fabulous

Amazing round trip. Go by Skyrail, which is fantastic fun with great views across hong kong & surrounding landscape. Save queues by buying your tickets at the travel desk in your hotel. Buy a combined ticket at the bottom of the steps up to the Buddha for entrance and lunch. They offer you lunch OR an ice cream & water. Lunch is probably the best deal as you get to eat in the vegetarian restaurant by the monastery. We walked back down the mountain, it is very hot and quite steep in places but well worth it. At the bottom there's a bus stop with a regular service back to the main station to get you back to Hong Kong. This whole trip all takes about 4-5 hours, not be hurried as it's all amazing.

Great excursion. This is a great day out on the cable car to see the wonderful big Buddha. The views from the cable car are amazing. We did not get the crystal ie see thru bottom and did not regret. Highly recommend .

Try to get to Tai O, little fishing village. We took the ferry to Mui Wo, which conveniently has a bus stop as soon as you exit the ferry. We had a very comfy bus ride through lush valleys up to the little traditional fishing village on an estuary. Small and walkable, but walk through until you find the "old police station" which has been on a point of land out there for 100 yrs...but has been remodeled into a luxury hotel? Very friendly staff, and worth a look around, especially seeing photos of it "before". Good lunch (hot pot with eggplant and pork) before getting bus (every 30 minutes) back to Mui Wo. Had much-needed ice cream from the little shops by ferry/bus area.

Excellent day out. We did a tour which meant we did not have to wait in a long line for lift etc. the Buddha and mines try lunch were positive experiences as was the visit to fishing village. The 25 minute ride in the sky lift was wonderful

Different, liked the temple. I found the main of Lantau island a bit fake (understatement) but the giant Buddha and the temple was great. I feel they have tried to ver commercialise the Buddhist retreat which was really unnecessary. I wouldnt go to see the village, but the views from the cable cars were great, we paid for a crystal cabin as the waiting took forever and this line moved quicker.

worthwhile experience. Taking the cable car to the great Buddha is a worthwhile experience. Pay a bit extra for the glass bottom car - unique experience. The top terminal lets you out at a mini Buddhist "disneyland" and a short walk leads to the temple and the hike up steps to the big Buddha

Very good one-day trip... C1 ( 2013.06.18 ) My one-day trip course.. After arriving airport.. 1. gnong ping 360(cable car).. 2. gnong ping village.. 3. Big Buddha.. 4. Po Lin Monastery.. 1~4. same area.. 5. Tai O.. 6. Disneyland.. This Schedule was my one-day trip to enjoy Lantau islnad.. I'm very satisfied with my schedule and recommand if you enjoy Lantau..

3-in-1. You will find HK's international airport here. So as HK Disneyland and Ngong Ping 360. I've been to Disneyland. I have yet to try Ngong Ping on my next trip.TIP: I suggest that you take the bus (in the morning) from the airport to Central. It's going to be a 40-min ride but you will be able to see a different HK. Nice to pass by tunnels :)

From Disney to Buddha!. I like Lantau because of the variety of available experiences. One MUST visit the largest seated Buddha in the world! From Disney, to Mui Wu, Tai O, Ngong Ping--take your pick, you won't be disappointed.

An amazing day.. When you are visiting Hong Kong make sure you allocate a day to go out to Lantau island. It is easy to get connecting trains from Kowloon via the MTR. Once there make your way to the cable cars. It is a pleasant trip across to Lantau Island, if you can afford it , go for the glass bottom car, as you will some beautiful sites. In addition, take up the option to go to the fishing village. It is educational if you have kids for them to see how other families live. I know my daughter was very appreciative after we left. All the people in the village and on the island are friendly. We went there on a foggy day and I believe it added to the mystical nature. Climb up to see the Buddha. It has around 270 steps, but well worth it and if my 65 year old mother can do it, so can you. My only real advice ladies is to try and not shop at the great outlets before you go to the island, as it is pain to carry your shopping. Although, for the Australians you can pick up great guess handbags for half the price we pay here.

Great way to spend half a day. We took a ferry to Lantau Island as we stayed near In Sheng Wan this time round. Trips to Lantau Island is pretty frequent. Adult ticket is about hkd 40 and for child 20. It was quite a leisurely ride on the ferry. In less than an hour we reached Lantau island.Following that we took a bus to see the Big Buddha. Cost us about hkd67 for two adults and a child. The ride on the bus is very scenic. Get to see the way of life of people on Lantau island and the beach. But be prepared it is a pretty long ride. About 45 mins before reaching the Big Buddha. The Big Buddha is our highlight for the day. Really magnificent. You can see the Buddha from a distance. It is pretty crowded at the Big Buddha and can be a bit cooling at times. Walking up to see the Big Buddha was fun. If you wish to go into the Big Buddha to see the exhibits and the highest point in the Buddha, you can get entry by just purchasing the vegetarian lunch coupon. The vegetarian lunch cost hkd78 for the basic one and about low of hkd 100 plus for the luxury version. Personally I felt in terms of food, the basic and the luxury version did not make much difference to me as I have tried both versions before. Just that the luxury one is a little bit more exclusive. Seating is a little more comfortable.The vegetarian food is eaten in the monastery. Found quite a pleasure to walk in the monastery. Find it to be peaceful. Before leaving, we had the hand grounded soy beancurd. It is very fine and nice. You can find the shop near the entrance of the monastery.We left Lantau Island by taking the Ngong Ping 360 cable car. It is a fun ride. Pretty long ride too. About hkd400 plus if I don't remember wrongly for 2 adults and 1 child.
My favorite. Lantau Island was my favorite part of HK! The mountains, tram and hiking are superb. I would recommend visiting the Big Buddha as well as the Wisdom Path and the hiking trails!

Nice Cable Ride to the Island. Great Cable ride to the island. Sadly we had to share a car with two tourist who were more bothered about taking photos of themselves and were a pain to sit with. The view was nice, the Island was a nice change but there is not much to it.

Spectacular views and stroll in Tai O fishermen village. Reach Lantau Island by MTR ( end of orange line ) A few steps from there you catch the Ngong Ping Cable Car( ~ 170 HK $ both ways ) . If you pay 30 HK Dollars more you will get a car with glass floor and you'll be able to see the fantastic view under your feet : mountains and sea .It worth the money !! After some 20 minutes you will arrive to the BIG BUDDHA that is situated in a small comercial village . From there you can take a bus to a small typical fishing village called TAI O . There you will stroll in the market and have a boat tour to the sea-between the very primitive terraces surronded by water - those terraces are part of the fishermen houses. Go back to Ngong Ping Village and after visiting the Buddha take the Cable Car down.If you are looking for OUT LET Shopping there is one just before you catch the MTR back to Honk Kong.It is a all day tour that will bring you to the old, humble and original chinese living way and to spectacular views .

Good to make your own way to Big Buddah and back. A very good day out can be had by taking the ferry then bus/ taxi to the big Buddah site followed by the cable-car then subway ride back for a complete and relatively cheap circuit .Pick the right day and the view from the statute itself is stunning as is the one from the cable car and a good way to take a break from the equally stunning but contrasting view of the Hong Kong city skyline.

must see. If in Hong Kong this should be a must see. Make sure on a hot day to take water as the steps up are a killer however once at the top there is a shop selling drinks and ice creams. Pictures do not do this place justice

A "must see" place.. Visiting this largest of HK islands allows you to see the contemporary and the old: from fishing villages,cable cars, airports, disney, to the giant Buddha: well worth a trip there.A fascinating island with its own changing culture. Loved it!

3 experiences Tao O, Big Buddha and cable cars. I went over via ferry, got at Central pier; walk through IFC 1 building. Buses are well marked once u arrive on Island. Go to Tao O, an old fishing village where once people live in their boats (boat people). It is rustic and unusual. It was a low-keyed experience that was welcomed from the frenzy of HK. Took a bus to Big Buddha from Tao O and then took the cable cars back to Kowloon. All can easily be done in a day. Even on a week end it wasn't crowded.

Visiting Buddha via Skyline. Cable car to the village and the actual area around the Buddha and monastery. Didn't particularly like the number of commercial outlets and souvenir shops in the village.To avoid the crowds get to skyline station before 10am

Worth the visit. My friend and I only visited the main village and the Great Buddha because we were scheduled to go to Disneyland in the afternoon. I think if we had more time, we would've explored the other attractions as well.If you're only visiting for the Great Buddha, I think it's already worth your trip. You had to climb a certain amount of stairs to reach the top but when you get there, the view is breathtaking. Although it'd be hard to take decent photos because there are many tourists. If you can explore the island with the perfect weather - not so hot not so cold no rain - it'll be a hassle-free enjoyable trip.There are cheap small food stalls where you can buy Chinese foods, water, and ice drops, in case you get hungry/thirsty while walking.
Big Brass Buddha. really nice to see this Giant Buddha. you have to climbs many stairs to visit the Buddha but it is definitely well worth it!

Visit Lantau island for Buddha and the cable car ride. Also has some great wetland. Beaches ok too. Loved the giant Buddha and the cable car. Old stilt houses nothing special and beaches ok. Take the ferry from Hong Kong to make it interesting and come back via Cable car. Wetland good for birds.

Wonderful Day.... It is a wonderful experiences traveling in Lantau Island...Nothing much to see though...They will take you to Cheung Sa Beach, which is very quiet and not so many people there... And than to Tai O Village, to see the stilt houses and experience some local fishmarket... And after that they will take you to the Big Buddha, Po Lin Monastery, Ngong Ping Village...There is also Disneyland Hong Kong at Lantau Island...

Not to be missed if you're in Hong Kong. Fantastic experience, from the cable car passing through the clouds to the Giant Buddah itself.A bit disappointed with the choice of food & beverage at the top.

Hongkong Disneyland. Disneyland is on the Lantau Island about a 20-30 minute train ride from kowloon or hongkong island. Only went to Disneyland when in Lantau aside from the Airport. Disneyland although the smallest was still very enjoyable. Waiting time for rides at the most were 30 minutes. Even then, line moved quickly. Food and drinks pricey so be prepared to spend most of your money on that. Musicals were fantastic! Enjoyed every one of them. This Disneyland was truly suited for my one year and toddlers. Was disappointed that there was no splash mountain. Because of its small size, I was able to finish Disneyland in one day. Fireworks show still magical!

A lovely day out. We took the cable car to the Big Bhudda. The crystal cars have glass bottoms which are great fun. The Buddha is a lovely place to visit and you get a very cheap ticket to go inside which also includes a free bottle of water and ice-cream (or some noodles at the temple site). One can't complain about the value of that. Once we were done there, we went to Tai O on the bus. Tai O is known as Hong Kong's little Venice. It is a fishing village where the locals live in stilted houses over the water. I would have liked to have spent more time there as it is interesting and has a certain charm. We had a nice relaxing boat trip for only 20 HK dollars (though we didn't get to see the famous pink dolphins). Lots more to do on Lantau Island so it is recommended by me for a good day out or even a stay-over.

Spectacular Cable Car Ride. A 30 minute subway ride from Kowloon (after changing trains) drops you off at the cable car station. The 6 km (4 mile) cable car ride over the green mountains, a couple of waterfalls and views of the airport brings you to the monastery and the largest bronze Buddha in the world. It is touristy and kitschy and feels like a theme park rather than a monastery. Also there are long lines at both ends (we spent over 1 1/2 hours in line while returning) and it is quite expensive. But the cable car ride is definitely worth it.

vegetarian food. A truly enjoyable experience, food at the monastery was excellent for vegetarians. Tried my hand at chop sticks unsuccessfully. Young monks staged a mock drill with sticks and drums on the rain drenched floor in front of the magnificent Buddha!

A Great Activity in Hongkong. When you talk about Hongkong , shopping always comes to your mind . By visiting Lantau Island your trip to Hongkong becomes a little different and adventurous , exciting and unforgettable . The thrill starts with riding the cable car , the crystal cabin in particular . It allows you to see what's down under ,the sea below , the mountain ranges , thick forests , trails and fantastic view of the vast airport . As you traverse and meet other cable cars , it gives you the great feeling of flying and on top of the world , conquering its awesome beauty . As you approach Lantau Island , you will see the Great Buddha and as you get nearer , you would love to take more pictures and could not wait to disembark and climb to him to get a closer look .Climbing the steps was worth it , it was a good exercise under the scorching sun and a good form of sacrifice too . Even if you belong to a different religion , you will feel the sanctity of the place and outmost respect for the people who especially visit the place out of faith .Pls bring a cap or an umbrella , towel and lots of water to hydrate you while you explore the place. Do not forget your sun glass . Trip back was via the cable car again . This time , no more picture taking but everyone was busy looking and reviewing the great pictures taken with the Great Buddha and souvenir cable photos . If you have not seen Lantau Island , you have not seen Hongkong . Go for it !

Cable car, big Buddha, monastery, beach abd pink dolphins . Cable car, big Buddha, monastery, beach and pink dolphins . Exectly in this prder, and. my experience was awesome!! When you're approaching cable car entrance, to your right some agency sells package tickets that includes cable car+ one day bus pass+ boat ride . They give you map and bus schedule.  It is indead cheaper, and well thought out tour.  I used apps from HK government tourism office, to get hints, routs and explanations. Was quite useful as well Sent from my iPhone

Excellent view from skyline. After an hour of queue, sitting the cable car to Poh Lin monestary is fantastic. The view is great. Can go up the Giant Buddha for a visit and pay HK30 to get a free drink or 'tau fu fah' + dessert + fried meehon at the Poh Lin monestary. It is worth of every single penny.

So different from Honk Kong. Great tour run by a local guide. Visited the local fishing village population 2600. Still living a very simple but happy lives. So different to the busyness of Honk Kong and the surrounding islands.

Glad i did it. I'm glad we took the ferry and bus to Lantau and the cable car back as the lines at the cable car on the other side was really long. Next time hiking on Lantau which looks like its got great trails

nothing much to see. not really worth the trip to go to this lousy island with it's over priced and underserved restaurants and non-smiling habitants, but i know some people who prefer to stay there while they are in hong kong on bussiness, and not in the big busy ugly city. personally i am disgusted iqually from this island and the hong kong city. both are over crowded and empty places.

the Big Buddha is awesome. We took a Celebrity shore excursion to Lantau Island to see Nong Ping Village and the Big Buddha. The ride up to the village was very scenic. Unfortunately the cable cars were under repair that day so we did not have that experience. The shopping village is charming and all the storekeepers and friendly and helpful. The Buddha is massive and very impressive. We did not walk the nearly 300 steps to the top but the views from the bottom were excellent. This is a must-see sight for a visit to Hong Kong.
Fun day out!. We caught the ferry from pier 6 and the number 2 bus from Mui Wo to the base of big buddah, The buddah is spectacular but the "village" is worth a miss

Traditional Indigenous Fishing Village. We visited Lantau Island on an official visit for work. However we used the opportunity to visit one of the local fishing villages. The markets here were great and we ate at a local Chinese restaurant - very cheap and very good food. You can visit the Golden Buddha while you're there but it was very hot and humid and we elected to pass. Lantau Island is easily accessible by train from Hong Kong.
Nice place. apart from cable wait time, everything else was ok. Avoid the kebab and Pizza restaurant in the Village.
Pretty and spectacular. I'd love more time to explore the natural wonders of the fun packed island. Home to Ngong Ping and Disneyland. Magic!

Big Buddha. Good bus service from all over to Lantau Island, take the standard cable car, crystal not worth the price, get there early to avoid the crowd, once up there lot of picture ops, eat at subway if indian since few of the staff are indians there & they know chicken, other chinese hotels language can be a big problem & may be end up with Bow Bow...

Great to get out of the city!. Enjoy a pleasant ferry ride to this fishing village-- but be aware there is a huge energy plant on the far side of the island. You don't really see it until your near the harbor or up on the hike from one town to the other. The nice things is that both towns have ferries leaving frequently! Tasty fish restaurants line both ports where you pick out exactly the fish you want to eat-- straight from their fish tanks. The towns have some tourist shops but being outdoors and having a brisk hike is wonderful

Best Island in Hong Kong. Everyone goes to Hong Kong Island. Most people go to Kowloon. But Lantau has plenty to see, do and eat for better prices.The MTR and Airport Express can get you there in minutes, and if you go round trip on the same day, you only pay for one way on the Airport Express.Besides Disneyland and the airport, Lantau has some great food at Discovery Bay and the giant Buddha, which is very easy to get to from the Tung Chung MTR stop.Lantau also has some of the best beaches in Hong Kong (on the days when the water quality is not hazardous) and the most popular nude beach (not legally, of course).

a different day out. Take the ferry to Mui Wo and then go my bus from Mui Wo you get to see the country side. You can go to Big Budda or Tai O Village.It is very reasonable prices but you need the correct money on the bus or an octopus card You can also take a cable car from Big Budda to Tung Chung and then the MTRback to central

A breath of fresh air. It was a nice change from the congested busy Hong Kong life. Our plan was to try different modes of transports, MTR, Cable Car Ride, Bus Ride down to the Ferry station, Ferry back to Hong Kong Island. Took the MTR to go to Tung Chung. Get tickets from the ticket office at the Ngong Ping cable car station. Took the crystal car cabin, single ride for the experience and a shorter line queue. It was a cool and memorable experience. Visited the large Buddha and Po-Lin Monastery.Then took the bus down to Mui-Wo and took the ferry back to Central Hong Kong. The ferry ride itself was another way to seeing the busy ports of Hong Kong.TIP: It is useful to have the octopus card which can be used on the MTR, New Lantau Bus and the Ferry. Saves time and hassle looking for change for fares.Advice: If you are going in December, it tends to be rainy, windy and cold. So it is helpful to have a raincoat or small umbrella with you.

A couple of nights in Lantau - ideal way to unwind after/before visiting Kowloon and/or Hong Kong islands. A great place to shop, experience a different facet of Hong Kong and seeing the Big Buddha and the pink dolphins at Tai O Village were undoubtedly the highlights.

Buddha. On Lantau Island is a large Buddha. You can go by cable car. This was very cool. When you reach the top, you have to walk a bit. Then you see the huge standing Buddha. This is very nice. You can make beautiful photos of it.

Take the skyrail to the Big Buddha. Other than the airport, not strictly on Lantau but Ckek Lap Kok island, we made two trips to Lantau, Disney and the fantastic Skyrail, the longest cable car in the world, to the Big Buddha.Take the MRT to Tung Chung on Lantau and make the short walk on the covered raised walkway to the Skyrail station. It seems quite expensive, but this is an engineering marvel, We queued for about 15 minutes, but judging by the queuing areas, this wait must get much, much longer at busy times. It was raining with low cloud when we took the cable car. As each car arrives, workers board the car and completely clean windows, hand rails, seats and floors before new passengers enter.The cable car soars out of the cable car station and over a narrow part of the strait between Chek Lap Kok Island and Lantau, then over a wide section of water and then rises to the largest cable car pylon in the world. The views are spectacular, even in the rain. The cable car crosses Hong Kong National park, so the fewest possible pylons were allowed during construction by the Swiss company that built the Skyrail. The journey takes about 25 minutes and after clearing the 'monster pylon' the Big Buddha becomes visible as the cable car crosses the beautiful National Park. Stunning views of the airport can also be had, as we climbed an Airbus A380 came into land.Once at the end of the journey you are just a short walk from Po Lin monastery and the Big Buddha, the biggest statue of Buddha in the world. By now the sun was shining and the skies had cleared. We had planned to take the bus and ferry back to Hong Kong, but we spent so much time at Po Lin, that my wife, a lifelong cable car hater, was forced to endure the return journey by cable car, this time in beautiful sunshine with views over the stunning coastal scenery towards the South China Sea. For Disney, just get off the MRT one stop earlier than Tung Chung at Sunny Bay and take the Disneyland Resort Line, the train is in itself worth the ride, even for those not raised as Disney Babes.
definately a must visit. If you go to HK especially with kids, do plan a trip to lantau island. The cable car ride was great fun and the view from the top with the Buddha statue was breathtaking

Amazing!. The ferry over to Lantau is very nice and highly recommended! Took around 1 hour. The Biddha is awesome and well worth a visit, and the little village is very nice. The Crystal Cabin down is such a cool experience as well!

nice & peaceful place. if you want to go here, please go early in the morning before 4.30pm.
I love taking the bus up rather than the cable car

Ngong Ping 360 -Great day out.. Great day out, easy to get to the Cable Station by train. Don't be fooled and buy tickets from the skalpers at the bottom of the stairs, wait until you get to the top and there is a ticket office up there. We bought the Sky-Land-Sea day pass, which included a boat trip visiting the Tai O still houses. The walk up to the Buddah is a challenge and the bus trip provides an exhilarating ride up the mountains and around the island. We loved the Vegeterian lunch at the Monastery.

day out to Lantau. Apart from large crowds on our day [Saturday] creating long lines for cable car it was a brilliant value for money event. Personally don't like heights but soon forgot on seeing best views of area, scenery and Buddha.

Golden Buddha shrouded in fog. Caught the 25 minute cable car (Aus $200 up to the stop . The whole top was covered in fog and gave it a wintery ski country feel. lots of shops and eateries lined the paved path to the Buddha. be prepared for steep step climb up to the top. The buddha is huge and the surrounding statues are beautiful. Free to climb up but you can pay to to go in the museum.After that go on the 30 minute walk through the bush on the wisdom walk past the wooden pillars with the heart sutra inscribed, past tea tree plants and the youth hostel. You can continue on to other walks -one goes to the fishing village where the endangered white dolphins live.

A must see in hongkong. A must see. Reach in the morning itself at 10am to avoid crowds. We had booked a mini bus but you can take an MRT too. . Take the cable car and go for the crystal cabin cable car, the extra money is worth it. Go straight to the big Buddha. You need to climb 260steps to reach it but it is all worth the effort. The serenity and the calmness you would see in the buddha is amazing. Then you can go to the monastery and on the way to the cable car you would find Starbucks for coffee lovers, subway and an Indian restaurant too

A change from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Lantau Island is the home of the airport, apartments, a fishing village and the great Bhudda. You can get to the Bhudda by boat and bus (Lantau Ferry and Bus 2 at the Ferry stop, about an hour) or on the underground and cable car, less time but not sure how long. The giant Bhudda is venerated by many at the site, which also houses a monastery. There is a tea house and a more commercial area. You have to walk up 276 steps to get to the statue, worth the effort. Go inside to gain a better understanding, have lunch at the monastery. A good place to meet locals.Quiet compared with the rest of the city, nice place to spend a day.

A must see, even if you're not into spiritual stuff. Temples and monasteries are fairly commonplace in Asia, so a visit to Lantau Island initially ranked pretty low on my "to do" list. Boy, was I wrong. It was fortunate that I decided to go on a "Oh, what the heck I might as well go" impulse otherwise, I might have missed out on seeing one of the better attractions in HK.There are various ways of getting there, but the cable car appears to offer the best views (more of that in a separate attraction review). There's certainly more to Lantau Island than just the Buddha Statue and the monastery, but just visiting both of these is pretty much fair enough for a visit.It's always a good idea to pack an umbrella (in case it rains- it also doubles as a sun parasol) and sunblock. There are lots of places to eat, and in case you run out of HK$, there's a Travelex outlet in the vicinity.Toilets can be a little on the filthy side though, and I have not observed any special facilities for the mobility impaired.
