There are unleashed dogs wandering about the temple grounds (not strays, as they seem quite healthy) but you may want to stay clear of them, even though I've been told by locals that they've never heard of anyone being bitten.
Religious Attraction. Enjoyed the Crystal (see through) cable car ride to Lantau Island and also the great view of the big Buddha.
Majestic Experience. The cable car ride to the Bid Buddha was excellent and breathtaking! We went on a misty day and it created such a majestic experience. Well worth it!!!

Must visit. The cable car ride going to the Island allows you to see a part of Hong Kong from a birds eye view. Reaching the island try Ebedneezer restaurant at the Ngong Ping Village.The curry rice was tasty. You can go up the Tan Tian Buddha without having to pay HKD 30 which I think is a rip off for an ice cream, a bottle of water and the chance to see the museum.
Buddha is nice but .... Except for the Buddha who is impressive I must admit, the village look quite artificial, if not cheesy. Funicular trip to the Buddha worth a try.

What's not to love?!. My boyfriend and I spent the day on Lautau Island. Took the cystal cable car to the top and headed straight for the Giant Buddha. Great little shops and amazing hiking trails. We ended up hiking around the main hill, around 4 miles and it was fabulous. Pretty foggy, though we managed to escape without rain. Made the hike nicer for sure!We will be back to hike Lantau Peak someday.

Serenity from the city!. Went there in July, and it was probably not the best idea. Cable car was down due to the weather, so we rode the bus (probably an hour). Twists and turns through the hills on wet roads - mostly scary. We persevered through the walk up in the rain. It was nice to just stand there and see the greenery for a hot second - a sense of accomplishment. Inside, a relic of Siddhartha - the possibility of the existence drove me the most. "Im this close to him!" Art works fill the interior - beautiful.
lantau. You could easily spend a week and not see everything. The cable car from Nong Ping is worth it. Fast train connects to Hong Kong island with connecting buses. Too easy.

Religious center or theme park?. We had an excellent day at Lantau Island, but came away a bit confused. As a religious site, Lantau has the Big Buddha and the Po Lin Monastery, both of which are worth a visit. Having said that, everywhere you turned (even in the religious sites), you were being offered things to buy, eat, etc. This was especially true in Ngong Ping Village, which is one giant shopping center. One of the best parts of the trip, is riding the cable car, a 25 minute trip over mountains and water to (or from) Tung Chung, where you can easily catch a train into the city. If you take the cable car, make sure to get one of the "Crystal Cabins." Watching the scenery from the bottom of the car is pretty awesome!
It's a real calm place to be.. Calm and chill. Traditions Are kept and islanders so all so nice.Cheap traditional food.Sea view and fresh seafood. You pick it and they cook it.

Make sure it is a nice clear day and not windy!. I thoroughly enjoyed my day trip to Lantau island. However if you don't have a head for heights it is certainly a NO NO. It is a long way up if you take the cable car (I believe you can also go by coach - but certainly wouldn';t fancy that)The scenery on way up is brilliant and once there, whenyou find the energy to climb up to the Buddha it is well worth the climb. The monastry was also a good visit and there was a wonderful feeling about the place. I thoroughtly enjoyed it - make sure you take your camera - so many pic to take.
majestic buddha. After a long journey between trams, subways, road, chairlift and walk we reach the majestic Tian Tan Buddha, the largest statue of Siddartha in the world...

No need to book a tour!. Take the star ferry from Kowloon to HK Island. Walk to the relevant ferry to Lantau Island. Journey takes about 40 mins. Once on the Island, walk out of the terminal to the bus stop. This bus will take you to Ngong Ping where the largest hilltop Buddah is found.Alternative ways are to travel to Tung Chung by MTR. then either take a bus to Ngong Ping or the stunning Cable Car ride. This is a much cheaper way than taking an organised tour.

Great escape from HK's concrete jungle. Me & my wife were recommended this place very strongly by one of my friends & the place didn't disappoint at all even though we had to spend close to 3 hrs standing in the queue to purchase tickets & wait for the cable car at either end.The cable car journey is worth it as you get a good view of the surroundings. The island is well laid out & is paved with cobble stone. They have created a small modern village atmosphere which is such a breath of fresh air, free from concrete buildings, vehicles & pollution.The highlight is the tall Buddha statue for which you have to climb lots of stairs. There is also a monastery on the island which serves free vegetarian food. If that is not your idea of having food then there are lots of shops around serving local chinese & continental dishes.

Very different to the city sites. The cable car trip is a must do for any visitor! the views are stunning and the whole set up very professional and modern. The Ngong Ping village is very touristy but good to see. The Buddha statue, and surrounds, are very impressive. Lots of steps but worth the effort. Amazing fish market at the fishing village of Tai O is well worth the time to visit, along with some of the food delicacies! Apart from the cable car, all areas on Lantau island covered by the public bus system so use the Octopus card to pay for fares - much cheaper than tourist operators!!
A great visit. Cable car was a great way of seeing views of hong kong and other islands, buddha was awesome, lots of steps but keeps you fit

Escape from the city. Lantau Island is great for a day trip away from the city. We started out buy catching the Ngong Ping 360 cable car up to the Big Buddha and Po Lin monastery, then we got a taxi down to the small fishing village of Tai O to experience a bit of traditional HK life. We finished up by returning to the top of the island by taxi so that we could make the best use of our cable car return tickets!

indians indians. the buddha himself is amazing but the chinese spirit for business tops it all. they have made a market place around the statue!!!!!!!they have made an artificial bodhi tree and the way to statue is imbued with goods you have to kinda buy..the whole island is very beautiful. monastery veg food is pretty expensive and if you arent quite hungry, might as well skip it as they serve really really too much food. liked the way the buddhists chanted ..seemed liked sanskrit in chinese to me.indians ...its sad to see more ancient, genuine buddhist relics in india get few visitors while the bronze , 20 year old lantau buddha attaracts millions.
The Stoep restaurant on the beach. Go to Lantau if only to dine on a tropical beach. Basic, but good food, in a wonderful setting. Cabs back to MTR or fast 30min ferry to Hong Kong Island.
Lovely, must do!!. the cable car ride to Lantanu Island was excellent. This is a must do!! Lovely views from the cable car and good eateries around once you land.

Fresh air and green space. I wish we had been able to stay longer, but the youth hostel on Lantau Island is a filthy nightmare. Lantau itself is gorgeous, green, and if you've spent any time in China, you'll appreciate how clean the air feels. The cable car ride is... pretty scary, actually, but worth it.

Not much to enjoy. Only been there once and didn't enjoy it as much as some of the other islands. REstaurants were pretty basic and food was not great. You could give it a miss and not really miss anything.
Out and about and rarely a tower block in site. Not a part of Hong Kong that many people see when they visit. Go to visit the beach at Chung Shah if you're going to the Big Buddah. Make a day of it

A Blessing. This was a marvelous day trip. We had lunch at the monastery and whilst it was simple fare it was delicious. Wonderful architecture to see and stunning wall paintings.Fantastic sights and a cable car ride with a glass bottom floor. And as a Buddhist who got married in a Catholic Church, I never had a ceremony carried out according to my faith. Having booked in advance we had a beautiful wedding blessing carried out by a monk belonging to the monastery. Truly wonderful day.

First tome to Hong Kong. April weather. Why were we not told ITS FOGGY IN APRIL.Took Sky lift to Buddah gardens and half way up, into fog/low level cloud.Gondola was white out. At the buddah stood on ground level for pic, andgot foggy outline of Buddah. Would be brilliant on fine weather.

Very relaxing. We took a tour to this island. Skipping the huge line for the cable car ride was very convenient. The ride itself is spectacular. After we got off the car, we were rushed to the bus. I would love to spend some time in the little tourist village with various shops and restaurants. On the other hand, we skipped all those steps to the big Buddha and got straight to the top of the hill. The guide told us the story of the statue and lead us to the Buddha's bones pieces. After Big Buddha, We had stops at the monastery down the hill and the fishermen village. Right now monastery is closed for the reconstruction until about winter but you still can walk around; it's very peaceful out there. At the end of the tour we got to the ferry that brought us to the central island.
dpejis HK holiday. The cable car (crystal cabin) adventure is such a good experience.They should put more activities and attractions.
much to see. ok, take the ferry from central to mui wo. then the bus to the big buddha, its stunning. then ngong ping to the other side of the island and back to the city with the metro.
Сontemplation. enjoying the beauty of nature and the touch of the oriental philosophyLiked: Buddhist temple, a large buddha, cable car with transparent cabins and sweet corn, steamed

Worth a visit. An easy to get to attraction, the MTR goes right to Lantau Island and then it's a five min walk to the cable car ride. The cable car journey is an amazing 5.8 kilometers taking you all the way to the temple and buddha. Once at the top there are many restaurants and sadly for a place of religious meaning there are lots of shops. You can eat at a small restaurant where the food is prepared by monks. A nice day out.

Worth It. Lantau Island was a place we were not sure if we would bother to visit, Seemed a long way from Hong Kong - but we were reall surprised. The Cable Car ride in itself was amazing and the kids really enjoyed it. There are plently of cafes to eat at at the top and it was very pleasant.

WOW! WOW! WOW!. We did this on our own and spent a day here. Easy to get to via MTR train. Pay the extra and get the glass bottom cable car it is worth it. The view is spectacular. Get there by 9am to get cable car as it gets crowded. View from Ngong Ping at the top absolutely fantastic. We walked the 272 steps to the budda. Plenty of places to eat but we bought some corn on stick and a pork sausage from a lady selling outside the tourist village. The corn was sensational. Pick your day make sure it is sunny. Take water, hat and sunscreen as you will get sunburnt. Get MRT to Tung Chung Stn. We took No21 local bus to Tao fishing village to have a look. Then took No 11 bus back to Tung Chung. Nice shopping centre here also. You cannot use your MTR ticket on these local busses you must have exact fare. It was a fantastic day and will take you all day to do what we did.

non authentic tourist trap. we went to Lantau for the day and went to see the big budha. firstly the cable cars are a great way to see the island and go much longer than you might expect. this is only any good however if the weather is good or ok as we discovered travelling through clouds seeing nothing but white for most of the trip. when you do get a view however it's breathtaking. I wouldn't bother with the crystal floors as there's nothing you can't see from the rest of the car. this is not the trip for you if you are scared of heights or worry if it gets windy.the Buddha itself whilst pretty spectacular was built in 1993 so not an ancient monument that you might hope for.the walk up to it is full of the usual tourist trap cages and souvenir shops so really makes what could be amazing very Disney and not in a good way.personally I wouldn't go again or recommend it but some would enjoy it.
Big Buddha. Cableway amazing and Buddha a treat, but got to be lucky with weather. Unfortunately we went on a day when the weather changed and had to buy a jacket as it got cold

Quite and relaxing place where a lot of things to do and visit.. This island southwest of Hong Kong is one of the better places for tourist attraction, to reach this island is simple, fast and comfortable through the Metro line.This unlike the chaotic Hong Kong is a more relaxed place where you can stay in contact with nature. Here in this island there is the famous Disneyland, the famous Big Buddha and his temple and the famous fishing village of Tai O. A truly unique place and definitely worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Very easy to get to on the MTR. The queues were quite long and eventually after an hour made it onto the cable car, The views are great and i would recommend this option rather than the bus, unless you have a fear of heights. Once at the summit you have a promenade with some shops and F&B options and then the Buddha. there are a lot of steps to reach the Buddha, and once up there isn't much to see so its not really necessary. Its worth a visit. The queue for the cable was much shorter on the way down.

A real contrast to Hong Kong. It is so much easier to get to Lantau these days, with the option of taking a ferry, a bus or the MTR, or any combination of them. We soon discovered that visiting Po Lin Monastery on a weekend was possibly not a great idea - we certainly were not alone. It was well worth the visit though and the site is so big that there was room for all. We opted to take a bus to the monastery as the queues for the cable car were horrendous with literally thousands of people waiting. There are plenty of food outlets and shops within the monastery grounds and amazing views of the outlying islands to be had from the Big Buddha. The rest of Lantau is quiet and rural, a complete contrast to Hong Kong. There are many good photo opportunities. Whilst we were there we also visited the old fishing village of Tai O which is still relatively unspoilt. A reasonably priced boat trip took us to see the stilt houses and out onto the bay in search of dolphin. Lantau is definitely worth a visit.

Peace and tranquility in Hong Kong. Away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, Lantau Island offers visitors breathtaking scenery when riding a cable car atop the high mountains heading towards the famous Tian Tian Buddha Temple - it's amazing to discover such tranquillity in Hong Kong!

If looking for peace.... This island, located away from the hustle and bustle of the main HK island, provides you with everything that you'll miss in HK or Kowloon: serenity, solitude and the Buddha right up there, looking down with his caring eyes. And also, the airport and Disneyland!

vey enjoyable. We had a great day on Lantau Island, we took the cable car with a glass bottom and it was fabulous. Half way across the water it broke down and for 10 minutes we swung about 150 feet in the air, they did keep us informed about the progress via the intercom. We went to The Big Buddha but that is another review. We had a vegetarian lunch there. I was a bit apprehensive about that but it was ample and satisfying. I would recommend a trip to Lantau as it was very good. Luckily we saw everything in the morning as it rained and was very foggy after our lunch.

Beautiful views from the cable cars. I took a taxi here from downtown Hong Kong and then the cable car up to the Buddha. I took the regular car (not the glass bottomed type) and the views were magnificent. The ride was about a half hour and much longer than I expected. After getting some nice photos of the Buddha with my telephoto lens I walked around the area with restaurants and decided on Ebeneezer's Kebabs - very tasty and good value. Two people could have been fed by one sandwich. It was too hot and I am too old to climb the 250 steps to be up close and personal with the Buddha. So, I made peace with myself by viewing it in the distance. Took the cable car down and then a taxi to Disneyland!
Easy trip. Tram to the top was worth the ride--don't bother to walk up to the Buddha, and the temple isn't much. Easy to get to, even for the timid. Guide not needed.

Worth a trip. This april was my second visit after many years and still enjoyed it very much. We took yellow line mtr (the line to disney) from Central up to Tung Chung, the last stop less than 1hr. As it is not a sunny day, we decided to take the standard cable car at hkd 98 per person one way and went back by bus cost hkd17 per person. Would recommend the glass bottom cable car which is much more expensive, if you came in sunny day. We enjoyed the beautiful scenery at the beginning of the climb, but it was too foggy at the top we were blinded by white fog, quite spooky i would say:) the cable ride took around 15min arriving at Ngong Ping village around 11am, many souvenir shops before we came to the giant buddha entrance. Before climbing up the stairs there is a locket where you can buy vegetarian lunch ticket. As advised by my Hongkong friend, we bought the deluxe one which is more expensive at hkd118 per person. Then we climbed up as we were not hungry yet. The Giant Buddha is impressive and we also went inside where there were shops selling souvenirs which has been "kai guang" or prayed by monks and also shrines for the deceased. Hongkong famous artist Anita Mui's ashes was kept in the shrine here. Then we went out to take beautiful pictures then walked down Towards the Po Lin monastery which was under renovation. We went straight for the veggie lunch, and served with delicious meals consist of mushroom soup, and 4 dishes which was plentiful for the 2 of us. The return trip by bus 23 took around 30min. The bus station located in the middle of the village where you can also take bus 11 to Tai-O fisherman village if you got time. Arriving at Tung Chung we managed to shop at the factory outlets there for branded stuff before heading back :)

Full day of adventure!. Easily a full day of adventure. Tip - Ngong Ping 360 cable car is the best way to reach the island as the views are amazing on the way there. Tian Tan (Big) Buddha, Po Lin Monastery, Wisdom Path and more. Photo opportunities abound! ^^

Cloud limited benefit. Took the cable car - great - booked the tour - excellent value for money - Tia village was great - unfortunately the cloud cover was very low so much so we couldn't even see the big Buddha when we climbed the 250 odd steps.

Travel tip. We went across to Lantau Island to visit relations. We went across by ferry (about 20mins) and went to one of the water front restaurants. The "TIP" is save your meal receipt and take it to the desk at the ferry terminal and you will get a free trip back! we would have had no idea if hadn't been for our relations who live there.2nd tip buy a "Octopus" card for all transport inc. ferries but not taxis also can be used in cafes and kiosks for snacks etc.
AMAZING!!. Ngong Ping Cable Car is amazing!! Try Crystal or book tickets from their official website, it will save you a lot of time!!

ngong ping ,,,polin monastery. This is also known as the big buddha with the height of abut 34 feet .I call it the statue of buddha with beautiful eyes.IT is said that it took nearly 12 years to complete this work ,,,to really reach at the base of it we nearly need to climb 268 steps...the goodest of the thing here is to get vegetarians food .Transportation:- MTR tung chung station exit B, then take ngong ping cable car which takes around 25 minutes. then walk for around 10 min to the monastery.HERE u can also shop ,eat relax .I fell a crystal cabin cable car should be taken and if u book through internet u really save a lot of time.

Big Budhha. We caught the star ferry across which was easy. Then a bus to the monastery. Be aware that the bus does not give change so try and have a mixture of notes. The bus trip was very bumpy and made me feel very queazy. Make sure you eat at the monestary, very cheap and humble food. Overall i would recommend going, good half a day trip.

OK but a bit scruffy in places!. We took the cable car ride up to the Big Buddha and the ride was great. We did go into cloud for a few minutes, but on the whole the journey afforded great views - and I got to see some aircraft movements at HK airport (sad, but I love it!). DO NOT buy your tickets from the touts parading up and down the lines waiting for the cable car - the official tickets are sold at the head of the queue.........however convincing they appear and annoying they become! The proper tickets are not that dear anyway - in fact, the ride is damn good value.Guys, this is a cable car, and it is bloody high - don't go if you don't enjoy heights.The initial impression upon arriving at the "top" is good, but sadly there are a few grotty establishments that really spoil the walk to the temple and the Buddha. Plenty of places to eat and clean toilet facilities are available. The Buddha is without doubt, very impressive and well worth the effort of going to see. The temple looked a bit sorry cloaked in scaffolding, but everything has to be maintained sometime.Look out for the wandering cows too ;-)

Don't Rely on Cabs. The main issue I had with Lantau was the complete lack of taxis. It is a nice place, but don't expect resort style villages, and the line to the Big Buddha was massive. It would be a nice place for a hike though.

A must see. Get the ferry from pier 6, best advice is to take the fast ferry as it will take around 1 hour on the slow ferry. Fast ferry is 420HKD and the slow ferry is 210HKD Buses to big budda are very easy to use and are right outside the ferry terminal

Disco bay - get on the boat and visit. Discovery Bay on Lantau Island is fab. Great beaches and a lot of good bars and eateries. It is a 20 minute boat ride from Central which costs buttons and the boat ride itself is great.
go and see the big buddha. very interesting trip to the giant Buddha , amazing how huge it is , also enjoyed our lunch at the monastery below

Big Buddha. Stair up so many steps is a good exercise to see the great Buddha. One feels like you were in the sky. A must to visit while in Hong Kong. When you were resting after climbing the stairs, a good snack sweet treat there are so good, like To Fu Far & soy bean milk.

A Great day out. Really enjoyed going up tot he top of the big budda by cable car. Fantastic views, though lots of people. The glass bottopmed cable cars mean no waiting in line for a cable car on the way back, as well as offering a good view.

A must watch in HK!!. Hardly an hour from HK central ( MTR).. this island has a lot of attraction for every age group. If you want to see and do everything (which you should) do plan for an entire day. Starting with the cable car and the Giant Buddha statue, this place is quite an attraction. You can also plan to trek the entie way. Do remember to carry a good camera and you will have lots of memories to take back home. If you take the cable car go for the one with the glass floor. Although its scary initially but then its absolutely safe and a sure shot recommendation. The view of the HK airport from the cable car is absolutely mindblowing. You can shop for souveniers at the Hill top ( although all the stuff there can be purchased at cheaper prices from the night market). In all a must see place in HK!!

Scary cable car but the buddah and monastery were great!. I have to admit that the cable car was incredibly scary as it was windy and rainy and on th way back covered in clouds - freaky!! The shops were a bit tacky but all good fun. The buddah was fantastic and we loved the monastery

Great, but.... This is a wonderful excursion and a "must" if you have at least 2-3 hours to go there. The atmosphere is wonderful, also the view.But be aware that there is only one transport to go there, the gondola lift "Ngong Ping 360" and if you happen to visit the big Buddha at a public Holiday, you may wait hours in the queue to go back. There is also a bus but it isn't always operating and takes a long way too. You may walk, but this is a Long way as well.

Highlight of our visit to Hong Kong. Lantau Island itself is a beautiful place but the sight of the big Buddha is absolutely amazing. We spent most of the day just walking the grounds around the Po Lin Monastery as well as exploring the Buddha statue. The view from the base of the statue is wonderful. Such a peaceful experience. The steps up to the Buddha are not for the faint of heart, especially with the heat and humidity, but it was well worth the climb.

Lots to do on Lantau. I've visited Lantau Island several times over the years, most recently on a quick trip to Hong Kong Disneyland - reachable by train or bus. One a previous visit we visited the Giant Buddha which can be reached via 2 bus lines. The island itself is lush and green - a big change from Hong Kong proper. Hong Kong International Airport is also located on Lantau Island.

A day at the Big Buddha. We took the MTR from Hong Kong Island for the day over to Lantau Island. We took the cable car up to the Buddha. The trip was impressive with some very nice views. Once up at the Buddha it was busy but not too bad being late winter and that helped make the climb easier (256 steps). It was well worth the effort.From the Buddha we headed down to Discovery Bay which was lovely.

Ngong Ping and Buddha. My nine year old son loved this so much that I think it may have been his first truly spiritual experience. We took the cable car across to Ngong Ping just as a thunderstorm was in the offing, and he was absolutely transfixed by the sight of the giant Buddha against the dark clouds and green mountains. He insisted on buying a replica Buddha statue to remind him of his visit and wants to go back when he can.

An unbelievable place near Hong Kong. First of all, i want to share my Cabin Car experience, we choose transparent floor crystal cabin car and when we were at some 1500 ft height. the feeling was awesome, it seems like there is no floor and we will fall down ... after a long ride we reached Lantau island, its a very natural place at such a height that you can literally say that you are in the sky. Po Lin Monasty and The Giant Buddha are the major attractions and there are some excellent restaurants too... a must visit place, recommended traveling by cable car
Worth a visit. Lovely Island. Worth a visit across on the Star Ferry even if just for lunch. However, make sure your ferry is going to Discovery bay and not other parts of the island.

Good place to visit. I took the regular boat from hong kong island, then the service bus to the big Buddha. I brought the ticket just to walk up to the Buddha and to walk round the visitor attraction at the top. I hadn't decided how to get back but there was a very short line for the cable car(5mins) so took that back down and then the bus back to HK.

SO much to do on this island. First of all, there is the Big Buddha. This is a magnificent site all in itself. There is a cable car that offers spectacular views of the island. However, it does not run in inclement weather, which during rainy season (April - August), is hard to know when it will be good. Citygate Outlets - this is a nice area to find some great name brand stores, including Adidas, Levi's, Columbia, Brooks Brothers, Coach, Kate Spade, and more. The prices are better than most malls, but still be prepared to spend a good bit. We took a bus to the Mui Wo Pier to meet friends for dinner. Right near the pier is a fantastic Turkish restaurant that serves some of the best Middle-Eastern food I've found in all of Asia. I unfortunately, do not remember the name, but it is right near the Deer Horn Bar - to the right if you are facing the pier/ferry. It's a must try! We only made it to a portion of things this island has to do or see in our one day. I plan to go back again and spend more time here.

weather ruined it. We stayed in Tai O, which was wonderful. Very touristy. It was raining, windy and very cloudy, we werent able to take the cable car up to the big Buddha. It was nice to get out of the big city.

Ride the Ngong Ping 360%, Visit the Giant Buddha. The Cable car ride is expensive but worth the penny..The Giant Buddha is really so huge.. During the time we visited this area there's a construction on going so the place doesn't look so clean..

Nice day trip out of Hong Kong. The purpose of our visit was to see the Big Buddah. Used the MTR for direct and easy access - from Kowloon with Octupus card - very easy. The chair. Lift is very well supervised and clean

Worth visiting. I went on an organised trip. Cable car first fantastic panoramic views not for height phobics especially if car is glass bottomed. Big Buddha then monastery lower down all highlights. Next we visited tai o a former visiting houses on stilts a place to shortly experience redevelopment as the bridge is constructed from Macau to Hong Kong. All travel guides I met were mines of information.
well worth the journey. the buda was lost in the fog but it was still a magical sight, the grounds are beautiful,theres a few shops to brouse in
Beautiful island. Lovely break from the manic Hong Kong Island. Recommend the trip to the big Buddha and enjoy a vegetarian meal at the monastry.

Lovely island. We had the fortune to engage a guide for several days who happened to live on Lantau and we got to see the inside and outside of all the places on the island,places where te average tourist even on an organised tour would not get to see,well worth the visit.
Fun trip!. Loved the cable car ride Ngong Ping 360 and visiting the Giant Buddha. This is a must, and the kids had a blast.

Worth the 40min bus trip from the ferry!. Ferry 30mins bus 40mins (up a very windy steep road) note on the way you see the prison on the left as you go up. Statue was only built in 1997 so it's new but still a sight to see! Including all the statues walking up to it and surrounding it,temple at the bottom also good to see,only thing that put me off was the fact that it was built so recently and made me think its only purpose was not for worship but for tourists! But it is still a sight to see ,the surrounding woods are good to see
Beautiful. Absolutely a lovely place. The narrow streets of the old town. The golden Buddha. And there are some really quaint old restaurants here as well.

Worth a visit. Bought a ticket through big red bus tours - good value- included cable car to Lantau Island and bus tour on the island that took us to a fishing village as well as the Monastery and the Big Buddha.To get there took the train to Tung Chung - with large shopping centre full of outlet shops - pre purchased tour tickets meant we didn't have to wait in huge line up to get onto cable car.The village next to the Big Buddha was full of souvenir shops and eateries.

The Big Buddha. Take a package tour that also takes you down to a quaint fishing village, and on a short boat ride through a fishing village on stilts. This makes the Big Buddha and Temple visit more worthwhile .

Wish for good weather.. So many different ways to get to, from and around Lantau Island, that some pre-planning is essential.As we visited 2 days before the cable car was due to reopen on the 21st (having been closed for maintenance) we went over by ferry from Central, took the bus up to the Monastery and Big Buddha, bus down to Tai O, then bus from there to the MTR at Tung Chung and on to Jordan MTR as a thunderstorm had come on as we were leaving Tai O. Unfortunately we definitely chose the wrong day.As we sailed into Mui Wo on the ferry, we could see clouds and mist on the higher hills. Sure enough, the more the bus climbed up, the more clouds and mist we found ourselves in. At Ngong Ping we stepped off the bus into what was more like swirling fog. You could hardly see anything. "Big Buddha" was lost in the fog, and we could only see the first 40 or so steps leading to it. Decided not to bother with the climb due to the poor visibility, so only had a short look around the misty area beside the Monastery before taking a bus down to Tai O. Here, all was relatively clear and we enjoyed a short HK 20pp boat trip for views of the stilted village and out to sea hoping to spot some dolphins. We saw none. We then enjoyed a walk around the village and visited the small one room museum to learn more about life in this rural fishing community.As we were walking around, we noticed the clouds were lower and darker than they had been when we arrived and decided to return to Kowloon by MTR instead of ferry. We were no sooner on the bus heading to Tung Chow MTR than the heavens opened and a thunderstorm began. The road is twisty and steep so being driven in a thunderstorm was somewhat hair raising! As the bus stop is undercover next to the MTR we were lucky and arrived back in Kowloon still dry.Despite our disappointment with the fog at the Monastery and Big Buddha, we nonetheless enjoyed the ferry trip across, the ride from Ngong Ping to Tai O, and Tai O itself. Lantau is completely different from Hong Kong and worth a visit regardless of weather.

Buy the combined ticket for the cable car, buses and the boat.. Set off early if you want to make the most of this island. We caught the MTR to Lantau, then bought the combined ticket before getting n the cable car up to Ngong Ping and the Giant sitting buddha, the ticket included all bus travel on the island, we visited Ta Ho fishing village, which is very interesting. At Tai Ho we used the ticket for a but ride around the fisherfolk houses and out to try t see the famous white dolphins. Unfortunately they were no where to be seen that day. The island of Lantau is very green compared with Hong Kong and Kowloon. Much of the island has not been build on as yet. A good day out.
BIG Budha. A must see as well as the small towns on the way there.Easy local transport. Try a cruise on the harbor to see the water dwellings. Unique!

Lots of rustic things to do. One can really local fare and experience local way of living by going to Tung Chung and Tai O. Nt rushed at all, it gives a different perspective of the hustle and bustle of HK island and Kowloon.

Long walk up the steps but well worth the effort. Long walk up the steps but well worth the effort. The views were very good for photography. The vegetarian meal was good even though I am not a vegetarian.

Splendid Lantau by Splendid Tours!. Where your comfortable shoes & meditation bracelets on this interesting tour. We enjoyed a meaningful and insightful tour to Lantau Island and the Po Lin Monanstery presented by our handsome guide, Ben. With Ben's Clint Eastwood vibe, we learned many interesting fact on the history of Lantau Island and the Buddhist Temple. We were permitted to respectfully enjoy a session of the Monks chanting in unison. The chanting combined with the fascinating architecture was very moving. The Tai O fishing village and ferry ride were special ways to gain insight into the local peoples culture outside of Cosmo Hong Kong. Sorry we missed the Ngong Ping Cable Car, but lucky people who get to enjoy that birds eye view.

Best thing was Lantau Trail DOWN from Po Lin Monastery. In short, nice gondola, nice buddah, lots of tourists, one of my best walks in life down from the area back to Tung Chen on a wonderful and beautiful walktrack in the valley! Breathtaking!Took the cableway (70HKD one way) up to the Po Lin Monastery to see the Big Buddah and the rest of the temple area. The Buddah in itself was very impressing, but almost found it greater from a little distance. Spent in total maybe 20 minutes on the Buddah and 20 minutes looking around the monastery sight. The view from the area was very nice, even though I visited on a cloudy day. DO NOT miss out on the "not much spoken about" Lantau trail back to Tung Chen. Had decided to ge already before going on the cablewal, so did not buy return ticket. Lady in ticket office tried to get me to change my mind, "it will take you four five hours to walk down, very bad road". I decided to anyway since I had a lot of time free. This ended up being the very best thing in the whole day, maybe even for a very long time. About 7k walk, took me two hours including plenty of stops for photographing the hidden away monasterys on the way down the montainside in the valley. Much more worth seeing than the Po Lin manastery, much more real. The walkway was nicely prepared and not hard to walk down, where it was steep there was always built in steps. Bring plenty of water though, and maybe some fruit. Went through rainforest, mountainside and valley, with beautiful views, smells and a sense of total calm. Hearing the monks singing when walking through the rainforest was absolutely amazing! In total I met three budist monks and one brave person walking UP the montain, this in my whole two hours of walking. To get to the Lantau trail (signs to Tung Chen and another village before), just follow the way to the Tee Garden/Hostel/Wisdom Path.

A good day out. Taking the MTS from Hong Kong out to Lantau couldn't be easier and once there heading up on the Gondola to see Big Buddha and the surrounding attractions is for sure, a decent day out.

Big Buddha. The climb to the top of the Buddha is not for the weak. Go slow and take your time. If you take a private tour, you may be able to drive directly to the top and look down or even walk down. We took a private tour and didn't have to do all the walking. Try to plan going early or late to avoid the crowds.

Away from the city. The Big Buddha statue and Po Lin monastery on Lantau Island are well worth a visit. We took the metro to Tung Chung and the gondola to the Ngong Ping village which provides access to the statue. Unforgettable !

Good. You have to go to Lantau Island to see the statue of the Buddha. Go by cable car for fantastic views. Some of the cable cars have a glass floor but I don't think it's worth paying an extra HK$60 for this. You'll need at least 6 hrs to see the buddha slowly

Big Budda and Disney Land are worth the trip. 360 cable car was down for maintenance so we just took the bus from the MTR station (#23 bus BTW). Big Buddha was an amazing experience. Disney Land was also great. I highly recommend going to Lantau.
good sights and shopping. a great day. visited buddha on cable car and great shopping at citigate shopping centre. a must to do in hong kong

Amazingly serene!. Just a quick metro or ferry ride from central Hong Kong, Launtau Island is an incredible retreat offering superb hiking, a few nice attractions (Disneyland if you're into that sort of thing) and pristine beaches! Grab a map, hop onto some kind of transport and go explore. Do treat yourself to lunch or dinner on one of the beaches there for the most laidback time you'll have in busy Hong Kong!

Simply the best. We were so surprised with Lantau Island. It is cheap and easy to get there. Buses wait for you on the island and then a trip to the Gold Buddha is an absolute must. If you like walking there are many hiking trails on the island. Next time we intend to stay on the Island and get up at dawn to see the Monks

Sky-Land-Sea Adventure NGong Ping360. What a cable car - I didn't understand what I was getting when buying my crystal ticket but because it was a bit more expensive - I guessed there was some added value. Yes there was - a cable car with a glass bottom floor which added just another dimension to the trip from Tung Chung to NGong Ping village on the island. Great views of Tung Chung Bay, the international airport, the giant Budha and the Lantau Island.

long way for ordinary. The location is way outside city center and the attraction is less interesting, the cable right give a view on the airport and surrounding mountains...The village waiting for you is touristic but well organized.Main interest is the big Bouddha and the monastery

Beautiful but yes, touristy. I agree with the advice to do not take the glass bottom gondola - its not worth the additional price. I took the gondola both ways, it was more expensive but I could afford it and it was part of the experience. I loved watching the fog roll off the nearby mountains, and yes- Big Buddha. It is touristy but - how else would you have known about such a high rated attraction if it wasn't?

Oh what a delight. we have visited Lantau Island on four previous occasions , revisiting the Big Budda and to view the progress on the building of a new temple and this was no different this time , however we undertook a detour to visit Tao O a small fishing visit at the far end of the island: easily and economically reached by coach. Here was the real China despite having been under UK control for such a lengthy period, the houses are built on stilts and the roads are in fact run oofs just like Venice. If you are only going to HK for a couple of days make this a hot place to visit you will not be disappointed.
A trek to see Big Buddha. Was good, second time round. Now they have cable cars it made the whole experience alot better and time efficient.

HOME. Disneyland, Ngong Ping 360, Citygate Outlet Mall is located in this island.The fastfood in Citygate has a good range of international dishes that are good. There is a fountain in Tung Chung. Open spaces and it's not so crowded compared to other parts of Hong Kong. There is a Christian service in Novotel. The airport is just few minutes away. And best of all, my wife has a company flat there so I get to be in Hong Kong and not spend for a hotel.

The "rural" Hong Kong. Take the metro line to Tung Chung or take the ferry from Central Pier (the best option in my opinion). Visit the great Buddha and Tai-O fishermen's village. You're so far from Hong Kong's agitation...

Interesting. Started with the pleasant trip over to the island on a ferry from the H.K. ferry terminal. The bus trip up to the mountain has a nice view of the area. The village is a tourists trap for expensive gifts & souveniors, still ok to browse around.The food places in the village were good though the main restaurant was a bit pricy.It was worth the climb up to the Big Buddha as the view from the top was very good.Its ashame all the souveniors shops around the base have spoiled the serenity of a religious place.

nothing special. Lantau island was the least interesting experience I've had in HK. HK has so much to offer that if you are pressed in time, Lantau island can be easily missed. Too many people, lots of tourist traps and attractions. If you get there don't miss Po Lin Monastery. In my opinion it is worth coming there with the boat from Central and then take a bus that drives through much of the island and to enjoy views from the window, then visit the monastery and climb up to the Buddha. The way to the top was so crowded with people! The cable road is not bad experience (and not cheap as well) as it offers nice views over islands.

A Great Place but a little too touristy. I liked the trip. But if you have the time wait for the gondola. The bus is not really comfortable especially if it is overloaded. My advice is do not take the glass bottom gondola its not worth the additional price. You really need to spend a half day there to see everything. My time was constrained but I did enjoy it. If you are a shopper leave time for the outlet mall.

Tourist trap -- stay away. Lantau is really bad version of what would happen if disney did buddhism. The whole thing is maddening how they've ruined the serenity of the island. Cable car is worthwhile, as is seeing the big buddha, and I'm sure other activities on Lantau might be ok, but the whole fake village and walk up to the buddha are just horrid.

:). Loved the cable car ride to the Big Buddha! Be prepared to queue on Sundays though... loads of tourists gives a commercial vibe to the place but just to see the Big Buddha is worth it... My friends took me to nearby Tai-O on a bus too, a small fishing village which was nice... we didn't get to catch the pink dolphins as it was cold out but heard you will have more luck in the summer. Also, there's a beautiful hotel there which is worth a visit, and maybe a bit, the Tai-O heritage hotel, used to be an old police headquarters.

Day trip including Lantau Island. The day trip was an excellent day away from the main islands. I found it very interesting in helping me understand the culture and traditions. Our guides were excellent and their knowledge was second to none

great spot, day well spent. lots of photo opps here. on the gondola an from the top. we didn't rush through so from TST, this wound up being a 6 hour trip for us. we had a nice, light, vegetarian lunch in the monastery (very affordable). There's a lot of steps on the way up to see Buddha but we made it and were happy we did.Lots of tourist related gift shops as well.Don't miss the Outlet Mall at the bottom of the gondola.

Amazing place. Love this place, wow was absolutely amazingThe sights, the atmosphere, the beautiful buildings, the views...Would 110% definitely go again, and highly recommendThe memories from here I do remember and will do forever!

Get off the plane and hit the ground touring!. Step off the red eye from the US and stow your luggage at the airport. Take a bus/train/ gondola to visit the big buhda. This used to be a remote place with a dirt road and one way to get to the monastery-the road. On my most recent trip, I found the once empty road built out with a small village ( if you have been to Aspen, Northstar at tahoe, Squaw Valley USA- that kind of village) complete with Starbucks. Walk through the village and then enter the original establishment - the monastery. The monks are gracious and generous to all their tourists. The scenery is beautiful. It is a working monastery, remember to be respectful. Eat at the monastery. It is the best vegetarian food you will eat and the sale benefits the monastery. Plan to spend several hours there. Your hotel room isn't ready yet anyway. The views are incredible. The museum inside the big buhdha complex holds treasures from ancient history and from recent years. The stairs- be ready for the massive amount of stairs required. There is no other way up ( at least the last time i went). It is an awesome spiritual place, even for this Catholic girl.

Peaceful. After days of city living in on HK island and Kowloon it was to time to branch out to Outlying Islands. I embarked on a trip to Lantau Island to visit Big Buddha. Travelling by train to Tung Chung and with the cable car out of service for maintenance just 24 hrs before my trip, I changed transportation to a coach service at Tung Chung station to reach the Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha. Winding roads forming a mountainous backdrop of lush greenery. Lantau Island is among 200 plus islands belonging to Hong Kong SAR with only a few inhabited. Arriving at the Ngong Ping Village you are immediately in view of Buddha. Taking the 268 steps to reach the Big Buddha on offer are tranquil views of surrounding mountain and sea views. "The eyes, lips, incline of the head and right hand, which is raised to deliver a blessing to all, combine to bring a humbling depth of character and dignity to the massive Buddha."(Discover Hong Kong). At the base of Buddha is the Po Lin Monastery and home to many devout monks. Really nice place to visit. Easy bus routes back into town

Fantastic trip. We visited Hong Kong in February 2013 and chose Lantau Island for our organised trip. We visited the avenue of stars first but only recognised Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan. We then visited a jewellery store. The highlight of the trip was the cable car ride to the Big Buddha. This also included a visit to the monastery where we had lunch. This was really good and we met some really nice people from Hawaii. We took the cable car back and then onto a fishing village that had houses on stilts. Here we took a boat ride around the village and then a short trip around the bay. We had a walk around the market and then back to the hotel. We had a guide called Ben and he was very good if a little bossy! This was a great trip and we saw a lot of Hong Kong? Well worth it

The aerial tram is worth the trip!. Everyone talks about the monastery & Big Buddah----don't get me wrong, they are impressive. But for us, the real thrill was the aerial tram ride over to Lantau Island. Spring fr the crystal cabin---the extra $$ is worth it for the experience, but the line is super short for your return to the mainland when they close and that was well worth the $$!
Lantau Delight. We traveled to see the giant Budda and the temples which is worth the trip. Lots of walking so take comfortable shoes.

Beautiful!. A really lovely, charming, serene island. There is a lovely fishing village, a giant Buddha, a lovely Buddhist monastery and cable cars to travel up and down the mountain that offer a lovely view of the island. A peaceful retreat from the hectic city of hing kong!A breath taking place that was my favorite part of my trip to China.

Worthwhile excursion if you already seen Hong Kong Highlights. We took a day trip to Lantau Island, which you can easily do on your own.First, we took the cable car to the Big Buddha. I recommend that you buy tickets online. Otherwise, you will probably have a 45 minute wait in the line. The scale of the cable car was impressive. Then we walked up to the Big Buddha. It is impressive, but not worth the trip to Lantau Island alone. Then, we took a taxi to the Tai O fishing village. There we walked around the stilt homes and saw all of the dried fish! To me, Tai O was the highlight of our excursion to Lantau Island.

So different!. In visiting Hong Hong we didn't expect to be touring round a green and pleasant island! Lantau Island shouldn't be missed, it's beautiful and lush with sandy beaches and an interesting history. Go visit the village of Tai O before the way of life there changes, see houses lining the river built on stilts and stalls set up throughout the village selling all sorts fo dried fish. The big buddha is a sight to behold, we didn't have to climb the 200+ steps as our bus had permission to drive to the top! As for the calbe car ride back down, wow! wow! wow! Fab views and heart stopping swoops across and down the valley.

not just for the airport. the big buudha is actually quit commercial and disney is disney but the beaches and the hiking are great... go in summer time and travel on the island by taxi as it is the easiest.

These mist covered mountains.... We took the cable car mid-morning when the area was covered by a patchwork of mist and cloud. This gave us clear views over the sea one moment and ghostly images of cables and cars vanishing into or emerging out of grey nothingness the next. About two thirds of the way into the ride we broke through cloud level and were rewarded with spectacular views over the hills and, towards the end, of the Big Buddha itself.The Buddha site and surrounding buildings is something of a curiosity. It began from a visit of Chinese monks to India on which they were impressed by the Indian traditions and wanted to bring something of that back to Hong Kong. On the other hand the site is clearly focused on drawing in tourist revenue and attracts the usual selection of reasonable shops and cheap stands. At the top of the climb the site of the statue is magnificent. Looking out on the remnants of mist folding over the ridges leading to the nearby sunlit hills I was unavoidably (cliche alert) reminded of vistas from Peter Jackson's Tolkein films. But in a good way. Visitors included both tourists and adherents which struck me as a little odd until I thought about the crowds around, for example, Notre Dame in Paris where the faithful mingle with the casual visitors and realised it was just the same and I was experiencing the shock of the familiar. The monastery below the statue is a classic Chinese temple with the incense burners and braziers and the statues of Buddha and the Bodishatvas protected by the staties of Temple guardians. Again, there was no shortage of adherents burning incense, paying their respects and leaving snall offerings. At the time this seemed to me to sit oddly with the tourist focus of the surrounding village although I have since learned more about the ways in which Buddhism in China has both survived and enjoyed something of a resurgence since the cultural revolution.My initial thought was that the historical Siddhārtha Gautama Buddha would have been horrified by the commercialisation of it all but I later decided that the Chinese tradition probably has it right - he would have found it hilarious. Well worth a visit if you have the time and a nice way to escape the hustle and bustle of central Hong Kong.

It was good!. Grab ur beer...Drink it before u climb the stairs to the Big Budga statue, drink the big one of course.After finish it, climb the stairs to get close to the Budha statue. Take a picture, play ur playlist from the iPod (use ur headphone of course), then see the view of Lantau island from there.. Its was GOOD!
NOT BAD. My family visited the Big Bhuda and walk around last week. There's a little village you can explore and learn about the history of Hong Kong and worth to visit.

Worth the hype... Went to this place finally...my fear of being suspended hundreds of metres above the ground really hit big time...lol....we had tickets for the crystal cabin which is actually a nice view ride but...one has their phobias...Getting to the Ngong Pong village is a 25 min ride from Tung Chung and the entrance is all about selling souveniers...every shop is full of wares to remind you that you are in HK. The big Buddha is really wonderful - the views from afar and from close are spectacular...climbing over 200 stairs to get to it was fun...and the view from the top of the bronze statue and the landscae around are wonderful. The Po lin monastery is serene. A really awesome trip...if not for my fear of heights ;)P.S. go early on weekdays (10 am @the ropeway to avoid lines both at the bottom and at the top)

Great for walks. Lantau island is the largest of Hong Kong's outer islands.It's a great place for walks. You can do the Lantau trail, part of the Hong Kong trail but it is 70km long. Stage 3 of the trail takes you to the top of Lantau Peak, Hong Kong's second highest peak: it's a tough walk but worth it if you get the weather: day I did was thick mist!If going to any restaurant go for Stoep it's by the beach and does great food. It's very popular at weekends so you need to book; but its worth it.Best way to get to the island is on the slow ferry which takes about an hour from central but you can sit outside on the upper deck and watch the world go by

Great destination for a day trip. go to the Big Buddha in early morning to avoid a long queue, and find the buses that take you to other little villages. It would be different atmosphere and experiences.
Definitely worth the ferry ride!. Very interesting place to visit with quite a few very nice beaches and a lovely little village that specializes in dried seafood products. Very picturesque!

A proper escape from the city. If you love hiking, mountains and beaches, then this is the place to be in HK. If you feel active, then conquer the peaks in the center of Lantau (Sunset Peak, Lantau Peak). If you feel more like an easy walk, then there are walks that start in Tai O and will take you along the southwest tip of Lantau or start in Mui Wo along the south east corner to Pui O. The main "attractions" (attracking the largest crowds) on Lantau are Disney, the Bid Buddha in Ngong Ping and Tai O. Personally prefer the Big Buddha for the views across the island and the views from either the cable car or the bus taking you there. As far as beaches go my personal favourite is Lower Cheung Sha because if the long stretch of sand and the nice restaurants along this beach.
The Big Buddha. Well worth a visit and the climb up the steps to the Buddha, pay 30 HK Dollars to go into the building under the Buddha, the price includes ice cream and a bottle of water.

5.3 kms of joy. It would appear this a venture to improve the conditions of the people living on the Island. You get a 5.3 km ride on a cable car, this itself provides some wonderful views, and it is not too expensive. The temple and statue at the end are well worth a look, the village of shops they have built as a further attraction is a little bit stagey, but some of the shops sell some very interesting items.

Small village and Big Buddha. Even though the village is a tourist development it is still a thoroughly enjoyable place to investigate, you do get the feeling that is has "essence of authenticity." Plenty to eat and buy. The Big Buddha was inspiring, The steps up are a challenge for those not as young or as fit as they used to be, but take a leaf out of the Buddhist ethos about patience and calm, climb these steps in the same way. Interesting starting point to learn more about this philosphy.

Great place to visit. Loved visiting Lantau Island despite all the rain and the steps!Well worth a look around and you can get some excellent photos.Only slight downside is the places to eat such as Subway and Starbucks can become crowded easily as they're only small and especially when the weather is bad. But I wouldn't let that put you off at all!

Monastery on the hilltop. Whenever I'm in Hong Kong I make it a point to spend a morning on Lantau Island. It's a good break to get away from the hustle and bustle of city life.Take the cable car from Tung Chung. It's a reasonably long ride high into the hills of Lantau Island with spectacular views of the airport and surroundings.The seated Buddha statue is 79 feet tall and if you're up to it you can climb the many stairs to the base of the statue.Nearby is the Po Lin monastery. It's best to visit the Buddha statue, the monastery, then have lunch at one of the restaurants there, maybe do a little souvenir shopping and catch the cable car back to Tung Chung.

Go with a Purpose. If you're travelling to Lantau Island it's probably to visit the Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha. Let's be fair, there's not a lot else there! But take the time to visit the Tai O fishing visit - you won't regret it.

Rode the Ngong 360 cable car to see the Big Buddha at Lantau Island.. The cable car ride took 20 minutes and was over hilly but scenic terrain. Below I could see a hiking trail that leads to the big Buddha. One can hike this trail in about 3 to 4 hours over hilly terrain to reach the Ngong Village area and from there it is a 10 minute walk to the big Buddha.

Pictureesque and fun. If you find yourself getting tired of the semi-controlled insanity that is downtown Hong Kong, a day trip to Lantau Island may be what's called for.Populated mostly by quite fishing villages, Lantau can be reached by the MTR or by ferry boat from Central Pier. Once on the island, there are plenty of ways to spend the day, from hiking in the mountains to fishing to just relaxing in one of the villages. There are also several beaches along the southern coast of the island which make for a great day trip. Furthermore, consider a trip up to the Big Buddha along with a vegetarian lunch at the monastery there. Disneyland Hong Kong is also located on Lantau if you need to shut the kids up for a day. It can be reached by train from Sunny Bay on its own dedicated MTR line.

Big Buddha and the Monastery. Headed to the Big Buddha, we tried to get on the cable car but the wait would take over an hour. We just took the bus which was just a few meters front the cable car line. In 45 minutes, we were at our destination. The Big Buddha looked really impressive. And because we haven't had lunch yet, we actually bought from the vendors in the area. Corn was at HK$ 10. Pricey for a quick snack but it was alright. Even tried the chicken leg. We also liked the monastery with all the incense and offerings outside. We didn't get to check out the village but we will surely come back. We took the bus going back to Tung Chung because the cable car line was going to take long again. Visited Feb. 11, 2013

Make sure you take the trip to Tai O. Take the MTR to Tung Chung and queue for the cablecar for about an hour and a half. Its worth it. Make sure you 'Go Crystal' for the cable car ride. It has a glass bottom for a bit extra. My kids faces were glued to the floor for the whole trip. Yes, Mum wasn't too happy. Note the giant bronze buddha on the way, a mere 37m tall. When you get to Ngong Ping, have a coffee and check out the buddha before catching a bus to the other end of the island at Tai O. When a dodgy bloke comes up to you offering you a boat ride, take it. For less than £2 per person, the boat takes you past the old fishing houses built on sticks, or rather twigs, before turning around and zooming out to sea. We were all flying around like T shirts in a washing machine. Great fun. When we stopped in the middle of nowhere we were delighted by 4 pink dolphins leaping out of the sea.Once safely back in Tai O bus terminus, catch the bus to Mui Wo, 50 mins. Have a nice swim on the beach before catching the ferry back to the madness of Hong Kong

Tai O ..Big Buddha..Lantau Peak. Tai O had been on the To Do list for a while... easy journey from Causeway Bay on MTR..seamless bus connection to Tai O... befriended by fellow traveller and pleasant lunch break and tour of Tai O with 20 dollar boat trip to see stilt houses in village and trip into ocean to see pink dolphins....tasty fried rice lunch with seafood... time pressing and short connection through village of Big Buddha..been there before and again impressed by scale of structure and serenity of site... LANTAU PEAK beckoned and attacked with vigour .. reached peak about 90 minutes later.. then pleasant walk back down hill to saddle between Sunrise peak and Lantau peak.. job done.. k nackered

Lantau Island. This is the island that your plane will land on when you arrive into Hong Kong but it has beauty and fun far away from the new airport.We did this on a tour (Greyline which is excellent in HK.) The Great Buddha is here and is reached by a 20 minute cable car ride which was fun and comfortable. As it goes up and up the view is unbelievable. You can also hike up the mountain on trails just below the cable car. Long way. When you reach the Big Buddha it is just lovely. The sheer size is striking and the surroundings are beautiful gardens that are immaculate and full of flowers. The temple near-by is lovely and you will have a vegetarian lunch prepared by the monks in a restaurant like area. It was really good even though I am not a vegetarian. The atmosphere is quiet and serene and a nice change from the bustle of HK. There is a small shop area with food, souveniers and other items for sale. Cobbled street. This is well woth the effort to go. Not to be missed for atmosphere and peace.
Great views of the Bay. On a sunny day it is a great way to take scenic pictures of the airport on the way up. Buddha statue is impressive!

A good day out!. As the weather was quite good for February, we decided to make a full day of our trip to Lantau and caught the ferry from Central to Mui Wo. I'm not sure if it was by coincidence or by design, but just as we arrived there was a bus about to leave for Tai O village, so we jumped aboard and enjoyed a pleasant ride from one side of the island to the other. Tai O is actually a small island, separated from the main island of Lantau by a very narrow channel, which is easily crossed by a footbridge near to the bus terminus. It's a fascinating mixture of a traditional waterfront fishing village with stilt-houses and modern high-rise apartment blocks set back from the seafront. We spent some time wandering the village streets with their fascinating shops and looking at the fishing boats in the harbour before making our way back to the bus station - only to find that we'd just missed the hourly bus to Ngong Ping by about 2 minutes! However, there's a taxi rank next to the bus stop and when the first driver informed us that it would only cost $48HK to take us there, we decided that was a far better option than hanging around for another hour and risking missing the next one!The entrance to Ngong Ping consists mainly of a modern shopping street, aimed squarely at selling various souvenirs to the tourists. The most fascinating shop for us is the Chopstick Gallery, where you can choose from literally hundreds of different designs and for the second year running, we came away with a beautiful set of chopsticks packed in an equally lovely gift box! In addition to the main attraction of the Big Buddha, there are country walks around the peaks, but as a chilly mist was starting to roll in we decided to call it a day and head back down by cable car. The views from the cars are fantastic, not least being the one as you come over the last peak and get a wonderful view of the airport with planes taking off and landing far below you. At the bottom, there's a good shopping mall next to the MTR station if you're not already shopped out, then a final form of transport - the MTR - took us back to our hotel. An excellent day out all round!
Cable car. Nice place you must go when your in hongkong. And must use a cable car. The view from iphone there is fantastic .

A really big Buddha. Well worth a visit Lantau can be easily reached by the MTR train. The sky lift is particularly good although you must be prepared for a long queue in both directions. The big Buddha is spectacular.

Big Budda - tour tickets. Not mentioned when you visit the Big Budda, When there enjoy a meal there prepared the Monastery. Meals are a little further than the steps.. When you buy a meal you can get a free ticket to see the inside of the Budda. But get your tickets before you ascend the steps to the Budda.

There's lot going on there. Many of the attractions will have their own reviews but there is plenty going on. It's where you arrive in HK by flight. There's Disney, if you like that sort of thing, the Sitting Buddha and the monastery with the cable car up to it. there are great hikes all over the island and Discovery bay for those choosing to live there. The big disappointment is needing a permit to have driving access to the south of the island and the Buddha. I'm a Harley owner and not having access is a real pain!

Don't be scared!. We took the Crystal Cable Car up to the island. I am not a fan of heights so this was a big step for me. Unfortunately (no not) we had a Mum, Dad & 7 year old on the ride with us and she could see that I was scared and proceeded to scream & jump up and down the whole trip. With a glass bottom cable car, this was quite terrifying! Arrived frazzeled & wanted to go back by a different means! Had an amazing meal at one of the restaurants which restored our energy and returned by same method which was much better.
Great day trip. We had a great day trip visiting Tai O fishing village and Big Buddha on a day trip organised though Viator.
Worth the visit!. Great site to visit with your family - take your time here, visit the Big Bhuda and walk around. There's a little village you can explore and learn about the history of Hong Kong

Very interesting. We really enjoyed the trip to Lantau Island. the queue to get a ticket was very long. We waited 45 minutes to get tickets but it was worth it. Definitely book a crystal cabin. This gives you a glass floor and an all around view on the cable car which takes about 30 minutes to get to the top. It's worth it! Quite exhilarating. Apparently if you book online you don't have to wait in the queue. The Buddha is huge. He is sitting on top of a series of stairs and the lead up is a walkway of statues that explain each of the Chinese years ... we each had our photo with our Chinese animal! The surroundings are well kept and very interesting. There are lots of challenging walks that you can do but they would definitely take a long time. We went for about 4 hours and walked out to the Wisdom Path ... this was an amazing series of huge carved wooden poles. It was easy to access and very peaceful. There is so much that you can do on Lantau Island that a day trip would be very full. It really is a place with something for everyone.

Excellent day trip to see the Big Buddha. I did this as a day trip with Grayline and I paid a little extra for the Crystal cabin, what this means is that the cable car cabin has a see through floor, and it was fantastic, I thought I'd be terrified but it was so exciting, I totally recommend paying the extra bit. The other bonus of going with a tour is that you don't queue for the cable car, and it doesn't matter if you go on the weekend or during the week there is always a long queue, so if you go on your own be prepared to wait in line. I had lunch at the monestary which is vegetarian and very tasty, the village itself has great shopping and of course the Big Buddha touches your soul. If you do nothing else whilst you are in Hong Kong this is an absolute must do.

Very big indeed!. We took the ferry to Lantau Island from HongKong central pier. Very nice views from the ferry. Then took bus 2 to the big Buddha statue. It it MASSIVE. And very beautiful and impressive. We then took the cablecart down. Big queue to get in, but worth it. Scary sometimes, but the views again are great. And at the end of the cable there is a metro to take you back to the city center. We spent a lovely afternoon doing all this.

The Big Buddha will make you exercise!. Once we got to the island, (we rode the MTR, Hong Kong's underground), we chose not to take the cable ride. Instead, we took the bus. As it turns out, it has small seats that we nicknamed "Chinese-Sized" seats. We went there only to see the Big Buddha. As it turns out, you need to climb some 100 (?) steps to get to the statue. Because of my bad knee, I passed on that, but the walk to the base of where the statue is, is quite interesting and pleasant and you get to see the colonels statues. Souvenir shops line-up the way (I am a sucker for fridge magnets). If you like cotton candy, buy one there!

Wonderful place. Dine at Lantau Island pier before heading towards Giant Buddha and Monk Monastery. There are some local restaurant close to the pier who serves fresh and delicious seafoods. It is located just after the bicycle parking area. The bus leaves around one o clock in the afternoon from the pier. So if you arrived around 11:30 in the morning you will have enough time to take a lunch and enjoy the view of the beach..Save a day tour to visit Lantau Island. If you are visiting Hong Kong for the first time don´t miss this mystic place!

Wonderful sight. The cable car ride was very pleasant even for someone like myself who is not good with heights. I never felt worried at all. In fact the scenery was a highlight. The Buddha was kind of humbling. Take some time to really see it from all different places and perspectives. I felt that even though there were a lot of people it didnbt' give the feeling of being overwhelmed. The walk up to the statue was spectacular while the monastry was fascinating and very, very busy. Must see when in Hong Kong.

Disneyland Hong Kong. Situated on Lantau Island the Park was surprisingly good (having taken this same group to Anaheim the year before). Going in January obviously had its advantages as the crowds are not so bad.

excellent place. loved the temple etc a really good day out.lots of very
interesting places to visit.
people are very friendly,
Not to Miss. Book tour through the Hotel,Great Guide. took us around the Island to the Old Fishing Village,Tian Tan Giant BUDDHA, and Lunch at the Monastery was the Best.
Disappointing. The cable car ride allowed magnificent views of the airport & surrounds. The Buddha was impressive, but the site itself was marred by massive numbers of junky souvenir shops.

Amazing Cable car ride and Tian Tan Budda. We took the MTR to Tung Chung and then the Cable car up to the Budda - be warned the desk selling tickets for the cable car at the bottom of the escalator over charges - just go to the top and pay at the official office - much cheaper. The Cable car ride is amazing - and seems to follow the old priests path to the Budda. If its a cool day take a coat as the cable car has open mesh panels and the wind whistles in. Go through the village (just a few tourist shops really and expensive) and climb up to the Budda. Don't be tempted by the offer of a snack or meal ticket to the second levels - they are only another 10 feet higher and it doesn't give you any better views. Also there is a vegetarian deli cafe behind the monks dining hall which serves exactly the same food as you would get in the monks dining hall but cheaper - and the portions are huge. The temple was being restored when we went last week - so we only saw the first two outer courtyards. Next we took the bus down to Tai O to see the stilt houses - very interesting - the tide was out. Then we took the bus back to Tung Chung and saw all the beautiful beaches and new apartments going up. A very nice day out

Visit the giant Buddha via Ngong Ping 360 cable car. Wow ... very cool cable car ride to get to the giant Buddha & surroundings. Request the clear-bottom car (extra fee) at least one-way, to get the feel of dangling over the hills and river. Fun, especially if there is at least one person with fear of heights in car.

In HK yet another kind of experience. Lantau island is in HK but totally different from the atmosphere in city area. There one can visit the Big Buddha, eating vegetarian food there and walk around to appreciate the nature and fresh air. Nearby big buddha, there are also shops and eating outlets. After that, you can take the shuttle bus to another attraction on the island, Tai-O, a fishing village and take a boat ride around the island which cost only HK$20. Walking in the village is just like back to rural village life. Old people playing mahjong in the house, people selling fresh fish along the street, shops slong the street selling dried fish, prawns etc. If you are looking for a place which is different from the town area, this island is a place you should go.

Giant Buddha on Lantau Island. Caught the MTR (Tung Chung Line), which actually ends on Lantau Island. Lined up for about 30 minutes to catch bus to the Po Lin Monastery as the cable car (Ngong Ping 360) was out of service for the week we were in Hong Kong. Took a while to travel to the other side of island, but worth the ride.Paid approx $6 AUS for a ticket to walk the stairs up to the giant bronze Buddha. Fantastic view, even if a bit hazy. The statue is majestic up close, and has rooms inside for deceased devotees to have their ashes (?) laid to rest and buddhist gift shop. After decending the stairs, walked a very short distance to the monastery where our ticket gave us a free vegan snack. Turned out to be a large lunch including soft drink, noodles and choice of 2 types of dim sum. Very tasty.Spent an hour going through the tourist village full of clothing, souvenirs and pottery. Reasonably priced.Allow a full day for this trip, well worth the visit.

must place to visit in Hongkong. a highy recommended place to visit in Hongkong. Since we're staying in Tsimshatsui, we decided to take the ferry ride to Lantau Island for a more exciting experience. From our hotel is a 7 minutes walk to the Tsim Sha Tsui Ferry Pier then we ride the Star Ferry to Central Piers (Hongkong Island), the star ferry ride between Central and Tsimshatsui has been rated first in the “Top 10 Most Exciting Ferry Rides” poll by the Society of American Travel Writers (“SATW”) in February 2009. At Central Pier 6 we took the ferry to Mui Wo Ferry Pier in Lantau Island then a bus ride brought us to Ngong Ping, where the giant Buddha is located. It was a view of superb natural surroundings and awesome structures. The cable car view going back down was also great (try getting the one with glass bottom). A totally wonderful experience.

It would be zero without the cable car. If you are used to visiting traditional and historically significant sites - my recommendation would be to stay on the cable car for a round trip. The cable car is great and well worthwhile doing on a clear day. The Buddha was built in 1993, one can assume to create a tourist attraction at the top of the hill. It is just that - built for tourists. Enjoy the ride, but don't expect a wonderful cultural experience! A few tips:1. Adjust your expectations that this is a fun ride and the town on top of the hill is a tourist destination - with Starbucks, Subway etc..2. Go on a clear day. The view is the biggest drawcard.3. Get there early. We went early and headed back a little before 1pm, the line was looooonnngg - having now visited I am sure those at the end wouldn't have felt the wait was worth it.4. If the line is long, pay the additional 200HKD (about $20) for the full tour and you go straight to the front of the line. You don't need to do the tour.So I don't feel like I wasted the day, I wouldn't say this is a MUST do in Hong Kong. Having been here a few times now, I now understand why it took me the time it did to get around to visit.

New Lantau Island Tour - City Discover. It was a misty winters day when I went on the above tour. Whilst the weather didn't detract from the tour the tour guide and the price did. I got to see everything I wanted - the Giant Buddha, rode the cable car, visited the fishing village. Whilst the tour guide was very informative and told us interesting facts, the problem with the tour guide was that we were taken to a point, given a brief overview and then left at the spot. Whilst eating the meal we had questions but there was no one to answer them. We were left to roam around the monastery on our own, and had yet more questions! We had lots of time to roam around on our own. The guide was never there. When she was with us she spent most of the time on her phone. Consider this tour very carefully!

Lots to do. Loved the cable car ride and the impressive big Buddha. We got a public bus to Tai-O and jumped into a boat to see the pink dolphins (none spotted) but a good tour nonetheless. Great day out.

Great Experience Outside of Central HK. I first visited Lantau in 2005. I remember it being a bit touristy, but a peaceful escape from the bustle of HK. On my recent travel there, I was surprised on how much commercialized it got, complete with a Starbucks, Subway and Ebeneezer's ( nice kababs ). Where else can you spot a buddhist monk grabbing a latte? Seriously, I did see that. The Ngong Ping cable car is a nice addition and enjoyed the trip. My suggestion is book in advance and take the standard cable car there and the clear bottom back. I went on a saturday around 12pm and had at least 45-60 min wait. The clear bottom was nothing to brag about, but will cut the trip back significantly because of the wait for the standard car. The Big Buddha is a beautiful site.
