I was lucky to visit on a clear day and received sensational views of the surrounding island. The Po Lin Monastery was interesting to visit. You will get a mix of people actually coming to pray and foreigners pointing at things. I enjoyed the vegetarian meal and would skip the fare in the faux-village. Despite the recent developments, Lantau is a must see in HK.

place that you must visit if you are in Hong Kong. Lantau Island - a place that you must visit if you are in Hong Kong... Po Lin Monastery and outstanding Tian Tan Buddha statue (Big Buddha)Po Lin Monastery - one of the major Hong Kong Buddhist shrines. Home for a large number of pious monks, the monastery is rich in colorful creations of Buddhist iconography. In its attractive garden full of flowers the birds are lively singing. To reach the Sitting Buddha of 34 meters height, prepare yourself to climb the long steep stairs. This magnificent bronze Buddha attracts pilgrims from all over Asia...

Real "must have". use the cable road in the crystal cabin-great view, unforgettable impressions for everyone.there stands the statue of Buddha, which is one of the five biggest of its kind in China and the world's largest bronze statue of a seated Buddha in the open air.

Quite side of Hong Kong. If you plan to visit the large Buddha statue travelling via the Ngong Ping 360 cable car. Please buy your tickets early as the queue was about an hour +. The experience is nice and the place is quiet compared to downtown Hong Kong. Walking towards the Buddha can be fun but not recommended for people with health problems mainly heart problems. It is a 200+ steps before you will reach the buddha statue.Still a great view from below!
Brand new facilities. Built for the new airport, all facilities are new including the gondola trip up to the Giant Buddha. Hotels are close to the airport which is handy.

Large, rather scruffy, bush-covered. We took the Star ferry from Central Pier to Mui Wo, then bus up to the Li Po monastery and Great Buddha - now a very commercialised tourist 'attraction' with Starbucks, Subway, and scads of souvenir shops. More like an annexe of Disneyland than a religious retreat. On the bus, it was interesting to see the older properties and things like the great dam and reservoir, the 'nuts and bolts' of living on an island, and the extraordinary engineering feats that keep the hillsides stable. It felt like one was seeing Hong Kong as it might have been sixty years ago. On the whole, it was - okay.

Beautiful Place to visit. Beautiful island to visit via cable car. The queue is very long but join the tour beat the Q. Love the Tai-O fishing village, the Big Buddah and the vegetarian food at temple.

Full of surprises!. Aside from the awesome airport , Lantau commands your attention with Disneyland and Ngong Ping as it's main attractions. But aside from the two , one should also venture within the coves of the island to savor the fresh seafoods in Mui Wo and the other inlets.

Worth a visit on a clear day. Take an easy metro ride to Tung Chung station, walk over to the cable car and treat yourself to a glass bottomed cable car ride to Po Lin monastery. The cable car ride takes about 25 minutes and gives some amazing views during the trip. The small village at the top is fairly touristy, but walk through it to the Giant Buddha and the monastery. When we visited the monastery was undergoing some repairs/extensions so a lot of it was undercover but the restaurant and outdoor bakery were open and well visited. Our cable car ticket included a bus ride down to Tai O, a fishing village, and a boat ride around the village houses which were all on stilts and above the water. It was eye-opening as to how they live. We caught the bus ride back to the monastery and the cable car back down the mountain. I didn't feel 100% comfortable at Tai O, can't put my finger on exactly why. As far as the cable car and a visit to the Buddha, it's highly recommended.

Sitting Buddha. We rode the gondola over to sitting Buddha and it was very touristy. We were there on a Sunday and it was very crowded. Buddha was beautiful as was the monastery but sacred grounds are overrun with souvenir shops and hawkers. The gondola ride was enjoyable but over priced. We took the "crystal" cabin and it was good only because it sped us in front of some of the crowd.
Nice Walk. We went for a free guided walk around the island and saw great sights. A good way to spend a morning.
fresh seafood. the ferry rides is pleasant bueatiful views. theres not much to do but eat the fresh seafood, which we thought was okay.

Excellent Experience. Visiting to view the Big Buddha by Cable Car, wow fantastic experience. Since we visited on 01st Jan 2013, we experienced queue to get in to the cable car, it took around 45 minutes.

Quite a bit to do here. Lantau has the airport, monastery, fishing village and much more. You cross by car or bus on 2nd longest suspension bridge. The fishing village is delightful. We ate the corn and amazing waffles. The monastery is a quick visit. Part of a grey line tour

Disneyland and NGong Ping ride are the main attractions. The biggest attraction on Lantau island is Disneyland which might not be as big as other Disneyland but good to keep you entertained for whole day, Firework in the night is just amazing. If possible, plan to stay in Disneyland itself. Though expensive but enjoyable.Another big attraction on this island is NGong Ping. Cable car journey takes you to the Giant Buddha. The journey above sea, mountains and jungle is amazing and can be enjoyed more from a crystal cabin (the car with glass bottom). Superb view of Hong Kong Airport (which also lies on same island) and building can be see thru rope way trolley.After reaching on the top one can visit statue of Giant Buddha, temple and monastery. Very soothing and peaceful place. A visit to see fishing Village of Tai-O can be done from here to see the Pink Dolphins. Don’t take full package of NGong Ping and choose selectively instead because all is not worth. Show of short movies etc can be easily skipped from the tour.Overall Lantau island is a one of the must place to visit in Hong Kong. Depends on preference, one can choose destination to travel here.

The highlight of my trip to Hong Kong. Lantau Island is definitely something you must do if you're visiting Hong Kong. Some may classify this place as a tourist trap, but the views up here are absolutely stunning, and seeing the Big Buddha in person is mighty impressive. There's also many neat monuments along the way for picture opportunities. I came here in early September 2012, so needless to say, it was scorching hot when I was here. If you do visit around this time, make sure you have sun block or at least wear a hat and sun glasses. The entire path leading up to the Big Buddha is out in the open, so you will have little to no shade. From the path of the cable car exit to the top of the Big Buddha, the walk can be quite exhausting if you're not in shape. Keep in mind that there is a lot of walking, specifically going up a lot of stairs. But nonetheless, if you feel like walking up all those stairs is too much, you don't necessarily have to go up. There's plenty of sight seeing, picture taking, eating and shopping you can do as well. There's little gift shops along the way, as well as local street food and restaurants. There was this one tented place where they served steamed milk and steamed egg. It was cheap and delicious! Great spot to hang out a bit before heading back to the exit. Getting here, I basically took the metro all the way to Lantau Island / DIsneyland. Once arriving, its pretty self explanatory which way to go. We ended up getting in the long line for the cable car. The cable ride was definitely a great way to get to the "Big Buddha" location. You'll get a scenic view along the entire ride. If you opt for a glass floor on the cable car, you'll have to pay a little more. Other neat things were along the cable ride, if you look down beneath you, you'll see people hiking all the way up to the same area. And on the way back down, you'll see planes taking off from the HK Airport. Plan a day trip if you do come. For the time vs money spent here, its quite a nice value. I highly recommend it.

Disney land !!!!!!!!. This is where the Disney land is situated.The HKDL is the world's smallest diney land but still one the best ones.It kept us busy for the whole day. It had somethong for everyone even my grandmother enjoyed the awesome park. The fireworks so well synchronized with music adds on to the fun park!!!!!!!!!

Excellent place, awesome. This is a zen place of Buddha, some of the sight must go through physical testing like walk up few hundred path to meet the Buddha. Highly recommend the path of wisdom, must walk 15 minute of jungle path from Buddha statue, but it worth.

Big Buddha is awesome!. You absolutely must carve out time in your HK visit to take at least a half day trip out to Lantau Island to visit the Big Buddha. It is so easy to get out there - 40 minute subway ride. Big Buddha is incredible and the cable car ride up to see it is even better. You'll be sorry you didn't go!

A tranquil piece of paradise in HK. A really pleasant day tour of Lantau Island with a nice ethos of maintaining the pristine environment by restricting visiting car numbers for example. Some fishing villages are poor but maintain their unique charm through a friendly and welcoming attitude. I just hope it doesn't lose it's charm when the bridge to Macau is completed.

wonderful Lantau Island. Geographically, Lantau Island is far from Kowloon or from the city. But because of the MTR, every tourist spot is just a matter of minutes to reach. I suggest you avail the tourist all day pass (and is cheaper if bought online).Going to Lantau Island if exit at Tung Chung then you'll see a mall across so u have to turn left and walk a few minutes. from afar you'll see an escalator which u should take. I suggest you should be there before 10AM. we were there at 9:30 but they already allowed us to take the ride since it is a Saturday so the queu is quite long. If you're there before 10 AM, u can leave Lantau early and proceed to your next activity. At lantau, there is Po Lin Monastery and the Buddha. make sure to go to the Buddha first (admission HK $28) but includes free meal. noodles and 2 kinds of pastry with a drink(coffee or juice). You can avail the meal at the Po lin monastery. Afterwards you can enjoy ocean park =)

Terrific. We visited Lantau Island twice The first time was to Disneyland. Very good not as big as Orlando but good all the same. The attractions were well laid out and there were no big queues, fast passes were available at some attractions. We purchased two senior tickets and it only cost us £8 each for a day ticket. Very easy to get to using the metro and they have their own train which takes you to within five minutes walk of the park entrance. Eating in the park was very reasonable with loads of places to choose from. There are several new attractions under construction. I do think though that they could have made it much bigger as there is loads of land on Lantau.There is also a huge Designer Outlet Mall on Lantau.

Big Budha. Hold your cold drink, and take a big breath in before climbing hundred of stairs.The view is so nice up there.Before reaching never ending stairs you'll find some more attraction and also gift shops, ice cream corner and various restaurant. We also watch Shaolin Kungfu show in a stage near all the restaurant.

Homage to largest outdoor Bronze Buddha in the world. One can still find good hiking trails, grazing cattle in concrete jungle H.Kong. When I sent pictures of the greenery to my friends, many could not believe that I'm in H.Kong!Also, being at peace with the largest outdoor Bronze Buddha!

must visit. you must visit Po Lin monastery and enjoy a vegetarian lunch there overseeing the statue of Budha, also visit a traditional fishing village and so in a small trip out in the sea to observ the white dolphins.

Great adventurous route: by boat, bus, cable car and Disneyland. Our trip was December '10. Lantau island was a great adventurous trip for us. We took the journey starting from Wan Chai area in Causeway bay. First we took a boat trip crossing from Wan Chai to Mui Wo harbor in Lantau island. The boat harbor was adjacent to bus station so you just step in to the bus route to Ngong Ping (the Big Buddha). Along the trip was an uphill journey, you can see houses and how people of Lantau live and also see scenery of the bay from the height. Arriving in Ngong Ping, you can climb the stairs to the Big Buddha.After climbing the Big Buddha we took the cable car going down. As it was n December, it was full of mist and brought big sensation going down as you couldnt see the end of the cable. Our kids were thrilling and screaming but we enjoyed it. At the end of the cable station we took taxi to Disneyland. It is recommended to go to Disneyland in late afternoon as so can stay there until closing at 8 pm and you can see the great fireworks at the end of the day. The day was fully adventurous for us and very memorable. I highly recommend this route to everyone :)

Beautiful. Firstly the cable car to ngong ping village, the view was great. A nice and enjoyable 25mins. You can easily get wifi at the village. Climb up to see the Buddha. Take the different trails they have and you find that place really peaceful, away from the bustling city life. Taking a bus out of the island is pretty nice, to see the houses on the hills. This place is a must visit when you go to hongkong!

Glass Bottom Cable Car Ride alone is worth it. I spent the extra couple of bucks for the glass bottom cable car ride, and if your not too freaked out by heights, then its worth it, really a fun ride and worth it. The island is great with a couple of places to eat, and plenty of souvenir shops and of course Starbucks (they are everywhere in Hong Kong). Check out the monastery, while I was there a ceremony was going on, which was interesting enough, not over the top impressive but still interesting to watch. Burning incense and offerings are made and its great to get involved. Then you walk up to the Giant Budha, which is why people go there, and its nice, but the I enjoyed the cable car ride and town more, so that was an added benefit. I put this on the really should do list when going to HK.

Love it. I love this place. After coming to this place, I figured out Hong Kong wasn't only about buildings. I can also enjoy the nature in Hong Kong. To avoid long lines at the Tung Chung cable station, we decided to take a ferry first from Central Port then we took the cable car back down. Then we walked to the Tung Chung MTR station. It is closed by. You wouldn't miss it. It was no line at all. It always nice when you don't need to wait in line. I would say we both enjoy the ferry as well as the cable car ride. They were both very scenic and you can see different kind of views for different ride. We really love the Big buddha. To walked up to the Big buddha, you need to first purchase a vegetarian meal. I just got the cheapest meal which was around $70 hkd. The meals were not that yummy but it was acceptable. I think it well worth it for the great view of the big buddha.

Good place to visit and Nong Ping crystal cabin is a must. Visit the Lantau Island after New year, especially to Ngong Ping was not too crowded as on the weekend.arriving in the morning, and we had to wait for another 15 minutes (they open at 10 am) was okay for us, as we still can walk arround.Took a return crystal cabin is so great. Good experience too.Arriving in Ngongping having time there, then we went to Tai O Fishing village by bus, it is not a very special or extra ordinary place to go, but it is very relaxing and advisable if you have time.Took the boat trip only for 20HKD per person, is something we should try.No regret to visit Lantau Island

The Island you have to visit if you stay more than 2 days in HK. It is the biggest Island of Hong Kong 246 Islands, twice as big as Hong Kong island. You have many activity but first you are in the middle of the nature and far from the big economical city center!!! A place where a lot of Hong Kong people go to breathe during the week end. To go there from Hong Kong Island, you have to choices, either you take the metro with the Tung Chung line (orange line) and it takes 25mn to go to Tung Chung g or you take a boat from central ferry pear quay number 6 and it takes 30mn with a fast boat, twice longer with a slow one (you arrive at Mui Wo). If you arrive at Tung Chung you can go by bus (30mn) to the big buddha and Po Lin monastry (ngong ping direction) or you can take a cable car (ngong ping 360) and you'll have a very nice view on the nature, the amazing Hong Kong airport. If you arrive at Mui Wo, take the bus, the staion is located at a few meters from the pear.Moreover you have many hikes to do, you can do kitesurfing, Bike & VTT and some beaches are nice!

A must visit. Loved the quiet but modern life in the island with its idyllic beaches and of the course the PoLin monastery. Its a wonderful place to see with its fishing villages and the modern international airport both existing on the same island.

Well worth the day trip. First up the cable car ride across to the island is pretty spectacular, you have the option of getting a 'crystal cabin' which has clear floor so you can see directly beneath you. Be warned though, lines can be massive (not sure if we went on a particularly busy day) but we waited in line for well over an hour to get on a cable car. The only other alternative way of getting there that I know of is by bus, which takes about an hour.My tip would be to buy your tickets online prior to getting there. There is a separate queue for online tickets which was not busy at all and I wish we had done that. Or take up a package when you get there, I'm fairly sure they fast-track you to the ticket counter instead of lining up. Otherwise come later in the afternoon when there is hardly anyone going across to the island. The Lantau Village which is where the cable car takes you is a replica village at the base of the big Buddha and is a bit of a tourist trap in reality, but a good spot to get something to eat/drink when you get there. The big Buddha itself is incredibly impressive and quite a site especially from the base/coming in from the cable car.

A breathtaking journey. A complete traveling experience. It is a 30 minutes cable car crossing Hong Kong channel and some hills. At the end of journey you can visit a big Buddha statue. You various can also enjoy some good restaurants and of course, souvenir shops. The only place that I can buy snow globe of Hong Kong. You would not find anywhere else in Hong Kong, including lady's night market, and airport.

Spectacular gateway. This is one of the most scenic ways to see sides of HK from above. In all fairness, for this trip it's really the journey that counts, not the destination. Yes, the Buddha is impressive, but the views from its base are definitely nice. But what makes this a great attraction is the cable car trip, and the views from above.I wouldn't do put in in the Must Do folder, but not far behind if you have some time to spare.
A peaceful place. The buddha statue is amazing and place is very peaceful,the cable car ride is breathtaking, the view of the airport from the cable car is tool good

Best cable ride ever. We went to the cable car by MTR so that was easy. The cable car ride was incredible - we paid extra for the glass floor and boy was it worth it. The ride was very long and very good value for money. We really enjoyed it.Once there we walked around all the attractions and my son walked up to the Big Buddha as too many steps for me.A great trip back too - well worth the effort.

amazing. the cable car is amazing....well worth paying the extra to get a glass bottom car. the trip takes about 20 mins and is very steep and high. the view of the buddah from the cable car is well worth it

Fantastic cable car ride over the island. Cheap entertainment to the very top of the island, by cable car, the longest we ever rode. Splendid views over the forest and the China Sea, and over the mountains of Lantau island. The village at the top is pretty touristy, but worth if only for its massive buddah!Very active visitors can hike up from the cable car terminal up to the very top. Quite a hike!

Beautiful.. Its a must go. The landscape is beautiful. The NGONG makes it an great experience to cross the island.
And the Big Buddha is astonishing. If you're in Hong Kong you definitely have to go see it.

Outlet Mall. It is always fun to go to the outlet mall on Lantau Island.But lately it's been bombarded with a lot of tourist from mainland China. Can't even find a place to sit and have coffee without waiting for a table to open up, it might be only because i was there on the holiday season and everyone is crazy shopping

absolutely amazing, lots to do, you can even avoid the touristy stuff. when we went, we took the cable car and then went to the big buddha, and then had lunch at the vegetarian restaurant run by the monastery. The next time I go, I want to hike the trail instead of take the cable car. Probably the best thing to do would be to hike one way and do the cable car the other way, because the views from the cable car can't be beat except maybe by going to victoria peak to see the harbor. In any event, Lantau Island has more things than you can really do in one day, and even if you stay in the area where the big buddha and the monastery are, you can spend all day there. Totally amazing and I can't wait to go back.
Touristy but Good. When you finally make it to the Buddha and monastery it's worth it, but everything you see on the way is super touristy. I was glad I went here though.

Has to be the highlight. Begin with a ride on the crystal cabin. brace yourself though, if you have fear of heights. it is an awesome experience. When in the monastery, it brings such peace of mind just walking around, in silence and the cold weather. Dont forget to eat in the ramen house on the right side on the way back to 360 ride :)

Buddha Temple. A Must-visit place when you travel Hongkong. Take the cable car, its about 5.7 km long. We can see the entire hongkong city, ocean, airport, tall buildings, mountains. It will be awesome!

Amazing Experience. My family and I did a day trip to Lantau Island. We caught the ferry over from Hong Kong Island then the bus to the fishing village. It was such a contrast to everything we had seen before and it was a highlight of our trip. The locals are so friendly and the markets are beyond anything you can imagine with the dried seafood hanging from any possible surface. The boat ride is a MUST as it allows you to see the huts.

Lovely Lantau Island. It's really another world - calm, peaceful, After the Buddha and Monastery we went to the village of Mui Wo for a seafood lunch and walk along the beach. You can take the cable car one way and return to Tung Ching station by cab from Mui Wo.
Beautiful scenery . Worth the queue during new year. The scenery is awesome and the environment is really fresh.. Suitable for family trip.. But i think they might need more restaurants..
Great Escape!. Went to Lantau Island for a 2 nights trip. I love the quite place like Mui Wo, Tai O. The scenery is very nice, the locals are friendly and helpful.

Worth a visit. Take the ferry over to Lantau and then the bus across the island to Tai O, an authentic fishing village where the locals still live on houses built on stilts in the river. Ignore the Big Buddha unless you like tourist traps.

Returning to see the Buddha. I was in Hong Kong in 1986 when this was being constructed and wanted to see it completed.We were staying in Mong Kock and got the MTR to Lantau, unfortunately the weather was very cloudy while we were there. We got the number 23 bus up to the monastery which took about 40 mins and was comfy, i don't do cable cars and 45 mins in one was my idea of "hell". The Buddha was well worth the climb up to although the monastery is being renovated. Weather was so cloudy when we left we could'nt see the Buddha but so pleased we went. Cost us £12 return for travel for 2 of us from Kowloon so don't go on an organised trip for £30-£40!Coat needed in November but not that cold.
Buddha. I went to see the big buddha. You should be in a good condition to master the stairs to the buddha (on top of the hill). When you are here consider a visit to the fisherman village Tai'O.
Great almost secret beaches. Pui O and Cheung Sha beaches - with life guards, restaurants, camping and BBQ and play areas are perfect for young children.

My encounter with Asia. I went to this place 2 years ago, and it was my first encounter with Asia. It took almost 2 hours to get there, and once I arrived I had to get a jacket and a scarf, believe me it can get really cold here in December, but I'll never forget the peace I felt here. Climbing the steps to Budah was harder than expected, but it's really something you can't miss from Hong Kong. You can take the amazing cable car to get down to the city again.

Scenic view and a good cable car ride. The cable car ride is about 30 min and you will surely enjoy the thrilling ride where cable car moves across the sea and mountain. Climbing up stair ..448 steps up and down to the big Buddha statue will make you a healthy person..

Patience required to visit Big Buddha. It took us 2 hours to finally take our turn on the cable car ride that takes us to Ngong Ping. And another 1-1/2 hours to get back. Going to Lantau needs commitment and one must go early to avoid the long queues. However, upon reaching, it was lunch time so we enjoyed noodles at one of the restaurants and began our tour of the place. It's also worth walking up to Lantau Peak and enjoy the quietness of the place.
Disneyland. Few people you talk to realise that Hong Kong has a disney, it is so easy to get to as the public transport is second to none. Had a great time the parades were fantastic.

it's about how the weather can spoil everything. At first, about how to get there: you are to take the Tung Chung (orange) metro line and take off on the Tung Chung station (it's the last station of the line - you won't miss it). Then, according to the signs find the "Cable Car". The prices are: Standard cabin ticket: 140$/95$ (adult/child), Crystal cabin ticket: 180$/140$ . Strongly advise you not to waist your money if it's cloudy up there - you won't see anything. Much better to take the bus (it's only 35$ for the Lantau day pass for unlimited rides on all regular routes of New Lantao buses).About the trip: it's really great place to go, you need a plenty of time to explore it - and a good weather to help you. Giant Buddha is the one Buddha facing the East - the other monuments face The West. So, it doesn't have a lot in itself - let's speak about the scenery. It's very beautiful up there if there is no wind blowing your face and trying to drop you down - and the rain making all your clothes wet and cold :) such a great challenge for your health. Have a walk to the Wisdom Path - it's magically picturesque there. Don't hesitate and go to the Lantau island. And a tip for non-vegetarian people - don't even try you stomach to eat this vegetarian dinner or lunch, sorry - it's a waist of money.it's much better to eat in the village - there is even Starbacks - don't worry you won't be hungry.

Big Buddha. Went on the chair lift to Nyong village unfortunately the weather was not so good up the top ,I suggest even if it is fine at the bottom and looks a little misty at the top take a jacket or umbrella, it was quite cool...was nice strolling through the village all touristy of course but nice, we didnt buy a round trip on chairlift caught the bus (23) from there to Tai O fishing village down the mountain where we strolled through their markets although with the rain a little heavier by then wasn;t pleasant with umbrellas everywhere in narrow streets. Caught the No 1 bus from the bust station which takes you to the fast ferry back to Hong Kong, handy to have some small notes or change the bus driver does not have change you deposit money in machine, they also have senior fares which is half price (not that they are expensive ) Then if you are in Kowloon catch the Star ferry back. a good day trip.
Great place. The Big Buddha and the cable car are worth a visit. Make sure you get there plenty early and are prepared to walk for a little bit.

Great view. I visited Lantau Island on early Jan 2012. The average temperature in HK was around 10 C degrees and it was even lower when we finally reached the Big Buddha site. The view was very beautiful up there, a lot of green trees with a hint of fog. Better to bring umbrella as the weather quite unpredictable nowadays.

The Big Buddha. The tram ride up to the Statue was well worth the trip. It was breathtaking. And there are places to eat up there and there is even a walking trail that follows the path of the cable car.

Beautiful day trip!. Wow! This was a beautiful trip away from the bustling hong king crowds. We took the subway from our hotel in causaway bay to the end of the Tung Chung station & took a glass bottom cable car up to the top. Lantau is a beautiful, lush island. Definitely worth the trip.

The Giant Buddha statue is a must.. We took a tour to Lantau Island which was a great way to see the Island. The giant Buddha is well worth seeing as it stands above the surrounding area. The whole area had a tranquillity to it that is hard to find in the rest of Hong Kong. We ate in the restaurant and had a very nice vegetarian meal, as it was a set meal we didn’t need to try and order separate dishes that we were unsure what the content was! The cable car is a very interesting ride with good views over the surrounding areas, not the best if you are worried by cable cars or heights!

Worth to visit at least one time. It was my third time in HK and did not wanted to leave this time without visiting the Big Buddha. As we went the same day of our departure, we were running out of time but it was enough for visiting it. It took us 3 hours because we took a taxi from the airport where we left our baggage it costs about 20€ and it is half an hour journey. Visiting the town, for me it is not worth it, it is completely focused for tourists and you can even find an Starbucks. The Buddha is amazing and I would definitely recommend to go upstairs as it is only 10 minutes walking. To go down and back to the airport we took the telespheric. Not the glass floor which is a little bit more expensive, but the normal one. The journey was about 25 minutes and then we took a taxi which costed about 3€ to go back home.
must visit. the tram ride, the weather, the options of places to eat at such height and the scenery was all spectacular
Seafood. Alfresco dining with the freshest catch from the ocean. Take a hike from Yung Shi Wan to Sok Ku Wan. Experience fresh air and scenic sites along the way.

Nice get away from the city. I would of really like to see more of this Island but I was only able to do the cable car (crystal one) up to the big Buddha. The cable car was amazing but the big Buddha is more of just a tourest trap. No real history. Found out that it was just put up there in the 90's and a plaza was just built around it. I was hoping for more of historic value.

great cable car. well worth the half hour ride (and lengthy queue) on the cable car. What a brilliant view from up there. A bit touristy when you get there but not too bad. The buddha is impressive. If you don't like heights you can always try hiking up but allow a day, it's a long walk!

Good day trip. Good day trip to see the giant Buddha by way of the cable cars. Must ride the crystal car with glass bottom.
As it is a tourist attraction, if you mind being in crowded area, don't go. Otherwise, it was an enjoyable experience with the usual tourist trap gimmicks such as photo souvenirs, lunch, more photo souvenirs, etc.
Nice Island for an escape from the concrete. I like the temple, it is beautiful, the big Budha is nice too. Go by boat and take the cable car back to Hong Kong island.

very beautifull view could not miss cable car.... very natural view of sea,mountain & land via cable car.a beautifull island created by god with all natural beauty minutely designed & appropriately fitted in this island.
Roller Coaster. A complete contrast to HK - you could have been in the Caribbean or the Med' - great place do not miss the Big Buddha

My best day in HK. I loved the trip to Lantau Island. It was a beautiful sunny day in November. We took the ferry from Central to Lantau Island. There are two types of ferries one is the slow one (1 hour) and the fast one (30 mins). The price is the same. I enjoyed the ferry ride a lot. On Lantau Island as we got out of the ferry, the bus station was right there. We took the bus up to the Monastery and the Big Buddha. The bus ride was also something like an hour. The Island is beautiful, it is so green and peaceful cows are all around. Finally we arrived there (it is the last stop so you do not really have to worry about getting off). We first went to the Monastery and had lunch there. They had a very nice vegetarian menu with tea, soup, rice, tofu, vegetables and spring rolls (for HKD 70 per person). If you save your receipt, you get later a free entry to the museum up at the Buddha. The monastery was under renovation in November 2012 so we did not spend much time there, we rather climbed up on the stairs to see the Buddha. It is a tough walk up, but not extremely hard, I expected something much worse (as I had a knee problem). There are also many stairheads between the staircases where you can rest if you have to. There is also a massive handrail on all the way up and down so the whole thing is very safe. The Buddha is breathtaking. As we climbed up, we found ourselves in the middle of a cloud, which was also fantastic. After visiting the Big Buddha, we took the cable car. Honestly, I had some hidden thoughts about taking the cable car before, but it was just great. Cabins were safe and clean, the view was amazing. The cable car landed at a metro station, so it was very easy to get to home after this adventure. I do recommend visiting Lantau Island, the Buddha and the Monastery.

Lantau is beautiful but beware the rip off. Walking round the island is a delight with hidden beeches and interesting and luxurious flora and fauna but avoid the fish restaurants they display live sea food but you can only eat it for a huge cost (the price if displayed is per 47 grams so is misleading) If you have the expensive set meals the sea food is stale and badly cooked easily the worst and most expensive food we had during our stay

beautifull small island outside busy hongkong. we go there by cable car and beck to HK by bus, a beautiful experience all day, choose the crystal cable cabin, u will see a beatifull scenery at the top, big buddha and the temple is a main attraction here at ngong ping village, but don't forget go to Tai O village by bus, it's a traditional market with cultural traditional fishing village, for some people maybe it's dirty to be there, but for me, i like traditional chinese culture this is a new experience to see traditional market outside of modern Hongkong, after that don't forget to see pink nose dolphin with a boat there

We Saw The Big Buddha. Lantau is a beautiful Island! We went mainly to see the Big Buddha - that was well worth the visit. The main international airport is on Lantau too, so when you are getting the cable car to see the Buddha, you will have clear views of the planes taking off and landing, all while being suspended high about the ground!
Take the cable car to the Big Bhudda. Prepare for queues but a great day out. Monastery and Buddha are amazing; So is Tai-O fishing village. Return by ferry...

Great day tripper. Suggest going weekends, not as crowded. Take the cable car and the bus back to MTR. Vegetarian lunch was a bargain and delicious. Tickets can be purchased @ base of Tian Tan Buddha. Group of 4 was US$40 for 5 dishes plus soup. No msg. Nice climb up to Buddha. No worries, there's restrooms at top.

Great views. Well organised and easy to get to. Take the glass bottomed gondolas for a better experience. On a clear day the views are stunning. Plenty to see and do at the Buddha.
The walking path is a tough challenge.

Serine and peaceful. The area surrounding the Tian Tan buddha (Big Buddha) is a very serine and peaceful location which is surrounded by mountain forests, shear rock cliffs and ocean views. The surrounding area probably boast the most stunning and incredible landscape views I have seen so far in Hong Kong. The dichotomy of the tall rugged mountains and the views are impressive. The best locations to see these views are on the Wisdom trail and at the top of the Big Buddha. It's a nice trip to get the ferry over, enjoy a vegetarian meal at the monastery and visit the buddha.

Day out at Silvermine Bay, Mui Wo and a small part of the South Lantau Country Trail. We have no idea what we were heading for. So we left our SkyCity Marriott for Tung Chung via the provided shuttle bus. After breakfast there, we took service 3M heading for Mui Wo. We had planned to stop at Nam Shan to walk a small bit of the South Lantau Country Trail. Without fail, we missed the bus stop and ended up at the Mui Wo Ferry Pier. It was a mistake we did not regret. Mui Wo is rather scenic even though the day was dreary and threatened to rain and it did.We have come prepared and all of us have our rain jackets. This apparently became useless because Lantau has higher humidity and the jackets made us overheat badly. Good thing we have umbrellas!We then walked back on the South Lantau Road (uphill!) back to Nam Shan. It was tiring but we made it. The mists covered the hilltops of Lantau lending it the same "sea of clouds" phenomenon we see in Taiwan's Nantou region, in particular the Cingjing area. Nam Shan campsite has toilets and even vending machines which accepted Octopus cards. A welcome for the exhausted children who are energized and motivated with the sweet drinks. We then trekked up to the helipad of the South Lantau Country Trail and that is as far as we went.We then returned to Mui Wo via the Old Village Path (fortunately downhill). The path was made of stone blocks and due to the rain, became slippery. We were careful and made it to Luk Tei Tong Tsuen. It is the first time we saw a real Hong Kong village. It is rather modern with brick and mortar buildings. Tiled on the outside too! There are lots of cattle in this area and we threaded carefully to avoid the cow poo. Surprisingly the poo were also on the Old Village Path which made you wonder if the cattle walked used the path as well.We boarded 3M again and headed back to Tung Chung. It was quite an adventure for our young children and they would gladly do it again.

This is Hong Kong?. You feel like you have entered a vacation beach paradise. You can take the train here from Hong Kong station, then take either the tram or the public bus..... you can also take a ferry back.. great place for a day trip to see the big Buddha.

Go for the Big Buddha and Shopping. The Big Buddha was incredible - especially the journey via Cable Car. The outlet shopping centre near the MTR station was poor in my opinion as most products weren't reduced significantly. The Nike, Adidas and New Balance outlet stores were the best - but they're dotted around HK.

Worth the trip. We took the ferry to Lantau Island, was totally worth it. The Big Buddha is stunning. The view from the top must be breathtaking on a clear day. And the temple with its stone carved pillars was stunning.

Po Lin Monastery and Giant Buddha - must-visit attractions. If you are a Buddhist I strongly recommend this. You do not need to pay to see the Big Buddha, however, you may purchase a vegetarian coupon for entry into the 3 levels exhibition hall beneath the Big Buddha. The coupon covers a simple meal in the monastery and it is absolutely value for money in my opinion.The feeling you get when you see the Giant Buddha 'in person' is nothing short of awesomeness.

Head to Discovery Bay. Easy boat ride from Pier to Disco Bay and it's beautiful views of Hong Kong. There are many places to eat and drink in the Plaza where you can enjoy the views and watch the nightly fireworks display from Disney HK. There is a fantastic golf course reachable by bus from the plaza. Take a nice 2 hour hike from DB, past the Monastery and into a local village on the other side of the mountain
Such steep hills & dense flora.. The MTR ride to Lantau.The Outlet shops.The cable car ride - excellent.The big Budha.The bus ride from the big Budha to the ferry back to Hong Kong.

Lovely island. Lots to do if your have time but our main purpose was to get to the big Buddha. If y can take the ferry to Lantau then the bus but get the cable car back, it's the best way to get the cable car unless you like hour long q's

Well worth a day trip. We were here on a Sunday and although it looked packed we were on the glass bottom gondola within an hour. Very serene, scenic, and great picture taking opportunities on the gondola. When you reach the top and end of the line at the Big Buddha it does feel like Disneyland but it makes for a very enjoyable day out to see the Hong Kong people and tourists having fun. There is a beautiful temple there as well. Wouldn't have missed it.

must see. We took the MTR to get to the cable carts i wouldnt waste my money on getting in a glass cable cart as your not really looking down your more looking around at the views. When you sit down in there they take your photo which you can buy them on the other side but they charge you a fortune.But other then that its very beautiful and the monestary is a working one but you can have a look. A lot of people get caught with the meal tickets as they only sell vegetarian foods at a koisk and is much cheaper then the reaturant that sell you the same thing any way.

Away from the city. There is a lot to do here and it provides a good break from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong city whilst only a 20 min MTR ride away. Lantau has lots to do from Disneyland to Ngong Ping 360 home of the giant Buddha and monastery. All a must see.

Horrid tourist trap. We took the MTR to get to Lantau Island yesterday. Weather was so so. We bought tickets in as "crystal cabin" gondola (glass bottom) for the ride to the top. Weather was rather cloudy and windy but we had a nice view going up.Once we got there it was a huge dissapointment. They take pictures of you when you get on the gondola and try to sell them to you at the top like some cheap amusement ride. Ngong Ping village is a travesty. Subway and lots of other chain restaurants line the walkway to the Big Buddha and the Monestary. Horribly touristy with all sorts of cheap attractions. Then we hiked up to the Buddha, which was beautiful and grand. That;s when I found the construction pictures inside... the whole thing was built around 1986! I really thought this was an ancient statue, but that's on me for not doing my research.Overall the whole experience was rather comical as we laughed our butts off after realiizing how new this statue was. The Monestary was nice. HOWEVER... this is NOT worth goign to see. Absolute waste of time as you can see many nice small monestaries in HK. Don't waste a day, unless you like outlet malls, tacky souveniers, etc... blah.

Must see.. One place not to be missed in Lantau island is Ngong Ping 360. Never mind Disneyland, this is a view dying for more. The serenity of the place is so wonderful that you find some "very we'll" fed and behaved strays that just lazily lie on its pathway. In many ways they are like the pop stars with every tourist wanting a photograph of them.

Big Budha on other island just 1 hrs from Hongkong bay.. We need 2 use ferry 2 go 2 lantau Island or using cable car. There is 2 type of cable car..1 wid bottom glass.... U can c beautiful view under ur feet... so scarry....but amazing. When arrive Lantau I use buss till d gate of Big budha. There 268 stair 2 climb on top of Big budha statue... but I cant climb too much.... so Ijust took pic frm below. There is nioce restaurant on d top (some ppl said) n d view so attractive.... I feel regret not try 2 climb those stairs. The complex of Big budha statue is on d mountain, when sumer U need umbrella n jacket when windy. Its better U bring some food n water. U can find some food shops here but very expensive.
Great Hiking, Who Knew?. Take the public bus to Tai O, fun little village. Get a hiking map and do some trekking along the mountain trails -- but bring an umbrella, it can dump on very short notice.
Beautiful!. Train ride to tung chung, cable car to Ngong ping village, Tian Tan Buddha and Po Lin Monastery ...& a bus ride to Tai O fishing village, Awesome day to be had and stunning views.

A bit touristy, but you can't really skip it. Most go for the Po Lin monastery and giant Tian Tan Buddha. I go because I love being on the world's longest cable car (I think). Great views and often good company. Take the MTR to Tung Chung and a brief walk to the entrance. Spend the morning and enjoy it.

Long queue for cable car. We took the cable car up to Lantau Island on Friday morning. It took us over 1.5 hrs before we were finally on the cable car. The village is very commercial. The Buddha is pretty big but unless you get a vegetarian meal, you cant go to the upper floor in the buddha. The Monkey Tale show is not worth it, if you are just paying for the ticket. It is a cartoon. In terms of cost, we got the package for 140 HKD/pp which included a one-way cable car ride, a snack in the village, the monkey tale show, bus pass and short boat tour in Tai O. This is an all day trip. If you are looking for something to do, this would be suitable but I dont think that it is one of the must-see places in Hong Kong.

For nature lovers. Some moments it seems to me that Tai O village, Tai O Heritage Hotel and views from Ngong Ping cable car impressed me more than HK skyline, permanent city smoke and luxury boutiques.Only one tip: every of two days that we visited Lantau it was drizzly weather in HK but very sunny in Lantau. So take care of yourself and take a parasol or just hat to protect from the sun - there is no shade on the way to Big Budda.

Cable is the smoothest I have ever been on. Went to the Big Buddha Lantau Island. Caught a train from Central to Tung Chung Station, exit B. Train cost HK$24 each, one way. Walked to the Ngong Ping 360 Cable car station (2 min walk). Cable costs HK$125 each, for a round trip. Caution as a man was trying to sell cable car tickets for HK$100 each, just as you exit the train. His tix looked nothing like the tix we bought at the cable car station. So not sure if it was genuine or a scam. Buying a tix for the cable car took a while as at each counter they were trying to convince people to buy a package deal. (Cable car, boat trip & fishing village). We chose to go on a normal cable car (crystal cabin costs a bit more), but no thanks. Normal car was enough excitement for us. Impressed as no clunk clunk as you go over the towers. So smooth. Its a lovely scenic ride on the cable car. You can see the airport from above. Lots of natural bush land below you. Then you get your 1st site of the Big Buddha. When you reach the end, you walk through a souvenir shop and they have made up the photo they took of you as you got onto the cable car. We opted for the photo of us on a keyring. Other options available. You don’t have to buy, if you don’t want, but they do hassle you a bit to buy. Lots of souvenir shops line the path to the Big Buddha, and a few restaurants. They even had a subway food outlet there. Opted not to walk the 200+ plus steps up to the Buddha. The view was great from the bottom. Walked around to the monestary. Back to the cable car for the trip back to Ngong Ping village. Wanted to go to the City Gate brand outlets mall which is near the Cable Car Station. This place is shoppers heaven for brand named goods at cheap cheap prices.

Ride the cable car. The cable car between the mountain (where the big buddah is) to the railway station is amazing. It is the longest cable car I have ever been on with fantastic views over the mountains and the river. This is a must to do if you visit.
Big Buddha. Liked the cable car - except we were trapped in it for 25 min with very noisy peopleThe view was great!

Great island to stay. We had a 3 night homestay on lantau island, walking 20 mins from mui wo to a car free area of the island. Easy walks, take a bus, taxi or hire bikes.We caught the local bus from mui wo to tai o fishing village, wandered around looking at dried seafood and stilt houses. We took the boat out to see the pink dolphins. Bussed back to nong ping, climbing up to the buddha, very doable with a six year old. Cable car overland to tung chung, we just took the cheaper tickets, we could see plenty. Bus to mui wo, then back to our lodgings. We hired bikes the next day, exploredthe sivermine bay area inclding the waterfall and cave (closed), paths were all concreted, so easy to ride on.Mui wo offers great chinese food at the cooked foods area near the ferry, also turkish and brazillian restaurants. Two supermarkets and a great 2nd hand bookshop.There are ferries to central and other places from mui wo.We had a great time there before we hit the hustle and bustle of hong kong island.We visited disneyland at a later date

A nice day out, but you need tricks to avoid queues. We visited the Grand Buddha and the monastery which I find worth a visit, but we lost hours in queues for the cable car, even while it was a Monday.Tips to limit your queueing time:Book your tickets in advance via the internet: there is a separate line for pre booked tickets and while we were queueing, there was absolutely no queue for the pre booked tickets: people with pre booked tickets were able to walk through.If you haven't pre booked your tickets, go early (between 9 and 10 am)If you can afford it, buy Crystal bottom tickets: on the way back everyone already has a ticket and is treated equally, but the queue for Crystal tickets is about a fifth of the normal queue. The glass bottom does not really add much to the experience - I only recommend it to cut back waiting times.We had the deluxe vegetarian meal in the monastery (HKD 120), which was excellent. We had five different dishes and ate outside in the shade. The larger your company, the more different dishes you will be served.There is also a standard meal that will be served in the indoors restaurant (HKD 70)The village that you will have to walk through to go to the monastery and Buddha is horrible: blaring music and all kinds of show activities that do not really with the religious character of the site.

Nature Nature Nature. Tips for the cable car:Come early to avoid queuesBook your ticket in advance on line or with the big bus, to already avoid one of the 2 queues. Best is to book a guided tour, not so expensive.Then you have the secund queue to take the cable car itself: you can avoid it if you are quite late to be on time for the guided tour.This place is great. You really meet the culture and religion here. This is not fake, even if you have shops in addition. Take time to discover and enjoy.
Big Buddha. Amazed at the size and spleandour of the whole complex. The new build bit will be stunning when complete. Enjoyed eating in the set menu fixed price vegetarian food hall at the back.

Cable car ride offers some spectacular scenery. An easy trip to Lantau on the MTR.We proceeded to ride to the Big Buddha via the cable car, which offered spectacular scenery. The Monastery was quite beautiful. Regrettably we did not visit the fishing village. When we returned to the rail station we visited the City Gate outlet centre which provided some good shopping and a nice cafe inside to have good coffee. Overall a worthwhile day trip.
Fantastic view. The cable car ride was great as you travel all the way to the top. Try riding with the glass floor cable car. Exciting!

Lots to do on Lantau Island-Disneyland and Po Lin monestry. We caught the MTR to Hong King Disneyland on one day and the nextday went out to the cable car to the Po Lin monestry and buddah. There is an outlet shopping centre at the MTR station near the cable car and the journey from H. K on the train fast and efficeint
Good place for taking it easy. Mui Wo was a charming place with a nice beach, great restaurants and a peaceful atmosphere. It is less than an hour's ferry trip from Hong Kong Island

Big Buddha and Fishing Village Tour. We took a tour to Lantau Island to see the Big Buddha and the fishing village in the crystal cable car.... The glass floor was amazing and I am sure we all spent our time looking down. The Big Buddha was amazing as were the surrounds. Very spiritual and serene. Our meal at the Monastery was delicious and could easily turn any meat eater vegetarian:) A warning to the ladies....if you need to use the toilet use the ones at the entrance as the others are "squat spots"!!! Not a good look girls:) Our time here was too short as we were on a guided tour and had to head off to the fishing village..... The village is very much worth seeing as it is an eye opener..."do people really live like this in the 21st century"? To see dried turtle really made my stomach turn.. I love turtles!!! But to see the dolphins (alive not dried) sort of made up for that (not really) but overall a tour worth taking.
Big Big Buddha. Glass bottom Cable Car gives fantastic views, well worth the trip, did not like the queue. Book online in advance if you can for the cable car.
Look around, don't be afraid!. Be observant when you take the cable car across to Lautau island, get to catch sight of interesting sights up the sky, down the sea and on the mountain.

A view and a half. Take the crystal cabin ride over to Lantau, it is worth the little extra to see Hong Kong harbour under your feet. Be warned, book your tickets on line because the queue is a killer if you don't. It is the best way to get to Lantau. The island is lovely but the original quaintness has now gone.

Great visit. Cable cars are great, glass bottom cars are good. The buddha is worth the walk and the fishing village is very peacful and worth the visit. The cheap boat ride for dolphin viewing is fun, although the chances of dolphin views are slim though.

A Day Trip to Lantau Island. The cable car ride was breath-taking with nice views along the way... riding in the Cyrstal Cabin was cool as you get to also see the sea and the mountain treks. There are some shops along the way to buy some souvenirs, a cuppa from Starbucks and some food places.It's worth the effort to climb up the countless steps to the Buddha as another breath-taking view awaits. Vegeterian food at Po Lim monastery was good and the staff are very attentive.

So much and so little know about it... Lantau Island has got so much to offer. On my day trip I took the cable car in Latau Island to the big Buddha, and then we were taken to see some very authentic fishing villages, but I can not recall the name. Definitely worth a visit.
Largest island in Hong Kong. Mostly undeveloped and there are meny gems to discover. Surely the Po Lin Monestary. But other places are as interesting

A quiet respite. A great place to visit to escape the crowds and congestion of Hong Kong proper. The island has the feel of a small village with walking trails, a few shops along the one city street, and some good eateries. No cars are on the island. Access is by ferry.

Day Trip to Lantau Island. We just recently did a day Tip to Beautiful Lantau Island whilst Holidaying in Hong Kong. We arrived after a perfect Forty Five min. trip by Motor Launch from Hong Kong Central Pier.Theres Lots to see including Beaches, Markets, the largest Sitting Buda in the world if you are feeling fit enough to climb the 420 something Steps you will get Fantastic views of the Islandand the South China Sea. You must visit the old Fishing Village and take the Boat Trip which finishes by going outside of the Harbour to view Pink Dolphins, and yes we saw them and they sure are Pink.After finishingbthe Day we caught the 360 deg. Chairlift back across the water to the Mainland the views are brilliant.

Better Option Than Tung Chung Cable Car. Many travelers will be tempted to see the Big Buddha by travelling to Tung Chung and taking the cable car. Whilst this used to be the fun and easy way it is now a nightmare with 1 1/2 to 2 hour queues at the cable car. The best way to do this, a little longer, but certainly more enjoyable is to do the trip from the other end as it were. Simply take a ferry to Mui Wo on Lantau from Central, the number 6 ferry. Easy as jumping on a train, though you might want to check the timetable all on the web. Waiting for you at the arrival plaza is a bus to Nong Ping where the big Buddha is. The bus terminal is the furthest to the left. You will need cash or an Octopus card - around HK$18. It is a 30 mins journey through spectacular countryside. After doing the Buddha just jump on the cable car (near where the bus dropped you!) in the reverse direction, go to Tung Chung and MTR back to your hotel. The real pleasure is seeing the huge queues at the Tung Chung end trying to get on that cable car and knowing you just walked on at the other end. Make sure you only buy a one way ticket!! BTW the factory outlets at Tung Chung are a con job. Don't waste your time.

Do-it-yourself day trip. World's tallest outdoor seated Buddha, Ngong Ping cablecar and village, Po Lin monastery [excellent meals], travelling on MTR railway and the community bus back to the hotel [very cheap!]

my son lives here so had the advantage of a resident to show me the sights. liked it all and food was great. Loved having a beer on waterfront and seeing the sunset. Dinner at night gave me a view of the Disney fireworks.
Giant Buddha. Very easy to get there on your own via ferry or metro and bus and nice get away from the city to see the Giant Buddha and monestary.

Majestic Buddha and excellent shopping!. The star attraction of Lantau island is of course the tian tan Buddha. However we did some unexpected shopping at the outlet mall thats right next to the subway. My wife went home with some Adidas shoes that were a whopping 80% off!

big budda. just do it yourself it cheaper, easy to get there as HK is a safe place and they are helpful. Ferry to Lantu and then a bus to Tai-o village and then back to see the budda and take the cable cars back and do some shopping in city gates outlet and then ferry back they sail till late.

Lantau is Beautiful!. If you go to Lantau, I recommend taking the bus from Tung Chung and making a stop in Tai O Fishing Village where you can take a lovely boat tour and have a nice walk around before taking the next bus over to the Big Buddha and the beautiful monastery. The ticket price when we went was a great deal compared to taking the cable car up and down and just seeing one attraction. The Ngong Ping 360 deal is a total tourist trap so just get out of there as fast as you can!
Great place to shop. If you want really good prices on top brands, dont miss visiting the citygate complex just outside tung chung MTR.
Peaceful !!. We went to visit Giant Buddha by Glass bottom Cable Car to go to Lantau.. The land is very peaceful & has no pollution. Also the small trek to statue was very nice..

Touristy, Overrated, touristy. If you are planning on seeing Lantau and the Big Buddha, make sure you have absolutely done everything else you can possibly do and see while in Hong Kong and surrounding. The Big Buddha offers little in the way of history and the small Disney-like town that has spruced up beside it is nothing more than the most blatant tourist trap. Of all the incredible history, culture and personalities that inhabit this part of the world, Lantau's Big Buddha and said 'town' offer none of it, but an easy way to separate novice travelers from their money.
Giant Budha. The giant budha is amazing, had lunch at the temple, vegetarian and tasted wonderful, the statues the temples were wonderful.
Big Buddah. Worth the trip there. The Big Buddah did not disappoint. Did not have that touristy feel to the area at all.
the Buddha. Yep another must do. Take the train (MTR) to Tung Chung and get the Cable Car to the Buddha. Great to climb but not necessary. Nice afternoon if not to hot.

Home of Big Buddha. The Big Buddha is massive, 250 steps up but well worth the effort. Mid sized tourist plaza, good food and shops. Small but very colourful carnival show at regular periods. Took the cable car back about £8 but good value as is quite a long trip. You can see planes taking off from airport from the cars.

Nice trip ... but feels untrue. Lantau has some very interesting and some very fake sites to offer. Travelling up with the cable car is a great adventure, surely for the kids, but also for the parents when it is somewhat windy. Consider taking the extra cost for the Crystal floor, the view is great and the queue is a lot shorter. When you get to the top, the "traditional village" is nothing more than a commercial centre. The shows are OK, but if you are limited in time, they should be the first you should skip. Walking to the monastery is worth the trip and when you really have got the courage climb to the giant Budha. The statue is even more impressive from close by and the view is great. Jump on the bus and experience the thrills when the driver races down the mountain, just know they do that all the time and hope the brakes are in good shape. Tai O fishing village is a mix of traditional and touristic, but in fact it is one of the single ways to make a living for those people. We did not see the dolphins, but the boat trip was also firn without them. Have a good meal in one of the local restaurants and return by bus to the ferry terminal or the MTR station. Particularly around closing time of the cable car this is a good idea as the queues at the top station are very long at that time. The Sea-Air-Land day pass offers an interesting program and is easy to use, but we had the feeling it was more expensive then when you would buy all elements separately (but then you must be a bit more organised yourselves)

Not enough time. Decided to book the Lantau Island Day tour (bus, ferry, bus, cable car, bus). As we weren't staying at a hotel on the pick up list, got up early to get to a hotel for 8am pickup. Ended up transferring to another bus after pick and circling around for and hour and a half before we ended up at the pier, just a short bus trip from our hotel. So if you are staying on Hong Kong Island, meet at Central Pier. The tour was too fast and not enough time to spend at the Giant Buddha and lunch with the monks (only saw one!) Lunch was rushed so we could get to the cable car in time to leave. The Cable Car ride was amazing and if you are okay with heights pay the extra for the glass floor one. Visit to a local fishing village included and this was an eye opener. Local guide was terrific. Extra hour at the Giant Buddha would have been appreciated.

Cable car and Big Budda is amazing. Use Mtr (orenge line) to go to the island. Ä°t takes around 20 minutes. After you get off the mtr you should follow the signs to the cable car. Ä°t is very easy to find. Cable car is really amazing. Get a crystal cabin. The view is great since the bottom is glass also. Though in the begining you feel like falling down but the you get used to it. There was a veeery long que on the cable car. Ä° didnt want to wait that long. So i took a bus (no11) and went to Tai O first which is a small village. Ä°t smells like fish bait because there are lots of dried fishes. There you should take a boat ride to see the stilt houses which is interesting. The ride is 20Hkd for 20 minutes. 1 hour is enough for the village. Then i took bus no 21 to Ngong Ping village. Big budda and the po lin monastry is very nice and impressive. Ä° can not say same things for the Ngong Ping village. Ä°t is very artificial and veeeryy touristic. So i passed the village quickly. And reached the cable car. There i understood that i did the right thing not to take the cable car in the morning because there was no one at the que. Ä° bought my ticket and get on the cable car within 5 minutes max. After the cable car i went to Citygate Outlet and did some shopping. Outlet was also nice. Then went back to central by mtr again. Conclusion: Cable car, po lin monastry and big budda you must see definetelyCitygate outlet and tai o village you should see. Ngong ping sucks. You fell like you arrived Disneyland but no Mickey and no fun at all

breath taking experience (April 15, 2011). Lantau Island in Hong Kong is definitely a must-see destination....There you'll find the giant outdoor buddha named as Tian Tan Buddha.... Riding in a cable car was a great experience....It overlooks Hong Kong Airport, gigantic mountains and the wide blue ocean >>> the Pacific Ocean i guess!! I had so much fun visiting that place...Best spot for the family and friends who are looking for adventurous tours.... Actually, there are so many interesting places to see inside Lantau Island... And am dreaming that someday my family & I could hang out there... ^_^

Lovely Lantau!. This has to be the most wondreful counterfoil to the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong Central- and its only a 25min ferry ride away. The ferry takes the traveller from Pier3 Central to the newly refurbished ferry station in Discovery Bay. From here walk across to the Plaza- there are good shops, bars and restaurants here. Colouful plants and flowers line the way. Everywhere is pristine and attractive. For a bigger shopping experience buses run through the tunnel to Teung Cheung. From here it is easy to catch the cable car up to the Big Buddha but do go early as the queues for the cable car are long to say the least. Climb the steps to the platform below the feet of Buddha. The view is well worth the steep climb! The temple close by is impressive as well. We ate our picnic in a peaceful area shaded by trees. Allow a full day for this as there are also some interesting tourist shops on the way back to the cable car.There are plenty of footpaths on Lantau to attract walkers and a Disneyland which lights the sky with fireworks each evening. A vast contrast to Hong Kong island.

Great day away from the hustle of Hong Kong. We had the hotel pre book the cable car which was a great help. Once you exit from the MTR most people head for the cable car station and this creates a huge queue but with the pre book you sail up the empty aisle. The only thing is that the actual queue getting onto the cars can take about 1 hour so be prepared. Option would be to go for the crystal cabin but not a great idea if you are scared of heights as you are really high up.Once the it is a pleasant stroll up to see the Big Buddha, 250 steps to climb so perhaps go on a cool day.The village itself is very touristy and quite expensive.

Bus route is also scenic. As it was windy and raining we opted for the bus route to go to Lantau. It was a great experience which we did not expect. Forests on both the sides, with a glimpse of mountain peak and the sea shore intermittently is a feast to your eyes. The fare is 80% percent less than the cable car fare.
The big Buddha. This was a great escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. The tram ride was beautiful as was the view of and from the Buddha. The Monastary had a certain peace about it.

Hong Kong October 2012. This was a fantastic day trip. worth the travelling. It is very clean and staff friendly. The cable car ride there was scary as not keen on heights. There was no rocking at all, even better. There was a smog around but still could see around, would be great if was clear as can see miles around. Was good value for money. I went to see the bronze Buddha, fantastic. Next time I will go to see the Monastery.

away from the noise Hong Kong. You can get there by subway from HK Island or mainland (orange line, destination Tung Chung). After you get off the subway road signs will direct you to the cable car station. It is quite expensive but deffinitely woth trying (can be bloodcurdling if you have acrophobia). Amazing view on the hills and airport! What you need to see is not only the impressive statue of Tian Tan Buddha but also Po Lin Monastery located nerby (at the moment being renowated). If you have more time, go to the bus station (a few minutes walk down from the statue) and take the bus to Tai O (fishing town). Its stilt houses give an impression as if the time has stopped there many years ago. From Tai O you can take a bus directly to the subway station. All the places are marked in English and it is really not possible to get lost. The Lantau Island is a perfect place if you want to take some rest form the noisy Hong Kong.

Landau Island and Buddha. We went on an afternoon tour from Hong Kong through a tour company. We travelled by crystal cable car to the Buddha and this was a fantastic trip. For the village we were driven up to the Buddha which again is impressive and there are some pretty spectacular views from the top. Back on the bus and down to the montestry which was OK for a few photos. Then free time at the really horrible "touristy" village - made me think on Sentosa in Singapore. Then we were taken to this fantastic fishing village which was really interesting...complete with some very strong aromas! The bus trip back was long with lots of twists and turns....then the classic stop... the bus needed petrol so a bit of a detour and delay. Quite a scream .... this huge tour bus stopping for petrol ....you'd think this reputable company would have arranged it a bit better. Still all in all and interested and fun afternoon.
Entertainment. This island is where the entertainment is! There is the amazing cable car, Disneyland, countless hiking trails, one great outlet center, so on!
Disneyland. Wow! Amaizing... but the long queues are definetely a negative for the location. Best option would be to get a two day pass and preferably select week days.
LOTS TO DO. There is a great shopping area out there that is a bit like DFO. Very cheap. Also, went on the cable car ride up to the big Buddha statue. Good views and lots of gift shops.

Awesome. A must do trip if you are in Hong Kong. the Buddha Statue is awesome and a good climb up to the top is well worth it. There are plenty of organised tours to Lantau Island, which can be a bit expensive, but it is very easy to make the trip yourself using the fantastic Hong Kong public transport, and a lot cheaper too.

to Commercial. the cable car ride was great except for the wait in line(1 hr) the view is great but when you get of the cable car you have photos shoved in your face and asked to buy then you have to walk through a gift shop to get out in the "street". the you will be confronted with "BUDDA WORLD" shops for a hundred meters or so with gift shops, starbucks ,etc. walk to budda is good but can be stressful for the unfit. the budda itself is ok except for the giftshops directly underneith the temple itself id good. We were expecting a more relgious and cultural experience but were dissapointed with the commercialism of it all

Try to avoid weekend and pre-book your cable car ticket online. The temple and Buddha itself is worth for a visit. However, we reach there around 10am on Saturday and it took us almost 2 hours to queue up for buying the ticket. We can't see what's in front and can only queue, else we will just take the bus which cost so much cheaper. Can choose to descend with cable car instead because it was less crowded when we leave around 3pm++. If insists want to take cable car, better purchase online ahead. It cost us HKD180/pax to and fro, looks more expensive than stated on their website. Except for the temple and Buddha, the rest are just too commercial. The long cable car trip does have a spectacular view, must try at least 1 trip!
Simply stunning views and well worth the visit.. An amazingly beautiful place, unfortunately a little to comercial when you are walking from the cable car. Shame because it doesn't need to be.

Lantau is what you make of it.... I visited Lantau as part of a tour to attractions around the island. When I booked my tour I knew the Giant Buddha wasn’t built in some ancient era in a primitive way; but that doesn't take away from how impressive it is to visit. Something that I particularly enjoyed about the island was visiting Tai Po (fishing village) and one of the beaches. This really gave me a sense of the daily life in Lantau, which I always like to witness. Sure the base of the Buddha is laden with various shops and vendors, but you can take something beautiful away from your visit if you take time out to walk around a bit and appreciate the natural beauty of the island..And of course, the glass bottom cable car ride back down the mountain is quite the experience! From souvenir-seeking tourist to intrigued people-watcher, a visit to Lantau island is definitely what you make of it. I definitely recommend visiting Lantau Island to supplement your trip to Hong Kong!
Must visit place in Hongkong. Don't miss the Giant Buddha even if you're not a Buddhist.. It's a very peaceful place to got to. About 30 mins by bus.

Great way to get out of the city. After a few days in downtown Hong Kong, we needed to get out of the city. We decided to take a trip to Lantau island. We didn't go witha tour, but took the subway there. It was extremely easy and cheap to get to. From the subway we took the cable car up to the big Buddha, then went on the wisdom walk. The whole day took about four hours, and I highly recommend.

Lantau Island.. A fabulous place to visit with only a short easy train ride from Central. Glass bottom cable car is an awesome experience with an approximately 4.5 km ride with 360deg views. Spectacular experience to ride up over the mountain and see the Big Buddah sitting on the side of the mountain. A truly wonderful experience and a must do if visiting Hong Kong.

A really good day trip. We took the ferry from Central over to Lantau - it's a really pleasant 50 minute journey over and you can take some fantastic photos from the boat of Hong Kong Island. If you have an Octopus card you can use that on the ferry rather than paying for a separate ticket.When we got to the island we got the number 1 bus to Tai-O. Most people tend to head straight for the Big Buddha so we found going to Tai-O meant that there were less queues. The bus ride takes about 35 minutes.Tai-O is a traditional market town and well worth a visit. You only need to spend a couple of hours here though. Most of the houses are on stilts and make great pictures. The market is known for its fish (dry and live) and there are a few stalls that sell really nice looking street food. There are a couple of temples that you can walk to but they're not spectacular so you wouldn't be missing anything too much.It's worth taking a walk along the water and seeing the metal houses - they're quite strange and most of the time the doors are open so you can have a quick peek inside.Near the start of the market are a series of little waterside bars - after you've done your sightseeing and are waiting for your bus it's worth having a beer or a tea in one. It's a nice way to spend half an hour.We then took the number 21 bus over to the Big Buddha which is great. The photo opportunities are fabulous. You only need to buy the $28 dollar snack package (rather than the full VIP food package).The museum is next to pointless unless you can read Mandarin but there are some nice little gift shops.The Monestary is very impressive and worth spending some time in there.The food you get with the $28 dollar package is surprisingly good - a decent sized and tasty portion of noodels and your choice of accompaniment such as spring rolls.From the Big Buddha we took the cable car over to Tung Chung MTR. It's a fantastic ride, although very high so if you suffer from vertigo you might want to avoid it. The views are fantastic, remember to look back and take a picture of the Buddha. You go really high and get great views of the airport - even planes taking off and landing.The ride lasts about 20 minutes. The train takes you all the way back to Kowloon or Central so you have a great round trip.
budha. saw it 10 years ago, a temple and the Budha, now it looks like a theme park, glad I saw it before the cable car and shops were added
Lantau Island. The chairlift up the the big Buddha is a must...views fantastic..then visit the Citygate Shopping Outlets...great bargains

Excellent travel by cable car. It is worth to take the orange line to Lantau and spend some time in the cable car and visiting the buda temple. For an additional pay Imwould recommend the crystal floor cabins: you willl enjoy the views on the botton and you will avoid queues, as most people take the regular one.There is a long and maybe hard trail along tne island that takes walkers thru very sloped areas ( you can see some parts of its way from the cabin. It seems to habe very well maintained woden and stone ground. If i'd have time, maybe I'd follow it.

Fascinating. Worth a visit, particularly the Tai O water village with its Houses on stilts and fish shops. Trip to the Bronze Buddha at the To Po Lin monastry is a must, and the vegitarian lunch is really nice. Take a trip back down on the Cable Car, great views.
very much geared to the tourist,. Used to be less commercialised but still worth a visit to see the out skirts of HK. Can take the aerial tram too, which does offer a great birds eye view

Finally made the trip and it was worth it. While Lantau is a bit further away, the glass bottom cable car ride offers beautiful views (you can go by road instead if you don't like heights). The huge Buddha on the top of the island is absolutely amazing. Take some me to walk around the area. The paths will lead you to some really beautiful sights.

Nice break from the main city, but an unnecessary hassle.. Consider spending more for a pre-booked, organized trip to Lantau. Even in shoulder season we waited hours in the cable car queue, and the local bus line was even longer. Visibility is not much better than from The Peak, and the site is horrendously touristy. However, we enjoyed climbing to the Buddha and spying on the airport from high above. Lantau is a good choice for a short visit to Hong Kong, but given this information in advance, we would choose to go elsewhere.

Cable car is a must, but once you get there.... Such a tourist trap... Fake history, fake heritage, fake village, fake experience...nevertheless, you need to go.The cable car is simply awesome, what a ride!!! What a fabulous piece of design and engineering that is. It is worth paying a few more dollars to go on the glazed car, since the floor is... made of glass and such experience is unique. The trail wiggling below the cable car is a beautiful sight from above. It is amazing to notice that, the cable car goes on and on, further and further till you may finally spot the Budda.Once you arrive deception might hit you, as hit me...it's such a fake environment created in that village.
