The tibet-like-architecture offers some shops and even a Subway, how appropriate and coherent :)The statue is indeed impressive, but please note that was actually erected in the 90s, which configured the fake historic environment I referred to above.If that doesn't bother you, just go!I'd go again, but knowing that the cable car is 75% of the fun.

Must do!. Brilliant half day trip. Great cable car ride, and the giant buddha is amazing! Go on an organised tour though, which is good value. Also, the tour guides get priority treatment and you avoid the enormous queues.

See the buddha!. You can get all the way to Ngong Ping by metro then all you have to do is walk across a shopping concourse to the cable car station. The cable car ride takes about half an hour as it hops between islands and you get to see the airport also. On arrival in Lantau you walk through a serious of tourist souvenir shops and can then buy a ticket (£2.80) to climb all the stairs to the buddha. The ticket gives you dim sum lunch also - two dishes plus noodles and a cold drink so very good value!

Hiking. Brilliant for hiking. Always take a map (maps from Government Office by Peak Tram Terminal) and compass and wear great walking shoes or boots. Main walks are signed on trails. Take as much water as you can carry. Do not drink from streams unless using a recommended water filter for Dengue Fever.Walking season is late September thru mid March. The Typhoon Season is about June to September. Late Typhoon is possible though. Weather on TVB Pearl is after 1930 news just before 2000. Always check the weather and pay special attention to Fire Danger Warning. Never set out on a walk if you are uncertain about conditions. Mobile technology may not work in remote areas.

Lantau Island's beautiful scenery. Lantau Island should not be missed with it's mountainous scenery. Bus service is frequent, cheap, and easy to navigate for any English speaking person. Tai O Village, Moi Pu, Po Lin Monastery, and the cable car are all interesting & scenic.

A nice getaway from Hong Kong. This place is a very nice getaway from Hong Kong for a nice daily trip very natural and organic place, with good sea side view.
Easy to get there

Green Hong Kong. Many places to visit other than the giant Buddha. Tai O is a nice fishing village, and for those who would like to go to the beach in Hong Kong, Lantau has some great places too!For those who have a late flight out of HKG, put your luggage at the B2 of the Tung Shun Shopping Mall and take the bus to the airport after this. Only 15 minutes away!
Big Budda. Get the MTR to Tung Chung, then the cable car to the Big Budda, wonderful views and an excellent trip, well worth the wait queuing, go early morning first thing to avoid the queue
Very Nice Place. Very Nice Place to Visit including Big Budha, Cable Car, Beaches.Very Good Natural Views as well. Close to Airport and Disney Land.

An awesome day trip. Spent an entire day on the island with my family including my grandparent and her sister. There was a lot to see on the island including the big buddah, and taking the NGong Ping 360 tram. It was a little crowded the day we went but it was okay because there was plenty to see so the lines werent terrible. The views from the tram are unbelievable. The only downside, is the tram is known to have mechanical issues so it occasionally closes to repairs. If you are planning on riding the tram, make sure it is running before you head out on your trip.
WOW. So amazing.. Did an afternoon tour across to see the giant buddah and visit the monestary. Well worth a trip. Lots to see and great photo opportunities

Great day out. Lots to do here including beaches but many people (me included) come to visit the monastery & huge Buddha. Both of these are recommended, as is the vegetarian meal at the monastery - included as part of the 70HK dollar ticket to the (small) exhibition underneath the Buddha. There's also a deluxe meal for about 100 or 110 HK dollars but the basic meal is huge & tasty.These places can get really crowded so try to get there early. If you want to escape the crowds the Nei Lak Shan country trail is a short (5.7km) circular walk that starts near the Tea Garden. This gives great views & is much less busy than the short 'Wisdom Path' walk.

Great Day Out. We visited this island to see the Buddha and even though the village is a bit touristy the Buddha is well worth the visit. The other attraction which is a must is the ride on the cable car. When we arrived on Lantau Island by ferry we hired a cab to go village and it was an experience driving on the winding roads through the mountins. For our return we decided to go on the cable car which was a breath-taking experience. This was a terrific day's outing away from the crowds in HK

The Huge Budha is awesome, but the Village looks fake. The 25 Minute Cable Car Trip was okay, the Crystal Cabin (transparent glass floor) was breathtaking and worth the extra fee. But the Traditional village houses at Lantau Island wasn't like what i pictured. It looks fake, not to mention no native stayed there. Those villages were literally built and designed to look like Traditional village. Those so-called traditional houses are shops selling lousy souvenir and knick-knack. From the drop off point of cabler car. It was about 10-15 minutes walk, there wasn't interesting photo spot until you reach the big Budha.

Very Close. Must do Po Lin Monastery and Tai O stilted fishing village. The queue for the cable car was long.
We did this trip for a fraction of the "Guided tours" price and was stupidly easy to organise.

Crystal cabin to Buddha. The view through the glass bottomed cable car was very impressive and amazing to see so many people walking the tracks through the dense sub tropical rainforest. The climb up the stairs to the temple and giant Buddha was hot and tiring but absolutely worth the effort. I was in awe of many old and fragile looking people who made the trek, inspired by their commitment.
Nice walk. Nice cable car, nice big Buddha lovely shops. If you want to buy something in the shops don't think you will find it elsewhere, you may not find it again. Just a couple of hours is enough

Good to relax!. Fed up of the hustle and bustle of the city life in Hong kong go to the nearest island Lantau Island, about 30 minutes boat ride, the boat are cozy and clean, the staff can speak English. Lantau island is impressive there is even McDonald 24 hours service.Many tourist from all over the globe, the prices of the rooms are a bit expensive, but it is worth it, the beachfront is long, and very clean, there are staff maintaining the beach, they are accommodating and friendly can speak English too. They say that there is a giant Buddha in the island but i was not interested to see it.Had fun and i was really enjoyed my stay. There are clean bathrooms, restaurants and beautiful flowers all over the place.I will go back again for sure!
Ngong Ping 360. The Crystal cabin is a waste of money. Take a Standadr cabin for you Cable car ride from Tung Chung to Lantau Island

Great half-day trip. Highly recommendable to book the cable car online, and not at the venue. We saved ourselves over an hour wait! Awesome views, though I felt bad for the poor monks who were so crowded...

See the Pink Dolphins from Tai O. The dolphins really are pink - it is quite exciting to see them as they are so different from other dolphins you will have seen. You can go to the fishing village as a tour including the Giant Buddha. The fishing village now makes its living as a tourist draw showing how it used to be - selling all sorts of interesting dried fish. I don't think there are many fishermen left, but it is worth supporting their economy by visiting.

disney's island. airport, disney, ngo ping, big buddha, there many tourist spot in this island.can go to citygate for food and shooping, there are many brands open their outlet here with cheaper price compare to other mall

Very nice view. Starting in the Citygates Outlet, get the cable car to Lantau. The views are spectacular.In Lantau you can go directly to Giant Buddha or walking around the village. There are some restaurants and a Subway there.The ladder to Buddha is a big challenge, but the view is a must see!
Great place. Nice and quiet,maybe the nicest place we visited in Hong Kong. We really enjoyed our visit there.The cable car was a bit too expensive but it was worth it

Terrific Day Trip. Awesome cable car ride enhanced with views through the glass floor. Fishing village was great to see but the drying fish were a little stinky so don't linger too much. Buddha statue visit and Buddhist Temple were a worthwhile experience too - although the stairs to the statue can be tiring. Stores are so-so, in my opinion.

Big Buddha and more. What a great day. Did one of the day trips which included tai o fishing village, vegetarian lunch which was amazing, big Buddha and the cable car. Scenery was amazing and the sky was clear and did not have the usual hong kong haze. Loved it.

Big buddha tour. Lovely island. I am not a vegetarian but thoroughly enjoyed the lunch at the monastery. Tour guide said shops were dear but we found them comparable to the markets. I am of the opinion if you see something buy it there and then. Recommended tour. Unfortunately the cable car wasnt working when we went there it was under maintenance.
Hong Kong's Venice. Unspoilt. Cuaght the ferry over and on our way to fishing village spotted water buffalo. The fishing village was amazing with buildings built on stilts over the water

worth a visit. Lantau Is is worth a visit because of the cable cars, the big buddha and the spectacular view going to the Island. We got the tour (glass bottomed cable, fishing village tour and big buddha tour) which is good value and skips the long queue. I love the fishing village the scenery is spectacular. However all other facilities - the lantau village, temples etc looked to commercial to be authentic

Peaceful, beautiful, and fun. On a free day from our guided tour, my friends and I easily took public transportation to Lantau Island and then the cable car ride to see the great Buddha. Fun, affordable, and absolutely breathtaking. The climb up to the Buddha was worth it as the Buddha and the views were amazing. Also great, the shops and restaurants nearby. Even those in our group who didn't really want to go said it was one of the highlights of our trip. The whole area just felt peaceful and is not to be missed. We spent half a day there because we also went to Disneyland(close) but I could've easily spent a day there.

Take the cable car for a fantastic ride and views. It is certainly worth taking a day off to go by the Cable Car to Lantau island and leave the hustle and bustle of Nathan Road and enjoy the hills and valleys of Hong Kong en route Lantau. In the peaceful Po Lin monastery a vegetarian meal is good value. If one is inclined Hong Kong DisneyLand is also nearby.

Stunning and Peaceful. Beautiful, quiet, green and peacful with amazing views of islands dotted all over the coastline. There are restrictions on vehicle numbers on Lantau, which is great for your sanity! The Giant Buddha statue, Nong Ping and Tai O fishing village are all must see attractions on your visit.

Lovely day out. A great day out away fro the hustle of the city, a quick trip across and you arrive at a little haven with plenty to see, good foodand drink and a tidy little beach...though if you jump into a taxi and head to the other side of Lantau, you will find a far better and bigger beach with beautiful sand and stunning scenery.

Beautiful!. This island is gorgeous. There are a lot of hiking trails, ask your concierge for maps. If not into walking, take the cable car. It's super easy to get to from Hong Kong or Kowloon. BUT I highly advise you to book your cable car tix in advance. The line ups are LONG, over an hour wait. We breezed right by everyone with our prepaid passes :)
Amazing views from cable cars. We loved the cable car ride although just took pictures of the Big Buddha from a distance and didn't bother walking up the steps (I think you had to pay)

half day tour. Just come back from Hong Kong and did many tours, one being Lantau island for aprox 6 hours. We were picked up from the Hotel on hong kong island and taken by bus to Koowloon by Gray Line with a tour guide that spoke very good english, transfered to a larger bus and then there were about 20 on the tour. We were driven from Kowloon city centre area past the cargo shipping terminal with the guide pointing out all the points of interest and statistics of the area, he was well informed and past his knowledge on to us, narrating all the time with interesting infmormation of the country side we were travelling through, we crossed over to the island on a bridge.We were taken to the Nkong Ping cable car terminal and one has the option of travelling in a standard cabin or for $100 HK dollars extra ( aprox $12AU extra you can travel in a crystal cabin which has a clear glass floor) which we did the extra being well worth it. You travel for 5.7km and offers visitors a spectacular 360degree panoramic views, including in the scenery, Hong Kong International Airport, Lantau National Park and the Giant Budda, we were on the cable car for aprox just over half an hour. From the terminal the other end we then went to Po Lin Monastery "Budist Kingdom of the South"this site is a pilgrimage visited by Buddist from all over the world.From there we were driven up the hill in the bus,"one can take the 100 odd steps up to the Budda " but we opted for the bus we were travelling on, here it parks in the car park and one only has to negotiate aprox 15 steps. There are 3 floors beneath the Budda The Hall of Universe, The Hall of Benevolent Merit and the Hall of remembrance.inside is a relic of Saykyamuni,consiting of some of his alledged cremated remains. Then from there we went on to Tai O fishing village, also known as the venice of the east,seeing the village's stilt houses on the water front,showing the striking contrast with the modern city, while at this village we walked through the dried fish market, which had very strong smells as one can imagine, but very interesting.During the whole tour there plenty of bathroom facilities and option to buy drinks and food.. From there we were taken back to our Hotel which took aprox an hour due to peak traffic in Hong Kong, a great day enjoyed

Brilliant ride on the cable car. Easy to reach on the MTR. Great ride with amazing views, especially in the Crystal Cars. Take a walk in the woods at the top - totally different from the usual HK experience.

Loved it!!!. We found out the sky tram that brings you to the island breaks down all the time. But that was after we had already visited:). Be that as it may, I would highly suggest visiting Lantau island and seeing big buddha if you ever are in hong kong. From a historical and cultural perspective it's an incredible stop. Some will say its too "touristy". Don't let that stop you. Bring your shades and some water, and I assure you that you won't be disappointed.

A side trip away from the busy city Lantau. Despite knowing the cable car was down for maintaineace, we took the kids to visit Lantau island. We traveled by mtr to Tung Chung and changed to the local bus which cost us HK35 per person which takes you everywhere on Lantau island the whole day. The bus ride through the mountains takes around 50 minutes to Ngong Ping. The entrance fees up to the Buddha cost HK 28 per person which comes with a visit into the statue and some snack which includes tau foo fah and some desserts. After that, we continue the side trip to Tai O, a small fishing village nearby. There were many stalls that sell seafood, we took a ride on the boat to see the village. Something very different from the busy city life. Worth a side trip.

Lantau Island. This island is the largest outlaying island in Hong Kong, almost twice the size of Hong Kong Island. More than half of it has been designated as Country Park area. Its tranquil and green environment makes it a popular spot for nature's lovers and hikers. There are many attractions on the island including, The Ngong Ping Skyrail, actually a cable car which takes you up to the Lantau Peaks and the Ngong Ping Village in around twenty-five minutes where you can see The Big Buddha.Considering it's size Lantau island has a small population of around 45,000, compared to 1.4 million on Hong Kong Island. On our most recent trip to Hong Kong we visited one of the residential areas Discovery Bay located on the south east coast of the island. It has a current population of around 14,300 residents from over 30 different countries, giving it a reputation as an expatriate enclave. Good beaches, lots of restaurants and a twenty minute 24 hour ferry ride from Central make it worth a visit.

Very Busy on the Cable Cars. The Big Buddha was worth the rather long queues to get on the cable cars! The cable car trip itself gave great views and was the longest cable car trip I have been on! You need to get away from the 'disney type' set up at the top of the cable car with restaurants and music. After seein he Buddha take the walk to the Knowledge Trail and viewing platform for a quieter more enjoyable experience.
Very nice and culturally rich.. The Biggest Buddha in the world - impressive. Cable crystal cabins - just WOW. Temple and life on the island is very different.

Lantau Island cable car trip. Well preserved fishing village. Took the 360 Ngong Ping cable car to Lantua Island. It was a pleasant ride. The village ws well preserved with shops selling sea products. Po Lin monastery is located on the same island. I world famous giant Tian Tan Buddha is awesome.

Buddha is awesome!. The Buddha is like nothing we've ever seen before. A great view and a marvellous sculpture! Ngong Ping is a great little town with lots to do to keep you amused all day. Fabulous food and shops as well. Definitely worth a trip up.
Lantau Island-take a side trip to visit. I went on a tour to Landau Island, went to Tao O, the fishing village, then to Big Buddah, and on the tram down. It was a great experience.

Wonderful vistas, pleasant atmosphere.. Reaching the cable car origination point is a snap by MTR. Once you overcome the que for the cable cars, you are rewarded with beautiful vistas of the Island as you head over the mountains to the landing plaza. We highly recommend taking the glass bottom gondola. When you arrive you'll find yourself in a well maintained shopping plaza with several places to grab some refreshments. What appear to be touristy shops actually contain some good quality gifts at decent prices, but save your shopping until you scale the stairway up to the Buddah. It's an arduous climb but reaching the top brings a sense of accomplishment. Amazing views surround you at the base of the giant Buddah. I'm sure you'll take many photos whilst on top of the mound. This was a reasonably priced "must see" excursion while in Hong Kong!
Big Budddha. You have to see this! The cable car is expensive, but it takes about 30 minutes, plus the Buddha and the monastery are worth a visit.
Hike across the island. Take time (and water) to hike across the highland and finish with a meal at the Rainbow Restaurant - 1st class. We stopped and had a swim at the beach on the way round!

soso for us. if u not yet going to lantau mayb this is good for the first time travellers..the island nothing to shout for us mayb in our country we got a lot this kind of island like langkawi, pangkor even. We have manage to eat the a po taufufar after 20 minutes walk but still not yet enough attracted us to revisit again, we may try changzhou next round

great half day trip. We took the 360 cable car instead of taking the bus to the mountain top, very nice view on the way to the top and it took almost half an hour. A china historical market place are located right next to the 360 cable car station. Great hiking to the giant budha and after we went for a budha meals close-by (very good price cost about can $40 for 5 of us). Still, we haven't explore the whole lantau island yet. Next time, we must spent a day or 2 to explore the whole lantan island.

take the tour. great guide, explained everything clearly. This is a way of life that is slowly disappearing. From humble fishermen to the giant buddha. The rail car is worth the money fantastic view of the area and the airport. Not that keen on the tourist trap shops you have to pass through to get to it. If you can use someone other than Grayline, their drivers are the pits.
Peaceful relaxed island. I lived there for 10 years, it is the best part of hong kong. Good food nice beaches and many monasteries, great hiking.
Lantau Island visit. Amazing cable car, very high. We arrived about 11am and only had a 5 minute wait.Incredible engineering to build the Budha so high up on a hill

Great views, good shopping, giant buddha!. We took the subway to Lantau Island which was quick and efficient, very easy to navigate as signs are in English and Chinese. On arriving, it was a short walk from the station where there are shops and a good post office (will understand English request for stamps!) to the queue for Ngong Ping 360 cable car.As mentioned in other reviews, there are two queues - one for those who have bought tickets and one for those with tickets. There are also another two queues though, one for the clear bottom cars and one for the normal bottom cars. The clear bottom (Crystal cars) queue ran much quicker so it was well worth the extra price. You get your photo taken when entering the car so be ready! We got ours done on the way down and it was luckily very soft focus so purchased it in the form of a snow globe. You can get keyrings and various trinkets with your photo on at the shop at the bottom and the top.There is a good variety of souvenir shops and a Starbucks in the shopping complex near the Buddha. I found very good quality gifts here and at much more reasonable prices than in the town. There is also a lovely tea shop selling traditional tea sets at very reasonable prices. I bought a dragon set at a fraction of the price I had seen similar sets on the main Island. Hubby walked up and around the Buddha whilst I went shopping and recovered from the cable car trip (I'm not great with heights and the car goes very very very high!).It's great to watch the planes take off at the airport below from the cable car. There's so much to see here so allow an afternoon or morning for your trip and if you don't fancy the cable car, you can get a tour bus / bus up on the land side
up to the highland. liked the big budha and the cable car. a clean place,picture friendly.cold and eco friendly.a nice wide park.

Ngong Ping 360. A good experience to take the crystal cable car across the sea and also some low mountainous area. The view is excellent and you can even see the runway in Hong Kong International airport. It is cooling especially towards November and December in Lantau Island. The whole journey will take around 30 mins and if you are travelling in a group of 6, it may be worthwhile to purchase the set tickets which includes the show and entrance to the exhibition at the Big Buddha.

Giant Buddha. As with all of Hong Kong, it's so easy to get to and it's fun to take the ferry. Getting tickets was a confusing process as there were 2 queue, 1 that seemed to be for people with tickets and the other for people who did not seem to have tickets yet. We joined the queue at the ticket office but were then offered tickets by a staff member. The cable car offers magnificent views over Hong Kong and surrounds. The Buddha is majestic, looking out over the highest point. For visitors who have not been to a temple, the Buddhist monastery offers a chance to go and look, although this one does not have the beautiful gardens one often sees at temples.

Get away from the city to see a more rural HK. Take the ferry from Central (outlaying islands) to Lantau. On arriving you will be at the Ferry / bus terminal in Silvermine Bay. Busy at weekends! Take the bus to the Budda or just have a walk round and sample some more traditional Chinese food from the many restaurants. The beach is quite large and busy at weekends. The Silvermine Bay hotel offers accommodation and food. Totally different to the city and only 45 mins away on the frequent ferry service. See a differant side to HK.

What an island. It's the island you land on as it hosts one of the best organized and modern airports. On the other hand you can visit few sight seeing places such as the Big Buddha statue or go for a hike with great sea views. There is also Disneyland (have not been there yet) and a large expat living area (DB = Discovery Bay), but if you stay there you cannot drive a car...

Loved our day tour. We had an extremely small group. We loved our guide, it was very relaxing. Shame about the pouring rain when we stopped at the longest beach on island. Wow how fantastic is the gondola ride!!!
Excellent tour onto island. We had a day tour leaving Hong Kong via ferry and coming back via cable car and bus. The whole experience was really good. The big buddah is really worth seeing.
nice drive. nice views of islands/ocean/bays driving around island. pretty. not what i expected. worth the trip.

Something for everyone. I have visited Lantau a number of times as I have family in Tung Chung. I always find it a relaxing and enthralling place to visit, much of the Island is a preserved national park. Maybe I have been lucky but I have never found crowds or lines a problem, although we do tend to set off early by habit.I can't comment on the value in the outlet mall, that isn't my thing, but I love Ngong Ping, although I go up by bus as cable cars terrify me. The bus is scenic and inexpensive way to travel. The Big Buddha is amazing. Tai O and Mui Wo are also worth seeing.There are many fine places to eat and of course the Disneyland resort park too if you have kids.

GETTING GIMMICKY. The factory outlets are by far NOT cheap to shop in. You will do better in Mongkok or even TsimTshaTsui or Shuen Wan or Tshatin.The Buddha area and lands end at Taipo is pleasant. Two extremes, i.e. lots of people and less people. You must expereince both to appreciate it.

Real China. Lantau to the north now has the airport and Disneyland but I would suggest getting the ferry from Central to Mui Wo (Silvermine Bay). Mui Wo is well worth a wander around and there are many walks out from the town into rural Lantau where the scenery is beautiful and you can see fields being farmed and buffalos. A stroll along the promenade by the beach is lovely and if you carry on to the pagoda there are splendid views.If you wish to go to Po Lin monastry where the Buddha is then get the bus from opposite the ferry terminal. There is a regular bus and an air conditioned bus, i suggest the former as the driver has to turn the air con off to get up the hills anyway. There are many walks over this side of the island so do check them out, i remember there were some good ones from Pui O which the bus passes through. Certainly a day on the island is worth while.
whole place was awesome. the trip on the cable car was scary & adventurous . great buddha and the whole place is worth seeing

take the Ngong Ping 360 early to avoid the crowd!. I'd been to the island before by ferry and this was my first time by cable car. take note that it closes at 6pm, because we got there at 5:30pm and they told us we could still ride the cable car, but we'd have to return right away upon reaching Lantau Island. we just went shopping at Citygate Outlet mall instead! :)woke up bright and early the next day, Saturday. we were on the cable car by 9:30am (they open at 9) and there was no queue at all! plus, we had the whole cable car to ourselves! if you're not afraid of heights, the upgrade to the Crystal Cabin (see thru floor) is totally worth it! the Big Buddha is a short walk from the cable cars, passing through the old-style village. the Wisdom Path would've make a nice trek too (2.5km according to the map), but we were flying out that day so we had to head back. we made our return trip by cable car around 11am and each car that passed us was full of tourists! and when we arrived at the station, the queue was sooooooo long! so come early, leave early. spend your time shopping at the outlet mall! there are some great bargains there! :) i wish this were a review of hiking on Lantau, but i'll save that for another trip!
Good sight-seeing.. Go up on the cable gondola - see the big buddha - come down on the bus, and take the ferry back to H.K.

Ngong Ping and Tai O. The usual caveat here is to arrive early and avoid the crowds, the ticket line is massive by 11am. The other little trick is to go with one of the offered 360 Tours, the touts will take you out of the line and escourt you to the ticket counters.

Great way to spend a morning. It takes a bit to get there but it's a very nice way to spend a morning. Mostly if you have that extra time in Hong Kong and already saw the usuall attractions (downtown HK, star ferry, etc.).Take the MTR and then the cable car. The cable car takes about 25 minutes but the ride is beautifull. If you're not afraid of heights, choose the glass floor ones.And if you're into shopping, there's an outlet just between the MTR station and the cable car entrance.

Impressive. We took the cable car up to see the giant Buddha. It was a long wait to get on (over an hour; we went mid-aft.), and almost as long to come back. Our tickets were supposed to be fast-track; I'm not sure - they seemed to get us in a faster line once we got up the steps from the 'landing' area where you get off the subway. We took the subway from downtown Hong Kong (Kowloon) and it wasn't difficult. I think just one change of subways. Inexpensive, too. The view from the cable car was spectacular. At the top there was an area where there were periodic demonstrations - the day we were there it was of martial arts. Lots of shopping and food stores. Then you pass an outdoor 'market' on your way to the Buddha. He is impressive. You can walk up the steps (lots of them!) and go around the platform he's seated on. You can't really see him from the platform though. We didn't go inside the building at the top, but apparently would have learned some interesting information if we had. Great view from the platform.
Not to be missed. A wonderful spot for pictures, for walks and strolls. very special place for enjoying great views. A bit far from Central and Tsim Sha Tsui but worth the time to visit
Lantau Island in the Rain. Rained the day we went, but that made it that little different. Suggest if it is raining you purchase the cheap plastic rain covers rather than an umbrella.
lantau island. very nice island in Hong Kong, got to see the big/giant Bhudda even got to climb in very long stairs just to get close in the Bhudda. visit March 2005

The big buddha alone is worth the trip. I have actually been there twice, in 2003 and 2011. The first time it was great, the second time, much less (because of such rain and fog that only the buddha's toes could be seen....). Besides the Great Buddha and the neighbouring temple, I would recommend to have a walk in Tai O to get a glimpse of the traditional lifestyle of a fisher's vilage.

Good for redeye passengers. Hotels in HK may not allow you to check in until 14:00 or later. What to do if your flight arrives early morning? Put your cases into left luggage at the airport and take a short bus trip to the base of the Lantau cablecar. Enjoy the fresh air whilst getting over jetlag, browse the monastery buildings before it gets too humid, then lunch on the island before taking the high speed rail link to Kowloon and the main island. An inexpensive and gentle start to a trip to HK.

Good day out. Take the MTR to Lantau, then the cable car to the Big Budda & Po Lin Monastry. Buy the Cable,Land, Sea ticket (HKD240) & make sure you specify the Crystal cabin on the cable car. The view through the floor of the cabin is worth the extra. It's a steep hike up the stairs to the Budda, but worth it. Then take the 21 bus to Tai O village. Walk the laneways & you'll find a lovely little cafe on the water, playing great lounge music & order a cold Tsing Tao, dim sum & kick back & relax.
The Cable Car.. This is a real treat and choose the glass bottom car.. I will never forget the ride . Beautiful and we took great photos from there.

Astoundingly scenic. The glass bottomed cable car ride was worth it in itself, we saw the monks riding over the mountainous terrain on their bicycles wondering how long it must take them to get to the monastery. Once there the giant buddha is majestic, the area surrounding it idilic and the monastery busy but for an history lover like me really interesting. The views from the seated buddha site were really amazing we all really loved it even our two small children. They loved the butterflies and surprisingly climbing the steps. If you go to Hong Kong do visit this and the extra payment for a glass bottomed cable car for us was a must when we go again we would not hesitate visiting again and would not quibble over the difference in price for the glass bottomed cable car. We visited in May 2010 not 2012 but could not go back that far.

Excellent Place to Visit. We had an excellent visit at the Buddha. The statue and museum were very interesting and made for some great pictures. We went to the restaurant while there as well. Great food...although vegetarian. Check out the vendors in the area. Not overbearing at all and will let you browse in peace. Business picked up and bargaining was a bit harder after the monks came around and blessed the vendors and their products. We took the gondola back to the bus station. A fun way to get back and see a bit more.

Lovely Lantau. Well worth making this great day trip. We did a tour to see the Big Buddha, Ning Cable car, fishing village etc. great idea if you have limited time as the tour bypassed the waiting lines. Nice change from the concrete jungle that is HK

A Brief Trip to Big Buddha. Had a few spare hours on the last day of a business trip and decided to do something I had not done before and took a ferry to Lantau Island to go and see the Big Buddha.Advice from hotel was to catch the train to Tung Chungon Lantau but I wanted the ferry experience one way. Advice was to catch train to central and walk to Star Ferry Pier. I forgot to ask which exit so that was first delay. Got there in the end but as I was time challenged a taxi would have been a better option for me.The ferry trip was great and it was good to get out of the city and the hustle and bustle and get a different perspective of Hong Kong. There were some birds that joined the trip and flew along behind the ferry diving for fish. Once I got to Lantau Island another flaw in my lack of information was that I did not know I had to catch a bus to Tung Chung to get to the cable car and there was no information at the terminal to give you this advice. I walked to the Silvermine Resort which was pleasant but wasted more precious time only to be told about the buses. Back I walked.There was a taxi waiting at the taxi stand back at the pier so for $135HK I got the driver to take me to the Big Budhha. The taxi driver was very nice and gave me some information on the drive that I enjoyed.The island has a very relaxed feel and there is still evidence of a traditional life. The Big Buddha was great and very pleased I made the effort to go. Caught the cable car back to Tung Chung and then the train with just enough time to pack and get back to Lantau by other means to fly home.A recommended trip if you have a few days in HK and more time than me to enjoy the experience at your leisure

One island - two ways of experiencing it!. Lantau is the largest island hosting the Airport, Ngong Ping and Big Budda among other attractions.Two best ways for visiting it: MTR to get right to Ngong Ping terminal, this gives you great views from the cable cars as well as access to Big Budda and the monastery.Another less considered option is a ferry from Central pier, this gives you a chance to experience the island's sceninc hiking trails, seafood restaurant and less touristy spots.

Great experience. The queues to travel on the cable car are very long, best to book a tour then you go straight to the front. We paid HK$290 each for a 3 hour tour. The tour included cable car return trip, bus trip to a fishing village with a sampan ride, visit the Temples & Buddha.

Great service but... again this was a good tour - only down side was that everything was a but rushed. Would have been nice to spend more time in teh Buddha. Also, some guidebooks in different languages migth be helpful
Amazing. Lantau Island was absolutely beautiful! The big Buddha is amazing and we had a wonderful vegan lunch on the mountain (The Buddhist monks don't eat meat).

A must-visit when in Hong Kong. Lantau Island is connected to the hustle and bustle of the city via the MTR and municipal ferry systems. We began our journey in the morning on the MTR and took it all the way to the Ngong Ping 360 cable car stop (about 30 minutes from Central Station). Next we took the cable car up to the Big Buddha and Po Lin Monasteries. When we were finished there, we could have taken the #21 bus to Tai O fishing village but the wait would have been 45 minutes. Instead our family of 8 took 2 cab rides down that took about 15 minutes. Upon arrival in Tai O, follow signs to take you away from the transportation area and into Tai O proper. When you're done sightseeing and buying items from the vendors, take the #1 bus to the ferry terminal in Mui Wo. There are two kinds of ferries from the Mui Wo terminal to Hong Kong Central. One takes 30 minutes and the other an hour - the slower one is slightly better for sight-seeing but both are efficient and take the Octopus card. There is a coffee bar and restrooms in the boarding area.

A must-see in HK. Accesible by subway or ferry & worth the trip from Kowloon. We took the cable car up to the buddha, which gave us great views of the area. At the foot of the buddha, there is a cute street with lots of souvenir shops as well as a tasty veggie restaurant at the Po Lin monastery. The buddha itself is breathtaking & much bigger than I imagined. Worth the trip.
MTR Service. Stayed at the Sky City Marriott so travels were with shuttle bus, MTRs, buses & taxi. On the whole the service is very efficient. Am very impressed with the transportation.

A little escape from the city. When you look for a perfect way to escape the hussle and bussle of HK and HK island, try to take the Ferry to Lantau Island. It has many places to visit and with the Big Golden Buddha overlooking the entire island you are bound to be watched over.It can provide you with nice nature walks, Disneyland HK and ofcourse upon arrival you will land on HK International Airport located on Lantau island. The cable car ride to the Golden Buddha will be a great way to overlook the island and see the airport from an unique perspective.Give it a try....
Great day out. We did this using a tour and we had a great time, it is a lush area rich in culture and would recommend it to anyone visiting HK

Awesome. Lantau Island is among one of the must see in Hkg. It is very well organised right from buying the tickets to the entire island set up.the fact that there is no time restriction to finish seeing an particular section in a stipulated time is great. See what u want, at your own pace. The Buddha is truly beautiful and over whelming. Just make sure u carry rain gear and have appropriate footwear. Buddha help if it it rains and u have to deal with soaking clothes and wet shoes... a real dampner in every sense. The cable cars are wonderful and can make some great photo ops...Have fun... Oh yes food, is kinda limited with choices, so if u like u may carry your food.....

Easy fun way to see Big Buddha. This is a quick easy trip that isnt too crowded. We took the subway and it's easy to get from the subway to the cable cars. When you get to the counter to purchase your tickets you can tailor your trip based on what you want to do.

Well worth a visit. Put aside a day to visit. We got the MTR to Tung Chung and then got the Crystal cabin cable car to the top - the wait was only about 25 mins which was less than I expected - we got the Sky pass which included the cable car, a all day bus pass, dolphin boat ride and the Monkey Tale entrance. The kids loved the crystal cable car and although it was hazy going up it was impressive to see the Buddha in the distance. Once at the top the Ngong Ping village was full of shops - my 15 year old was happy with that and bought a few bits - can recommend the 'Ding Ding candy' from the food shop - wish we had bought more!We decided to walk up to the Buddha first which was great - take it slow, there are lots of steps although beautiful views on the way up so an excuse to catch your breath and take photos. We walked back down and went to the Monkey Tale show - it is really a moral story told by three monkeys - it was nice to sit down in air con but would not have done it if my kids had not wanted to see it. The Kung Fu exhibition is well worth seeing - lots of oohhs and aahhs - very impressive and would be happy to watch it again. We got the bus then to Tai O and got the boat out to see the pink dolphins. If you get this as part of your ticket you need to walk through Tai O a little bit to get the right excursion - the first few boat excursion sellers are quite rude and were a little taken back when I spoke back to them in Chinese.  The boat trip is worth it - we saw a few dolphins which really made the trip. I was last in Tai O about 20 years ago and it has changed a little since then but well worth visiting. All in all a great day - tiring - where comfortable shoes and take plenty of water - would really recommend!

Mehh... don't expect too much history or culture. The village itself is just a huge tourist trap filled with shops such as Starbucks and various resturants. The Giant Buddha was constructed in the 1980's i do believe so there's little or no history behind the monoment, The monestary was plesant and colourful, yet still overtly touristy. All in all, the island (or atleast the Buddha and the surrounding area) is just a huge torust trap, be advised!

Biggest Budha. For the first time we visited the Budha. We travelling on the cable car, crystal class so we had a glass bottom. it was fabulous. Thoroughly enjoyable day. Must be fit to climb the stairs though, but well worth it when you get to the top.

Giant Buddha vs Cable Car. Visiting Lantau Island to see the Gaint Buddha is worth the visit. But the line up to ride the cable car to the Gaint Buddha was a 2 hour wait. My suggestion is to take the number 23 bus up to the Gaint Buddha. I'm not sure if you can purchase a one way ticket at the top to ride the cable car down. You are not missing much if you don't ride the cable car.

Disneyland and Buddha. I thought the Island was lovely and very green. We spent our first 3 nights at Hollywood Disneyland Hotel. It was wonderful with shuttle buses running constantly. We came back and went up to the Buddha which we should have just stayed longer and included it while we were there. It was lovely and very worth doing if you like to get back to the history of Hong Kong and enjoy the scenery.

Big Buddha is watching you. Though not malevolently, of course....but he does dominate the scenery. After an easy commute by bus from Lantao Airport (the number 13) to the monastery (it was definitely better than hanging around there for hours for my flight), I was struck by how an atmosphere of tranquility manages to pervade, despite the crowds. Climbing up to the Big Buddha is of course a must, even with vapour clouds obscuring him. A wander round the monastery itself afterwards was also rewarding and there is a good tea room with a selection of dishes. Definitely recommended.

A little piece of calm in Hong Kong. Lantau is the place to go for a much slower pace than can be found on Kowloon. Lantau has it all, good hotels, great shopping at Citygate, Hong Kong Disneyland, Ngong Ping 360 and the Tian Tan Buddah and the Po Lin Monastry (the last 3 can be reached either by bus or the Cable Car.), the very old village of Tai O(which can be reached on the No. 11 bus from outside TungChung Metro Station on Lantau). For those who love hiking Lantau is also the place for you as you can take the hiking path which runs under the Cable Car route to Ngong Ping 360. Nearly forgot the great restauants on the island as well.

Big buddha, cable cars and tai o village. Great place to spend the day. Too many things to see and do. Mtr to tung chung then short walk to cable cars. U can also take the bus up. Ferry can get u to lantau as well then a bus to big buddha at Ngong Ping. Ngong ping is where you can spend about 2-3 hrs or more if u do the walking trails, climb up to see the big buddha close up, catch a show or two. There is shopping of course as well a variety of foods from lamb kebabs to garlic bread..vegetarian meal available up the 280+ steps. Buy meal tickets at the bottom of the steps. If u are taking the cable car back down, u must b back in the terminus by 6pm, so plan out your time well. Note that lines are huge to buy tickets but a separate line for online ticket pickup..no line, no waiting (note online booking must be done at least one day in advance..this is advisable as u can save yourself a couple of hours waiting in line). There is bus to tai o (rural fishing village), also to mei wu (? for ferry) from ngong ping. I found tai o an interesting place (lags behind the rest of hong kong) and u can go out to open sea in a boat excursion n if u r lucky u can see the pink dolphins. Of course, there is disneyland which was low on our priority.

Well worth the time. On a hot July public holiday afternoon, we wanted to escape the crowds and the heat and did both by riding the cable car to the top to see the Bug Buddha. The trip itself is well worth it even if you don't spend much time at the top. It was easy to get to on the Metro. The cable car ride is about 20-25 minutes each way and there is a lot to see on the way up. There were so few people, we got a cable car to ourselves on the way up (without paying the private car surcharge) and shared it with another family of 4 on the way back down. Good clean bathrooms too at both the bottom and the top. We enjoyed the views of the ocean and the mountain and were glad we took this side trip.

worth a day. The Big Buddha is very commercial but worth the detour. The fishing village Tai O is very pittoresque. The markets but also the walk along site teh coast to see the housing is very interesting. All this connected by a great bus system.

A must do. Our tour company (and there are many) picked us up from the hotel and drove us out to the cable car on Lantau Island. We were met at the other end and driven to the 'Big Buddha'. It is huge and really worth seeing. By using a tour company you bypass all the many crowds waiting in line. We then visited a local seafood market and monastery before catching our fast ferry back to HK island. Take bottles drinking water with you and some sandwiches or similar-saves time and money when on the island. Wear comfortable walking shoes and apply some block-out.
A Peace of Tranquility. Its the place thats almost serene, away from the bustling city, to a part of Hong Kong, that most tourists never see.
Nice day out in old Hong Kong. loved it great exsperience, big day, plus you get picked up at the hotel

Going there with cable car best part. If you are not afraid of high places then this is your destination in HK. Take cable car and enjoy from views. VIllage is also very nice to visit but not so spectacular. I can recommend.

visit the Buddha statue by cable car. visit the Buddha statue by cable car, don't forget to visit the monastery and have a vegetarian lunch. that's more healthy and interesting than the international eateries you will find on you way to the statue.
Big Budha place. Breath-taking bronze Budha sculpture. Very nice for a day-long family trip.
Wonderful tour. Great places to see...big Buddha...temples fishing village and wonderful bush

amazing!!!. The cable car ride to the island was the hilight! U can spot the big bhudda from a mile away, it was beautiful and tranquil. Be sure to carry a hat and lots of water if u are goin in summer. There are stalls which sell them if u do forget.
fantastic. beautiful. well worth a trip. take plenty of water and sun cream!

love it here. wow this is a good place
try NOT to come here weekends
weekdays - much better
a very nice island
a must
"Wonderful". This is a day trip from Main Island Hong Kong. Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery are the gems of this Island. A must visit in Hong kong.
Ride the aerial tram. The aerial tram ride from the MTR station to the "Big Buddha" is definitely worth it.

Over developed, over populated - was over it!. I did this trip 13 years ago. Its easier now, more sophisticated and more comfortable. But its lost its soul. The train trip is easy. The monastery has been renovated. The cable car took more than an hour to line up for and then you are sandwiched in for 25 minutes in groups of 10. It was much better when it was a big trip - ferry, bus was uncomfortable, but the place was not over run. Its like the reconstructed Great Wall. If you like to feel HK then don't go here. Also the fishing village used to be a beautiful little village that was a mission to get to. Now its part of "the package." We didn't even bother after seeing how commercialised this area is. Don't waste a precious day in HK on this.
Worth seeing in a day trip.. You can get the real feeling of Chinese traditions and anjoy the tea ceremony in the village. The bronze Budha is definitely the to attraction there and a must see.
Lantau Island. The cable ride was quite and experience. well worth the ride. The Temple and the Budda are really amazing. Well worth it
The Country side of Hong Kong. Fantastic seafood and scenery of green. Very different from the HK island skycrappers scene.

Fantastic Day. Went there by ferry to Mui Wo and took bus no. 2 to Nong Ping. The Po Lin Monastery is a must. The walk up to the big Buda is taxing but if you buy your meal ticket first the entry to the museum there is free. The meal is a must. Vegetarian (I thought YUK) but it was the best meal I had in Hong Kong. Well worth the money and a great experience.
Great day out to see giant gold Buddha. Took the train and then a bus up to see the giant Buddha and the monastery there. Great day trip and took loads of great photos.
Disneyland of course !!. Went only to Disneyland and airport here. Love Disneyland. Got no chance to visit NgongPing 360 here, which was famous. Too bad. :(

Ngong Ping 360 - the gateway to Lantau Island, Hong Kong. the most memorable cable car trip to the themed village of Ngong Ping is a must visit attraction when in Hong Kong. Take a cable car from the terminal near Tung Chung MTR station. Queue for the general cabins is very long. So, if you are not cash strapped, ask the assistant manning the line for Crystal Cabin, and immediately you get VIP treatment. They help you buy the ticket, and take you to the boarding area without having to wait long. The best part of the Crystal Cabin is that it has a glass bottom through which you can see the world passing by. You feel like god. It is an amazing experience in itself.The journey to the island offers some spectacular views all along. The view of the giant sitting Budhha from the cable car is beautiful. Once you reach the island, the themed village welcomes you with a plethora of attractions. You can buy t-shirts, gift items, various kinds of food, souvenirs, etc from many shops that dot the village. If you buy the package tour to Tai O fishing village, there is a bus which takes the tourists to the village. Tai O is a very old fishing village with stilt houses around Tung Chung Bay. You can take a stroll through the village market, visit the old temple and take a speed boat ride for half an hour which takes you around the village. It is worth visiting. Especially for people who are interested in photography. But, please remember to get back to your bus on time,as it quite a distance from Ngong Ping.Once back, there is Po Lin monastery and the giant Budhha sitting on top of a hillock. The Budhha is best photographed during the first half of day, as the sun sets behind it, and you might not get a good shot in that light. While returning, please remember that there is a time limit for the cable car, and you must reach the terminal at least 30 minutes before the last departure. For a day trip, it is worth the money you spend.

Nice day out. We took the MTR to Lantau then a bus up to the Big Buddha. Incredible views at the top, over-commercialized at the bottom in the "village". Afterwards, we took a bus to Tai O and really enjoyed strolling around the village. There still remains some pockets of authentic village life before the onslaught of tourism. Interesting houses on stilts and great photo-ops.
Giant Buddha!. Not Buddhist, but it is a great piece of art work. I also had the vegetarian meal at the monastery, which wasn't that great, but I was glad to support them.

Loved the Giant Buddha. We would definitely recommend a visit to Lantau Island. The cable car ride up to the Giant Buddha is spectacular and the Giant Buddha itself is most impressive.
The only thing I found out of place were the many fast food restaurants and gift shops.

must stop. In addition to the airport... you have to atleast go to the end of the subway line.. i believe its called Tung Chung... and take the gondola up to the Big Buddha! We also spent 5 hours at Disneyland which is on Lantau Island! Is very similar to Disneyland in Anaheim so we didn't need a full day there! But was there when it opened and enjoyed it.... then went on to the Big Buddha!

A Tranquil Place. Went to & fro via bus. The view from the window during the ride is amazing. Reminds me of traveling to Baguio City in my country. It's a very peaceful place.. Of course Buddhism is tranquility.
Wow. 2nd visit to this amazing island a must see is Buddha well worth the bus ride and great way to spend a day. Loved the Buddist Temple also. Make the effort

Brilliant! Brilliant! Brilliant!. A must see in Hong Kong! The views from the cable car are spectacular! We didn't get the glass bottomed cable car and I think that was a good decision considering the height and elevation of the car as you are travelling out to the island. Once you get out to the island, there is a temple, a giant Buddha etc. All of these attractions are free and there is no need whatsoever to pay for the extra tour that they run from the cable car station! We really enjoyed this day. We took the Metro from Central all the way out to where the cable car leaves. In typical Hong Kong fashion, there are sign posts everywhere guiding you as to where to go.

Ngong Ping 360. Weather was a bit crazy that day. good thing we skipped Disneyland and went for Ngong Ping 360 instead. It was a great ride although it was very windy with thick fog at times. Great view of lantau island.
Cable Car Delight. This is the world's longest cable car and offers fantastic views of the island and Hong Kong Airport. Take a glass bottom gondola to enhance your experience.

Eating. A must for any visit. The open air fish food restaurants are a great experience especially when dining with friends. The trip out from Hong Kong Island is great but the leaisurely trip back is even more enjoyable on a barmy summer's evening

Lovely day, highlight of our HK trip. Had a fantastic day here with my husband and our 2 children (7 and 9). The cable car was truly spectacular, the weather was clear and fine and views were amazing, once we got to the island we walked through the small parade of shops to the big budda and also went to the monastery, would really recommend everyone who visits HK to do this trip, we went both ways in the glass bottom cable car, slightly shorter queues, it was well worth it, the kids loved it.
The giant Budda. Well worth a trip out to Lantau to see the largest seated bronze Budda in the world.

Must do .... Husband and i did this tour. A must do for tourists. Awesome experience all round. Statue is amazing. Low clouds cast amazing effect on the area. Vegetarian meal at monastry was very good and ngong ping cable car ride awesome. Village was an experience.

Amazing. The cable cars to the big Buddha is a must! It was my absolute favorite part of our honeymoon. The view from the cable car is beautiful and a fun ride. Once you get to the area there are lots of attractions to visit and photograph.

very high. you need to have a strong legs to climb up the giant Buddha. in there, the view is awesome especially if there are fogs everywhere! =) you can also stroll around the monastery and try to appreciate their culture.

A great cable car ride, the Big Budha, monastery, and a nice hike!. The ride up on the cable cars is very scenic and you come to appreciate the mountains on this island. The Big Budha is an interesting site and destination, as is the adjacent monastery. Take the time to walk further on if you have time. the trail up to the peak of Lantau mountain is very steep with countless stairs and takes about an hour. The views are stunning and the hike, while strenuous was excellent and a quiet sojourn with very few other people out there.

A marvellous trip.. Fast easy transport using the MTR to Tung Chung then a cable car trip to Ngong Ping followed by a short walk to the Tian Tan Buddha. If the cable car station at Tung Chung is busy, don't worry, it moves quickly. The cable car journey across the hills of Lantau North Country Park offers many opportunities for photographs. The Tian Tan Buddha sit at the top of hill with 240 steps to the base of the Buddha plinth. It's an easy climb as there are 14 flights allowing a space for catching the breath on hot sultry days. Once at the top there are several chambers below the Buddha giving useful information for visitors. The Buddha is very impressive, from afar then during the climb to the statue. If you have time in Hong Kong, don't fail to visit.

Unexpected find...thanks to TripAdvisor reviews. This was my 2nd visit to Hong Kong in 15 years, and I probably wouldn't have thought of visiting Lantau Island if not for the TripAdvisor reviews... and I'm glad that I did. You can take either a bus or MTR, which would take you at least 45min from Kowloon/Hong Kong to Tung Chung where you will arrive at the cable car station (Ngong Ping 360). With the bus, you will get to go through the world's 7th longest suspension bridge - Tsing Ma bridge. Once you arrived at Tung Chung there is a big shopping mall next to the cable car station, but there are also ample restaurants and street stalls on top of the hill.Try the crystal cabin cable car with the glass-bottom, though it is a little pricey in my opinion. With seemingly no solid footing under your feet, you will get weak knees and have uncontrollable urge to hang on to something in the beginning, but it is fun and the view is spectacular. You get to see a bay on the island as well as the mountains as the cable car climbs. You will also see the Chek Lap Kok airport, and with good weather you can also see Hong Kong island.Once you reach the hill, you will go through some sort of a mock village pathway that tries to emulate a rustic Chinese feel with shops lined up on both sides but fails miserably the moment you see the Subway sandwich sign. Still, you can't fault the effort of the people running the place in trying to monetize the attraction, at least the place is well-maintained. Take the steps up to the big Buddha statue, it is really not that difficult if you consider yourself relatively fit. The magnitude of the statue can only be appreciated once you are right next to it.After you have exerted yourself physically, take a rest at one of the street stalls before you take your ride back. There are various local snacks and the tau foo fah (dessert made from soy bean water) allegedly made with mountain water is a must-try.It was an enjoyable day trip with the family, and I should think you won't regret it if you visit Lantau Island.

Big Buddha. This was on the top of our list upon arrival at HKIA, we took the bus to Tung Chung & chose to board the crystal cabin (glass-bottomed cable car). The feeling was great as well & the cable car ride was worth the try, as we were able to clearly see the trails on top of the hills not to mention the cool air as we opened the cabin windows. Upon seeing Big Buddha from the cable on the last uphill ride, all of us were really excited. We explored the Ngong Ping Village, after which we headed to climb all 280+ steps. Reaching the top, peace & serenity reigned all over, a good place to medidate & enjoy the nice scenery as well as the cool/foggy weather, Overall, it was really worth the visit.
Cable car up to Lantau Island Wonderful views. Agreat day trip up to Lantau Island, all the shops are lovely, good food and the steps up to the Budda good excercise.

Peace and Serenity. Reached the Lantau Island and climbed up to the Big Buddha. It was absolute peace and serenity there. A great place to just chill and relax and enjoy the beautiful scenery. The path of wisdom was majestic too.

Disneyand and Giant Budha. Where the East meets the West, modern cultures on one side of the Island and step back a hundred yrs on the other side.Went to Disneyland which was a bit dissappointing, it was very small and crowded, but easy to get to by public transport, if you want to have any rides be prepared to queue for up to an hour every time. Went to the giant budha by public transport as well and it took over an hour but was everything l expected, climbed all the stairs to go to the top and the views were fantastic, had lunch at the monastary which was vegetarian and very good, you are given tea with your meal but you have to buy water. We came back by the cable car and it was scary, such steep descents and it was very windy, you can have a glass bottomed cable car or the standard, l suggest the standard if you are scared of heights and if heights absolutely terrify you this would not be a ride to take. Over all a busy tourist trap but well worth a visit.

Big buddha temple well worth a visit.. A fantastic cable-car ride to see the buddhist temple although the extra charge for the glass-bottomed experience on the cable car itself isn't worth it. The temple is serene and peaceful...the surrouding shops largely superfluous and slightly tacky.

The cable car ride was a highlight. We loved the cable car- the views of gorgeous mountains and water were breathtaking! If you are on a tour you can bypass the longish lines to see the Buddha.The giant Buddha is something else. Even though it is relatively new it is a sight to behold! It is set up very well for tourists.... as far as offering food, souvenirs etc..This was a wonderul part of the trip for us - Dont miss it if you are in HOng Kong!

A world apart very worth visiting. Very interesting and enlightning trip. We got the caple car which is amazing really high but efficiant walked up and around the giant budda and took in a meal in the temple. Very different from down town Honk Kong peaceful.
Worth it for the giant buddha. Just nice beacause of the giant buddha.. Those many steps werent that bad even with a baby carrier....Many option of restaurants.Cool cable car ride.
It is a big Budha. Worth a view, but it is just a big buddha and it's fairly new too.

Day trip to Lantau. When you are in Hong Kong, a day trip to Lantau Island and a visit to the Po Lin Monastery is a must. We went there by Ferry from the docks near Central's Star Ferry Pier, Hong Kong Island. The ferry ride is around 60 minutes and you dock at Mui Wo. From there you can take a bus to the Monastery. There are about 200 stairs up to the Big Buddha and there is a museum beneath the Buddha. The view from the top is amazing, especially when there is mist over the hills and mountains in the distance. When returning through Mui Wo, stop for a bite at one of the local restaurants.
I saw dolphins!. Really enjoyed Lantau Island, specially Tai O. Made the boottrip trough the village and went on the see where I saw pink dolphins. Such a wonderful experience!
well worth it. Take the bus at least one way. You will enjoy the views!

Take the Cablecar, see the Buddha, Eat in the Veggie restaurant!. Do ensure you visit this great sight in HK, you won't regret it!Take the cablecar from Ngong Ping (queues can be long so get there early) for a spectacular 20-minute ride up the mountains. The view over the ocean and airport is fab, and the cablecars are really quite high.Once you get off the cablecar and head towards the buddha, do ignore the trashy commercial bit that has sprung up with a Subway, Starbucks etc. Don't be tempted to eat in these places, but instead buy a ticket to eat at the monks restaurant. You can buy a ticket in the booth at the base of the buddha, and eat after you climb the stairs to the top.In the restaurant, you go in and they just bring you veggie dishes, with rice. I am not a vegetarian, but the food was delicious.I didn't take the cablecar back down, but instead took a bus ride to a nearby fishing village. The thrill of riding the bus down the mountains, through twisty roads is not for the faint-of heart, but was really rather fun!

Fun day out of HK City. After a 30 minute train ride on the super easy to navigate metro, we reached Lantau Island. Here we visited the big Buddha and did some great shopping at the discount mall. For the shopping part of things, get prepared to pull your elbows up and charge...there are very little manners or courtesy shown in the malls when a bargain is to be had!
Well worth a trip on the longest cable car up to the huge golden buddha. Great views but slightly scary from the cable car if you don't like heights.

Journey to big buddha Lantau island. If you are sick of shopping and walking the street of Hong Kong,You can try to go on a small trip to Lantau Island.Over there, you can do hiking around the island.The big buddha at the Lantau Island is big and one of the attraction in Hong KongBelow is a link that I have write on the way to meet the big Buddhahttp://siaocumber.blogspot.com/2012/06/journey-to-big-buddha-lantau-island.html.Enjoy the photos !!!!

Nice weekend trip. We visited the Big Buddha and the temple beside it. It's very accessible. We traveled by MRT to Tung Chung station then transferred to the Bus leading to Ngong Ping Village. We didn't take the cable car as we felt it was risky given some reported incidents in the past. The bus ride was like an adventure, as it traveled through zig zag roads. Excellent driving skills - I've taken this trip 3 times already and am always amazed at how good they drive the buses.Main highlight is the Big Buddha, where you have to take about 250 steps up. It has been well kept. There is no entrance fee to go up to the Big Buddha. But there are some counters at the food of the steps which sell you meal tickets. The meal tickets allows you to go inside the Buddha when you get up top, but to me, it's nicer to enjoy the Big Buddha from the outside, you get to go 360 degrees around the Big Buddha anyway without having to pay the meal ticket.You can then visit the temple. Nothing special, but if you haven't seen a temple, it would be good to go in and see.Don't miss the vegetarian food at the temple, cooked Chinese style. Again, if you haven't tried this, it's a learning experience. You can either have a sit down meal or just buy from the snack bar. We didn't get a meal ticket at the entrance, but instead just went to the snack bar to get some food, at least we get to choose what we wanted to eat.If you have some energy to take a walk, just go past the Big Buddha and there is a trail to Wisdom Path, where you can get to see a circle giant wooden posts with Buddhist texts on them. It also offers a great view of the mountains and water. We hiked up one of the highest hills offering magnificent views. Few people know about this area.

Climb up to the Big Buddha. I've been to the Lantau Island several times and i'll keep coming back again. The most convenient way to get to the place is by cable car. Be prepared to queue for about 15-20 mins if you going in the morning or early afternoon. Unless you are taking the crystal cabin where it's more expensive but not much of a queue. When you arrive at Ngong Ping, you will see the usual touristy shops and staff selling you your photo that they took when you board the cable car. If you need to get some souvenirs, skip the expensive touristy shops and you can get some cheaper alternatives as you walk down towards the Big Buddha. You can consider getting some pendants or crystals which were blessed by the monks at the foot and top of the Big Buddha statue.You have to climb up to the Big Buddha if you are here. Tiring but nice scenery up there.
Day tour. I love the scenary & strong wind. Very tiring to walk up the 250 steps to Giant Buddha.

Don't miss it!. Enjoyed Laides Market the BEST! Got some real bargains to bring home. Also enjoyed the Flower Market - bought "Sensitive Plant" seeds - sure hope I can get them to grow here in Florida. You touch the plant and it wilts immediately - just temporarily. Also enjoyed 1881 - beautiful area.
Nice Island for a day or two. Disney and Nong Ping Hill/ Monastery. Good fun for 2 days.

Giant Budhdha@Lantau. If ever you have a day@Hongkong,never ever miss a chance to visit the giant Budhdha@Lantau Island.It is to be seen to be believed..how peaceful that atmos is.Tallest Budhdha in the world@a peak well designed by the HK authorities.The PoLin monastery is truly wonderful too.You must climb 200 steps to reach the Budhdha Idol..not difficult.But worth it.
Give it a miss. Not worth the visit, had been years ago when lived in HK and so returned but really wouldn't waste your time. Not scenic.

great tourist spot... I will never climb those steps to the Big Buddha again as I don't think I would have the energy but the cable car ride was excellent and well organized and the little shops at the end had lovely items in them and were very reasonable..

Allow time. We have been 3 times and you really need most of the day, the cable car is amazing but the journey is worth it to see the Big Buddah, the walk up the steps is hard work but you can stop a few times on the way up, but a must if you are going to Hong Kong.

A different view of Hong Kong away from the hustle and bustle. We took the fast ferry to Lantau Island then the bus to Ngong Ping Village where the giant Buddha is located. The Frommer travel guide states that the ferry and bus times are coordinated so that when you arrive by the ferry you are able to take the bus right away. That was not correct and we had to wait an hour for the bus. During that time we amused ourselves by having breakfast at McDonalds! The bus itself is an air conditioned coach, so quite comfortable. The road to the Buddha offers some great views along the coast. Ngong Ping Village is very commercial with many different shops. We weren't expecting this, but when we browsed in the shops, we found them to have some interesting and good quality merchandise. The Chopstick House was one of particular interest, as was the Peking Opera store. The bathrooms in Ngong Ping Village seem to be the most modern and the cleanest. The ones on the way to the Wisdom Path should be avoided. The giant Buddha is just that - giant. We walked up the many, many stairs in the heat. It was worthwhile - there are some fabulous views from the top. We purchased a meal ticket to eat in the Po Lin Monastery which gave us access to the museum inside the Buddha. If you are limited for time, forego the museum, as it is not very interesting. We walked the 15 minutes to the Wisdom Path. Once again, some gorgeous views. We ate at the Monastery - the budget lunch. We had vegetable soup which was not very tasty, rice and 3 different vegetable dishes. While the food was plentiful and edible, you don't eat there for the food; more for the experience. We did see a monk when we were dining. We took the cable car back to Tung Chung, which was faster than the bus and offered excellent views. There were 4 of us in the cable car - so not crowded in (maximum occupancy is 17). The cable car terminal station is in - you guessed it - a mall! In this case, according to Frommer's, the only real outlet mall in HK. We did not find the prices to be that much less expensive than either at home or in HK proper, but the mall was very busy with shoppers. We took the MTR back to Kowloon, which was efficient and since Tung Chung is the start of the line, we were able to have seats all the way back. If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, visit Lantau Island. While it is still commercial, there is lots of green space, great views, and offers a different perspective on HK.

such a heavenly island... I enjoying the breathtaking view of the island, from the astonishing view of the grassland slopes and the boundless rivers overlooking from above the crystal cabin, during the 40 minutes Cable Car to Ngong Ping Village. Far from the hustle and bustle of the streets in HK city is a serene and heavenly place like this . Upon arrival, you will see an enchanting ivory pillar which served as an entrance through the Po Lin Monastery and to the right is the way up to the Giant Buddha which was so magnificent specially if you reach the top.There were a number of establishments and restaurants to dine and hang with. It is best to visit early in the morning because it gets really hot come noon time. We started our day tour here in Lantau as early as 8am afterwards, head straight to Disneyland thru the cable car return trip and the connecting MTR from Tung Chung to Sunny Bay station.More stories on:http://hazelovestraveling.blogspot.com/2011/10/hongkong-exploring-city-on-day-2.html
interesting. well worth the visit It is very interesting and informative

Great island. Went here for a day. It was amazing. It's like you are not in hk with all the natures and the beach. I love the seafood restaurants there but I wasn't able to try coz we hang mostly by the beach

OVER-RATED!!!. The Budha is over-rated. It was built less than 100 years ago and with all the walking required to see it, I didn't think it was worth it. I was in Kyoto less than a year ago, so the bhudda temple here disappointed me compared with what i saw in kyoto.

The Big Buddha- another must see in Hk. Although a bit touristy (with Starbucks etc..), it is well worth the climb to see the Big Buddha.Definitely try the vegetarian meal in the temple.The cable car is good on clear weather days.

Take the Stairs up to the Budha. You can take the subway out to where you catch the cable car over to Lantau Island. The cable car ends at shopping/restaurant area as the base of the steps up to the Budha. The ride is amazing and several kilometers long giving you excellent views along the way. Once there, it is worth taking the steps up to the Budha, but take your time as there are a lot of them - especially if it is hot. Once at the top, make sure you go inside as there is a free tour with very interesting information.

Check the weather. If you are going to see the Big Buddha, check the weather. We were lucky as the weather was clear, but a bit breezy. It can often be misty and the Buddha is lost in the cloud. Take the cable car the views are stunning

Make the Trip!. I had a late night flight, so this was the perfect way to end my trip to Hong Kong! The cable car ride offers spectacular views and even though I didn't pay for a private car (nor did the people around me), they didn't cram the cars full of strangers. It was very nice having the entire car to just my daughter and myself. We got a lot of great photos on the ride over to the giant Buddha. There are a LOT of stairs leading up to Buddha, but don't be discouraged. The view from the top is breath-taking (behind Buddha). Mountains roll on as far as the eye can see. I was not expecting such a picturesque scene at the top. Most definitely worth the trek up the many, many stairs. The Wisdom Path is neat, but quite far from everything else. Still, a nice walk through the woods. Don't be surprised if you encounter a large bull on the path. It certainly startled me and was unnerving since it was just my toddler and myself at the time when we ran into it. I asked around about it and was told it lives over in that area. Apparently those bulls are not terribly uncommon on Lantau. It didn't bother us; we just moved out of its way so it could pass. Buddhist vegetarian lunch was quite good and very filling. Enhanced the entire experience. Wonderful day trip. The bathrooms were horrifying. Try to go before you get on the cable car.

The Big Buddha. After a enjoyable ferry trip seeing Hong Kong harbour and a windy bus ride we arrived at the Big Buddha. Very commercial but enjoyed the climb to the big Buddha. Lots of eating places and temples to see, a nice day out.

lots of places to go.... big range of things to do -- mountain biking (you can rent good quality bikes near Tung Chung MTR station), hike or take the cable car to the Big Budha, rent a vacation home or camp on the beach; check out Discovery Bay community and hike from there to Mui Wo passing by an older monastery and an occasional feral cow from when a dairy farm used to be, and then bike around Mui Wo (bikes are around HK$10/hour) and then take the Kaito back to Discovery Bay. Tai O fishing village is another popular stop.

Worth the day trip there. Go early before the crowds, so you don't have to wait in the tram line. Or pay more for a glass bottom tram and wait ~5 minutes. Have lunch earlier, 11:30 am Monastery cafeteria is opened and for $65 HKD per person you can have a very filling Vegetarian lunch. Then go hike up to the Bronze Buddha (take receipt from lunch and get inside the museum for free). It's very peaceful, few monks around, but lots to see and do. Before you even make it to the monastery grounds there's a huge new consumerism mall that will distract most visitors, keep going forward to the Buddha. There's snacks at the top and amazing views, worth the trek in the heat and sweat.

Wonderful day trip. The Buddha on the mountain is quite the site to behold. Walking around the island and the temple was a highlight of my trip. Definitely include this as a stop for sightseeing in Hong Kong.

Big Buddha. THe trip by glass bottomed cable car was great even though I do not like heights once there the walk around gives one a feel of the place but a climb up the stairs to the Buddha is not of the feint hearted or the unfit. If you do a bus tour they take you to the top by bus so you get up close and personal with the Buddha

Great experience. Really amazing day spent here. Walk the steps, marvel, and go inside for a walk around. Come back down and eat at the monastry for a very tasty vegetarian lunch. Walk the grounds and take the cable car to enjoy a long ride and truly amazing views. Go home happy. Simple :)
