beautiful trip. Loved Lantau. The cablecar ride was long and beautiful, although a little shakey! The village at the top is quaint. The Buddha is massive and worth climbing the 200 and odd stairs to see. The veiws out to the valley and temple are wonderful too.

Lantau Island tour - fun day. Went on an organised day tour involving ferry ride to the island, Tao fishing village, Giant Budda statue and cable car ride. Was an enjoyable day overall. The Giant Budda and surrounds are beautiful but it detracted a bit when we found out the statue was built by the government about 12 years ago for the tourist industry rather than being an authentic site. The other thing which detracted a bit was the lack of clean sit down toliets.
fun and good for families. like - cable car ride. like - gelatolike - soy bean curd (apparently its made from the spring water)like - the Buddha (majestic)

So many things to do, so little time (and energy!). My husband was blown away by the gem of this island.We did the climb up the Big Buddha, went to the temple there, and better, chanced upon some trails (one of which was the Lantau Island Peak) - amazing views there.Just be sure to wear proper shoes, and bring sunscreen, a hat and of course mosquito repellent and explore the various paths ( I called the island Butterfly Island - there were so many of them!!!)It wasn't that warm when we went (we arrived at 1 pm) but I can imagine it gets quite humid in summer, so stay hydrated then.

Yes, This is Worth Doing.. If you have half a day of leisure time to spare while in Hong Kong, you may enjoy taking the aerial tram from the MTR station at Tung Chung up the mountain to near the top of Lantau Island at Ngong Ping, where you can see the Tian Tan ("Giant") Buddha; the largest, seated, outdoor, bronze Buddha in the world. I enjoyed this outing and found plenty of places to eat and to rest both before and after the aerial tram ride. In addition to the Giant Buddha, spend a little time exploring the grounds of the Po Lin Monastery. I thought it was beautiful up there.The day I was there (a Friday afternoon), the line to buy tickets for the tram was 45-minutes long. People who already had their tickets went right to the front. You might as well opt to buy the tickets for the tram cars with the glass bottom ("Crystal Cabin"), because they are not that much more expensive, and it is fun to look directly below you as you proceed up and down this long tram ride; it takes thirty minutes each way. The view from the tram cars is, indeed, quite impressive. Children will love it. Take your camera.

Giant Buddha,Temple, and Sky ride great!. Village was a little too Disneyfied. Monkey theater was not worth it. Reminded me of the Tiki Room at Disneyland. Buy the ticket for the Giant Buddha and snack. After you tour the Buddha you can have a snack of 2 dim sum and rice noodles in the Monastery. Yummy!

Big Buddha and Pink Dolphins. Big Buddha is amazing. Pay to walk up to the statue, you get a cold water and an ice cream as well as great views and photo opportunities and a museum visit thrown in. Then take the bus to Tai O. Walk through the village and market streets. Before you leave, pay the 20 HKD (about $2.85 USD) to take a skiff out to see the pink Dolphins. The day we went we were treated to about 10 of them breaching, and playing just outside the bay.

A beautiful scenic island with mountains beaches and a giant buddha!. You can take an amazing cable car ride to the top of a mountain and then hike down to a beautiful beach on the other side and have a late lucy on the sand of an unspoiled beach.

Surprising Lantau. I am sure that BIG BUDDHA is one of the highlight of HK. But there are more to Lantau Island. one must visit Mui Wo, Tai O as well as Discovery Bay. One friend said that travelling by ferry to Discovery Bay is like travelling by boat to Corsica.

Nice Scenery!. Like: a) Nice scenery but provided u muz climb the long staircases. It's very windy up there, bring a windcoat if u wn.b) The shows "Monkey Tale" and "Walk with Buddha" are worth it. Buy the HKD 250 per prs package. Including round trip with crystal cable car and free admission to Monkey's Tale show and Walk with Buddha.Dislike: Cannot opt to hv own family members in cable car. They will try to fill in up until 7-8 ppl in one cable car.

Lantau Island and Hai O. Lantau Island is the largest island in Hong Kong. Ngong ping is the main plateau in Lantau. Po Lin Monastery was built and a bronze tian an buddha or giant buddha statue about 85 ft was built there. You can ride Ngong Ping cable car to the island. It takes about 30 minutes ride. I tried the crystal cable car and in the beginning you will feel quite scary over the glass in the cable car but later you will really feel excited as looking around the beautiful scenery around the island.There is a fishing town near Lantau called Tai O. I love the small village where you can find temples and even church and schools. I remembered I tried the BBQ cheese prawns over there and it is really cheap and delicious.
Budda. It was a beautiful day with mist to set the mood and still warm enough to walk around and take in the views great day!

A good day trip. We took the ferry over to Lantau Island, then the bus up to the monastery and the Big Buddha. It was very misty the day we were there, which added to the spiritual atmosphere (and meant you couldn't see the tourist shops!). Saw an excellent performance by the Shaolin monks at the monastery. Took the train back to Hong Kong - very efficient.

the beaches near Discovery Bay. did you like the movie 'the truman show'? so don't miss the village Discovery Bay on Lantau island. a village with houses lined up, perfect people, no dogs barking, children who do not cry, flower gardens. a bus service takes you around the hills. in the square you can dine in one of the many restaurants. but is it really worth going to Discovery Bay for the beachs!
The Great Buddha. Take the MTR to Lantau Island and visit the Giant Buddha - the cable car journey alone is worth the visit - great day out.

an oasis. I took a quick trip to Lantau Island to see the big Buddha statue. More research was needed as it was not something I could do in a morning. However, I walked around the streets and along the beach and totally relaxed. This island is so peaceful, clean and quiet. Next time I will plan to spend longer and get to the Buddha.

Wonderful day out. Recently did a Lantau Island Tour with Tour East. What a fabulous day a must do if you have the time. Wonderful and knowledgable guide, vegetarian food at the temple was amazing. Would highly recommend.
Lantau Island Tour worth doing. The Giant Bhudda is worth seeing. The 360 Cable Car is great, Fishing Villages and a Trip to the beach finish the story.

excellent. i took crystal cable ride to visit lantau and enjoyedvisited bigh buddha watched walking with budhha it gives nice spiritual experiencei suggest u to take crytal cable ride its bit expensive than normal cable car but it is woth it

Do an organised day tour. Best value for money to do an organised day tour which includes ferry ride, lunch and cable car ride. Also visit the Big Buddha and the most beautiful beach. Great value for money.
A TRIP BACK INTO HISTORY. AN inexpensive train ride followed by a cable car ride to visit the Monastery and the great statue of Buddha.

fun experience. I have visited twice. Once with family and the other time with friends. Each time we took the subway to get there so we could feast our eyes on the Big Buddha. From the subway we took the cable car and watched the more adventurous folks below us that were hiking to and from the spot. Great views when you get there. Fun little shops. My only disappointment was the Big Buddha isn't that old but still is picturesque and a fun excursion.
cable car to ngon ping. good experience, with 15 euros you can go up to ngong ping village to see the giant buddha, the biggest buddha in the open in the worldthe island is wild and beautiful

Big Buddha. Had very quick trip to the Lantau Island (3 hours round trip ;-) ):
- ferry from Hong Kong to Lantau
- bus 2 to the Big Buddha
- cable car back to the Tung Chung
- MTR to Hong Kong
I wish I had more time to stay on the island.

Must see!. Wonderful day at Lantau! Beautiful nature, wonderful landscape, Big Buddha, definately must visit when you're in Hong Kong. Something completely different from the center of town. I was a little bit tired from the visiting crowded city and went for a one day rest there, and filled my batteries! Cable car with glass bottom was awesome! Recommand crystal one because you can see everything what's beneath you..

Do the Ferry and Bus. Travel by ferry to Mui To and take the #2 bus. The bay views are gorgeous and the bus ride is like a mellow rollercoaster through the mountainside. It is very easy and very cheap!
amazing day out. visit the budda, cable cars, bus back into *station* great experience
Excellent. Do the cable car ride because it is truly one of the hidden treasures

Escape from the city. This was my second trip, previously visiting by train and cable cars. As they weren't working we arrived by ferry and took the bus up to the giant buddha which was a totally different experience. Must return on a hot day for the beaches. A scenic and inexpensive day out.

Interesting. Lantau Island can be visited in half a day. We rode the glass bottom scenic cable car. My daughter enjoyed it. She and her bff enjoyed walking around and going up the stairs leading to the big Buddha. It was also an experience for them to see the temple with all the figures all around. We also ate at one of the restaurants there.

Scene from Cable ride is awesome!. The ride is definitely worth it. Just that u need to luck on the waiting time. We are lucky that there isn't many people if not, you can wait @ least 2-3hrs just to have the crystal cable car ride. Which I experience during my last view. This time round we expected the same.. as we went during Vesak day.. But there isn't any Q! When u are there please go and have the Veg @ the temple! The bee hoon is nice & cheap! Go for the beancurd. There's one very old shop that call dragon something.. (sorry I forgot the name) the bean curd there to me is better. try their mixed.. which is normal beancurd + black seasame.

Touristy. Sky tram is pretty exciting, go for the glass bottom one, unless you're afraid of heights. But once you get up there is pretty touristy. Went and saw the big Buddha and also a bizarre extreme Po Go show. It's kind of super weird....

BIG BUDHA. I just returned to this place, was there in 2005, and a lot has changed! Now the place have a little village with loads of places to eat and shop (starbucks, subway, pizza, pasta you can get it all)! Got alot more touristy since I was there last...Take the Cable Car up and down, very cool and the view is great! Choose a Crystal car, it has glass floor so you can look down, makes the trip a bit more fun and wild! The trip is best on a clear day, so check the weather and if you have the option go on a good day. It can get very misty up there, and the view of Budha and the area will pretty much disapear on misty days...BIG BUDHA is still great!

Book for Cable Car. If you do not go with an organised tour or book your cable car tickets in advance you could, like us, be faced with a VERY long wait in a queue. When we arrived at the cable car we were informed that there would be a 45 minute wait. That would have been bad enough but it turned out to be just over two hours! The biggest frustration was the lack of information from the cable car "organisers" who told you absolutely nothing apart from a mantra of "45 minutes" which after an hour was patently absurd. Book your tickets in advance and you bypass the queue.The journey on the cable car takes almost 30 minutes and provides tremendous views. It was fairly windy on the day we visited and the car does get blown around a bit, but nothing too frightening. Nearing the top we plunged into hill fog and this stayed with us to the end of the journey, To get to the steps leading to the Buddha you pass through a cluster of shops and cafe/restaurants and a variety of statues which line the path. There are several hundred steps leading up to the Buddha and for many it's a tough climb. Unfortunately when I reached the top of the steps, the whole area was enveloped in fog and only the outline of the Big Buddha was visible. Very disappointing but not unexpected.In spite of the long queue and the poor weather I enjoyed the experience and would recommend it to anyone with a reasonable head for heights.
Very Humbling. Took a trip to visit Lantau island took the cable car which is a 'must do' in Hong Kong and was not disappointedrecommend a visit to all travellers

Worth a visit. the island itself is beautiful, you don't have to go with a tour, we got public transport. The monestary is also beautiful. We went for a long walk through the rugged landscape of the island and saw some breath taking views
Very Different. Cable car ride is excellent, but book in advance to avoid the queues. Big Buddha and the temple are an amazing site to behold.Definately a must do in HK.

Big Buddha. Lantau Island, the airport Island, is famous for its big Buddha statue. You can also find Disneyland there. If you get there via metro you can visit a big outlet centre next to the station for shopping. To the buddha statue you can go by bus or, as i did, via cable car, where you can get some stunning views over the island. It is also possible to hike to the big buddha, but the trail looked very steep and exhausting. Form the statue there are a few walks to other sights and you can go by bus to a little fishing village where it is posssible to see pink dolphins and to experience the life of the people there.

The great outdoors. Many will know Lantau as the location of the airport and Disney but it has plenty more. If you like walking it has lots of trails that are unspoilt and have few other walkers. The giant Buddha is probably a day trip in itself and if you eat at the monastary (you should all veggie) you will not need to eat for the reat of the day! Tung Chung has a covered and A/C shopping centre and there is an outdoor and indoor swimming pool. Cable car journeys mean you get to see the surrounding islands, airport and if the smog clears the Chinese mainland.
Worth the trip. Cable car to visit the Big Buddha was very good .Only drawback was the queue .Need to buy tickets in advance.

Wow...that is one Big Buddha!. Lantau Island is an easy trip from Hong Kong and well worth it. We bought the glass cable car up and decided to take the bus to Tai O fishing village on the way down. Part of your ticket price are these vouchers worth x number of dollars at the shops at the top, so fyi use them if you are going to get a coffee or a trinket.  The glass bottom cable car - a total must! It is a bit of a scary marvel - but still pretty awesome. The day we went was pretty foggy but still at one point when we were floating in a cloud my husband and I had the same 'kids on Christmas morning' look on our faces.  Arriving at Lantau Island is a little weird because there is a Subway and a Starbucks which I get it's a tourist spot but still. There are many tourist shops that sell goods of varying quality.  We did not go to the Tale of the Monkey or the other movie on Buddha but I heard from others that this was a skip.  Big Buddha - the steps are plentiful to get to the top but totally worth it. The Big Buddha makes me smile even now writing this but to others it was a holy experience. It was a powerful experience to see others so overcome with emotion and made me realize how small our world view can be as Westerns.  We left the Buddha and went to the temple for lunch. Now it is with great shame that in one keyboard strike I tell you Westerns should have more of a world view and in the next I write about the lunch. That food was unforgettable and not in a good way. I think if you can maybe you should skip the lunch at the temple and just donate some money. We wanted to be culturally sensitive and not turn our noses up at the food served so we ate as much as we could to check the box.  Seeing the Big Buddha was a highlight of our trip the lunch will go down in the history books. You can see the whole experience on the face of my husband in the attached photo. One note for dog lovers - there are several feral dogs, I saw many puppies on Lantau Island. They must live off the the scraps that people give them as they will follow you if you have food. They are not aggressive or hostile in fact they are quite timid. I saw several people kicking at these animals and it made me sad so just an fyi.

Lantau has something for every one. Lantau island ,if you are visiting Hong Kong or Kowloon and you are flying there,then you will have visited Lantau island,as this is where the airport is.But don't just whizz away on the airport shuttle MTR and not return until you fly out, come back enjoy this island.For the Kids and big kids theres Disneyland (not for me) Theres Ngon Ping 360 cable car going up to see the golden buddha, if its not cloudy (was for me).Theres beaches and pleanty of greenery if you thought its all buildings. And hidden away over the far side is Tai O island ,step back in time,catch the number 21 bus from golden buddha, this is where until the Hong Kong exchange, was the English navys- weather station !!!!!(we know different).Tai O is conected to Lantau by a small bridge ,before that it was a small boat.It has a very low key history section hidden between the shops,but worth a look to see what it was like.Take a walk through the market and off towards the old police station,and pass rows of silver painted squatters houses,with an official notice saying they will be removing them (shame) later see houses that must have been navel ,but now are homes to the locals.The old police station has been transformed into a hotel,but behind it a the steps to the ex weather station (big sign saying military keep out)Walk along the stone pier and catch a ferry back to Tia O town for $10hk each about £1, first he takes you out to sea to try to spot pink dolphines,then back through the harbour under the bridge you first walked over,up the river to see the houses on stilts,where everybody lives and back to the bridge to get off.All for £1 quite a bargin, so give a tip to the driver not the fare taker on the steps.The town at the end of the Mtr which is where you get off for the Ngon Ping 360 cable car ,has a shopping center full of designer shops ,but these are factory outlet stores,so a bargin may be had ,if your into label wear.

If you go by the cable car... beware!!!!. It is a nice place, but if it is foggy you will not see the big Buddha. The monkey tale is only for kids (if you do not have them with you, skip it)! Be aware of the fact that the cable care service is VERY UNSTABLE. Not that they are not doing their job, but if there is a thunderstorm warning (remember it is Hong Kong, so every other day...) the will stop the service and you might stuck up there. (They done this to me twice.) Make sure that you do not have to run anywhere after this program.

A good day trip from Kowloon are. We booked a day trip to Lantau whilst on a city break in Hong Kong and enjoyed it. They picked us up from our hotel and we crossed over to Lantau and visited the beach area, a fishing village, including a trip out on the boat to see the fishing boats the people live on. We also visited the site of the Big Budha and had lunch at the monastery. Recommended if you have a spare day in Hong Kong.
Another Part of Hong Kong. Disney Land (if you have kids) is a must and Ngong Ping Cable Car a worthy trip.

Family Fun .. Way up High. Lantau Island is one of the biggest islands in Hong Kong and is rich in nature and wilflife, and we recommend this islandas a must see for a family on holiday or even locals if you haven't already been.Lantau Island is packed with great views of the lush green forest and also has a fair share of man made attractions and offers so much to tourists : Great views, calm atmosphere and education/enlightenment.You can take the Ngon Ping 360 cable car transport system and have an option to use the crystal cabin cable car all around the island and you can get to see a beautiful bird's eye-view of the island's forest, which contains a well made hiking trail, if you like long and peaceful walks between or inside a forest.Upon exiting the cable car you are met with a small village which brings souvenir shops, restaurants and small market stands.Souvenir shops are well worth entering themselves as they can make a trip last a lifetime and the restaurants that serve delicious food to keep you full and satisfiedThe island also brings a hint of wildlife; tamed animals that gives the island brings you even more closer to nature and while walking ahead there are buildings and theatres that englighten you on Buddhism, how it started and their religious views.Down the end of the village path leads you to the main attraction: One of the world's largest buddha statues.There is about 200 flights of stairs leading up to the giant buddha statue and it leads to one of the highest points in Hong Kong.Lantau island is definitely one of the must see attractions and is truly a great experience.
Go to the Big Buddah. Great day out, especially for kids. The cable car ride to the Buddah is not to be missed. Also, eat in the restaurant and order the fish...amazing!

Lantau Escape. If you want some quiet time away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong itself take the ferry over to Lantau. We took the bus to Po Lin Monastery and climbed up all the steps to see the Giant Buddha - it was well worth the climb!

An Island with Magnificent View. My first time came to this Islands was very wonderfull.. I reach by MTR from the down town about 30 minutes.. Walk to the cable car stations, get the tickets, and using it to reach the green mountain.. Visited Ngon Ping 360 Village.. Walk above the sea, the HK Airport, smoke cloud with 7 station of cable car.. drive about 30 minutes to reach ngon ping 360 villages.. Awesomee trip...

Sunday lunch. Our friends living in Hong Kong treated us to their Sunday afternoon ritual of a scenic boat trip to Lantau Island and a wonderful sea food lunch in one of the several open air restaurants dockside. Delicious!

History, religion and views all in one. This is a destination for a great family day trip. The cable car from the last MTR station offers full views of the airport, the ride was itself a ighlight. The walk thru NgogPing gives visitor a feel of stepping back in time and provides shopping and food rests.The big buddha and the climb to it puts you in touch of it serenity. Not to be missed if you're in HK.

Visit this big buddha statue. This is one of the biggest sitting buddha statues in the world. A must see in Hong Kong. The best way to get there is take the NP360 cable car! When you get off at Lantau Island, you walk right into a small village like shopping street, where you can buy some authentic sweets and food. To see the buddha statue, you need to walk the stairs, which is quite high. I would go there again when I have some spare time again.
A must!. This is a must on your visit to Hong Kong; make sure it's in line with your tour(s)

Peaceful interlude in Hong Kong.. We visited the Sitting Buddha at Lantau Island. It was great to escape the bustle of Hong Kong and we happened to choose a day when the clouds dispersed and sunshine appeared. The Buddhist Temple is well worth a visit and the grounds are well kept and we had an enjoyable stroll. There were a few dogs also enjoying the tranquility. They appeared to be healthy and well fed by the Monks.There is an interesting shop that sells quality jewellery and artifacts.

On a Clear Day.... Perhaps on a clear day, the Buddha is worth seeing, but not much else of interest in the Ngong Ping area. Save some money and time (arrive before 10 a.m.) and take the #23 bus up (use your Octopus card) and the cable car down. Avoid Npong Ping Village (well, you have to walk through it to get to the cable cars), as it's nothing but souvenir shops. Skip the museum at the top of the Buddha unless you're really into sutras written in Chinese. Bring a camera for the cable car ride down.

A must visit. The cable cars up to the Budha and monastery you have to do. Truly an awsome experience. Not to mention the shopping outlets near the train station. We went crazy with all the cheap clothes !!!

A fair journey but spectacular once you get there. There is a bus from MTR Tung Chung station and be aware, there is a huge queue for this public bus. We had to wait around 30min for 2-3 buses before we could board.Another thing to be aware of is that once you arrive there, it is much colder and icier weather than inside the city, so bring extra clothes.The climb to the giant buddha takes 10 minutes, and the views and photography are magnificent.
Peaceful. A lovely quiet little backwater after the hurly burly of hong kong.Nice walks a good restaurant and even a post office.
The Big Buddha... SEE IT!. Blog review of Lantau Island and the Big Buddhahttp://thewayfaringpeacock.blogspot.com/2011/10/would-you-look-at-that.html

Big Buddha, Cable Car & great veg food. great cable car ride with Big Buddha - i did not climb up but some of my family did and was very amazed by the expereince. I think the vegetarian meal is a must must have. Really great, portion too large though... It is cooling too

big buddha. I went to Lantau to see the famous Big Buddha and I really enjoyed the visit. To go there you can either walk along the very well marked trail or take the cable up. I was lazy, so I took the cable. Once at the top, I enjoyed the visit and the little village nearby.

A Day on Lantau Island. We only had two full days in Hong Kong, and I am very glad we spent one on Lantau Island. There are many options, but we enjoyed our trip: subway to Tung Chung (Octopus Pass), Cable Car to Ngong Ping (we skipped the extra cost for the glass bottom "Crystal Car"), use free coupons for a cheap trinket in gift shop, get Starbucks, hurry though touristy Ngong Ping, see The Big Buddha, walk to Wisdom Path and see part of the Lantau Trail system-with almost no other humans in sight, walk back to Po Lin Monastery and enjoy some snacks (buns and soy milk), bus #21 to Tai O to see the stilt houses and fish stalls, and bus #1 to Mui Wo to catch the 50 minute ferry back to Hong Kong. It was nice to get out of the city. We went on a misty day and it was still great, with the Buddha appearing out of the mist and clouds. The monastery was very interesting, with lots of nice flowers and incense. The variety of dried seafood for sale in Tai O was awesome! Note: For nature lovers, there is a little visitor center in Ngong Ping that has info about the birds, etc of the area.

Big Buddha is a blast but skip the lunch. Back in March, we took the MTR from Central to Tung Chung on Lantao Island. From the MTR station we did a bit of shopping at the CityGate Outlets, then we caught the #23 bus from CityGate to Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. Buying the Day pass for HK$35 each worked out cheaper than 2 or three single bus rides - CityGate to Big Buddha, Big Buddha to Tai O, Tai O to the ferry etc).The cable car was not working (maintenance?) and they hadn’t put on any extra buses - the buses come every 25 minutes but there was a queue about 3 busloads long so we ended up waiting about an hour to get on the bus. This was THE worst transport experience in Hong Kong because every other mode of transport in Hong Kong is so good with trains and ferries etc every 5-10 minutes etc. The road journey was interesting with a winding narrow road taking you up into the hills to the Buddha. Where the bus stops is a bit “touristy” with naff souvenirs etc. Despite the hard sell on the vegetarian lunch for $65 we luckily avoided this as it looked like crap (fried spring rolls, mushrooms and rice). Others have reported it to be the worst meal they had in Hong Kong.It is however worth buying a ticket into the Big Buddha (plus an ice-cream) for $25HKD. The carved/painted panels are worth a look and the ice-cream is your reward for trekking up all those steps!We went to check out Tai O fishing village by bus but it was another 35 minute wait for the next bus and we couldn’t be bothered waiting so we jumped on the bus to Mui Wo, a pretty little fishing village with a couple of nice restaurants perched on the hillside. We had a late lunch there (about 3.30pm) of chicken cashew nuts, sliced beef and vegetables, fried rice, pork and vegetables etc for $280 HKD for three of us (much nicer than the lunch at Po Lin Monastery). We took the fast ferry back from MuiWo to Central getting off at the International Finance Centre (IFC) – tallest building in Hong Kong – where we did a bit of browsing around the shops. What a great day!!!
nice getaway. choose the crystal cabin (see thru glass floor) cale car cabin. it's cool!

Great experience ever!. I love the ride by cable air to see the Lantau Island, so It took 15 minutes to go to the island but the view is amazing and when you get there you going to see huge statues and a very cool island,

Big Buddha. Had a wonderful day out to Lantau Island.The ferry ride gives the opportunity to enjoy the views of all the islands around Hong Kong harbour, and scenery is great on the the bus ride up to the Buddha. We enjoyed the food stalls and some people watching before climbing the steps to the Buddha itself. Amazed & delighted to also discover a fabulous shoe shop nearby ! : )

Bestfood Resto. Whenever we have friends visiting, this resto is always a popular choice. Very local and convenient. They can pick up customers from Tungchung mtr station and bring them back afterwards. Good food and reasonably priced. Don't expect a fine dining ambience though :) like i said ,it is very local...
A nice day trip. I was pleasantly surprised by this trip. The cable car was good fun and the buddha worth a look. Saw many hikers which could be a good option.

#1 thing to do in Hong Kong is Lantau Island!. If you have just one day in HK, go to the monastery in Lantau island. Very easy to get there - it is the last stop of the train line (forget the name.) Right there are signs for the Pnogn Ping 360 (which is the cable car taking you to the top.) Get a cable car with "glass bottom"- it's worth the extra $$. Get the vegetarian meal in the monastary: totally worth it. Also, do your shopping in the village. A little pricey but the quality is much better than you would get anywhere else in Hong Kong.

spritual delight. What a place it was, amazing. Right from the start, the moment u take a ferry ride from hongkong side your excitement begins, it is almost one hour ride to lantau island. One has two simple options to go to lantau, either u take a ferry from hongkong side or can take MTR. We chose to go by sea. Once u reach island u have to take bus (bus stand is right in front of ferry terminal) to reach monastery, its a half an hour drive to Nao ping village where monastery and Big Buddha is situated. Very nice calm and beautiful place it was. Big Buddha is situated on hill top and to reach there u have to take 264 stairs, so it may be difficult for children and old age people.Must visit place if u are going to Hongkong.
Disney and Big Budda. For Big Budda take the cable cars both ways. For Disney, you only need one full day to see it. Suggest taking the MTR if you have time - the special Disney line is worth seeing.

Top of the world. Love here, big Buddha is Massive! Gotta walk alot of stairs to get to top but you feel good when you get to the top! Cable cars was out of service when we went but previously its a must go on cable cars! Very good sights and gets you excited, don't worry if you scared of heights i felt safe and looked at sides views but looking down sights not much to see anyway. Get a souvnier its all been blessed! Oh by the way the veggy restaurant is lovely too.

Big Buddha. We went from Nathan Road area of Kowloon by tube and had 1 change. Then by bus up some very steep inclines to reach the monastery. Buddha certainly is big but neither it or the temple is as old as I had supposed however well worth a visit. Simple vegetarian restaurant at the temple.

Visit the big budda. My daughter and I caught the ferry from central pier number 6 to Lantau Island a fast ferry about a 20 min journey then bus number 2 to the big budda the bus only takes the exact money no change given so have about 17.40HK for the bus fare. It is about a half hour journey up the mountain by bus to the Budda,we ate lunch there but would not really recommend it. Lots of very steep stairs to climb to the Budda.
Tranquil and peaceful. Amazing views and fantastic monastery and artefacts. Worth a visit

Very nice place. Perhaps a bit too far if one stays only a couple of days in Hong Kong. however, I would advise those who stay a bit longer to go and see this place. Great views from the top of the hill, where there is the large buddha. And absolutely delighful buddist temple which is worth a visit. Some small shops near the temple would also help you to find a souvenir for your visit.

Big Buddha worth the visit. Took the train to Tung Chung. The cable cars were not operating so took the bus around Lantau Island to the Big Budda. It was a great sight. We really enjoyed walking up the steps and around the Budda. Also took a look at Po Lin Monastery which was nice. The cable cars would have been a highlight but it was definitely worth the trip.

Worth a visit. This is a high light when you visit hong kong. Take the MTR to the Cable car which travels over to Lantau, the views are breath taking. We had a ball over there and the Buddha was awesome.

Big Buddha. Very easy to get to by Bus or Cable car- great for family day out. Cimb the steps to get a closer look then visit the temples around, some touristy shops in the village and some decent places for food too.

Lantau Island great escapade. The place is awesome especially in Ngong Ping:-)historical sites like the big buddha is breathtaking, i am also impressed at the buddhist monastery . you can also see the disneyland and you can ride at the cable car going to the Giant buddha.

A different side to Hong Kong. Love: the big Buddha, the vegetarian meal at Po lin, and how it's really green and peaceful. The mountainous landscape is gorgeous. We visited Tai O and it was way too crowded. It's a fishing village, so be warned, there are fishy smells and fish everywhere. A rather quaint place though. Lots of snacks if you're interested! Like smoked cuttlefish and pastries.

Do it - it’s a great experience! But do go early to avoid the crazy queues.. Although a bit expensive side, this is an experience that is well worth a few hours of your time. Just a few couple minutes walk from Tung Chung MTR station lies the Ngong Ping cable car station. The cable car ride itself is about 25 mins across hills & there are spectacular views of the mountainside trails. You can also see the entire Hong Kong International Airport along the way, with the planes landing, taxiing to the runway and taking off. If you have no fear of heights, take the “crystal cabins” – cable cars with a see-through glass floor. Not only is it slightly different & interesting, the queues for these cabins are slightly shorter although there are more of the standard cars hanging on the cables. The crystal cabins are more expensive though, so ask for the promotions prices at the counter before you pay.There will be folks at the base of the station asking you to take package tours or even selling tickets for a bus one way and a cable car the other way back, but I’d highly recommend taking the cable car both ways – you can always take a bus up a windy mountain road anytime. At the other end of the cable car line lies the somewhat artificial Ngong Ping village. Made to look like old China villages, this place is just the venue of the cable car station and a collection of souvenir shops & restaurants. You will walk past all of this on a well-defined 15min pleasant route to the highlight of the trip – the big Buddha statue at the top of the hill. From here, there are also public buses to Tai-O, a nearby fishing village. Depending on the weather, I guess it can get pretty cold, hot or wet as there isn’t a lot of shade. I’d also recommend that you check out the opening hours of the cable car ride (I think it changes according to the seasons & also closes for maintenance) then go as early as is practical for your own schedule. The queues can get horrendously long just to get tickets & board the cable cars, as long as an hour or two. And once the queue snakes out of the shaded station area, it can get pretty uncomfortable with the heat & sun, especially if you have kids in tow. Pros:- Unique experience & superb views - Try out the crystal cabins (see-through glass floors)- Very nice way to spend a few hours out of the city Cons: - Not cheap- Queues for the tickets can get extremely long from the late morning onwards

Worth Visiting Whilst in Hong Kong. Have been here 4 of my 5 times in Hong Kong - each to show a new traveller the site.Unfortunately this time the cable car was out of action so the trip via bus was a litle tedious and time consumingThe new monastry is currently under construction, but the works that have occurred at the site since my first visit have made a tremendous difference aesthetically.The 250-stir climb to the big Buddha is worthwhile but if you can't undertake thisthere are good views of the Buddha from the base.

If you like beaches, bike rides, scenery without buildings.. Lantau is a short ride from Hong Kong. You actually land there when you fly in. It is connected by bridge, but if you are interested in the beaches or the bike riding , mountain or road, you should come by Ferry to Mui Wo by ferry. I was there on a Sunday in late March. Temps in the high 70's, empty beaches, great scenery.

Home of the Big Buddha. This is where Buddhists go to visit and pray at the imposing yet serene Big Buddha! Climb up countless stairs to the top where the temple is. They also serve vegetarian lunches of gigiantic portions enough to feed an army. On Lantau Island also you will find the Sky City Marriott Hotel, one of my favourite hotels, and it is just next to the airport so getting your flight is an absolute breeze! In the Marriott is the Man Ho restaurant. Man Ho is the home of the famous and exquisite KIng Lobster Dumpling which makes gourmets swoon in ecstacy! It made me, The Travelling Gourmet swoon...

Budha a bit of a tourist trap. Our trip to Lantau was a mixture of pros and cons. With the cable car out of action on our trip, we had to queue 20 minutes or so for the 30-40 minute bus trip up to the Budha. Due to the queue we knew it would be pretty busy once we up there, we were quite surprised though by the numbers there and the Disney Land feel to the placeThe Budha itself was relatively impressive I suppose but the sheer number of tourists there took a lot away from the attraction in our eyes (seem to be the case everywhere these days)The trip got a lot better once we decided to walk back down to Tung Chung. The walk, which is pretty easy, takes you down the hillside on a concrete path, through some great scenery and past a couple of monasteries, far more authentic than that at the Disneyland like bus drop off!We got a bit lost once at the bottom of the path, where the signing seems to end but we just carried on walking in the same direction, slowly heading towards where the cable cars heading back into Tung Chung and got back to the MTR a bit short of 2 hours after leaving the Budha site.We'd certainly recommend this if you like a bit a walk and fancy getting away from the crowds, bar 4-5 monks, we only encountered another 5 or 6 people on our walk down

Unexpected Haven. Not knowing what to expect, I was totally amazed upon my arrival. No cars, lots of restaurants and a bathing beach to boot! Restaurant prices were unexpectedly reasonable in comparison to HK and the seafood was fresh. My visit was in March so not the peak season but I was amazed by the serenity of the place; however judging by the size of the restaurants, I gather it can get pretty busy during the peak season. No matter; go if you can; the ½ hour ferry ride alone is worth it!

very interesting. Visit to the 'Big Buddha' well worth the effort, a very long climb up a long stairway though, not for the unfit.Beautiful Temple reached through a long walkway of statues of guardian generals.Plenty of souvenir market stalls on the outside, restaurants both inside and in the village
Cool. Lovely place with awesome view! A getaway from the bustling city life.
Big Buddha!. We took the cable car to the Big Buddha. A must see attraction while in HK. Make sure to go on a clear day. Lots to see and lots of souvenir shops while in the top of the peak.
Nice day trip. Visit the Giant Budda and temple. Avoid Disney. See the old fishing villages.
My first time. We were so happy that we went with my lovely niece. Unfortunately, that we could not take the Nong Ping 360 so everything was great.

Great way to get out of the city!. I took the ferry to Lantau Island and walked from the south to north side. This stimulated my appetite and I tried a restaurant with the best prawns I have ever had.
relax place. good place for those who like nature. Place to skip from city busy life and it is the place to see how hong kong local people lives.
What a Contrast. Such a contrast from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong Central and Kowloon. Just a 40 minute ferry from Central. Beautiful sandy beaches! Great walks.

Lovely island with big Buddha. Having been to HK so many times, this is the first time I visited the Big Buddha. The island is lovely and you get a nice view after walking all the steps up. You can see the surrounding small islands and get close to the clouds!

A little disapointed. Went to see the buddah and Po Lin. The buddah was a little big, but I wasn't all too impressed. What made the visit not so good was that the cable track was out of order and too many gift shops. I saw mayby 10 buddahs, but 3-4 times as many gift shops. Highlights for me was the tea restaurant, Linong Tea, in the village. Chop stick gallery was also cool.
A tourist among the tourists. Went there on Sunday with thousands of Chines. Very special tobe a Eropean tourist between the Chinese tourists
Lots to do. Like: Po Ling Monastery, Ngong Village, Seat Buda, Walk of WisdomDislike: really nothing
Must visit. There is a mall called Citygate. You may find various branded items store such as Coach, Nike, etc. The price is a discount compared to usual store

Lovely beautiful little island. Next time I visit HK I intend to stay on this island, I can just I imagine grabbing a ferry back after a day in mad HK to the peace of this place, and really, the fast ferry is only 30 mins. Kick back and sit on the beach or wander round the little fishing village...what's not to like
Awesome. Awsome ride in the cablecar through the mountauins with the Big budda on the destination! The views are specacular! Either from hong kong and the mountain!

Gives you a different view of hong kong. I took a bus about to get out of city . It has an outlet mall where the metro arrives if you are looking for cheaper shopping . I headed for the mountains . Breathtaking

Go to see the Big Buddha and enjoy the cable car ride. One of the fun activities in Hong Kong is to take the Nong Ping Cable Car up to the Big Buddha on Lantau Island. The cable ride is breathtaking and you should opt for the glass floor. The ride is about 25 minutes each way, but you will notice the time cause it is so much fun. There are nice shops on the walk up to the stairway which many opt to walk up to get to the very top. Some of our party walked up, but some of us took pictures from below and went to the nearby Monastery and had just as much fun. It is an easy metro ride to the cable car. However, plan at least half a day to enjoy this experience.

Plenty to see and do on Lantau.... This place provides the opportunity for a lovely day out, starting with a ferry ride from central to Lantau Island.The trip to see Big Buddah was lovely along the island's winding roads, and the temple at Ngong Ping was beautiful to see. Tai-O village is also a worthwhile detour. There is also the opportunity to do plenty of walking on the island if you are so inclined, and the scenary is truly beautiful to see (the terrain of the island is very rugged and heavily wooded).
Well Worth a Visit. We took the Star Ferry then the bs up, fabulour ride up, weather not great but would go back just to see in better weather.
timing. we arrived too late to do anything and the island does not have a lot of information. so better to get some advise first before to go.
Overated. OK, but I have seen better monasteries in other Asian countries.The cable car was out of order, but it would be worth checking out.

Peace...Bliss. Want to get away from the buzz of Hong Kong? This is a good place to be. The Tung Chung MTR station is the place to go if you want to go to the Big Buddha. The cable car is right outside the station. If you take a cab, it's a long ride, costing about HK$140 or so. Takes easily 30-40 minutes through desolate roads, a lot of climb as well. The airport and the DisneyLand are in Lantau island, which seems way more peaceful than the crowded Kowloon area or Hong Kong island.

Oriental wonder, Hong Kong must see. Hong Kong welcomes you, whether you want to shop, experience its history or to wonder at it’s many tourist attractions.Lantau Island is a trip you can travel to yourself or do as I did, take a guided tour. I recommend this as the driving may well be a bit of a challenge to get to Lantau Island but once there it seemed to be easier.Lantau Island is well known for its Po Lin Monastery and its Giant Buddha. I’d heard about it and thought of it as being a rather large edifice – Wow it is gigantic, towering over the thousands of visitors who come to see and be in awe of it every day.Seeing it is a bit of a challenge if you go on a slightly inclement day as we did. As we stood and took in its massive frame, fog quickly came and covered it up – but seconds later, there it was again.On our Lantau Island tour this was our last attraction, on the way to Lantau island we’d also stopped to view the two suspension bridges, one is the largest suspension bridge in the world. After arriving on the island we swapped tour buses and went to a beach then on to the historic and rather quaint Tai O fishing village- this mostly built on stilts and as the name suggests fishing is dominant when you walk through the ancient market streets and go out on the water in a specially built tourist boat.From here we headed to the main attraction: Po Lin monastery and the Giant Buddha.Nothing can prepare you for how large this massive Buddha is.... he is surrounded by beautiful statue ladies as he sits on his lotus leaves. His vital statistics include weighing 250 tonnes and he is 34m tall. You can go inside him and visit ancient Chinese writing and wall art, over two floors.Our tour guide said he was cast in Japan but I have since read it was in China but wherever it was, he now sits huge on the hill in the Ngong Ping Plateau. He has his right hand raised in welcome and it is this welcome you need as you walk up the 200 steps to enjoy him, his maidens and the view around.Don’t worry, you can drive up if you wish.The Monastery he looks down on was once a small place built by three monks, but over the years it has grown to a large and most attractive place for modern monks but also for thousands of Buddhists and general visitors from all over the world. A new hall is being built at the back and when it is finished the monastery will look even more impressive as you walk up to it.Inside the Pin Lo monastery is magic. The three gold statues preside over dozens and dozens of full-in-bloom orchids of all colours. I love orchids so I was in raptures. A monk came in and kneeled to pray – how personal was that for us to see? I loved being inside this monastery, I quietly stood and looked outside, up the hill to the Giant Buddha, he dominates where-ever you are when at the monastery.We had lunch in the vegetarian restaurant, a seven-course banquet served on the revolving table and the food was, surprisingly, truly delicious.Other attractions we did not visit, so i cannot review them, but I add them so you will know the value of spending time on Lantau Island: Hong Kong Disneyland, nearby the monastery is the Wisdom Path which leads to the Heart Sutra, an outdoor prayer place.There was a huge swimming pool, lots of shopping opportunities and generally the daily life of Lantau Island is easy to see and for you to take memorable photos, as I did... far too many I think!!I know there are plenty of options to get to Lantau Island but as we took the luxury of going on a tour I cannot list the transport arrangements here: the massive cableway was not working and is due to open midway through 2012.
Well worth the visit.. An excellent day out. Travel by train, short walk to the cable car giving a great view of all around. Plenty to see and do with some good photo oppotunities.

Nice visit to the Big Buddha and Tai-O. The cable car was out so we took the bus to Ngong Ping. A rather winding but scenic ride. For those who get car sick, it could be a slight problem. I get car sick quite easily so I slept throughout the drive up.It was nice and windy when we got there. A nice long climb up to the Big Buddha. We even visited Anita Mui's niche. I'm quite a fan of hers so it was a nice. We also went to the Wisdom Path. Unfortunately, the words were in traditional mandarin so I didn't quite understand what were written on the large sticks. But the view was really great.After that, we took another bus to Tai-O. That was a really worthwhile trip. We took the boat out to see the dolphin but didn't see a single one, unfortunately. My young son was very disappointed. But the walk around the fishing village was a really great one, seeing the house on stilts, live seafood and tasting the yummy street food.
Lantau - big Buddha. Surprising special place , Great contrast from the business of Hong Kong Island and Kowloon
Beautiful Buddha. So serene and beautiful. nice way to spend the day.

Ample time choice - One Day trip. Ngong Ping 360 + Big Buddha + Tai OTung Chung MTR Station take NP360 to Ngong Ping, have a Veggie Lunch in the temple n visit the Big Buddha. Then take a bus to Tai O to see fish village and the house on the sea. Choices of going back to Kowloon or HK 1.Bus to Tung Chung MTR or 2.You may take a walk on Silver Beach in Mui Wo by bus to Mui Wo Pier and then sail to Central.** Show your respect, no bring meat n "Tai O Shrimp Paste" to temple.

well organised. We got the ferry from Kowloon to Hong Kong Island then to Lantau which was all well signed then at Lantau there is bays again well marked where the buses pick you up and take you to your chosen destination we went to the Budda. We were amazed how many bikes were at the ferry terminal at Lantau!!!

That's one BIG budha. :). A trip to the giant Budha is worthwhile, as long as you bare in mind that there are a LOT of steps leading to the statue. And I mean - a LOT.The view from the top of the mountain, next to the giant Budha is simply breathtaking.
So much to offer. Beaches, fishing villages, dolphins, buddha, monestery, cable car, some big hills for hiking, even a local brewery (Typhoon)... Lantau always has lots to offer.

there is so many lovely temples and site to visit. you have to go visit LANTAU theres a huge temple there lots and lots of stairs make sure you take lots of water and lots off rest stops so hot and a hard walk to the statue on the top of the mountain lovely views and worth the walk but hard for the people with walking problems

whilst the cable car is being maintained, freebies are on offer. The day we went was misty and rainy and the cable car was out of commission for maintenance. The replacement bus did a fantastic round-island tour (without commentary obviously) and when we reached the Big Buddha there were very few tourists. If you spent over 60HKD in a transaction you received a free MTR ticket to use for your return journey. Tickets to the shows (story of buddha and the monkey tale) were free as well. Climbing to the big buddha involved 260 steps which was manageable and lunch at the monastery (although vegetarian) was truly excellent. In fact, my dad didn't realise we weren't eating chicken :) reflecting the fact that tofu is a remarkably versatile food.

Visit if you have time. Big Buddha!! Take the bus from Mui Wo, visit the buddha and then come back down to the Stoep where the locals eat. Fabulous bread - you may want to take some home. The menu is South African and Mediterranean. Great spot! From Central Pier No. 6 (near Central's Star Ferry Pier or MTR's Hong Kong Station), catch a ferry to Lantau Island's Mui Wo (Fast Ferry takes 40 minutes, Normal Ferry takes 60 minutes). At Mui Wo, take New Lantau Bus No. 2 up to the Buddha. Eat a veggie meal at the Po Lin Monastery. A great day.

Well worth a visit. This is another 'must do' whilst in Hong Kong.The views are magnificent from Lantau peak, and the ride on the cable car affords some spectacular views en route.Then of course this is the home of the Big Buddha (the largest outdoor one in the world apparently).The fishing village of Tai O is a step back to another time. Well worth visiting too, as, once the old people who inhabit the water village have gone, this may not exist and become just a part of history?

would want to come again. it was a rainy day....filled with mist and fog...couldnt see beyond 5 meters...the whole place was quite and serene....but very unsatisfying as the weather was not on my side...if i have a chance to come back to Hk...lantau island is definately on my list...

Beautiful Day. I loved the island, I'm sure it helped that it was a beautiful day (for the most part). The Buddha was the favorite I've ever seen (and I had spent the whole month previous doing Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore, so I had seen ALOT of buddhas) The touristy town is cute, tea store is cool, I spent maybe 2 hours there in total. The cable car was down for maintenance, the bus ride was long but scenic (took my ipod with me). However my favorite part was going to the Tai O village after, such a contrast from the Ngong town. I was going to try some fresh seafood but after seeing everything I did in the markets I stuck with egg balls but It is so cool to see. Everything imaginable from the sea is sold there, mainly dried and they sell fresh stuff straight from there nets also. I just walked around and took pictures of everything, there is a bus that goes straight to Tai O from Ngong.
Raining and Wet. We took a bus instead of the Ngong Ping 360 cable car ride due to the bad weather.
Far from the maddening crowd...HK style. Lantau island has some of the vestiges of what HK used to look like. It is quieter and has more green spaces. It is worth the trip...take the ferry.

See the Big Buddah. WE went on a day that was a bit cold, so walking to the top the wind was howling, the village was nice, but we did not catch the cable car back as it was a bit pricy and opted for the bus bac.
GREAT. Buddha is good, town is good. A defintite must do.

A nice escape from Hong Kong. Great hiking on Lantau with nice views of the harbour. Easy to get around by bus, the timetables are clearly marked and details on when the next bus arrives are displayed.

great day out. We went on an organised tour to the island that included a trip to theTai O fishing village where the houses are on stilts and you catch a boat and have a walk around the narrow streets and the guide tells you what the strange products on the stalls are. They are not trying to sell you these fish products, its just a fasinating insight into others lives. You then go to the Pin Lo monastary and the big Buddha where we had a vegetarian meal included in the price. I recommend having this as it is delicious and the best meal I had in Hong Kong. The trip was supposed to include a cable car ride home to the mainland but it is under renovation after some people were stranded when it broke down a few weeks ago. The guide said they are updating the whole system rather than chance that happening again.
Must visit Ngong Ping 360. I love it here....Cold and fresh air and nice view..Visit the Great Buddha

A nice escape from the bustle. Although the cable cars are currently out of service for maintenance, the bus journey was quite enjoyable through the rolling mountains. The Po Lin Monastery and the Tian Tan Buddha were a good way to spend half-a-day.
Great Buddha. Most amazing place I have visited during my stay in Hong Kong

Interesting deals. Lantau island is ok if you wish to visit the giant Buddha. Well, nothing special with the giant Buddha, but at least you need to see it for once.
If I would go on Lantau island again, it would be for the Citygate Outlets, where I can get many deals on designer wear and accessories.

Worth the climb. We took the crystal cabin going to Lantau Island which was pretty cool because you'd get to see the bottom view since the floor is made of glass. We were kind of afraid to stand on the glass floor though. Before reaching the steps to the Giant Buddha, you will come across some shops, restaurants, and photo-op attractions like old cable cars. The climb was pretty tiring but it was worth it! The Giant Buddha looks remarkable and so is the view from the top! Make sure to wear comfortable shoes as you will be doing a lot of roaming!

Visit the Big Buddha here. If you can, get on an organised tour to see the Big Buddha on Lantau Island. I say that because it will be the easiest way for you to navigate all the crowds wanting to travel up to the Big Buddha on the cable way - there can often be lots of people waiting and a tour group will go before the rest of the public. The Big Buddha is great to see - and there is a beautiful monastery at the foot of the Buddha where you can get some lovely food. It's a very nice day out.
Perfect day trip. If you want to have a perfect slow day, go to Lantau Island - the nature around, magnificient cliffs, beach and Big Budha are there for you! :)

A grand day out. To get there there are a few options, tung chung then bus/cab, cable car from tung chung to po lin monestery or take a ferry from central piers to mui wo. No matter the choice there is lots to do here, tour the monestary, walk up lantau/sunset peaks, try one of the many trails across the island. To a trip to the old stilted fishing village of tai o or just enjoy cheung sha beach where you can get some good food a sun tan and well chilled out. An alternative is the walk from mui wo over to discovery bay or vice versa. Both spots have regular ferries back to central.
Big Buddha. Definitely worth a visit when in HK... Avoid the cable car when it's misty though, you sadly won't see a thing.

A Different Hong Kong. Lantau island is lovely. As well as Nong Ping and the Big Buddha there is the stilt village at Tai O where you can see a traditional way of life and see the Chinese white dolphins on a boat trip while they are still here. There are the most beautiful beaches at Cheung Sha, Pui O and Mui Wo and you can enjoy an alfresco lunch at one of the restaurants on the beach whilst taking in the most wonderful views. South Lantau is a National Park and there are the most wonderful walks and hikes. The paths are well marked and there are plenty of toilets en route.Don't just get off the ferry at Mui Wo and get on the bus to Nong Ping. Enjoy South Lantau it is truely a beautiful place.

Definitely worth the trip!. It was quite a trip to get there [an hour or so]. But seeing the Giant Buddha, going up the steps to get closer to it, seeing the other buddha surrounding it -- it was awesome! Don't ever leave the place without tasting the hot bean curd -- super yummy!!! I could have given a 5-star rating but the cable cars were not operational the time we visited. Go visit this place!!

Giant Buddha. Well worth the trip ,cable car was being upgraded on our visit ,but there was a bus service to the Giant Buddha.Its huge !the other bonus is the Factory Outlet shops on your return to cable car /bus depot with some great eateries indoors .
Travelling on local buses. Saw the Buddah and the local bus ride there. Awed by the buddah on the hillside
okay. quite an interesting island, but is not extremely clean. very interesting however, but i am not used to the atmosphere.

A comfortable walk in the woods.. The cable car is under repair, take the bus to the budda.Don't forget to enjoy lunch in the vegetarian shop in the back of the Pao Lin temple(aside the restaurant),You can choose whatever you like.
Home Away from Home. Great place to live.. access to shops and close proximity to numerous walking trails, and easy commute by MTR to HK City, and easy access to HK airport.
Lovely. Superb visit, cool cable car ride. Worth the extra for a crystal car.
Really loved the Buddha and the wisdom path. Most people don't go to the wisdom path butit is so worth it. I would say that it is even better than the Buddha!

Beautiful place. This is a gorgeous place, filled with peace and tranquility away from the hubbub life in Kowloon and Hong Kong Island. It is a beautiful place to enjoy the mountain scenery and lovely beaches. The fishing village is unique, take a sampan ride around it. The only disappointment was the Buddha, too much commercialism surrounding him.

Amazing - in a good weather. Save this trip for a nice day and enjoy the ride on the chair lift as well as the nature hike around the peak (about 2 miles). Make it a special point to visit the "Buddhist wisdom path" off to the side. The views, the temples and the overall experience is definitely worth it.

Biggest bronze seated buddha, Po Lin and Tai O. Lantau is a bigger island than I had realized and although I was going to visit using the MRT and cable car up to the Po Lin Monastery I went on a tour because the cable car is not operating for 2 months. Doing it this way I also go to see the Tai O fishing village at the far end of the island, where whilst exploring around the village I followed the sound of a violin. The man stopped playing when I picked up my camera and disappeared but returned quickly with another string instrument whose name I don't know but it seemed of the place. He proudly let me take his picture. That was a special moment. The seated Buddha was impressively big, but the village shops and Starbucks gave the whole Buddha area a very commercial tone. The vegetarian meal at the Po Lin monastery was the deluxe and I liked it but I've had much better in my home town. The drive took us past several beautiful beaches which in warmer times might be inviting.

"Loved It". We went to the giant Buddha. The cable car was closed for maintenance unfortunately so we caught a taxi. Taxis are faster and cheaper if a few to share the cost. We then went to a fishing village called Tai O and it is well worth a visit. My favourite place in Hong Kong. We left our luggage at the airport in storage as we arrived early and knew our room would not be ready so it was a good way to fill in time.
Really depends on the weather!. The Buddha museum and the monastery grounds were beautiful, but in foggy conditions, the views are drastically impacted.

Tian Tan Buddha 21/02/2012. Having caught the 23 bus (as the cable car is closed for 2 months) I was taken on a journey through some beautiful and astonishing scenery. Lantau seems to be a beautiful must see during a short stay in Hong Kong. Had the weather have been substantially better I would have enjoyed it all the more. Today was very cloudy, grey and it was drizzling. I had to keep my camera under wraps as I didn't have an umbrella (schoolboy error!) I managed to take a few shots of the enormous Bronze Buddha which in itself was truly amazing. WOW. So what ever the weather this is a must do if you have very limited time here. P.S!! There is a themed walkway/village which is not worth the walk through but you will have pass it if you take the cable car. Lots of 'theme park' style shops etc.

Go to the big Buddha!. I've been to hong kong many times but have never seen the big Buddha til now. Well worth the trip! But make sure you book a tour that will take u all the way to the top of the Buddha. That way, the steps you will climb will be the ones going down. Easier on the knees :)
No cable car. Didn't manage to see the big buddha as the cable car was out of operation and it was misty
Don't forget to visit Citygate Outlet store. Great venue for lots of shopping!!! Highly recommended.

Citygate. Nice place for shopping.. cheap ... though probably you can get the same prices in discount stores at TST too... still worth going for a half a day... we didnt visit the Ngong Ping as the cable car was closed for maintenance.. .

Big Buddha. This is always a must when we visit HK. Each time gets easier too. The cable car was suspended, but was fine. We took the metro to Tung Chung, last stop, and as soon as you walk out, you catch the No 23 bus which takes you up to the buddha. It was 35HKD unlimited one day pass. For senior, pay when you board for half price. They have definitely expanded the monastery, with new roadways, new paths, and Ngong Ping shopping area. The vegetarian meal was 68HKD for standard, there was also a deluxe version but we passed on that.
Look around. Great walks and birds you will love it! For food try silverMine bay and mui wo

Great relaxing day out!. From Causeway Bay to Lantau Island via train took me about 30 minutes. Spent a few hours at the shopping center but the main purpose of this trip was the Big Buddha which is another 20 minutes ride by bus.

Fog added to the sanctity. It was a trip (subway, ferry, ferry, bus) to see the Big Buddha, but I enjoyed the journey and didn't have a better option with the fog. It is a nice place to walk around and attempt to tackle the stairs to the Buddha without break. You can see if quickly (30min-1hr), but the journey will take the same depending on your starting location, mine was Langham Hotel in Mong Kok.
citygate outlet, disneyland. good view of the ocean, greeneries are nice! one of the must visit area in HKG

Away from the hustle and bustle. Just a short boat trip away or travel by land.
Great place to get away from the busy shopping areas and get some fresh air and peace.

Great but don't go if its misty or cloudy, you won't see the Buddha. The cable car was out of action because one stopped for an hour recently trapping people. The bus is long and windy road. If and when the cable car gets fixed, it may be a better, though less safe option

Away from the mad city. Lantau is a big island. That's where the Big Buddha stands. There are many villages and rural areas. You can pretend breathing almost normal air there. There are a few beautiful walks to do in the mountains.

big Buddha. HK airport, the big Buddha and Tai O is all on this island. take a cable car from Tung Chung MTR station to the Big Buddha. worth paying for the view en-route.
Tai O is accessible by coach from Tung Chung bus station. Tai O is a nice place to get out of the busy mainland HK.

Big Buddha. Good afternoon out, used the glass bottom cable car to get to the Big Buddha. Got the MTR from Central to Lantau and the cable car station is next to it. We were fortunate that the Mandarin Oriental and orgainsed our tickets for the cable car becasue the queues were very long. When you reach the peak just below the Big Buddha there is an element of tourist atractions and easteries, gift shops. that said once you climbe the hundreds of step to see the Big Buddha it is worth the experiance as the view alone is fantastic

A fantastic trip to Po Lin. Take your time and plan a day trip to Lantau Island. Take the MTR and from there by bus to the Po Lin monestry. Beautiful and very peacefull. Do have a lunch with the Chinese in one of the restaurants. And most of all a steep climb to the Giant Buddha to pay your respect. Go back if you dare by the cable car. It will be a splendid day on a Hong Kong Island.
Great break from HK. Missed the stop for the Buddha (bus line) and ended up at a small fishing village that was an enjoyable excursion. Sometimes you just stumble on these great spots !

Go see Big Buddha. When we went the Cable cars were down for maintenance so we had to take the bus...not bad. Slept for the 45mins and only spent $20HKD each way...way cheaper than $160. Big Buddha is a sight to see. The Climb up to the Buddha is a mine altering experience. I suggest going to see big Buddha then going to Disneyland...a few hours at Disneyland and your done.
Biggest Buddah Statue in HK.. It's worth seeing, and enjoy some vegetarian food from the monestary.
Worth the visit. Great trip, super easy to get to on the train, shopping centre at the station then a lovely, fun cable car ride to Big Buddha.
Great day out. we had a very enjoyable day here and the cable car was amazing.

HKG is not just shopping!. Experience the not-so-busy Hong Kong. Great to visit and experience. See the temple and nearby sites at Ngong Ping. The cable ride from CityGate mall was a thrilling experience (especially if you take the "Crystal Cable Car"...and have a 360 degree view (well not the top.. just below). climb the stairs to see the Buddha and visit the temple nearby.There are shows about Buddha and monkeys (a package trip can be purchased near CityGate Mall.

Big Buddha. Opt for the Crystal Cable Car on the way up which has the see through glass floor. Strolling around Ngong Ping and ultimately the Big Buddha was such a great experience. I highly recommend that this is something that you cannot miss when in HK. Don't forget to visit the Wisdom Path, it's nestled away in the mountains where you can see the Heart Sutra scribed on large wooden pillars.
View from the top. Nice view especially if you are riding the cable car on a clear day. Experience took me about ten to twenty minutes (lost track of time).
Day out.. Pick a clear day and not at the weekend - we went to see the Seated Buddha and it was excellant as was the vegetarian lunch in the monastery.

Enchanting Place. We got here very quickly due to the swell connected metro station. Once you get to the main spot there are 2 types of cable cars that take you up to the Lantau Buddha. We chose the slight higher prices but beautiful glass bottomed cable car and had a great experience traveling up to the top. Once there we walked through the small quaint village looking at knick knack etc till we reached the largest open air statue of Buddha and it was a very sere moving experience. Just being there made one feel peaceful. Then we visited the monastery below which served buddhist veg. food eaten by the monks as well. It was a great experience and then we got back so its a half day trip which one can end by visiting a fair that takes place neat the exit of the cable car ride.
Respite. Lantau is a great get away from Hong Kong and the hustle and bustle. Less than an hour ferry ride, or you can take the MTR, and it's very quiet. Good seafood in Discovery Bay and Mui Wo.

Big Buddha. Thde biggest buddha in the world is situated on Lantau island. It is easy to get to by train from Central district. The cable car to the Buddha stretches for around 5 kilometres providing excellent photo opportunities on a clear day.

Crowded, but worth it. Just outside the city is Lantau Island, home to the Po Lin Monastery and the world’s largest outdoor Buddha. Lantau is accessible by the MTR (subway) and definitely worth a day trip. From the subway station, the 23 bus or cable cars will take you to the monastery; we opted for the bus. The Buddha statue sits at the top of a large staircase and provides a spectacular view of the surrounding mountains and valleys. The swastika on Buddha’s chest may seem a little disconcerting, but keep in mind the symbol was used in Chinese culture long before the Nazis hijacked it. If you don’t mind a walk, the Path of Wisdom is just fifteen minutes from the main area. Large, carved planks of wood are set upright in the ground along the path and stretch more than thirty feet into the air. Arranged in a figure eight pattern to represent infinity, they are quite an impressive sight set against the backdrop of mountains.Read more and see photos at:www.thetattooedtraveler.com

Disneyland not up to it cant even buy a hot dog //BUDDAH on Lantau breath taking. Go early avoid crowds // dont expect the same as you would in USA // FOOD IS BELOW PAR // but he rest of Lantau is great

Loved our visit. We did our own thing and caught the ferry to Lantau and then the local bus to the Big Buddah. We then caught the cable car down to the train station and and train back to Kowloon. A wonderful day out and it cost us only about $22 each
Big Buddha and very touristic... Well, it is a very big Buddha, but I missed the history behind it. Ebeneezer has nice food and a free wi-fi :)

A must if you have the time. Take the MTR to Tung Chung (about twenty mins) and you have reached Lantau Island. The airport is here, but the "big" draw here is the Big Buddha at the Po Lin Monastery. You can take a bus up there if you like to avoid the crowds or don't like heights - otherwise take the cable car which affords wonderful views of the South China sea below. I didn't like the theme-park like restaurants and shops that they have since built at the entrance to the Monastery but get past the fast-food joints and wonder at the feat of engineering that put the biggest bronze statue of the Buddha in the world at the summit of some hundreds of steps. And the view from the top is stunning. The termples at the monastery are beautiful and work is currently underway to build a bigger one (this spoils the view a little, but the price of progress i guess). The meal at the vegetarian restaurant was excellent value too and makes a nice stop for lunch.If you have the time, take a stroll along the Wisdom path which leads away from the Monastery and the crowds. It is clearly signposted and affords beautiful views of the island's mountains and surrounding countryside.

Beautiful Buddha!. An easy metro ride from the city will get you out to the island. A cheap bus ride takes you all around the island and to a cute little fishing village where you can see more of the chinese fishing lifestyle. You absolutely must visit the large seated buddha on the island.
LANTAU ISLAND...Surely be back again. The place is nice. My friends enjoy the cable car ride very much.
Fishing Village. well worth the visit interesting to get away from the city

Smiling Buddha. We were off to see the Big Buddha!! It was a located at Lantau island a long way from our hotel but the infrastructure is very convenient and very easy to travel even if you are going on your own. It took us about 45 mins to get there and the weather was really pleasent as we went during Winter. We could only see a glimsp of the Buddha from the bus ride and it looked really small but once we got down..... The Buddha more of the Golden Buddha was sitting there above a mountain of stairs with a beautiful smiling face.... It was so peaceful looking at it... you can imagine how many people were climbing up that fleat of stairs just to go and pay their respects regardless of their age... once inside....theres this place of worship and it was made so homely....with a lot of peace and you could actually see how people prayed so faithfully in hope of seeking blessings.... it was really nice but by the end of the day we were exhausted too much to take in for one day

Worth the visit. The cable car ride is wonderful - if you have a clear day. The cable car is located right next to the airport. (You can see the cable cars from the terminals.) The big attraction is the large Buddha - climb on up and look around inside. There are also some good hikes in the area. It was actually the end of October 2008 when I went - the weather was warm & very windy.
a real retreat fm the big city. countryside and endless hiking trails and some good food after a long day
must do !. Ngong Ping, Giant Buddha, Po Lin Monastery must be visited. Easy to reach; last stop Tung Chung station and cable car from there. It takes about half an hour journey over the sea and peaks

Retreat from the busy city!. Highly recommend the Ngong Ping 360 Holiday tour. They take you to Tai O Fishing Village where you can see the different life style people live in. Also they tell you the background and history of the place they bring you. You can take the crystal cable car where the floor is made of glass. Not sure if it's worth 70HKD because you can just look down from the regular car and see the same thing. But if you have children, I'm sure they will love it!

Fantastic glass bottomed cable car!!. Must see when one is in HK. We had gone in Feb and it was freezing cold. We took glass bottomed cable car which was fantastic. Had great day trip and great pictures taken. The giant Buddha was amazing!!

Excellent day out.. Ferry across the bay, then bus to Tai O fishing village. Lunched from stalls in the market. (grilled scallops, dried squid, black bean bun etc). Then bus to Ngong Ping for Po Lin Monastery and Big Buddha. Pot of tea from tea grown there. Finally bus to Metro Station and back to Kowloon. Do NOT need to book a tour, our trip was far cheaper and more flexible.

Nice break from the hectic city. A full day trip - first by ferry, then coach to a beach, fishing village (very interesting to see some of the dried and fresh fish on sale), trip on a boat through the village, drive to the Big Buddha, lunch (vegetarian) in a Buddhist monastery, walk through shopping area to cable cars, cable car back to airport, drive back from airport. Very busy day but plenty of contrast and nice to see a more quieter way of life in Hong Kong. Lunch was very good - surprised at this as I have never eaten vegetarian Chinese food before.
So relaxing !. This Island is a very relaxing Island to visit and many things to do and see there. We only wish we had more time to spend there.

Giant Buddha. Most people prefer to take the Ngong Ping cable car up to the mountain. However, as we found the price too steep, we took a nausea inducing but very cheap (HKD17) bus ride up the mountain. I'm not a buddhist, but the view from the top of the stairs is worth the long flight up.
go by ferry. as a tourist you have not to rush. Take a boat from Victoria and enjoy the trip on the harbor and sea to Lantau.Much better than to go by car.

That place I really love!. This is No. 2 attraction in Hong Kong at my personal ranking. I do not know why there is not so much tourists as I would expect. You can easily reach this site by metro and the cable car station is just near the metro station. I would advise you to go up by the cable car and down by local charter bus because it is significantly cheaper and more fun (at time of visit the price of round trip on the cable car was 140HKD and the one-day pass on any local bus route with included coupon to one free cable car trip cost was 104HKD).
