There is no admission fee to visit monastery itself.At the time I've been there the weather was very misty, nevertheless the view from the cable car cabin was great! The cable road is long, makes some twists over the mountains so you will have a good chance to see the most part of Lantau from the cabin.As to the monastery itself sure you'll fill a touch of the good aura of this place. I saw quite a number of shrines, but, man, this is a special one! I can add no more words - just try to get there and see it yourself if you are in Hong Kong.

A MUST SEE AND DO WHILE IN HONG KONG!. We had a great day trip excursion to Lantau. Get an early start and spend the entire day there. We took the train MTR to Tung Chung , and then the cable car to the top. It is best to take the cable car, spend a few more HKD and get the "Crystal Car" which is an all glass cable car! Yes all glass even the floor! The view will blow you away! You can walk up to the BuddahWhen you arrive at the top head for a visit to the Giant Buddha and the Monastery. There are 2 museums there , one about a monkey and one on Buddha story. Honestly you can skip this.  We did the big vegetarian lunch at the monastery. It was good but no meat! It was tasty, I didnt see a bunch of other restaurants there so not sure if there are better options.Take the bus from the top to Tai O. The narrow streets and stilt homes of this small fishing village must be seen. As must do is the market area. It is quite a site and reminds one of rural China. Lots of open air stalls, seeling fresh fish and slated ones, veggies etc.. There is also a small temple that was worth a stop into,..I saw numerous tiny dolphin excursion boats. i am not surre I would truat goimg out on these rinky dink boats but you can decide for yourself.. After this take the bus to Cheung Sha Beach for a swim. Or go directly to Mui Wo, possibly for dinner. From there, take the ferry (every hour) back to Central.Take the Star Ferry back to Kowloon and watched the light show! Have fun!!

Lantau Island. At one time you could only get to Lantau by ferry, but now that it houses the new airport, there is a high speed rail link. You can also get the MTR (underground) to Lantau and take a cablecar up to the top to the enormous buddha, reached by 100 (I think) steps. Po Lin Monastery is at the same place and is worth visiting - you will see the robed monks going about their daily business and can purchase a vegetarian meal if you wish. A small Disneyland has recently been built on Lantau Island and this can be accessed by the MTR. We didn't go into the theme park but visited the Disneyland hotel which was beautiful. A marble and glass creation, very tastefully done with a choice of restaurants, lovely views and a souvenir shop. On the far side of Lantau is a small fishing village called Tai O which is worth a visit - some residents still live in houses on stilts in the river. The old H.K. is fast disappearing, but it is still a place full of character.

Well worth a trip. Travelled out to see the Big Buddha and wasn't dissapointed. Amazing spectacle. The cable car up is fantastic! We took the glass bottomed one and it was like being in a helicopter. We walked back through the valley, beautiful but tiring as it was very steep downhill all the way.

Visiting the Big Buddah. Very nice (far) though the queues (again) were too hectic, we opted for the bus ride (40min up) and went down with the cable car (we queued for a good 40min) The Big Buddah was quite an amazing sight
Pity few people go. what a lovely relaxing place, and not many tourists

My visit to see the Big Buddah. Visiting Hong Kong for the first time, this was the place I wanted to visit. I heard so many storied from friends and family about Lantau Island. It gives you peace and serenity. It's beautiful and the Buddah was so big! You think you are near but its actually quite a walk. We did not take the Cable Train to the Island since they were closed for maintenance. We took a cab up there and it was a very windy road so make sure you do not have motion sickness if you opt for this form of transportation.I recommend you were comfortable shoes or sneakers because there will be a lot of walking. Overall it was an amazing experience and I enjoyed every part of it.
Fantastic. Monastery and Buddha really a must see in Hong Kong. My only advice would be if you have any aversion to heights DO NOT use the cable car!!

Do a round trip yourself - great day out. Take the MTR from the city then the cable car to the Big Buddah. Walking round the statue and the monastery is an ethereal experience on a par with Corcovado and Cape Reinga. Take a few minutes out to watch the locals and the monks paying their respects. Then to get back take the bus down to the harbour, have lunch on the seafront and take the ferry back to HK for a great day out.

relaxing place. Going to Lantau Island is easy via MTR. The cable cars were fun, but not the waiting in line. The cable cars were spacious, so we have to share a ride with other people we don't know. It was enjoyable to walk around and just see what the place has to offer. Going up the long flight of stairs to the giant buddha was a challenge, but it was worth the effort. Leaving Lantau Island close to its closing time was a mistake, the lines were so long, and we had to wait for and hour and a half which was really tiring (after walking all day). tip: leave earlier than the rest of the visitors.

A great day trip. We took a day trip with Gray Line to Lantau Island. The Cable car transported us up to its top station from where we were driven up to see the Tian Tan Buddha. The views from the Cable Car were great particularly of the airport and the priority given to Gray Line meant that we avoided all the lengthy queues both on the way up and on the way down. The bus to the Buddha saved us climbing the 260 steps. Again a great view and the small museum was very interesting.We then returned down to see the Po Lin Monestry complex which was an interesting and educational experience. Our final trip was to the Tai O Fishing Village to see the fish market and houses on stilts.A very interesting and enjoyable trip.
Great Day Trip. Touristy but worth the trip, easy on the ferry and you get to see the Giant Buddah.
Must See. Visit the Giant Budda and fishing village, see the pink Dolphins.

Great experience. Firstly, remember to take your wallet!!! There is a outlet shopping centre located at the train station - and it has all the big brands - we spent $$ in the polo Ralph Lauren and addidas stores all with the entire range of shirts etcWe didn't bother catching the cable car as the line was 2hrs, plus the ride is very slow and we didn't want to be locked in such a confined space for 1hr!Bus ride as approx 45mins and relatively painless.The big budha is great, take some lunch up there and sit/ relax and enjoy the open space

A different side of HK experience. It's worth it to stay a couple of days on lantau instead of Central or Kowloon. The only outlet shopping mall is here in Tung Chung, but more than that, there's the Big Buddha and the hills of Lantau Island to explore. If you have plenty of time, you can even hike up to Big Buddha, but for those on a schedule, there's the Ngong Ping cable car that can do the legwork. Yes, the area around Bing Buddha it is a pretty crowded place, though it is nothing compared to crowds of HK island, and it's a totally different side of HK that you just don't get to see in Central or in Kowloon. Despite the crowds, it feels quite serene and spiritual, perhaps because the Buddha is sharing that hill with Po Lin monastery and temple. There are plenty of people praying and the smell of incense and birdsong fill the air. Here and there monks go about their daily wanderings. It's a pretty nice place to just be and watch the life go by, and if you're up there between 12 and 4pm you can partake in the vegetarian lunch prepared by the monks. The only thing is that the line ups for Ngong Ping cable car can get pretty long. The day we were there, the line up to get back down was 3 hours long. Something we found out accidentally - if you buy a Crystal Car ticket for the cable car on the way up, then you get to go into a separate, much shorter line! We did, and our line up on the way back was only 1 hour instead of 3!Some photos of our trip to Big Buddha here: http://lenamitranic.smugmug.com/Travel/Hong-Kong/20951232_6P2GNm
interesting. Visit the longest escalators and temple and Johnson Road is great for shopping

Big Buddha. We got the boat to lantau to see the Big Buddha. It's about 30mins on a bus after the ferry trip. Worth a visit as few shops/eateries near the big budha. You've got to be fit to walk up the 241 ish steps to the actual Buddha. Breath taking view one you're up there.

A nice day out. We got to Lantau (Silvermine Bay) via the ferry from Central. Unfortunately, the skies were grey due to air pollution which marred the enjoyment of the harbour skyline. Otherwise, the ferry ride was fine. Once at Lantau, we hopped on the bus for the outdoor buddha. The scenery on the island was passable - not exactly jaw dropping, but not bad either. It would have been nice to do some walks on the island if we had the time. The tourist village at the foot of the Outdoor Buddha was a big tourist trap though. To end the day, we took the cable car ride down to Tung Chung MTR station. Quite scenic, as you get a view of the island and the airport but we probably won't be doing it again anytime soon considering the price of the ticket. Bear in mind that the queues could be daunting if you travel down just before closing.

Beautiful island. A nice daytrip is to take the slow boat from central to Lantau and the bus trip to "big Buddha" + Temple. Take bus back to Tseun Wan and reach Red Line to down town. A cheep way to have an nice daytrip

A commercialized "pilgramage" to the Giant Buddha. We had to make two trips to Lantau Island to visit the Buddha because we arrived too late on the first day (around noon) and the line to BUY tickets was 2 hours long. There were no "blue" taxis (the only ones that go up to the Buddha) to be had whatsoever. When finally made it on the second try, we were impressed with the cable car ride (pay for the one with the see-through bottom on the way up) that took us across many passes. However, it was a tremendous disappointment to arrive in what they will call a "culturally themed" (read: commercialized) master planned "buddhist village" consisting of chain establishments (i.e., Starbucks), restaurants, shops and - because it was Christmas - vendors booths that schpeeled fake snow and sold and Christmas related junk like snowmen, elves, and miscellaneous ornaments. All this occurs at the base of the Giant Buddha - how inconsistent with the meditative and spiritual nature of Buddhism! A fascinating tourist attraction (if for no other reason than to see the odd contradictions of Buddhist spirituality and western commercialization) - but don't come and expect a pure Buddhist spiritual experience.
Great cable car ride. The cable car ride is fantastic, and vegetarian meal at the monastary excellent
Consider one day for the whole trip - you ll be mesmerized by the views and the entire experience to see Big Budha. I never get tired taking my friends visiting Hong Kong there ...
A long walk to the top. Very enjoyable from the cable car ride to the giant Buddha and Po Lin Monastary abit commercialised and a 250 steps to the top

Lantau Island - still a sanctuary from it all. I read a review saying that Lantau's ruined now the airport has been built, and felt I had to respond. It seemed a bit strange, as Lantau Island is still larger than Hong Kong Island, and there's an awful lot of it that hasn't had an airport built on top of it. Yes, it's not 100% unspoilt by the 21st century (there's a Disneyland, and there are buildings, and roads, yes...) but there's still plenty of space to go for a hike and forget that you're in one of the most densely populated parts of the world.Much of Lantau is still as sleepy as it was before - don't let more regular ferries and an MTR connection at Tung Chung put you off - you can still get a very rural experience in Lantau. I would recommend (if you're in the mood for a strenuous hike) that you try Sunset Peak from Mui Wo. If you just want a more relaxing day, then the beach at Pui O is usually very nice. Other attractions like the Big Buddha and the Ngong Ping 360 are worthy of their own reviews...If you're visiting Hong Kong solely because it's a big, exciting city, then Lantau is probably not for you. If you're here for a little longer and fancy a break from the hectic downtown rush, certainly worth getting out here.

Sadly, the new airport has ruined it. In the old days, a boat ride to Lantau Island was fun. Spending time at the old monestary was interesting, even after they built the huge Buddha. However, once they built the airport, the original character of Lantau Island vanished. A real shame!

Glorious Buddha!!!. A cable car ride from the base of the mountain is the best way to take in the sights. For the others there are walking or bus rides options.The walk up the many many steps to the gigantic buddha can be a tad bit tiring but once you reach the top...AMAZING. Take your time going arounf the place and grab a fruit lollie to eat on the way down. This attraction will take you a couple of hours only so plan something else to do as well ...like a trip to disneyland/ocean park. as it will leave you with plenty of time to kill.

A little treasure. Lantau Island is only a 30 minute ferry ride from either Hong Kong or Kowloon yet it is 100 years away, why people insist on a Hong Kong post code when they can commute from Lantau is beyond me. It has a Giant Buddha for culture vultures, and excellent restaurants they speak little English but are very friendly. The restaurants may look a little scruffy but the food is exquisite.

A truly humbling experience. Went to Tung Chung station from Hollywood Hotel by MTR and took Bus # 23 to the Big Buddha. Climbed approx. 220 steps to reach the top where the enormous bronze statue of Buddha is seated serenely. Walked to Po Lin Monastry and up the Wisdom Path. Had some great vegetarian meals at the restaurant. Really enjoyed the scenic surroundings and shopping at the Nong Ping village.
Giant Buddha. Worth to going on Ngong Ping 360 to see giant buddha on cold weather.

Beautiful Island. Lantau Island is a large island with the statue of Buddha at the peak. One needs to take the cable car to reach there. The cable ride is also very scenic and takes you thru the valleys of the various mountains, finally to the peak.Lantau Village has lots to do. Nice restaurants, and of course the peak where the statue of the Giant buddha lies. It was a hot sunny day when we reached there, but at the top, it was cool and breezy and very peaceful.
Must see in Hong Kong. Visiting Lantau island and the giant Bhudda is a must for a trip taking in Hong Kong. Take the glass bottom cable car ..... great ride

A good trip out of the city. Either a 30 or 45 minute ferry from HK island to Lantau then a bus ride on twisty and hilly road up the mountain to the Big Buddha and temple complex. Quite busy, but a large enough area that it did not feel too crowded. Returned via cable car and metro to Central. Easy to do independantly and an enjoyable and scenic day trip.

A good way to see Hong Kong from the ferry. Take a ferry ride to Lantau Island for a great way to see the city from the water and enjoy a wonderful seafood experience at the island. The island itself is very basic, not much to see or do other than indulge in the seafood on offer. All the seafood is on display in tanks out front of the restaurants and there are some interesting varieties on offer. You won't be disappointed the quality is excellent!

Big Buddha is stunning. Well worth sticking on to an itinerary on HK. We travelled by bus to the Big Buddha and then returned via cable car - a good way of doing it as the queues for the cable car going to the Buddha were over 1 hour long. You will really enjoy this trip.

Skip tours - do Lantau on your own. Its very easy to do this on your own. MTR directions are very clear and the cable car station is right across the last stop. Don't feel compelled to buy a round trip ticket for the cable car because the return one way from Lantau is very cheap.Sign up for the vegetarian meal, worth the experience and the food is interesting.

Great Tour Lots to See !. Loved our visit to Lantau, we took a day tour to save time, it was very busy though and extremely touristic but loved the Big Buddha, we had to que for a long time to catch the cable car back which was a bit annoying. Our vegetarian lunch at the monastery was absolutely delicious and our guide was fantastic so overall well worth the money.
City and Wilderness. Lantau is the biggest island in Hong Kong. It is worth exploring if you have time but at least visit the Giant Buddha.

Traditional Living. Lantau is fascinating, a real mix of east meet west. Modern shopping malls alongside traditional Chinese shops and markets. Do be sure to visit the huge Flower Market and the Caged Bird Market.

Beautiful & Tranquil. This Island is something else! - So tranquil. I could easily live on this island! Not many cars so noise is minimal, transport of buses leave BANG ON TIME (literally, as oon as clocks ticks), gorgeous restaurants and we found a pint of Strongbow whilst watching the boats/ships - PERFECT!

Nice breather from hustle bustle of Kowloon. After numerous visits to Hkg, I haven't yet gone to Lantau to see the Big Buddha, so i decided to do so on this trip. It was fairly easy to get to. I read the reviews here and was good to go. I had intended to go on a weekday, taking the advice of some contributors here to avoid crowds and save money. BUt i had a free sunday and decided to go on a sunday instead.I took the MTR to Central and took the ferry over.I took the fast ferry b/c i missed the slow one. But i was relieved while on the ferry to take the 'fast ferry' (which is 30 min vs 1 hour). the water does get rather choppy and rough at times. (fast ferry cost around double the price of the slow one).i arrived at about 11am so it wasn't too crowded. I then took a bus up to the BB. There were a few tour buses there but not bad. The stairs going up to BB wasn't bad at all. I expected more climbing but it was quite do-able (and I have exercise induced asthma). I explored for about an hour. If i had more company maybe we could have hiked more. I had some lunch at one of their 'dai pai dongs' and had a tofu dessert. They seem to have advertise that alot. I also went to Tai O, which i really didn't see much. Many vendors selling dried goods/seafood. Go early, enjoy the scenery and fresh air. There are vendors selling souvenirs as well. When i got back to the pier, Mui o (?) i had some clams with rice. I was very disappointed. There were a bunch of restaurants concentrated there. THe lady gave me a chinese menu and i ordered from that. I ordered clams but they came out super super small and at least 1/2 didn't even hav e meat in them. i think overseas they would not allow one to net clams that small. Anyway, when the bill came i noticed she shortchanged me. Then i asked her wasn't the price xxx and she pretended she didn't know the price on the chiniese menu and pointed to a banner w/ the english menu. She comes back and the change still isn't right. I decided not to hassle and deal with her and just left. But a bit disappointed nto to have some good seafood choices.

Big Buddha Blessings. A great place to be not only as a tourist, but also as a pelgrim. Enjoy the environment and the ceremonies of the Po Lin Temple. Enjoy the food being offered for a very low price and large quantities. Don't hold your money in your pocket, but give your donations, be generous. You will be blessed!
Lantau Island. Good ride on the 360 cable car, nice view. The shopping at the Citygate was great after visiting the Lantau Island

Citygate Outlet, a different kind of shops. The other pattern of shops among TST, Causeway Bay, Mongkok. Why not check in 4 hours advance for departure for shopping there. Free shuttle bus from Novotel Citygate to airport, that won't miss your flight.

Buddha in the sky. gorgeous Buddha high up on top of Lantau island with little village to wander through before taking the cable car down. Make sure you go by ferry and bus first then by the cable car go experience the trip to the island by water and land. A fun day out W

Big Buddha inspiring from cable car. The cable car ride to the Big Buddha is quite something especially as the Big Buddha comes in sight in the distance in the hills.Tai O fishing village - a very down market "Venice of the East" - is an interesting stop. It has a quite "genuine" feel to it: a fishing village of about 3000 people, with shops selling dried fish (especially fish stomachs which are highly prized for their anti-ageing properties). Compared to the high tech bustle of Hong Kong it is a little perhaps fast closing window on a part world.
Great seafood but pricey. They have fresh and great seafood varieties but very pricey. Not worth to travel there for the food since you will find cheaper and same quality seafood in the city.

Best part of our trip. Magnificant view if you take a short hike along wisdom path to its ends. The climb up the stairs to the Buddha statue was okay for healthy adults and children. Might be challenging for the older folks.

Die Die must go. Big Budha, must go place... see the huge budha statue on the hill, just a great view and place to take photo.Fishing Village, one of the best place to go, and eat sea food or what ever food from sea on the road side, all fresh... We eat the "tofu fa" there, with ginger sugar, just amazing, taste very good... omg, we can't stop eating there.We took ferry from pier 6 to the fishing village, and continue with the bus direct. fast ferry take 30 min, while ordinary ferry is 1hr, bus will take another 30 minutes.

A must see while in Hong Kong. Lantau island is a must see area, since your flight will land on Lantau island! While there, visit the following:1. Ngong Ping 3602. Tung Chung - shopping mall3. Discovery Bay4. Disneyland.5. Tao O1. Ngong Ping 360 is a cable car ride from Tung Chung to the famous Buddha temple on Lantau island. THere are two types of cable car, standard and glass bottom. You are so high up, that the glass bottom cable car is not more scary, it just gives you a better view. Its very safe, steady and fast moving. THe whole 7km journey takes about 25 minutes. Take the 400 or so steps up to the Buddha and take in the glorious views. Althouhg i havent tried it, the vegeterian meals availalbe are worth a try. Alternatively for the more fit, there is a hiking trail which goes along the same route as the cable car, taking about 6 hours or so.. not light walking.2. Enjoy many outlet stores here such as Burberry, Ralph Lauren, Bally etc for some great discounts. Be prepared for some long ques at checkout with Chinese tourists buying goods enough to fill multiple suit cases.. this is no joke!3. This is a very popular spot for ex-pats. Considered an environmentally green zone with no car access. Access is by ferry from Central HK Island, or buy bus from Tung Chung. THere is a nice shopping mall and numerous restaurants/bars such as an Irish pub etc.. Commuting is by foot or golf buggy! A must see on your list of things to do in Hong KOng4. Disneyland... yeah your kids will be happy. OTherwise, a tiring experiecne best avoided on hot days.5.Tao - a traditional fishing village, with a history dating back thousands of years. Again, it will give you another impression of HK...

Beautiful. Take the cable car over but if you suffer Vertigo then a stiff drink beforehand should help :) After the Monastery, take the bus to the fishing Village of Tai O for a gorgeous and authentic stilt housed fishing village.
Big buddha. Amazing sight - definitely go by cable car, although don't bother to pay the extra for the glass bottomed car, it really isn't worth it and you will have to queue for longer.

Get fit by walking up 200 odd steps to see the largest buddah. A must see is Lantau Island with its famous Buddah I believe the largest in the world.There are for memory about 206 steps to the top but well worth walking the distance.Apart from the Buddah there are several shrines you can visit . There are several statues surrounding the Buddah and inside is a memorial to the people that have past. You can have a cool drink and taste some tufu at one of the eating places .The workmanship in the carving at the shrines is amazing.
360 Cable Car. Must take the cable car. Advice: Take the tour that you can buy at the station. It is much faster and express lane.

Cable cars, Buddhas, Monasteries and fishing villages. Take the 30 minute train ride from Hong Kong for £1.50 each way and walk across the square to the Ngong Ping 360 cablecar for a pleasant ride. Walk through the Disney style shopping and food outlets to reach the excellent Giant Buddha (a climb of 200 steps) and Po Lin Monastery.Catch the bus to the interesting Tai O fishing village and the bus from there back to Tung Chung. There is a Factory Outlet Mall next to the Train and Bus Station but prices are cheaper in the UK
Zilch.. I don't get it. Lantau Island, big deal. There are millions of other islands out there.

A hidden "treasure" Island. Although it is a bit far from Central (25 mins by MTS) there is a lot to do in Lantau Island. Beautiful hiking tracks, visit to Tai O old fishing village, Giant Buddha by cable car, Mui Wo beach and nice sceneries and more. If you are "brand" addict you can visit Citygate Outlets. Usually all Brand products are 50%-70% cheaper than other shopping malls. Hong Kong International Airport is at your door step so it is very convenient.
nice escape, largest seated buddah. a must do when visiting hong kong. nice beaches, old time fishing village and the seated buddah were all highlights on this island

Best passtime for a layover of more than 6 hours. Hongkong is one of the busiest airports with a large number of airlines using it as a layover hub. Needless to say there are passengers like myself struggling to think of things to do to kill time. Luckily for me the HongKong Immigration is very tourist friendly. They are not comfortable with English though, so don't bother asking, most nationalities have a visa on entry so just walk out of the Airport and hop on to the bus to Lantau Island. I think it is the S1 that takes you to Tung Chung metro station from where you can easily walk to the Ngong Ping cable car terminal. The most famous attraction of Lantau is the Bronze buddha statue at the top of the mountain and the journey to the top is part of the fun. You can drive, take the bus or use the cable car. The latter is the recommended option, see my revies for Ngong ping cable car for detailsOnce on top you can visit the village, pay your respects to lord buddha at the temple. The bronze buddha is in need of maintenance and polishing. The trip from the Airport and back including the visit to the buddha would take approx 6 hours ( time I took ) if you use the cable car and 10 hours if you use bus service. All in all : a very good way to kill some time and experience some local culture, cuisine and do some sightseeingthe trip including the cable car set me back only by ~ HK$ 250 (including 1 meal)you can also shop for souvenirs, Shops are reasonably priced.
Great cable car ride!. We waited for 1.5 hours just to get on the cable car but it was worth it. Nice scenery and the Giant Buddha is awesome.

Hike Up Lantau Peak. I ended up hiking up Lantau Peak when I missed the turn for the "Path of Wisdom" near the bottom of the hill by the Big Buddha. I just kept climbing the steps, and next thing I knew, I was on top with fantastic views. I totally recommend the hike. Whomever is taking care of the stairs is doing a wonderful job.

Cable Car Ride followed by LONG walk back. Took a cable car ride over to the island and then walked back. Enjoyed the walk back but its not for the faint hearted - took probably 3 hours of constant going up and going down and legs were sore for a couple days afterwards.

Excellent dreamworld location. Visited Discovery Bay - it is liker a set from the Truman Show mixed with Stepford Wives. Brilliant facilities, restaurants, bars ferry and buses. I really enjoyed my visit. Not sure it is really Hong Kong - it is certainly different to Kowloon side - it was like a visit to the seaside as a child.

Dont miss the Giant Buddha. A short ferry ride to the island allows you to leave the big city and get the feel of the small village life in HK. Several great attractions their... Tao O fishing village, see it early! The giant Buddha is well worth the short bus ride there. I would recommend that you take the bus everywhere. It is quite convenient and cheap. Catch it where the ferry leaves you off and find the one to Tai O.... you can then catch one from there to the Buddha. Plan to have a dinner at the Buddha at the monastery that is at the base of the statue, well worth the experience. The beaches on the island are great too... an easy one day trip form the bustle of the city!

Lots of Enjoyable Things to Do. We spent a day in the lesser-frequented areas of Lantau Island, and had a great time. Lunch in a waterside restaurant at Mui Wo was very nice, the scenic bus trip up to the Big Buddha was good, and the cable car back to Tung Chung was spectacular. It was a complete day out.
Giant Buddha. Always enjoy going to a Buddhist monastery.This was average pity there was no blessings or actual worship allowed

Go the Lantau and see the big Buddha.. We went to Lantau our last day. Unfortunately the cable car was closed, but we took the bus from the cable car to the village which has the monastery and big Buddha. So glad we went over there. You need almost a full day. We took the subway (orange line) out to the last stop on Lantau. Right there from the subway you can catch the cable car or a bus to the village. Some people like to take the ferry over. If we had more time we might have done that just to get some different scenery. We were very impressed with Lantau

Interesting place to explore. The cable car offered a very good view of some parts of the island, and we could see the trekking trails on the hills. The Big Buddha and Wisdom Path were interesting too! However, be prepared to wait for an hour to get tickets to the cable car, and then u wait again. I'll most likely go back to Lantau again to explore Tai O, which I didn't get to explore this time.

Something for everybody. Lantau Island is quite big and there is something everybody can choose from. The highlight for most people is the Big Buddha but for me personally it was a boat trip in Tai O village which is easily reachable by bus from Ngong Ping. The trip was organized for dolphin watching but although we didn't see any, it was fascinating - before going on the open see, the boat takes you on a ride through the village and you have a change to see the houses on pilots from a different perspective than at any other time. But aparts from the "touristy" stuff, there are also various possibilities for shopping in the area near the MTR station.

Hike to the big buddah... much better way to see Lantau island!. Only for the physically fit, about 15km of hiking over two of Hong Kongs tallest peaks, Sunrise at around 860m and Lantau at around 950. Around 1200-1500m physical ascent and a little bit less descent. I did this trip in four hours (but I am rather fit and by myself), but should be a good days hiking for most people. The views are little short of spectacular though check the weather first for a clear day (you will see more) and for the wind (it can get pretty windy up there as they are steep ridges). Easy to get there and back - take the ferry to Mui Wo from Central pier (about 30 mins) where you can stock up on food/water/supplies from the supermarket. From Mui Wo walk up South Lantau road for about 3km until you get to Nam Shan (a little campsite area with toilet etc). Then take the Lantau trail and stay on it for the next 12-15km over Sunset and Lantau peak, then down to the big buddah. From the big buddah you can take the bus back to Mui Wo. Absolutely awesome!

For the Big Buddha. Went to see Big Buddha, took MTR to Tung Chung then switch to cable car. Nice way to see the view from top although can be quite a scary experience if u are afraid of heights or clautrophobic. It rained when we went, the trip back was scary coz the mountains were covered by forge and we couldn't see a thing with the cable car swinging in gusty winds!

Big Buddha: take bus up and cable down!. The scenery is fabulous and the Big Buddha very impressive, though the whole experience is very kitsch; in the tourist-themed Chinese village we had to endure awful jazzed up Christmas carol music all the time.But! I have advice: There are two ways to avoid the queues. I would recommend you just get the bus up to the village and the cable car down. Problem is, nobody tells you about the bus. I think it is no 23 and it goes from the MTR station on Lantau and is very cheap (about $17). I discovered it by accident because we had to come back by bus after the cable car broke down! I suspect if you took the bus up to the village in the morning, you'd have very little queuing for the cable car ride back.Alternatively, most of the queuing is to buy the ticket - if you have bought a ticket online in advance, you can bypass much of it, though you still have to queue to get on the cable car. We queued for around 2 hr; I think it would have been more like 30 min if we'd had an online ticket.I was surprised at the lack of Tourist INformation at Hong Kong MTR or on arrival at Lantau: we'd originally thought we'd like to go back by ferry, but it was difficult to find out how to do that . I noticed there was a bus from the Buddha place to a ferry so that might be another option.

Don't Miss a Visit to Lantau Island!. Prepare to spend at least a half day (4 hr+) getting to and from and visiting Lantau Island. It's an easy trip to the island via MTR. The cable car ride to Ngong Ping offers spectacular views of the island and beyond. Don't miss the impressive Tian Tan Buddha (lots of steps to get to the top), Po Lin Monastery and Wisdom Path. Tip: go during the week and arrive at the cable car queue before 10 am (when it opens) to avoid long lines.
Buddha. Buddha was interesting but very touristy and too commercial in nature. Seems a lot of the cultrual aspects have been lost in search of the almighty dollar

cable ride to the past. begins with an amazing and never ending cable car ride. When you reach you feel like you've gone back to an ancient Chinese village. Good shows on the Buddha. A few good eating places and then the amazing Buddha statue and a monastery.
Big Buddha, tourist trap. We went to Big Buddha and had to stand in line for 3 hours. So either go very early or don't go at all.

Don't bother. Very underwhelmed by the whole experience. Cable car views are indeed impressive but no more than what you would get at any off season ski resort and undermined by the persistent Hong Kong layer of smog that are clearly visible from higher altitudes. Queues to board the cable cars were at least 1 hour and the Buddha statue and village itself are very tacky and totally commercialized. Tried to stay on board at the peak but the attendants threatened us and insisted we get off only to get back in line for another hour to return. If you want to be impressed go to Sichuan to see Dafo, Le Shan.

nie views form the MRt. Take the subway its worth a trip inexpensve and nice views along the way . Outlet mall at end of the MRT . Good selection of designer labels can then take the cable cars to see the Bhudda .

Nice to get away from the crowded places.. Took the ferry to Mui Wo then the bus to see the Budha, then bus down to the MTR on the west of Lantau. Also made a separate trip to Discovery Bay to meet friends. Free ferry ride back with restaraunt receipt from DB.

A must see.. We did a metro ride to the cable car, viewed the Buddha and the Monastery, then a bus to the ferry to view the village and finally a ferry back to HK island. Wonderful day out. Get to the cable car early as it gets very busy and get a single ticket even if they ask you how are you getting back? The Buddha and the Monastery are incredible.

great day trip. loved the trip to lantau. we took the ferry there and the MTR back. views from the ferry would have been great had it not been so hazy out. the buddha is awesome in person. Tai-O is a great town, go early to be there before the tourists arrive. pretty cool to see, a drastic change from hong kong island. personally I loved the ferry ride there, and the ngong ping cable car back so you can see the buddha from the cable car. definitely do NOT need to pay extra for the glass bottom car. the bus rides to the towns are very easy to use and see, just look at the TA links for times and plan accordingly.
Must Go. Great view from the cable car. You must visit Tai-O fishing village, the street food taste great.

get out of the city. Its like having the the lake district (albeit without the lakes) 30-60 minutes from Hong Kong. you can't get much better than that. get your hiking shoes on and hit the hills. favorites for me are the traverse from the saddle between lantau peak and sunset peak to mui wo (i.e. not over the summit) and from the big budha to tai o.
A must see.. Unique island with the Big Buddha sitting high on the mountain. Great cable car ride for around 3 kilometres to get there. Lots of souvenir shops, and lovely gardens.
Hideous queues spoil the experience. one hour to get a ticket and another 40 minutes queuing for the gondola - . Another hour to get back down. Not worth it - find another way to visit.

You have to do this once. Take the MTR to the trams that go to Lantau. Take the tram to Lantau. The ride is almost thirty minutes and have your camera ready. Yo can see everything. On Lantau visit the world's largest bronze Buddah. This is a fabulous way to spend half a day. When yoy return, visit the shpping mall above the MTR (subway) station.

A Ski Lift to see the Giant Buddha,its breathtaking........... Very close to Hong Kong's main airport is one of the most exciting ski lift rides to see the Giant Buddha,getting there is not for the faint of heart as the ride gently ascends to a steep climb high into the mountains and over the top of the ridge to a valley descending steeply then rising again till the Giant Buddha comes to view.The ride on a sunny day is breathtaking and made more so as the floors of each ski lift have a glass bottom so the feeling of floating is heightened and not for the faint of heart.Once you calm down the scenery and excitement of the ride adds to the thrill of doing it.Be cautious a see if there are low clouds and wind as this will make the ride rather uncomfortable as the pagoda lift has a tendancy to sway once it reaches the mountain top and descend to the valley below.I have experienced this once in my lifetime and I would have reservations doing it again.It can be an experience of a lifetime but choose a warm sunny day for the vista you can capture with your camera and just go for it......................

A contrast to the busy city. We took the MTR to Lantau Island and then took the gondola up to see the Big Buddha. From there we took the bus to the fishing village and another bus back to the MTR station. The Big Buddha is very pretty to see but for me, the most interesting part of this journey was the visit to the fishing village where many houses are on stilts. It's hard to believe this sleepy village is so close to the bustle of Hong Kong. It was easy to find our way around by following and reading the signs.

Peace!. Must go for all travellers to Hong kong. The rope way is simply amazing and breath taking, try taking the glass floor one. The monastries at teh island are simply breath taking. The giant Budha is visible from the final final few minutes of the ropeway.Must see for all!

Check the weather before you set off.. The easiest way to the Buddha is from the cable car at Tung Chung. The MTR will have you at the cable car station ~30 minutes from leaving Tsim Sha Tsui – it’s worth getting there early to avoid the queues. The cable car journey is enjoyable, however weather dependent. On arriving at the top station, there’s a very touristy shopping precinct (including Subway and 7-Eleven) – the Buddha is about 10 minutes walk, followed up a ~250-step climb to reach the Buddha itself. Included in the return cable car ticket is the ‘Walking with Buddha’ experience, accessible from the shopping precinct near the top station. It’s a short but informative story on Siddhartha Gautama’s path to enlightenment as Buddha.Tip, the nearby Po Lin Monestary is worth a visit. It also provides a more genuine lunch experience than the main shopping precinct – although noting their all-vegetarian menu may not be to everyone’s taste. Tip, it’s worth noting that on a foggy day you have difficulty seeing the Buddha when you’re standing right below it – although there’s a degree of charm with fog, I’d highly recommend you check the Lantau Island weather before setting off.
Brilliant!. The cable car ride to see the Big Buda is the highlight of our trip!

OMG. Stairs, stairs, stairs. That Budha is too tall!!And cold too, even if its warm or hot in HK... take a pullover.My husband and kids loved the cable car too even though it just scared the willies out of me!!
You have to go to this amazing Island. great view, excellent day out - highly recommended

Spend some time there. Lantau is where the airport is located. There are major housing developments (high rises) but also smaller towns around with some beaches. Taking the cable car to the great Buddha is a worthwhile experience. Pay a bit extra for the glass bottom car - uniques experience. The top terminal lets you out at a mini Buddhist "disneyland" and a hsort walk leads to the temple and the hike up steps to the big Buddha

The weather will determine whether its worth the trip. We went over to Lantau on a day that was rather foggy - though most days of our trip were foggy so this could be typical. We managed to get a small window where the buddha wasn't completely shrouded in clouds, but that didn't last long. It started to clear a bit on the way down but that is the risk you have if you go up when its not clear. The lines are crazy. The crystal car is a bit more expensive, but it might be worth it if you can skip the line. I bought a metro day pass and it had a 10% off coupon in it, i'm not sure if it is valid for the crystal car or not as i forgot to actually use it and i opted for the cheaper car. We didn't take the ferry - we arrived and the ferry had gone and it was 40mins to wait for the next so we took the subway, think is was 22HKG$ out (hence buying the day pass for $55).After you get to the top of the cable car you end up in this tourist trap, walk through it to get to the bottom of the buddha. If you want to eat or see the buddha museum you can buy a dinner ticket for $60, the museum is under the buddha statue rather small, mostly in chinese), the dinner is at the veggie restaurant (follow the signs). Lunch was veggie soup, silken tofu and veggies, firm tofu and veggies, bok choi and deep fried spring rollsThere is also massive mall at the exit of the subway, apparently it is an outlet mall but i checked the prices and if you live in north america there was nothing that I saw worth buying (perhaps super high end stuff is a decent price but i was checked standard shops that would be in malls at home)

Fun - more than just the big Buddha. We took an all-day trip there and weren't disappointed. The giant Buddha is impressive, but so is the beauty of the island. The cable car ride was great. We even had a vegetarian meal which was very tasty and filling.
Ngong Ping Cable Car & Big Buddha worth to visit. Tried the crystal cabin for cable car... seems like you watch a giant brocolli (the tree)..

Wonderful day out and lunch.... Great walk around the island to the sea food restaurant areas (about an hour walking up and down some concrete paths), some cracking views (except the power station one on bit) and some wonderful sea food at Fu Kee Seafood. Cracking little island

Good day trip. This island is home to the world's largest Buddha. Go by MTR and cable car with a return bus ride down the mountain through villages and catch the ferry back to Central on HK Island. Discovery bay golf club can also be accessed by ferry- great course - fantastic views- approx Austalian $270 incl club rental
Buddha!. Our experience to lan tau could have probably been the best except for the long frustrating queue for the cable car. Avoid visiting on public holidays.
make trip if you have time and Money. It is far from Main City.. But it is expensive to reach Gaint Budha and Diseney land.. and travel on Cabe Car..

Ngong Ping 360. Try to get cable car ticket from travel agency for cheaper price before reaching there to avoid long queue at ticket counter. In my opinion only, normal cable car and crystal car has no much different, try to save that for food.
skyrail. if you have a change take the sky rail up the mountain -great views but beware could take long time to get on due crowds-pick your days.
Wonderful. We went out to Lantau Island by the train and enjoyed the outlet shops beofe we went out by bus to the Big Buddha which is something that you must do while in Hong Kong.

Good day trip. We went to see the Big Buddha, Tai O and spend money at Citygate outlets. We were going to do a tour (Big Buddha/Ngong Ping Village, Tai O and the Monastery) but were short on time. We were told the Monastery wasn’t really worth it so we skipped out on that. Big Buddha – We got the Crystal Cabin from Tung Chung to Ngong Ping and then chose to ride the bus down. Why? We were told that the lines for the cable car down were bad so we thought we’d get a bus instead. NOTE: if you get motion sick, be prepared for the bus! A woman was throwing up on the bus towards the end… it was not very pleasant. The Big Buddha itself – getting up there on a hot humid day… not fun. There are a lot of stairs. Actual Big Buddha was cool.Ngong Ping village – very touristy. Not really what I thought it would be. Tai O fishing village – this was nice! There’s people trying to get you on their boats for a tour, you can probably haggle them for a better rate. We skipped out on that. We just walked around by ourselves. Eating food here may be more difficult if you don’t read Chinese. This was probably our favourite on our quick Lantau Island trip.Citygate outlets – right outside the train station. This is a decent outlet. Only need a couple of hours there and you’re done.

Best tour in Hong Kong!. Among all the tours I took in Hong Kong, this offered the best insight into the provincial Hong Kong life (which I never knew existed!) The quaint fishing town offered a view of Hong Kong Island life, populated mostly by senior citizens. The Buddhist temples and the monastery were also very insightful. The vegetarian fare that came with the tour was the best chinese food I've ever had. In fact, I'd be coming back, just for the food!
Visit Big Buddha. More to Lantau Island than the airport... Take the cable car to the top of the mountain and visit the Big Buddha...
must visit the big buda. use the metro to get to the big buda, excellent service and value for money
Nice little Island. Away from the city. Beach is clean. Catch a Ferry here to Hong Kong or the MRT to Disneyland Hong Kong.

Fishing Villages!. The best part about Lantau is NOT that big buddha that hoards of tourists go climbing up, but the quiet little village of Tai O, on the other side, where history seems to stand still. The hundreds of tiny ramshackle houses built on stilts over the water add a unique charm and quaintness that cannot be found anywhere else in modern day Hong Kong.

Eat, Pray, Love. Literally dissimilar to a noisy and busy Hong Kong center, Lantau Island is a sleeping beauty of tranquil nature and religion inspire. A combination of ferry and bus lasting roughly 1.5 hours will bring travelers from Victoria harbor to greenery Ngong Ping highland to enjoy the authentic art of eat - pray - love. Alternatively, the highland can be reached by cable car to view a stunning panorama, especially by the sunset. Like anywhere else in the city of food-lover, appetizing local sweet soup and snack food welcome travelers by few street vendors next to the gateway of Po Lin Monastery. Once entering Po Lin Monastery and visiting Giant Buddha, take some time to discover a small exhibition inside the bronze Buddha statue to acquire interesting info regarding Buddhism progress in Hong Kong and Southern China as well. By there, shop some religion-oriented souvenirs which may be found only at this prominent Monastery albeit the price seems a bit high.Also, the next door Ngong Ping theme park is a must-go to sip some tea, shop ancient clothing and watch outdoor theater. The small park shall offer travelers a different glance of Hong Kong with its nostalgia and romance.

The Big Buddha is worth a visit. Take the ferry from near Star Ferry then the bus to Big Buddha but take the Cable car back to the area near the new airport and leave time for a look around...shopping in the terminal area is brand new and attrcting locals so provides people watching

Big Buddha and Po Lin Monastery. Lantau island is green island with very few people living here (comparing to the rest of HK territory).Take the Cable Car to the Ngong Ping Village. The Cable Car is one of the longest in the world and scenic views of Lantau Island, busy HK Airport and surrounding sea make the trip worthwhile. You may also get off the Cable Car at interchange station and take the hike to village. it is nice however not so easy walk - considering humidity and air temperature. Once you arrive to the village you can not miss Big Buddha - the statue is visible from everywhere.Po Lin Monastery is under reconstruction however, there are still many thing to see and enjoy.plan about 2 hour to stay in the village unless you want to see some of the shows there: Walking with Buddha, Monkey Theater... many small shops with souvenirs will tempt you to spend some money there - I found out that prices are quite competitive to the HK City, hence don't worry, if you like something, you may buy it there as well.It is one of my favourite place in HK and I have been there already 3x in last 2 years...
nice and fresh air. We went to see the big buddha. Nice view, fresh air. Its something not so hongkong cos there are greens everywhere. Cool and fresh!

Must See. To be able to see the Giant BuddhaEasy to get to using the underground systemAccess to the Buddha is via a cable car, which lasts about 25minsIn places it can be very high, but great funGood view of HK airport on the way upWhen you get to the Buddha they will ask you to pay - only pay if you want to go inside and to the museum. To walk to the top it is free, great views from the top
Giant Budha. Dont miss this...do the half day tour....out by bus...then cable car and mini van to fishing village and back by ferry....excellent...best tour we did.

One day picnic. We were told that the travel to Lantau takes a long time - almost 2 hours from HK island and were always deferring the trip there due to the travel time. However, come October (better climate in HK), we decided to visit Lantau. Reaching Lantau is not easy. One has multiple options with combination of MTR ( till tung chung), bus or cable car; or ferry from central and then bus. Be prepared for long queues if you are travelling on weekend. Once you reach Lantau (base of big buddha) you realise that the travel time was worth it. The approach to statue has road side shops for food and nice gates for photos. The climb to big buddha is almost 250 stairs. So be prepared. But once you are on top, the climb is worth it. The view is fabulous. For once you will not find a concrete structure in HK, its all nice and green. Take pictures of buddha, view the gallery and just enjoy the greenery. After coming down, do not miss the monastary. Its a nice old temple of buddha and certainly a visit. Full veg food served here as well. Overall, an excellent day spent. Although bulk of time is spent in travelling, its convenient and worth it. The kids enjoyed the open space and would like to go back again soon.

Cable car. The cable car trip is great fun! Take the #23 bus up and the cable car down. They sell combo ticket for 98HKG. There is a big sign and it's impossible to miss it.That way you skip the long line at the cable car, and you get to see the great view from different angles.

Lantau Island. Very close to Hong Kong, But open and very senic. We took the Ngong Ping Cable car, Po Lin Monastery (big budda), Tai O Village, Tour. Go on a clear day if you can . Arranged thru Hotel and saved the wait at the ticket booth. Worth the price especially if you on a tigh schedule.

Lantau Island, pay slightly more and avoid queues. Lantau Island is well worth a visit for the stunning cable car ride alone. We paid 300 HKD and this included the glass floor cable car and a bus trip with tour guide to the fishing village. Also included a brief tour around the temple and big buddha. There was virtually no long lines for the crystal cabin (gondala), so well worth the little bit extra. A must do when visiting HK.

A great experience. We went on the metro, very very easy to use and where amazed when we arrived to see a hugh shopping centre with Starbucks etc. We then used the cable car to go to see the Buddha, well worth it even though we both hate heights!

Big Buddha, sight never to be forgotten. This mentioned to me as the site of the Big Buddha. But the trip was much more. I made a circle trip. I took the ferry from Pier#6 to Lantau Island. I then took the #2 bus that went up the mountain to the site of the great Buddha. I then took the cable car ride back down the mountain to the subway system, MTR. I took the subway back to Hong Kong Central. The site is fantastic,but has all the elements of a tourist location. Lots of little shops trying to sell you trinkets,etc. I went to the cable car site first and worked my way back to the Buddha. You walk up an incredible set of stairs,like a stairmaster. The Buddha is enormous and very inspiring and sits atop a temple. Next to this, is the monastery. Like all Buddhist monasteries, light joss sticks is important and mystical. I must have spent at least 3 hours walking around and sensing a confectioner to the energies of life. It's a little weird. Coming was a bit jarring

Cable Cars & Buddha. The Cable cars are excellent, you can have a car with a glass floor or a standard steel floor and when you arrive at the top there is a small shopping village offering souvenirs and food outlets. On the other side of the village are the steps leading to the Giant Buddha and the Monastery. The restaurant at the monastery is of course vegetarian and when you purchase the meal it also gives you a ticket to go up to view the Buddha. It is a very interesting day and is easily accessible by MTR,
way to the Buddha. try to go on weekdays - too crowded on weekends, but still good to go - you can hike if you like as well
Great trip. Visiting the Buddha was magical and we really enjoyed participating in the tradition of lighting the incense.
great day trip,. easy to get to, go on a sunny day, great day trip, relaxing and well worth a visit

Lantau Island - Ning Ping Cable Car, Big Budha and Fishing Village. Travelled from Hong Kong Island to Lantau Island using the £5 Tourist Ticket (24hr - cheap as chips). We opted to go on the 360 tour with the crystal cabin please remember to utlise the 10 % discount voucher which you received with your travel ticket.Cabel car ride was fantastic and by us choosing the crystal cabin this has a glass floor which allows you to see more. We dont want to say too much as it will spoil the experience but it is a must!!!Another experience included in the tour was the fishing village. A wonderful opportunity to meet the real locals which keeps the fishing village alive. Remember these locals have gone through real hardship but still have a warm heart and a smile on their faces. There are places to eat there and the food is fantastic but please remember this is a local village and every penny you spend helps them survive and maintain their way of life which is a dying art. The little stalls are run by the older generations who support their families and are trying to continue the tradition ... So spend spend spend :) and help this community to continue with the additional income which, us as tourists, which is their main lifeline.We would recommend if you don't do the 360 tour to actually arrange to visit the fishing village independantly and spend sometime with the real people.The Big Budha is a sight to be hold however the 200 plus steps can prove to be a challange especially in the hot humidity but at least you can get a cool refreshing icecream or drink.

It was just okay..... I've been looking forward to visiting the big Buddha in Lantau Island for a long time.However, I was a little disappointed with the lack of nice food and the extremely long waiting time for the cable car.Although I did enjoy the cable car ride very much, but upon reaching there, the scene is spoiled by many mainlanders selling cheap goods around the area.The only redemption for this trip was being able to pay my respects to the Buddha and the nice tau foo fah (beancurd dessert) at the food of the hill.

Home of the Ngong Ping 360 cable car. Lantau island is a good place for a half day sightseeing in hong kong apart from the ocean park, victoria peak, victoria harbour, ladies market, disney land etc etc.There are 2 ways of reaching the iland 1 by the Ngong Ping 360 cable car & the 2nd one by bus. We choose to travel by the cable car. We started at 8.00 am in the morning and came back by 6.00 pm so it was almost a full day. The cable car ride to the top is just awesome having some excellent views of the city, airport, sorroundings etc etc. The ride is about 20 mins approx (dont remember clearly though). On top there is a buddha statue & A Buddha Temple. There are a couple of eateries on top which also serve indian food and theres also a subway on top so indian/vegan travellers neednt worry about the food. On top after you aling from the cable car you will enter the nong ping village where the statue, temple, shops & the eateries are there. The Place is very neat, clean and maintained very nicely. During winter this place gets very chilly so its important that you carry good wollens with you. I would conclude by recommending everyone of those who love cable cars, Buddhist Monestries to going to this place.

if you do one tour, then do a day tour of Lantau Island and the Giant Buddha. Lantau Island and Giant Buddha Day Trip from Hong Kong Great tour and good tour leaders, The Giant Buddha, tour of the Lantau island, and the vegetarian lunch at the Monastery was exceptional (even some proclaimed total meat eaters had to eat their words). The cable car return journey was great viewing and at times breathtaking.Whilst it was a group tour, you were made feel like the only people on the tour.Would highly recommend this tour to everyone visiting Hong Kong.

An excellent day trip. Since we arrived around mid-day the lane for the cable car was long. So we decided to go to the big Buddha by bus and return by cable car. We spend several hours up there visiting the monastery, having our lunch there then climed up to the Buddha and visited the museum inside. Tip: keep your lunch order ticket and you get into the museum for free!). Nice view from up there. The cable car ride back was spectacular and well worth it. We did not spend too much time in the stores up there except one which had beautiful but expensive cloths.

An excellent day out. As previous reviews state it is well worth paying a little bit extra for the crystal cabin. What I would say is check the weather. I went up on a lovely clear morning but the return was very foggy and it limited views, so I would advise going up in misty/ foggy weather.Use the MTR to access Lantau island. It's air conditioned & an efficient service.

BREATH-TAKING. Absolutely spectacular views as you go up cable car...i will strongly advise taking the crystal cabin which is a bit more expensive...queues coming down on the mountain in the standard cabin line are much longer and you also get to see through the cabin which is lovely. Get there early so you can have lunch at the many restaurants up there...the monastery is also quite interesting.

Beautiful scenery on the way. We took the Metro and then its a 3 min walk to the cable car. Though we were there at 10.30 we had to wait for an hour to board the crystall cabin car. The view from the cable car is fantastic you pass mountains, sea, fields you can see the airport. The trip lasts 20 min each way. We just visited the Big Buddha and the wisdow path. On that day it was too hot with over 90% humidity so we didnt have the courage to continue to the Thai O fishing village, which I suppose was worth a visit. So make sure not to go on a very hot day to enjoy it to the maximum. Glad that on the return way we didnt have to wait more than 5 min for the cable car. Consider to spent 6 hours including the transportation.

Best part of our trip to Hong Kong. we took the MTR from central with our Octopus card to Citygate on Lantau Island and it is only a short walk to the cable car ride to go and see the giant Buddha.It was 11.30am and there were no waiting to purchase our tickets, the cable car ride is simply breathing and takes about 15 minutes to reach the top.We had a clear and very hot day which made the views truly spectacular.We would recommend the Walking with Buddha show, beautiful experience.Lots of shops, cafes and tourist stalls selling all kinds. The Giant Buddha is a very impressive and well worth climbing the 200 or so steps to access some great views over the South China Sea.It was really hot and humid in July so bring comfortable shoes for lots of walking and a hat or brolly for the strong sun.Upon our return to Citygate we done some shopping in the outlet centre(lots of shops) and then got on the E11 double decker public bus for another scenic trip back to central.Loved the whole experience and would highly recommend it for a full day out of the city.Bring your camera!!

Away from the hustle and bustle of the HK city. great place to be, especially when the weather in hong kong is cooler and one can enjoy the walk all the way to the big buddha. sculptures and carvings were amazingly intricate and oh, while you are there, don't forget to try the bean curd jelly near to the big buddha

Heavenly Experience. We waited for a few months for the sky to clear during winter months to see the Buddha. Our lucky day turned out to be Buddha Jayanti (birthday). The cable car route is breathtaking with a few turns between the mountains. As we crossed the 2nd hill, the Buddha appeared as if we were in heaven and he was sitting in the clouds. We walked from the cable car stop and up the hill, the picturesque location left an impression. Must not miss in HK

Its not worth the hassle. I admit that it was foggy and rainey but it took about 45 minutes to get to the cable car from HK and another 25 minutes in the cable car(the only cool part) to get to the top to see bunch of status, pay rediculus amount of money for terrible food and come back. And by all means AVOID the FISHINIG VILLAGE as it is a dirty, smelly place where bunch of poor people live in miserable conditions and tourist go there to take their pictures. Come on!!! The only good thing about this place is the cable car in a sunny day (big if in the summer!) and the big buddha if you can see it(again a big if in the summer). Would not recommend it.

Beautiful Island. Go there by yourself, easy and much cheaper.Example route: Take the MRT to Tung Chung (orange line). Coming out to the "Cable Car". Arrival at the village of Ngong Ping nice visit. Go to the "Big Buddha" (wonderful time).Then you can take the bus to "Tai-o Village". Fishing village. You can make a cheap boat ride.Finally direction "Mui Wo Village" at the pier to catch the ferry to the island of Hong Kong.

Lantau - Tsing Ma and Po-Lin Monastery - well worth the tour!. My wife and I took the day tour (with Splendid Tours) to Lantau. We started with a viewing of the Tsing=Ma bridge - world's longest suspension bridge and a very impressive engineering feat. Great views of the Hong Kong landscape. Then we changed buses for the trip to Lantau Island. Kim the guide was knowledgeable and entertaining, taking us to Hong Kong's longest beach (okay, not long by Australian standards) then on to the Tai-O Fishing village. We were guided through the village market past traditional stilt houses and into a Taoist temple where we were informed about the differences between Taoism and Buddhism and some of the practices there - notably the protector of fishermen. The cable car was down for it's annual safety overhaul, so the bus took us up to the Po-Lin monastery and the giant seated Buddha at the top of the mountain. We viewed the Buddha museum and then the Buddha statue. It is an impressive sculpture, noted as the world's largest outdoor seated bronze Buddha. This was followed by a visit to the Po-Lin (precious lotus) Monastery - a working buddhist monastery. Lunch at the monastery was included in the price and it was a wonderful vegetarian banquet. The location was perfect, nestled among cloud-tipped peaks with waves of distant hills off to the horizon. All up it was a great way to spend a day and such a contrast with the bustle of the shopping districts.

Very enjoyable. Took the ferry over, followed by the island bus. I was happy with that decision as it allowed me to enjoy the scenic ride out there, plus my hotel is in Central so it made it an easier decision. Went and saw the Big Buddha, ate the vegetarian Monestary lunch (did not splurge for the upgraded lunch). The lunch was good, if a bit bland. Rice, potato soup, with a couple sides of sauteed veggies. The Buddha was worth the trip and it's a very pretty, scenic change of pace from the hustle and bustle of the city. I took the air tram back down the mountain, it's a more direct way back and the views shouldn't be missed. Followed by a long and expensive taxi ride back to Central. I'd take this to and from route again as I think it served the purpose of leisure going and expedited coming back perfectly. The only change I would consider is possibly taking public transportation for that last leg if I was spending my own $$. On the way back, we saw hikers out walking the very well maintained trails. If I went back I would add that to my journey, but it would add quite a bit of extra time and walking to an already full half day affair. Would I recommend it to a friend? Absolutely.

Awesome - Must See attraction. Big Buddha at Lantau island is a must see - just for the cable car ride :)Make sure to purchase the ticket for the crystal cable car ride - coz thats when you get to travel in a glass bottom cable car. The view from the cable car is simply awesome. Fully green and very scenic ! The magnificient budhha statue attracts visitors ! There is also Subway and an Indian Restaurant close to the souvenir shops - where we had very tasty veg biriyani and roti / veg curry.

A great trip!. We certainly enjoyed our afternoon out to 'The Big Bhudda' - but here are a few tips that some might find useful (and that we would follow if we were to do the trip again!):1. Book on-line. This approach might get you a discount (depending on which tour or ticket you choose), but more importantly will allow you to avoid the queue to buy tickets (it took us an hour of lining up to get the tickets). Go to [--]2. Book a day ahead - the book on line feature doesn't let you book a same day ticket (we discovered - which is why we ended up having to line up)3. Book the crystal cabin if you have the spare cash - Firstly it's totally cool (and not as scary as I thought it would be) to be able to see through the floor. But secondly, when you are coming down from the Bhudda the line for the crystal cabin are a lot shorter.4. If you don't want to spend quite as much on the cablecar ride, consider buying the 'one way crystal ride, other way regular car ride' option- and then ask if you can have the crystal ride coming down rather than up (see note 3)5. If you book on line - when you get to the cable car terminal - DO NOT join the huge line - follow signs for prebooked tickets and tours (or ask the attendant where to go) - and you get to avoid the first line6. Take an umbrella!So we didn't follow any of our tips. We took the MTR to Tung Chung station, and then followed the signs out of the station to get to the Cable Car Terminal. The train ride was about thirty minutes from Central.We waited in the heat for more than an hour just to get to the ticket booth. And just when we thought we were done with lining up, we then had to line up for another half hour (after purchasing the tickets) to actually get onto the cable car. (See photos of queues).The cable cars carry a maximum of 10 - with most actually carrying between 7 and 10.It was spitting with rain when we arrived at the top. It was still hot though. The 'village' was a little bit 'Disneyfied', and very touristy (there was a Starbucks and a Subway up there for example), but plenty of things to do (and plenty of things to buy!)Walking up the steps to the Buddha was certainly a work out - but worth it for the view!

Stunning!. We chose the standard cable car as the queue was moving faster than the crystal queue even though there were ten times as many people in it. The journey to the top was fairly uneventful as there was a heavy mist. However when we reached the top, the village-like feel of the shops and stalls with relaxing music, smells of incense and atmosphere was great. The monastery was beautiful and the climb up to the Buddha was well well worth it. A great trip for a half day.

Several HK attractions on Lantau Island. Lantau Island isn't an actual attraction itself, it is one of the main islands in Hong Kong which hosts several main attractions as well as our international airport (HKIA). You can make one of several great day trips to Lantau island, here are some, not in particular order of preference. 1.) Disneyland (1 day trip or combine with Ngong Ping 360). Have a day at Disney, can't go wrong if you've kids. Alternatively, go to Disneyland early so you can finish in 3-4 hours, then head to CityGate for lunch and spend the afternoon at the Ngong Ping 360 attraction, seeing the Giant Buddha. 2.) Ngong Ping 360 (1/2 - 3/4 day trip or combine with Tai O fishing village to make 3/4 to full day trip). If you have the energy and stamina you can go for Disney first than Ngong Ping 360 as mentioned above. Alternatively, visit Ngong Ping 360, the Giant Buddha and Po Lin Monastery more casually. If you have time and interest, you can add the Tai O fishing village with is nearby. 3.) Lantau Island Hiking - there are some great trails for hiking in Lantau island, you can even hike all the way to the Giant Buddha. This is a popular activity for hiking enthusiasts in Hong Kong. This can be a good way to avoid the chaos from the city. We recommend at least 1 day in Lantau for visitors to Hong Kong and 2 if you want to have separate visits to Disney and Ngong Ping360

A wonderful day trip out of Hong Kong. We took the MTR, using our Octopus Card, to the base of the cable car. At the cable car station, we purchased a package that included round-trip on the cable, and a tour of the fishing village and the area below the Buddha. We were escorted to the ticket booth and aided in buying our tickets. The cable car ride was lovely, and the sight of the Giant Buddha as we came over the hill was fabuous. We met Peter, our guide, in the village at the top of the cable car. We boarded a bus to the Tai O fishing village, where Peter escorted us through the market place, pointing out the various delicacies. We also visited a Taoist Temple and learned about the rituals used there. We boarded the bus again and were taken to the area below the Giant Buddha. Peter pointed out various points of interest and then left us at the Po Lin Monastery, the end of the tour. We decided to have lunch at the monastery, as others at this site had recommentded it. This was a big mistake. The food was the worst we had on our entire trip. The spring rolls tasted as though they had been fried in oil that was going rancid. The rest of the food was so oily, it was inedible. I would not recommend that anyone eat at the monastery! After lunch, we walked out to the Wisdom Path, definitely worth the walk. We decided that our knees could not handle the stairs to the Buddha, but enjoyed the view from below. Overall, we would recommend doing this day trip. We felt that signing up for the tour was a good idea, and having Peter as a guide added to the overall experience and allowed us to relax and enjoy ourselves without the worry of how we would get from one place to another. We would recommend this tour for those who, like us, are less adventurous.

Visit the Big Buddha .. you wont be disappointed!. We recently visited Hong Kong and did a day tour to Lantau Island. This was a really great tour.We first went and viewed the Tsing Ma Bridge that takes you across to Lantau Island.Its the worlds longest road/rail suspension bridge.On Lantau Island we went to see the Big Buddha, and wow.. is that just the greatest thing to see... sitting way up high on a mountain! We toured the museum inside the Buddha and then went down to the Po Lin Monastery for a vegetarian lunch... fantastic! We then took the Cable car back down the mountain... that was really cool! This tour was a really great way to spend the day!

fantastic ride to the biggest buddha in the world. i decided to try the crystal car ride up to the big buddha, a very good decision,a very scary ride as the floor is transparent and crossing the first stretch of water it seems and is very high,scenery breathtaking.$169 for the return journey ,well worth it.go on line and prebook as it will save queing.dont forget your camera,a hat [sun can be strong]and water

Fantastic cable car view!. The fellow at the ticket counter kindly warned us away from the guided tour; bought only round-trip "crystal cabin" cable car (worth the few extra dollars because most choose regular cabin, so the line moves more quickly) and thoroughly enjoyed the scenic 25-minute trip. Found the village kitschy and not particularly interesting, but VERY much enjoyed strolling around the monastery/temple grounds (felt more like PRC than HK) where we had a satisfying and inexpensive lunch. (NB: the "deluxe" lunch for two is worth the extra few dollars for the nicer seating; the "regular" lunch venue looks a bit like a school cafeteria).We spent about 5.5 hours total, including subway ride from our Kowloon hotel. Frommers recommends taking the ferry to Lantau island and the cable-car back, which we probably would have done if we had gotten an earlier start.

Fabulous Day Trip. Great day trip! Lots to see!!! Very authentic!Great places to eat lunch- so if you are sick of HK food there is subway and japanese, pizza ect.....and we were sick of chinese food by the last day!great gift and souveniers!take LOTS of pictures!

A very peaceful stay at Lantau Island- Gaint Buddha. The journey starts from the 45 minutes cable car which takes you to the awesome ride to the best and most beautiful city of HK..The view of airport is just awesome...and u wont find the better place then Giant Buddha in entire HK

Daytrip into serenity. If you've had enough of the hustle and bustle, the crowds and the skyscrapers of Hong Kong, treat yourself to a day off on Lantau Island. It's easy to get there by MTR (Tung Chung), then the fun starts at the cable car. As I had to cue for an hour I guess it makes sense to buy tickets online in advance, but even though I had to wait so long the breathtaking ride in the glass-bottom gondola over the bay and through the lush green mountains to Ngong Ping 360° was definitely worth it.The artificial Ngong Ping village at the end of the cable car ride was not a highlight in partiular, but the giant Buddha statue and the Po-Lin Monastery were amazing. Really beautiful and impressive! Even though there were many tourists I found some quiet spots to sit down and marvel at the view from the Buddha platform and in the shady courtyards of the monastery. As a vegetarian I appreciated the vegatarian lunch at the monastery very much and I was lucky enough to hear a chanting ceremony after lunch.In the afternoon I took the bus to the fishing village Tai-O, which was also a nice change to hectic Hong Kong, and from there the bus back to the MTR station, which took a bit over 45 minutes. So if you don't want to rush through all the sights, but have some time to enjoy the scenery and serenity, better plan a relaxed daytrip to Lantau Island.

big buddha!. The island is about twice the size of HK island but much less densely populated and much of it is covered by rainforest. We docked at Mui Wo and jumped on a bus to Ngong Ping on the west side of the island, to visit the Po Lin temple and monastery and the giant Tian Tan Buddha statue.The statue really is enormous. We could see it sat on the hill from the bus, miles away. It’s the biggest outdoor seated bronze Buddha statue in the world. We climbed the 260 steps up to it, and back down, wandered around the nearby Po Lin monastery, and had lunch at the monastery’s veggie café before heading back to Hong Kong Island.

Something different. After visiting the chairlift and everything at the top of the mountain, we caught a bus to Mui Wo and walked back to the train station at Tung Chung. It was at times a bit of an adventure to find the right track, and a couple of climbs are steep enough, but all well set out with stairs and railing. We found it a great way to get out of the city for a couple of hours. It is between 8 and 10 kilometres over hills, so you need to be ready for a good walk and make sure you have plenty of water.

Giant Buddha. It's easy to get to the gondola for this trip - MTR gets you there easy peasy. If you can drag yourself away from the factory outlet shopping centre you can go up the chairlift to the world's tallest outdoor seated buddah.spend the extra (minuscule amount) for your own glass bottom gondola. you can wait and request a private one for the privilege. the ride is about 20 mins so this is recommended. the wait is maybe 2 minutes longer.have lunch with the monks - which is really yummy - spend the extra for the upgraded menu.walking up the steps to the Buddha was really fun. lots of steps but what you're climbing to is amazing! a very good view rewards you at the top.enjoy the walk around this serene beauty and later come down the same way you went up; of head off to Tai-O for some time at the pearl village.
