Due to time slipping away we went to disneyland with our afternoon instead. I don't regret this at all (LOVED DL) but still want to visit Tai-O someday.

Take the ferry and than the new Lantao.... Take the ferry and than the new Lantao Bus to discover this beautiful island. The ferry is around 4 Dollars and the bus day pass around 6 Dollars. With the bus you can visit several beaches like Mui Wo or Shek Pik. Don't miss the China Bear Pub at the ferry in Mui Wo.

Nice to see a bit of greenery in Hong Kong. We had a great day on Lantau Island. We went with an organised tour which stopped at a fishing village, the Giant Buddha, the monastery and a trip on the cable car at Ngong Ping. We had lunch at the monastery which was very good. The fishing village was very interesting, the community live in houses built on stilts over the water and then the market was filled with every type of dried and fresh fish you can imagine, as well as some you can't! The buddha was great, the views were fabulous from the top although the stairs aren't for the faint of heart. The cable car was also good, although I wasn't too impressed with all the stopping it did. Having said that our guide said it almost never happened and I don't particularly like heights. No-one else on our car seemed that bothered.It's definitely worth visiting the island, although I think to get around all the sights you would need to go with a tour group. It's good to see another side of Hong Kong.
The Best Thrill and Fun.. The Cable Car travel is heart bursting travel. The Giant Buddha is great and NPONG Village is very beautiful. Once in a life time have to visit these place.

Lantau Island. A trip to Lantau Island is very exciting and little bit advengerous. the trip through cable car for about 5 Kms is very exciting. The visit to the Buddah Statue sitting atop the hill is wonderful sight. The place is very calm and cool breeze and the fresh air is very charming. The view from the hill top is very attractive. The vegeterian foods served in Pa lin Monastery is very good with vareity of chinese vegeterian dishes served which is good for a healthy diet. The atmosphere in the monastery is full of prayer chants and the smell of incense. Also the visit to the local fishing community hamlets and their market will give as insight to the old hongkong fisherman culture. The end of the trip was a visit to Tea Making Shop which makes fantastic tea. I was suprised to see to tea blossiming in to flower when dipped in hot water and the green tea they prepared was of great refreshing taste.

Giant buddha was huge and good. went to giant buddha few days ago....it was good ...far from hongkong main area...we need to take train to reach lantau island and then take bus which takes i think 27$pp for return trip of giant buddha . you can also go via cable car which take 96$ return and they claim tht it has see through floor ... though we did not go via it as the road also is very scenic and bus takes right upto giant buddha... you can also visit the meusem and this is charged ...though we were running short of time so we did not go there but giant budha was huge and the view from there was awesome ...i thing u must visit this as it is far from the main island and those who have spare time can s[end a day there as close by there is a monestery and some other attraction

A nice getaway from the hustle and bustle of HK. Lantau Island is less than 30 minutes from HK by MTR. Arrived there to take the scenic cable car ride to Ngong Ping Monastery. Chose a single way ticket so that I could take a bus ride (bus #2) down the other side of the island and hop onto a 20 minute ferry ride to Central. I found it to be a great way to see the island, the small villages that are along the bus route down from the top of the island. Enjoyed a "deluxe" vegetarian meal (100HKD includes entry to visit the Buddha and a museum) at the monestary as well as some relaxing moments under the trees listening the to birds chirping, a welcomed change from the noise pollution of HK! The big Buddha is pretty impressive, but the museum inside I could have skipped.Renovations are landscaping being done at the base entrance to the monestery so you'll ned to watch your step.

Nice Getaway from Hong Kong City. Lantau is like the antithesis of Hong Kong city. No skyscrapers, mostly just rolling mountains, waterfalls, and jungle draped hillsides. The only sign on most of the island that you are still in Hong Kong is the Ngong Ping 360 cable car taking tourists up to the Giant Buddha, and a walking path you can take to hike up there yourself if you are a masochist and don't mind suffering in the heat and humidity. If you do, you are rewarded with fantastic views on a less-smoggy day (preferably in the morning hours to get better views before it heats up and the smog settles in).Lantau is an easy Metro ride from Hong Kong Island and Kowloon. Takes about 25 minutes from Mongkok, probably 15 from Hong Kong Central. There is also a ferry you can take there, but if you want to visit the Giant Buddha, the metro is the way to go.

Great Serene Island in Hong Kong. We visited Hong Kong for 4 days and spent most of them in Lantau Island. It is a beautiful, clean, friendly place with lots of attractions to go to. We went to Disneyland for one and a half days and it was just awesome. We also visited Ngong Ping and Tian Tan. The place is average but a different scenery. We also booked through Asiatravel a room in Silvermine Beach Hotel, also in Lantau Island. We were very pleased with the service of Asiatravel. Our check in was a breeze. The hotel however is also average, nothing to get so excited about. The staff are friendly though. Tung Chung mtr station is also nearby. From there we were able to visit Kowloon and Hong Kong Island. There is also a ferry terminal in Lantau Isaland, that is in Mui Wo. The fast craft is really fast and steady. The Citygate Mall near Tung Chung mtr is a treasure spot because it has outlet stores of branded items like Nike, Roxy, Adidas, Columbia, Esprit, Giordano etc. We really got big discounts as big as 60% off. The buses in Lantau really do follow the time schedule, very disciplined. One advantage of being in Lantau Island is that it is near the International Airport. One could reach the airport from Tung Chung terminal at about 10 minutes for only 3.50 HKD via S1 Bus. I love Lantau Island, quiet and pleasant.

The Wisdom Path - Take this trail walk to “Wisdom” :). Enough said of the Big Buddha or the cable car on Lantau Island.Followed the clear signage that leads to “The Wisdom Path” which is near the base of the Big Buddha.It’s a very scenic walk which you will pass by a “Teahouse” first and a tea plantation. Continued the walk for about 15mins will bring you deep into the trail to reveal a mountain scenery of peace and tranquility apart from the busy Big Buddha & Po Lin Monastery. In here, you will thought you’re in a Chinese martial arts movies filming scene. The place or path consists of 38 wood columns with calligraphic inscription of the “Heart Sutra” position along the hill.Many might not understand the Chinese words or even understand the “Heart Sutra” but this walking trail or the large open space might be nice for people who enjoyed the nature.Personally walked here in the winter season and it was very cooling and nice weather. I wouldn't recommend if it's in the summer time unless you're dressed lightly.

Mystic but...... it is definite must sightseeing in Hong Kong. It takes only 15-20 min from Kowloon with subway. (Besides, You can get enough information at Star Ferry/ Information Desk. any map, how to reach the other islands..etc) About Lantau, everything was really great...it was very crowded since it was sunday..The only thing that made me dissapointed is : --- Lantau is the most mystic part in HK...but Seeing starbucks made me little bit dissapointed...

Great excursion!. We had a great excursion to Lantau. I do recommend an early start and an entire day there. We took the subway MTR to Tung Chung (I guess it is not a subway when it goes above the ground), and then the cable car to the top. Do take the cable car. It's better than walking and then have more time and energy for everything else. Of course visit the Giant Buddha and the Monastery. I too would skip the 2 museums there about the monkey and the Buddha story. We did the big vegetarian lunch at the monastery. It was good but there may be better options. Take the bus from the top to Tai O. The narrow streets and stilt homes of this small fishing village must be seen. As must the market area. It is quite a site and reminds one of rural China.We did not take any of the numerous tiny dolphin excursion boats. To my eyes, the seaworthiness of these crafts were questionable, but that's jsut me. After this take the bus to Cheung Sha Beach for a swim. Or go directly to Mui Wo, possibly for dinner. From there, take the ferry (every hour) back to Central. Then we took the Star Ferry back to Kowloon and watched the light show. It was a great day. Enjoy!

Spend a day on Lantau. If you are in Hong kong for a few days like other reviews have said a visit to Lantau is a must do! We went to Lantau in March 08.We took the MTR to Tung Chung and then the cable car ride from Tung Chung there and back (this is quite a long ride about 20 minutes one way) the views were really good. We would off like to have walked back to Tung Chung but time was against us.Visit the bronze Buddha statue and the monastery, I would personally miss the shows. There are a few shops to look at and places to eat/drink.From near the bronze statue there are buses which you can catch to different parts of the island,depending on want else you want to see.In summary well worth a visit.

Don't miss the world's tallest outdoor seated bronze Buddha!. For anyone going to Hong Kong, this HAS to be in your to do list. The massive bronze Buddha and the views from the Buddha platform are just absolutely beautiful and what a huge contrast from the views on Victoria Peak! You forget to realise that only a small percentage of the Hong Kong islands are occupied and there are still quite a lot of undeveloped islands.When we went there last year (Sept. 2007) the cable car that takes you from Tung Chung town centre to Ngong Ping was shut down (due to an accident where an empty cable car fell off the cable and crashed but I believe it reopened earlier this year.) It was probably a good thing for me as I am absolutely terrified of heights and would have just died. We took the MTR to Tung Chung station and took the Tung Chung - Ngong Ping bus No. 23 (you can swipe your Octopus card here) Tip: try to come here between Monday to Saturday as these are their "off peak" days and Sundays are their "peak days" where the bus fares are more expensive (one-way $25 compared to $16) and there are a lot more tourists around.The bus ride takes around 1 hour to get there but it's quite scenic and quite relaxing. You will drive past small pockets of villages that dot these hills and a few seaside towns.Our first impression of the seated Buddha atop a mountain was just spectacular! What a sight to behold! It was pictures galore from here on! We climbed the 256 steps to get to the platform (16 sets of 16 stairs - I am not sure what this signifies) and stopped several times as this had been my first exercise in years! It was also a good way of getting a ton of pictures from these steps. When you get to the top, you will be greeted by 8 smaller bronze statues (beautiful as well). Access to the Buddha is free but if you want to go to the exhibition halls below the Buddha it will cost around HK$60 (a vegetarian meal is included as well). There are also a number of little stalls selling Buddha related souvenirs such as necklackes, statues, incense, etc.We spent about half an hour wandering around and taking lots of gorgeous photos of the Buddha and the lush green scenery below. We then headed to the Po Lin Monastery where the main temple houses 3 bronze statues of the Buddha representing his past, present and future lives as well as many Buddhist scriptures. Again, there was a lot of photo opportunities in this wonderful and interesting monastery.After about an hours and a half we caught the bus back to Tung Chung where we discovered the new Citygate mall. It's not a huge mall compared to the malls in the mainland but still quite good value as this is mostly a factory outlet selling well known brands - Nike, Adidas, Shanghai Tang, Ralph Lauren etc. It was the end of the summer shopping festival when we got here and we stumbled upon the entire Ralph Lauren store for 50% off! Not a bad mall at all!Tip: If you're on a limited time in Hong Kong, definitely do the Buddha and Po Lin Monastery in the morning. It should only take you 2 hours return by bus transport and another 1 hour to admire the area then you're done and have the whole day free for another activity!

Walk back from Statue. Like previous reviewers I think the trip to Lantau is unmissable. We took the cable car across to the island from Tung Chung. We visited the statue (don't bother with the museum inside) and the monastery, then took the footpath back down to Tung Chung. I would highly recommend the walk, but don't forget sun screen and water. The path is easy to follow, not too rough or steep but you would need reasonable footwear. It was very quiet, we only passed a few other people, and it gave us a chance to appreciate the wild life and views at a leisurely pace. The only difficulty was once we got back to Tung Chung- we took a wrong turning, but follow the main road round and there are maps on lamp posts to help you. This was one of our favorite days, the busyness of the statue were nicely counterbalanced by the solitude of the relaxing walk down the hillside.

An absolute must.... Lantau island is an absolute must-do. My husband and I went to Hong Kong in October 2006 and decided to go to Lantau on one of the days. Fantastic decision. The Ngong Ping 360 cable car trip to the Buddah was worth going on alone. Wandering around the peaceful Monastery was welcome relief after the buzz of Hong Kong Island. My tip? Make sure you wear comfy shoes - the walk up all of the steps to the Buddah is a bit of a climb, but worth it for the views over the surroundings from the top. And make sure you rember your camera!

Great experience on Lantau island. We have just returned after an exciting 5 day holiday in Hong Kong. One of the highlights of our visit was definitely the trip to Lantau island to see the Big Buddha statue.We started our journey after a delicious dim sum breakfast at Maxim's on the second floor of City Hall. We took the MTR from Hong Kong station to Tung Chung station (the last stop on the Tung Chung line). The fare was about HK$20.10 per person one way using the Octopus card.From Tung Chung, we took bus no 23 from the bus terminus in Tung Chung town and enjoyed a 1 hour journey through the hills and seaside beaches towards the town of Ngong Ping where the sitting Buddha and the Po Lin monastery are located. The first glimpse of the sitting Buddha is truly awe inspiring and to climb the 259 steps up to the statue is really an unforgettable experience. On the way up, you can view the spectacular rural scenery and green verdant hills surrounding the area. In the distance, we could see the cable cars of the yet to be opened Ngong Ping 360 being put through their trial runs.We spent about an hour taking photos and admiring the scenery before making our way down again to catch bus no 23 back to Tung Chung.At Tung Chung, we also took the opportunity to do a bit of shopping at the newly opened Citygate mall. There are various factory outlets of well known brands like Adidas, Nike and Samsonite, selling goods at very good bargains. I got a Samsonite back pack for about HK$180 which I believe is an absolute steal! All in, it was a very enjoyable trip to Lantau island. It was a good opportunity for us to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and just to enjoy a quiet half a day in the countryside, recharging our batteries. I highly recommend a trip to Lantau island for the overall experience.
Lantau Island Hong Kong. I highly recommend a visit to Lantau Island Hong Kong. There are magnificent Buddha Statue and many traditional Chinese building. A good place to relax yourself.

Lantau Island/ Giant Buddha/Po Lin Monastery. We just spent a week in HK and our trip to Lantau was a definite highlight.We started our day with an excellent dim sum brunch at the moderately-priced 3rd floor Maxim restaurant in City Hall (5 Edinburgh Place) with its bustling atmosphere and great view of the HK waterfront. Don't confuse it with the more formal dining room on the second floor.Then we walked over to the Outlying Islands Ferry Pier No. 6 (to the west of the Star Ferry) and took the 50-minute trip to Mui Wo on Lantau Island. From Mui Wo we took Bus 2 on a scenic, winding climb up to Ngong Ping where the Giant Buddha and Po Lin Monastery are located. It's a wonderful, serene atmosphere. After climbing the 259 steps (our daughter counted them) up to the world's tallest, seated, outdoor, bronze Buddha, we took in the monastery and enjoyed a vegetarian snack which is included in price of admission (HK$24).There's an excellent sounding hike down from the Ngong Ping described in the indispensible Hong Kong Tourist Board publication "Hong Kong Walks". But on the day of our visit the weather was sketchy and we opted instead to take bus 21 to the fishing village of Tai O. This turned out to be an inspired choice.Visiting Tai O is like looking in on old rural China -- at least it seemed that way to me. The village houses are rudimentary, built on stilts and made of tin. We walked from the busstop to the iron bridge and crossed to the main part of town, walking past tiny shops, simple restaurants and lots of stilt houses to Hau Wong Temple.Many of the doors were open and we glimpsed the modest homes of the villagers.Tai O is only a couple of hours from Hong Kong but it's a big step back in time. I would have loved to have eaten a meal in one of the restaurants on the main street, but we weren't sure of the bus and ferry schedules and didn't want to miss our connections.We took bus 1 back to Mui Wo and then the ferry back to HK, but you could also choose bus 11 to Tung Chung where the airport MTR can whisk you back to the city.All the transportation info you need is clearly posted in English as well as Chinese. Using the Octopus card to pay our ferry and bus fares saved a lot of hassle as buses don't give change.If you're looking for a day away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, Lantau Island is a perfect choice.
